XXXXX XXXXX, the claimant, is a citizen of Pakistan, and claims refugee protection pursuant to ss.96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant alleged the following:
He fears his political opponent XXXXX who is a member of the XXXXX, his supporters, Sipah-e-Sahaba (SSP), and other Sunni fundamentalists because of his religion, namely Shia, and his political opinion. He is a devout follower of the Shia faith, and his family is very active politically. He belongs to a middle class family residing in XXXXX, Punjab. In 1984 he XXXXX in the XXXXX. In 1993 he formally joined the XXXXX. In 1994 the fundamentalist Sunnis made negative remarks and harassed his family because of his community, social, political, and religious work. In XXXXX 2000, he protested against XXXXX and his family involving the treatment of a Christian servant XXXXX who worked for XXXXX family, who later died from injuries sustained by the family. The police initially refused to register a complaint against the XXXXX family as they were influential members of the SSP, and the family threatened the police. He (the claimant) rallied support for XXXXX family, including protests and speaking to the local media who aired the news of XXXXX death and the atrocities committed by XXXXX. When the government learned about the incident, its officials ordered the senior superintendent to register the case and take actions. The police registered the case, arrested and detained XXXXX for approximately a week. Afterwards, XXXXX spoke against him, and XXXXX supporters, including SSP members, physically assaulted him on several occasions out of revenge and to silence him.
In XXXXX 2002 the claimant's cousin, representing the XXXXX, XXXXX against XXXXX XXXXX nephew in the same XXXXX during the XXXXX. The claimant actively campaigned for his cousin, however, XXXXX nephew won the XXXXX. XXXXX became more powerful and the threats against the claimant continued as well as attacks by SSP members, including an attack on the claimant's home in XXXXX 2002, however, no one was home at the time. He and his family moved to XXXXX in XXXXX 2002 approximately 20 to 22 miles away from the claimant's home. Further, on XXXXX 2002 XXXXX and the SSP traced the claimant's whereabouts and four masked men attacked his car. They hit the windshield with their guns, and as the claimant escaped from the vehicle they hit him on his back and shoulder with their guns. They disappeared after they heard sirens from approaching vehicles. He received medical treatment for his injuries. The police questioned him about the attack, however, they refused to register a complaint against XXXXX and his supporters. The next day he filed a private complaint against XXXXX and his supporters with the Judicial Magistrate, XXXXX. On XXXXX 2003 his wife who had a heart condition suffered a massive heart attack and died.
Afterwards he decided his life would never be safe in Pakistan, his brother hired an agent, and he travelled to Canada on 29 April 2003 using a fraudulent United States of America passport. He filed a claim for protection on 16 May 2003 in Canada.
DETERMINATION
The panel determined that the claimant is not a Convention refugee as he has a viable internal flight alternative outside Punjab in Hyderabad, Sindh Province. There is no serious possibility of the claimant being persecuted or being personally subjected to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, or to a danger of torture in Hyderabad, Sindh Province.
ANALYSIS
The claimant's identity as a citizen of Pakistan has been established by his National Identity Card,1 his children's registries in XXXXX,2 his birth certificate,3 and copies of his Pakistan passport (which remains in Pakistan).4 The panel also accepts the claimant's wife passed away on XXXXX 2003 of a heart attack as noted in the death certificate submitted.5
Having concluded, through the following analysis, that an internal flight alternative (IFA) is available to the claimant, the panel has not made any finding in relation to the well-foundedness of his fear in his city of Gujranwala, Punjab.
The panel then applied the two-pronged test.6
Is there a serious possibility of the claimant being persecuted in the IFA location?
The panel found, after carefully considering all the evidence, that the claimant was targeted by the local politician in his area, XXXXX, his supporters, and SSP members who support XXXXX who the claimant alleged is also a XXXXX of the local SSP. The panel determined on a balance of probabilities that once the claimant left his area of XXXXX, Punjab, neither the local politician nor his SSP supporters would have any interest in pursuing the claimant. It is the claimant's own evidence that he was targeted by XXXXX out of revenge, to silence the claimant, and to prevent him from speaking against him XXXXX within Gujranwala. The claimant alleged the police in his area refused to register complaints against XXXXX as they feared the political clout the XXXXX member had in his area and the police also feared the local SSP. As a result, the panel determined that there is no credible evidence that XXXXX or local SSP members would have any clout or impunity if they targeted the claimant in XXXXX, Sindh Province.
The claimant testified that XXXXX has influential family members including his nephew who won the XXXXX in XXXXX 2002 for his area, and other close relatives, namely the XXXXX and a senior level official XXXXX. The panel noted the claimant did not lead evidence that he had any particular problems with XXXXX relatives. The panel found that there is insufficient credible and trustworthy evidence to establish the claimant would be pursued by XXXXX relatives or, if he became noticed by them outside Punjab, that they would attempt to harm him. The claimant's profile is that of a local XXXXX and XXXXX, who also actively supported his religious community, and spoke out against the injustice involving the murder of a Christian by the hands of XXXXX. The panel noted the claimant's cousin who submitted a statement into evidence7 claimed that XXXXX had a grudge against the claimant and targeted him. However, the panel also noted although this was the same cousin who ran in the elections against XXXXX nephew, he did not allege he had any specific problems as a result, from XXXXX or his nephew, the winner of the XXXXX.
The panel considered the following. The panel accepts the claimant's religion is Shia as corroborated by the president of the XXXXX dated XXXXX 2004,8 the statement from the XXXXX of the XXXXX in XXXXX dated XXXXX 2004,9 and the statement from XXXXX dated XXXXX 2004.10 Further, the panel accepts the claimant was the XXXXX in 1984 and that he formally joined the XXXXX in 1993. The claimant submitted an undated poster with his picture enclosed promoting himself for the XXXXX.11 He also submitted a membership card from the XXXXX dated XXXXX 1998 XXXXX District, XXXXX,12 indicating he was the president of the party at that time. The claimant also submitted a letter from the president of the PML-N XXXXX dated XXXXX 200413 indicating the claimant was elected as XXXXX XXXXX in 1984, he was president of the XXXXX in 1993, and as a result the fundamentalists, local opponents, and SSP made him a target of their criticism. Further, he supported the claimant's allegations regarding the death of the Christian girl, that the claimant registered a criminal case, and that prompted an arrest. In addition, he supported the claimant's allegations that the claimant actively XXXXX against his XXXXX rival in XXXXX 2002, exposing the opposition's criminal acts, and when XXXXX won the XXXXX and his supporters attempted to kidnap and attack the claimant, however, the police appeared and the claimant was saved. He claimed the XXXXX family had influence, is powerful, and backed by the XXXXX and the Pakistan army. Further, the claimant provided a number of other statements of support corroborating the claimant's allegations as stated above, including from XXXXX dated XXXXX 2004,14 the claimant's father dated XXXXX 2004,15 and the claimant's cousin dated XXXXX 2004,16 who ran as a XXXXX, and also claimed that the claimant's wife died of a heart attack due to the threats from XXXXX, and that XXXXX and his nephew XXXXX hold a grudge against the claimant because of his "overseeing" the case of the Christian girl and his speeches during the XXXXX. Further, he stated that in XXXXX 2003 two of the claimant's cousins were murdered by the XXXXX because of the animosity against the claimant's family. The mother of the Christian girl, XXXXX, submitted a statement XXXXX 2004,17 and XXXXX husband submitted a letter dated XXXXX 2004,18 supporting the claimant's allegations. Several newspaper articles were also submitted involving the death of XXXXX, protests that occurred, police raids, arrests that took place, and subsequent legal actions against the persons accused of the incident.19 Further, other newspaper articles were submitted concerning violent assaults or death dated XXXXX 199820 and XXXXX 200321 and the most recent concerning the murder of the claimant's cousins in XXXXX 2003. The panel also noted the death certificates22 entered into evidence for the claimant's cousins and the denouncement of the murders by the Shia community in Wazirabad.23
The claimant stated his family is middle class and that he was self-employed on the XXXXX from XXXXX 1977 until XXXXX 2003 in XXXXX, XXXXX in Punjab Province. The panel noted the XXXXX that was entered into evidence in XXXXX, District Gujranwala, indicating the claimant's father XXXXX XXXXX.24 Within his statements to immigration officials he claimed his brothers and his father run the business, XXXXX of XXXXX and XXXXX.25 Further, within his PIF the claimant claimed that his two sons, two daughters, and two sisters live in Gujranwala, his father, one brother and two sisters live in Wazirabad, and his mother and one sister live in XXXXX, all in the Province of Punjab. Further, he testified at his hearing that his family continue to live in Gujranwala, Punjab Province, however, they have moved from their original home and are in hiding out of fear from XXXXX and his supporters.
The panel considered the other letters the claimant submitted on behalf of his claim. On XXXXX 2003 the claimant's father wrote that even after the claimant's cousins' deaths the claimant's enemies are still roaming freely, threatening the family, and the police have not taken any action against them.26 A letter was also submitted from a lawyer in Gujranwala dated XXXXX 2004 indicating he was not able to find anyone who wanted to come forward to testify against the claimant's enemies, and even the court of Magistrate did not act impartially, appointing a policeman as an inquiry officer who had already refused to take any action against the "culprits".27 A statement registered by the claimant with the court of Judicial Magistrate Wazirabad dated XXXXX 2002 was submitted into evidence.28 Within the statement the claimant alleged he was threatened and physically assaulted by persons yelling, "We will teach you a lesson for delivering speeches, making propaganda and doing politics against us", and they threatened to kill him.29 Further, within the statement the claimant alleged the police refused to register the complaint as the accused were influential persons as such he registered a complaint at the Judicial Court.30 In addition the claimant stated that the accused are terrorists of an influential, "vandalistic" organization XXXXX, who raped and killed a Christian girl, namely XXXXX, in XXXXX 2000.31 A medical report was submitted from XXXXX Hospital dated XXXXX 2002, indicating the claimant attended the clinic on XXXXX 2002 and his injuries amounted to swelling and abrasions, a pain killer was prescribed and bed rest recommended.32 A summons was submitted into evidence for the claimant along with his witnesses to appear at the police station in Wazirabad to provide their statements on XXXXX 2002 as an inquiry had been ordered into the criminal case.33
The claimant alleged within his narrative that his problems originated between himself and XXXXX in 1994 as he was his XXXXX opponent, and a rivalry developed. Further, he testified at his hearing that his problems became more serious in XXXXX 2000 after the death of XXXXX, the Christian servant. Further, he claimed because XXXXX was an active member and leader of the local XXXXX, the XXXXX also began targeting him under the direction of XXXXX. It is his evidence that he was threatened with violence, called a "kafir", intimidated, his home was fired at when no one was home, his wife died of a heart attack, and he was physically assaulted several times. He claimed he moved once in Gujranwala in XXXXX 2002, approximately 20 miles away from his home, and he was located by XXXXX and his supporters, however, he continued to work on the XXXXX until he left Pakistan in April XXXXX.
The panel considered the statement provided by the XXXXX of the XXXXX in Wazirabad dated XXXXX 200434 stating that in XXXXX 2002 the goons of XXXXX attacked the claimant and his cousins, they were injured, and the police refused to provide any assistance. Further, the XXXXX indicates the XXXXX set ablaze the XXXXX, and the claimant's cousin was a witness to the burning and as such he and the family became a target of the XXXXX. In addition, he claimed that on XXXXX the goons of XXXXX murdered the XXXXX of XXXXX and XXXXX, because of the animosity towards the claimant and his family, and as a result the claimant is not safe. The panel also considered the statement submitted from XXXXX dated XXXXX 2004 that indicates the claimant is Shia and his work within his community has caused him to have a personal enmity that he was attacked with an intention of political and religious narrowness and he was forced to leave Pakistan as a result.35 The panel also noted the Mourning Meetings that were submitted into evidence.36
It is the claimant's own evidence that he was targeted in his home region of Gujranwala, Punjab Province, by a local XXXXX supporter and SSP members, because of the influence the XXXXX supporter XXXXX had in his community, and that XXXXX is also the leader of the XXXXX locally. It is also his evidence that the same person was able to influence the local police with intimidation to such an extent that they refused to file the claimant's initial complaints. The claimant was asked if he feared harm outside his local area, or province, in Hyderabad, Sindh Province.
The claimant stated he could not relocate to Sindh Province because XXXXX and the XXXXX would find him as they have power and they would kill him. Further, he testified he would not keep quiet if he moved to Hyderabad, and he would soon come to the attention of Sunni fundamentalists in his area or other political opponents. In addition, he testified Shias are getting killed everywhere in Pakistan and protection for Shias is not forthcoming from the Government of Pakistan.
The panel found the claimant's evidence in this regard as not credible as outlined below. The claimant has no national profile, and after considering the totality of the claimant's evidence, the panel does not accept local political or religious leaders would want to, or have the resources to track the claimant down in Hyderabad, Sindh Province. The panel determined on a balance of probabilities, that the interest in the claimant in Gujranwala was mostly political and personal, it is after all the claimant's own evidence that XXXXX used the religious fanatics to further persecute him through his religion. "My XXXXX opponent XXXXX an active member of the XXXXX, used this toll against me to spread stories about we being kafir. They discouraged people from maintaining any type of relationship with me."37 As a result, the panel found it is only reasonable to assume that once the claimant removed himself from his area and posed no further threat to XXXXX endeavours, he would no longer have any reason or desire to harm the claimant. As a result, the panel found there is no more than a mere possibility the claimant would be persecuted by anyone in Hyderabad, Sindh Province. The panel noted the newspaper article from the weekly Zameer dated XXXXX to XXXXX 200338 that indicated the claimant and his family have been targeted in the past by "local" XXXXX members and the police registered the case against the persons named in the murder of the claimant's cousins, and the police were searching for the accused.
The panel determined the claimant's problems in Gujranwala were mostly political and the following statements to immigration officials reinforced the panel's finding.
The claimant claimed within his statements to immigration officials that he feared the XXXXX,39 however, he omitted mentioning he feared the XXXXX. The claimant explained the omissions by stating when he made those statements he was "neither alive or dead" as he left his children and parents behind in Pakistan. The panel found the claimant's explanation unreasonable as it is reasonable to assume the claimant would have not omitted the XXXXX if he feared them as he alleged in his narrative. The panel noted the claimant never mentioned that he spoke against XXXXX members, or that he is a Shia, in fact when he listed his religion he claimed Islam, and did not specify Shia Muslim.40 The panel noted the claimant claimed within his narrative that he is a devout follower of the Shia faith, and because of this fact fundamentalist Sunnis "always gave him a hard time", and his XXXXX opponent was a XXXXX member and because of this, XXXXX supporters targeted him. The panel found under the circumstances of this claim, the claimant's failure to mention the XXXXX or that he was targeted partly because of his religion seriously undermined the existence of a subjective fear of persecution from the XXXXX when he left Pakistan.
The panel also noted the following statement the claimant provided to immigration officials when he was asked to explain in his own words why he is seeking refugee status and/or why he could not return to his home country.
As XXXXX I had some problems with XXXXX started in 2002. In 2002 XXXXX killed some Christian girl and I had supported her. (The claimant was asked by an immigration official what do you mean supported her?) We had done a demonstration against the XXXXX this was to protest her killing. In XXXXX 2002 during XXXXX one of my cousins was a candidate for the XXXXX For that reason I am afraid of the XXXXX -they are in power now. My life is in danger because I am with an opposition group.41
The claimant was asked to explain the discrepancies noted within his statements to immigration officials to that of his narrative, namely when the Christian girl was killed by the XXXXX member and when his problems began as his narrative indicates the Christian girl was killed in XXXXX 2000 and his most serious problems began then. He explained the discrepancy by stating he was upset at that time and he could not recall dates or events. The panel found the claimant's explanation unsatisfactory as it is reasonable to assume the claimant would recall when his problems began in Pakistan, recently or several years ago. The panel noted the claimant is a well-educated XXXXX -year-old man, who has been steadily employed in Pakistan since 1977 when he graduated from university. The panel also noted the claimant had legal representation when he was interviewed by immigration officials on XXXXX 2003 and the use of an Urdu interpreter, that the claimant acknowledged he understood.42
Further, within the claimant's statements to immigration officials he acknowledged that he "lied" about his identity and whatever his agent may have stated to obtain the documentation, that an agent arranged his travel documents and the travel plan from Lahore, Pakistan to the United Kingdom to Toronto, Canada.43 He claimed he traveled on a false U.S. passport under the name of XXXXX, his own photograph was in the passport, he traveled with the agent, and returned the passport to the agent afterwards.44 Further, the panel noted the claimant denied within his statements to immigration officials that he had previously applied for a visitor visa, or that he had been refused admission into another country.45 However, further in his statements to immigration officials he indicated he had been refused a U.S. visa in XXXXX 2002,46 within his PIF the claimant acknowledged he was refused an United States of America visitor's visa in XXXXX 2002 for an unknown reason,47 and the panel also noted the claimant filed an application at the U.S. Embassy in Islamabad on XXXXX 2002 according to the copy of the claimant's Pakistan passport.48 The panel noted the claimant has established a pattern of misleading immigration officials and this undermined his credibility.
The claimant was asked to explain why he applied for a U.S. visa on XXXXX 2002, and he testified his life was in danger, he had received threats, so he thought of leaving Pakistan. In light of the claimant's evidence that he thought about leaving Pakistan as early as XXXXX 2002, the panel found his explanation for "neither being alive or dead" when he explained the discrepancies noted in his statements to immigration officials as also unreasonable. The panel had time to prepare, plan, and to think about his reasons for leaving Pakistan and this undermined his explanation further.
The panel determined that an internal flight alternative is available to the claimant. The panel considered whether or not the claimant would be persecuted in Hyderabad by other Pakistanis because of his Shia religion or for political reasons.
The panel considered the two witnesses that testified at the claimant's hearing. The first witness stated that he knew the claimant since 1995 from his neighbouring village and like the claimant he was a XXXXX worker. He also testified that he is aware the claimant's religion is Shia and he was active in the Shia community. Further, he testified the claimant was targeted in his region after he protested against XXXXX death in XXXXX 2000 and registered a case against XXXXX when everyone else was too afraid to speak up as XXXXX is part of the influential class in their area. The witness testified he left Pakistan in XXXXX 2000, however, he knows from his conversations from home that XXXXX family is more powerful than before, as XXXXX has powerful relatives, and he corroborated the claimant's allegations concerning XXXXX relative's political positions and that the claimant would not be safe if he returned to Pakistan. The second witness stated he is the claimant's cousin, that they originate from the same village, and he is also a Shia. Further, he testified that the claimant was at the forefront of every religious activity and became popular politically in their village when he won the XXXXX in 1984. He claimed he became an enemy of XXXXX XXXXX after he protested the murder of XXXXX, and was attacked by XXXXX supporters. As stated earlier, the panel accepts the claimant's identity that he was an active member of the XXXXX and he is also a Shia. Further, the panel accepts the claimant protested with many others the death of Asia, and he registered a complaint against XXXXX for justice for the Christian girl. The panel considered the witnesses' testimony that they did not believe the claimant would be safe in Pakistan because of his political opinion and religion. The panel does not accept, however, the claimant would be at risk of serious harm in another region outside Punjab. The panel considered the documentary evidence, and it does not support these allegations. The panel prefers the independent objective evidence over that of the claimant and his witnesses. The panel noted the claimant's witnesses were not neutral in their beliefs, one is a XXXXX member, the other a Shia cousin, and they are both successful refugee claimants.
The claimant has no national profile and, after considering the totality of the claimant's evidence, the panel does not accept XXXXX XXXXX, other XXXXX leaders including XXXXX influential relatives, or religious leaders would want to track the claimant down in Hyderabad, Sindh Province, or have an interest in harming him today. The panel determined, on a balance of probabilities that the interest in the claimant in Gujranwala was XXXXX, and local XXXXX opposition members attempted to quieten the claimant in regards to his political activities in Gujranwala, especially regarding the death of XXXXX and the circumstances that led to her death. As a result, the panel found it is only reasonable to assume that once the claimant removed himself from his area and posed no further threat to XXXXX in Gujranwala, his opponents would no longer have any reason or desire to harm the claimant. The documentary evidence indicates XXXXX activists usually do have the option of moving to another region of the country, unless they are of high prominence.49 The panel noted this is not the profile of the claimant as he was a local XXXXX of the XXXXX. Further the panel noted that there are hundreds of thousands, perhaps millions, of political activists in Pakistan today.
The panel considered whether or not the claimant would be persecuted in Hyderabad by other Pakistanis because of his Shia religion. The panel is well aware of the country conditions in Pakistan today concerning religious minorities and Islamic fundamentalist groups, including religious violence.
The panel acknowledges that certain Shias are persecuted in Pakistan today, however, the documentary evidence also reveals that not all Shias are persecuted in Pakistan. The documentary evidence reveals that 20% of the population of Pakistan is Shia and that Shias are generally protected by the government and are well integrated into Pakistan's society, but there have been outbreaks of violence between the two sects.50 Most Sunni Muslims live peacefully with Shia Muslims.51 Shias are not systematically discriminated against by other elements in Pakistani society.52 They are not an economically disadvantaged group, they are found in all of the professions, in government and in the army.53 Where Shias have been the targets of Sunni violence, the perpetrators are generally members of extremist Sunni organization, such as Sipah-i-Sahaba-i-Pakistan.54 Many of the victims were Shia professionals, doctors and lawyers, who were not politically active or involved with sectarian groups.55 Incidents of sectarian violence between Shia and Sunni Muslims typically occur during Muharram, when Shia Muslims mourn the death of the Prophet Mohammad's nephew.56 Government efforts to stem this included mass arrests of those suspected of participation and a public call for religious leaders to enforce a code of conduct resulting in fewer deaths in the 2001 Muharram period than in 2000 and no deaths in 2002.57 The panel noted the claimant claimed Sunni fundamentalists always gave him a hard time by making negative remarks, however, he did not lead evidence that he was persecuted by religious fanatics until they were influenced by his XXXXX opponent, XXXXX, whom the claimant openly criticized.
In addition the documentary evidence indicates that there were fewer killings between rival political factions and sectarian groups during the year, however, there was increased violence against Christians.58 The government claims it is committed to protecting the rights of religious minorities, General Musharraf himself is reported to be a liberal Muslim, who has little patience with Islamic militants or religious intolerance.59 Wealthy religious minorities and those who belong to religious groups that do not seek converts report fewer instances of discrimination.60
The important issue in this claim is whether adequate61 state protection is available to the claimant respecting his fears of being persecuted, tortured, losing his life or being subjected to cruel and unusual treatment or punishment at the hands of members or supporters of the XXXXX or other Sunni fundamentalists in the future. The panel refers to the presumption of state protection set out in the Supreme Court of Canada decision in Ward62 and finds it also applicable to s.97. States are presumed to be capable of protecting their citizens and it is the claimant's burden to rebut the presumption of state protection with "clear and convincing proof" of the state's inability to protect. The claimant stated the local police originally did not register his complaints because of the influence of XXXXX, however, the panel noted the claimant never attempted to relocate outside of his region of Punjab and seek protection.
The panel finds the claimant's allegation that the state is unwilling or unable to protect Shias from threats, physical mistreatment, death or torture by Sunni extremist groups such as the XXXXX is not supported by the documentary evidence. The panel considered the actions being taken by police and government authorities to curb sectarian violence in Pakistan. According to the documentary evidence, the government has taken steps to curb religious extremism and militancy, with mixed results. During the year (2002), the government undertook a major effort to curb religious extremism.63 Five organizations responsible for sectarian killings were banned by year's end and the government accelerated a crackdown on members of several extremist groups.64
The panel found on a balance of probabilities that although problems exist, killings still occur, and random acts of violence happen, there is no longer impunity for these acts. The panel cites Villafranca.65 The panel also recognizes the present political structure of Pakistan.
No government that makes any claim to democratic values or protection of human rights can guarantee the protection of all of its citizens at all times. Thus, it is not enough for a claimant merely to show that his government has not always been effective at protecting persons in his particular situation. Terrorism in the name of one warped ideology or another is a scourge afflicting many societies today; its victims, however much they may merit our sympathy, do not become Convention refugees simply because their governments have been unable to suppress the evil. Where, however, the state is so weak, and its control over all or part of its territory so tenuous as to make it a government in name only, as this court found in the case of Zalzali v. Canada (Minister of Employment & Immigration), [1991] 3 F.C. 605, 14 Imm.L.R. (2d) 81, 126 N.R. 126 (C.A.), a refugee may justly claim to be unable to avail himself of its protection. Situations of civil war, invasion or the total collapse of internal order will normally be required to support a claim of inability. On the other hand, where a state is in effective control of its territory, has military, police and civil authority in place, and makes serious efforts to protect its citizens from terrorist activities, the mere fact that it is not always successful at doing so will not be enough to justify a claim that the victims of terrorism are unable to avail themselves of such protection.
The panel found the claimant has not rebutted the presumption of state protection with "clear and convincing proof." The documentary evidence referred to above indicates that the government and the police are responding to the acts of sectarian violence perpetrated against Shias and are making serious efforts to find members of Sunni extremist or fundamentalist groups and to bring them to justice. The panel prefers the documentary evidence over that of the claimant because it comes from independent and objective sources with no interest in the outcome of this claim
While the panel accepts that Pakistan is technically not a democratic state since the military coup of October 1999, the panel found that the civilian police have remained, and with the assistance of the military continue to make serious efforts to deal with and prevent sectarian violence between Sunni and Shia Muslim extremist groups. The case law clearly indicates that a guarantee of state protection for all citizens, at all times, is not to be expected and nor is perfect protection. In Milev, the Federal Court of Appeal stated:
The fact that the state does not provide perfect protection is not, in itself, a basis for determining that the state is unwilling or unable to offer reasonable protection in the circumstances.66
With respect to this particular claim, Milev confirms that, while protection against Sunni extremists in Pakistan may not be perfect, it is available and adequate. In summary, while there is sectarian violence in Pakistan, Shias are not a disadvantaged group, and the police do respond to outbreaks of violence by arresting perpetrators from both sides of the violence. The panel prefers the documentary evidence before the panel to the evidence of the claimant because it comes from numerous independent sources with no interest in the outcome of these proceedings. Although there continues to be ongoing sectarian violence in Pakistan impacting on both Sunni and Shia Muslim groups, the panel found that the authorities are making serious efforts to control it and stamp it out. The news articles and documents submitted by counsel reflect the ongoing violence but also that the police are actively pursing the culprits of such criminal acts.67
Based upon the foregoing analysis, the panel found that there is adequate state protection for the claimant in Hyderabad, Sindh Province.
The panel found that there is insufficient credible and trustworthy evidence to establish this claimant would be persecuted in Hyderabad, Sindh Province by Islamic fundamentalists or by anyone else, because of his religion or political opinion.
After considering all the evidence, the panel determined that there is not sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence to establish that the claimant would be at risk of persecution for any reason in the IFA location, Hyderabad, Sindh Province.
Would it be unreasonably harsh in all circumstances for the claimant to move to the IFA location?
The panel considered whether it is reasonable in all circumstances for the claimant to seek refuge in Hyderabad, Sindh Province. The panel noted the claimant has a Bachelor of XXXXX degree from the XXXXX and that he has over XXXXX years of work experience in XXXXX within Pakistan. He speaks Urdu, Punjabi, and English. He appeared healthy and able-bodied. He would be able to travel to the IFA location.
Based on the foregoing analysis, the panel finds that it would not be unduly harsh for the claimant to seek asylum elsewhere in Pakistan, such as in Hyderabad, Sindh Province. The documentary evidence before the panel indicates that most citizens enjoy freedom of movement within the country and the freedom to travel abroad.68 The claimant is not a national political leader or religious leader whom at times are restricted. Further, the evidence reveals that groups with a limited internal flight alternative are women, mixed inter-religious and inter-caste couples, some Ahmadis and Christians,69 and as such the panel noted the claimant does not fit the above documented profile.
While the claimant may find it difficult to live elsewhere in Pakistan, this in itself is not sufficient to eliminate an otherwise viable internal flight alternative. What is required is nothing less than the existence of conditions that would jeopardize the life and safety of the claimant in traveling to a safe area elsewhere in Pakistan and actual and concrete evidence of such conditions.70 The claimant has failed to discharge the onus of establishing that he does not have a viable internal flight alternative elsewhere in Pakistan.
Having considered all of the evidence, the panel finds that there is not a reasonable chance that the claimant would be at risk of persecution at the hands of political opponents or the XXXXX or anyone else if he were to return to Pakistan today.
The panel noted that a person in need of protection must establish that removal to the country of reference would subject them personally to the harm feared.
The panel then considered the elements of S.97(1). For the same reason, that is, the availability of a viable internal flight alternative in Hyderabad, Sindh Province, the panel finds that there are not substantial grounds to believe that he would be subjected personally to a danger of torture, or is at risk of his life or at risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if he were to return to Pakistan. The panel noted the claimant claimed that he had never been arrested nor is he wanted in Pakistan today.
The panel also finds for the reasons already given that there is an accessible internal flight alternative for the claimant in Hyderabad, Sindh Province and for the same reasons as articulated above it is reasonable for the claimant to relocate to the IFA area. As a result, there is no serious possibility that the claimant faces a risk to life or risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment or is in danger of torture if he were to return to Pakistan and relocate to the IFA area.
CONCLUSION
For these reasons, the claim is rejected.

XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX is a citizen of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). She claims refugee protection in Canada under section 961 and subsection 97(1)2 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (the Act).
THE ALLEGATIONS
The claimant stated that her aunt, XXXXX XXXXX, was married to a certain Mr. XXXXX who was suspected of being an accomplice in the assassination of XXXXX. That is why, for their safety, the claimant and her brothers and sisters moved several times to stay with friends or with their grandmother.
The claimant said that she had spent two years in Kinshasa without a fixed address until she had left for Canada on XXXXX, 2003, transiting through Ivory Coast and arriving at Dorval on August 23, 2003.
DECISION
The panel finds that the claimant is not a "Convention refugee" and is not a "person in need of protection" according to the Act for the following reasons.
ANALYSIS
To establish her identity, the claimant filed a birth certificate issued on XXXXX, 2003, and a certificate of loss of identity documents issued on XXXXX, 2003. When confronted as to how she had obtained these documents, the claimant said that it was her aunt who had taken care of obtaining them.
Confronted as to whether the documents were genuine or false, the claimant said that she did not know, adding that her aunt had paid to get them.
The panel expressed some doubts about the two documents. However, since the claimant has two sisters living in Montreal, they could come and testify that the claimant was indeed XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX. The panel said that it was satisfied as to the claimant's identity.
To come to Canada, the claimant said that she had travelled with a false passport, which she had returned to her facilitator. She also said that upon her arrival at the airport in Montreal the immigration officers kept her airplane ticket and her boarding card without giving her copies of them. The panel does not believe this because why wouldn't they have made copies when they had done so for other documents?
The fact that she had returned the false passport to the facilitator deprives the panel of an important and relevant document that would at least have corroborated the claimant's testimony about the route she had taken from the DRC to Canada.
The panel finds that Elazi3 applies to this case:
I take this opportunity to add that it is entirely reasonable for the Refugee Division to attach great importance to a claimant's passport and his air ticket. In my opinion, these documents are essential to establish the claimant's identity and his journey to come to Canada. Unless it can be assumed that a refugee status claimant is actually a refugee, it seems unreasonable to me to ignore the loss of these documents without a valid explanation. In my view, it is to easy for a claimant to simply state that he has lost these documents or the facilitator has taken them. If the Refugee Division insists on these documents being produced, the facilitators may have to change their methods
Minimizing the importance of the passport and air ticket as documents to be produced or ignoring their non-submission for all sorts of reasons in my opinion only serves to encourage all those whose only purpose is to take advantage of a system which is intended solely to enable genuine refugees to come to Canada.
To come to Canada, the claimant testified that she had passed through Ivory Coast where she had spent almost three weeks and through Morocco where she had gone through customs control so that she could wait in the airport waiting room for a second facilitator who accompanied her from Morocco to Canada.
Confronted as to why she had not claimed refugee protection in Ivory Coast or Morocco, the claimant said that her aunt XXXXX had not told her to claim refugee protection in these two countries. This shows that the claimant did not have a subjective fear of persecution in the DRC otherwise she would have claimed protection in the first Convention signatory country where she had set foot.
Regarding a similar conduct, the Honourable Mr. Justice Dubé said in Skretyuk:4
?...? the panel was required to take into consideration the claimants' conduct when they failed to claim refugee status in two countries before arriving in Canada. A claimant travelling through a country that is a signatory to the Convention must claim refugee status as soon as possible, or the claim may not be considered.
The claimant said that her problems had begun on XXXXX 2001, when the military had come to her grandmother's house where the claimant lived to arrest her uncle XXXXX who was suspected of having participated in XXXXX assassination.
The claimant testified that her brother had been arrested on XXXXX, 2003, that is, after the XXXXX, 2003 verdicts in the trial of XXXXX père. Confronted, she repeated several times that the verdicts had been rendered on XXXXX, 2003, whereas, on line 24 in answer to question 41 on her PIF, she indicated the following: [TRANSLATION] "in XXXXX 2003, after the verdict (XXXXX ,2003) in the trial for the assassination of XXXXX XXXXX". Questioned about the inconsistency, the claimant said that the Refugee Protection Officer (RPO) had asked the questions very quickly. However, she was asked these questions several times. The inconsistency between XXXXX and XXXXX 2003 undermines the claimant's credibility.
Furthermore, when confronted about the events concerning XXXXX assassination and the trial of his alleged assassins, the claimant said that she did not know anything about those events. This is rather implausible coming from someone who says she was persecuted because her uncle XXXXX was suspected of participating in XXXXX assassination.
This leads the panel to conclude that the story is wholly invented, especially since the name of Mr. XXXXX does not appear in paragraph 5.83 of the United Kingdom Home Office of April 2003, among those who were arrested in the XXXXX affair. The panel is of the opinion that the claimant has not been living in the DRC since XXXXX 2001, for is it plausible that she would have lived without a fixed address from XXXXX 2001 to XXXXX 2003, allegedly because her aunt XXXXX had never been at home and so she could not live there, and also allegedly because she could not live with her grandmother who had apparently been sick? Nevertheless, apparently, she did go to live there in XXXXX 2003.
The claimant testified that she had gone to live with her grandmother on XXXXX, 2003, while, on lines 24 and 25 in answer to question 41 of her PIF, she indicated that she had gone to her grandmother's house on XXXXX, 2003. Confronted, she said that she did not know the reason for the inconsistency This other inconsistency, where she allegedly lived for three weeks or for six months with her grandmother in 2003, undermines the claimant's credibility.
At the port of entry, the claimant said that her sister and her aunt, XXXXX XXXXX, had been arrested, but she did not mention that her brother had been arrested as well. Confronted on this point, the claimant said that she had been afraid to say so. However, the alleged arrest of her brother was supposed to have been the triggering event that had led to her leaving her country. The omission undermines the claimant's credibility.
Given so many omissions and implausibilities that undermine the claimant's credibility, the panel finds that the claimant is not credible and, in this connection, the Court of Appeal ruled as follows in Sheikh:5
?...? even without disbelieving every word an applicant has uttered, a first-level panel may reasonably find him so lacking in credibility that it concludes there is no credible evidence relevant to his claim [...] In other words, a general finding of a lack of credibility on the part of the applicant may conceivably extend to all relevant evidence emanating from his testimony.
This decision fully applies to the present case.
CONCLUSION
As a result of the preceding analysis, the panel finds that the claimant is not a "Convention refugee" and is not a "person in need of protection" according to section 96 and subsection 97(1) of the Act.
Furthermore, the panel finds that the claimant has failed to present any credible or trustworthy evidence on which it could have made a positive decision. It therefore finds that there is no "credible basis" for this claim, pursuant to subsection 107 (2) of the Act.
The panel rejects this claim for refugee protection.

ORAL REASONS
Mr. XXXXXXX, citizen of Bangladesh, asked for refugee protection pursuant to Sections 961 and 97(1)2 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant is 18 years old. He just turned 18 two months ago. He alleges that his father is a XXXX of a XXXXXX in Dhaka, Bangladesh, and that his family was targeted by criminals. The claimant was kidnapped four times between 2001 and 2003, when he left his country. Each time, his father paid the ransom which was asked by the kidnappers, and the claimant was released. As indicated in his Personal Information Form (PIF), his father was afraid to ask for police protection, because that could have resulted in the claimant being killed by the kidnappers.
After the claimant was kidnapped for the fourth time, in March 2003, his father arranged a Canadian visitor's visa for himself and for the claimant, and they both came to Canada on July 27, 2003. The claimant has family in Canada. His father's sister and her husband live here. The claimant's father left him with the family, and he himself returned to Bangladesh. The claimant asked for Canada's protection at the end of August or at the beginning of September 2003.
Should he go back to Bangladesh, the claimant is afraid to be kidnapped again, and even to be killed by the kidnappers.
ANALYSIS
As I have mentioned before, the claimant is now 18 years old. When he came to Canada, he was still a minor. When all the events described in his PIF took place, he was between 13 and 16 years old. Consequently, he has a limited knowledge about the events which had happened and about actions taken by his family. In addition to that, the claimant has a speech impediment. I must however state that he expressed himself clearly and gave satisfactory answers to my questions, even though he had some difficulty speaking. However, due to his age during the alleged events and to his speech impediment, there were also some limitations to the scope of the questions I could ask.
The claimant's identity was not a problem in this case, since he came to Canada with a valid Bangladeshi passport and with a Canadian visitor's visa. I therefore conclude that his identity has been established.
The claimant produced several corroborating documents concerning problems he had experienced in Bangladesh. However, these documents have to me a probative value only if I believe the claimant's testimony, because basically, they were written by the claimant's parents, by people who are family friends or who are his father's collaborators.
I have asked the claimant to provide details and explanations concerning the alleged events. He answered my questions in a straightforward manner, and basically, there was no contradiction between his written and oral testimonies. There were some minor plausibility issues regarding certain events, but they were not serious enough to damage the credibility of the claimant's testimony in general. There were also some problems with the claimant's testimony concerning the change of address by his family after he was kidnapped for the first time. The claimant testified that his family moved at that time, whereas no such change of address is indicated at question 18 of his PIF. But again, this is not sufficient to reject his testimony as not credible in general.
The documentary evidence is very clear as to the raise of criminality in Bangladesh. It is amply illustrated in the documentary package submitted by the Refugee Protection Officer (RPO), as well as in press clippings provided by the claimant. The kidnapping of children for ransom seems to be a widespread practice among the criminals in Bangladesh. The documentary evidence provided by the claimant indicates that in such cases, police get involved in searching for and sometimes finding the abducted young people, even though not always with success. However, I accepted the claimant's explanations that his father was afraid to report his kidnapping to the police, fearing that the criminals holding the claimant could kill him if they learned that the police had been notified. I find it plausible that the families of the kidnapped children, like the claimant's, can be reluctant to call the police, who are reputed to be corrupted and inefficient.
Consequently, I found the claimant's story plausible. His testimony was credible. He also provided an extremely detailed narrative, as well as corroborating documents. Therefore, even if there might have been some minor problems with the claimant's testimony, I decided to give him the benefit of the doubt.
DECISION
Considering all the above, I conclude that the claimant has established that, should he go back to his country, he would face a risk to his life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. Therefore, I accept that he is a "person in need of protection", as per Section 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
CONCLUSION
The claim is accepted.

XXXXXXXX is a citizen of Haiti. He fears persecution, cruel and unusual treatment or punishment or death at the hands of attachés in Haiti and he asserts that there is no state protection available to him against the harm feared.
The Claimant's Evidence
The claimant came to Canada on a student visa, supported by his father, but his father stopped this support when he learned that the claimant had turned over revenues from a property his father had entrusted to him, to his mother. The claimant's student authorization was valid to XXXXX 2003. A particular situation arose that caused his mother and siblings to flee Haiti in XXXXXX 2002 for the Dominican Republic, and, in early XXXXX 2002, when he made his claim in connection with that same situation, they had not yet returned to Haiti. By the time of the hearing, they had been forced to return. The claimant fears persecution, cruel and unusual treatment or punishment and death at the hands of attachés who have tormented his mother for many years.
The claimant asserts that since about 1987, attachés have harassed, threatened and extorted his mother and asked her to store weapons for them and to join their political party. These people could act as they wished thanks to their links to the régime. They thought her to be well off because of her house and her marriage to an influential businessman. He divorced her but let her stay in the house, and, even after the divorce, when he would look out for her, the attachés would leave her alone; likewise, when another influential person, associated with one of the military régimes that ruled the country, would look out for her, the pressure from the attachés would subside. Apart from such temporary relief from attaché pressure, and when she would occasionally flee to seek sanctuary at a church, the harassment, extortion and threats would continue.
The claimant asserts that he could not return to Haiti for were he to return he would face community pressure to take up arms to defend his mother against the attachés, and this would put his life at risk. The attachés would take a persecutory and dangerous interest in him as well for the simple reason that he was a Haitian returning from abroad, and the attachés were known to target such people.
Decision
The claimant is not a Convention refugee. However, the claimant is a person in need of protection.
Analysis
Identity
The claimant's identity is readily established through his passport and various other personal documents available to the panel.
On Credibility
I have considered the claimant's evidence and find his evidence generally reliable insofar as his mother's experiences are concerned. He testified in a straightforward manner and, under questioning, spontaneously provided details beyond the circumstances he described in his
Personal Information Form (PIF). His information is broadly consistent with that of the documentary evidence, especially insofar as the availability of state protection is concerned.
I am thus satisfied as to the general credibility of his evidence, except as noted below.
I do not accept the claimant's assertion that he would be forced into taking up arms against the attachés by communal pressure for the following reasons: When asked whether his adult brother there had faced such pressure, the claimant said this was not the case. When asked why, then, did he think he would face such pressure, he suggested that this was because he was the eldest and that with both he and his brother there, there would be pressure. In my view the claimant is simply speculating that he would face communal pressure to protect his mother. Beyond this, notwithstanding any communal pressure to do so, it would be fully his choice whether or not to take up arms to defend his mother or, indeed, to defend her in any manner at all. The fact that he is seeking asylum in Canada, from where he can hardly defend her against the daily pressure from attachés, suggests to me that while he may love his mother and care about her well-being, he is not inclined to engage her assailants in a manner that would put his own well-being at risk. His fear of harm in this connection is not well founded.
I do, however, accept the claimant's assertion that the fact of his return to Haiti from Canada would mark him as an attaché target. This assertion is supported in the documentary evidence in Exhibit A3 at Tab 10, page 1, where we read that, "the attachés' favorite targets are rich merchants, businessmen, brand-new vehicles, former soldiers, opposition political militants, and Haitians returned from abroad." On attachés generally, the documentary evidence indicates, in an article in Exhibit A4 that " the term "attaché" is widely used in Haiti to describe armed or unarmed civilians "attached" or working with police or military units." In the same document we learn that contemporary attachés "reportedly derive their power from the support of higher authorities, including...the ruling Lavalas Party...". Most significantly, the document indicates that "police attachés do what they like at the police station," "are more powerful than the policemen," and commit a range of abuses, including arrests, thefts and murder.
Moreover, the documentary evidence before me in Exhibits A2, A3 and A4, as well as Exhibit R4 broadly suggests that state protection against attacks from the attachés is not available. We read in Exhibit A2 at Tab 1 that, "Haitian National Police (HNP) officials at all levels were implicated in corruption, incompetence and narcotics trafficking. The HNP failed to pursue criminals, promoting a growing condition of judicial impunity." In Exhibit A3 at
Tab 10A, a February 2003 article entitled "Democracy Unraveling," provides further details on the impotence of the judicial sector. It is in this context that, according to Exhibit A3 at Tab 10, page 17 the attachés "arrest people, steal people's money, steal vehicles, put people in secret cells and kill them later on. Those people are so powerful that the policemen are not able to do their job as policemen."
Nexus to the Convention Refugee Definition
While the claimant argues that the attachés are a political party, the evidence before me suggests otherwise. The claimant's evidence as well as the documentary evidence suggest that each régime, in effect, has had its own attachés, but their targets have remained essentially constant. The attachés are people whose special connection with the powerful authorities at the time allows them to engage with impunity in criminal conduct for personal gain. They target political opposition militants to demonstrate loyalty to their political patrons, to assure continued patronage. This allows them to target businessmen, merchants and Haitians returning from abroad for these are presumed to have money or to have access to money, and it is this money that the attachés are seeking to gain through theft or extortion. The claimant's mother has been one such target, on account of her being a small-time merchant and, at least in the attachés eyes, a property owner. In any event, the claimant is not a former soldier nor is he a political opposition militant. The attachés' interest in him and people like him is for his wealth or perceived wealth. It is a purely criminal interest.
My analysis above leads me to find that the claimant fears criminality in Haiti, unrelated to any Convention ground. His Convention refugee claim fails for lack of nexus to the Convention refugee definition.
The Section 97(1)(b) Claim
The claimant asserts that he is a person in need of protection because his removal to Haiti would subject him personally to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment at the hands of the attachés.
The documentary evidence canvassed above is silent as to the geographic range of attaché activity in Haiti, but in my view it is reasonable to think that attachés operate throughout the country. The documentary evidence suggests a general collapse or near-collapse of civil society in Haiti and, in large measure, a pervasive absence of the rule of law. As well, inasmuch as the claimant's fear of harm is based on his being a Haitian citizen returned from abroad, the risk he faces is not faced generally by other individuals in or from Haiti.
The documentary evidence canvassed above also leads me to find that there is no state protection available to the claimant in Haiti against actions of the attachés.
The question remains what the likelihood is that the claimant would be subject personally to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
My analysis of the documentary evidence above leads me to conclude that political opposition militants and former soldiers are, among the attachés' favourite targets, the most likely to suffer the imprisonment in secret cells and the summary execution described above. Their elimination furthers the interests of the attachés' patrons, who in return continue to accord their patronage to the attachés. Businessmen, rich merchants and Haitian returnees from abroad are more useful for what can be stolen or extorted from them. Given the culture of violence of the attachés and their capacity to commit criminal acts with impunity, it is reasonable to think that only when such people disappoint their extorters would they face physical harm or death. For this latter group, while it is more likely than not that they would face threats and extortion, there is only a reasonable chance or serious possibility that they would face a risk to their life or a risk of harm such as would be cruel and unusual. The claimant falls into this latter category. Does the claimant merit Canada's protection?
The Standard of Proof on a Section 97(1)(b) Claim
The Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) is silent on the standard of proof to establish a claim for protection under Section 97(1)(b). The Federal Court has issued conflicting judgments on the matter.
In Thangasivam, Kantheepan v. Minister of Citizenship and Immigration (F.C., no. IMM-8986-03), Snider, November 25, 2003 the Court was ruling on a motion to stay the Applicant's removal scheduled for November 27, 2003 pending the outcome of his application for judicial leave and judicial review concerning a PRRA officer's decision. It held that the words "would subject them personally...to a risk to their life...." are not qualified, and therefore, "balance of probabilities" must be the applicable standard. The Court also notes that Section 97 follows the wording of the Charter, Sections 7 and 12, to which a higher evidentiary standard applies.
In Tameh, Ali Farrokhi v. Minister of Citizenship and Immigration (F.C., no. IMM-6266-02), Blanchard, December 15, 2003, 2003 FC 1514 the Court was reviewing a decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD). It held that the Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB) applied the correct standard of proof, that is, "serious possibility" as set out in Adjei, to the question of whether the claimant feared persecution at the hands of the régime or faced a risk to his life.
In Li, Yi Mei v. Minister of Citizenship and Immigration (F.C., no. IMM-5838-02), Gauthier, December 22, 2003, 2003 FC 1514 the Court was reviewing a decision of the RPD where the Court noted that the most serious issue raised was whether the IRB had applied the correct standard to determine whether the Applicant was a person to protect under subsection 97(1) of the IRPA. It held that "pursuant to subsection 97(1) of the Act, there must be persuasive evidence (i.e. balance of probabilities) establishing the facts on which a claimant relies to say that he or she faces a substantial danger of being tortured upon his or her return. Second, the danger or risk must be such that it is more likely than not that he or she would be tortured or subjected to other cruel and other degrading treatments." The Court added that the RPD must continue to give the benefit of the doubt to a claimant. An appeal of this decision has been filed at the Federal Court of Appeal.
In my view, there are ample reasons to prefer the position taken in Tameh with regard to the standard of proof in making a determination under Section 97(1)(b). The challenge of determining the correct standard of proof is an exercise in statutory interpretation. The current approach to statutory interpretation favours an approach that examines the legislative context and the intent of legislators over a simply literal construction of the statutory provision in question. This contextual approach is particularly important where - as is the case with Section.97 (1)(b) - the statute is silent on the point in question.
(A) The purpose of the statute and the particular provisions
The Immigration and Refugee Protection Act sets out a series of objectives. Sections 3 (2) (c) and (d) are relevant to the issues in this case, in that they give general guidance with respect to refugee protection. It is notable that the intent of Parliament in this regard is the same, whether or not a claimant is seeking protection under Sections 96 or 97(1)(b). They read:
(2) The objectives of this Act with respect to refugees are
(c) to grant, as a fundamental expression of Canada's humanitarian ideals, fair consideration to those who come to Canada claiming persecution;
(d) to offer safe haven to persons with a well-founded fear of persecution based on race, religion, nationality, political opinion or membership in a particular social group, as well as those at risk of torture or cruel and unusual treatment or punishment; (emphasis added)
In my view, the reason for this is that the provisions of Sections 96 and 97 express the way in which Canada chooses to safeguard core human rights. These provisions have common roots in the international instruments that articulate core human rights. The provisions of Section 97(1)(b) derive, practically speaking, from principles articulated in the 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights, especially Articles 3 and 5. The 1951 Convention relating to the Status of Refugees (Refugee Convention) - of which the key provisions are incorporated in
Section 96 - evolved in the same context as the Universal Declaration and responded programmatically to address the predicament of a particular subset of the human community suffering a denial of human rights. The Refugee Convention's preamble begins, "Considering that the Charter of the United Nations and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights approved on 10 December 1948 by the General Assembly have affirmed the principle that human beings shall enjoy fundamental rights and freedoms without discrimination..."
In the same manner, reflecting the evolution of international humanitarian law that has taken place in the last half-century, the incorporation into the IRPA of the Section 97(1)(b) provisions responds programmatically to address the predicament of a larger group of people than the Refugee Convention can accommodate, who face a similar and, in some instances, arguably more severe abuse of their fundamental rights in their home countries. Both Sections 96 and 97(1)(b) seek to protect people against prospective serious breaches of their human rights.
(B) Prospective risk assessment and the nature of the evidence supporting a claim
Not only do Sections 96 and 97 engage core human rights; the determination of the risk to those rights is, in both instances, prospective. As well, the evidence in support of a claim under either or both sections has certain basic characteristics that distinguish refugee protection determination from other forms of adjudication in Canada.
In all but a small minority of cases, the claimant's evidence is presented through an interpreter; cultural differences can affect the way what the claimant says is understood by the decision-maker even where the decision-maker has been trained in cross-cultural communication; and where the claimant has been the victim of trauma, and even here, what is trauma in one culture may not be trauma in another, this too may impede testimony going to the heart of the claimant's fear. One might also consider that although the claimant knows she or he is in a protection hearing, and has presumably been told that the hearing is in camera, her or his prior encounters with officialdom may not have been good, and, indeed, it may have been officials in the home country who were the source of her or his suffering, thus there may be a natural reticence to testify openly, and it becomes apparent that the decision-maker is faced with a formidable challenge in making findings of fact.
Apart from the challenges facing a claimant in presenting her or his evidence, objective country evidence is rarely so specific as to allow a direct confirmation of or challenge to something a claimant asserts. It is often if not almost always the case that the same countries where there is significant human rights abuse, and where the state is either the agent of persecution or powerless to stop it, are generally the very same countries that have become skilled at concealing the worst abuses and denying access to neutral observers and investigators. Thus, country evidence may, for example, suggest the plausibility of the claimant's assertions, but except in the most rare of circumstances, it cannot confirm the claimant's assertions. Likewise, it may raise doubt about the reliability of a claimant's assertions, but not exclude the possibility that they are true.
Finally, in recognizing that protection decisions rendered are prospective, we recognize that they are inherently speculative. The decision-maker is assessing the risk of harm a claimant faces in a distant land based on relatively general country information, where even the most recent of the events prompting the claimant's escape or departure will have taken place months or years before.
Parliament did not legislate a standard of proof for making determinations under the Refugee Convention as incorporated in the former Immigration Act. It was while that Act was in force that the matter was considered and resolved by the Courts. In Seifu v. Canada (Immigration Appeal Board) [1983] F.C.J. No. 34, A-277-82 the Court held that the evidence must show that the refugee status applicant has good grounds for fearing persecution. In Adjei v. Canada (Minister of Employment and Immigration), [1989] 2 F.C. 680, [1989] F.C.J. No. 67, A-676-88 the Court, following Seifu, held that "although an applicant has to establish his case on a balance of probabilities, he does not nevertheless have to prove that persecution would be more likely than not." The Court called this standard "good grounds" or "reasonable chance" or "a "reasonable" or even a "serious possibility", as opposed to a mere possibility. In setting the standard as it did, the Court appears to have been acutely sensitive to the realities of the protection determination process described above. It appreciated that for the claimant the stakes are high-her or his life, liberty, or personal security is at issue; that for the decision-maker, the evidence is always shrouded in the mist of uncertainty; and that there is virtually no capacity to save a claimant from the possibly fatal consequences of a wrong decision once that claimant is removed as a consequence of a failed claim.
In my view, it is not appropriate to assess the standard of proof question in connection with Section 97(1)(b) against the background of civil law. In setting the standard of proof as it did in Adjei, the Court recognized the special challenge involved in assessing evidence of events in a foreign country, with a foreign culture, with documentary evidence usually far more generic than claim-specific and most often with the claimant's evidence coming through an interpreter
interpreting from the claimant's language, and on that basis predicting what could happen to the claimant should she or he return there. These features of a protection claim distinguish such proceedings from civil litigation. That this is the relevant context in which to assess the standard of proof question is effectively affirmed by Parliament's choice in designing the structure of IRPA by co-locating Sections 96 and 97(1)(b), and in treating them identically in the articulation of the Objectives and Application of the Act, set out above.
(C) The results of the adjudication process
In this context it is reasonable to think that had Parliament considered the standard of proof established in the jurisprudence in connection with refugee status determination to have not been the correct standard, a different standard of proof would have been legislated along with the refugee definition in Section 96. There would be no need to legislate a standard of proof where the Courts had already articulated one and where what had been articulated was satisfactory. Now, even as the IRPA is silent on the standard of proof in Section 96, it is also silent on the standard of proof in Section 97(1)(b). Given the similarity of the human rights protected, the evidence presented and the objective sought, and how whether the RPD determines that the claimant is a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection or both, there is no hierarchy of status and the same refugee protection is conferred under Section 95(1)(b) and the same protected person status ensues under Section 95(2), it is reasonable to think, in my view, that Parliament is silent on the standard of proof in Section 97(1)(b) because that standard is apparent, and it is the standard in Adjei.
(D) Consideration of the tribunal's process
Multiple standards of proof for the same claim for the same status by the same claimant on the same story leads to more complexity in case preparation for the parties and a more complex and slower tribunal process including hearing and determination. Considerations of process and efficiency should not drive the interpretation of substantive provisions. At the same time, an interpretation that is consistent with the overall scheme of the Act is preferable. The great value of an expert administrative tribunal is that it allows the rendering of simple, quick and fair decisions on specific and limited matters, in this case, protection determination. If a viable interpretation is available which respects the norms of international protection and facilitates an efficient and accessible tribunal process, then, in my view, it is the preferred approach.
(E) Fair results
Statutory interpretation is faulty when in its application it yields unfair or absurd results. Section 97 already contains various limitations on its applicability. It is reasonable to think that had Parliament intended to limit the applicability of the section further, it would have so legislated. Were we to apply two different standards for the granting of protection under Sections 96 and 97, the result would be that although two people might face the same serious harm, and face the same risk of experiencing that serious harm, one would be protected and the other not because the harm feared by one was on a Convention ground and the harm feared by the other was not. This would surely not be a desirable outcome. The United Kingdom's Immigration Appeal Tribunal, in Kacaj (Secretary of State for the Home Department v. Kacaj, Immigration Appeal Tribunal, Appeal No. CC-23044-2000, July 19, 2001), in addressing the standard of proof issue in connection with Article 3 of the CAT, mentions that applying different standards to asylum and Article 3 claims would be surprising when both conventions are concerned with whether future ill-treatment will amount to a breach of a person's human rights. The use of different standards of proof was thought to lead to confusion and inconsistent decisions. The point is well taken in the present context. It is not simply a matter of decision-makers being confused and potentially issuing inconsistent decisions. Decision-makers may be quite comfortable applying different standards of proof as required by legislation or the Courts. But the reputation of the justice system is at stake where two people from the same country, fearing the same harm, and equally having no state protection, get different decisions on protection, just because the harm feared by one is on account of his political opinion and the harm feared by the other is on account of having helped convict a prominent mobster.
Determination
For these reasons I adopt the standard of proof set in Tameh and find that the claimant
XXXXXXXXXX is a person in need of protection because there is a reasonable chance or a serious possibility that he would face a risk to his life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if he were to return to Haiti. I therefore accept his claim under Section 97(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
