INTRODUCTION
These are the reasons for the determination of the claim for protection made by XXXXXXXXXXXX, a citizen of Panama, who bases his claim for protection upon his Jehovah's Witness religion.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant alleges that as a Jehovah's Witness, he has been insulted, has had rocks thrown at him and during the past four years in particular, he has experienced acts of vandalism against his home. According to the claimant, the police did nothing to provide protection to him.
The claimant indicated that because of harassment, his parents moved to a different part of Panama City, but the claimant and his brother remained in the same house. The claimant indicated his brother was not having problems because he was not a Jehovah's Witness.
The panel received in evidence as well a letter from the claimant's father discussing the increasing violence in Panama and indicating that his children had been the objects of hostility in Panama.
ANALYSIS
The panel notes the documentary evidence in assessing whether there is an objective basis to this claim for protection. The panel notes in particular Exhibit R-2, which is a Response to Information Request dated March 11, 2003. This document provides information from an official at the Latin America Administration Section of the Jehovah's Witnesses World Headquarters in New York during a March 10, 2003 telephone interview. This official stated that Jehovah's Witnesses are a legal organization operating freely in Panama. They have a branch office and missionaries working in Panama, where they have been operating freely for several decades. This official at Jehovah's Witnesses World Headquarters reported that his office has no knowledge of attacks, harassment, violence or other forms of mistreatment or abuse suffered by Jehovah's Witnesses in Panama over the last decade. He said however there may be isolated cases of prejudice and mistreatment by some groups or individuals, although no nationwide pattern or discernable situation of concern has been noted.
This evidence is supported by other documentary evidence before the panel. For example, in Exhibit R-1 at Tabs 3 and 4, which are the International Religious Freedom Reports for 2001 and 2002, it indicates that the government generally respects religious freedom in practice in Panama. The government at all levels strives to protect this right in full and does not tolerate its abuse, either by governmental or private actors. The documents further indicate that relations among the different faiths are generally harmonious and finally that aggressive Evangelical Protestant criticism of "new" religions such as Jehovah's Witnesses is not widespread.
These documents which set out the objective situation for Jehovah's Witnesses in Panama paint a different picture from the claimant's allegations. The claimant alleges for example that in January 2001, someone said he would like to shoot the claimant, and in July 2001, a group in front of his house was shouting, "You will never know when something will happen to you". The claimant alleges that he took these two incidents as death threats.
In light of the documentary evidence which does not provide support that Jehovah's Witnesses are mistreated in such a fashion in Panama, the claimant was questioned further. The panel noted that the alleged death threats occurred in January and July of 2001 and the claimant did not change his residence until November of 2001. He alleges that the last two months he was in Panama, XXXX and XXXX 2001, he was in hiding at his parents' place where they had been living since approximately the mid-1990s without serious problems.
The claimant was asked why he remained living at the same address where he allegedly received these two death threats until November 2001. The claimant responded that they could not move, that this was their house. He said even if he was living four hours away, the gangs are controlled by the mafia and they will find him anywhere in Panama. He says they will go after him because he is a Jehovah's Witness.
The panel asked if his parents, who are also practising Jehovah's Witnesses in Panama, had been suffering problems in their new place of residence where they moved in the mid-1990s. The claimant indicated that nothing serious has happened to them so far other than some vandalism.
In the panel's view, the claimant's testimony was not plausible, nor credible. Surely if the claimant truly believed that he had been the subject of two genuine death threats, it is not plausible that he would remain living at the same address for so long. It is not plausible that if the claimant truly received two genuine death threats, one in January and one in July 2001, that he would not move to his parents' place, which has been a place of safety for them, until November 2001. The claimant's actions in remaining at the same address are indicative to the panel of a lack of subjective fear of persecution.
This conclusion by the panel is supported by the above noted objective documentary evidence. The panel places more weight upon the independent objective documentary evidence which comes from international sources, including the World Headquarters of the Jehovah's Witnesses in New York, than upon the claimant's testimony which is clearly self-serving and implausible.
CONCLUSION
On the basis of all of the above, the panel concludes that the claimant has not established a well-founded fear of persecution in Panama on the grounds of his Jehovah's Witness religion nor any other Convention grounds. The claimant has further not established a reasonable chance of a risk to life, a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, nor a danger of torture.
On the basis of all of the above, the panel concludes that the claim for protection made by XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX is rejected.

INTRODUCTION
XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, a citizen of Costa Rica, claims refugee protection pursuant to the provisions of Sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
ALLEGATIONS
In September 2000, the claimant worked as a business administrator in the XXXXXXX XXXXXXX Company warehouse. During the course of his employment, he observed the owner of the warehouse, a Mr. XXXXXXXXXXX, and two other unknown men, whom he thought to be Colombians, inspecting approximately 10 bags containing a white substance, which he thought to be cocaine.
Mr. XXXXX and the two men became very angry that he had seen them with the cocaine. They warned him not to say anything or tell anyone including the police about what he had seen. Otherwise, they threatened that they would kill him and his family.
The claimant alleges that he continued to work at the warehouse for approximately another eight months, at which time the warehouse closed. He told no one other than the members of his family what he had seen.
The claimant also received threats or threatening telephone calls at his office and also at his mother's home where he was living. He alleges that a friend of his, XXXXXXXXX, who was a police officer, was present in his house when one of the threatening telephone calls was made. Mr. XXXXX wanted to make a report about the cocaine incident and the threatening phone calls.
The claimant insisted however that his friend not tell anyone because he feared that he (the claimant) and other members of his family would be killed. As a result, there was no police investigations made. Neither did the claimant report this incident to any other agency in Costa Rica that might have been available to assist him to prosecute the persons involved.
Fearing for his life and the safety of his family and on the advice of his mother, the claimant left Costa Rica on XXXXXX, 2001. He arrived in Canada on the same day. His claim for refugee protection was made on January 27, 2003.
ANALYSIS
Identity
The claimant established his personal and citizenship identity through genuine documents (including his passport)1 he provided in support of his claim. I accept that he is a citizen of Costa Rica.
State protection
The determinative issue in this claim is whether state protection would be forthcoming.
The Chairperson has the authority under Section 159(1)(h) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (SC 2001, c.27) to identify decisions of the Board as jurisprudential guidelines to assist Members in carrying out their duties. The Board's policy on the use of jurisprudential guidelines is available on the Board's website.2
Effective May 15, 2003, the Chairperson identified two decisions of the Refugee Protection Division as jurisprudential guidelines.3
Members are to consider and follow these decisions when determining claims in which the availability of state protection in Costa Rica is the determinative issue in claim profiles of risk due to general criminality or sexual orientation.
At the commencement of the hearing, counsel for the claimant, Ghislaine Mac Lellan, requested an adjournment. She wanted to present evidence from a psychologist, a Canadian nurse and a Costa Rican doctor. She advised that the claimant had requested the initiation of an Interpol investigation into the activities of the company which employed the claimant in Costa Rica. She argued that such an investigation would assist in determining whether the claimant was a person in need of protection.
I noted that the Immigration and Refugee Board had advised the claimant and his counsel on September 12, 2003 that the hearing of the claimant's claim for refugee protection would take place in Ottawa on December 18, 2003. Counsel had more than three months to prepare for the hearing and to arrange either for the attendance of the witnesses personally or by way of videoconference or conference call. Alternatively, their evidence could have been submitted in the form of affidavits.
I also advised counsel that the basic issue to be resolved was whether or not there was state protection available to the claimant in Costa Rica. Counsel admitted that she had received a copy of the jurisprudential guide and that she had read the decision of Mr. XXXXXXX (TA2-14980).
In my opinion, the tendering of additional evidence from other witnesses was not crucial or even relevant. I advised counsel and she agreed that the onus was on the claimant to prove that state protection would not be forthcoming if the claimant returned to Costa Rica.
I therefore rejected counsel's request for the adjournment and the hearing proceeded.
The first question I had to determine was whether the decision in TA2-14980 applies in this case.
I determined that the facts and the evidence regarding country conditions in this claim are sufficiently close to those before the panel in TA2-14980.
The same standard RPO disclosure package for Costa Rica in TA2-14980 was also disclosed at the claimant's hearing, including an additional document to update the source of materials for the jurisprudential guide.
The claimant did not file any complaints with the police. He was concerned for the safety of himself and his family given the threats made against him. He also stated that the police forces in Costa Rica are corrupt ("you can buy their services"). The police would not have helped him.
The claimant did not lodge a complaint either with the Ombudsman office or with the Ministry of Security. The claimant was unaware that the Ombudsman or the ministry even existed.
Given the various remedies available to deal with police abuse or misconduct, I do not find the claimant's reasons for his lack of effort to seek state protection to be persuasive. I find that the claimant ought to have made some investigations of the existence of these institutions and their mandates and then pursue the options opened to him by reporting the incident and the death threats to the police. If there was any misconduct on the part of the police, he was free to report to the Ombudsman, the Ministry of Security or the Constitutional Accord.
The availability of state protection for this particular claimant is clearly the determinative issue in this claim. Ignorance of the complaints mechanism is no excuse for the claimant's failure to pursue the avenue available to him in Costa Rica.
The availability of state protection in Costa Rica has been comprehensively analysed in TA2-14980. That reasoning applies to the facts of this claim. As a result, I adopt the reasons given in TA2-14980.
I find that the claimant has not discharged the onus of showing clear and convincing proof of the state's inability or unwillingness to protect him.
DETERMINATION
Given the findings of available state protection for the claimant, XXXXXXX XXXXXXXXX, I find that he is not a Convention refugee and that he is not a person in need of protection pursuant to Section 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
Accordingly, I reject his claim for refugee protection.

XXXXXXXXX and her two sons, XXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXX, are citizens of Morocco. They claimed refugee protection in Canada for reasons of membership in a particular social group, namely families who are victims of domestic violence. The panel has used the Board's guidelines on persecution against women and the guidelines relating to minors.
DETERMINATION
The claimants are Convention refugees pursuant to section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
ANALYSIS
Identity
The claimant and her two sons provided valid identity documents. The panel is satisfied as to their respective identities. Numerous documents and psychological reports support the claim that the mother and her children were victims of abuse and mental torture (see Exhibit D-11.1 to 11.11, volumes 1 and 2).
Facts
The circumstances surrounding the claimant's decision can be outlined as follows:
The claimant and her children were subjected to the volatile and violent moods of Mr. XXXXXX, the claimant's husband and the children's father. The claimant's sister testified that she had seen bruises and marks on her sister's body several times. The claimant's husband tried to kill her. He beat one of the children with a garden hose.
He would not tolerate the slightest refusal or hesitation by his family to be subservient to him. The main details of this "hell," as the claimant called it, are set out in the personal information form (PIF) and the psychological reports. The claimant and one of her children are currently in therapy; the older child refuses to go.
Credibility
The principal claimant testified very candidly and spontaneously. She answered questions directly even though some of the memories were painful. Her behaviour was just as meaningful in getting across the seriousness of the marital problems she endured. The claimant was a credible witness.
At the hearing, the claimant's sister, who lives in Canada, described the events she had witnessed. She also gave an account of the discussions that had led the claimant not to return to Morocco at the end of her visit to Canada, as had been planned. The panel finds the witness to be credible.
Finally, as proof of her credibility, the claimant referred to the steps she had taken as of XXXXX 2003 to obtain a final divorce from her husband. Her first efforts were unsuccessful because of some malicious advice she received. The claimant's fragile, depressive state also helped delay the process. However, prior to the hearing date, the claimant found a lawyer who was more aware of the specific type of problems posed by a divorce in the special circumstances currently faced by the claimant. At the hearing, the claimant spontaneously provided the business card of the lawyer looking after her case. Exhibit D-12 is a letter confirming the steps that are under way. There is no doubt that the claimant, who always referred to Mr. XXXXX as her "former husband" firmly intends to divorce her attacker and to protect the children from their father's extreme fits of rage.
Possibility of exclusion under 1F(b)
The claimant testified that her intention had not been to kidnap her children but simply to protect them. When Mr. XXXXX learned that she and the children had claimed refugee protection in Canada, he complained to the Canadian ambassador in Morocco that his wife had kidnapped his children. An assistant to the ambassador met with Mr. XXXXX to discuss the matter.
The Minister's representative expressed an interest in the case, but, on April 16, 2004, stated that he no longer intended to intervene since there was no information suggesting that the claimant might be excluded under Article 1F(b) of the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees. In his letter, he stated that he had contacted the Canadian embassy in Rabat to check whether the claimant's husband had brought criminal proceedings against her. There are no charges against the claimant. The Minister's representative added that, since the children's father had authorized them to travel with their mother in XXXXX 2003 and the claimant had initiated divorce proceedings in 1996, and, in view of the sensitive issues raised by this case, he did not think there was substantial enough evidence to justify applying the exclusion set out in Article 1F(b). Finally, he saw no need to intervene with respect to issues of credibility, as indicated in the notice announcing his participation sent on September 26, 2003 (see English text in Exhibit M-1).
After carefully reviewing the evidence, the panel agrees with the Minister's representative on these points. The claimant testified that she had never intended to kidnap her children. She gave in to pressure from some members of her family, who, seeing that she was so unhappy and that she was battling with a situation in which her life and her children's physical and mental security might be in danger, convinced her to remain in Canada and claim Canada's protection. Since there is no reason to doubt the credibility of the claimant or her sister, the panel finds that the decision was not premeditated and was the result of thinking guided by the need, first and foremost, to protect the children. The information found in the psychological reports supports this need for protection.
The exclusion clause found in Article 1F(b) does not apply in the instant case.
State protection
The claimant's counsel referred to numerous documents to demonstrate that the state cannot adequately protect the claimant and her children from the agent of persecution. She made eloquent submissions based on detailed research into this type of question. The panel will provide only a broad summary.
According to Nahla Abdo, an expert on spousal abuse problems in Morocco, spousal abuse is a major problem. The committee for the elimination of discrimination and violence against women deplores the lack of seriousness of Moroccan institutions and society in general in ensuring that all discrimination and violence against women and children are eliminated. Moroccan society is patrilineal, and women have no say in making decisions in the family. Spousal abuse is considered a private matter. This fact constitutes a major obstacle to the success of the ratification of the protocol signed by Morocco. As well, abused women do not receive effective, adequate services. They have little leeway to complain about abuse. Victims' shelters are few in number and do not have the means to provide lasting protection. The police side with men and are seen as an additional means of oppression. The vast majority of police officers are male, and they receive no training on these sensitive issues. They are interested only in cases in which a crime has already been committed, which is often too late for women.
Sharia law is particularly strict in dealing with these matters. The Moudawana or personal status law confirms that women are inferior to men. Women have no immunity from their spouses. There are no measures to protect children from a violent father. Although divorce is allowed, restrictions make obtaining it difficult and very rare. It is not unusual for a judge to return a complainant to the attacker's home. Women cannot live alone. If their family does not want to take them back, they are left to their fate. A divorce cannot be granted without the husband's consent.
Some changes to the law are planned so that the country can comply with the protocol it has signed. However, the government has not enacted all the necessary legislation or established mechanisms to reinforce the new legislation.
In the case of the claimant and her children, the panel believes that the legislation is insufficient to protect abused children. See Nahla Abdo's report, Exhibit D-1.10. Moreover, Exhibit D-13 confirms the inequalities noted by other experts in this area. Exhibit A-1.2 (U.S. Department of State, Reports on Human Rights for 2003, page 11) confirms the inequalities that exist within families. There is no law governing domestic violence. Exhibit A-1.6, a report by the WOAT (The World Organization Against Torture) provides a detailed account of matrimonial obligations and their application as described. Finally, Exhibit A-1.8 describes the steps involved in obtaining a divorce. It is not unusual for a divorce to take more than 10 years to be resolved. There are no measures for guaranteeing custody of the children to the mother or for ensuring that the father's contact with his children will occur in a protected, supervised environment to make sure the children remain safe. From this standpoint, the documentary evidence reveals that the state provides only limited protection to women dealing with serious spousal abuse problems in the current legal context.
In the claimant's particular case, given the current legal framework, the particularly violent acts endured in the family context and the fact that Mr. XXXXXX blocked the proceedings associated with the 1996 divorce petition, the panel finds that the evidence as a whole shows that the claimant has discharged her burden of proving that state protection is ineffective in cases such as hers and that of her children.
Internal flight alternative
The claimant stated that her "former husband" has threatened her parents. Her younger sister has been accosted and bothered. To gain a measure of peace, the claimant's parents have had to move to another city. Apparently, Mr. XXXXX is still harassing them. However, the distance has created a zone of relative safety. While this move to another region may be relatively effective for the claimant's parents, the same would not be true for her and her children. It can be inferred from the facts of the case and the attacker's character that a move to another city would not protect the claimants or be enough to keep away the agent of persecution. As mentioned above, there are no laws prohibiting the children's father from taking them back home. The same situation applies to the best interests of the children. Relocation within the country is not a viable option in this case. Moreover, the Moudawana applies throughout the country.
Conclusion
For all these reasons, the panel finds that XXXXXXXXXXXX and her two children, XXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXX, would face a serious possibility of persecution if they had to return to Morocco.
Their claims for refugee protection are accepted under section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, the principal claimant, is a citizen of Venezuela and claims refugee protection pursuant to ss.96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act. XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, the minor claimant, is the son of the principal claimant and also a citizen of Venezuela. He also claims refugee protection pursuant to ss.96 and 97 of the Act basing his claim on the claim of his mother.
The principal claimant is the designated representative of the minor claimant.
ALLEGATIONS
The principal claimant alleged that she came to Canada to seek protection because she was constantly harassed by one XXXXXXXXXXXXX who was her friend in Venezuela and that the said friend threatened her life. She alleged that the threats were the result of her refusing the sexual advances of XXXXXXXXXXX who is a lesbian.
DETERMINATION
I find that the claimant is not a Convention refugee, as she does not have a well-founded fear of persecution for a Convention ground in Venezuela. I also find that the claimant is not a person in need of protection in that her removal to Venezuela would not subject her personally to a risk to her life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, and there are no substantial grounds to believe that her removal to Venezuela will subject her personally to a danger of torture.
I find that the minor claimant is neither a Convention refugee nor a person in need of protection for the same reasons as his mother as his claim depended on the circumstances of his mother.
ANALYSIS
The claimant testified that she befriended XXXXXXXXXXX in 1998 when her family moved to the city of XXXX where her father operated a restaurant. Her newfound friend frequently came to her father's restaurant where she worked so they got close. After a while XXXX told the claimant that she was in love with the claimant. She responded that XXXX must be crazy as she, the claimant, was not a lesbian. XXXXX reacted that she was joking after the claimant's response but after a short while resumed making advances to her. The claimant testified that XXXXX became hostile to her female friends, especially XXXX and XXXX as XXX thought that the claimant was a lesbian and was having a relationship with one of the two friends. The claimant testified that when XXXX threatened to harm XXX and her family she reported the hostility to the police. The claimant provided documentary evidence of the police report1. This document confirms that the XXXX had uttered threats to the claimant. The claimant further testified that her friend XXXX who was also her lawyer advised her that should the threats get more serious, it would be necessary for her to go to Caracas and seek help from the department of defence. I find the claimant's failing to follow the advice of her lawyer and going to seek help from the department of defence or higher police authority to be a failure to seek protection where, on a balance of probabilities, it would have been forthcoming.
The issue to resolve in this case is whether it was objectively unreasonable for the claimant to have sought state protection. While states are presumed to be capable of protecting their nationals, it was open to the claimant, according to the law, to rebut the presumption of protection with "clear and convincing" evidence. I find, on the evidence before me, that the claimant has not rebutted that presumption in this case. The claimant did not follow the advice of her lawyer who told her the steps to take if she felt the threat had reached serious proportions. She did not approach a higher level of authority of the police where she had initially reported threats from the perpetrator.
Based on the above reasons I find that there is no serious possibility that the claimant would be persecuted for a Convention ground if she were removed to Venezuela. I also find that the claimant's removal to Venezuela would not subject her to a risk to her life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment and there are no substantial grounds to believe that her removal to Venezuela will subject her personally to a danger of torture.
For those reasons I reject her claim.
Regarding the circumstances of the minor claimant, I reject his claim for the same reasons as his mother in so far as his claim is based on the outcome of her claim.
The principal claimant raised the issue that she fears for her son's life in Venezuela as he suffers from epilepsy and is currently receiving treatment in Canada and feeling better. She testified that Venezuela does not have emergency response services like the 911 system in Canada that saved her son's life one time when he suffered a seizure while at school. In response to questions about persons in situations similarly situated as her son the claimant stated that the cost of medicine is very high and her son would need to seek treatment in private clinics as his uncle who suffers from the same ailment does. I find that this is not an acceptable reason to seek refugee protection.
According to section 97 (1) (b) (iv) of the Act, protection on the basis of a risk to life or a risk to cruel and unusual treatment or punishment is not available where the risk is caused by the inability of the country of reference to provide adequate health or medical care. I find that protection is not available to the minor claimant in this case as the risk he allegedly faces is caused by the inability of Venezuela to provide such care. The claimant has not provided any evidence before me to indicate that Venezuela is unwilling to provide health or medical care to the minor claimant. I, accordingly, reject his claim on this basis as well.
CONCLUSION
Based on the above reasons I find that XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX are neither Convention refugees nor persons in need of protection and I, therefore, reject their claims.

XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX (the "claimant") is a citizen of Somalia who claims refugee protection pursuant to Sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
PRELIMINARY MATTERS
At the beginning of the hearing, both the claimant's counsel and the Minister's representative made applications for late disclosure of documents in this protection claim pursuant to Rule 44 of the Refugee Protection Division Rules because these documents had not been disclosed to the Board as is required by Rule 29(4) of the Refugee Protection Division Rules. The claimant's counsel's disclosures are meeting intake notes made by a clergyman while interviewing the claimant in detention in Canada on October 29, 2004 and were disclosed by the claimant and his counsel the day of the claimant's refugee protection claim hearing. These notes outline the various problems that confronted the claimant while he was living in XXXXX, Washington as well as his juvenile criminal convictions, imprisonment and parole and the impact that these problems had on him during this time.
The Minister's application for late disclosure of documents is the Minister's Amended Notice to Participate, both in writing and in person, at the claimant's refugee protection claim hearing pursuant to Article 1F(b) of the Convention and related documents concerning the claimant's criminal convictions in the United States in XXXXX 1998, all received by the Board on October 29, 2004. The basis of, or reason for, the Minister's application for late disclosure of these documents arose from the Minister's error in disclosing a Notice of Intent to Participate based on the issues of the claimant's credibility and Article 1E as opposed to Article 1F(b) of the Convention.
I accepted both counsel's application and the Minister's application pursuant to Rule 44 of the Refugee Protection Division Rules. In making these determinations, I considered all of the relevant factors, including those listed in Rule 30 of the Refugee Protection Division Rules, the Commentary to Rule 30, and the Chairperson's Guideline 7, in particular 1.2 Disclosure of Documents and Witness Information respecting counsel's application. With respect to counsel's Rule 44 application, the Minister's representative had no objection to the late disclosure of this document by the claimant and his counsel. In addition, notwithstanding the Minister's earlier error respecting the Minister's Notice of Intent to participate pursuant to Article 1E as opposed to Article 1F(b) of the Convention, the claimant and his counsel had notice of the claimant's convictions in the State of Washington in XXXXX 1998 pursuant to the Minister's Notice of Intent to Participate disclosed on August 19, 2004 pursuant to Article 1E. In addition, the claimant's counsel had no objection to the Minister's application for late disclosure of the Minister's Amended Notice of Intent to Participate respecting Article 1F(b), and made no application to postpone the claimant's refugee protection claim hearing because of the Minister's late disclosure. As well, the claimant's counsel's post-hearing submissions dated November 3, 2004 respecting the application of Article 1F(b) to the claimant's protection claim were accepted by the Board.
ALLEGATIONS
In his Personal Information Form ("PIF") narrative, the claimant makes a number of material allegations respecting his fear of persecution in Somalia. However, given my determination that the claimant is excluded from the Convention refugee definition pursuant to Article 1F(b) of the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees (the "Convention"), I did not find it necessary to consider the claimant's allegations respecting his fear of persecution in Somalia or whether there was sufficient evidence before me to determine that the claimant's fear or persecution in Somalia for a Convention ground is well-founded.
DETERMINATION
I determine that the claimant is not a person in need of protection pursuant to Sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act. My reasons are as follows.
ANALYSIS
Identity
I find that the claimant's identity as a national of Somalia is established by his testimony and the documentary evidence before me, namely a letter issued to the claimant by the United States Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya advising the claimant that the United States Immigration and Nationality Service had determined him to be eligible for resettlement in the United States as a Somali refugee.1
Exclusion - Article 1F(b)
The determinative issue for me in this refugee protection claim was whether the claimant is excluded from refugee protection because there are serious reasons for considering that he committed a "serious non-political crime" pursuant to Article 1F(b) of the Convention. On the evidence before me, I determine that the claimant is not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection because he committed a serious non-political crime while a resident of the United States. My reasons are as follows.
The first issue to be addressed is whether the claimant has been convicted of a serious non-political crime outside of Canada. The Minister submitted into evidence a number of documents that indicate that the claimant was convicted in XXXXX, Washington of rape in the first degree, robbery in the first degree and assault in the fourth degree in the Superior Court of the State of Washington, County of XXXXX, Juvenile Court on XXXXX, 1998.2 In addition, the claimant is a registered sexual offender in XXXXX, Washington until XXXXX 2099.3 The documentary evidence submitted by the Minister also indicates that the claimant is a wanted felon in the United States and a Parole Arrest Warrant was issued against him on XXXXX, 2004 for a failure to attend a scheduled appointment with the Juvenile Rehabilitation Administration of the State of Washington on XXXXX, 2004.4
I considered the evidence of the witness, Mr. XXXXX, a Parole Officer with the State of Washington Juvenile Rehabilitation Administration Region XXXXX in XXXXX, Washington. Mr. XXXXX provided the following testimony at the hearing. The claimant is currently on his parole caseload. The claimant was convicted of rape in the first degree because the rape involved the use of a weapon. He cut the woman victim of the rape with a knife and used a telephone cord to strangle her. He also held the knife to the woman's child's throat and asked the woman to have sex with him. Both the rape and the robbery were in the first degree because of the aggravated nature of the crimes. The claimant was designated a "serious offender" because of being convicted of rape and robbery, both in the first degree.
At the hearing, the claimant provided the following testimony respecting his trial and conviction in the State of Washington on the charges referred to above in XXXXX 1998, and his breaches of his parole conditions following his release from prison. Although he had a trial and was convicted of the charges, his female roommate at the time, one of the victims, lied about the rape, robbery and assault incident and he did not commit these offences. Upon his release from prison in XXXXX 2002, he was required to take a polygraph test because some unknown person had thrown a firearm in his car. For this breach of his parole conditions, he was sent back to prison for thirty days. He did not complete the conditions of his parole in the State of Washington and fled to Canada because he had a lot of problems. He was living with a family that was not his real family and he could not find a job after his release from prison. He could not follow all the parole conditions imposed on him and wanted to start a new life in Canada.
I considered the case law respecting the application of Article 1F(b). The burden of establishing "serious reasons for considering" that Article 1F offences have been committed falls on the Minister.5 There is no requirement to balance the nature of the Article 1F crime with the degree of persecution feared.6 In order for a crime to be characterized as "political", thus falling outside the ambit of Article 1F(b) (serious non-political crimes), both aspects of a two-pronged test must be satisfied:
(a) the existence of a political disturbance related to a struggle to modify or abolish a government or government policy;
(b) a rational nexus between the crime committed and the accomplishment of the political objective sought.7
In this protection claim, neither prong of the test has been met, and the offences committed by the claimant and for which he was convicted in the United States are clearly non-political crimes.
I also considered the case law respecting what constitutes a "serious" non-political crime pursuant to Article 1F(b) of the Convention. A misdemeanor probably lacks the requisite seriousness to be considered under Article 1F(b).8 In Taleb et al,9 the court found that the offence of attempted kidnapping is a "serious" offence within the meaning of Article 1F(b). In Chan,10 the court found that a conviction in the United States for using a communication facility to facilitate trafficking in narcotics was a "serious" offence. In Sharma,11 the Court upheld the finding by the Board's Refugee Determination Division that armed robbery was a "serious" non-political crime. Again, in Chan,12 the Court referred to the following quotation:
With a view to promoting consistent decisions, UNHCR proposed that, in the absence of any political factors, a presumption of serious crime might be considered as raised by evidence of commission of any of the following offences: homicide, rape [emphasis added], child molesting, wounding, arson, drugs trafficking, and armed robbery [emphasis added].
As a Member of the Board, I take judicial notice of and I considered the relevant provisions of the Criminal Code of Canada, namely those provisions of the Code that address the commission of offences of sexual assault and robbery in Canada. The evidence before me indicates that the claimant was convicted of rape in the first degree and robbery in the first degree, aggravated forms of rape and robbery, because both offences involved the use of a weapon. Therefore, I specifically considered Sections 272 (sexual assault) and 344 of the Code respecting sexual assault and robbery with a weapon. Section 272 states in part:
(1) Every person commits and offence who, in committing a sexual assault, carries, uses or threatens to use a weapon or an imitation of a weapon; Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
(a) where a firearm is used in the commission of the offence, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years and to a minimum punishment of four years; and
(b) in any other case, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.
Section 344 states in part:
(1) Every person who commits robbery is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
(a) where a firearm is used in the commission of the offence, to imprisonment for life and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of four years; and
(b) in any other case, to imprisonment for life.
I find that foregoing provisions of the Criminal Code of Canada would form a solid basis for finding that the commission of either one of these offences in Canada constitutes a "serious" non-political crime.
I also considered whether their were any mitigating circumstances or factors respecting the claimant such that Article 1F(b) of the Convention no longer applies to the claimant. I refer to Paragraph 157 of the UNHCR Handbook on Procedures and Criteria for Determining Refugee Status that states:
In evaluating the nature of the crime assumed to have been committed, all of the relevant factors - including and mitigating circumstances - must be taken into account. It is also necessary to have regard to any aggravating circumstances as, for example, the applicant may already have a criminal record. The fact that the applicant convicted of a serious non-political crime has already served his sentence or has been granted a pardon or has benefited from an amnesty is also relevant. In the latter case, there is a presumption that the exclusion clause is no longer applicable, unless it can be shown that, despite the pardon or amnesty, the applicant's criminal character still predominates.
The evidence before me indicates that the Superior Court of the State of Washington convicted the claimant of rape in the first degree and robbery in the first degree as a juvenile and that at the time of these convictions in XXXXX 1998 the claimant was the age of 13 years. In addition, the claimant's testimony that these convictions arose because of the family that he lived with and this family was not his real family. To corroborate this allegation, as referred to above, the claimant submitted into evidence intake notes from a meeting that he had with a clergyman in the presence of a chaplain on October 29, 2004 while in detention in Canada. In these meeting notes, the clergyman states that at the age of approximately 11 years, the claimant was initially sent to live with a family in XXXXX, Washington.13 The writer goes on to state in part:
In 1995 this family immigrated to Vancouver, B.C., Canada and left XXXXX behind in the care of another family. This family lived in an apartment with an extended family. XXXXX slept in the living room. He reports being beaten by the father of the house, accused of theft and crimes, which he said he did not commit. He reports that one such charge was that he attempted an assault with a knife against members of his household. He was accused of stealing a car when it was taken and the keys to the car were missing from the home. He reports that he did not do this, and that the car was later found stripped down with many parts missing. He said he was not involved at all with the theft. He was 12 years old at the time. He reports that he was not believed by the juvenile justice system. At the age of thirteen he was accused again by a member of his care-giving family of rape. At that time he was a given a sentence of the remainder of his youth in detention. He reports being very angry during his incarceration with the family who had agreed to care for him. He believed that they agreed to his care in order to obtain the money from his welfare, but cared little for him. He remembers being like the family scapegoat for blame, and was beaten by them for grievances that he did not commit. He had attempted suicide in detention by cutting his wrists with glass. He did this while in a closed circuit monitored room at the correctional facility. He was cared for by attending health professionals who prescribed heavy medication, which included Ritalin. He was given six medications altogether he recalls.14
Based upon the claimant's testimony and the documentary evidence before me, I accept that the claimant had a troubled life as a juvenile in XXXXX, Washington from age 11 onwards and after his arrival in the United States as a resettled Somali refugee from Kenya, and at the time of his convictions in the State of Washington, he was a juvenile of 13 years of age. However, there is no medical or psychological evidence before me that indicates that the claimant has suffered from or continues to suffer from Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder or that there is any other condition affecting him. In addition, the documentary evidence before me and the evidence of the witness, Mr. XXXXX XXXXX, indicate that there were aggravating circumstances respecting the claimant's conviction of the offences of rape in the first degree and robbery in the first degree. These aggravated circumstances include the claimant's use of a weapon (a knife) in committing these offences, using a knife against and attempted strangulation of the female victim with a telephone cord, as well as holding a knife to the neck of the female victim's child as part of the commission of the rape. This same evidence indicates that the Superior Court of Washington, Juvenile Court designated the claimant as a "serious offender" and for this reason he was sentenced to a longer period of incarceration than the standard range for these two offences.15 The claimant is also a registered sexual offender in XXXXX, Washington until XXXXX XXXXX, 2099. In addition, the evidence before me indicates that the claimant breached his parole conditions on three separate occasions (unauthorized leaves) in the State of Washington before fleeing to Canada to avoid his conditions of parole. For all of the foregoing reasons, I find there are no mitigating circumstances such that exclusion from Article 1F(b) of the Convention does not apply to the claimant. In making this finding, I refer to Jafri where the Federal Court held that because the serious offence of murder had been committed by the claimant 27 years ago and that the applicant was only 18 years of age at this time, these were not sufficient mitigating circumstances to not bar the claimant's refugee protection claim.16
There is no evidence before me that the claimant was convicted in the United States without due process or a fair trial. The claimant breached his parole conditions and chose to flee the United States without completing the conditions of his parole. Therefore, I find the claimant's evidence that he was wrongfully convicted of rape in the first degree and robbery in the first degree to be self-serving and not credible. Based upon the documentary evidence before me, the claimant's testimony and the testimony of the witness, Mr. XXXXX XXXXX, I find that the foregoing crimes for which the claimant was convicted in the United States in XXXXX 1998 constitute a sound basis for having serious reasons for considering that the claimant has committed a serious non-political crime outside of the country of refuge.
The second issue to be addressed is whether Article 1F(b) of the Convention should not be applied to the claimant because he completed the prison term of his sentence in the United States prior to coming to Canada. At the hearing, and by way of post-hearing submissions, counsel for the claimant submitted that Article 1F(b) of the Convention does not apply so as to exclude the claimant because he served the entire prison or jail term of his sentence and was released on parole. Counsel submits that Article 1F(b) only applies in the situation where the jail term of the sentence is not served by the claimant. In support of this argument, the claimant's counsel cites Chan17 where the Federal Court held that Article 1F(b) is not applicable to refugee claimants who have been convicted of a crime committed outside Canada and who have served their sentence prior to coming to Canada. In addition, the claimant's counsel makes the following post-hearing written submissions:
1. Pursuant to Section 50(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, a removal order is stayed "in the case of a foreign national sentenced to a term of imprisonment in Canada, until the sentence is completed".
2. Pursuant to Subsection 128(1) of the Corrections and Conditional Release Act - "An offender who is released on parole, statutory release or unescorted temporary absence continues, while entitled to be at large, to serve the sentence [emphasis added] until its expiration according to law".
3. Pursuant to Subsection 128(3) of the same Act, despite Subsection (1) of the Corrections and Conditional Release Act, for the purposes of Section 50(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Section 40 of the Extradition Act, the sentence of an offender who has been released on parole, statutory release or an unescorted temporary absence is deemed to be completed unless the parole or statutory release has been suspended, terminated or revoked [emphasis added] or the unescorted temporary absence is suspended or cancelled or the offender has returned to Canada before the expiration of the sentencing according to law.
4. This provision, coupled with the reasoning in the Chan decision means that it would be contrary to law to exclude the claimant. The sentence of the claimant must, in law, be deemed to have been completed once he was released on parole. Since the deeming is both for the purpose of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and the Extradition Act, the Board must recognize this deeming provision and find that Article 1F(b) is not applicable to the claimant.
5. The Chan decision was also based upon a finding that a person convicted abroad was not excludable under Article 1F(b) because of the scheme of the former Immigration Act. The relevant provisions in the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act remain the same, namely Section 101(2)(b) for eligibility and Section 115(2) for removal. In Chan, the court noted that a person who is convicted abroad, and has served his sentence prior to coming to Canada cannot be found ineligible to make a refugee protection claim in Canada or be returned to a country of danger from which the claimant fled unless the Minister has issued a public danger opinion against the claimant. Allowing exclusion on a conviction abroad alone, without a Ministerial danger opinion, is contrary to the intent of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act. It would have the effect "of virtually abrogating" the legislated need for a danger opinion.
I considered the documentary evidence before me respecting the sentences imposed on the claimant by the Superior Court of the State of Washington. On his conviction for the crimes of rape in the first degree and robbery in the first degree the claimant was sentenced to 150 weeks for each conviction for a total sentence of 300 weeks or over 5.5 years of incarceration in a facility operated by the State of Washington Department of Social and Health Services, Division of Juvenile Rehabilitation.18
I also considered the following testimony of the witness, Mr. XXXXX XXXXX respecting the claimant's sentences for being convicted of rape in the first degree and robbery in the first degree in the State of Washington. Again, Mr. XXXXX is a parole officer with the State of Washington Juvenile Rehabilitation Administration in XXXXX Washington. The claimant was released from a juvenile prison facility on XXXXX, 2002 and therefore he would have only served approximately four years of prison time. However, the documentary evidence before me indicates that the Superior Court of Washington, Juvenile Court credited the claimant for time already served of 201 days.19 In addition, according to Mr. XXXXX testimony, the claimant was released from prison after serving 80 percent of his sentence, the minimum under the law of the State of Washington. Part of his sentencing on the conviction for rape in the first degree as well, was to serve two years of sex offender parole following his release from prison. This two years of parole imposed the following conditions on the claimant: (a) attending sexual offender treatment; (b) weekly meetings with a parole officer with the State of Washington Juvenile Rehabilitation Administration ("JRA"); (c) to avoid being around all high risk places such as zoos or parks unless in the company of a chaperon approved of by his sex offender treatment provider; (d) no contact with the victims of the offences that he committed; (e) no contact with any person that is two years younger than he is; (f) to actively seek full-time employment; (g) to not be tardy in attending his weekly meetings with a parole officer; (h) to obtain verbal permission from the JRA before leaving the Country and to obtain written permission from the JRA before leaving the State of Washington; (i) to remain at his address of record and provide notification of any change in his address of record to the JRA; (j) to provide information to the sexual offender registry in the State of Washington to ensure that the information remains accurate; and (k) to take a polygraph test as directed by the JRA.
Mr. XXXXX also provided the following testimony respecting the two-year parole portion of the claimant's sentence. The claimant did not complete his two-year parole because he has been on unauthorized leave since XXXXX, 2004. As referred to above, in XXXXX with this unauthorized leave, JRA issued a Parole Arrest Warrant against the claimant on January 30, 2004 for failure to keep a scheduled meeting with a JRA parole officer on XXXXX, 2004.20 The claimant was found to be on unauthorized leave on three previous occasions during 2003. For the first two unauthorized leaves, the claimant was sent back to prison for two weeks and for the third unauthorized leave, he was sent to prison for one month. Under State of Washington law, the parole portion of a criminal sentence stops when the parolee is on unauthorized leave or is otherwise in breach of his or her parole conditions or requirements. For this reason, the claimant is currently still under the parole portion of his sentence in the State of Washington. If he were to return to the United States today, he would face a further period of incarceration, and the Parole Arrest Warrant issued against him on XXXXX, 2004 currently remains in effect.
I also considered counsel for the claimant's submissions concerning the Corrections and Conditional Release Act, and as a Member of the Board I take judicial notice of the provisions of the Act. Although the claimant's counsel makes reference to Subsection 128 (1) of the Act in his written submissions, counsel doe not refer to Subsection 128(2) of the Act. Subsection 128(2) states:
Except to the extent required by the conditions of any day parole, an offender who is released on parole, statutory release or unescorted temporary absence is entitled, subject to this Part, to remain at large in accordance with the conditions of the parole, statutory release or unescorted temporary absence and is not liable to be returned to custody by reason of the sentence unless the parole, statutory release or unescorted temporary absence is suspended, cancelled, terminated or revoked.
In his written submissions, counsel also refers to the deeming provision contained in Subsection 128(3) of the Act. Subsection 128(3) states:
Despite subsection (1), for the purposes of 50(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, and section 40 of the Extradition Act, the sentence of an offender who has been released on parole, statutory release or an unescorted temporary absence is deemed to be completed unless the parole or statutory release has been suspended, terminated or revoked or the unescorted temporary absence is suspended or cancelled or the offender has returned to Canada before the expiration of the sentence according to law.
With respect to the claimant's sentences and parole conditions in the United States, I find the operative words in Subsection 128(2) of the Act are "unless the parole, statutory release or unescorted temporary absence is suspended, cancelled, terminated or revoked". I also find that the operative words in Subsection 12(3) of the Act with respect to the application of the deeming provision are "unless the parole or statutory release has been suspended, terminated or revoked...". Based upon the evidence of Mr. XXXXX, I conclude that the claimant's parole in the State of Washington was suspended, terminated or revoked pursuant to the laws of the State of Washington by reason of the claimant's three unauthorized leaves in breach of the conditions of his parole.
I also refer to Section 135 of the Corrections and Conditional Release Act. Subsection 135(1) of the Act states:
A member of the Board or a person, designated by name or position, by the Chairperson of the Board or by the Commissioner, when an offender breaches a condition of parole or statutory release or when a member or person is satisfied that it is necessary and reasonable to suspend the parole or statutory release in order to prevent a breach of any condition thereof or to protect society, may, by warrant,
(a) suspend the parole or statutory release;
(b) authorize the apprehension of the offender; and
(c) authorize the recommitment of the offender to custody until the suspension is cancelled, the parole or statutory release is terminated or revoked or the sentence of the offender has expired according to law.
Subsections 135(10) and 135(11) of the Act state:
(10) For the purposes of this Part, an offender who is in custody by virtue of this section continues to serve the offender's sentence.
(11) for the purposes of this Act, where a suspension of parole or statutory release is cancelled, the offender is deemed, during the period beginning on the day of the issuance of the suspension and ending on the day of the cancellation of the suspension, to have been serving the sentence to which the parole or statutory release applies.
Again, in evidence before me is a Parole Arrest Warrant issued against the claimant by the JRA of the State of Washington on XXXXX, 2004 for breach of one of the conditions of his parole on XXXXX, 2004. In addition, it is Mr. XXXXX evidence that the claimant was recommitted to serving his sentence in prison on three separate occasions for breaching the conditions of his parole in the State of Washington. Based upon the foregoing provisions of the Corrections and Conditional Release Act, the documentary evidence before me and the evidence of Mr. XXXXX, I find on a balance of probabilities that the scheme for suspension, termination, and revocation of parole in the State of Washington in the United States is similar to suspension, termination and revocation of parole in Canada. In addition, the Chan21 decision does not refer to the Corrections and Conditional Release Act, and as such the decision is not authority counsel's submission respecting the Act. For all of the foregoing reasons, I conclude that provisions of the Corrections and Conditional Release Act do not assist the claimant respecting the application of Article 1F(b) of the Convention to his protection claim.
Based upon the foregoing documentary evidence and evidence of the witness, Mr. XXXXX, I find that the claimant has not fully completed the sentences imposed on him by the Superior Court of Washington, County of XXXXX, Juvenile Court on XXXXX, 1998. Therefore, I also find that principle enunciated in the Chan decision is not applicable to the claimant.
With respect to the claimant's counsel's remaining written submissions, I find that they are not applicable to Article 1F(b) of the Convention. My reasons are as follows. The Federal Court of Appeal in Zrig22 refused to limit Article 1F(b) to crimes that are extraditable pursuant to a treaty. Rather, it interpreted the reference to extraditable crimes in Pushpanathan as an indication of the nature and seriousness of the crimes that may fall under Article 1F(b). Based upon the foregoing analysis, I find that there are serious reasons for considering that the claimant has committed and was convicted of a serious non-political crime outside of the country of refuge, and as such he is excluded from the Convention refugee definition pursuant to Article 1F(b) of the Convention. Pursuant to Section 98 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, I also find that the claimant is excluded from being a person in need of protection pursuant to Section 97(1) of the Act.
CONCLUSION
Having considered all of the evidence before me, and for all of the foregoing reasons, I determine that XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX is not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection, and therefore I reject his claim.

These are the reasons for decision with respect to the refugee protection claim made by XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX (alias XXXXXXXXXXXXX, alias XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, alias XXXXXXXXXXXX, alias XXXXXXXXXXXXX), who claimed to be a Convention refugee, under section 961 of the Act. He also claimed to be a person in need of protection, under paragraphs 97(1)(a) and (b)2 of the Act, stating that there are substantial grounds for believing that if he were returned to Algeria, his country of citizenship, he would be personally subjected to a danger of torture, to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
L. Cozza, of SARIM, was appointed as his designated representative in this case.
The evidence presented by the claimant, his counsel, the Refugee Protection Officer (RPO) and Lucie Séguin, representing the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC), essentially consisted of the claimant's testimony, his Personal Information Form (PIF) and personal documents, and documents related to the social and political situation in Algeria. They formed Exhibits A-1 to A-9, R-1 to R-6 and M-1 to M-14.
It should be noted that, through her representative, the Minister intervened in this case, to raise the question of the application of the exclusion clause, Article 1F(b) of the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees, on the grounds that the claimant had committed a serious non-political crime before he was admitted to Canada.
THE FACTS
The facts alleged may be summarized as follows:
The claimant was born on XXXXX, 1966, in Algiers, the capital of Algeria. Before he left his country, he had been unemployed since 1988.
The claimant was deported from Germany to Algeria in XXXXXX 1999. At the end of the year, he went to Tunisia in order to reach Italy. However, his plan did not succeed. In 2000, the claimant travelled secretly to Morocco in order to get into Spain. He paid 6,000 French francs for the trip, which was also aborted. He then returned to Algeria.
The claimant told the panel that the regional security directorate [Direction régionale de la sécurité (DRS)] and military security services [Sécurité militaire (SM)] had asked him to break into the offices of the XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX. The claimant said that he took some documents relating to the party, even though it had been banned since 1992.
As early as 1992, the claimant had decided to leave Algeria. On XXXXX, 2001, he left Algeria by boat. He arrived in Canada at Baie Comeau on June 4, 2001. However, he did not seek refugee protection until June 11, 2001.
The claimant said that, if he had to return to Algeria, he did not know what he would fear; he said that he was not afraid of anyone. While he said that he had converted from Islam to Catholicism in 2000, the claimant could not identity the supreme head of the Church; he did not know what Easter was; he has not been baptized; he has not taken courses on either religion or the Bible; and he thought Christmas was on December 24 or 25.
THE APPLICATION OF THE EXCLUSION CLAUSE
The case law has established that it is not necessary to rule on the merits of a claim, i.e., inclusion, before deciding whether the exclusion clause applies.3
Section 98 of the Act provides that
A person referred to in section E or F of Article 1 of the Refugee Convention is not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection.
Article 1F(b), which is reproduced in the Schedule to the Act, reads as follows:
The provisions of this Convention shall not apply to any person with respect to whom there are serious reasons for considering that
(...)
(b) he has committed a serious non-political crime outside the country of refuge prior to his admission to that country as a refugee; (...)
The panel feels that it is important to emphasize that, for the application of Article 1F(b) of Article 1, the panel is not required to balance the "seriousness" of the claimant's conduct "against the alleged fear of persecution."4
With respect to the burden of proof, it is recognized that the party that raises the issue of the exclusion clause must prove that it is justified. The onus is therefore on the Minister to prove that the claimant must be excluded, in accordance with Article 1F(b). In this regard, the Honourable Justice McGuigan wrote in Ramirez:
[...] the burden of establishing serious reasons for considering that international offences had been committed rested on the party asserting the existence of such reasons, i.e., the respondent. 5
As for the degree of proof required, the Honourable Justice Robertson indicated in Moreno that the Minister does not have to prove that the claimant was charged with or convicted of the acts attributed to him, but the Minister must meet the standard of proof implied in the phrase "serious reasons for considering," in Article 1F(b):
It is universally accepted that the applicability of the exclusion clause does not depend on whether a claimant has been charged or convicted of the acts set out in the Convention. The Minister's burden is merely to meet the standard of proof embraced by the term "serious reasons for considering".6
The Honourable Justice Décarie was in full agreement in Bazarghan,7 as was the Honourable Justice Nadon in Mohamad.8 As well, the panel notes that this standard of proof is lower than that of the balance of probabilities.9
In the case before this panel, are there "serious reasons for considering" that the claimant, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, has committed at least one serious non-political crime?
The evidence on the record revealed that on XXXXX, 2000, the claimant was involved in a case of attempting to defraud through the use of false documents in Algeria (Exhibit M-4: Interpol document from Algiers, dated XXXXX, 2002). In Germany, he was involved between 1992 and 1994 in a theft from a motor home, infractions of the laws relating to foreigners on two occasions, as well as one offence of attempted identity theft (Exhibit M-6: Interpol document from the Federal Republic of Germany, dated of XXXXX, 2001). The evidence also showed that he was involved in a theft in Amsterdam in XXXXX 1992. In addition, a warrant for his arrest was issued by the public prosecutor's department in XXXXX, Germany, for the execution of a prison sentence of 1233 days, more than three years, for aggravated robbery with violence (Exhibit M-6). In addition, on two counts of robbery, he was sentenced to a total term of imprisonment of six years and nine months, beginning on XXXXX, 1997 (Exhibit A-9: translation of a sentence of the Federal Republic of Germany of XXXXX, 1997).
At the hearing, the claimant made the following admissions: He committed two armed robberies in Germany; he was arrested in Germany in 1994 for theft from a motor home; he used false documents in Europe; he was arrested in Amsterdam, but had not stolen anything there; he felt forced to commit offences because he did not have enough money to live on. He also said that in Canada he had stolen things without being charged; he also tried to steal a computer from a car and he has worked here illegally. In addition, the claimant testified that, in 2000, while he was in Morocco, he found the bodies of three dead Algerians in his apartment. He said that even though he had no connection with their deaths, he had not notified the police or emergency services, and had left for Algeria in XXXXX or XXXXX 2000. He also said that in Germany, around 1993, he hit a person violently in self-defence. He said he thought he had killed that person, but was relieved when he saw him again a few days later. He said he had not been arrested for these aggravated assaults. He related a relatively similar incident that took place in Algeria around 2000. In addition, he said that in Canada, as well, he almost hit someone one day. He said that the person had been lucky and if he saw him again he would "punch his face in." He denied, however, that he had been involved in attempting to defraud through the use of false documents in Algeria, and maintained that he had no criminal record in Algeria.
With respect to his sentence (Exhibit A-9), and the warrant for his arrest issued by the German authorities to execute a prison sentence of 1233 days (Exhibit M-6), the claimant testified at the hearing that he had been sentenced to eight years in prison. However, according to Exhibit A-9, the term was six years and nine months. When confronted on this point, the claimant said that there was only one conviction; he had already served 21 months before being sentenced; and that from the date of sentencing, he had served about three years. In all, he served five years and one month of his sentence. When questioned about the 1233-day-sentence to be served, he indicated that it was a credit. Showing clemency toward him, the German authorities released him on XXXXX (he then said it was XXXXX, 1999), and then deported him to Algeria, accompanied by two Interpol officers. He also said that, if he were returned to Germany, he might have to serve that sentence; or, after five or ten years, the conviction might lapse. He said, to make a long story short, he was deported before serving the whole sentence and that, if he returned to Germany, he might be put in prison. Finally, he admitted, everything was very complicated.
The claimant was also confronted with the fact that in his answer to question 21 on his PIF, signed May 22, 2002, he stated that he had never been convicted of a crime or criminal offence. As well, in answer to question 22 in his Notification of Claim as a Convention Refugee, dated June 12, 2001, at Montreal (Exhibit M-1), he stated that he had never been charged with or convicted of an offence or a crime in any country. There was a similar statement in question 22 of Exhibit M-2, which was dated July 12, 2001, at Toronto. The claimant's explanation was that this statement was not accurate because when he is in Europe he always commits some kind of crime; it's automatic.
Now, what meaning is to be given to the term "non-political crime"? According to paragraph 152 of the UNHCR Handbook:
In determining whether an offence is "non-political" or is, on the contrary, a "political" crime, regard should be given in the first place to its nature and purpose i.e. whether it has been committed out of genuine political motives and not merely for personal reasons or gain. There should also be a close and direct causal link between the crime committed and its alleged political purpose and object. The political element of the offence should also outweigh its common-law character. This would not be the case if the acts committed are grossly out of proportion to the alleged objective. The political nature of the offence is also more difficult to accept if it involves acts of an atrocious nature.
Paragraph 155 of the Handbook adds:
(...) In the present context, however, a "serious" crime must be a capital crime or a very grave punishable act. Minor offences punishable by moderate sentences are not grounds for exclusion under Article 1 F (b) even if technically referred to as "crimes" in the penal law of the country concerned.
Writing for the majority in Pushpanathan,10 Mr. Justice Bastarache said with respect to Article 1F(b):
It is quite clear that Article 1F(b) is generally meant to prevent ordinary criminals extraditable by treaty from seeking refugee status, but that this exclusion is limited to serious crimes committed before entry in the state of asylum.
The documents filed on the record showing that the claimant had committed crimes, namely, Exhibits A-9, M-3, M-4, M-6 and M-7, are credible. It is obvious that these are serious non-political crimes. Furthermore, the claimant has confessed to a number of his crimes.
Consequently, in light of the case law, the documentary evidence and the testimony on the record, the panel has serious reasons for considering that the claimant committed serious non-political crimes before he was admitted into Canada. The panel refers here to the aggravated robbery with violence, for which German authorities issued an arrest warrant to execute a 1233-day-prison sentence, as well as to his failure to assist a person at risk when he discovered three dead bodies in his apartment in Morocco in 2000. The panel also refers to the aggravated assaults, one in Germany in 1993, and the other in Algeria in 2000. It should also be noted that the claimant has not served his sentence for one offence and has not even been charged in respect of the other offences.
DECISION
Consequently, the panel has serious reasons for considering that the claimant has committed serious non-political crimes and that, by reason of Article 1F(b), and in accordance with section 98 of the Act, he is excluded from the definitions of refugee and person in need of protection.
The panel finds that the claimant, XXXXXXXXXXXX (alias XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX alias XXXXXXXXXXXX, alias XXXXXXXXXXXXX, alias XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX), is not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection.
Consequently, this claim for refugee protection is rejected.

1. 96. A Convention refugee is a person who, by reason of a well-founded fear of persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership in a particular social group or political opinion,
(a) is outside each of their countries of nationality and is unable or, by reason of that fear, unwilling to avail themselves of the protection of each of those countries; or
(b) not having a country of nationality, is outside the country of their former habitual residence and is unable or, by reason of that fear, unwilling to return to that country.
