XXXXXXX, a citizen of Haiti, approximately nine years old,1 arrived in Canada in the fall of 1999 when he was approximately four years old. He claimed refugee protection on March 21, 2002 alleging a well-founded of persecution because of his membership in a particular social group, namely abandoned minor children.
He is also seeking refugee protection on the ground that he is subjected to a risk to his life and to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.2
It should also be noted that XXXXXXX from the Service d'aide aux réfugiés et aux immigrants du Montréal-Métropolitain (SARIMM) [(translation) support services for refugees and immigrants of metropolitan Montreal)] was designated as the representative for the claimant, who is still a minor.
Recall that the claimant had arrived in Canada with XXXXXXXX. Ms. XXXXX had custody of young XXXXX until the Honourable Justice XXXXX XXXXX of the Court of Quebec, Youth Division, removed him from her custody following a request from the Direction de Protection des droits de la Jeunesse (DPJ) [(translation) directorate for protection of the rights of the youth].3 After those incidents, an investigation was conducted (a DNA test) to establish the child's parentage,4 and it determined that XXXXX XXXXX was not young XXXXX biological mother. Shortly after, it was learned that XXXXX XXXXX had abandoned the child and returned to Haiti.
In the XXXXX, 2000 judgement,5 the Honourable Justice XXXXX XXXXX of the Youth Division of the Court of Quebec decided that [translation] "Ms. XXXXX XXXXX is not the child's mother" and [translation] "orders that the child receive all services required in view of his circumstances (medical follow-up, social follow-up)."
A lawyer with Montreal legal aid subsequently applied to the Department of Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) to recognize young XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX as a Canadian citizen under subsection 4 (1) 6 of Part I (The Right to Citizenship) of the Citizenship Act. On November 18, 2003, the director of Montreal legal aid received a letter7 from CIC stating that the application was denied.
SUMMARY OF THE ALLEGED FACTS
In support of his claim for refugee protection, the claimant alleged the following.
He says his name is XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX and that he is a Haitian citizen. Unfortunately he has almost no memories of his childhood in Haiti, except that his grandmother had wanted to drown him. He had arrived in Canada in 1999 with XXXXX XXXXX, and after the DNA test, he learned that this woman was not his mother and that his mother and father were unknown.
He is very afraid of returning to Haiti. Since XXXXX XXXXX fled there because she had been afraid of being charged criminally or by Immigration Canada for abusing him, the claimant is convinced that XXXXX XXXXX would kill him or have him killed if he were to return to Haiti.
He also alleged that the Haitian State would not protect him from XXXXX because he is of no interest to the State and because both his mother and father are unknown.
If he returns to Haiti, the claimant would be a street child, prey to prostitution and homelessness. [Translation] "Impunity is reins in this country; crimes go unpunished." The Haitian authorities are lax towards corruption among the police, civil servants and partisans of the regime.
These are, in essence, the facts made known to the panel by the claimant.
ANALYSIS
To establish his identity and citizenship, the claimant filed a single document: a birth certificate8, which indicates that XXXXX is his mother.
In light of this one document, the panel can only state that the claimant has not proven his identity and citizenship. The panel must consider the DNA test conducted, which demonstrated that XXXXX XXXXX is not his mother, and especially since the claimant conceded in his answers to questions 15 and 37 of his Personal Information Form (PIF)9 that he does not know his biological mother or father.
However, still with respect to the claimant's identity, the Minister's counsel pointed out in her submissions that the preponderance of evidence on record establishes that the claimant's name is XXXXX XXXXX and that he is a Haitian citizen. The panel shall abide by the submissions of the Minister's counsel, given the absence of evidence to the contrary.
In addition, the panel wants to make it clear that it took into account section 106 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act even though the claimant does not possess acceptable documentation establishing his identity. Also, in light of the circumstances surrounding his arrival in Canada, the claimant has provided a reasonable explanation for not having any identity papers and has demonstrated that he has taken the steps available to him to try to obtain the documentation.
Moreover, the panel took into account the Convention on the Rights of the Child which states:
Where a child is illegally deprived of some or all of the elements of his or her identity, States Parties shall provide appropriate assistance and protection, with a view to speedily re-establishing his or her identity.10
The same Convention also states:
1. In all actions concerning children, whether undertaken by public or private social welfare institutions, courts of law, administrative authorities or legislative bodies, the best interests of the child shall be a primary consideration.11
Regarding the claimant's credibility, the panel is prepared to accept the facts alleged in support of his refugee protection claim. In arriving at this conclusion, the panel has also taken the claimant's testimony into account. His testimony was spontaneous and visibly sincere, albeit of poor quality.
The panel also considered the Chairperson's guidelines on child refugee claimants, which states:
In general, children are not able to present evidence with the same degree of precision as adults with respect to context, timing, importance and details. They may be unable, for example, to provide evidence about the circumstances surrounding their past experiences or their fear of future persecution. In addition, children may manifest their fears differently from adults. 12
In light of these guidelines and the claimant's young age, the panel deems that the claimant's testimony deserves to be given the benefit of the doubt regarding its truthfulness.
However, the panel determines that the claimant is not a "Convention refugee"13 because his fear of Ms. XXXXX has no nexus with any of the five grounds in the refugee definition.
However, the evidence on the record showed that the claimant is a "person in need of protection" because he has nowhere to go and to live safely if he were to return to Haiti. Under the circumstances and given that it appears impossible to locate the claimant's biological mother or father, the panel finds that, in accordance with the principle of best interests of the child, a principle recognized by the international community, the claimant cannot return to Haiti, where it would be possible that his life will be at risk.
As such, the panel finds that the Declaration of the Rights of the Child applies in this case, and it states:
The child, for the full and harmonious development of his personality, needs love and understanding. He shall, wherever possible, grow up in the care and under the responsibility of his parents, and, in any case, in an atmosphere of affection and of moral and material security; a child of tender years shall not, save in exceptional circumstances, be separated from his mother. Society and the public authorities shall have the duty to extend particular care to children without a family [...]14
In addition, it should be noted that the panel reached this decision in view of the fact that the claimant has no known father or mother in Haiti and that its decision would not have been the same if his parents had been known.
DETERMINATION
The panel therefore determines that XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX is a "person in need of protection" as defined in paragraph 97(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and accepts his claim for refugee protection.

These are the reasons in support of the decision concerning the claim to "Convention Refugee" status of XXXXXXXX. The claimant alleges that he is a citizen of Pakistan and that he has a well-founded fear of persecution because of his political opinion and his membership in a particular social group. He is also alleging that he is a person in need of protection because he faces a risk of torture or risk to life, or of cruel and unusual punishment or treatment.
The Minister's representative filed Exhibits M-1 to M-12 consisting of documentary evidence on Human Rights in Pakistan.
Counsel's written submissions were received by the IRB on September 2, 2003 and were taken into consideration by the tribunal.
THE ALLEGED FACTS
The claimant alleges the following:
He was born on XXXXXX, 1974, in XXXXX, XXXXX.
In 1997, he joined the Police department, as a XXXXXXXX, and was posted in XXXXX. In XXXXX 1999, the claimant learned from an informant that XXXXX XXXXX, a close associate and family friend of the Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and of his elder brother, Shahbaz Sharif, the Chief Minister of the Punjab Province, was the chief of the criminal underground mafia in Punjab.
Besides smuggling drugs and weapons, XXXXX XXXXX operated illegal gambling joints, with the connivance of the Pakistan Moslem League (PML) government which he was heavily funding.
After verifying the information, the claimant brought the matter to the attention of his superior officers. They appeared uninterested. When he tried to take the matter to the higher officials, he was prevented in doing so by his immediate superiors.
About a month later, the claimant was stopped on his way home on his motorcycle by six armed men. They beat him in the nearby park and threatened that if he continued to "meddle" with XXXXX XXXXX affairs, he would be killed.
The claimant reported the incident to his superior officer who ignored it. His superior officers discouraged him from talking about XXXXX XXXXX and his criminal world, and his colleagues distanced themselves from the claimant.
A few days later, the claimant began to get threatening phone calls from XXXXX XXXXX hench-men. He was afraid because, in XXXXX 1995, a sub-inspector had already been assassinated by XXXXX XXXXX.
The claimant wanted to flee his country, but his financial resources were insufficient. In November 1999, the claimant managed to get some loans from friends and relatives and, in XXXXX 1999, he escaped to the USA.
A year later, in XXXXX 2000, the claimant returned to Pakistan because he had been erroneously informed, in XXXXX 2000, that the military authorities had "smashed" the "crime mafia". On XXXXX, 2001, gunshots were fired from an unknown vehicle at his friend's car, the claimant was also in the car. The same night, the claimant was threatened by XXXXX group. He was told that he was still on their hit list. The claimant then realized that they were still operating freely.
On XXXXX, 2001, the claimant flew to the USA and on March 20, 2003, he requested protection in Canada at the Lacolle border.
Determination
The claimant established his identity as a Pakistani citizen (A-111: passport seized by CIC); nevertheless after carefully reviewing all the evidence, both oral and documentary, the tribunal has reached the conclusion that the claimant is not a "Convention refugee2" nor a "person in need of protection3".
A notice of intervention had been sent by the Minister on July 3rd, 2003 to the effect that, according to documentary evidence, the Pakistani police forces were committing human rights violations.
The claimant was a police officer in Pakistan and as such he is excluded from the definition, according to Sections 1F (a) (crimes against humanity) and (c) (acts contrary to the purposes and principles of the United Nations) of the Convention.
ANALYSIS
I Exclusion
1. Method of recruitment
The claimant was asked what motivated him to enter the police. At first, he said that the police were violating Human Rights, persecuting the people, oppressing the people by taking money from them, killing people. The claimant was further invited to clarify why in such circumstances, he wanted to become a police officer. He explained that his aim was to join the police and serve the people with justice and honesty. He testified that there was no police officer in his family, but that he was from a religious family with a "soft heart". He added that he was committed to join the police and do the efforts he could.
The claimant testified that he applied to the XXXXX Public Service Commission and that he took a specific written exam and had an interview to become a XXXXX. It is clear that the claimant joined the police voluntarily.
2. Nature of the organization
Even though a legal organization, part of the governmental structure, the Pakistani police force, through corruption of the system, committed human rights violations.
According to Exhibit M-64 (Background paper on Refugees and asylum seekers from Pakistan - UNHCR - centre for documentation and research, Geneva, May 1998):
" In 1996, then - President Leghari alleged that police officials pay bribes to the politicians and senior officials in order to get posted to police station of their choice, subsequently recouping their investment by extorting money from citizens (US DOS for 1996, 1997).
Another observer noted that "many of those killed in fake encounters are people whose only crime was to be politically active and who had never been known for any kind of violent act", while others were victimized solely for being in the wrong place at the wrong time and were later labelled "MQM activists".
The Chief Minister of Punjab is reported to have cited the great amount of corruption in the police force as one of the factors contributing to the violence in his province. (...)".
Here are two more recent examples:
The Pakistani police committed extrajudicial executions.
According to Exhibit M-25 (Human Rights Watch World Report 1998,p. 1):
"Sectarian violence and the government's harsh response to it dominated Pakistan's political landscape in 1997, leaving little scope for improvement in human rights. (...)
The change of government did not herald an end to human rights violations in Karachi. At least 400 persons had been killed in the city between January and November, victims of extrajudicial executions by police and federal security forces or retaliatory killings by the MQM".
The Pakistani police continued to practice torture.
According to Exhibit M-36: (Amnesty International Report (January to December 2001):
"In April, police officials acknowledged that torture, particularly of members of disadvantaged groups, continued to be practised. In May, Law Minister Shahida Jamil criticized the previous government's failure to invest in police training, stating that police frequently had no other investigative techniques but the use of force to extract confessions. (...)".
The tribunal concludes that on the basis of the documentary evidence found in M-27, M-38 and M-69, the Pakistani police committed and continue to practice extrajudicial executions and torture.
3. Rank in the organization
The claimant testified that he started to work for the police as a trainee XXXXX, T/SI, and he filed as Exhibit P-1910, a Police identity card dated XXXXX, 1999. He said that he had one issued before but that it was too old and in bad condition, that is why he had gotten a new one. The claimant further explained that he started directly at the XXXXX level, the levels under his, being XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX. So the claimant was not a simple officer.
According to him the training lasted almost a year, from XXXXX 1997 until XXXXX 1998. It is confirmed by Exhibit P-311, order regarding the completion of his basic one year Police Practical Training Course, dated XXXXX, 1998.
Then, he testified that he attended courses A, B, C and D, which is also confirmed by Exhibit P 312, order dated XXXXX, 1999 regarding the completion of his practical training courses A, B and C and the possibility to start course "D" (Police Practical Course), at Police Station XXXXX. The claimant said that course A lasted from four to six weeks, course B almost as long, and that after course C, he started course D at the end of XXXXX 1999 for two years.
The claimant further alleged that in XXXXX 1998, he started "A" training which consisted in studying law in a police district where reserve forces are sent for peace, they tell you how to lead these forces consisting of 40 to 50 constables and head-constables, they teach you how to present yourself to a superior. He also said that he started the rounds after coming into that district.
To the question "Did you have the opportunity to apply this training ?", the claimant answered: "Once or twice I went, it could have been in XXXXX 1998; they tell you how to go around this gathering, how to place your men around ". Then, he confirmed that twice in XXXXX 1998 he applied this training consisting in leading police forces.
He also gave the example when he was sent three times to keep the peace with the reserve, while people were raising slogans: he was in charge of twenty people.
The claimant was asked how many constables he had under his command, as a trainee. He replied that it depended on the ratio of crimes. He gave as an example: "You may have two constables and three to four assistant sub-inspectors, you can also ask for more constables".
To the question, "Why is your training so long ?", the claimant answered: "You are appointed in any district under an experienced supervisor, an Inspector, who tells you how to do prosecution, FIR, daily routine, reports".
The tribunal concludes that although a trainee, the claimant maintained a position of authority, having constables under his command.
4. Knowledge of the atrocities
The claimant admitted during his testimony that he knew that the police were committing Human Rights Violations.
The claimant confirmed documentary evidence according to which there are many "encounters" between common-law criminals and police. The claimant admitted that it was happening within the jurisdiction of the police station where he was working. The claimant testified that the policemen "just pick up the criminals, let them free and shoot them". He added: "The policemen kill them, of course".
The claimant was asked when was the first time he heard about that. He replied: "I do not remember the date, it was during the "D" course, when I came to the police station, between XXXXX 1999 and XXXXX 1999". He said that it happened only once and that he did not have the exact figure, as to how many were killed during that "encounter". Then he said: "three people were killed".
The claimant acknowledged that innocent people as well could be victims in these encounters, but that he did not "observe" it happened with "political people".
The claimant was asked how he could justify staying in the police if they are killing people in his own police district. He replied that his ambition was to do something at his level, that he could not do anything about "them". He further testified that the Senior House Officer (SHO) was the person in charge of those "encounters" or he would appoint someone else who is reliable to him.
Then, the claimant said: "Police in our country do not care about anyone, they can kill anyone; police are part of the army, they do not care".
The claimant admitted that he had seen his colleagues beating a person who was under arrest. He added: "We have the worst police in the world". He admitted that he attended "harsh interrogations" where they beat the accused many times, that it is a daily routine, and he added that the whole world knows about the behaviour of the Pakistani police, "the interrogation is just to persecute".
He was asked whether the reputation of the police changed during the year, between XXXXX 1997 and XXXXX 1998. The claimant replied that the police's reputation did not change and that it was ill-reputed. He added that he heard of a lot of Human Rights violations, but he continued because: "My ambition was to perform my role with honesty. I am an honest person. If people come to me I can provide justice and honesty".
The claimant testified that in XXXXX 1999, he was warned by his superiors that he should "hide the truth" and be part of the "system as it is going on already", in other words, that he should not be "soft". He added that during the "D" course, he was reminded it from time to time, but that he did not think of leaving the police at that time, because he was "completely committed".
The claimant was confronted with Exhibit A-713 (US Country Report, page 5, paragraph c: torture...) to the effect that police are still torturing people:
"Police personnel continued to torture persons in custody throughout the country. A newspaper reported that there were 80 cases of torture in police custody in Lahore".
We conclude that the claimant admitted knowing about the atrocities and being present many times.
5. Opportunity to leave the organization
The claimant testified that he decided to leave Pakistan in XXXXX 1999, but that he only left in XXXXX 1999. He continued to work for the police until his departure. He did not resign from his job because he thought that "if things are normal again, he could do his job again". He added that he was not dismissed from the police.
We conclude that the claimant was free to leave the police but chose to remain in the police force until his departure from Pakistan.
6. Length of time in the organization
The claimant testified that he worked for the police from XXXXX 1997 until XXXXX XXXXX 1999, for approximately two years and four months.
He started in XXXXX.
According to jurisprudence14, there are serious reasons to believe that the claimant was an accomplice in the perpetration of crimes against humanity.
The same acts that constitute crimes against humanity under Section 1F(a) are also found to be contrary to the purposes and principles of the United Nations pursuant to Section 1F(c).
We conclude that the claimant is excluded from the definition, under Section 1F (a) and (c).
II INCLUSION
Furthermore, after carefully reviewing all the evidence, both oral and documentary, the tribunal has reached the conclusion that the claimant is not a "Convention refugee" nor a "person in need of protection" for the following reasons.
We found the claimant's testimony not to be credible. Omissions and inconsistencies on essential elements of his claim led us not to believe the claimant's allegations of persecution.
We do not believe that the claimant was attacked in XXXXX 1999.
The claimant testified that he was badly beaten in XXXXX 1999, he was bleeding from the nose and had a swollen face, he had to stay seven days in hospital, at the XXXXX Medical Centre, in XXXXX.
The claimant was first confronted with the fact that in the medical certificate, dated XXXXX, 1999, filed under Exhibit P-615, there is no mention of hospitalization. The claimant replied: "I got this certificate from them, I do not have a discharge certificate". This answer does not explain the discrepancy between the certificate, in which medication only is prescribed, and his testimony. For these reasons, we do not ascribe any probative value to this medical certificate, nor to the FIR filed by the claimant (Exhibit P-716) which refers to a medical report dated XXXXX, 1999.
The claimant was also confronted with the fact that the date of this alleged incident is omitted in his PIF. He did not give a reasonable explanation for this omission. He only said that he got the help of someone. For all these reasons, the tribunal does not believe that this alleged incident occurred.
In addition, the claimant testified that he decided to leave Pakistan in XXXXX 1999, but that he only left in XXXXX 1999, and continued to work for the police until his departure. This behaviour shows a lack of subjective fear.
He further testified that on XXXXX, 1999 he went to the USA, where he stayed eleven months until XXXXX, 2000, as confirmed by his passport.
He did not claim refugee status in the USA because he said that he did not know the word refugee.
The claimant testified that he returned to Pakistan in XXXXX 2000, he alleged that his father was sick and that he wanted to see whether the "circumstances were good" after the army coup.
He testified that he was in hiding when he arrived in Pakistan "because he had to take precaution". This is omitted in his PIF. He said that he was living at his uncle's place, in a village, 25 kms away from his father's house, he would drive his uncle's car to go and visit his father. He also said that when they tried to shoot him and his friend, in XXXXX 2001, they were going to his friend's home in his friend's car. The claimant was confronted with the fact that going around in a car in public places is inconsistent with being in hiding. He replied that he was not as free as in the USA, which is not an explanation. Therefore, we do not believe that the claimant was in hiding.
We also do not believe that the claimant was attacked while in his friend's car on XXXXX, 2001.
First, because the claimant filed as Exhibit P-817, a FIR, dated XXXXX, 2001 to which we cannot give any probative value since it refers to the alleged incident "about a year and a half ago", described in the FIR dated XXXXX, 1999 (Exhibit P-7) which we did not believe happened.
In addition, "prima facie" this document dated XXXXX, 2001 (Exhibit P-8) contradicts the allegation that the claimant was not working in the police since XXXXX, 1999 because it reads: "I am resident of the above said address and serving as XXXXX XXXXX in Police Department".
Furthermore, when confronted as to whether he had any proof of this incident, the claimant said that he did not think it was important to file a receipt of the repairs of the damaged car.
The claimant left for the USA a second time on XXXXX, 2001.
He did not claim refugee status either this time. He said that he had no job, he did not know anybody and a lawyer would have cost him 5000 to 6000 US$. His lawyer asked him whether there were other reasons. The claimant then said that he was told that it was hard to get refugee status in the USA and that many people were living there without status.
The claimant added that after September 11, 2001, he became very scared, but he did not inquire from the US Immigration authorities; eventhough he had a visa valid until XXXXX XXXXX, 2001 and, therefore, was legal. He said that it was his mistake.
The claimant was asked why it took him more that a year to come to Canada and ask refugee status. He replied that he thought that with the passage of time things will get better.
The tribunal is of the opinion that the claimant's behaviour shows a lack of subjective fear.
The claimant did not establish, should he return to Pakistan that he would have a "reasonable chance" of being persecuted, in the words of Adjei18, nor that he would face a risk of torture or a risk to his life, or of cruel and unusual punishment or treatment, because we did not believe his story of persecution.
CONCLUSION
For these reasons, we find that the claimant, XXXXX XXXXX is not a "Convention refugee", nor is he a "person in need of protection", as defined in Section 9619 and 9720(1) a) or b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
The claimant is excluded from the definition under Section 1F (a) and (c).

These are the reasons in support of the decision regarding the claim made by XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, a Cameroonian citizen, who alleged a well-founded fear of persecution in his country because of his political opinion.
SUMMARY OF THE ALLEGED FACTS
The claimant, whose education is in XXXXX XXXXX, distinguished himself during his university studies through his brilliant XXXXX between Paul Biya's government and students. Because of this XXXXX, highly valued by President Biya, the claimant became a preferred XXXXX on all youth-related issues and, as a result, Biya appointed him as a XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX committee of the party in power, the Cameroon People's Democratic Movement (CPDM).
From then on, the claimant was given a great deal of responsibility and was involved in very complex missions, crowned by his appointment as XXXXX XXXXX of President Biya Youth (PRESBY). Unfortunately, over time, this organization, which had been established to promote socio-political mentoring for young people to prepare them to take over, became an instrument of political propaganda aimed at the electoral fringes to benefit the authorities.
This ambiguous situation and the government's false promises had negative consequences for the claimant and his family, including physical and mental abuse. The claimant, feeling threatened, had requested a meeting with President Biya, but was unsuccessful. Following this, certain that the President of the Republic had literally used him for his own purposes, the claimant decided in XXXXX 2003to resign from his position.
Taking advantage of a mission that was to be held in the United States, the claimant left his country for the United States, where he arrived on XXXXX, 2003. After a stay in the United States, he arrived in Canada on April 1 and sought Canadian protection two days later.
Long before the hearing, the Solicitor General expressed his intention to intervene in this case, since sections F(a) and F(c) of Article 1 of the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees potentially applied to the claimant.
ANALYSIS
In his submissions, the Solicitor General argued that the claimant should be excluded under articles 1F(a) and (c) of the Convention because he had been XXXXX of President Biya Youth (PRESBY) until he left Cameroon and therefore had worked closely with the President of the Republic of Cameroon, Paul Biya, since 1996. The Solicitor General particularly emphasized the fact that there were serious reasons for considering that the claimant, by virtue of his position as XXXXX of PRESBY and his knowledge of the human rights abuses perpetrated by the authorities, should be considered an accomplice in their activities.
Page 2 of Exhibit M-31 provides the following information about human rights violations:
The Government's human rights record remained poor, and it continued to commit numerous serious abuses. Citizens' ability to change their government remained limited. Security forces committed numerous unlawful killings and were responsible for disappearances. They also tortured, beat, and otherwise abused detainees and prisoners, generally with impunity. However, the Government prosecuted a few offenders. Prison conditions remained harsh and life threatening. Security forces continued to arrest and detain arbitrarily various opposition politicians, local human rights monitors, and other citizens, often holding them for prolonged periods, often without charges or a chance for trial and, at times, incommunicado.
Page 1 of the same document states that:
Cameroon is a republic dominated by a strong presidency. Since the early years of independence, the Cameroon People's Democratic Movement (CPDM) has remained in power. In 1997 CPDM leader Paul Biya won re-election as President in a vote boycotted by the three main opposition parties. ?...? the election generally was considered by observers not to be free and fair.
Exhibit M-102 describes the major violations committed by the Operational Command (OC), a special army unit set up by decree in 2000 by President Biya, with the mission of ensuring security in the province of Littoral. Page 3 of this document states that:
[TRANSLATION]
The people of Douala very soon complained about the serious abuses committed by OC soldiers. Repeated disappearances were reported ?...?
Page 6 of Exhibit M-113 states the following about the PRESBY:
[TRANSLATION]
Repression of the democratic movement was and still is going on. ?...? demonstrations and meetings organized by opposition parties are regularly prohibited, allegedly for radicalism. ?...? A demonstration organized by the Parliamentary Opposition on January 13, 2001 to protest against the NEO ?National Elections Observatory? and demand the establishment of the NIEC ?National Independent Electoral Commission? was harshly repressed, with the assistance of plain-clothes parallel police officers and the militias of PRESBY, a fascistic organization affiliated with the CPDM.
Exhibit M-144 confirms that the PRESBY organization was proposed and/or is maintained by the government in power. Page 2 of this document states that:
[TRANSLATION]
?...? the power holders are launching "Autodéfense". The two movements are sowing terror in the Ngoa-Ekellé area, leaving the students Ndam Soulé and Djengoué Collins high and dry. Their sponsors, who are still power hungry, arranged their "exile" or their conversion.
Some are in the West, after passing through Burkina. The others are in President Biya Youth (PRESBY) today. This organization received official unction in November 1996, on the occasion of the 14th anniversary of President Biya's coming to power. It was believed that his militants had returned to civilian life when, in late 2000, they revealed themselves and, with punches, forcefully broke up the march on Etoudi Palace conducted by members of the Social Democratic Front (SDF) to present to Biya a memorandum on the Independent Electoral Commission.
The article headed "Armed PRESBY Gang Attacks", produced in Exhibit M-16 in a bundle,5 corroborates this violence perpetrated by the PRESBY. The article states as follows:
?...? After hours of heated arguments with top level government officials, and after darkness descended on Yaoundé, a gang of over 200 youths, allegedly belonging to the President Biya Youths, PRESBY, armed with pistols, attacked, leaving several injured. Over a dozen opposition militants were reportedly hospitalised.
This is also corroborated on page 20 of Exhibit M-18,6 which states that during French President Jacques Chirac's visit to Cameroon on January 13, 2001, a PRESBY group savagely and publicly attacked the opposition:
As another example of how the Government was trying to frighten and embarrass the opposition. Asonganyi and Che described events during the French President Jacques Chirac's visit to Cameroon in connection with the Franco-African summit in January 2001. During the parade in Yaoundé on 13 January 2001 before the summit, opposition politicians including the SDF had taken up positions like everyone else on the parade ground in the town centre. However, members of the so-called "Presby group", which had close ties with the Government, had infiltrated the SDF group. When Chirac's convoy passed by, members of the Presby group threw stones at the convoy, so that it looked as thought it was SDF politicians who were behind this action. The chauffeur and private secretary of the SDF Chairman, Jon Fru Ndi, were then openly attacked by the Presby group.
Finally, page 3 of Exhibit M-127 states as follows:
[TRANSLATION]
?...? Paul Biya set up tribal militias and other heavily armed self-defence groups in an attempt to save his unpopular regime. These militias, which brought terror and death to university campuses and neighbourhoods in the capital city, would systematically attack members of certain communities, suspected of having close ties to the opposition. ?...?
These tribal militias are heavily funded by the authorities ?...? this is true for the Presby and Jachaby youths, who take their orders directly from the presidential palace.
According to the Solicitor General, exclusion is particularly warranted since the claimant, as the XXXXX XXXXX of PRESBY, an association that defends Paul Biya's ideals, displayed tremendous tolerance with regard to the government in power, in order to derive advantages from it. In fact, he never resigned from his position, despite that government's bad reputation.
According to his testimony, the claimant voluntarily joined the party in power, the CPDM, in 1996. Because of his outstanding work with young people, Biya appointed him as XXXXX of President Biya Youth in XXXXX 1996. This association was set up to establish a dialogue between the government and students on decisions involving student demands. As part of his duties, to which he devoted approximately 25 hours per week and through which he significantly increased student involvement, the claimant had numerous meetings with the Head of State and his representatives. His responsibilities as PRESBY XXXXX consisted of XXXXX the national office's activities, XXXXX members of the national committee, XXXXX and XXXXX internal and external conferences, XXXXX cultural activities, and XXXXX invitations from influential people in the party. In short, as he stated [translation] "I went wherever there was a need.".
The claimant added that he had travelled solely on his duty passport, a privilege granted to him by his government when they sent him abroad for the first time to France in 1999. He also conceded that some PRESBY members had committed certain acts of violence, but he downplayed these acts, describing them as isolated incidents that, according to him, had not been dictated by his management. He also mentioned that he was aware of the use of torture by Biya's government, which, according to him, was an oppressive, despotic government that would arrest opponents and opposition leaders. The claimant also added that this regime had been oppressive since independence in 1960. He stated that he had definitely noticed this oppression in 1997, saying:
[TRANSLATION]
?...? being myself a witness. I have to say that as of 1997 I noticed that there were a great many blunders, and I witnessed the arrest of XXXXX XXXXX.
When asked to explain how he had witnessed this arrest, the claimant, throughout the hearing, tried to downplay his involvement and replied that he had learned about this arrest like all Cameroonians, i.e. in the newspapers. He also stated that he had never thought of dissociating himself from PRESBY because the students would not have looked favourably on this action. In addition, although he knew that the Biya regime was oppressive and murderous, he did not resign because, in his view, when a person decides to resign, he or she needs to have an alternative; and in his case, if he had resigned, he would have been called a subversive and a traitor. He added that his resignation would have been frowned on, either by the young people or by the authorities.
It should be noted that the claimant was first elected XXXXX of PRESBY in 1996 for a XXXXX -year term. He ran for XXXXX in 1998 and was re-elected for a XXXXX year term. When asked why he had run in 1998, he replied [translation] "Didn't reach the objectives that had been set." In 2002, he again ran for XXXXX of PRESBY and was again re-elected. When again asked why he had run for the position of PRESBY XXXXX, he replied [translation] "The work felt like a calling to me."
The law and case law
Articles 1F(a) and (c) of the Convention, incorporated into Canadian law through section 98 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, which applies in this case, excludes the following persons from the "Convention refugee" definition:
The provisions of this Convention shall not apply to any person with respect to whom there are serious reasons for considering that:
(a) he has committed a crime against peace, a war crime, or a crime against humanity, as defined in the international instruments drawn up to make provision in respect of such crimes;
(b) ?...?
(c) he has been guilty of acts contrary to the purposes and principles of the United Nations.
It is now well established by the case law that when a claimant is not identified as the perpetrator of a crime against peace or a crime against humanity, that claimant is still subject to the exclusion clause through complicity. In this regard, Linden J., in Sivakumar,8 summarized the concept of complicity as follows:
It is clear that if someone personally commits physical acts that amount to a war crime or a crime against humanity, that person is responsible. However, it is also possible to be liable for such crimes, to commit them as an accomplice, even though one has not personally done the acts amounting to the crime.
MacGuigan J., in Ramirez,9 assessed the degree of complicity that could lead to the application of the exclusion clause. He stated as follows:
Clearly no one can commit international crimes without personal and knowing participation. What degree of complicity, then, is required to be an accomplice or abettor? A first conclusion I come to is that mere membership in an organization which from time to time commits international offences is not normally sufficient for exclusion from refugee status. ?...? however, where an organization is principally directed to a limited, brutal purpose, such as a secret police activity, mere membership may by necessity involve personal and knowing participation in persecutorial acts.
Nadon J., in Mohammad,10 listed the principles of the concept of complicity:
1. A person who commits a crime must be held responsible therefor.
2. A person may be responsible for a crime he or she did not personally commit, that is, as an accomplice.
3. The starting point for the existence of complicity is personal and knowing participation by the person in question.
?...?
9. A person who continues to hold a leadership position in such an organization with full knowledge that the organization is responsible for crimes may be considered an accomplice.
10. Evidence that the individual protested against the crime, tried to stop its commission or attempted to withdraw from the organization must be taken into consideration in determining whether he or she is responsible.
In the case before us, it is clear that the claimant voluntarily joined President Biya's party and worked very closely with him. In 1996, the claimant was elected XXXXX of PRESBY. Despite his full knowledge of the Biya government's practice of torture and the acts committed by his association, PRESBY, he ran for XXXXX twice following his first term as XXXXX and was re-elected each time. He never tried to dissociate himself from PRESBY and did not resign from his position as XXXXX.
Admittedly, following the first sitting of his hearing, when the possibility of exclusion was raised, the claimant tried to downplay the significance of his position as PRESBY XXXXX and his duties, as well as his cooperation and meetings with President Biya. Unfortunately, he has failed to convince the panel, since all the evidence submitted clearly demonstrates his close cooperation and his complicity with Paul Biya.
In light of the case law and considering the evidence on the record, the panel is of the opinion that, in this case, the Solicitor General's representative has discharged his burden of proof and that, consequently, there are serious reasons for considering that the claimant committed crimes against humanity or was complicit in such crimes.
CONCLUSION
Therefore, the panel determines that the claimant is excluded from the application of the Convention, pursuant to Articles 1F(a) and (c) and cannot be granted protection in Canada, as set out in section 98 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

Following are our reasons related to the asylum claim of Mr XXXXXXXXXXXXXX XXXXXXX, his wife XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, and their son XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX XXXXXXX. Also claiming with them are the sons of Mrs XXXXXX XXXXXX XXXXXX XXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, as well as her mother, Mrs XXXXXXXXXXX XXXXXXXX. Finally, Mrs XXXXXXXX nephew, Mr XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, is also claiming asylum with them. All of the claimants are citizens of Costa Rica, and avail themselves of articles 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
At the beginning of the hearing, Mrs XXXXX was appointed designated representative for her minor children XXXXX , XXXXX and XXXXX.
FACTS
The facts can be summarized as follows.
The principal claimant, Mr XXXXXXXXXXXX was a XXXXX in his country, Costa Rica.
In XXXXX 2001, he was sent to a XXXXX station of "XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX", in the province of San Jose. This place was known for its high level of delinquency, drugs, killings, firearms and clandestine alcohol.
A lot of persons in this place come from Nicaragua and Colombia.
On XXXXX 2002, the claimant and other XXXXX caught a group of people involved in arm trafficking and drugs. One of the persons interrogated mentioned the name of XXXXX XXXXX, who is the XXXXX of the "Comité du développement du secteur de la Carpio dans l'Uruca". He would be a corrupted man, without any scruples.
The claimant would have come to the conclusion that there was a group of delinquents that was protected by some powerful people. Those delinquents could thus act without being punished.
XXXXX XXXXX would have bought the silence of the principal claimant's bosses, due to his economic power.
Starting in XXXXX 2002, the principal claimant would have started to suffer pressure, moral as well as economic. The claimant writes in his Personal Information Form (PIF): " ...peu à peu mes chefs m'ont fait à côté en m'écartant de mon poste pour accomplir mes tâches, de risques sans jamais être informé, en passant également sur toutes les lois du travail. Ceci coïncide précisément le même jour, que j'ai donné toute l'information à mes chefs immédiats... " (reproduced as is from paragraph 14 of the answer to question 41).
His bosses would have told him that the reason for that was the pressure of Mr XXXXX XXXXX, who had a lot of power.
On XXXXX 2002, the claimants received their first threatening phone call. The man calling said he was doing so on behalf of Mr. XXXXX XXXXX, and uttered death threats.
Threatening phone calls continued, day and night. On XXXXX 2002, the principal claimant presented himself to make a denunciation to the "Organisme d'Investigation Judicaire" (OIJ). There, he would have been told that it was impossible to do anything to protect him, if the claimant had no proof.
After that, the phone calls continued, but the people against the claimant and his family also threw stones at their house and broke the windows.
In XXXXX 2002 the principal claimant was transferred to another sector, less dangerous.
Everything was going much better, but the claimant was transferred back again to his former place of work, where he had had so many problems.
At this place Mr XXXXX XXXXX and many persons came to threaten him in person and to tell him he would make the claimant and his family disappear.
There would have been also people watching the claimants' house and work places.
On XXXXX 2003, three men would have brutally attacked the principal claimant, asking him not to say anything to the police. They also would have told him to leave the country, with his family, if he wanted to continue to live.
The last warning would have been given on XXXXX 2003. Some people came in the claimants' house, destroying a lot of things and leaving a note saying: "aujourd'hui c'est le matériel mais demain il pourrait être vos vies qui vont disparaître" (reproduit tel quel du paragraphe 25 de la réponse à la question 41).
After this last incident, the claimants decided to leave their country, some members of the family arriving before other members of the same family in Canada.
All the claimants base their claims on the same facts related by the main claimant. However, some of them add some new facts, but those facts are all related to the main narrative of Mr XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX.
ANALYSIS
After having analyzed all of the evidence, testimonial as well as documentary, we are of the opinion that all the claimants are not "Convention Refugees"1 nor are they "persons in need of protection"2 and this, for the following reasons.
The main question in this case is one of protection. The principal claimant said he asked protection only once to the OIJ, but this organism would have told him that he needed sufficient proof. This is all what he did. We are aware that the principal claimant is a policeman, but we do not think that he has discharged the onus of showing clear and convincing proof of the state's inability or unwillingness to protect him.
We confronted the principal claimant with exhibit A-2, which is a jurisprudential guideline done in accordance with article 159 (1) (h) of the Law (Immigration and Refugee Protection Act). This article reads as follows:
" 159. (1) The Chairperson is, by virtue of holding that office, a member of each Division of the Board and is the chief executive officer of the Board. In that capacity, the Chairperson
h )may issue guidelines in writing to members of the Board and identify decisions of the Board as jurisprudential guides, after consulting with the Deputy Chairpersons and the Director General of the Immigration Division, to assist members in carrying out their duties;"
Therefore the President identified the decision of the Board that was written by Mrs Schlanger as a jurisprudential guide. This is what is deposited under exhibit A-2. In this decision, which makes a review of different documents relating to state protection in Costa Rica, we can read the following extracts:
"...There are a number of recourses available in Costa Rica for the assessment, prosecution and granting of remedies resulting from failure of law enforcement agencies to conduct their work...if police misconduct or abuse occurs, an effective mechanism for lodging complaints exists through the Ombudsman's Office, which serves as a recourse to citizens who have complaints about violations of their civil and human rights, and about deficiencies in public and private infrastructures. It investigates complaints, and when appropriate, initiates suits against officials. ...The law provides for the functional, administrative, and judicial independence of the Ombudsman's Office. Furthermore, the Constitution provides for the right to a fair trail, and an independent judiciary vigorously enforces this right...
....The documentary evidence also indicates that the Judicial Investigative Police (OIJ), which has a 20 member anti-gang division, is currently in the process of investigating the numerous San José youth gangs and has profiled the alleged gang leaders....
...The extensive account of prosecution of crimes in the various courts in Heredia, and the resulting sentences indicate that criminals in Costa Rica are being punished. The panel finds that all the above0-cited documentary evidence indicates that Costa Rica is making serious efforts to protect its citizens who are victims of crime.
...Given that Costa Rica is a longstanding stable, constitutional democracy, with an independent judiciary providing effective means to deal with individual instances of abuse, the claimant bears the onus of establishing that state protection would not be available. The claimant must do more than simply show that he went to some members of the police force and that his efforts were unsuccessful. The more democratic the state's institutions, the more the claimant must have done to exhaust all the courses of action open to him...."
There is also a mention in this jurisprudential guide of government organisms dealing with drug dealers where one could ask protection.
The panel finds that the claimants have not discharged the onus of showing clear and convincing proof of the state's inability or unwillingness to protect him. The main claimant asked for protection only once, to the OIJ. The people at this organism told him they needed proof. The claimant wrote in his PIF that "la loi au Costa Rica ne permet pas comme prouve aucun enregistrement téléphonique, et dans autre sens il n'existe pas non plus de lois qui permettent d'interférer un appel téléphonique.... (reproduced as is from paragraph 18 answer of question 41) With respect for his opinion, we never heard that before, even though we heard a lot of cases from Costa Rica. The claimant did not present documentary evidence on this point either. On the contrary, his counsel, in his submissions on page 10, referred the Panel to an information request dated October 25, 2000 and bearing the number CR135539, in which we can see that wiretapping is allowed: "when cased of witnesses requiring protection reach the Public Ministry, the measures at its disposal have been to request wiretaps to locate the source of the telephone threats...." (p. 10 of his submissions). The claimant also had other chances to go back to OIJ to present evidence: at the end of XXXXX 2002, there were stones that were thrown at his house, the windows were broken. He could have called the authorities to come and have a look at his house, to make an inquiry, try to find some fingerprints, etc. Also, on XXXXX, 2003, they received a threatening note. He never went back either to the OIJ to present this note.
He told us there was not other organisms in Costa Rica that could have helped him. The only place, according to him, was the OIJ. Invited to tell us if he could have gone to the Ombudsman, he answered to us that "the Ombudsman only takes care of business issues". We then told him it was not what was written in exhibit A-2, even reading to him the part where it says that one can go to the Ombudsman to complain when one is not satisfied with police work. The principal claimant answered: "you have that, but in reality it is not like this". He also added that democracy in Costa Rica is just on paper, and that as a policeman it was very hard to be protected.
The claimant XXXXX told us that he went also once to the OIJ, on XXXXX 2003. He went to report a threatening phone call. He was asked why did he go to the same organism as the main claimant, since he already knew that this organism did not help when the main claimant went to report the same thing, i.e. threatening phone call. XXXXX answered: "I thought they would take it seriously, because we are from the same family, it is the same issues". He did not show us with this that the State was unable or unwilling to protect him.
We may also infer from the testimony given by the main claimant that there exists protection in his country. Indeed, he said that he did not report anywhere the XXXXX incident "because if I report this to the police they were going to kill us, even me, being a XXXXX". He writes in his PIF, paragraph 15 of his answer to question 41, that he was warned not to say anything to the police, after this incident of XXXXX. If the Costa Rican police and authorities were so inefficient or unable to protect its citizens, why would those people who were after the claimants tell them not to report anything? Why would the claimant say in his testimony that if he reported this incident to the police, "they were going to kill us"? It is very plausible to think that those people who were after the claimants were AFRAID of the authorities, that is why they did not want the claimants to address themselves to the authorities. We presented our point of view to the main claimant who simply answered the following: "I do not know about other people's fears, I just know about mine".
We also consulted carefully exhibit A-1, which is the "cartable regional de Montréal août 2003". The documents inserted in this cartable all talk about Costa Rica as being a democratic country, where effective means of dealing with its citizens' problems exist.
We also read very carefully the written submissions that were sent by the claimants' counsel. We want to comment some of his allegations before the conclusion of our decision. The counsel refers to two exhibits, P-12 and P-35. The counsel makes a very general conclusion, based on two very specific cases. He writes in his submissions: "The above two articles describe a country that is not interested in pursuing justice". This, according to us, is too much of a general statement concerning two very specific cases. Also, he mentions a decision bearing the number CRI 138217. E, dated January 22, 2002, containing an attachment, that is, an article from the Tico Times. The counsel quoted certain extracts out of context. The article talks about "rampant petty crime", which is not the case in the main claimant's narrative. The claimant talks about a Mr. XXXXX XXXXX, being very important and influent economically and who has a lot of contacts. We are not talking here about "petty crime".
Again, when the counsel quotes the president Abel Pacheco, from the document produced under P-36, he does it out of context. The President expresses himself about the murder of a young girl, who was 11 years old at the time, by a neighbour who was obsessed with her. She was beheaded. We therefore understand fully the comments of the President, when he says: "Je ne suis pas gêné de dire que ce dernier horreur m'a bouleversé. Le Costa Rica est malade. Nous sommes des victimes d'une violence sans limite honteuse et se dirige contre les plus faibles " (reproduced as is from the translation of P-36). We were very surprised to read the claimant's counsels' submissions when he twisted the facts to says the following : "At Exhibit P-36, we read that the president Abel Pacheco describes Costa Rica, not as a democratic country replete with an effective police force and a judiciary system, no; such remarks are reserved for the department of the Immigration Canada and those responsible for drafting the guidelines on Costa Rica...". The comments of the President were made in relation to that particular incident, which indeed is terrible. He was not at all commenting on the police force and judiciary system of his country, and the same comment could have been made by any President of any country where such a barbarian act would have taken place. We will not quote and comment on all of the claimants' counsel's submissions. Suffice us to say that we did not find in the counsel's submissions any documents or arguments that would have made us think that the State of Costa Rica was unable or unwilling to protect the claimants.
As the panel therefore finds that there is adequate state protection available to the claimants in Costa Rica, it determines that they are not "persons in need of protection".
Before concluding, we want to add that we are satisfied with claimants' identities, since a copy of their passports is deposited in our file.
CONCLUSION
For all those reasons, we therefore conclude that the claimants are not "Convention refugees", nor are they "persons in need of protection".
Consequently, their claim for asylum in Canada is denied.

XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, a citizen of Burkina Faso who was born in Ouagadougou on September 2, 1977, has claimed refugee protection under sections 961 and 972 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (the Act).
SUMMARY OF ALLEGED FACTS
The claimant was born in Burkina Faso but resided there for only two years, since she went to live in the Ivory Coast, from 1978 to 1983, and in Senegal, from 1983 to 1999. She took courses at the Université de Montréal from XXXXX 2000 to XXXXX 2001.
A citizen of Burkina Faso, the claimant alleged that she could not return to her country because she would be forced to do military service. She also alleged that she cannot live in the Ivory Coast, where she grew up, because of the xenophobia problems there. Finally, she alleged that she cannot live in Senegal because she was discriminated against there in various ways because of her Burkinan origins and also that she cannot return to live in that country because of her Christian religion.
ANALYSIS
The Refugee Protection Division (RPD) determines from a review of all the evidence that this claim should not be allowed, since the evidence adduced by the claimant is insufficient to establish that she is a person referred to in section 96 and subsection 97(1) of the Act.
The claimant's identity has been established by her testimony and by various documents relating to her Burkinan citizenship. The claimant has also established that she lived in the Ivory Coast and studied in Senegal for several years.
The panel determines that the claimant, who took residence in Senegal, could live in that country. The panel refers to document SEN35851.F,3 dated November 2, 2000, which stated:
[Translation]
Nationals of countries that are members of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) automatically receive permanent residence in Senegal pursuant to an agreement entered into by the ECOWAS member countries.
According to the ECOWAS Website, the countries that belong to that organization are: Benin, Burkina Faso, Cape Verde, the Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, the Ivory Coast, Liberia, Mali, Mauritania, Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, Sierra Leone and Togo.
The panel has made a negative determination based on section E of Article 1 of the 1951 Convention, which is worded as follows:
This Convention shall not apply to a person who is recognized by the competent authorities of the country in which he has taken residence as having the rights and obligations which are attached to the possession of the nationality of that country.
In light of the evidence as a whole, the panel determines that XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX cannot be considered to be in need of international protection, since she is accepted in Senegal, where she can have most of the rights normally attached to the possession of the nationality of that country. The claimant resided in Senegal for several years. From 1983 to 1989, she went to elementary school in Dakar, Senegal; from 1989 to 1996, she attended secondary school in Dakar; and from 1996 to 1998, she studied at the University of Dakar, where she obtained a degree as a XXXXX XXXXX. In August and September 1997, she worked as a XXXXX XXXXX; and from November 1998 to July 1999, she worked at the XXXXX of Dakar as a XXXXX assistant. In actual fact, she left Senegal because she had obtained a grant to come and study at the Université de Montréal. The claimant studied in Senegal, took residence there and resided there on an ongoing basis. It was not a mere stay.
Moreover, the claimant has not satisfied the panel that she is a person referred to in section 96 and subsection 97(1) of the Act.
The claimant made conflicting statements.
In her first narrative in the Personal Information Form (PIF), the claimant stated that she had left Senegal because of the unrest there. She also stated that life in Canada was pleasant and that she appreciated the kindness of Canadians; these were the reasons she gave for not wanting to return to Senegal.
At the hearing, the claimant stated that she could not return to Senegal because she had been discriminated against there during her studies and had not had an opportunity to study. When the panel pointed out to her that she had nevertheless studied and even gone to university there for several years, the claimant said that she had not had an opportunity to do her master's degree and that there was systematic discrimination against people from foreign countries. Once again, the panel is surprised, since the university she attended is recognized as a place where people from a number of African countries study. Moreover, the claimant was privileged compared with other students, since she even worked as a research assistant during her time in university.
The claimant then added some information she had allegedly left out of her two pieces of written evidence, namely that she had worked as a Jehovah's Witness and had been persecuted in Senegal because of this. The panel does not believe this story, since, based on its assessment of all the evidence, the claimant added these facts for the purposes of her hearing. In her PIF, this is an amendment made much later, since this information was omitted from the first and second narratives. The claimant's explanations have not convinced the panel, since these are significant omissions concerning essential facts.
An analysis of all the evidence does not make it possible to establish or determine that the claimant is a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection. The claim of XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX is therefore rejected. Moreover, she must be excluded from the definition of refugee, pursuant to section E of Article 1 of the 1951 Convention.

These are the reasons for decision in the case of XXXXX XXXXX.
The claimant is currently 26 years of age. He claims to be a citizen of India. He stated that he left his country on XXXXX, 2003 to come to Canada. He has made a claim for refugee protection in two parts. First, he claims to have a well-founded fear of persecution by reason of his imputed political opinion. Second, he claims to be a person in need of protection under section 97(1)(a) and (b) of the Act.
ALLEGED FACTS
In support of his claim, the claimant alleged the following.
In his country, he lived in the city of Bathinda, where he began working with his father in his father's XXXXX company in 1999. He later became a partner in this company.
On XXXXX, 2002, one of the company's XXXXX was stopped by the police who, after conducting a check, arrested two passengers, who were terrorists, as well as the driver. The police accused the driver of transporting terrorists and weapons. He was tortured.
On XXXXX, 2002, the police went to the company's offices and arrested the claimant. He was tortured but released two days later after being questioned about the terrorists.
On XXXXX, 2003, the police again raided the company's offices, stating that they had found a bag containing explosives in one of the XXXXX. The claimant was arrested and tortured and accused of possessing explosives. He was released three days later. He was then told to report to the police station on XXXXX, 2003 to give information about the terrorists.
Afraid of being tortured again, the claimant left his home on XXXXX, 2003 and went to his uncle's home in the city of XXXXX in the state of Haryana. When he did not report to the station on XXXXX, 2003, the police raided his home and arrested his father. The next day, the claimant's uncle learned of this and made the claimant leave his home to go live with a friend. From there, the claimant travelled to Delhi, where he made arrangements with a smuggler, who obtained a visitor visa for him and helped him leave his country to come to Canada.
ANALYSIS
After analysing all the evidence, both testimonial and documentary, I have determined that the claimant is neither a refugee nor a person in need of protection.
Identity
I examined the exhibits in the record, in particular the photocopy of the claimant's passport (Exhibit R-20) and his driver's licence (Exhibit R-2), and I am satisfied as to his identity.
Credibility and basis of the claim
The claimant had a great deal of difficulty giving direct answers to the questions he was asked, and I had to intervene more than once to remind him of the question and to point out to him that he must first answer the question before entering into explanations, which, very often, explained nothing. I question his testimony on these points.
With regard to the basis of the claim, I must note that the story contains such major contradictions and inconsistencies that it cannot be true.
First, with regard to his fear of returning, the claimant stated that he was afraid to go back to his country because he would risk being killed by the Indian police, who have considered him a terrorist since XXXXX, 2002, when he was first arrested. I have difficulty believing the claimant on this point because if the police had indeed accused him of being a terrorist, it is not unreasonable to think that they would not have arrested him on XXXXX, 2002, then released him two days later, then arrested him again on XXXXX, 2003 and tortured him, then released him again three days later - particularly since the claimant stated that when the police arrested him the second time, they claimed to have found a bag of explosives in one of the XXXXX they searched at that time. The police would surely have charged him formally and brought the case to court.
Moreover, there is cause to wonder about the arrests and torture the claimant claims to have endured in his country. In his Personal Information Form (PIF) signed July 23, 2003 and in his testimony, he stated that he had been arrested and tortured on XXXXX, 2002 and on XXXXX, 2003. However, during an interview with an immigration officer (see the officer's notes filed with the immigration documents as Exhibit A-2), at question 51, he was asked whether he had ever been detained by the police or military forces in another country, and he answered yes, stating that he had been arrested in his country on XXXXX, 2002. When questioned about this discrepancy regarding the date, he stated that it was an error because what he had said was XXXXX, 2002, not XXXXX, which is not impossible. However, with regard to the fact that he had mentioned only the arrest of XXXXX 2002, the claimant was caught off guard and gave a number of explanations, each of which contradicted the others. He first stated that he had been asked only about the most recent arrest. This explanation does not hold because, according to his account, his most recent arrest occurred on XXXXX, 2003. Realizing that this explanation did not work, he then stated that when he was questioned on June 27, 2003, he had simply been asked on what date he had been arrested by the police and he had stated XXXXX, 2002. This explanation does not hold because according to his PIF, he had been arrested not once, but twice. When I pointed this out, he provided another explanation, stating that he had been asked when he had been arrested for the first time. With this final explanation, the claimant was obviously altering his testimony to get himself out of the predicament since question 51, which he had to answer, reads as follows: "Have you ever been detained by the police or the military force in any given country?" The question is not at all debatable. As I have said, the claimant was simply trying to get out of a difficult situation.
Still along the same lines, it should be noted that during this interview, the claimant failed to mention not only that he had been arrested twice, but also that he had been tortured. This can be seen fairly clearly in his response to question 55, when he was asked if he had anything else to add. He spoke of the reasons he was afraid to return to his country, but made no mention of having been tortured. When questioned on this subject, he stated that he had been told to write something brief. I reject this explanation, as the claimant's response extends to four lines. As I pointed out to the claimant, it is clear that if he had wanted to write that he had been tortured, there was plenty of space in which to do so. Therefore, I do not at all believe the claimant on this point.
Furthermore, in another document that he completed himself and signed with his own interpreter (the document entitled "Schedule 1", filed with the immigration documents as Exhibit A-2), in response to question 4J asking whether he had been detained or imprisoned, he answered yes; however, at the sub-question asking for details about his detention(s), he made no mention of the two arrests or of having been tortured. In explanation, he stated that this may be an error because he was simply asked whether he had been detained by the police and he had answered "yes". I reject this explanation because although it is true that he answered "yes" to the question regarding detention, he also gave a response to the sub-question requesting details but did not, as mentioned above, refer to having been tortured. This leads me to believe that the claimant was never arrested or tortured as he claims and that his story was simply invented for the purpose of his claim for refugee protection.
In her arguments, counsel for the claimant pointed out that the interview notes were not retranslated for the claimant and that we do not know in what form the questions were asked or what the claimant's exact response was, therefore suggesting that the notes may contain errors. I reject this argument for more than one reason. First, those documents were disclosed to the claimant well before the hearing. If he had noticed errors or inaccuracies as he claims, he was free to have the interpreter, the immigration officer or both summoned to testify in order to re-establish the facts, but he did not feel it necessary to do so. Second, in this particular case, the officer's notes are in English. The claimant was therefore able to understand them without an interpreter: at question 11 on his PIF, he stated that he spoke Punjabi, and at question 12 asking "What other languages or dialects do you speak and understand?", he answered "English". Further, at the end of his PIF, after signing the document, he signed the statement reading: "I declare that I am able to read English and that I fully understand the entire content of this form." This means that the claimant acknowledges that he speaks and understands English. Therefore, if he had noticed errors as he claims, he could have made this known well before arriving at the hearing. I therefore reject this argument.
In addition, the claimant stated that his family had had to move because of the situation, leaving Bathinda to settle in Barnala as of XXXXX, 2003. However, he produced a series of documents contradicting this statement. He filed Exhibit R-10, allegedly an affidavit from his father confirming that he had indeed been arrested and tortured. However, in this document, dated February 25, 2004, his father states that he lives in Bathinda. When confronted about this, the claimant stated that his father had gone to Bathinda only to prepare this document. This explanation does not hold because, as I have already indicated, the father states that he is living in Bathinda. The claimant then gave another explanation, stating that his father had written Bathinda because they have a house in that city. I reject this explanation as well because the issue was not whether the family owned a house in Bathinda but whether they live there. Therefore, on this point, Exhibit R-10 contradicts the claimant.
It should be noted that the claimant produced a number of documents in support of his claim, in particular Exhibit R-10 and another affidavit (also filed under R-10) from a municipal councillor in Bathinda. I attach no probative value to this document since it only repeats the claimant's story, which I have already stated is not credible.
That being said, I find that the claimant has not established that there is a reasonable chance that he would be persecuted should he return to his country. With regard to section 97(1)(a) and (b) of the Act, it should be noted that the claimant submitted no particular evidence on this point, confining himself to the story he related in his PIF, which I have already stated is not credible.
DECISION
Consequently, the Refugee Protection Division determines that XXXXX is not a refugee or a person in need of protection. I therefore reject his claim for refugee protection.
