INTERLOCUTORY DECISION - File MA3-05452
In this file, Counsel objected to the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) hearing proceeding by way of videoconferencing. Counsel argued that the Board unilaterally decided to select claimants from certain countries to have their cases heard through videoconferencing from the Toronto office to Montreal. Counsel raised an objection on the constitutionality of videoconferencing. The required notice respected the RPD rule 48, and therefore, the Panel gave the appropriate time to Counsel to make written submissions as well as the representative from the Ministry of Justice to submit arguments. The panel then took the file under reserve and examined all arguments presented in order to rule on this objection.
The Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB) has statutory duty to proceed informally quickly and fairly.
Section 162 (2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) provides that "Each Division shall deal with all proceedings before it as informally and quickly as the circumstances and considerations of fairness and justice permit".
The claimants were present in the Toronto IRB office with their Counsel. The member and the interpreter are from the Montreal IRB. The Board has stated that the reason for proceeding in some cases by videoconferencing is the reduction of the Board's unprecedented backlog of cases in Toronto, and an increase in average processing times. The Board has had to use all means at its disposal and has had to find more effective ways to manage its national caseload. All three of the Immigration and Refugee Board's Divisions have experience in conducting their hearings by videoconferencing and have done so for a variety of reasons including operational necessity. The Board is therefore relying on its statutory authority to hear cases by videoconference and on the decision of the Federal Court in Gonzalez1 (2002, FCT-1229, November 28, 2002), which "approved of the hearing of refugee claims by videoconference". Videoconferencing is one of the tools put at the RPD disposal as per section 164 of the Act.
Given the backlog in files in Toronto, the Board chose selected files to be transferred by choosing specific countries, based on a number of factors, such as the number of claims in the Toronto inventory for a given country and the operational capacity of the receiving office to have those claims heard; familiarity of the receiving office with claims from the country concerned; the language associated with the country concerned, and the need for and availability of related interpreters in the receiving office, as well as the geographic teams in the Toronto office that had the highest inventories.
The Board member can decide that in exceptional circumstances, a videoconference can be unfair for unaccompanied minors, for the mentally incompetent, for detainees, and for other complex cases, such as ones requiring the presence of minister's counsel. However, in this particular case, there is no evidence that such exceptional circumstances exist. The panel therefore overrules Counsel's objections for the following reasons.
The RPD rule 59 (2)(f) obliges Counsel to provide a summary of legal arguments to be raised. The legal arguments presented by Counsel were related to discrimination based on nationality, section 15 of the Charter. Counsel argued that the claimants to be heard by videoconference are chosen by specific countries, and therefore on nationality, and although the Board states that this policy is based on neutral administrative factors without any intent to be discriminatory, the impact is discriminatory based on nationality.
The Panel believes that although selecting certain cases by nationality for videoconferencing may constitute differential treatment, it is not treatment which is discriminatory for the purposes of Section 15 (1) of the Charter as interpreted by Canadian courts. In the Andrews2 case, the Supreme Court of Canada held that not all distinctions or differential treatment in the law amount to discrimination. Discrimination may be described as a distinction, whether intentional or not, but based on grounds relating to personal characteristics of the individual or group, which has the effect on imposing burdens, obligations or disadvantages on such individual or group not imposed upon others, or which withholds or limits access to opportunities, benefits and advantages available to other members of society.
Counsel's Charter argument is based on the idea that claimants coming from other countries who have hearings in person enjoy an advantage over claimants from those countries that are selected to proceed by videoconferencing. The panel refers to the Act which clearly indicates that both ways are allowed by statute and valid in the absence of exceptional circumstances as stated above and either way claimants receive a fair hearing without disadvantaging those that are heard by videoconferencing.
The Supreme Court, in the Law3 case, built upon Andrews and other cases that followed to articulate the proper approach to analyzing claims of discrimination under Section 15(1). Justice Iacobucci stated, "It may be said that the purpose of Section 15(1) is to prevent the violation of essential human dignity and freedom through the imposition of and disadvantage of stereotyping or political or social prejudice, and to promote a society in which all persons enjoy equal recognition at law, as human beings, or as members of Canadian society, equally capable and equally deserving of concerned respect and consideration. Legislation which effects differential treatment between individuals or groups will violate this fundamental purpose, where those who are subject to differential treatment fall within one or more enumerated or analogous grounds, and where the differential treatment reflects the stereotypical application of presumed group or personal characteristics or otherwise has the effect of perpetuating or promoting the view that the individual is less capable or less worthy of recognition or value as a human being or as a member of Canadian society. Alternatively, differential treatment will not likely constitute discrimination within the purpose of Section 15(1), where it does not violate the human dignity or freedom of a person or group in this way..."
It is the member's belief that videoconferencing, although it may constitute differential treatment, it is not treatment which is discriminatory under the Andrews test of disadvantage or the Law test, which adds the element of violating human dignity. Videoconferencing does not impose a burden or disadvantage on the people whose cases are heard by this means. Videoconferencing, although it is not identical to an in person hearing, does not disadvantage the claimant such that Section 15 of the Charter would be engaged. The claimant still has a full and fair hearing and there is no unfairness in selecting claims from a particular country to be heard by videoconferencing. The Board had to take into account the context of the overburdening caseload in Toronto that obliged them to select cases to be heard by means of videoconferencing. The reasonable person would also realize that the criteria used to choose which countries to transfer for hearing are similar to those used to allocate cases to teams. On a balance of probabilities, this would lead a reasonable person to conclude that although the selection was done on the basis of country of origin for administrative purposes, there is no reason to feel that his dignity as a national of a particular country was being demeaned.
Furthermore, Canadian courts have determined that the requirements for procedural fairness are met and that a hearing by videoconference does not substantially differ from a hearing in person.
The videoconference procedure .... allows the witness to be brought electronically into the Court where the Court has the opportunity to hear and see the evidence as it is given and to control the evidentiary process while it is taking place. The witness is live before the Court and the Court is live before the witness. R. v. Dix (1998) 125 C.C.C. (3d) 377 (Alberta Court of Queen's Bench)
The evidence (by videoconference) had all the features of evidence given in court except for the actual presence of the witnesses (...). There was nothing about the manner in which the witnesses testified that suggested that the remote location of the Court and the mode by which the evidence was being taken had any influence upon them. Bradley v. Bradley (1999) B.C.J. No. 2116 (B.C. Supreme Court)
Although every claimant has a right to a hearing, the Act does not give or entitle one to a hearing in any particular region or in front of any particular member. Each case is decided on its own merits. Variance in acceptance rates can be due to a number of different factors on which Counsel argues in her submissions. In order to prove that cases were being decided unfairly, the claimant would have to show that the difference in acceptance rates could not be justified by differences in the merits of the claims heard, which is not the case in Counsel's submissions.
With respect to Counsel's argument that a hearing by videoconference is not in accordance with the principles of fundamental justice, and thus violates Section 7 of the Charter, the Panel believes that a hearing held by videoconference is an oral hearing which provides the claimant with the opportunity to state his case and to know the case he has to meet. This complies with the standards set out in Singh4, whereby the Panel believes that there is no denial of natural justice and/or procedural fairness in hearing a claim by videoconference.
The Supreme Court in Singh sets out the requirements of fundamental justice in the context of a refugee hearing. They are that the refugee claimant has an adequate opportunity to state his case and to know the case he or she has to meet given the nature of the fundamental right in question "security of the person" this means an oral hearing. In a videoconference, the claimant does have the opportunity to state his or her case and to know the case he or she has to meet, he can see, hear and comment on the evidence presented and he has the opportunity to respond to any concerns expressed by the decision-maker. The claimant is in front of the decision-maker in all relevant respects, particularly in that the videoconference is held in real time, so there is direct communication among all participants. In brief, it has all the essential elements of an oral hearing.
What is ultimately important is fairness, and the fact that the law or its application could be even better does not invalidate a provision which meets the requirements of fairness. The Panel refers to the Lyons5 decision from which the following is quoted: "It seems to me that section 7 of the Charter entitles the Appellant to a fair hearing. It does not entitle him to the most favourable procedures that could possibly be imagined."
With respect to Section 7 of the Charter being infringed by the use of videoconference hearings, the Panel notes that in the Singh decision, the Supreme Court held that in the context of a refugee hearing, Section 7 of the Charter on "security of the person" is engaged. Justice Wilson found that the fundamental justice required that there be an adequate opportunity for a refugee claimant to state his case and to know the case he has to meet. Both requirements are met whether the hearing is held in the presence of the claimant or by means of videoconferencing.
With respect to the argument that the Charter right to a fair hearing is of greater importance than administrative convenience, the Panel believes that a hearing by videoconference is a fair hearing. As noted in the Toronto registrar's letter of February 23, 2004, the Board has a statutory obligation to hear cases as expeditiously as possible. In Pillai6, it was stated that the Board is the master of its own procedure. It is required by Section 68 (2) of the Immigration Act, now IRPA Section 162(2), to deal with proceedings before it as informally and expeditiously as the circumstances and the considerations of fairness permit. At paragraph 26, the Court said: "It is required to strike a balance between expeditious proceedings on the one hand, and procedural fairness or natural justice on the other".
Counsel argued that credibility cannot be properly evaluated if the claimant is not physically present before the decision maker and therefore, the claimant does not get the benefit of a full and fair hearing. The Panel believes that credibility can be adequately assessed by videoconference. Canadian case law on the subject indicates that an adequate assessment of credibility can be made by videoconference. The Panel refers to the decision of R. v. Gibson7, indicating that videoconferencing was entirely acceptable and that the claimant could clearly be seen and observed, including his facial expressions and body language. Furthermore, it indicates that on balance, the use of video technology will not preclude a fair trial and will not in any way impede the right to make full answer and defence.
(...)the (...) video link was entirely acceptable. I could clearly see and observe the witness (...) including her facial expressions and her body language. In fact, I would go so far as to say that a well-placed camera may accentuate the expressions of a witness under cross-examination. (...) I am satisfied that the use of video technology will not preclude a fair trial and will not in any way impede the right to make full answer and defence. R. v. Gibson (2003) B.C.J. No. 812 (B.C. Supreme Court)
In the decision of Bradley v.Bradley8, it is indicated that videoconferencing had all the features of evidence given in court except for the actual presence of the witnesses. There was nothing about the manner in which the witness testified that suggested that the remote location of the court and the mode by which the evidence was being taken had any influence upon him.
In R. v. Heynen, it is indicated that there was no breach of any principles of fundamental justice, the use of video testimony enhanced the capacity of the court to evaluate testimony. There was no significant difficulty in evaluating testimony but rather the judge found several advantages such as camera angles and close-up views, in many respects, enhanced the ability to evaluate demeanour.
(...) In some respects, the use of video testimony enhanced the capacity of the Court to evaluate testimony. (...) I found no significant difficulty in evaluating testimony, but rather noted several advantages. Camera angles and close-up views, in many respects, enhance the ability to evaluate demeanour. R. v. Heynen (2000) Y.J. No.6 (Yukon Territorial Court).
In Gonzalez versus M.E.I, which is the only Canadian case dealing with a refugee claimant being heard by videoconference, it was argued that videoconferences did not accurately assess the demeanour of the claimant. The court rejected this argument, finding that videoconference did not adversely affect the procedural fairness owed by the Board to the claimant
Counsel argued that videoconferencing can impact on the claimant's level of comfort in presenting his or her case, and therefore, it should not be used. The Panel believes that it is not possible to state as a general rule that claimants are less comfortable with a hearing held by videoconference rather than in person hearing. As stated in the Toronto registrar's letter, "Circumstances may exist that would render a case not appropriate for videoconferencing. If Counsel has reason to object to the holding of a videoconference in a particular case, he can request an in person hearing". This is however decided by the member on a case by case basis. If Counsel does not feel that a videoconference will serve the best interests of his client, Counsel and claimant also have the option of going to the regions where the hearing will be held to appear in person. In this particular case, there is neither an affidavit from the claimant nor any psychological report documenting any fear or attesting to how his stress and discomfort would prevent him from having a fair hearing. There is no evidence upon which the Panel could conclude that to hold a hearing by videoconference would be unfair.
With respect to the claimant's expressed surprise at the purported lack of clarity of picture and sound at the previous videoconference hearing, this is in contradiction to what he said at the hearing, that he could see and hear the interpreter perfectly well. Neither the claimant nor the Counsel expressed any concern about the quality of the picture or the sound at the first sitting.
The Panel wants to underline that in a videoconference hearing as also in an in person hearing, claimants enjoy the right to, a) have a real time hearing before the decision maker, b) to adduce oral and documentary evidence in support of their claim in the hearing, c) access the assistance of Counsel to advance their claim, d) access an interpreter if they cannot speak English or French, e) have a designated representative appointed to aid them in advancing their claim if the circumstances warrant it, f) call evidence from other witnesses in support of their claim, and g) receive written reasons if the claim is rejected. These entitlements enable the claimants in videoconference and in person hearings an adequate opportunity to state their case and to know the case to be met as required by Singh. The claimant and Counsel have not shown that holding a videoconference hearing undermines these key elements of the oral hearing.
Counsel argued that for claims referred to the Toronto offices, claimants do not agree with the administrative process to transfer. The IRPA however, under Section 164, authorizes the Board to conduct its hearings by means of live telecommunication without consent. The Board also has control of its own procedures as a quasi-judicial administrative tribunal. Cases such as Prassad v. MEI, Cota Alfredo Barajas v. MCI, and Gorodiskiy Volodomir v. MCI have confirmed this point of law.
There is also compelling public interest in Canada in having refugee status determined as soon as it practically is possible after a claim is made. This is confirmed in the decision of Seth9 v. Canada. Furthermore, the IRB has experience in conducting its hearings by videoconference. All three of its divisions have conducted hearings by videoconference for various reasons, including operational necessity. The Federal Court has approved of the hearing of Convention refugee claims by videoconference in the decision of Gonzalez José Ciprian Gonzalez v. MCI.
Counsel argued that the claimants do not trust the technology or has concerns about the reliability and confidentiality. On this issue, the Panel wants to stress that the IRB has many years of experience in conducting its hearings by videoconference. Videoconferencing has been a widely used and successful technology that has been used by the Immigration and Refugee Board. Any attempt to tap into point to point ISDN videoconferencing (the system that the Immigration and Refuge Board use) terminates the videoconference. This therefore allows the RPD hearings by videoconference a measure of security and confidentiality.
In conclusion, the claimants have not shown that having their claim heard through a videoconference hearing would constitute a serious violation of their human dignity, and therefore constitute discrimination in the substantive sense. The claimants have not shown that the hearing of their claim by videoconference infringes their Section 7 or 15 of the Charter of Rights. The Panel concludes that none of the arguments raised by Counsel in this case, establish that the claimants will suffer any substantial prejudice or that the fairness of their hearing will be compromised by proceeding by way of videoconference. The panel therefore overrules Counsel's objection and will reconvene the hearing to continue on the merits of the case.

INTERLOCUTORY DECISION ON OBJECTIONS
TO HEARING BY VIDEOCONFERENCE
Section 162(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (the Act) provides that "Each Division shall deal with all proceedings before it as informally and quickly as the circumstances and the considerations of fairness and natural justice permit." Thus, the Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB) has a statutory duty to act simply (informally), quickly and fairly. It must use all means at its disposal to fulfill this obligation.
The Refugee Protection Division (RPD) is facing a difficult situation. With a disproportion in the volume of claims between RPD offices, more particularly, an unprecedented workload concentrated in Toronto, and an increase in average processing times, the RPD has had to find more effective ways to manage its national caseload. One tool at its disposal is found in section 164 of the Act. It authorizes the Board to conduct hearings "by means of live telecommunication". Hearing claims by videoconference has improved the RPD's ability to address the challenges it is facing and to deliver on its public commitment to hear claims simply, quickly, and fairly.
The Immigration and Refugee Board has experience in conducting its hearings by videoconference. All three of its divisions have conducted hearings by videoconference for various reasons including operational necessity. The Federal Court has approved of the hearing of Convention refugee claims by videoconference: Gonzales, Jose Ciprian v. M.C.I. (F.C.T.D. no. IMM-2005-01), MacKay, November 28, 2002; 2002 FCT 1229
In face of the Board's clear authority to conduct hearings by videoconference, counsel has raised a number of arguments against proceeding in this way. Although the Board recognizes that there are circumstances in which videoconferencing should not be used, such circumstances do not exist in this case. I overrule counsel's objections for the reasons that follow.
I will deal first with the argument that selecting cases to be heard by videoconference on the basis of the country of origin constitutes discrimination based on nationality and is prohibited by section 15 of the Charter. Since the 1989 Andrews decision, the Supreme Court of Canada has followed an analytical approach to equality rights cases. This approach includes the determination of whether differential treatment constitutes discrimination within the meaning of s.15(1). What is relevant to respond to counsel's argument in this case is that distinctions are discriminatory only if they have a negative effect, such as imposing a burden, obligation or disadvantage; or limiting access to opportunities, benefits or advantages available to other members of society. Counsel's Charter argument is premised on the idea that claimants from other countries who have hearings in person enjoy an advantage over claimants from those countries selected for hearings by videoconference. This tribunal considers that both ways of proceeding are allowed by the Act and, in the absence of exceptional circumstances, are equally valid. There is no unfairness in selecting claims from a particular country, in this instance, Nigeria, to be heard by videoconference. Canadian courts have found that the requirements of procedural fairness are met and that a hearing by videoconference does not substantially differ from a hearing in person.
The videoconference procedure [...] allows the witness to be brought electronically into the Court where the Court has the opportunity to hear and see the evidence as it is given and to control the evidentiary process while it is taking place. The witness is live before the Court and the Court is live before the witness. R. v. Dix (1998) 125 C.C.C. (3d) 377 (Alberta Court of Queen's Bench)
The evidence [by videoconference] had all the features of evidence given in court except for the actual presence of the witnesses.[...] There was nothing about the manner in which the witnesses testified that suggested that the remote location of the court and the mode by which the evidence was being taken had any influence upon them. Bradley v. Bradley [1999] B.C.J. No. 2116 (B.C. Supreme Court)
Counsel contends that a hearing by videoconference does not satisfy the court's intent in the Singh decision, which calls for an oral hearing. In Singh, it was held that the procedure for determining refugee status was inconsistent with the requirements of fundamental justice because the procedure set up by the Immigration Act did not provide the claimant with an adequate opportunity to state his case or to know the case he had to meet. The Refugee Status Advisory Committee made a recommendation to the Minister on the basis of a transcript of the claimant's examination under oath. The claimant was given no opportunity comment on recommendation given to the Minister. In response to this ground for objecting, I point out that whether the claimant is present in the same room as the member or appearing by videoconferencing, the claimant does have an oral hearing before an RPD member, can see and hear and comment on the evidence presented and has the opportunity to respond to any concerns expressed by the decision-maker.
Counsel submits that as part of its evaluation of credibility, the Board must be able to evaluate the claimant's demeanour and that there can be no serious assessment of demeanour by video. Canadian case law does not support the view that demeanour cannot be assessed in a hearing held by means of videoconference. At least two cases have commented that videoconferencing can be better than actual presence :
[...] the [...] video link was entirely acceptable. I could clearly see and observe the witness [...] including her facial expressions and her body language. In fact, I would go so far as to say that a well-placed camera may accentuate the expressions of a witness under cross-examination. [...] I am satisfied that the use of video technology will not preclude a fair trial and will not in any way impede the right to make full answer and defence. R. v. Gibson [2003] B.C.J. No. 812 (B.C. Supreme Court)
[...] In some respects, the use of video testimony enhanced the capacity of the court to evaluate testimony. [...] I found no significant difficulty in evaluating testimony, but rather noted several advantages. Camera angles and close-up views, in many respects, enhance the ability to evaluate demeanour. R. v. Heynen [2000] Y.J. No. 6 (Yukon Territorial Court)
Counsel has also suggested that the selection of certain countries to be transferred to other cities may not have been done on the basis of objective criteria or in good faith. The choice of which files to transfer falls squarely within the tribunal's right to be master of its own process. It must take into consideration a number of factors that are relevant to its statutory obligation to deal with proceedings simply, quickly and fairly. Among those factors would be the specialisation of the members in the regions receiving transferred files. The RPD operates on the basis of geographic specialisation because refugee determination requires developed familiarity with country conditions. Members develop expertise dealing with a certain region or group of countries. For this reason it is appropriate to transfer blocks of files where members have geographic expertise - i.e. all from same country.
Counsel argues that the claimant did not consent to being heard by videoconference. However, unlike section 165 of the Canadian Criminal Code, or Rule 1.08 (2) of Ontario's Rules of Civil Procedure, the use of videoconferencing is not contingent upon the consent of the person concerned. By enacting section 164 of the Act, Parliament explicitly conferred discretion on the Division to choose between a hearing in the presence of the subject of the proceedings or by means of live telecommunication such as videoconferencing. Consent of the person concerned is not required.
Counsel has further argued that the claimant speaks with a marked Nigerian accent, which would be significant when it came to communication and comprehension of his testimony. Whether the claimant was testifying in person or by videoconference would not change his accent. If his testimony is not comprehensible due to his accent, an interpreter may be required. If the accent is just difficult to understand at times, whether he is attending in person or by video, he may be asked to repeat some parts of his testimony. The claimant will suffer no prejudice because his case is heard by videoconference.
None of the arguments raised has established that the claimant will suffer any substantial prejudice or that the fairness of his hearing will be compromised by proceeding by way of videoconference. As I indicated earlier, the objection is overruled and the hearing will continue.

These are the reasons for decision with respect to the claims for refugee protection of XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, a citizen of Costa Rica who was born on XXXXX, 1979, and her son, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, who was born on XXXXX, 1997, and for whom she was appointed the designated representative.
The claimants alleged that they are persons in need of protection as well as Convention refugees under sections 96 and 97(1) of the Act.
Basically, the adult claimant alleged the following in her answer to question 41 of her Personal Information Form (PIF).
She met XXXXX XXXXX in XXXXX 2001 and, in XXXXX 2001, moved with him into a house owned by his mother. XXXXX was jealous from the very beginning. His jealously quickly escalated, and it became so bad that in XXXXX 2002 she decided to leave this man who had become violent and who called her a whore, hit, slapped, shoved and pushed her, dragged her on the ground and even raped her three times while they were living as spouses.
XXXXX stubbornly refused to accept their breakup. He hounded her, harassing her directly and through third parties.
On XXXXX, 2002, the claimant, who could not stand the telephone harassment any longer, went to the police station (XXXXX) of XXXXX, where, she said:
[Translation] I filed a complaint. My complaint did not accuse anyone in particular, even XXXXX. I did not mention him even though I was convinced he was behind this. I was afraid he and the people who made the calls would harm me. That is why I asked that my telephone line be monitored and I requested protection for myself and for my child. However, an intervention order was never made.
On XXXXX, 2002, while the claimant was coming back from work, XXXXX attacked her and then forced her to get into his vehicle. Driving at high speed, he crashed into a pole while coming out of a dangerous curve. The claimant was taken to the XXXXX XXXXX hospital to undergo tests and receive the care she needed.
The claimant continued by stating:
[Translation] After that incident, I decided not to report him.
XXXXX would not let go and continued harassing the claimant by telephone. After losing three jobs in a row and moving six times to escape this man, she was attacked again on XXXXX, 2003. She decided not to follow the advice of a witness to the scene, who urged her to report XXXXX.
Informed by a teacher at her child's school that a man claiming to be a close relative had come and asked to see her son, she decided to take the child out of school on XXXXX. After describing all these difficulties and horrors to an acquaintance of her father's uncle, who lived in Canada, she took his advice that she exile herself to Canada, where she could obtain protection.
The claimant fears returning to Costa Rica, her country of citizenship.
IDENTITY AND CITIZENSHIP
The identity and citizenship of the claimants have been established through reliable documents to which the panel attaches probative value, namely the passports issued to them by the Costa Rican authorities.
ANALYSIS
The consideration and analysis of this claim for refugee protection raise a determinative issue: is there adequate protection for the claimants in Costa Rica?
After reviewing the facts and the adult claimant's testimony and written evidence, it became clear to the panel that the adult claimant did not file any formal complaint with the authorities against her assailant, XXXXX XXXXX, despite all the suffering he put her through. Although she was raped three times, viciously attacked for the first time on XXXXX, 2002 and then another time on XXXXX, 2003, and beaten the entire time they lived together, she never filed a complaint against XXXXX XXXXX. According to what she said, she filed only a vague complaint seeking to have her telephone line monitored to expose those threatening to retaliate against her if she did not go back to live with XXXXX XXXXX, whom she deliberately did not accuse even though she knew he was behind all the telephone threats. In passing, the panel would like to note that, during her testimony, the claimant contradicted her PIF by saying that she had stated in her complaint that the originator of the threats was her former boyfriend, XXXXX XXXXX. When confronted about this contradiction relating to the only complaint she had allegedly filed, the claimant gave the panel no explanation. When asked to adduce in evidence a copy of her alleged complaint, she said that her mother had been unable to obtain a copy from the authorities because it was a personal document. With all due respect, the panel cannot accept such an explanation, since the complaint did not belong to the police themselves but to their police records, which means that a copy could have been obtained simply by making a request, supported, if necessary, by an authorization from the claimant.
Three rapes, six moves and the loss of three jobs due to the behaviour of her assailant, XXXXX XXXXX, did not manage to convince the claimant to lay a complaint or to seek help or assistance from the police or a women's rights organization in Costa Rica because, according to her, protection in that country takes a long time to obtain and is unreliable. She also feared that XXXXX would be imprisoned for two months and then get out of jail, kill her and commit suicide: this became her excuse for not availing herself of the protection of the Costa Rican authorities. It is appropriate to compare this excuse to the documentary evidence to determine whether it is convincing and has some basis.
The panel asked the claimant to explain to the panel how she had had the courage to report threatening telephone calls even though she knew that XXXXX XXXXX was behind them and knew that the complaint might lead to reprisals against her if it resulted in his arrest, even though she had not expressly mentioned that the originator of the calls was none other than her assailant, XXXXX XXXXX. This strikes us as inconsistent. The claim that her life and that of her child were her only motivation for not laying a complaint against XXXXX does not hold up, since, in either case, she laid herself open to retaliation by XXXXX by filing a complaint. When asked to dispel any doubts about this inconsistency, the claimant contradicted her PIF by stating that she had expressly mentioned XXXXX name in her complaint.
When the panel mentioned to the existence of resources that provide help and assistance to victims of domestic violence in Costa Rica, the claimant immediately stated that she had not gone to see any advocacy groups for women who are victims of spousal abuse.
From a review of the claimant's testimony, the panel is compelled to find that she deliberately cut herself off from the help and assistance the Costa Rican authorities make available to victims of domestic violence in that country. She did not bother to find out about the real effectiveness and professionalism of which the Costa Rican police and other advocacy groups for women who are victims of spousal abuse are capable.
A review of the documentary evidence concerning Costa Rica, and specifically the evidence on violence against women versus the quality of the protection available in Costa Rica, compels the panel to find as follows.
From every point of view, Costa Rica is a free and democratic country. This finding is confirmed by the Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for 2002,1 which stated:
Costa Rica is a longstanding, stable, constitutional democracy with a unicameral legislative assembly directly elected in free multiparty elections every four years. . . . The judiciary was generally independent.
Generally, this document described Costa Rica's human rights situation as follows:
The government generally respected the human rights of its citizens, and the law and judiciary provided effective means of dealing with individual instances of abuse; however, there were problems in a few areas. There were some instances of physical abuse by police and prison guards, and the judicial system processed some criminal cases very slowly, resulting in lengthy pre-trial detention for some persons charged with crimes.
The Country Reports stated as follows with respect to violence:
Domestic violence was a serious problem, and traditional patterns of unequal opportunity for women remained, despite continuing government and media efforts to advocate change.
More specifically, the Country Reports described the situation of women as follows:
The government identified domestic violence against women and children as a serious societal problem. The national institute for women (Inamu), an autonomous institution created in 1998 that is dedicated to gender equality, received 63,990 calls on its domestic abuse hot line from January through October. During this same period, Inamu counselled 4,097 female victims of abuse in its San Jose office and accepted 194 women in Inamu-run shelters. Inamu maintained 41 offices in municipalities around the country and had trained personnel working in 32 of the country's 81 cantons.
The office of the special prosecutor for domestic violence and sexual crimes prosecuted 448 cases related to domestic violence during the year, compared with 456 cases in 2001. Inamu reported that 24 women were killed in incidents of domestic violence during the year, compared with 11 in 2001.
The 1996 law against domestic violence establishes precautionary measures to help victims. At year's end, the legislative assembly was still debating a bill to qualify violence against women as a crime, which would classify certain acts of domestic violence as crimes and mandate their prosecution, whether or not the victim pursued charges against the perpetrator. The authorities incorporated training on handling domestic violence cases into the basic training course for new police personnel. The domestic violence law requires public hospitals to report cases of domestic violence against women. It also denies the perpetrator possession of the family home in favour of the victim. Television coverage of this issue increased in news reporting, public service announcements, and feature programs. Reports of violence against women increased, possibly reflecting a greater willingness of victims to report abuses rather than an actual increase in instances of violence against women.
Other documents included in the documentary evidence provide a list of organizations whose mission it is to advance the situation of women in Costa Rica. The list of organizations found in the documentary evidence2 stated the following in its introduction:
The following list of organizations dealing with the advancement of women and gender equity in Costa Rica was taken from the website of the directory of national organizations in charge of policies and programs for women in Latin America and the Caribbean (Directorio de organismos nacionales a cargo de las políticas y programas para las mujeres de américa latina y caribe). The list is comprised of organizations active in the promotion of women's rights in 1998.
Instituto nacional de las mujeres (national women's institute)
The institute is an autonomous governmental entity. It was formerly called the national centre for the development of women and the family (Centro nacional para el desarrollo de la mujer y la familia, cmf).
Objectives:
To define and promote national policy for gender equality and equity;
To defend the rights of women;
To promote equality of the sexes;
To act as coordinator and to ensure that government bodies establish and implement a national policy for gender equality and equity;
To promote the full participation of women in social, political, cultural and economic life.
Delegación de la mujer agredida (women's delegation)
It is accountable to the ministry of government in coordination with the national women's institute.
Objectives and functions:
Free help for women who have suffered physical, psychological and sexual violence, reception and processing of complaints, official protection, legal, psychological and medical assistance and referral to hostels.
Defensoría de la mujer (office of women's affairs)
It is accountable to the office of public defence (defensoría de los habitantes) and the ministry of justice and pardon (ministerio de justicia y gracia).
Objectives and functions:
To protect, extend and promote the rights and interests of women against violations, restrictions and discrimination arising from the actions or omissions of the public authorities; and
To help eliminate discrimination against women by protecting and extending their rights.
The same documentary evidence stated:
In addition to the main activities mentioned above for the national women's institute, the Tico Times reports that the institute's national plan for the attention and prevention of domestic violence (planovi) operates two shelters for abused women in Cartago and San José (6 Aug. 1999). In one of its reports, la nación provided a list of resources in Costa Rica that offer services to victims of sexual violence (6 June 1999). They include the phone number of an emergency help line, which is 800-300-3000; the women's delegation (delegación de la mujer), which can be reached at 222-7372 or 222-7533; offices for women's affairs in the municipalities of Alajuela, Goicoechea, Moravia, San Carlos Puntarenas and Paquera (there are 32 such offices in the country, however, not all of them are specialized in domestic violence training); social work offices in hospitals and clinics of the Costa Rican social security office (Caja Costarricense de Seguro Social); and the family court (Juzgado de familia) or mixed court (Juzgado mixto) to which the victim should file a complaint.
Another la nación report adds that the emergency help line called "breaking the silence" (rompamos el silencio) provides relevant information to the person calling, including legal orientation and emotion support, while maintaining anonymity (3 Jan. 1999). This emergency help line is staffed by 30 female volunteers and is coordinated by the "mujer no estás sola" ("woman is not alone") program of the non-governmental organization feminist centre of information and action (centro feminista de información y acción, cefemina). The women's delegation, in addition to the activities mentioned above, also provides follow-up with women's complaints related to sexual violence and will accompany them through the judicial process.
Another initiative responding to violence against women in Costa Rica is a project financially supported by the Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA) that would facilitate the Universities of Toronto and Western Ontario in providing assistance for the University of Costa Rica "to develop human resources in domestic violence prevention and intervention" (Canadian Newswire, February 25, 1999). The resources allocated to this project, which will run for five years, will help the university of Costa Rica "train, for example, teachers, students, court personnel, and journalists, in how to respond to the problem of domestic violence."
The following information on the services and activities of the office of women's affairs within the ombudsman's office (Defensoría de los habitantes) is in addition to that mentioned above and is provided in the office's 1997-1998 annual report.
With regards to domestic violence, the office carried out training sessions on the contents and application of the law against domestic violence within the public sector, and educated public servants in overcoming the myths and stereotypes that serve as obstacles to the application of this law. Furthermore, while this law mandated the office to monitor the actions and irregularities of state officials or institutions (sujetos públicos), the office had treated every case of domestic violence brought before it and had provided women with assistance in the preparation of making a request for protection measures through the appropriate channels (vía jurisdiccional).
The office continued to develop training initiatives for groups of women with emphasis on the issues that contribute to the cycle of violence, the importance of self-esteem and the legal channels available to victims of violence.
With regards to sexual harassment, the office wanted to organize conferences and workshops with persons, who, because of their position in the workplace, would be able to promote and disseminate the law against sexual harassment in employment and teaching (Ley contra el hostigamiento sexual en el empleo y la docencia). To that end, the office established an informal agreement with the public education ministry to facilitate the training of civil servants who were in charge of managing the application of this law and its internal regulation in the various educational institutions in the country.
In terms of domestic violence statistics, la nación states that the women's delegation (Delegación de la mujer) received 12,231 complaints from January 1998 to December 22, 1998, 46 more than in the previous year. Furthermore, according to the women's delegation, the number of domestic violence cases reported and phone calls made to the emergency help line tended to increase during the Christmas holiday season (la nación January 3, 1999). One of the help-line operators stated that the increase in complaints made by women could be attributed to a greater consumption of alcohol by men.
In 1999, according to the national women's institute, there has been an increase in the number of cases of violence against women reported, as well as an increase in the number of women calling the emergency help line (la nación 10 Nov. 1999). As of 31 October 1999, the help line had received 8,729 calls, an increase from the total of 8,640 received in 1998. Of the 4,210 cases of violence against women processed by the women's delegation between January and October 1999, 2,188 were new ones. The numbers are expected to increase in the months of November and December because potential aggressors are likely to spend more time in the home and consume more alcohol. The national women's institute reports that 20 women had died as a result of aggression against them in 1999, 16 of whom were killed by their spouse or partner. At least 8 of the 20 women were on a list of passionate or conjugal homicides (Homicidos pasionales o conyugales) being investigated by the judicial investigations body (Organismo de investigación judicial, oij).
This description of the situation of women facing violence in Costa Rica would be incomplete if the dimension added by another response to information request3 were not noted. It stated:
A summary of the 1996 law on domestic violence includes reference to psychological aggression by a spouse or domestic partner, but only refers to police intervention at the home where the aggression takes place and the authority to expel aggressors from the home.
Earlier, the executive submitted to congress another bill to increase the number of courts that could handle cases of domestic violence, and requested congress members to approve one of the above-mentioned bills that would penalize physical, sexual, economic and psychological aggression against women (Proyecto de ley que penaliza la agresión física, sexual, psicológica y patrimonial en contra de las mujeres).
A 1999 report on the shortcomings of the law on domestic violence refers to obstacles in the legal process for effective conclusion of some cases, lack of training among many policemen, and the capability of police to expel an aggressor from the home. The report cites the example of women who were killed by their former spouse or partner while travelling on a bus from work, and the case of a woman who repeatedly received threats from her estranged husband, with police not responding to the majority of her calls.
In terms of the tools available to women who are victims of violence, the panel might add (even if this remedy was not one chosen by the claimant) that there is a divorce law allowing spouses to end their relationship once and for all.
The domestic violence act, passed in 1996,4 established preventive measures to help victims of domestic violence, who can go to see a police officer or judge and ask to keep their home and exclude their spouse, to have firearms seized, to be paid support and to have child custody suspended. The law also required hospitals that admit battered women to report cases of violence, and there are television advertising campaigns and special broadcasts on domestic violence.
The national women's institute, an independent organization that deals with women who are victims of violence, has 41 offices in the various municipalities of Costa Rica, with staff who have been specially trained to meet needs in 32 of the country's 81 cantons. There are shelters for victims of spousal abuse in which women and their children can take refuge.
The panel is compelled to note that Costa Rica, which already has a free, impartial and fair judicial system, has provided that system with a budget and measures to reduce violence against women and to ensure better protection for victims of such violence. Not only have the Costa Rican authorities, through the minister for the status of women, expressed their willingness to support the search for solutions to violence against women, but they are also making laudable and significant efforts to this end.
The issue of state protection, which is a determinative one in this case, must be assessed in light of the principles established by the superior courts, which this panel would like to briefly mention.
In Ward,5 the Supreme Court of Canada examined the issue of state protection. The principle established by the Court is that, except in situations of complete breakdown of the state apparatus, it should be presumed that a state is capable of protecting its citizens. This presumption can be rebutted only through "clear and convincing" proof of the inability of the country in question to protect its citizens.
The learned Hugessen J.A. added the following in Villafranca:6
No government that makes any claim to democratic values or protection of human rights can guarantee the protection of all of its citizens at all times. Thus, it is not enough for a claimant merely to show that his government has not always been effective at protecting persons in his particular situation. . . .7
In a unanimous judgment by the Federal Court of Appeal, and I am referring here to Minal Kadenko,8 the Honourable Décary J.A., writing for the Court to address a certified question about protection by the state of Israel, noted the following:
When the state in question is a democratic state, as in the case at bar [Israel], the claimant must do more than simply show that he or she went to see some members of the police force and that his or her efforts were unsuccessful. The burden of proof that rests on the claimant is, in a way, directly proportional to the level of democracy in the state in question: the more democratic the state's institutions, the more the claimant must have done to exhaust all the courses of action open to him or her.
In another case,9 Heneghan J. stated that claimants must show that they took all reasonable steps, given the situation in the country of origin in general, and must prove the steps they did in fact take, as well as their relationship with the authorities.
The superior courts tell us that claimants are first required to pursue the courses of action available in their country before availing themselves of international protection. This does not mean, however, that they are required to do anything that it would be objectively unreasonable for them to do in seeking protection from their country of citizenship. Thus, they do not have to go so far as to endanger their own life10 or jeopardize their safety by pursuing courses of action that would be pointless in the circumstances.
As regards the quality and level of protection available within a state, it cannot be expected that a state will guarantee the protection of its citizens at all times. Nor does protection have to be perfect. Where a state is in effective control of its territory, has civil and police authorities in place and makes serious efforts to protect its citizens, the mere fact that it is not always successful in doing so will not be enough to justify a claim that victims are unable to avail themselves of such protection.11 The standard of protection is that of adequate protection, the Federal Court of Appeal having held that protection must be "adequate, though not necessarily perfect."12
In light of the principles established by the case law and the situation that exists in Costa Rica with respect to state protection from domestic violence, the panel finds that Costa Rica, a country that is recognized to be free and democratic, is presumed to be capable of protecting its citizens. It is up to the claimant to rebut this presumption through clear and convincing proof of the inability of the Costa Rican state to protect her.
The panel's finding about the existence of adequate protection for victims of domestic violence in Costa Rica was recently endorsed by the Federal Court in Arguedas, Maricela Los Angeles Alfaro, et al. v. C.I.C., in which the Honourable Lemieux J. concluded as follows:
A review of the state apparatus in Costa Rica in relation to the problem of domestic violence meets the standards required for state protection in by refugee law. The tribunal enumerated those elements in its reasons.
The claimant left her country before the state had even had an opportunity to demonstrate its ability to protect her and the reliability of the tools available to her for that purpose. By limiting herself to her belief that protection takes a long time to obtain and is unreliable, without really trying to verify whether what she believed was true, and by refusing to lay a complaint against XXXXX each time the opportunity arose, the claimant turned her back on the justice system. The words of the learned McKeon J. are applicable here:
The relevant evidence to determine this issue would include the documentary evidence and the personal circumstances of the claimant. The claimant's own subjective feelings on state protection would, however, not be a relevant factor.13
It seems clear to the panel that the claimant did not attempt to avail herself of all the services offered to her in Costa Rica. She closed her eyes to all the measures designed to provide safety and peace of mind to victims of spousal abuse in Costa Rica, measures that make it possible to conclude that there is adequate protection14 for victims of domestic violence in that country.
On the question of state protection, in a recent case (Medina v. Canada),15 the Federal Court, per the Honourable O'Reilly J., stated the following at paragraphs 7, 10 and 11 of its judgment:
?7? Applicants for refugee protection must show that state protection was not available to them, or that it would be unreasonable in the circumstances to expect them to have sought it out. States are presumed to be in a position to protect their citizens, unless applicants prove otherwise: Canada (Attorney General) v. Ward, ?1993? 2 S.C.R. 689. The question, then, is whether Mr. Medina's evidence should have persuaded the Board that state protection was not available to him, or that it was unreasonable to expect him to have tried to obtain it under the circumstances.
. . .
?10? On balance, however, the Board concluded that Mr. Medina should have tried to obtain protection from the authorities because there was at least some assistance available in El Salvador. It said it believed that "if he returns to El Salvador, [he] has a responsibility, if he is again threatened by gang members or other criminals, to report these incidents to the police and that protection could be obtained."
?11? Mr. Medina provided no evidence that other persons in his situation sought and failed to obtain state protection. Nor did he show that he had tried and failed to get state protection. In this situation, "the claim should fail, as nations should be presumed capable of protecting their citizens," Ward, above at p. 725.
Once again, the panel notes that responsibility for providing international protection becomes binding only when national or state protection cannot be provided to a claimant. International protection is surrogate protection.16 It follows that the claimant's first obligation was to give priority to Costa Rican solutions to her problem before claiming international protection in the way she did.
The claimant did not provide clear and convincing proof that the Costa Rican state is incapable of protecting its citizens. The burden was on her to rebut the presumption that the state can protect both her and her son. The claimant did not discharge this burden.
After reviewing the facts, the documentary evidence, the circumstances of the case and the Chairperson's guidelines on women who claim refugee protection on gender-related grounds,17 this panel determines that there is adequate protection for victims of violence in Costa Rica and that the claimants have not shown through clear and convincing evidence that the Costa Rican state would be unwilling or unable to adequately protect them if they returned to their country of citizenship.
DECISION
For all these reasons, the panel determines that the claimants, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, and her minor son, XXXXX XXXXXX XXXXXXX, are not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection pursuant to section 96 and subsection 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
Accordingly, the panel rejects their claims for refugee protection.

ORAL REASONS
These are the reasons for decision in the case of Ms. XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, citizen of Somalia, and her minor, XXXXXXXXXX, citizen of the United States of America, who asked for Canada's protection pursuant to Sections 961 and 97(1)2 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
Ms. XXXXXXXXXXXXX was appointed as designated representative for her minor son.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant alleges that her father, who was a businessman in Mogadishu, was killed in 1991, when the civil war in Somalia started. Both the claimant's parents and the claimant herself are from the minority Brava tribe. The claimant's mother, together with her, fled Mogadishu and went to Brava, a city where most of the Bravas lived. Her mother tried to make a living for herself and her daughter. However, she passed away in 1997, due to an illness, and the claimant was left alone.
The claimant started living with a friend of her mother, a single woman with three children. The economical situation was difficult, and the woman started abusing the claimant and telling her that she should go out and sell her body in order to bring money for food.
The claimant wanted to leave Somalia, but did not really have a way out, until she met a person who was ready to buy properties belonging to her father. However, the claimant did not sell those properties for money, she did so in exchange of a promise to take her to the United States. Following the transaction, the man took the claimant first to Mombassa, and then, via Malaysia, to the United States.
Upon her arrival in the United States, the claimant applied for refugee status, which was denied to her, as well as her appeal from that decision. In the meantime, the claimant met a man in the United States, whom she married in a religious Muslim ceremony. However, he was not able to sponsor her, nor to formally marry her, because he was not yet officially divorced from his first wife.
The claimant came to Canada in XXXXX 2003, and at the border, asked for refugee protection.
Should she go back to her country, the claimant is afraid that she will be in danger of rape or other physical abuse or even death, as a young single woman from the minority Brava tribe without any family protection. As for her son, the claimant stated that he does not have any fear of persecution or any other fear in the United States. The son, as I mentioned before, is a citizen of the United States.
ANALYSIS
We have asked the claimant several questions concerning the reasons for her leaving Somalia. She answered in a spontaneous, direct way. Although she was quite young at that time, she was able to give very coherent and plausible explanations. She explained her situation clearly, without hesitations. She was also able to explain the situation of her clan or how she can be recognized as a member of the Brava tribe. I found her testimony particularly credible.
In order to establish her identity, the claimant was not able to present any direct identity documents from Somalia, but she obtained the passports of her father and her mother, as well as an old photo of her parents. She also explained in a credible way how she was able to obtain those passports. There is a striking physical resemblance between the woman on the old photo and the claimant. There is no doubt that the woman on the photo and in one of the passports is the claimant's mother. We also have on file a few affidavits from Canadian citizens and permanent residents, who confirm that they knew the claimant and her parents in Somalia, and that she is from the Brava clan. Also, her testimony concerning her tribe was very credible.
The claimant was questioned about why she was refused in the United States. She did not present the decision which she had received. She said that she would try to obtain that decision if required; however, she explained that she was refused, being considered as a victim of the war and not a person targeted for persecution, which is also plausible. So I decided to give her the benefit of the doubt on this point and to accept her testimony concerning the reasons of her refusal by the United States as plausible.
Concerning the fear of return and objective documentary evidence concerning the Brava tribe, we can read in the UK Assessment3 that:
"The Benadiri ?...? and Bravanese (people long established in the city of Brava, believed to be of mixed Arab, Portuguese and other descent), suffered particularly badly at the hands of armed militia and bandits as their home areas were fought over by the competing USC factions and the SPM. USC/SNA forces in particular singled out the Benadiri and Bravanese, with a campaign of systematic rape of women."
Further down, this information is also confirmed in another paragraph of the same document, which quotes the report of a British-Danish fact-finding mission in May 2002 (Exhibit A-114), which suggests that:
"?...? Bravanese have mostly fled from the coastal town of Brava, although some are still living in the town, which is controlled by the Habr Gedir. Information suggested that Bravanese who remained faced abuses forced labour, sexual slavery and general intimidation."
The documentary evidence also confirms that women, particularly from the minority clans, who do not have male protection, are vulnerable in Somalia, particularly in the areas where the civil war is still raging. We can read in the same UK Assessment, under paragraph 6.105, that:
"Most vulnerable have been women who have been internally displaced within Somalia, who have lacked the protection of powerful clan structures, and those from minority clans and ethnic minorities."
As for the general situation in Somalia, although it seems that the civil war ended in the north of the country, the Somaliland, with some kind of semblance of government there, the situation in the south, in Mogadishu and Brava, where the claimant is from, is still very unstable and it is difficult to speak about the existence of a government in these areas.
Considering all the above, I conclude that the claimant, Ms. XXXXXXXXXXX, has established a well-founded fear of persecution as a member of a particular social group (young women without male protection), as well as on the grounds of her nationality (member of the Bravanese clan). She is therefore a "Convention refugee", as per Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
However, this tribunal cannot grant the protection to the claimant's minor son, XXXXX XXXXX, since, as his mother stated, he does not have any fear in the United States. His father lives there, and the United States government is certainly able to offer protection to a minor child.
CONCLUSION
The claim of the minor claimant XXXXXXXXXXX is refused, while the claim of Ms. XXXXXXXXXXXXX is accepted.

I. INTRODUCTION
XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, a 30-year-old citizen of the People's Republic of China, has claimed Convention refugee status on political grounds, alleging that he fears persecution by the authorities. He has also claimed to be a person in need of protection1 on the basis that he would be personally subjected to a danger of torture, to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in China.
II. ALLEGATIONS
The claimant alleged that, from 1997 on, he was part of the village committee for XXXXX in XXXXX, Fujian province. He was a messenger; when he was not passing on messages, he stayed in the committee's office. Over the years, he often saw the committee, along with police officers, take women for abortions at the XXXXX hospital, pursuant to the one-child policy. On XXXXX, 2003, the mother of XXXXX, a neighbour, came to get help from the claimant. XXXXX XXXXX was expecting her third child, and the committee was guarding her at its offices. That evening, the claimant released her. The next day, he admitted what he had done. He was ordered to bring the fugitive back within three days. He left XXXXX on XXXXX, 2003, and China shortly thereafter.
III. DETERMINATION
The Refugee Protection Division is of the opinion that there are serious reasons to believe that the provisions of paragraph 1F(a) of the Refugee Convention must be applied in this case. This means that, as set out in section 98 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX is not a Convention refugee2 or a person in need of protection.
IV. ANALYSIS
Exclusion
1. The claimant described the enforcement of the one-child policy. If a woman's first child was a girl, she had to wait four to five years to have a second child. Even if the second child was a girl, the family could not have a third child. A third pregnancy led to abortion, which was forced if not done voluntarily. If the woman gave birth in another province, the third child was not registered in the family record book of Fujian province.
2. The claimant described his duties as a messenger for the village committee of XXXXX in XXXXX district, XXXXX city, Fujian province. If there was a fight in the village, he was responsible for advising the antagonists to stop, as well as arresting, detaining and questioning them and reporting the incident to the village leader. The claimant added that the village leader was actually the one responsible for conducting interrogations. If he considered it necessary, he asked for help from the police, whose station was half an hour from the village. The youngest committee member, the claimant stayed at the office, took telephone calls and did the cleaning. While the leader conducted interrogations, the claimant boiled water to make tea. When a storm was announced, it was up to him to notify the villagers by putting up signs. The claimant also played a role as a guard.
3. The claimant described his role as a guard. When a woman was pregnant for the second time, after having a boy, or the third time otherwise, she was brought to the office. There was a small cell in the office. The guard guarded her for two hours; there was a rotation every two hours. If the women fled, her husband was detained. The claimant said that the only people arrested pursuant to the policy in 2003 were the couple involved in his story. It is this couple, whom the claimant testified that he had released, who are the source of his problems.
4. The claimant said that he did this work from 1997 to 2003. When asked whether he had detained women in 2002 for the purpose of abortion, he initially said that he had not. But when asked the question again, he answered in the affirmative, saying that some women had been arrested. However, he said he did not remember how many were arrested in 2002, since it was so many years ago. He was asked how many women had been arrested while he was performing this job, that is, from 1997 to 2003. He answered that there had been about 10. He explained that there had been 10 monitors in the village. When one of them learned that a woman was pregnant, he reported this to the village leader, who decided whether the woman had to be arrested. When asked whether he had been among the 10, the claimant said that he had not, that he had always stayed at the office to take calls and that he had not been present for the arrests, which he said were very dangerous to the women's health. A little later, however, he did admit that he had also been one of the people who made inquiries. It would even be more accurate to say that he was forced to admit that he himself had been among the 10, but, he insisted again, the 10 were responsible mainly for security and, as the youngest, he stayed at the office.
The difficulty the claimant had in dissociating himself from the other informers, who were members of the village committee, instead supports the argument that, as a committee member, the claimant behaved like the others. The only thing he did not admit was whether he himself had also reported any pregnant women who were violating the one-child policy.
5. The claimant admitted that, from 1997 to 2003, he had guarded eight or nine women at the committee's office before they were taken to XXXXX for abortions. He did his two hours of guard duty before being replaced. He admitted that he had guarded the same person more than once, in other words, that he could come back on duty and have to guard the same person again before she was taken to XXXXX. Although he denied being one of those who went to arrest pregnant women or took them to have their abortions, he did participate directly in the process by guarding imprisoned women until they were taken to undergo forced abortions.3
6. The claimant explained that, because he was younger, he had been relegated to the committee's office while the other committee members took women to XXXXX to obtain abortions. He was at the bottom of the hierarchy. The claimant was rather ambiguous about the question of whether he had wanted to rise in this hierarchy so he could leave the office and accompany his colleagues taking women to XXXXX. After acknowledging that there was some prestige involved in being able to escort women to the hospital, he said no when asked whether he had wished to be part of the hierarchy so he could take the women himself, but he stated that those at a low level had to stay at the office. Despite a few weak denials, the claimant did not really oppose the one-child policy or the role of the committee, of which he was a member, in applying that policy. At a minimum, as a member of the group that apprehended women for the purpose of forced abortion, he was, if not a direct participant, at least complicit in carrying out the plan.4 The fact remains that the claimant's thorough knowledge of the committee's functions indicates that he was indeed a member thereof. The panel therefore finds that the claimant's testimony about the duties he performed is credible.
7. The claimant alleged that he had released one of the women and that this was the cause of his problems. The panel does not consider it necessary to look at the inconsistencies and contradictions brought out by the testimony. That said, the claimant alleged that he had freed one of the incarcerated women. Despite the claimant's lack of credibility as regards the woman, or the woman and her husband, whom he allegedly released, the panel finds that the claimant has acknowledged that he was in a position that enabled him to release at least one of the women who were supposed to have a forced abortion. It seems obvious to the panel that he never did so. No doubt his job would have been affected if he had. He might even have had to leave his village. However, it must be noted that the claimant never put forward a defence of duress.
8. The claimant's counsel argued that applying the one-child policy was not the village committee's only function. This is true. However, knowingly participating on more than one occasion in the enforcement of this policy, which may be reasonable in theory but which is horrible in its application, cannot be accepted. Even thinking about its application is repulsive to anyone who considers what it involves. Its application is contrary to international principles and standards relating to human dignity and rights. Article 3 of the Declaration of Human Rights states that everyone has the right to life, liberty and security of person. Article 5 states that no one shall be subjected to torture or to cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Yet this is what the claimant participated in when he guarded imprisoned women who were to undergo abortions.
Moreover, the Supreme Court of Canada has described forced sterilization as a practice that is clearly contrary to Canada's human rights obligations.5 In this respect, the panel finds that, if forced sterilization is considered brutal, it has no choice but to consider forced abortion to be a similar act with a similar impact, in accordance with international instruments, particularly Article 7-1(g) and (k) of the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Tribunal:
Article 7: Crimes against humanity
1. For the purpose of this Statute, "crime against humanity" means any of the following acts when committed as part of a widespread or systematic attack directed against any civilian population, with knowledge of the attack:
. . .
(g) Rape, sexual slavery, enforced prostitution, forced pregnancy, enforced sterilization, or any other form of sexual violence of comparable gravity;
. . .
(k) Other inhumane acts of a similar character intentionally causing great suffering, or serious injury to body or to mental or physical health.
The panel's interpretation of paragraph 7-1(g) is based on the history of the provision, which originated in the Draft Code of 1954,6 which tried to codify the principles derived from the Nuremberg trials, the charters7 of which are recognized as one of the sources of the definition of crimes against humanity.
Inclusion
During the hearing, credibility questions raised in relation to matters central to the claim were not satisfactorily answered. However, since the panel determines that the claimant should be excluded, it will not deal with them in these reasons.
V. CONCLUSION
The panel determines that, through his acts, namely guarding women who were going to undergo forced abortions because of their opposition to such a practice, the claimant was complicit in crimes against humanity. In the panel's view, if a person who was complicit in forced abortion were not excluded from Canada's protection, this would outrage the Canadian public. The panel therefore determines that the claimant is excluded under paragraph 1F(a) of the Convention.
