These are the reasons for decision with respect to the claim for refugee protection of XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, a 27-year-old citizen of Peru. He alleged that he has a well-founded fear of persecution in his country of origin because of his sexual orientation and his membership in a particular social group, namely homosexual minorities who are persecuted in Peru. He also alleged that he would be personally subjected to a danger of torture, to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if he had to return to Peru.
ALLEGED FACTS
The evidence in this case, as presented by the claimant, his counsel and the refugee protection officer (RPO), is made up of the following: the claimant's Personal Information Form (PIF), oral evidence, identity documents and personal papers, as well as documents on the socio-political and human-rights situation in Peru. The claimant's PIF and oral evidence revealed the following facts:
The claimant was born in the city of Lima, where he lived his entire life. In his PIF, he stated that he attended school for 16 years, including a year of university studies in XXXXX, and that he has had four different jobs since December 2000, including one in the United States, where he lived from XXXXX 2000 to XXXXX 2001. He stated that he is single and that he began living publicly as a homosexual in Peru in XXXXX 2002.
The claimant based his claim for refugee protection essentially on the fact that his neighbours near his home and his fellow students - whom he identified by name at the start of the hearing - harassed and attacked him because of his homosexuality. The claimant testified that his problems had begun in XXXXX 2000, when he was beaten by a group of homophobic students from the university he attended. He was advised to leave the country, so he went for five months - from XXXXX 2000 to XXXXX 2001 - to live in the United States, where he was able to work in Miami. However, he did not seek the protection of authorities there because of their refusal, he said, to grant refugee protection on the basis of sexual orientation and, above all, because of the violence and discrimination that exist everywhere in the United States.
The claimant returned voluntarily to Peru, where, in XXXXX 2002, he ended up deciding to live openly as a homosexual. Driven out of the family home by his intolerant father, the claimant began life as part of a homosexual couple for the first time when he lived with a certain XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX from XXXXX 2002 to XXXXX 2003. During that period, people from their neighbourhood attacked the couple twice, on XXXXX and XXXXX, 2002; as a result, the claimant had to be hospitalized for three days, from XXXXX to XXX, 2002, at the XXXXX clinic. After each attack, the claimant and his partner went to a police station, where no one would listen to them and where they were even dismissed off-handedly with the threat that they would be detained for "immoral conduct." The couple ended up separating in XXXXX 2003.
In XXXXX 2003, the claimant began another homosexual relationship with a certain XXXXX XXXXX, which lasted until mid- XXXXX 2003. During that period, homophobic individuals attacked the new couple while they were strolling hand in hand in a park on XXXXX, 2003. The claimant and his partner notified a police officer who was on the scene, but, rather than helping them, he took them to the station, where they were put in a cell for a few hours because of their "immoral conduct." On XXXXX, 2003, neighbours came to their home and, after savagely attacking them, told them to leave the neighbourhood. The claimant and his partner had to be hospitalized for a few days, again at the XXXXX clinic, because of the attack. In the meanwhile, the claimant lost his job twice despite approaching the ministry of labour, where officials did not want to hear what he had to say.
In such a context, the claimant flew out of Peru on XXXXX, 2003, and landed in New York the next day. He then travelled by road the same day to the Canadian border at Lacolle, where, as soon as he arrived, he expressed his intention to claim refugee protection. He said that he feared for his life if he had to return to Peru, where he would again be harassed and attacked, not only by the neighbours and students who had already harassed him but also by Peruvian society, which is largely homophobic, including the security forces. In his opinion, the Peruvian authorities were unable to provide him with adequate protection.
These, in substance, are the facts brought to the panel's attention by the claimant, the only person who testified in this case. The panel must decide whether he is a Convention refugee1 and/or a person in need of protection,2 based on the criteria established in sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
ANALYSIS
After thoroughly analysing all the evidence, both testimonial and documentary, the panel finds that the claimant has discharged his burden of proving that he would be personally subjected to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if he had to return to his country. The panel's reasons are as follows:
Having had an opportunity to observe the claimant's behaviour, the panel notes that, on the whole, he testified directly and spontaneously, without exaggerating. The panel does not find any significant discrepancies between his testimony and his previous statements, whether in his PIF or at the port of entry. He filed in evidence medical certificates and notarized affidavits, which seemed to confirm several of the facts he referred to in his testimony. There is, of course, the fact that the claimant voluntarily returned to his country of persecution in XXXXX 2001, but his explanations were not unreasonable. The panel has no reason to doubt that the claimant is homosexual, and it has decided to give him the benefit of the doubt as to the possibility that he was persecuted in his country because of his homosexual orientation.
What remains to be determined is whether the claimant would be at risk if he returned to his country of origin. The most recent documents seem to indicate that the Peruvian authorities are not yet able to provide adequate protection to sexual minorities. A very recent report by the U.S. Department of State on human-rights practices in Peru contained the following passage:
On April 22 (2003), the Front for the Right to be Different, a gay rights group, began a campaign to amend the Constitution so that it would forbid discrimination against people for their sexual orientation. Homosexuals face strong discrimination, and most preferred to remain anonymous for fear of social sanctions from their families and by society in general.3
Moreover, Andrew Reding, an expert on sexual minorities in Latin America, recently published a wide-ranging study on the status of homosexuals in North American countries. The part of his study concerning Peru contained the following significant passages:
Though there are no longer any laws explicitly prohibiting sexual activity between civilians of the same sex, authorities frequently invoke vague laws aiming to uphold "public morality" as a tool to repress sexual "deviance". Moreover, Section 269 of the Military Penal Code of 1988 provides for penalties ranging from 20 days to 20 years in jail for "dishonorable acts of carnal knowledge against the order of nature."
The Lima Homosexual Movement (Movimiento Homosexual de Lima, MHOL) was founded in 1983. But Peru's first gay pride parade was not held until 2002, when a scant few hundred marchers braved Lima's hostile atmosphere. Marchers wore masks to hide their identities as they bore signs saying "we want to be visible, but intolerance suppresses us."4
Finally, the Board's Documentation Centre has produced a number of questions and answers on the status of homosexuals in Peru. The most significant passages are as follows:
Whilst homosexuality is legal in Peru persecution of gays and lesbians does still occur. For example there are periodic raids on gay bars and clubs. In 1996 such raids led to 600 arrests.
Notwithstanding this there is a surprisingly active gay scene centred in Lima. There are over 10 clubs and bars, 3 saunas and even 4 gay hotels. In 1997 Peru had its first gay parade and there are several LGBT organisations including the Homosexual Movement of Lima (MHOL), founded in 1983.
...Homosexual acts, in private and between consenting adults, are not illegal. Laws referring to "public morality" however are often used against gays and lesbians. The Constitution and numerous other pieces of legislation include anti-discrimination provisions, but none refer to sexual orientation specifically. Gays are banned from the armed forces and the police (GayTimes 2003).5
Lima apparently has a relatively small gay community for a city of 8 million people. ... The gay scene is much smaller than Buenos Aires, Sao Paulo, Rio de Janeiro, or Bogotá and about the same as Santiago. Also, the gay scene here is so well-hidden that when I first came to Lima in 1997 it appeared there was no gay community here at all. ...
Although Lima has become a little more liberal in the last few years bear in mind that Peru generally still has a macho and conservative culture. ... [H]omosexuality continues to be viewed negatively so adjust your behaviour accordingly and keep a low profile in public. Acceptance will only be achieved slowly and by not provoking reactionary elements (9 May 2002).6
There are no specific legal protection measures for homosexuals in Peru. Despite Constitutional articles that declare every person equal under the law, in practice homosexuals are subject to a variety of abuses by police authorities. Although there is no legal provision outlawing or penalizing homosexuality in Peru, police authorities penalize some homosexual behaviours by considering them transgressions against morality and good traditions, as specified in Article 450 of the Peruvian Penal Code. . . .
Although homosexual men and women are not targets of violence because of their sexual orientation, they do face expulsion from their homes and from their work, can be detained by police for extortion or intimidation, can be slandered and, particularly in recent times, the news media describe persons as homosexuals to denigrate or ruin their lives. . . .
In Peru, homosexuality is associated with prostitution, drugs, sex, depravity and scandal, among other things. This is a reason why many homosexuals prefer not to be open about their homosexuality. Hiding their sexual orientation has been the way many homosexuals avoid societal discrimination and homophobia, and gain access to public or private employment.7
In light of these extracts from the independent documentary evidence, it seems obvious to the panel that, for the moment, homosexuals who want to live openly as such in Peru are at risk in every part of the country.
Before concluding, the panel should make clear that the claimant's identity documents entered into evidence are acceptable, so that the panel has no doubts about his identity.
CONCLUSION
The panel finds that the evidence with respect to the most important points of this claim for refugee protection is sufficient to establish that there is a reasonable chance the claimant would be personally subjected to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if he returned to Peru. For this reason, the panel determines that the claimant, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, is a person in need of protection. His claim for refugee protection is therefore accepted.

The claimant, Mr. XXXXXXXXXXX, is a citizen of Indonesia. He claimed refugee protection pursuant to sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (the Act).
SUMMARY OF ALLEGATIONS (as they appear in the Personal Information Form)
The claimant is Protestant. He showed compassion and patience for XXXXXXXXXX, a man who used to extort money. As a result of the claimant's attitude, XXXXXXXX stopped transgressing the law. Both men became friends. In XXXXX 2001, the claimant "evangelised" his new friend and gave him spiritual guidance through weekly church attendance and involvement in social activities. Muslims who learned of this turn of events disapproved.
On XXXXX, 2002, XXXXX XXXXX decided to convert to Christianity. Members of Jemaah Islamiah (JI) threatened to kill the claimant. On XXXXX, 2003, members of JI threw stones at the claimant's kiosque, burnt his car and waved their weapons, threatening to kill him. He escaped from the back door of his kiosque.
The following day, when he went to report the incident to the police, the latter saw nothing wrong in what happened to him. On XXXXX, 2002, he fled to Jakarta. Three days later, he left Indonesia and arrived in the USA.
Nineteen months later, on XXXXX, 2003, he arrived in Canada and applied for protection.
DETERMINATION
The panel determines that the claimant is neither a "Convention refugee"1 nor a "person in need of protection"2.
ANALYSIS
The panel considers that the claimant's passport3 seized by Citizenship and Immigration Canada is a sufficient proof of his identity.
The claimant alleged that he feared the JI. Despite repeated questions, he was unable to tell who the JI is or what its activities are. The panel is of the opinion that a thirty-three-year-old person with twelve years of education should be able to describe the alleged agent of persecution seeking to kill him. Consequently, the claimant's credibility is adversely affected.
The claimant testified that when he reported an alleged attack on his store on XXXXX, 2002, the police told him that such an incident had already taken place and he had to accept it. He was asked again and again to repeat what the police told him. He stated that a policeman said to him that he was an infidel; this is what the JI do in the area and he was "too brave to teach Christianity to a member of the JI" and nothing else. Yet, he indicated in his narrative that the police told him that according to the Islamic law, it was proper and normal for him to be stoned to death, which makes the police no better than the people who supposedly attacked him. Pressed to explain this inconsistency, he answered that the police thought that it was normal because he is an infidel and he was too brave. Then, he argued that he mentioned what his narrative contains. He finally replied that the JI said that he deserved to be stoned to death. His failure to address the inconsistency erodes his credibility.
During his hearing, the claimant affirmed that XXXXX XXXXX was a member of the JI. He was asked why he omitted this allegation in his written statement. He responded that he was sorry, he made a mistake. The panel does not accept this response since if the person who sought conversion from Islam to the Protestant faith, was a member of a reputed militant Islamic group4, his story takes on a greater dimension. Furthermore, he omitted to mention in his oral testimony the allegation in his narrative that on XXXXX, 2002, JI assailants swore to kill him. He replied he was sorry. Finally, he did not mention in his narrative that since his departure from his hometown to the present time, members of his family and his friends have been questioned about his whereabouts by the JI. He explained that he forgot. These omissions reflect negatively on his credibility.
The claimant submitted a one-page police report5 to corroborate the attack on XXXXX, 2002. He said that he reported that the assailants were from the JI and this is mentioned in the police report. It was pointed out to him that it is not mentioned. He responded that it was not because the police is afraid of the JI. This shows how easy it was for the claimant to contradict himself and justify his last version of events. Consequently, the panel does not find him to be credible.
The claimant was advised that according to his written statement, he was brushed away by the police when he went to report the XXXXX, 2002 attack. Without the police report, one would never imagine in reading his written statement, that the police had made a report. He had no comment to offer. Moreover, according to his narrative, the JI attackers on XXXXX, 2002, threw stones at his store while in testimony, he alleged that they ransacked his store, destroyed his merchandise, walls, equipment, including his show window and fence door. He replied he was sorry he did not write that down. Consequently, the panel grants no probative value to the police report and does not find the claimant to be credible.
The claimant was confronted with Schedule 16 in which he indicated:
"Someone tried to kill me. A man named XXXXX tried to kill me. He wants money from me to buy alcohol. Sometimes I give it to him, sometimes I do not. When I do not give him money, he threatened me. He said if I do not give him money, that he will kill me. This happened in XXXXX 2002."
He explained that he was nervous when he arrived at the Canadian border and he could not concentrate on what he experienced before. In the panel's opinion, this is not a valid justification for giving a version of events which is in no way consistent with his written and oral testimony. Consequently, the panel does not believe that he faced problems in Indonesia as alleged and his whole story is a fabrication.
The claimant testified that he had a US visitor's visa since the year 2000 and he went to the USA on XXXXX, 2002 "to save himself". He gave a confused description of how someone associated with an Indonesian - Christian association took advantage of him after he gave him money to assist him in seeking asylum in the USA. He first stated that in his opinion, a claim for asylum was filed on his behalf. To follow-up questions, he backtracked. His counsel also commented upon conditions for a claim to be considered as being filed or not. This comment is of no merit since the claimant was simply requested to reveal whether he claimed protection in the USA and he acknowledged that this is what he understood. He was asked why he earlier stated that he was of the opinion that a claim for asylum in the USA was filed and at the same time, in question 36 of his Personal Information Form (PIF), instead of listing all claims for protection or requests for asylum he would have made in any country other than Canada, he put "N/A" (not applicable). He said he did not know. Because of his confusion, change of mind, and inability to provide an explanation, the panel does not believe that he applied for protection in the USA and does not believe that in the nineteen months he spent in the USA, he showed he had a subjective fear.
In order to assess the claimant's risk associated with sections 96 and 97(1) of the Act, the panel carefully took into consideration the general documentation, counsel's submissions as well as relevant case law. It carefully reviewed each and every document, even those dating back to 1998, like Human Rights Watch7 or consisting of an individual opinion8 or coming from a partisan organisation9 which cannot be recognised as independent sources. The panel also noted that according to the Europa World Yearbook 2003, 9,6 % out of a population of two hundred and six million is Christian. Violence against Christians in Indonesia is well documented. Although not satisfactory, the situation of Christians is not hopeless as shown in the following documents:
"Following a sharp drop in violence between Christians and Muslims in the provinces of Maluku, North Maluku, and Central Sulawesi, inter-religious tolerance and cooperation improved during the year. During the first 6 months of the year, many Muslims and Christians in those provinces worked together to repair mosques and churches."10
"After brokering peace accords signed by Christian and Muslim community leaders in the provinces of Maluku, North Maluku and Central Sulawesi, the Government deployed large numbers of troops and police in key conflict areas and encouraged Java-based Islamic extremists to depart. Interreligious violence decreased in all three provinces; the death toll in the Malukus fell by two-thirds. Peaceful conditions prompted many displaced persons to return to their homes (...) The Government made progress in promoting religious freedom by cracking down on terrorists and other extremists who carried out attacks in the name of religion."11
"(...) it was the election of Abdurrahman Wahid as President in October 1999 that many ethnic Chinese first saw some hope for improvement in their situation in Indonesia. (...) The new President was relatively quick to translate his hope into something more concrete when in January 2000 he issued Presidential Decree No.6/2000. The Decree revoked a 1967 law, which prevent the performance of rites and rituals associated with Chinese beliefs and culture outside of the home. Chinese New Year 2000 was therefore celebrated publicly in Indonesia for the first time in over 30 years and significantly, without incident. Many ethnic Chinese therefore entered the year 2000 with great expectations for further improvement in their situation (...) During the recent period, incidents of violence against ethnic Chinese have declined relative to the period preceding it, which included the May 1998 violence (...) There has been progress in Indonesia politics on anti-discrimination, however this has largely remained rhetoric."12
"The general impression among Indonesian specialists is that incidents of specifically anti-Chinese violence have decreased since 1998-1999."13
"According to Human Rights Watch executive director, the police (...) were the poorest trained and poorest paid of any part of the security forces, and were thus not effective as law enforces. (...) In some places, as in Ambon, the police were seen to be from one side of the conflicts, so that there were allegations that the police were supporting the Christians and the army was supporting the Muslims (HRW 24 Oct. 2000)."14
"We praise the adoption of the Chinese New Year or Imlek as a national holiday and the policy to scrap the term that identifies Chinese-Indonesians as non-indigenous people as good signals to develop equality. But there are some basic discriminatory rulings which have not been revoked, while those already annulled remain non-operational (Chinese-Indonesian expert Andrie Wongso told the Jakarta Post on Thursday) (...) Andrie suggested that the government look at Chinese-Indonesians here as an asset for the country who would develop the nation alongside other indigenous people. Manu Chinese-Indonesians want to dedicate themselves like Kwik Kian Gie, State Minister for National Development Planning, but they hesitate due to the discriminatory atmosphere, (he said)"15
"Two men opened fire at a church during the Easter service in an eastern Indonesian town, lightly wounded seven people, including a four-year-old girl, police said on Sunday. (...) Despite the attack, thousands of Christians in Poso, some 1,600 km north-east of Jakarta, flocked to churches in the lakeside town for Easter Sunday masses, Mr Tranggono said, adding hundreds of police had been deployed to secure the services."16
The panel is finally of the opinion that by the mere fact that an Indonesian is of Christian faith is not sufficient to conclude he or she should be given protection. The burden of proof is still on his or her shoulders.
For all the above reasons, the panel does not believe that the claimant provided credible evidence which would establish a possibility of future persecution or risk of harm. Therefore, the panel is of the opinion that there is no serious possibility that he would suffer the harm he alleged should he return to Indonesia. He is neither a "Convention refugee" nor a "person in need of protection".
CONCLUSION
The claimant of Mr. XXXXX XXXXX is rejected.

XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX and her minor son, XXXXXXXXXXXXXX XXXXX, are citizens of Angola and Portugal. They are claiming to be Convention refugees and persons in need of protection within the meaning of sections 961 and 97(1)2 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
Ms. XXXXX XXXXX was appointed as the designated representative of her minor child.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant, aged 24, and her son, aged 5, were born in Angola. The claimant's father, a Portuguese citizen, passed away in 1980. The claimant's mother, an Angolan citizen who was Portuguese by marriage, passed away in 1990.
Since the claimant no longer had any family, she stayed with her mother's boss, XXXXX XXXXX and his wife, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, both of whom are Portuguese. The claimant and her mother had been living with the XXXXX because the claimant's mother was their housekeeper. Despite her young age, the claimant replaced her mother as the housekeeper when her mother died. She had to quit school at age 14 to look after her adoptive mother (identified as such after her mother died) when she became ill. Her bosses abused her, and when she managed to escape, she would seek refuge with a female friend, with whom she began a clandestine romantic relationship.
In January 1998, the claimant admitted to her adoptive parents that she was homosexual, which triggered her adoptive father's anger. The claimant was hit again, which required her to stay in bed for two days. The claimant was subsequently raped by Mr. XXXXX who threatened to kill her if she reported him.
The claimant reported her sexual assailant to the police anyway. He was summoned the following day, but after he bribed the police, no charges were laid against him. The claimant was raped again at the end of February 1998, and the following month she discovered she was pregnant. She claimed that she tried to commit suicide with pills, but that Ms. XXXXX came to her rescue and wanted to know who the father of her child was. Mr. XXXXX forced the claimant to say that it was one of his employees, a Mr. XXXXX who was homosexual as well. Mr. XXXXX agreed to give his name to the claimant's child.
Several months later, Ms. XXXXX learned the truth from the neighbours, which resulted in Ms. XXXXX separating from her husband. This separation was short-lived: one month later, Mr. XXXXX came back home because his wife was ill and was financially dependent on him. This illness led the claimant and her bosses to Portugal so that Ms. XXXXX could receive treatment. The claimant's child was entrusted to Mr. XXXXX during their four-month trip to Portugal.
During her stay, the claimant took steps to obtain a Portuguese passport because she was of that nationality by birth, her father being Portuguese. Mr. XXXXX seized this passport when they returned to Angola.
In XXXXX 2003, Ms. XXXXX passed away and her husband turned to alcohol, which resulted in him trying to sexually assault the claimant again. She managed to flee and sought refuge at Mr. XXXXX home. With Mr. XXXXX help, the claimant left Angola on XXXXX, 2004 with her child and a false Portuguese passport. After travelling via Portugal and the United States, she arrived at the border at Lacolle on XXXXX, 2004 and claimed refugee protection.
The claimant submitted that she cannot live in Portugal because Mr. XXXXX being Portuguese, would be able to find her.
DECISION
The panel determines that the claimants are not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection for the reasons set out below.
ANALYSIS
To establish her identity, the claimant filed an identity card issued by the Portuguese Republic (Exhibit P-2), which was seized by Immigration Canada. The panel has a certified true copy on file (Exhibit A-2). Regarding the minor claimant, a personal book issued by the Republic of Angola (Exhibit P-3) was filed, also seized by Immigration Canada (Exhibit A-2). The panel finds that the claimants provided acceptable documents establishing their identities within the meaning of section 106 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
To start, the panel wishes to point out that the claimant testified that she had travelled with a false passport between Angola and Portugal when she went to that country in XXXXX 2003 with her adoptive parents. She stated that this was because of the urgency of their departure in light of Ms. XXXXX health condition. The claimant stated that she returned to Angola with her identity card and Portuguese passport, issued in her name (Exhibits P-2 and A-2), during her stay. However, since Mr. XXXXX had confiscated this passport, according to the claimant, she had travelled with her son to the United States using a false Portuguese passport that did not contain her name or her photo. She stated that when she arrived in New York, she threw away, under no force or duress, all her travel documents, including her passport, allegedly simply at the direction of Mr. XXXXX who was still in Angola. Needless to say, that act deprived the panel of important, relevant documents that could at least have corroborated the claimant's testimony that it was indeed Angola that she had left, and not Portugal or some other country, to come to Canada via the United States, with false travel documents.3
The claimant testified to being a citizen of Angola and also of Portugal by birth, since her father had been Portuguese. Her parents had approached the Portuguese authorities when she was born to obtain citizenship for her for that country as well. As for her child, the claimant testified that he is Angolan because he was born in Angola and that he is Portuguese as well because the claimant has Portuguese citizenship.
When asked to tell the panel what steps or formalities she had had to complete to have her son granted Portuguese citizenship by the authorities of that country, the claimant answered that she had had to follow the procedure - in other words, go to the Portuguese embassy and submit [translation] "her papers" to prove that she is Portuguese. Therefore, it is a simple formality, and Portuguese officials do not have the discretionary power to deny her child Portuguese citizenship.
The panel believes it is unnecessary and redundant to undertake a lengthy analysis of the credibility of the claimant's testimony, which on several points is not trustworthy, because the panel believes that there is no reasonable chance that the claimant and her son would be persecuted and/or threatened if they were to return to Portugal.
At the start of the hearing, the panel directed that it would first like to hear the evidence concerning the refugee protection claimants' fear of returning to Portugal. The claimant stated that Mr. XXXXX a Portuguese citizen, had family in that country and that it would be easy for him to find them. She claimed that Mr. XXXXX had sworn that he would kill her and her son. During the hearing, the claimant was confronted with the statements she had made at the port of entry, where she had said that she could not seek refuge in Portugal because she did not know anyone there, which is inconsistent with her oral and written testimonies, in which she claimed that it was because Mr. XXXXX would be able to find her there, which is a point she did not bring up when she claimed refugee protection. When asked to explain this, the claimant responded that she had been tired and nervous when she arrived.
When confronted with independent, trustworthy documentary evidence4 indicating that Portugal is a democratic country with an independent legal system and police officers who protect citizens, the claimant gave no response that the panel considered to be reasonable and of use. Since this was a crucial point, the panel restated the question and asked the claimant why she could not go to the Portuguese authorities for assistance and protection. This time, the claimant answered that she had learned from some acquaintances that lesbians and homosexuals were discriminated against in Portugal. Since she had evaded the question, it was repeated for the third and final time. The claimant thought at length and then said that she had decided to come here (to Canada), not there (to Portugal). When asked to explain her answer, the claimant testified that she knew that, in Canada, the government would protect her, whereas in Portugal she did not know this. The claimant was confronted with her written testimony, in which she states that she lived in Portugal for four months; she was then asked what had led her to believe that the authorities in that country would not protect her. Once again, the claimant attempted to evade the question by saying that, during her stay in Portugal, she had seen on the televised news that homosexuals had been assaulted in that country. The question was repeated to her again, this time stressing that she was seeking protection against Mr. XXXXX. The claimant answered [translation] "I don't know".
As to her fear of persecution as a lesbian, the claimant was confronted with the documentary evidence filed as Exhibit A-4,5 which indicates that there is a centre for the gay and lesbian community in Portugal, that homosexuality is not a crime in that country and that homosexuals are not persecuted there either. The claimant again said that, during her stay in Portugal, she had heard on the news that some homosexuals had been assaulted in the streets because society does not accept them. When asked to tell the panel whether, to her knowledge, the police had intervened during the alleged assault, the claimant answered [translation] "I suppose so, but I'm not sure," and added that she had seen on television that the police were there, but that she did not know what had happened after that.
The panel rejects the claimant's explanations as unsatisfactory. The claimant has the responsibility to provide clear and convincing evidence demonstrating that the Portuguese state is unable to protect her.6 Portugal has not experienced a complete breakdown of its state apparatus, and as such, we must assume that the Portuguese state is capable of protecting its nationals. The documentary evidence7 clearly shows that state protection is available and accessible in Portugal. The claimant did not rebut the presumption that she could avail herself of Portuguese state protection. Refugee protection claimants have the obligation to seek the protection of their own country before claiming refugee protection in another country. The panel finds that the Portuguese state is able to protect the claimants, and there is no evidence demonstrating that such protection would be ineffective.
CONCLUSION
After analysing all the evidence, and given the lack of credibility of the claimants, the panel determines that they are not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection.
Moreover, setting aside the evidence found to be not credible, the panel has no other evidence before it, from either the documentation on the country or any other source, that could lead the panel to the conclusion that the claimants are Convention refugees or persons in need of protection.
The panel rejects the refugee protection claim made by XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX and her son, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX.

These are the reasons in support of the decision concerning the claim for refugee protection of XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, a citizen of Costa Rica, who is claiming refugee status on the basis of section 961 and subsection 97(1)2 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).
IDENTITY
The claimant's identity has been reasonably established, as his Costa Rican passport was seized by Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) and a copy was placed on the record.3
ALLEGED FACTS
A reading of the claimant's Personal Information Form (PIF), in particular his answer to question #41, revealed the following facts:
The claimant alleges he is a 36-year-old citizen of Costa Rica, from XXXXX. The Ministry of XXXXX employed him as a XXXXX from 1991 to 2004. He claims to fear being persecuted by homophobic persons in society at large because of his membership in a particular social group, namely, homosexuals.
The claimant also alleges he has been a carrier of the AIDS virus for 11 years. He alleges that, since 2003, he has had problems obtaining the retroviruses needed to treat his condition. At XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX hospital, where the claimant was being treated, the medications were administered to him irregularly.
On April 6, 2004, the claimant participated in a march to denounce this situation, and that is when his colleagues and the XXXXX XXXXX learned of his sexual orientation and that he had AIDS. The claimant was subsequently threatened and pressured by them, with the result that he was unable to work XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX because he risked "infecting" them.
On April 7, 2004, he was barred entry to the XXXXX and was attacked and threatened by his co-workers and his XXXXX XXXXX. He also received telephone calls at his home telling him that his house was going to be burned down. On April 10, 2004, stones were thrown at his house and injurious words were written on the walls. In the circumstances, the claimant left his house at his mother's request to go and live with a friend in XXXXX.
The claimant alleges that after speaking with representatives of the Ministry of XXXXX, he was offered another position as an office worker rather than as a XXXXX. The claimant turned down this offer because he had studied to become a XXXXX, and besides, he claims that his co-workers refused to work with him.
Owing to this discrimination the claimant alleges having suffered in his country, he decided to leave Costa Rica on XXXXX, 2004, for Canada. He made his claim for refugee protection on May 21, 2004.
DETERMINATION
After having analysed both the testimonial and documentary evidence, and after having heard the representations of the refugee protection officer (RPO) and of counsel, the panel determines that the claimant has not shown there would be a "reasonable chance of persecution" were he to return to his country, and is therefore not a "Convention refugee". Nor has he shown that he is a "person in need of protection".
ANALYSIS
The claimant bases his claim on his homosexuality and the fact that he has AIDS, the reason he was persecuted by XXXXX XXXXX, who allegedly threatened his life; and he fears society at large.
He further alleges he is the victim of discrimination, since the retroviruses he needs to treat his AIDS were not administered to him regularly. For all these reasons, he fears returning to his country.
JURISPRUDENTIAL GUIDES
The jurisprudential guides pertaining to criminality and sexual orientation in Costa Rica have been disclosed in this case. The panel believes that the decision of our colleague Schlanger, Decision TA0-15870, applies in this case, since certain facts and the evidence regarding conditions in that country are quite similar to those in the present case.4
The determinative issue in this case is whether the state of Costa Rica can ensure the claimant's protection. In the above-cited decision, extensive analysis was done as to the existence of a thriving homosexual community in Costa Rica and the fact that the community was not the target of systematic persecution by the authorities or by society at large. It also closely perused the documentary evidence pertaining to sexual minorities, the police, mechanisms for lodging complaints of police abuse, recourses for victims of violence and discrimination, and the level of democracy in Costa Rica.
In the case in point, the claimant, who claims to have received death threats on April 7, 2004, from the XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, and to have been attacked at his home on April 10, 2004, when stones were thrown at it and injurious words were written on the walls, never filed a complaint with the police. According to his testimony, he took no steps to do so, because he was afraid he would be asked questions about his sexual orientation and his illness.
As mentioned earlier, in Decision TA0-15870, all recourses available to the claimant were closely perused. If the claimant did indeed receive death threats, it is reasonable to think he would have filed a complaint with the police, particularly as he knew the names of the XXXXX who were threatening him. The panel also notes that if the police officers abused their authority, the claimant could have filed a complaint with the Office of the Ombudsman. In addition to the Ombudsman, there is also the Constitutional Court, which can help protect the rights of sexual minorities if they are threatened. In the above-cited decision, a number of other non-government organizations are mentioned as also providing assistance in protecting the rights of sexual minorities.
The claimant also claims he was the victim of discrimination in the workplace, since his employer told him he could no longer keep his XXXXX position because he had AIDS, but that he was offered another position within the Ministry of XXXXX as an office worker. On this point, at the hearing, the claimant provided many details about the advice he received from the XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX where he XXXXX. He told of receiving a number of telephone calls from her following the incident of April 7, 2004, when a group of XXXXX and colleagues barred his entry to the XXXXX. Yet, in his narrative, the claimant makes no reference to his private conversations with the XXXXX, but instead refers to conversations with representatives of the Ministry of XXXXX. When asked to explain this discrepancy, for any comment, the claimant said it was not important. The panel is of the view that he had the possibility of complaining about the conduct of the Ministry of XXXXX authorities. In fact, in the above-cited decision, it states that a person who has been discriminated in the workplace can file a complaint with the Ministry of Labour. In the present case, the panel notes that the claimant worked at the Ministry of XXXXX since 1988 and was employed by this ministry as a XXXXX from XXXXX 1991 until XXXXX 2004, and his employment was somewhat stable for quite some time. The panel further notes that his employer offered him another position as an office worker, and if the claimant believed he was the victim of discrimination he could have pursued the matter by filing a complaint with the Ministry of Labour.
Finally, the claimant alleges that he was a victim of discrimination because he was occasionally denied the medications he needed to treat his health condition, being infected with the AIDS virus. At the hearing, the claimant provided many details about the medications he was unable to obtain regularly at the hospital where he was being treated, and said this was one of the reasons he was seeking the protection of Canada. However, when the claimant claimed this protection and was examined by an Immigration Canada officer on May 28, 2004, he made no mention of this reason. He spoke of discrimination because of his homosexuality and the fact that he is HIV-positive. The officer continued the examination, asking him if he took "medication," and the claimant said, [translation] "Yes, I take three medications together that cost $600 a month paid for by the government". If the claimant was indeed occasionally denied the retroviruses he needed to treat his medical condition and this was a reason he was claiming refugee protection, it is reasonable to think he would have spontaneously told the officer who interviewed him on May 28, 2004, about the problems related to obtaining his medications. The documentary evidence on the record and quoted below makes no mention of problems with the administration of the medications for carriers of the HIV virus in Costa Rica. In fact, the report of Andrew Reding5 refers to two favourable decisions rendered by the Supreme Court of Costa Rica in favour of people with HIV. Notably, at page 45, we can read as follows:
In 1997, the Costa Rican Supreme Court issued two rulings benefiting persons afflicted with AIDS. In the first, it found that the Calderón Guardia Hospital discriminated illegally against AIDS victims for over 10 years by refusing to provide laboratory services for them. The second ruling directed the Costa Rican Social Security Fund (Caja Costarricense de Seguro Social, CCSS) to provide antiretroviral medications to a psychology graduate student who was ill with AIDS. In its verdict, the court stated that "medical assistance is a duty of the Costa Rican State, derived from the concepts of justice and social solidarity contained in the Constitution, and the mission it assigns to the Costa Rican Social Security Fund." Until that decision, it had been CCSS policy to provide treatment only to pregnant women infected with HIV.
Costa Rica is now the only country in Central America that provides advanced antiretroviral cocktail therapy to all who need it, including foreign residents.
In addition, the panel notes that if the claimant was indeed denied medication, he could have sought a recourse of protection before the Constitutional Court, as noted in the above-cited decision.6
In view of all the above, given the various remedies available to the claimant to deal with the abuse or misconduct of citizens or his employers, the panel does not find the claimant's reasons for his lack of effort to seek state protection to be persuasive, and finds that the claimant should have pursued the options open to him, by reporting the discrimination he suffered to the Ombudsman, the Ministry of Security, the Constitutional Court, or an agency dedicated to protecting homosexuals and lesbians in Costa Rica.
In the present case, the claimant never sought the protection of his country. It was incumbent upon him to overcome the presumption that the authorities were able to protect him. While the situation is not perfect in Costa Rica, this panel cannot conclude that there is clear and convincing evidence that the Costa Rican state would be incapable of protecting the claimant if he had to return to his country.
CONCLUSION
In view of the foregoing, the panel determines that the evidence submitted to it is insufficient to establish that the claimant, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, should he return to his country of origin, Costa Rica, could face persecution on a Convention ground, and that there would be a "serious possibility" of his being subject to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
Accordingly, the panel rejects his claim.

XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, the claimant, is a citizen of Colombia.1 She claims refugee protection pursuant to ss. 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
Allegations2
The claimant is twenty-six years old. In Colombia she was educated, worked and lived in Bogotá. Her father worked for XXXXX in Colombia for 25 years and because of his work did much travelling by road. Because of his association with this large well-known government company her father was well known and was sometimes robbed of food and money on his road travels. Her father retired from XXXXX and set up his own company but work for this company also entailed travel by road in Colombia.
The claimant came to Canada to study because her father insisted that knowledge of the English language was important to her, but also because of the armed conflict in Colombia. She arrived in Canada with student authorization on July 31, 1999. She claimed refugee protection on January 12, 2000.
Determination
The panel finds that the claimant is not a Convention refugee as she does not have a well-founded fear of persecution. The panel finds that if removed to Colombia the claimant would not face a risk to her life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment beyond the risk faced generally by other individuals in Colombia. No evidence was adduced that could lead the panel to find that substantial grounds exist to believe that she will be subjected personally to a danger of torture.
Analysis
At the hearing the clamant specified that she feared being kidnapped or killed by the FARC should she return to Colombia. She was asked to tell of any interactions between the FARC and her father, siblings or herself in Colombia.
She testified that when her father travelled by road on his work for XXXXX he would, sometimes, be stopped by persons who identified themselves as members of the FARC. These persons would demand of her father the cash he had on him together with any food that he may have in the car. Her father would then be allowed to continue on his journeys. She further testified that her father stopped working for XXXXX in 1996 or 1997 and together with former co-workers at XXXXX started his own
company. Travelling for his own company, though less frequently than when with XXXXX, he was still sometimes stopped by the FARC with the same demands as formerly. The claimant testified that for the past three years her father has travelled by air on behalf of his company so has not encountered the FARC.
According to the claimant the instances noted above were the only problems encountered by her father from the FARC. Given the information in the documents on Colombia, the panel accepts, on a balance of probabilities, that her father was sometimes stopped on his road journeys and did have to hand over monies and food that he had with him in his car. However, that was the extent of the harm suffered by the claimant's father. The claimant was clear that nothing further happened. There were no threats involving her, no mention of her by the FARC, nothing that would presage harm to her by the FARC based on her father's interactions with persons in the FARC while travelling for either XXXXX or his own company.
The claimant attended school and university in Bogota and had no interactions there with the FARC. In her job she travelled day and night by public transport, using taxis when her shift work entailed travel at times when buses were no longer running. The journey lasted thirty minutes. She had no interactions with the FARC. She testified that as far as she knew neither of her brothers had experienced contact with the FARC in Bogota. She testified that three months ago her father and youngest brother (10 years old) moved from Bogota to the town where her paternal grandparents live - XXXXX, about three hours drive from Bogota. The claimant had no evidence that in XXXXX her father or brother had experienced any interactions with the FARC.
With the evidence before it the panel cannot find that there is a reasonable chance that the claimant would face persecution by members of the FARC based on the limited interactions between her father and members of the FARC, interactions that stopped once her father started travelling by air three years ago.
Colombia is a country in which a civil war has been ongoing for decades and in which extortion and kidnapping are common. This is not a claimant who presented evidence that the FARC had any information about her or had sought any information on her. They had not uttered any threats against her. Based on the evidence of the claimant's life in Colombia and the lives of her father and siblings, the panel lacks evidence that the FARC could perceive the claimant as opposed to them either based on their political values, their links with the drug trade, or any of that guerrilla group's other activities. Since her father stopped travelling on his business by road he has not encountered problems from the FARC. The panel does not find in the evidence before it that the claimant, if removed to Colombia, would face a risk to life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment there other than the risk faced generally by other individuals in that country.
The claimant at the hearing admitted that she would have returned to Colombia when her student's authorization ended in XXXXX 2001 but for her father's advice that she remain in Canada. She says that he did not tell her why he so advised. The panel therefore lacks information to lead it to find that his advice was based on any threats directed to the claimant or any fear of harm to her in Colombia beyond the general risk faced by all Colombians in the on going civil war there.
The claimant said that her fear of return to Colombia was also based on her marriage in Canada to a Canadian citizen. She said that if she returned to Colombia her husband would be perceived as wealthy, and because of her relationship with him she would be perceived as wealthy and therefore be more vulnerable to kidnapping. She testified that her husband works in the construction trade here and that he was originally from Chile.
The panel lacks credible evidence that a naturalized Canadian working in the construction trade would be perceived as wealthy in Colombia. Further the panel lacks credible evidence that would allow it to find that because of her marriage there is a reasonable chance that the claimant would face persecution from the FARC based on her membership of a particular social group: wife of a Chilean citizen who became a naturalized Canadian citizen.
The panel lacks sufficient evidence that would allow it to find that should the claimant return to Colombia her marriage to her husband would put her life at risk, or put her at a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment greater or different than the generalized risk of random violence there in the continuing civil war.
The panel lacks credible evidence that would allow it to find that the claimant is a Convention refugee or a person in need of refugee protection pursuant to s. 97. (1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
Accordingly, the panel rejects the claim to refugee protection of XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX.
