Introduction
XXXXX XXXXX, a twenty-seven-year-old citizen of Macedonia and XXXXX XXXXX, a thirty-one-year-old citizen of Kosovo, Yugoslavia, seek refugee protection under subsections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.1 The claims were joined according to Rule 49 (1) of the Refugee Protection Rules because they are husband and wife.
Allegations
The claimants alleged the following led them to flee Yugoslavia, where they were living and seek refugee protection in Canada. They alleged that they cannot return to Macedonia or Yugoslavia. The claimants met when the male claimant was in Macedonia on holiday, married on XXXXX, 1996 and lived in Prizren, Kosovo until the war began in January 1998.
During the war, there was no tolerance for Albanians in Kosovo married to spouses of different ethnic backgrounds. The claimants alleged that a neighbour married to a Serbian woman was killed, along with his family in XXXXX or XXXXX 1998. Following this, the claimants moved to another city, Jakovo, where they lived with the husband's aunt until XXXXX 2000.
While there, the male claimant assisted others to try to defend themselves against attacks by other groups such as the Serbs. He also helped to evacuate people from areas that were dangerous because of the fighting in Kosovo. The group was known as the UCK. The couple were advised by her husband's friend that it had become known by the UCK that the female claimant was Macedonian and that their lives could be in danger at the hands of the Albanian people. The couple crossed illegally into Albania and stayed with a friend of her husband until they arranged to come to Canada. The claimants alleged that they could not go to Macedonia because the male claimant is not Macedonian and it is too dangerous being married to an Albanian. They cannot return to Kosovo for the same reason, a mixed marriage.
On the day of the hearing, the claimants amended their Personal Information Forms (PIFs)2 to read that the male claimant advised others on how to defend themselves and that he advised people that they could help them to evacuate in areas that might be dangerous. The hearing was held over three days, March 4, 2003, December 9, 2003 and January 13, 2004.
Decision
I find that the male claimant is excluded under Section 1F of the Refugee Convention and is therefore not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection. I also find that the claimants are not Convention refugees as they do not have a well-founded fear of persecution for a Convention ground in Kosovo or Macedonia. I also find that the claimants are not persons in need of protection in that their removal to Macedonia or Kosovo would not subject them to personally to a risk to their lives or to cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, and in that there are no substantial grounds to believe that their removal to Kosovo or Macedonia will subject them personally to a danger of torture.
Analysis
At the beginning of the hearing, the claimants were told that credibility and their perceived political profiles, ethnicity and membership in a particular social group, that is families, were issues and that the onus was on them to establish their claims. The claimants also identified religion as an issue but no mention of this was made in their PIF narratives. The member added change of circumstances to the issues and allowed counsel time to speak with the claimants with respect to the added issue. There are numerous instances of inconsistencies, implausibilities and omissions which led the panel to find the claimant had failed in this responsibility. The following, while examples, are not exhaustive. The panel notes the following:
* Where a claimant swears that certain facts are true, this creates a presumption of truthfulness unless there is reason to doubt their truthfulness.3
* The existence of contradictions and inconsistencies in the evidence of a claimant is a well accepted basis for a finding of lack of credibility.4
* The Board does not have to accept a witness's testimony simply because it was not contradicted at the hearing.
* The Board is entitled to make reasonable findings based on implausibilities, common sense and rationality.5
* The Board is forward looking in its decision-making.6
* The Board is entitled to prefer the documentary evidence to that of the claimant originating from a variety of reputable mutually independent sources to that of the claimant because they are objective and have no interest in any refugee claim.
At the end of the first day of testimony, it was decided by the member to ascertain if the Minister was interested in intervening. The Minister issued a Notice to Intervene on May 16, 2003.7 The panel also notes the following:
* The onus is clearly on the Minister to establish that there are serious reasons to consider that the individual has committed an excludable act.
* The meaning of the standard serious reasons for considering is now determined in Canadian law as a lower standard of proof than a balance of probabilities.8
* Serious reasons for considering and reasonable grounds to believe with respect to exclusion require something more than suspicion or conjecture but something less than proof on a balance of probabilities.9
Personal Identity, Female Claimant
The panel will deal with the identity of the female claimant first and for this section of the reason, she will be referred to as the claimant. On the first day of the hearing, the female claimant had only her birth certificate in support of her identity,10 the claimants having travelled to Canada on fraudulent Finland passports.11 The birth certificate had no photograph on it. When asked how she obtained the certificate, the claimant alleged that her sister went to the police station in her town and simply asked for the document with no letter or other indication that the claimant required the document or that the sister had the right to obtain it, stating in her words, that they "give her easy". She testified that she received it in April or March 2002 and that it was an original just like the one she had before, which she alleged had expired. The claimant testified that her original birth certificate is in her parents' home.
The claimant testified that no one in her family has spoken to her since she was married in 1996 because they disapproved of her marriage. She has spoken to her sister to help obtain documents and who allegedly is more tolerant than the rest of the family. The claimant alleged that Macedonian birth certificates expire about every two years. The female claimant was directed to the date of issue, June 5, 2001 and to the fact that there was no expiry date on it, nor was there a place for an expiry date. The claimant was asked to explain how the date of issue was June 2001 when she received it in March 2002. The Refugee Protection Officer (RPO) asked her when she requested it. The claimant alleged that she had contacted her sister when she finished her PIF with her lawyer. The claimant was told that she had signed her PIF on June 14, 2001. The claimant then alleged that she had had a meeting with her lawyer before they finished the PIF and he told them they needed a minimum, birth certificate and after that she contacted her sister. The claimant was inconsistent in her testimony, alleging first that she contacted her sister when she finished her PIF, then alleging that it was before she finished her PIF and offered no explanation for the lack of an expiry date, despite the fact that she had alleged that Macedonian birth certificates expire about every two years.
The screening form indicates that several documents were required, including, but not limited to, passports, birth certificates, marriage certificates, identity cards, and evidence of religious and political affiliation. Earlier, when her counsel asked her if they had tried to obtain documents such as their marriage certificate and religious affiliation, the claimant alleged that they had contacted the male claimant's brother for the documents in February 2003, about a month ago, and that she would try to contact her sister again for a document indicating her religious affiliation.
In part, the claim is based on the fact that the claimants are of different religions, she a Christian, he, a Muslim, which they allege is not accepted by either their parents or society. I do not accept as credible that the claimant would ask her sister to obtain only her birth certificate before she signed the PIF and then asked for the other required documents much later. The claimant testified that her sister had only to go to the police station and request a birth certificate with no information from the individual involved. The claimant's testimony was inconsistent with respect to when she requested the document and there is a lack of an expiry date on the certificate or even a place for an expiry date, despite the claimant's allegation that birth certificates expire about every two years. The country documents show that fraudulent documents are easily obtained in Macedonia. Therefore, given the claimant's lack of credibility and the availability of fraudulent documents, on a balance of probabilities, I give the birth certificate no weight.
The Board received additional identity documents on December 5, 2003, including a Certificate for Holy Baptism and a health card for the female claimant.12 The claimant alleged that they came from her sister, who had lots of trouble with her parents in obtaining the documents. The sister did not, however, obtain the original birth certificate which the claimant alleged was at her parents' home. The claimant alleged that her parents disapproved of her marriage and had not spoken to her since she married in 1996. The claimant alleged that her parents are still angry with her and that her sister took a chance in speaking to her. The baptismal certificate is dated May 7, 2003. The Health Card lacks the year, although there is a place for it, 19--. On a balance of probabilities, I find the claimant's action with respect to obtaining documentary evidence regarding her personal identity is inconsistent with those of someone who fears persecution.
The claimant alleged that her parents did not approve of her marriage. Later she alleged that before 1989, Muslims and Christians used to get married, but with the first demonstrations in 1989, it, the hatred, started and she never knew it. If, as she testified that she never knew about the hatred, then, on a balance of probabilities, her family was not a part of it. It is implausible that the claimant would not know of the religious hatred between Muslims and Christians if it was in her own family.
Given the claimant's lack of credibility above, the timing of the receipt of the documents, that is in December 2003, when the claimants had sufficient time to obtain these documents prior to the first hearing, and given the availability of fraudulent documents in Macedonia, I give these documents no weight.
The claimant tendered her marriage certificate in support of her identity as a Macedonian citizen. It was allegedly issued by the United Nations, obtained by the male claimant's brother, according to the male claimant's testimony. The place for the citizenship of the male claimant has been left blank. The claimant explained that this was because it was issued in Prizren, his place of birth. The female claimant testified that the Board could accept the documents as authentic because they all contained the identification numbers of the claimant, which she testified would be on every document issued to citizens of their countries.
The male claimant did not secure an Identity Card, explaining that the records were destroyed during the war. The member stated that she had specialized knowledge that the U.N. provided Identification Cards for purposes of identification for those whose cards had been lost or destroyed in the war. The claimant stated that he did not know how they, meaning others, got them. The male claimant gave varying testimony about his marriage:
* He said his parents were unhappy with his marriage
* He said his parents were dead when he was married, explaining that he meant family when he said parents
* He reiterated that his mother was dead when he got married
* The male claimant then testified that his mother was not present at the marriage because she was sick with cancer
* He testified that he was married in October of 1996, not May, 1996
* He said that he was not married by a Muslim priest but in a civil ceremony. When asked if there was a word other than priest to designate the Muslim religious official, (the interpreter stated that that was his word, as he, the interpreter was a Christian). The question was put to the claimant, if there was another word for a Muslim clergyman. The claimant testified that no, that was the one.
Given the above inconsistent testimony while his own counsel was asking questions and who gave the claimant every opportunity to explain the inconsistencies, and again, given the availability of fraudulent documents in Kosovo,13 I give no weight to the marriage certificate with respect to the female claimant's Macedonian citizenship.
Counsel indicated in his questioning that the claimants were asked for all the documents mentioned in the screening form. The panel is aware that documents are not necessary to establish identity if there is a reasonable explanation as to how the claimant tried to obtain such documents and why they were unobtainable. The claimants had from at least June 14, 2001 when they signed their PIFs, until March 2002, the date of the first sitting in the hearing to obtain the required documents before the first hearing. In addition, the claimants had no knowledge that the hearings would be continuing beyond the first scheduled day. The identification documents came in only after the first hearing and when in February 2003 the claimants asked for them. The claimants were represented by counsel. Their lack of diligence in pursuing their case is inconsistent with the actions of persons who really feared for their lives.
The female claimant's health card is missing the year of the date of issue. The female claimant was challenged with respect to her birth certificate. On a balance of probabilities, I give the identification documents of the female claimant as to her citizenship as a Macedonian no weight. Counsel submitted that there was no indication that the information on the documents was in question and that it would be difficult to have so many documents with the correct identity numbers in them. The female claimant did, however, testify that the identification numbers were the same on all the documents and therefore, she knew that consistency was required. She also gave inconsistent testimony as to when she asked her sister for the birth certificate, changing it to accommodate the date of issue. The panel notes that the panel cannot be satisfied that the evidence is credible or trustworthy, unless satisfied that it is probably so, not just possibly so.14 Therefore, on a balance of probabilities, given the overall inconsistencies of the claimants with respect to the female claimant's Macedonian identity, I find that I cannot make a finding that the claimant is a citizen of Macedonia.
Personal Identity, Male Claimant
The male claimant has established his identity as a citizen of Yugoslavia through his Yugoslavian Driver's License which contained his picture and is dated XXXXX, 1972,15 and through his testimony as to his citizenship, which the panel accepts as credible with no implication as to the rest of his testimony.
Exclusion
The Minister filed the Notice of Intent to Intervene in the refugee hearing of the male claimant on the basis that his involvement with the UCK (Ushtria Clirimatrae E Kosoves) also known as the Kosovo Liberation Army (KLA) which raised matters involving Article 1F(a) of the United Nations Convention relating to the Status of Refugees and therefore exclusion became an issue. The KLA have been documented for widespread, systematic and severe human rights abuses, including ill treatment and torture of detainees.16 The panel will comment on the material contained in these documents at length further in the reason.
Crimes Against Humanity
Article VI of the Charter of the International Military Tribunal defines Crimes Against Humanity as "murder, extermination, enslavement, deportation and other inhumane acts committed against any civilian populations. Leaders, organizers, instigators and accomplishes participating in the formulation or execution of the common plan or conspiracy to commit any of the foregoing crimes are responsible for all the acts performed by any persons in execution of such plan.17
The Federal Court ruled crimes against humanity may be defined by various international instruments but courts may also consider statements of academics, commentators and various domestic, international courts, and tribunals in defining crimes against humanity since they flesh out the bare bones of the definition provided by such international instruments as the Charter in the International Military Tribunal.18
The Canadian Parliament defines crimes against humanity as: Murder, extermination, enslavement, deportation, imprisonment, torture, sexual violence, persecution, or any other inhumane act or omission that is committed against any civilian population or any identifiable group and that at the time and in the place of its commission, constitutes crimes against humanity according to customary international law or conventional international law or by virtue of its being criminal according to general principles of law recognized by the community of nations, whether or not it constitutes a contravention of the law in force at the time and place of its commission.19
Crimes against humanity must generally be committed in a widespread or systematic fashion and may be committed in war or peace.20
Accomplices as well as principle actors can be held subject to exclusion. The court interpreted the word 'committed' in Article 1F(a) by enunciating the following principles:
(a) mere membership in an organization involved in international offences is not sufficient for exclusion from refugee status
(b) personal and knowing participation in prosecutorial acts is required.
(c) membership in an organization which is directed to a limited, brutal purpose, such as secret police activity, may by necessity point to personal and knowing participation
(d) mere presence at the scene of prosecutorial acts does not qualify as personal and knowing participation
(e) presence coupled with being an associate of the principal offenders amounts to personal and knowing knowledge
(f) the existence of a shared common purpose and the knowledge that all parties have of it is sufficient evidence of complicity21
According to Ramirez,22 one of the fundamental purposes upon which complicity rests is the existence of a shared common purpose: "He was an active part of the military
forces committing such atrocities, he was fully aware of what was happening and he could not succeed in disengaging himself merely by ensuring that he was never the one to inflict the pain or pull the trigger."
Madame Justice Reed comments on the meaning of shared common purpose in Penate: As I understand the jurisprudence, it is that a person who is a member of the persecuting group and who has knowledge that the activities are being committed by the group and who neither takes steps to prevent them occurring (if he has the power to do so), nor disengages himself from the group at the earliest opportunity (consistent with the safety of himself), but who lends his active support to the group will be considered to be an accomplice. A shared common purpose will be considered to exist.23
In Gutierrez, the court stated as follows: "three prerequisites must be established in order to provide complicity in the commission of an international offence: (1) membership in an organization which committed international offences as a continuous part of its operation, (2) personal and knowing participation, and (3) failure to disassociate from the organization at the earliest safe opportunity."
The Federal Court has dealt with complicity in a number of cases involving 1F(a) exclusion.24 Six factors have been identified in analysing complicity, namely, method of recruitment, (voluntary/involuntary), nature of the organization, position/rank in the organization, knowledge of atrocities committed by the organization, opportunities to leave the organization and length of time in the organization.
Method of Recruitment
In this section of the hearing, the male claimant was testifying and I will refer to him as the claimant. The claimant gave conflicting evidence about what happened with respect to his recruitment. On the first day of the hearing, the claimant alleged that he was in hiding at the time the KLA knocked at the door to inquire about his uncle who was involved with, and was organizing for, the KLA. Because the uncle was an old man, according to the claimant, the KLA came to inquire about him because he had not gone. The KLA saw the claimant there and asked where he was from. The claimant told them that he was from Prizren and had only been there for two weeks, because his house had been destroyed. He did not tell them that he was married to a Macedonian woman. They told the claimant that he should go with them as they worked for the people. The claimant alleged that he told them he would go, as he had nothing to hide. The claimant alleged that he stayed with them for four months, went every week for about three days a week and they used to teach them how to use the arms during the first week of training, so they, including the claimant, were shooting things, specific targets.
The claimant went on to further explain that sometimes they did not use real ammunition in training after the first week. He also alleged that the situation was getting better and they would go to meet people in different villages to meet people who lost sons to see if they needed help which the claimant alleged they could give them. The claimant alleged that he was trained because he had not completed his military service.
The claimant testified that he went with the KLA because he had nothing to hide. It was only later that he said that he also went because it might put his uncle in trouble.
The claimant alleged that he had been in hiding for two years when the KLA came to the door and that he was in the sitting room when his uncle opened the door and they came in. The claimant was asked why he did not immediately hide when the knock came. He testified that he thought it was neighbours or relatives. Although the claimant was given several opportunities to explain why he would not be afraid of neighbours, who he alleged had no interest in him, coming to the door, when he was allegedly hiding from everybody, including them, the claimant did not offer any explanation other than he had not done anything wrong.
The claimant testified that he had joined the KLA in 1999, but later stated that it was in 2000, as he had alleged in his PIF. Then after he saw what was written on the paper [narrative], he knew it was another time.
The member reminded the claimant that at the beginning of the hearing he had sworn to tell the truth. The claimant then testified that he responded that way because the KLA did not mean anything to him, that he did not kill anyone and that his main problem was that he was married to a Macedonian woman. The claimant stated that he knew he should have told the truth but that he did not pay much attention to it. I do not accept this as credible. The claimant identified the year he was with the KLA as 1999, he was sworn to tell the truth and he knew that at the hearing the panel would decide whether or not his claim for refugee status in Canada would be accepted. The claimant knew that his testimony was important. On a balance of probabilities, I find the claimant was with the KLA in 1999.
The claimant's description of the events by which he was recruited was inconsistent throughout. He testified that he was in hiding for two years, then was not concerned when the knock came on the door because he thought it was just the neighbours. Given the opportunity to explain the inconsistency, he reiterated that he thought it was neighbours and did not know that they would come inside but that he had done nothing wrong and had nothing to hide. I do not accept this as credible. The claimant alleged that he was hiding from the neighbours for two years but did not hide when a knock came on the door because he thought it was just neighbours. On a balance of probabilities, I find the claimant not to be a credible or a trustworthy witness with respect to either hiding from everyone or how the KLA found him.
The claimant testified that he went with the KLA partly willingly and partly because of his uncle. When asked to explain what he meant, the claimant testified that the KLA came to see if his uncle was sick because he had not been with them for a week. He testified that his aunt and uncle told him it was best that he go with the KLA and tell them that he was there only two weeks. He also testified that he told the KLA people that he was only there two weeks as soon as they asked about him. He further testified that it was partly by choice and partly because of his own situation that his wife was Macedonian and he wanted to show that he was not connected to Serbs. The claimant stated that his uncle was old and tired and that was why he had not gone. When the claimant went with the KLA, the uncle was able to stay home.
The claimant testified that he went to train in order to defend himself because he had not completed his military service. Originally, the claimant testified that he told the KLA people that he was from Prizren on the day they first came. Later, when asked by the Minister's Counsel, he testified that his aunt told them. Although not put to the claimant, this inconsistency was part of a pattern of inconsistencies with respect to his involvement with the KLA. The claimant also testified that he did not want to fight while he was in Prizren and a lot of them did not want to jeopardize their lives. He did not like war and did not see it as a choice. However, he testified that one of the reasons he went with the KLA was because he needed to learn how to defend himself as he had no military training. He said it was normal. It was only much later that the claimant alleged that he went unwillingly because what would happen to him would be what happened to others, he would be killed. He did not state this on the first sitting of the heearing when questioned by his counsel. Then he stated that he went with them, partly by choice and partly for his uncle's sake. Therefore, on a balance of probabilities, I find that the claimant went with the KLA willingly.
Nature of the Organization
The documentary evidence tendered by the Minister's representative, Mr. P. Singh, contains overwhelming evidence that the KLA has been involved in many and brutal human rights abuses. The following, while not exhaustive, are examples, the whole of which are contained in Exhibit M-3.
Human Rights Watch reports the KLA committed abuses in which they abducted and murdered civilians during and after the war.25 The KLA was responsible for serious human rights abuses in 1998, including abduction and murders of Serbs and ethnic Albanians considered collaborators with the state. The KLA, which evolved between 1996 and 1999 from a scattered guerrilla group to an armed movement and ultimately to a more formidable armed force, engaged in military tactics in 1998 and 1999 that put civilians at risk. KLA units sometimes staged an ambush or attacked police or army outposts from a village and then retreated, exposing villagers to revenge attacks. Large massacres sometimes ensued, helping publicize the KLA's cause and internationalize the conflict. It is clear that the KLA understood the political benefit of publicizing civilian deaths after having attacked Serbian checkpoints near ethnic Albanian villages, exposing civilians to revenge attacks. Elements of the KLA are also responsible for post-conflict attacks on Serbs, Roma and other non-Albanians, as well as ethnic Albanian rivals. Immediately following NATO's arrival in Kosovo, there was widespread and systematic burning and looting of homes belonging to Serbs, Roma and other minorities and the destruction of Orthodox Churches and monasteries. As many as one thousand Serbs and Roma have been murdered or have gone missing since June 1999. Elements of the KLA are clearly responsible for many of these crimes.26
The KLA was organized into seven operational zones including Dukagjin where Djakovica (Gjakova/Jakova) was located, usually based around villages or series of villages. There was a central command structure discernable by 1998 and the KLA recognized Geneva Conventions. Despite the structures there are no known cases of KLA soldiers having been punished for human rights abuse.27 Prizren municipality was the site of many crimes during the period of NATO bombing. Villages north of the city were particularly hard hit due to KLA activity in the areas and the use of certain villages as rebel transit routes.28 One of the first regions hit by the Serbs after the NATO bombing was a series of villages along the ten kilometre stretch of road between Prizren and Djakovica. Many of the villages under attack were well known for their ongoing support of the KLA and arms were most likely flowing through these villages from Albania since 1998 and the KLA were frequently seen in and around the area, sometimes attacking police on the main road.29
By June 20, all Serbian and Yugoslav security forces had withdrawn, leaving Kosovo under the control of NATO-led Kosovo Force (FROR). The KLA and ethnic Albanians carried out widespread burning and looting of homes belonging to Serbs, Roma and other minorities. Members of minority groups in Kosovo have been detained, beaten and sometimes tortured with as many as one thousand Serbs and Roma reported unaccounted for after abductions since the end of the conflict. Although a desire for revenge provides some of the explanation for the violence, Human Rights Watch research suggests that a great deal of the violence is politically motivated; namely the removal from Kosovo of non-ethnic Albanians in order to justify an independent state.30 Thus it has become increasingly clear that the KLA is an organization with a single brutal purpose, that of removing non-ethnic Albanians from Kosovo. A Finnish forensic team was granted permission by the local Kosovo authorities to exhume bodies from six sites, three of which were expected to hold the bodies of victims of the KLA.31
The International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia was founded in May 1993. As of July 2001, the tribunal investigations against the KLA continued and the post conflict abuses against the Serbs and Roma were criticized as the seeds of future revenge and lasting instability in the region.32
The FAS Intelligence Resource Program reports that the KLA began in Macedonia in 1992 and appeared for the first time in public in 1996 assuming responsibility for a series of attacks committed against police stations and police men in Kosovo and Metohija. The KLA is organized in small compartmentalized cells and its strength is apparently divided between a manoeuvrable strike nucleus of a few hundred trained commandos and the much larger number of locally organized members active throughout the region.33 The hundreds of thousands of Kosovar Albanians are taking shelter in many of the KLA controlled areas. The KLA is receiving recruits from the refugee population in Albania primarily and they are training aggressively.34 Thousands of young Albanians left their jobs both in Kosovo and all across western Europe where they had been working to go and join the fighting for the independence of their homeland; a three per cent income tax on all exiles working in Germany, Austria and Switzerland and funds sent by family members working abroad. Arms were procured from all sources but the single most important early channel was from the Serbs themselves.35
The 1991 Amnesty International (AI) Report states that the KLA seeks independence for Kosovo by violent means and has attacked Serbian police, civilians and ethnic Albanians if regarded as loyal to the Serbian authorities.36 There were numerous reports of the UCK (KLA) and other armed Albanians perpetrated human rights abuses, particularly forcible displacement, ill treatment, abduction or deportation of non-combatants Serbian, Montenegrin, Albanian or Romani ethnicity.37
AI report for 2000 notes that the KLA were responsible for widespread human rights abuses, the victims being Serbs, Roma and Albanians accused of collaboration with the Serbs. Hundreds of people were unlawfully killed or abducted and partly as a result of these attacks, more than half the non-Albanian population had fled Kosovo by the end of 1999.
The International Committee of the Fourth International (ICFI) published on the World Socialist Website notes that the KLA's program is ethnic separatism, driving out of Kosovo Serbs, Montenegrans, and other minorities, creating a Greater Albania including Albania, and the Albanian populated areas of Macedonia.38 Given the above, on a balance of probabilities, I find that the KLA is an organization established for a single brutal purpose.
Complicity
In Gutierrez, the court stated as follows: "three prerequisites must be established in order to provide complicity in the commission of an international offence: (1) membership in an organization which committed international offences as a continuous part of its operation, (2) personal and knowing participation, and (3) failure to dissociate from the organization at the earliest safe opportunity.39
Madame Justice Reed comments on the meaning of shared common purpose in Penate: As I understand the jurisprudence, it is that a person who is a member of the persecuting group and who has knowledge that the activities are being committed by the group and who neither takes steps to prevent them occurring (if he has the power to do so), nor disengages himself from the group at the earliest opportunity (consistent with the safety of himself), but who lends his active support to the group will be considered to be an accomplice. A shared common purpose will be considered.
The claimant was asked the purpose of the UCK (KLA) at the Port of Entry (POE). He stated that there is a need over there, that he had no house and he was married with a Macedonian girl. He further stated at that time that "We used to go in the mountains to see if there were any Serbian people coming to protect our people, that he was in active combat for two to three hours and that he left the group because they found out he was married to a Macedonian and he was afraid they were going to kill him. He told the officer that he joined in 1999.40 The claimant testified when his counsel asked about this that he only trained for two or three hours for the first week and several hours the second. The claimant was asked questions about the information given at the POE. It has come to the attention of the Board that the interpreter there was inadequate, so the information on the POE for the male claimant was not considered with respect to any inconsistencies which arose because of it. However, the male claimant's testimony at the hearing will be considered. When asked if the claimant was in the mountains, for example to look for Serbs, the claimant testified that maybe the Serbs will come again. He further stated : "So to protect the Albanians who live in the area, we could protect them in the case the Serbs came back."
The claimant had previously testified that the situation was getting better. Then when asked about the evacuation, he testified that the pressure was still on, NATO was there but the situation was not good, the killings were going on all the time and people were getting killed and that is why they trained "us". The claimant was inconsistent even as he testified and when given the chance to explain by his counsel and the Minister's counsel. His PIF referred to advising on the evacuation and advising people on defending themselves. The claimant testified that he was not qualified to do that. He had no reasonable explanation as to why his oral testimony was inconsistent with his PIF. On a balance of probabilities, I find the claimant not to be a credible or a trustworthy witness with respect to advising others on evacuation and self-defence. This is consistent with the KLA's operational procedure as described above.
The claimant was asked what he knew about the KLA, that is that it had a "bad reputation". He testified that he did only after he came to Canada. The claimant was asked if he was recruited to serve in the KLA in Prizren where he lived. He stated that he was not but that he would have left right away if he was, because he was well-known in Prizren and he would have problems because he was married to a Macedonian. The claimant testified that, if he was asked to join in Prizren, he would have never joined them because the KLA would have seen him as a collaborator. He joined in Jakovo because nobody knew that he was married to a Macedonian. He testified that he was not part of them, that is those who went and fought. Later the claimant testified that he would not have stayed in the KLA, but would have gotten on with his life.
Therefore, on a balance of probabilities, I find that the claimant knew the reputation of the KLA and that they were known for killing Serbs and other minorities and that as long as they were no threat to him, he would have stayed until he could get on with his life. Therefore, on a balance of probabilities, I find that the claimant was complicit in the crimes against humanity of the KLA.
The claimant testified inconsistently with respect to other things which goes to the claimant's overall lack of credibility. For example, in his PIF, he stated that he advised people on how to evacuate. He confirmed this to his counsel by stating in answer to a question about evacuation, that there were still killings and that is why they trained us. Later, when the Minister's Counsel referred to the claimant's role in evacuation in the PIF, the claimant testified that he was not able to do that.
The claimant testified that he used real bullets. He told the Minister's Counsel that he did not. When the Minister's Counsel put the inconsistency to him, the claimant alleged that he meant that he used real weapons, not real bullets. He also originally testified that he trained for three to four hours for the first week and after that they had guns but no ammunition. Later he testified that he trained three to four hours the first day and three to five hours the second day. When the inconsistency was put to him, the claimant alleged that maybe he understood the question to mean how many hours he trained the first day.
Given the above, I do not accept the claimant's testimony as credible or trustworthy with respect to his participation in the KLA, including his training, his knowledge about the organization and when he was a member.
Opportunities to Leave the Organization
The claimant was asked when he left the organization. He testified that he was told by a friend that others may had found out that he was married to a Macedonian. He testified that he left for Albania the next day. The claimant stayed with the organization as long as it was of no risk to him, regardless of the fact that he knew that others were at risk. He was able to leave as soon as he found out he was at risk. Therefore, on a balance of probabilities, I find that the claimant did not leave as soon as he was able without risk to himself. Therefore, on a balance of probabilities, I find that the claimant was complicit in the crimes of the KLA.
I have found that the claimant joined the KLA of his own free will, which has been found to be an organization which was established for a single brutal purpose. I have found that the claimant knew about the reputation of the KLA and that they killed civilians and minorities. I have found that the claimant did not leave the organization as soon as he was able to without endangering himself. Therefore, I find that there are serious reasons for considering that the claimant should be excluded from protection under section F of Article 1 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
Inclusion
Given that I cannot find the female claimant a citizen of Macedonia, I cannot find her either a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection. I have found the male claimant excluded under Article 1F. Even if I had not so found, the country documents do not support the persecution alleged by the claimants in either country.
Yugoslavia
In YUG42036.E, the Research Directorate, in commenting on religious freedom with respect to Roman Catholics indicates that religious and ethnic discrimination is prohibited by law and the government generally respects this right in practice. Further, it states that religion is not a significant factor in Kosovo. Most Albanians [in Kosovo] know that their future security depends on tolerence and co-existence with other peoples. Their leaders recognize that any constitution must safeguard the rights of minorities. Marriage between Muslims and Catholics is so common that individual cases go unremarked.41 On a balance of probabilities, if marriage between one Christian denomination goes unremarked, I find that marriage between Muslims and other Christians, that is Orthodox, would also be accepted. In areas such as Prizren there is long acceptance among different communities.42
In addition, the male claimant tendered a letter of attestation in support of his claim to be a Muslim.43 The letter had no security features on it. The member declared that she had seen other letters of attestation from mosques in Kosovo that had such security features on them and asked the claimant to explain, if he could, why this letter had no such features. The claimant stated that it depends on the mosque. The claimant testified that he did not attend a mosque but observed some of the religious traditions such as Ramadan. When asked how his brother obtained the letter, he explained that while all the records of the Mosque were destroyed during the war, his brother asked for the letter, giving the particulars. The cleric then asked ten or more people who survived. The claimant alleged that he had been registered at birth at the mosque. The claimant's brother cannot be considered to be objective. Given the claimant's overall lack of credibility, I give the letter no weight. On a balance of probabilities, I find the claimant not to be a Muslim.
Even if I found the claimant to be a Muslim, which I do not, I find there is not a serious possibility he would face persecution if he returned to Yugoslavia. In addition, no evidence was adduced which would support a finding that the male claimant would be at risk to his life, cruel and unusual treatment or punishment or to a danger of torture.
Macedonia
The Ohrid Agreement was the culmination of negotiation that sought to end hostilities between ethnic Albanians and Macedonian government forces. It rejects violence for political aims and preserves Macedonia's unity by denying possible ethnic division of the country. Minority languages used by more that twenty per cent of the population, shall receive official status and speakers of these languages shall have the right to be provided public services, primary, secondary and university level education and judicial proceedings. Albanians meets the twenty per cent criteria.44
The female claimant stated that she had no fears if she returns to Macedonia. Therefore, even if I found the claimant to have established her identity as a citizen of Macedonia, which I do not, the claimant has no fear of returning to Macedonia. Therefore, there is not a serious possibility that she will face persecution or be at risk to her life, cruel and unusual treatment or punishment or a danger of torture.
Conclusion
Having considered all the evidence, I have found that there is no evidence by which I could find XXXXX XXXXX to have established her identity as a citizen of Macedonia and therefore she is not a Convention refugee and not a person in need of protection and I reject her claim.
I have found there are serious reasons for considering that XXXXX XXXXX should be excluded from refugee protection and therefore he is not a Convention refugee and not a person in need of protection and I reject his claim.

The claimant is a citizen of Uruguay. In XXXXX 1997, he started working in a XXXXX business in Montevideo, owned by one XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, who was also a police official. Essentially, the claimant's duties were to accompany clients to banks and, when required, to drive XXXXX to meetings. In mid-1999, the meetings took on a disconcerting turn. The claimant found that the meetings involved the hand-over of boxes to unknown characters in return for money. In XXXXX 1999, he learned from XXXXX, a truck driver, that these boxes contained arms and ammunition. The claimant went to XXXXX and told him that he was going to leave his employ. XXXXX offered to increase his salary. When the claimant demurred, XXXXX told him to simply forget the idea of leaving his service. The claimant went on sick leave. XXXXX pressurized him to return. Finally, the claimant did so. In early XXXXX 1999, the claimant left Montevideo to work as a XXXXX in Punta del Este, some 160 kilometres away. In XXXXX 2000, he was arrested by two police officials and taken to Montevideo. He was called a traitor and beaten. He lost consciousness. When he came to his senses, he found he was in an abandoned building under guard. XXXXX came to see him. XXXXX offered to give him one more chance. The claimant continued working for XXXXX until XXXXX 2000. The claimant went to see a lawyer. The lawyer told him he could not help him. The claimant then spoke to a policeman acquaintance about the possibility of making a formal complaint against XXXXX. His acquaintance refused to listen to him. The claimant then moved to another city, Colonia, to work at a XXXXX repair service station. His son in Montevideo phoned to say the police were searching for him. The claimant went into hiding. Again, the police came to his son, saying that they had a warrant for his arrest but failed to produce one. In XXXXX 2001, the claimant fled to Canada.
ANALYSIS
State protection is the determinative issue in this claim. Ward1 has firmly established that every state must be presumed capable of protecting its citizens unless "clear and convincing" evidence is presented to the contrary. The evidence presented by the claimant is simply not clear and convincing enough.
The claimant's main argument for not seeking police protection is because he believes that police are corrupt and rather than attack crime, support it. Pockets of police corruption exists, it is true. The documentary evidence, however, indicates that the state has been making serious efforts to combat such corruption.
In August 1997, the Public Prosecutor's Office of Police was created "to prevent and stamp out irregular actions" by police. At the same time, the National Inspection of Police that had been established in 1992 was expanded so that it could co-ordinate more efficiently with the Prosecutor's Office in the investigation of irregular or illicit police actions. It is true that XXXXX used his police office for private profit and used this office
to intimidate the claimant. Despite a lawyer's wrong advice and the hostility of a police acquaintance, he could have gone to the Public Prosecutor's Office and filed a formal complaint against XXXXX. While a psychologist's report indicates him to be a person of high anxiety, this still does not excuse him to approach his own country for protection if such protection is reasonably affordable.
Counsel has argued that courts seldom prosecute corrupt police officials and the higher an official is in the echelon, as is XXXXX, the less the chance of his being persecuted. What the documentary report is saying is this, "While the courts seldom convicted and punished police enforcement officials in the past, such prosecutions are occurring more frequently."2 Over 400 police officers have been indicted in the past three years for offences ranging from corruption to abuse.3
Uruguay remains a functioning democracy with an independent judiciary. The Country Reports on Human Rights Practices states that "the law and judiciary generally provided effective means of dealing with individual instances of abuse."4 A United Nations Human Rights Committee document states that:
Considerable progress has also being realized with the enactment of new laws and codes and with the strengthening of democratic institutions and processes aimed at promoting and protecting human rights.5
It has thus not established to my satisfaction that the claimant is in need of the surrogate protection that the international community provides. It is only when the need for such surrogate protection has been proven that either Section 96 and Section 97 of the Act kicks in. That not having been done, I reject the claim.

XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX XXXXXX XXXXXXXX XXXXX the 'female claimant", their minor XXXXX XXXXXXXXXX XXXXXXXXXXX, the "minor", and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, the "mother-in-law", are citizens of Colombia, and they claim refugee protection in Canada pursuant to ss. 96 and 97 (1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).1
A Hearings Officer (Minister's Representative) participated in the hearing pursuant to subsection 170(e) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.2 The claimants had been notified3 by letter that matters involving Article 1F(a) of the 1951 Convention have been raised by the claim, in light of the principal claimant's former status as a soldier in the Colombian armed forces.
The testimony was given over a period of three sittings (January 7, 2004; July 20, 2004; August 3, 2004).
ALLEGATIONS
The claimants allege the following.
They received death threats from members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia - Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC) - in Colombia, because of the principal claimant's links to the Colombian armed forces. The principal claimant served in the armed forces of Colombia from the year 1988 until his departure from Colombia in XXXXX 2001. He had received his elementary and high school education at the XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, XXXXX, XXXXX, and, later, did a Professional Military Services course at the XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, XXXXXXX.
The principal claimant had many assignments4 as an armed forces XXXXX, and, by 1996, his identity as a soldier was known to the guerrillas, and he was considered a target for reprisals. One indication was that, in the year 1996, while the army carried on military operations in Antioquia, near to the principal claimant's military base at the time, a detained individual was found to be carrying a note with a written order to kill the principal claimant.
Subsequently, in XXXXX 2001 and XXXXX 2001, while the female claimant and the minor resided at the home of the mother-in-law in Bogota, the family received serious threats to their lives, through telephone calls. The callers stated that they were aware of the principal claimant's work against the guerrillas and his position in the army and gave notice that the family was declared military targets. The female claimant received a
"suffragio" (condolence letter/death notice) on March ^, 2001. After the call in XXXXX 2001, the principal claimant sought protection for his family. However, his superiors informed him that they were unable to provide that protection because of lack of resources. Therefore, after the subsequent calls in XXXXX 2001, the principal claimant decided to leave Colombia to seek international protection. The claimants travelled to the USA on XXXXX, 2001 and from there they entered Canada on XXXXX, 2001.
DETERMINATION
After careful consideration of all of the evidence, I am of the opinion that the exclusion provision (Article 1F(a)) of the Act is applicable in the claim of the principal claimant and that he is not a Convention refugee. I concur with the conclusion of the Hearings Officer that the principal claimant comes within the parameters of Article 1F of the Refugee Convention.
I determine, also, that the female claimant, the minor, and the mother-in-law have established valid claims on the basis of the allegations and the documentary evidence, as, in my opinion, no adequate national protection is available to them in Colombia.
All claimants established their identity5 as citizens of Colombia, and there is no evidence that they possess any other nationality.
ANALYSIS
In considering the issue of exclusion in the claim of the principal claimant, I take note of the following statutory provisions and the case law.
Section 98 of IRPA6 states that persons referred to in Article 1F(a) of the Refugee Convention are not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection, and states, in part:
"The provisions of this Convention shall not apply to any person with respect to whom there are serious reasons for considering that:
"(a) he has committed a crime against peace, a war crime, or a crime against humanity, as defined in the international instruments drawn up to make provision in respect of such crimes..."
In several decisions,7 the Court has dealt with the issue of serious reasons for considering that a crime, as defined in the international instruments,8 has been committed, and I am guided, primarily, by the decisions in Ramirez,9 Sivakumar,10 and Moreno.11
In Ramirez,12 the Court found that the burden of proving that the claimant should be excluded from determination as a Convention refugee is on the party so asserting, rather than on the claimant to demonstrate that he should not be excluded from such status. It further held that the test for determining whether there are "serious reasons for considering" that a crime has been committed, require less than a balance of probabilities.
The Court13 also reviewed the degree of involvement required on the part of the claimant in order to be excluded from Convention refugee status, and found that accomplices, as well as principal actors, may be subject to exclusion. It was held that a person could be considered to be an accomplice, if there is personal and knowing participation in the persecutorial act, and the Court went on to provide examples of this test. It stated14 that:
"... mere membership in an organization which from time to time commits international offenses will be sufficient for exclusion from refugee status where the organization is principally directed to a limited , brutal purpose, which may, by necessity, involve personal and knowing participation in persecutorial acts...someone who is an associate of the principal offender can never be said to be a mere onlooker..."
The Court15 also looked at the claimant's opportunity to have left the organization earlier, without risk of harm to himself, and the length of time in the organization.
In Sivakumar,16 the Court looked at the method of recruitment (voluntarily) in the claimant's organization, the nature of the organization (violence/killings), the claimant's position/rank in the organization, including his high-level promotions, the claimant's opportunity to leave the organization and the claimant's length of time in the organization.
In Moreno,17 the Court further clarified that a claimant can be held for guilt by association where the organization in which he is involved is premised on achieving political or social ends by any means necessary, while still considering that mere membership in the organization involved in international offenses is not sufficient basis on which to invoke the exclusion clause.
Firstly, on the issue of credibility, I consider that, in very significant areas, the principal claimant has presented implausible testimony with respect to his military assignments and the military operations in which he was involved. Counsel has argued that the principal claimant's oral testimony and explanations remain un-contradicted. However, I note the following.
In the narrative of his PIF,18 the principal claimant presented clear and very precise details of his military assignments, outlined as follows. From XXXXX 1998 to XXXXX 1990, he was the XXXXX of 40 men with the XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX - XXXXX. From May 1990 to October 1990 he was the XXXXX of 20 men with the XXXXX XXXXX in the Department of XXXXX. From XXXXX 1990 to XXXX 1991 he was involved in surveillance of XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, in XXXXX. From XXXXX 1995 to XXXXX 1997, he was the XXXXX of 60 men involved in anti-guerrilla operations and surveillance XXXXXX with the "XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX in XXXXX XXXXX. From XXXXXX 1999 until his departure, he was attached to the anti-guerrilla operations with Mobile Brigade XXX XXXXX in XXXXX, XXXXX.
From XXXXX 1991 to XXXXX 1995, and XXXXX 1997 to XXXXX 1999, the principal claimant was attached to the XXXXX XXXXX and XXXXX division.
The principal claimant states that in his first assignment in the Department of XXXXX, he and his men were in charge of public order of nearby towns and that there were operations against guerrillas. In his stint with Brigade No. 4, the XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX Unit, he was seconded there to lead the XXXXX Unit. Guerrilla operations were carried out in XXXXXXXXXXXXX. When he became a XXXXX in 1995 and was sent to be a XXXXX at the base in XXXXX, he participated in missions around XXXXX.
When the principal claimant joined the XXXXX XXXXX, he was a member of the rapid deployment force at the XXXXX base in the town of XXXXX in XXXXX, and he states that:
"...the special deployment force would be called on to do operations against guerrillas. Especially in that period from XXXXX 2000 to XXXXX of 2001 I was a member of the mobile brigade XXXXXXXXXX where there was numerous combats with terrorists groups especially FARC. We would try to take back towns taken by the guerrillas, liberate kidnapped people and liberate roadblocks. We had operations in XXXXX, XXXXX, XXXXX and XXXXX. I was a member of the XXXXX group in charge of planning such operations. My title was XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX. I would also be involved in implementation of the operations. I remember particularly two difficult missions against the guerrillas one for about three months in XXXXX and another for about three months in the Department of XXXXX ..."
In his oral testimony, however, the principal claimant has presented a different picture. In response to specific questions about the stated anti-guerrilla operations, he described these operations as mere administrative tasks. He testified that he was never involved in any combat activities that might be deemed atrocious or a violation of human rights. He stated that he had never been involved in the capture of guerrillas, and that basically, his mission was to train soldiers. He explained, further, that the expression "anti-guerrilla operations", in his particular case, merely meant showing a military presence as a means of support for the communities, being there to control and safeguard bridges and highways, being involved in the transportation of goods from one place to another and, generally, providing security in the areas. He stated that, occasionally, persons would be stopped at roadblocks and their documents checked. However, he stressed, he was only involved in administrative duties and missions. He had received training in human rights, and he was conscious of his role as a soldier.
The Hearings Officer has concluded that the principal claimant's oral testimony and explanations in this area are not plausible, and has pointed out excerpts from his documentary package19 in support of that conclusion. I concur with that conclusion, taking into consideration the principal claimant's XXXXX rank in the Colombian armed forces for at least thirteen years, and based on the documentary evidence on the activities of the Colombian armed forces in those same years, and in the geographical areas of the principal claimant's military assignments/operations.
I note decisions20 of the Court where it is held that the Board is entitled to make reasonable findings based on implausibilities. In particular, I note the commentary in Faryna v. Chorny21 on the test of a witness' credibility where it is stated that:
"...the test must reasonably subject his story to an examination of its consistency with the probabilities that surround the currently existing conditions. In short, the real test of the truth of the story of a witness in such a case must be in harmony with the preponderance of the probabilities which a practical and informed person would readily recognize as reasonable in that place and in those conditions..."
The Hearings Officer has highlighted relevant references in his documentary package22 which indicate that there were intense guerrilla and anti-guerrilla activities in areas identified as those corresponding to where the principal claimant served, such as in XXXXX, XXXXX and XXXXX. From that package, I have reviewed some specific studies/reports23 of credible sources such as Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch, the United Nations Human Rights Commission and the United States Department of State Report. These reports cite the Colombian army as being guilty of committing gross human rights violations against the civilian population for decades, with virtual impunity, before and during the claimant's period of service.
One such source24 says the following:
"...violations of international humanitarian law- the laws of war- are not abstract concepts in Colombia, but a grim material of everyday life. War bursts into the daily activities of a farm, a village, a public bus, or a school with the speed of armed fighters arriving down a path or in four-wheel drive vehicles. Sometimes armed men carefully choose their victims from lists. Other times, they simply kill those nearby, to spread fear. Indeed, a willingness to commit atrocities is among the most striking features of Colombia's war...the Colombian army teaches its officers the basics of international humanitarian law and makes instructional material available to officers, professional soldiers, and recruits...
Nevertheless, after examining hundreds of cases and interviewing many officers, government investigators and civilians who have witnessed violations, Human Rights Watch concluded that the army continues to engage in serious violations of the laws of war, with little apparent will to investigate or punish those responsible. At the root of these violations is the Colombian army's consistent and profound failure or refusal to properly distinguish civilians from combatants..."
Another relevant example of the documentary information states the following:
"...the information received by the Special Rapporteur shows that violations of the right to life are continuing to occur n a large scale and that there are no indications that an improvement is foreseeable in the short term. Members of the army, paramilitary groups, the police, and to a lesser extent guerrilla groups are reported to have been responsible for a large number of violations of the right to life..."25
"...during 1990 and 1991 the army launched major offensives against guerrilla forces in several parts of the country. Little or no effort was made to protect the civilian population during these operations...Military commanders routinely claim that unarmed civilians extrajudicially executed by soldiers were guerrillas killed in combat. Blaming the guerrillas is another of the army's usual responses to accusations of human rights violations..."26
The United States Department of State reports27 on Country Conditions in Colombia for the years 1991 and 1993 give the same grim picture, and in each case state that members and units of the army, sometimes in collaboration with paramilitary forces, participated in a number of human rights violations including extrajudicial killings,
disappearances, torture and arbitrary detention, and that the army is reluctant to distinguish between guerrillas and non-combatants during counterinsurgency operations.
A project28 undertaken by the Norwegian Refugee Council, subtitled "Agents of Displacement: Colombian Armed Forces 1994-2002" provided the following summary:
* Successive Governments have assigned the armed forces a growing role not only in the counter-insurgency fight, but, also in maintaining public order in general
* The Army has used indiscriminate means and methods of combat during its clashes with the guerrillas in various places, resulting in a number of mass displacements of peasants
* The implicit or sometimes obvious support by the armed forces of paramilitary activities and the impunity for violations of human rights by army members are also among the aggravating factors
* There are persistent reports of disappearances and arbitrary executions, as well as support to the paramilitary groups
* According to the Colombian Commission of Jurists (CCJ), the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights in Colombia and several human rights organizations, government forces have played a role in many of the crimes committed by the paramilitary.
*
As pointed out by the Hearings Officer, Human Rights Watch, in its annual report covering events of 1998, describes both the army's direct human rights violations and those accomplished indirectly through paramilitaries in the following way:
"...the Colombian army continued to commit serious violations with little apparent will to investigate or punish those responsible. As in the past, at the root of these abuses was the Colombian army's consistent and pervasive failure to enforce human rights standards and distinguish civilians from combatants. In eastern Colombia, where paramilitary forces were weak, the army was directly implicated in the killing of civilians and prisoners taken hors de combat, as well as torture and death threats. In the rest of the country, where paramilitaries had developed a pronounced presence over the past decade, the army still failed to move against them and tolerated their activity, including egregious violations of international humanitarian law; provided some paramilitary groups with intelligence and logistical support to carry out operations; and actively promoted and coordinated joint manoeuvres with them..."29
The above reports reflect some of the situation during a period when the claimant was a serviceman of rank, who, by 1996, had already been targeted for his work as an XXXXX in the Colombian armed forces.
I also find very persuasive, another Report30 of 1994, prepared by the Inter-Church Committee on Human Rights in Latin America (ICCHRLA) which states:
"...during its two most recent visits to Colombia, ICCHRLA representatives travelled to several conflicted zones in the country and received reliable reports of the same pattern of violations that have been signalled in the past. These include extrajudicial executions of civilians by military personnel which are later presented as " guerrillas killed in combat"; indiscriminate bombing and aerial strafing of communities where the military suspect a guerrilla presence and forced recruitment of civilians who are obliged to dress in military uniforms and act as guides in conflictive zones..."
In addition, one of the key assignments of the principal claimant, albeit a brief one, was his attachment to the Mobile Brigade XXXXX, where he served as XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX. The principal claimant considers that his position as XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX does not place him in the role of an accomplice. I do not agree.
A general description of the Mobile Brigade 31 is as follows:
"...the centrepiece of army strategy is the Mobile Brigade. The Mobile Brigade is conceived as a highly mobile force equipped with weaponry and vehicles suitable for the country's rugged, often densely forested countryside...Mobile Brigades are composed of professional soldiers who volunteer..."
...mobile brigade strategy follows a general pattern. The goal is to trap guerrillas, forcing them to flee by a route already covered by troops. The Mobile Brigade begins by softening up an area with the bombing of supposed guerrilla settlements and strafing from a variety of aircraft...despite the government and military's assertions that Mobile Brigades do not commit systemic abuses, some government agencies and independent human rights groups have documented a broad, consistent, and often shocking pattern of serious violations of human rights and the international covenants governing internal armed conflicts...Americas Watch believes that spreading terror among civilians is an integral part of Brigade strategy and appears to be tolerated and sometimes openly articulated by Brigade Commanders..."
By the year 2000, when the principal claimant assumed the title of XXXXX and was XXXXXXXXXXXXXX with Mobile Brigade XX, the reputation of the Mobile Brigades was widespread. I do not agree with counsel's arguments that the principal claimant, for all of his years in the armed forces and his XXXXX rank, had no knowledge of the abuses committed by the Mobile Brigades or any other part of the army.
Counsel has conceded that it is evident that some members of the Colombian army have committed crimes against humanity, as that term is defined in the relevant international instruments, but that the principal claimant did not personally commit such crimes, and he "should not be excluded by virtue of being an accomplice to crimes
committed by others".32 Counsel argues, further, that, for the most part, the principal claimant was a XXXXXXXXXX, who also spent a large portion of his army years with the XXXXXXXXX unit, and in studies; that his anti-guerrilla service did not involve direct combat with guerillas, and that his testimony remains un-contradicted, and should not be deemed implausible.
Even if the principal claimant did not personally commit atrocities while being a soldier, he admits that he had some knowledge of some of the stated atrocities, and he did not disengage himself from the armed forces at his earliest opportunity. Therefore he is complicit. In Sivakumar,33 cited above, it is stated that it is possible to commit crimes against humanity as an accomplice even though one has not personally done acts amounting to the crime. In Bazargan,34 the Court said that personal and knowing participation can be direct or indirect, and that one can be an accomplice to the organization's activities, by knowingly contributing to those activities in any way or making them possible, whether from within or from outside the organization.
The principal claimant has admitted that he was regularly informed of guerrilla
activities in various areas from his Commanders. As a young man, he watched TV and read the newspapers. He received some information of the army activities through radio news, and some from his superior officer, such as his captain. He had heard of some of the anti-guerrilla activities in the red zones35 in the Antioquia area. He had heard of the incident in Tello, San Antonio, where there were intense guerrilla activities and the guerrillas had taken eight towns. He had heard of the massacres in Rio Frio, of October 1993 where human rights violations were committed by the army. By that date, the principal claimant was already at least five years in the service. He had heard about the violations committed by the XXXX Brigade and the fact that those violations caused the XXXX Brigade to be disbanded by the authorities. As pointed out by the Hearings Officer, notorious massacres such as in Rio Frio (1993), Segovia (1996), Mepiripan (1997) and El Aro (1997) should have raised concerns for the principal claimant that the military's involvement in paramilitary atrocities was systematic and it is not plausible that he would not have had knowledge of the reports connected to these incidents.
The claimant states that, as far as he was concerned, the Colombian army paid keen attention to operating as an army and avoiding human rights violations. He argued that individual violations by some delinquent personnel cannot indicate that the Colombian army was geared to a single brutal purpose. He stated that according to the polls in Colombia, the Colombian army was the second most respected entity, after the Catholic Church.
In my view, the principal claimant's responses establish that he had some awareness of the activities of the army, and the atrocious activities of army personnel. Those activities are documented, and they go back to the years of the principal claimant's early service and during his rise to the rank of XXXXX. He was not an ordinary soldier who merely followed orders, and, what is more, he clearly stated that, while with Mobile Brigade XX, he was a member of the XXXXXXX group in charge of planning operations in XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX. He was also involved in the implementation of operations. Therefore, he contributed to the acts and activities of these forces.
In addition, with respect to the issue of rank, length of time in the army and opportunity to leave the army, I note that, for many years, the principal claimant served as a XXXXXX which is XXX in rank in the army hierarchy. Later he served as a XXXX, a position which is XXXX in rank in the hierarchy. These are not XXXXX positions, in my opinion. The principal claimant joined the army as a volunteer, and he was under no obligation to remain in the forces during that period of human rights violations. He spent fourteen years with the armed forces, and he did not disengage himself from the armed forces until his family was directly threatened by guerrillas.
Based on the above, I find that there are serious reasons for considering that the principal claimant, XXXXXXXXXXXXX, has been an accomplice in the activities of the Colombian army, and in crimes against humanity during his service with that army. Accordingly, he falls within the parameters of Article 1(F)(a). He is not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection.
With respect to the other claims, and their objective basis, I considered the documentary evidence on the current situation in Colombia. I note that it is stated that members of the guerrilla movements such as the FARC engage in reprisals against persons of certain profiles. Family members of Government or army operatives can become prime targets, as they too are perceived to have political opinions that are opposed to those of guerrillas such as FARC.
More significantly, it is stated36 that, in such situations, the Colombian authorities are unable to extend their power and authority in terms of security and the rule of law, and to provide its citizens with adequate protection. It is accepted that the principal claimant, as a soldier, sought protection for the family and that it was not provided.
For these reasons, I accept the claims of XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, XXXXX XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, and XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX.
I reject the claim of XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX.
