XXXXXXX XXXXXXX XXX XXXXXXX XXXXXXX XXXXXXXXXX XXXXXXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXX XXXXXXare citizens of Colombia. The claimants claim to be in need of refugee protection pursuant to sections 96 and 97(1)(a) and 97(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
At the hearing, the claimant was represented by Michael Loebach, Barrister and Solicitor. The Refugee Protection Division was represented by a Refugee Protection Officer, M. Ramoutar, and the Minister was represented by David Cranton, Barrister and Solicitor. The Minister participated in this claim based on Article 1F(a). The Minister alleges that the claimant is complicit in crimes against humanity based on his service with the Department of Administration and Security (DAS).
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant alleges that he worked for XXXXX years for the Department of Administration and Security (the DAS). For the first eight years, he worked as an XXXXX and later with some in-service training, he became an expert with XXXXX. Because of his knowledge and expertise about XXXXX, the FARC guerrillas contacted him and demanded that he collaborate with them by providing instructions about XXXXX to their colleagues.
His refusal to collaborate with the FARC resulted in he and his family being targeted by the guerrillas. His wife and he received a number of threatening calls from them. On one occasion on the night of XXXXX, 1999, he was shot and severely wounded by them. Then on XXXXX, 2000, when his wife and their children were driving to XXXXX with their uncle, they were forced off the road by the FARC. As a result, their car smashed against a rock causing severe injuries to their daughter. He talked to his boss at the DAS about these incidents. His boss sympathized with him but did not offer him a bodyguard to protect him.
ANALYSIS
Both the issues of exclusion and inclusion were raised during the hearing. The panel will deal with the issue of exclusion first then with the issue of inclusion.
Exclusion:
Article 1(F) reads in part as follows:
The provisions of this Convention shall not apply to any persons with respect to whom there are serious reasons for considering that:
(a) he has committed a crime against peace, a war crime, or a crime against humanity, as defined in the international instruments drawn up to make provision in respect of such crimes;
The Federal Court of Appeal, in Sivakumar states that there is "little, if any, difference" between "reasonable grounds to believe" and "serious reasons for considering".1
Both standards "require more than suspicion or conjecture, but something less than proof on a balance of probabilities" [ibid., "reasonable grounds to believe" has been defined as "a bona fide belief in a serious possibility based on credible evidence"].2
Crimes against humanity are defined in Article 7 of the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court, signed on July 17, 1998. It is the latest word on the subject. Crimes against humanity consists of:
...imprisonment or other severe deprivation of physical liberty in violation of fundamental rules of international law, torture, other inhumane acts of a similar character internationally causing great suffering, or serious injury to body or to mental or physical health.
Canada's Crimes Against Humanity and the War Crimes Act specifically endorses as well as incorporates the definition of crimes against humanity from the Rome Statutes by stating that crimes described in Article 7 are crimes against humanity according to international law (Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act 2000).
In this case, the question is whether XXXXX XXXXX is legally responsible as an accomplice for the crimes of murder, torture and enforced disappearances perpetrated by the DAS during his years of service with the DAS.
Liability of Accomplices:
The attachment of responsibility to accomplices is supported by Article 6 of the Charter of the International Military Tribunal (IMT Charter) one of the instruments referred to in Article 1(F)(a). Article 6 of the IMT Charter states:
Leaders, organisers, instigators and accomplices participating in the formulation or execution of a common plan or conspiracy to commit any of the foregoing crimes [including crimes against humanity] are responsible for all acts performed by any persons in execution of such plan.
The principle of complicity of an accomplice has been examined by the Federal Courts in Canada. In Ramirez,3 it was established "personal and knowing participation" and a "shared common purpose" as being essential requirements for a finding of complicity. The Federal Court enunciated the following test:
At bottom, complicity rests..... on the existence of a shared common purpose and the knowledge that all of the parties in question may have of it.
In Harb,4 the Federal Courts addressed the concept of complicity by association:
Personal commission of crimes is not required. Once the organisation with which Harb was associated has committed such crimes and he meets the requirements for complicity imposed by precedent, the exclusion applies even if the specific acts committed by the appellant himself are not crimes against humanity (para. 11).
The Federal Court stated that a simple denial, even if credible,
.... cannot suffice to negate the presence of a common purpose. A plaintiff's actions can be more revealing than his testimony and the circumstances may be such that it can be inferred that a person shares the objectives of those with whom he is collaborating. (para. 27)
In this case, evidence indicates that the principal claimant is a complicit accomplice. He had a long service with the DAS. He had knowledge of its commission of crimes against humanity, although he did not personally commit excludable crimes. He was occasionally directly involved in activities more closely associated with abuses conducted by the DAS in Colombia. The evidence and the commendations set out in the extract from his service record indicate that he had some involvement in a XXXXX 1994 raid, the capture of two persons in 1996, and the neutralisation of a terrorist plan in 1997.5 Since the DAS does not have a limited brutal purpose, complicity must be established by additional indications of the principal claimant's participation in the DAS's crimes.
DETERMINATION OF COMPLICITY:
Whether or not the principal claimant is complicit is essentially a factual question requiring evaluation of his particular circumstances.6 The Federal Court has enumerated six factors which should be considered to determine whether an individual is complicit in crimes against humanity.
These are listed as follows:
1. Nature of the organisation;
2. Method of recruitment;
3. Position/ rank in the organisation;
4. Knowledge of organisation's atrocities;
5. Length of time in the organisation; and
6. Opportunity to leave the organisation;
1. Nature of the Organisation:
The DAS was set up in 1962 to organise intelligence against the state's insurgencies.7 The DAS is divided into four main branches: intelligence, protection, investigations, and foreign affairs. The documentary evidence8 indicates that the DAS is included in Colombia's "security forces". Although the DAS is an independent organisation reporting to the President of the nation, it also works with the police and the military in Colombia.9
The principal claimant did acknowledge that part of the DAS's mandate was to gather intelligence against organisations working against the Colombian Government, and it provided intelligence reports to the nation's President and his advisors who would pass the intelligence information to the military and/or the police. The principal claimant also testified that the unit he worked for shared technical information with the police anti- XXXXX group, that the last two DAS directors during his service with the DAS, came to work for the DAS from the police, that military officers were seen visiting the DAS headquarters, and at times, the military officers were also appointed as DAS supervisors.
Direct DAS Involvement in Atrocities:
The documentary evidence indicates the DAS's direct involvement in murder, torture and disappearances on a widespread or systematic basis in Colombia. A report by Colombia's Attorney General10 included the DAS as a public institution that committed human rights violations generally and the Minister's disclosures confirm that the DAS has been directly implicated in murder,11 torture12 and enforced disappearances.13
Regarding murder, the documentary evidence14 indicates the following specific examples of the DAS's involvement in murders:
1. An armed undercover DAS agent was found with a list of 50 students. He was held responsible for at least one shooting at a university where five students and two professors were shot.
2. Charges were laid against two DAS agents for the murder of a communist youth leader.
3. The DAS were found to have a list of members of a political party. One of these members was shot, and others were followed, threatened and shot at.
4. Regarding enforced disappearances, the DAS is alleged to have participated in some 1700 disappearances since the mid-1970s including some 198 disappearances in the first nine months of 1990 alone.
The DAS's complicity in crimes committed by the paramilitaries:
The DAS has also been complicit in murder, torture, and disappearance carried out by the paramilitary groups. The DAS has been accused of collaborating with paramilitaries on a number of occasions.
1. The documentary evidence15 indicates that the Commission of Verification on Urabas report on violence, accused the DAS of aiding and abetting paramilitaries.
2. The documentary evidence16 indicates that Major Lazaro boasted that he received support from the DAS in his organisation of local paramilitaries.
3. The documentary evidence17 indicates that the DAS appears to have been involved in human rights violations in Sucre, either directly or indirectly or through complicity with the paramilitaries.
4. The DAS was implicated when the Colombian military and the police withdrew three days prior to the paramilitary massacre in San Carlos, Antioquia.18
Furthermore, intelligence sharing is the most common means of the DAS's specific complicity in paramilitary crimes against humanity.19 One example of such complicity is the massacre that took place in Barrancabermeja in May of 1998. In April and May of 1998, the DAS sent intelligence reports to the military and the police in Barrancabermeja, warning of a planned paramilitary massacre. Operating with the DAS's intelligence, the armed forces withdrew from the town, and the paramilitary gunmen, some of whom were reportedly wearing bullet-proof jackets with DAS insignia, entered the town, rounded up the citizens, questioned and terrorised them and murdered or disappeared 30 people. The DAS agents and other security forces made no discernible attempt to prevent the massacre or pursue the gunmen20 and, subsequent to the massacre, the DAS regional director and two DAS agents were punished for failing to prevent the massacre.21 In this regards, a Canadian independent tribunal heard testimony of witnesses of the massacre in May 1999, and the tribunal concluded that the Colombian Government must be held responsible for crimes against humanity committed in Barrancabermeja.22 Public security forces, including the DAS, were held responsible for that incident to have taken place.
Therefore, based on the evidence adduced, the panel finds that the DAS was involved in some of the atrocities associated with human rights in Colombia.
2. Method of Recruitment
The principal claimant testified that he joined the DAS voluntarily based on his friend's recommendations. He said that he needed employment at the time he joined them. He was attracted to this job because of stable employment with the Government of Colombia.
3. Position/Rank
The principal claimant was trained in the DAS academy for six months. He graduated with a designation as an XXXXX XXXXX. Later, his title changed to "secret agent" and then to "XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX".
Initially, he worked as a XXXXX in the Protection Department where he was assigned to protect high-profile individuals including the Minister of Justice and the XXXXX of El Tiempo newspaper. In 1992, he joined the XXXXX group which, in 1995, was moved to the XXXXX Department. The principal claimant testified that the XXXXX group had 12 to 15 agents, and it was located in the main DAS headquarters in Bogotá.
On XXXXX, 1998, the principal claimant was promoted to the rank of XXXXX XXXXX at the rank of level 9 which he stated was a very low rank. His testimony indicates that he started at the rank of level 3 as a student. He said that the top rank for non-university graduates was level 17. He stated that level 14 is the first rank for Specialized Detectives and level 17 was a rank for Specialized Detectives in charge of a group. In his testimony during counsel's questioning, the claimant indicated that he was in charge of one of the shifts. During re-examination by the Minister's counsel, the principal claimant stated that he worked as a supervisor of a shift when a regular shift supervisor was away on holidays.
Based on the evidence adduced, the panel is of the opinion that the principal claimant was a middle-ranking member of the XXXXX XXXXX group since he was at level 9 and on several occasions, he filled in as a shift supervisor. The panel is also of the opinion that the claimant was a faithful employee of the DAS, and because he upheld and followed the DAS's principles and mandate, he received constant promotions in his employment. As a result, in his final days with the DAS, he became an occasional shift supervisor.
In Sivakumar, the Federal Court, in making connection between rank and complicity stated that:
In my view, the case for an individual's complicity in international crimes committed by his or her organization is stronger if the individual member in question holds a position of importance within the organization. Bearing in mind that each case must be decided on its facts, the closer one is to being a leader rather than an ordinary member, the more likely it is that an inference will be drawn that one knew of the crime and shared an organization's purpose in committing that crime. Thus, remaining in an organization in a leadership position with the knowledge that the organization was responsible for crimes against humanity may constitute complicity." (para. 10)
4. Knowledge of Organization's Atrocities
At the hearing, the claimant admitted to hearing reports of allegations against the DAS on the television and reading them in newspapers. He acknowledged that, from approximately 1990 onwards, he would hear in the media about investigations of DAS members who had violated human rights. He testified that he frequently saw these reports.
In his testimony, the claimant indicated that, at the time of joining the DAS, he had knowledge about the police and the army committing human rights abuses, but he had not heard about the DAS committing such abuses. When asked as to when he became aware of the DAS being involved in committing human rights abuses, at one time he indicated he could not recall. Later he stated that in his first year of employment with the DAS, he did not hear about the DAS committing human rights abuses, but from 1990 onwards he had knowledge about the DAS committing such abuses. He testified that he was specifically aware of reports criticizing the DAS for its role in human rights violations that took place in Barrancabermeja.
Furthermore, in his testimony the claimant provided one notorious example of crimes against humanity perpetrated by DAS agents from his office when he described the case of Mr. XXXXX, the XXXXX of the Investigations Department's Anti-kidnapping Group. In approximately 1992, Mr. XXXXX, who was well known within the organisation, was sentenced to 55 years in prison for forced disappearances and torture. In his testimony, the claimant admitted discussing this case with his co-workers at the DAS. He said that he knew disappearances were a general problem in Colombia and that he was aware of DAS agents being accused of or being responsible for some disappearance cases.
The claimant denied any knowledge of the DAS responsibility for murder and torture. The panel does not believe that the claimant was unaware of the DAS's involvement in murder and torture. He knew Mr. XXXXX was punished for forced disappearances and torture as early as 1992. The DAS was a part of the state security forces involved in murder and torture during the 15 years he worked for them. He testified that he knew about the state's involvement in torture and murder from the TV and newspapers, and he knew about dead bodies appearing daily in Bogotá's streets bearing the unmistakable signs of abuse and torture.23 He said that the department, which collected these bodies, was in the same building and located adjacent to where he worked.
Based on the evidence adduced and for above mentioned reasons, and guided by the following case law, the panel finds that the claimant, in this case, had the knowledge, since 1990, that the DAS committed human right abuses. Evidence indicates that he had firm knowledge about the DAS committing human rights abuses, including torture, when Mr. XXXXX from the DAS was sentenced. And after the Barrancabermeja incident in 1998, the claimant had sufficient knowledge about the DAS committing human rights abuses in collaboration with the police, the army and the paramilitaries. He also admitted that human rights violations were addressed by DAS leaders at internal meetings he attended and publicly.
In Shakarabi,24 the Federal Court found that professed ignorance of human rights abuses may be found not to be credible. The Court stated that:
It is much too simple to say that one is unaware of barbaric actions of an organization in order to try to distance oneself from these barbaric actions. If, as in the present case, an individual lives and works in a country where persons around him are disappearing and where one hears of persons arrested and tortured, it appears to me to be totally unbelievable that one would not have knowledge of what is taking place". (para. 25)
In El-Kachi,25 the Federal Court found that knowledge of activities satisfies the mens rea element required for complicity. The Court cited the accomplice test from Penate stating that:
...in view of his experiences during 16 years in the SLA and the documentary evidence, the applicant had the knowledge of the nature and scope of the criminal activities in which the SLA was involved. He thus demonstrated personal and knowing participation in the crimes, satisfying the mens rea element.
The claimant provided contradicting information in regards to having been given training on human rights abuses. When asked by his counsel, the claimant indicated that human rights information was provided in memos and human rights seminars conducted by DAS leadership. He admitted that he personally attended meetings related to these issues. During subsequent examination by the Refugee Protection Officer (RPO), he stated that he did not attend specific human rights seminars but had "chats" with his co-workers and conferences related to human rights. During the Minister's counsel's redirect, the claimant denied attending human rights meetings and claimed he did not know what he was referring to earlier. During his counsel's redirect, the claimant indicated that the essence of human rights related information communicated at the DAS between approximately 1990 and 1998/1999 was simply that the DAS would not allow human rights violations to take place and whosoever committed such abuses would be tried and punished.
When asked to explain the above contradictions, the claimant could not provide a reasonable response. He indicated that he attended a few meetings where specific cases were not discussed, that lot of things had happened during his 15-year employment with the DAS. He said that he did not remember them exactly, that he did not remember whether his information on human rights violations by DAS members came from news reports or DAS meetings.
The panel does not find the claimant's response to be reasonable. In his earlier testimony, he had admitted knowing that the DAS had committed human rights abuses as early as 1990, that he had attended meetings and conferences and had "chats" with his co-workers about the DAS committing human rights abuses. As well, he had knowledge about a leader of the DAS being convicted and sentenced for committing human rights abuses. In his testimony, he admitted having knowledge of serious DAS atrocities, to the extent that he had considered quitting the organisation. When asked if he had protested to his superiors regarding the crimes committed by other DAS agents, the claimant admitted that he never thought of raising that issue with his superiors; instead, he focussed on doing his job properly. He then added that he considered himself as a lower-ranking agent, and he did not know if his protests would be taken into account. In Penate,26 the court held that:
..... a person who is a member of the persecuting group and who has knowledge that activities are being committed by the group and who neither takes steps to prevent them occurring (if he has power to do so) nor disengages himself from the group at the earliest opportunity (consistent with safety for himself), but who lends support, will be considered to be an accomplice. A shared common purpose will be considered to exist.
Based on the evidence adduced, the panel finds that:
* From 1990 onwards, the claimant had knowledge about human rights abuses conducted by the DAS.
* The claimant knew what "human rights abuse" meant.
* He never protested to his superiors in an attempt to prevent the abuse from continuing.
* He had ample opportunities to disengage himself from the DAS. Although he had thought about quitting the DAS, he did not do so, not even for his own safety after the incident of XXXXX, 1999, when FARC guerrillas shot him for failing to collaborate with them.
* He embraced the goals of the DAS, and by lending his effective support since 1990, when he first learnt of the atrocities committed by the DAS, he accepted the darker aspects of the DAS operations and international crimes committed by them.
In regards to the claimant's allegations that crimes committed by DAS agents were punishable is not consistent with the documentary evidence before the panel. In 1993, the IACHR27 reported that only 20% of crimes were investigated of which 4% ended in conviction, an impunity rate of 99.2%. In 1995, the US Department of State28 reported that 97% of all crimes and a higher percentage of political crimes go unpunished. In 2001, the UK Country Assessment for Colombia29 reported that the impunity rate for political crimes was virtually 100%. Of 2000 forced disappearances over a 15-year period in Colombia, only one case resulted in a military criminal sanction.30 The claimant's wife's testimony describing the situation in Colombia as "chaos" appears to be more accurate and genuine. Based on the documentary evidence and the claimant's wife's testimony, the panel finds that since the impunity rate is so high, it is not likely that crimes committed by the DAS would be punishable as the claimant alleges. The panel, therefore, does not believe the claimant's allegations that crimes committed by DAS agents were investigated and guilty agents were punished.
5. Length of Time in the Organisation
The claimant was a DAS agent for 15 years from 1985 to 2001. His PIF indicates that he enjoyed his work and was reluctant to leave because he was only five years away from pension.
6. Opportunity to Leave the Organisation
The claimant, in his testimony, admitted that he could have resigned from the DAS at any time without any risk to his personal safety.
Based on the evidence adduced, because of his lengthy service with the DAS, his knowledge, since 1990, about DAS committing human rights abuses, and the fact that he did not leave DAS when he could have done so at any time without any risk to his personal safety, the panel finds the claimant to be a complicit accomplice.
Widespread or Systematic:
A legal requirement commonly accepted as part of the definition of crimes against humanity is that they must be committed on a widespread or systematic basis (Rome Statute, Art. 7(1)). When considering whether crimes against humanity were committed by the DAS on a widespread basis, the number of DAS agents in Colombia relative to the other security forces were considered. The claimant's testimony indicated that he heard a lot more reports about abuses by the police and the army as compared to the DAS, but acknowledged that the smaller size of the DAS could explain why there were fewer incidents of human rights violations by the DAS. On the basis of per capita/per member crimes committed by DAS agents was equivalent to those committed by the army and the police.
The claimant's testimony indicates that in the year 2000, there were approximately 9000 agents working for the DAS. The Europa World Year Book 2001 indicates that in August 2000, there were 130,000 members of the Colombian army and 95,000 members of the police. Based on this Colombia had a ratio of 14.4 soldiers and 10.6 police officers to every DAS agent.
When records of human rights violations per security force are compared to account for these ratios, the number of abuses committed by the DAS agents is seen to be equally widespread or systematic as those of Colombia's other security organisations.
For example:
1. Insofar as Torture Complaints, in 1991 to 1992, the documentary evidence31 indicates that the DAS had nine complaints against them, while during the same period, the army and the police had 93 and 106 complaints, respectively. Based on an equal number of DAS agents compared to army yields 9x14.4=130 complaints as compared to 93 complaints against the army and 9x10.6=95 DAS complaints as compared to 106 complaints against the police.
2. A more recent comparison of human rights violations, the documentary evidence32 indicates that in the year 2001, the DAS committed 20 human rights violations as compared to 132 by the army and 97 by the police. Based on an equal number of DAS agents compared to army yields 20x14.4=130 human rights violations by the DAS compared to 132 by the army and 20x10.6=95 human rights violations by the DAS compared to 97 by the police.
The documentary evidence33 indicates that enforced disappearances were perpetrated by security forces, including the DAS, on a massive scale during the claimant's term of service with the DAS. The United States Department of State reports 462 torture cases committed by security forces, including the DAS between June of 1995 and October of 1996.34 As demonstrated above, the documentary evidence provides serious reasons for considering that DAS abuses were just as widespread as those of the police and the army when the ratio of personnel is considered.
Also, the DAS has been complicit with respect to crimes committed by the paramilitaries. Evidence indicates that the DAS committed human rights abuses in collaboration with the police, the army and the paramilitaries during the Barrancabermeja incident in 1998. The claimant admitted that human rights violations committed by the DAS during this incident were addressed by DAS leaders at internal meetings he attended and publicly.
CONCLUSION
The evidence adduced is compelling and credible that the DAS committed crimes against humanity and that the claimant is complicit in these crimes. The claimant was an active participant of an organisation responsible for widespread or systematic killings, torture and enforced disappearances of individuals and groups considered to be operating contrary to the interests of Colombia; as well, he had knowledge of these crimes. Even if the claimant was never the one to inflict the pain, he was a middle-ranking member of DAS and was aware of the atrocities committed by the DAS for a long time. He had opportunities to leave the DAS after knowing about the atrocities committed by them, but he elected to stay, even after he was shot by the FARC.
Therefore, based on the totality of the evidence before the panel, the panel finds that the claimant, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, falls within the parameters of Section F(a) of Article 1 of the Convention, and, as a result, based on Section 98 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, he is not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection pursuant to section 97(1a) and 97(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
Inclusion:
The panel considered the claims of the claimant's wife and his children.
Agents of Persecution:
The agents of persecution in this case are the FARC guerrillas. They identified themselves as the Urban Militias of the FARC guerrillas when they met the claimant for the first time in the first week of XXXXX 1999. Subsequent to this incident, the claimant and his wife received a number of threatening calls from them.
Based on the foregoing evidence, the panel finds that the agents of persecution in this case were the Urban Militias of the FARC, and they were motivated to harm him because he did not collaborate with them to provide instructions about XXXXX to their colleagues.
Nexus
The FARC is one of the two major leftist guerrilla organisations in Colombia. It is a political organisation with a political agenda. Although it is in opposition to the present government of Colombia, when invited, it participates in peace talks initiated by the Government of Colombia. The documentary evidence indicates that:
Peace talks initiated in 1999 between the government and the main armed opposition group (FARC), Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, collapsed on 20 February...35
In this case, the FARC was targeting the claimant because they wanted him to provide them instructions on explosives. The claimant's refusal to collaborate with the FARC is perceived by them as a defiance of their directives. In this case, the claimant is perceived by the FARC to be an opponent to their organisation and their activities in Colombia. Failing to collaborate with the FARC to provide instructions on XXXXX to their members is considered as an opinion against them.
As per Ward,36 political opinion is any opinion in which the machinery of the State is engaged. In this case, the FARC is not only an anti-government entity, it also participates in peace talks with the Government, initiated by the Government, and, therefore, the FARC is a component of the "state machinery".
Based on the above reasons, on a balance of probabilities, the panel finds that the claimant not providing instructions about explosives to members of the FARC guerrillas is interpreted to be an anti-FARC imputed political opinion. The panel finds, in this case, that a political opinion was imputed to the claimant, and, therefore, the claimant has established a nexus to the Convention refugee definition.
Objectively Well-founded Fear
Though there were credibility problems with regards to the claimant's position concerning exclusion, the panel finds no such problems with his and with his wife's testimony concerning what drove them away from Colombia.
In this case, the claimant worked for the DAS, a government security agency in Bogotá, Colombia. He was an expert with XXXXX. He gave courses about XXXXX to individuals who were taking courses to become members of the DAS. The documentary evidence37 indicates that in the case of the FARC, any state official is automatically seen as representing an oppressive regime against whom all means are justified in their revolutionary struggle, including kidnapping and killing of their families. Based on the aforementioned evidence, the panel finds that both the claimant and his family had the right profile to be targets of the FARC guerrillas.
The question then arises whether there is a serious possibility that the guerrillas would target the claimants should they return to Colombia. The claimant testified that, should he be returned to Colombia, he will be located by the FARC because they consider him to be their enemy for failing to comply with their orders to provide instructions about XXXXX to their members. The claimant's testimony indicates that the claimant's principles did not allow him to provide instructions about XXXXX to the guerrillas. As a result, upon his return to Colombia, the FARC will initially target him and force him to comply with their demands. Failing to achieve this, they will kidnap and/or kill his wife and children. His evidence generally agreed with the documentary evidence. For example, he indicated that the FARC had the technology to locate people they sought. The documentary evidence38 indicates that one specific feature of the conflict in Colombia is the high rate of kidnappings, which, in 2001, reached 3,041 persons, an average of 8 per day. Extortion practices, including ransoms and other forced payments are commonplace. The main perpetrators reportedly are guerrilla groups.
The most recent documentary evidence,39 not entered at the hearing indicates that the FARC has infiltrated almost all of the organisations in Colombia. The same document indicates that:
... For the middle and upper classes of individuals who have been victimized by extortion and intimidation at the hands of the guerrillas, it is even more difficult to escape. The guerrillas have sophisticated intelligence-gathering capabilities. They can track one's physical whereabouts through the use of taxi drivers, domestic servants, airlines and travel agencies. They have access to private bank records and credit card activities, and they can track someone down based on their paper trail.
In the same document, the associate professor at Stetson University College of Law indicated that members of the FARC, the ELN and the AUC are present in "nearly all the urban centres of any note in Colombia."
The same document indicates that the armed groups' capacity to locate and target threatened individuals remains unchanged since Alvaro Uribe Velez assumed the office of President in August 2002. According to the Georgetown University adjunct professor, both the guerrillas and the paramilitary groups often employ highly sophisticated databases and computer networks. An individual who is threatened in one area of the country will not be notably safer by relocating to another. Depending on the nature and reasons for the threat, the victims can be pursued relentlessly. There are countless stories of men and women receiving threats in Bogotá or Medellin after relocating from another area and attempting to live anonymously in the big city. Many have been killed after seeking refuge in another part of the country. There are also cases of people leaving the country for a period of months or years, and then being killed after returning. Memories are long and data is systematically recorded and analysed.
Based on the above documentary evidence, the panel finds that the FARC has the capabilities of tracking down their targets anywhere in Colombia, indicating that there is no viable internal flight alternative for the claimant's family in Colombia. The finds that the claimants have a well-founded fear of persecution at the hands of FARC guerrillas should they return to Colombia.
State Protection
The Colombian government authorities have failed to provide adequate protection to their citizens. The documentary evidence indicates that:
A major internal armed conflict between the Government and the leftist guerrillas, particularly the FARC and the terrorist organisation National Liberation Army (ELN)- as well as right-wing paramilitaries, particularly the terrorist organisation United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia (AUC), caused deaths of between 5,000 and 6,000 civilians during the year, including combat casualties, political killings, and forced disappearances. Serious violations of human rights were commonplace....40
The documentary evidence41 clearly indicates that Colombian authorities have been unable to stem the violence perpetrated by the guerrilla groups and the paramilitaries. The notion of obtaining state protection is made even more unrealistic by the fact that these insurgencies have infiltrated most of the state security organs.
The documentary evidence also indicates that even members of the parliament lack state protection in that they are kidnapped by the FARC from the assembly headquarters. The document indicates that:
On April 11, the FARC committed a daring daylight kidnapping of 16 members of the Valle del Cauca departmental assembly from the assembly's headquarters in downtown Cali. FARC operatives dressed in army uniforms announced that the building was being evacuated because of a bomb threat and hurried victims into a waiting bus painted in army colors....42
Furthermore, the documentary evidence indicates that one fifth of Colombia has no state protection whatsoever. The documentary evidence indicates that:
Threats against local authorities are common and countrywide. The precarious situation of mayors and council members and other municipal authorities is illustrative of the weakness of the state. Roughly one fifth of Colombia's municipalities are without state security presence (i.e. army or police). In many smaller municipalities the limited police presence is no guarantee against threats by illegal actors.43
Another document44 indicates that the FARC has bombed police stations including police headquarters in Bogotá injuring and killing several civilians and policemen. On May 2, the FARC forces launched an inaccurate gas cylinder bomb at AUC forces in the small town of Bojaya; the bomb struck the town church where about 300 civilians had sought refuge, killing 119 civilians including 45 children and wounding at least 105 others.
Based on the documentary evidence, the panel finds that state authorities are not capable of protecting themselves against the FARC, other guerrilla groups and paramilitaries, and, therefore, at the present time, they are not capable of adequately protecting the citizens in similar situations as the claimant's family in Colombia.
Therefore, based on the evidence adduced, the panel concludes that the claimants have rebutted the presumption of state protection and have clearly established that, in their case, the government of Colombia is not able to adequately protect them.
CONCLUSION
Based on the evidence adduced and the documentary evidence, the panel finds that there is a serious possibility that the claimant and his family will be persecuted at the hands of the FARC should they return to Colombia.
Even though the panel finds the claimant has a well-founded fear of persecution at the hands of FARC guerrillas, because there is no balancing as per Arica,45 he is excluded. Since the claimant, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, is excluded, he is not a Convention refugee nor is he a person in need of protection.
However, the Refugee Protection Division determines that XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX and XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX are Convention refugees.

Introduction
XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX (hereinafter "the claimant" or "the principal claimant") is a male citizen of Colombia. He claims to fear persecution at the hands of the National Liberation Army (ELN) on the grounds of his pro-government/anti-ELN political opinion. He also claims that he is at a risk to his life or of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment at the hands of the ELN, if he returns to Colombia.
XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX (the second claimant) is a female citizen of Colombia and is the spouse of the claimant. She claims to fear persecution on the grounds of her membership in a particular social group, namely, close family member of the claimant, at the hands of the ELN. She also claims that she is at a risk to her life or of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment at the hands of the ELN. The second claimant relied on the narrative of the claimant and bases her claim to refugee protection on the claimant's claim.
Allegations
The claimant made the following allegations in the narrative of his Personal Information Form.1
In 1999, the claimant's brother, a XXXXXXXXXXXX, was threatened with death by guerrilla and paramilitary groups due to his work with Internally Displaced Persons (IDP's). He was accepted as a landed immigrant through the Embassy of Canada in Bogota as a member of the political refugee class, RS4. Following his departure, the claimant's family began to receive threats from the ELN.
The claimant is an XXXXXXX. In 2000, after he started to work for the Government of the Department of XXXX with the XXXXXXXXXXXX, the claimant began to receive threatening phone calls, on approximately a monthly basis, at his office and his home from a representative of the ELN. The claimant was advised that, as a government employee, he was automatically declared a military target. The claimant received threatening letters from the ELN at his office and home, as well as floral arrangements and a note of condolence ("sufragio") used by the guerrilla as death threats.
Throughout 2001, the claimant sought protection from various authorities including the Municipal Office of XXXXXXXXXXX, the Ombudsman's Office ("Defensoria del Pueblo"), the Attorney General of the Nation ("Fiscalia") and GAULA. GAULA assigned to an investigator to the claimant's case but advised that, due to the intensity of the conflict and the large number of people receiving threats, it was impossible to provide individual personal security. The claimant changed telephone numbers, place of residence, daily routines and travel routes and transferred to a less public position in the
government. The claimant continued to receive threats from the ELN until he and the second claimant left Colombia in XXXXX 2002.
Analysis of the Principal Claimant's Claim
Credibility
I find the claimant to be a credible witness. He testified in a spontaneous and unembellished manner and there were no material inconsistencies in his testimony or contradictions between his testimony and the other evidence before me.2 Therefore, I believe the allegations he has made in support of his claim to be true.
Identity
The claimant's identity as a national of Colombia is established by his credible testimony and the supporting documentation filed, including, a certified true copy of his passport and citizenship card.3
Nexus
I find that the claimant fears persecution by reason of his political opinion, namely a pro-government/anti-ELN political opinion. The claimant's pro-government political opinion is established on the basis of his employment by the departmental government of XXXXXXX, Colombia, signalling his support of the established governmental system. The claimant's anti-ELN political opinion is established on the basis of the claimant's stated opposition of the ELN, his refusal to comply with their demands, his association with his brother, XXXXXXXXX, who eluded the demands of the ELN, and the fact that his participation in the established governmental system indicates an opposition to the irregular forces in Colombia, including the ELN. The political nature of the ELN is well established in the documentary evidence.
Persecution
The claimant fears being persistently threatened, kidnapped, physically assaulted, tortured and killed. The type of harm feared by the claimant constitutes persecution.
Well-foundedness of the Fear of Persecution
I find that there is a reasonable chance that the claimant will be persecuted if he returns to Colombia for the following reasons.
The claimant was persistently threatened with harm and death over a period of a year and a half,4 which is a example of past personal persecution.5 The documentary evidence indicates that the ELN engages in other forms of human rights violations feared by the claimant such as kidnapping, torture and extrajudicial killing.6 There is evidence of a similarly situated person having been persecuted in that the claimant's brother XXXX XXXXXXXX was vigorously threatened by guerrilla and paramilitary groups in 1999 due to his public service work as a XXXXXXXX for XXXXXXXX of displaced families. Based on the evidence that the claimant's brother presented to the Canadian Embassy in Bogota, Colombia, he was admitted to Canada as a member of the political refugee class along with his family.7
The claimant possesses a number of profiles, any one of which could result in the ELN persecuting him, according to the documentary evidence on the current political violence in Colombia.
The claimant has a particular profile as a former government employee as he was employed by the Government of the Department of XXXXXXXX.8 Documentary evidence indicates that, in addition to elected officials, employees of all levels of government, especially those in positions of responsibility, are persecuted by the ELN.9
As a professional XXXXXXXXX10 who owned property,11 the claimant fits the profile of persons generally perceived to belong to a class wealthy, professional and/or land-owning persons in Colombia. The documents on country conditions in Colombia indicate that the guerrillas kidnap and extort members of the middle and upper classes, both because they are deemed to hold opposing political views and because they are seen as a potential source of funds.12
The claimant possesses the profile of an individual who opposed to the methods and objectives of the ELN, both because he personally failed to comply with ELN demands and because he is related to an individual targeted by the ELN. Several letters from the ELN to the claimant indicate that the claimant and his family will suffer consequences if he does not meet their demands13 and the documentary evidence corroborates that persons who do not comply with demands made of them by the ELN are marked for persecution.14 The claimant's brother was targeted by the ELN for his work with XXXXX and after his brother XXXXX fled Colombia, the claimant and other family members were threatened by the ELN because the ELN could not find XXXXX.15 The documentary evidence establishes that relatives of persons who are, or have been, targeted by the ELN, are themselves often persecuted by the ELN because they are deemed to hold the same political opinion as the targeted relative or simply out of revenge against the initial target.16
State Protection
In assessing state protection for the claimant in the current Colombian context, I relied only on the items listed in the September 2003 Refugee Protection Division Package on Colombia that are marked with an asterisk.
In Villafranca,17 the Court of Appeal specified that,
... where a state is in effective control of its territory, has military, police and civil authority in place, and makes serious efforts to protect its
citizens from terrorist activities, the mere fact that it is not always successful at doing so will not be enough to justify a claim that the victims of terrorism are unable to avail themselves of such protection.18
The type of situation contemplated by the Court in Villafranca, specifically, a situation in which state protection, though imperfect, exists, is not the situation in Colombia today. The Government of Colombia is not in effective control of its entire territory; its military, police, judicial and civil authorities are significantly infiltrated by the guerrilla and paramilitary forces; its efforts to protect its citizens are genuine but are ineffective; and its inability to protect is not limited in scope but rather is so common-place that the citizenry has largely lost faith in the existing protection systems.
Lack of Territorial Control
The documentary evidence shows that the Government of Colombia is not in control of its entire territory. According to national and international sources, the guerrillas and paramilitaries have their respective areas of control in rural Colombia19 as well as in numerous urban centers.20 21 Furthermore, a report by the United Nations High
Commissioner for Refugees indicates that the guerrilla forces were striving to gain increased territorial control of Colombia in approximately 2001-2002.22
Infiltration of the Military, Police, Judicial and Civilian Authorities
The documentary evidence clearly shows that although there are military, police, judicial and civil authorities in Colombia, the guerrilla forces, including the ELN, are increasingly infiltrating these state institutions to the extent that their ability to function purely in the interest of the state is being compromised. Most sources acknowledge that the guerrilla forces have infiltrated the military at the lower ranks and some sources contend that the infiltration extends to the officer corps.23 24 There are also references to the infiltration of police forces by the guerrilla.25 Reliable sources report that the FARC and the ELN have infiltrated at least the local level judiciary, in part by forcing local politicians to appoint judicial officials who are under the influence of the guerrilla.26
There is indication of guerrilla infiltration in national ministries including the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and in departmental and municipal institutions.27 The
infiltrators collect intelligence and influence the awarding of public works contracts and personnel and budgetary decisions. According to expert sources, the guerrillas are running their own candidates in some municipal elections28 and it is estimated that guerrillas control public spending in roughly 20 per cent of the country. In sum, there is evidence of a significant degree of infiltration by the guerrilla in the protection agencies and authority structure in Colombia.
Ineffective Protection Efforts
The Government of Colombia makes efforts to protect its citizens; however, its efforts are insufficient to effectively address the vast need for protection against the guerrilla and paramilitary forces. A substantial network of protection apparatus exists, including the National Police, the Armed Forces,29 the Ombudsman's Office ("Defensoria del Pueblo"), the Attorney (or Prosecutor) General's Office ("Fiscalia"), the Inspector General's Office ("Procuraduria") and the GAULA units.
Since President Alvaro Uribe Velez took office in August 2002, there have been several initiatives to bolster protection provisions largely related to the National Police
and the Armed Forces .30 However, some recent initiatives, such as the limited state of emergency declaration and the establishment of "rehabilitation and consolidation zones", in which movement was restricted and curfews allowed, were found to be illegal.31 The government's Peasant Soldier Program ("Soldados Campesinos"), in which rural volunteers are given training in exchange for protecting state held territory, was met by an announcement by the ELN that these volunteers are labeled military targets.32 The Peasant Soldier Program, along with the government sponsored Civilian Informant Network, has been criticized by Amnesty International and the Colombian Commission of Jurists for drawing non-combatants into the conflict instead of protecting citizens.33 Significantly, in the same time period, the ability of the Attorney General's Office ("Fiscalia") to investigate and prosecute human rights cases has deteriorated and the Ombudsman's Office ("Defensoria del Pueblo") has a diminished capacity to monitor and prevent human rights violations.34
Scope of Inability to Protect
Finally, the state's inability to protect is not limited in scope. Protection of the population requires that human rights violators are routinely and appropriately punished, and the existence of such punishment factors significantly in the state's capacity to prevent human rights violations from occurring. The documentary evidence emphatically states that impunity for human rights violators is at a critical level in Colombia. Due to a lack of resources, protection for witnesses and investigators, co-ordination between government bodies and, sometimes, obstruction of justice, there is a high degree of impunity for the accused.35 In the case of the ELN, current documents show that the group continues to engage in kidnapping for ransom, detonating bombs in urban centres, blockading regions and municipalities, as well as declaring participants of the government's Peasant Soldier Program, military targets.36 The general conclusion of respected international organizations is that level of violence has remained almost the same since the beginning of Uribe's presidency in mid-2002 as it was in the years immediately prior.37
Summation on State Protection
Whether a country is making serious efforts to protect its citizens is a key consideration in assessing whether the requisite level of state protection exists. However,
even serious efforts taken to protect the citizenry must be viewed in the factual context to ascertain whether those efforts meet the protection needs of citizens in an actual sense. In the context of the current levels of political violence in Colombia, the state protection apparatus simply cannot provide meaningful protection for the many Colombians who are in grave danger of human rights violations, and, thus, protection does not adequately exist. The claimant testified that he approached several state protection agencies,38 and though it was acknowledged that he was in serious danger, the agencies advised him that they were unable to provide him protection39 because the intensity of the conflict and the volume of threats made against citizens made it impossible to provide each individual with protection .40 On the basis of above, I find that the state protection is not available to the claimant if he returned to Colombia and faced persecution.
Internal Flight Alternative
I find that there is no internal flight alternative for the claimant for the following reasons. The documentary evidence indicates that the ELN operates throughout much of the territory of Colombia, including all major cities. 41 Although not physically present
throughout the entire territory of Colombia, expert sources report that the ELN have highly sophisticated databases and computer networks that are capable of locating targeted individuals anywhere in the country.42 43 Significantly, the ELN, following some years of stagnation or decline, is currently increasing its ranks and armed actions44 and its increased intelligence and communications sharing with the FARC enhances its ability to successfully locate a targeted individual.
I also base my finding that there is no viable internal flight alternative for the claimant on the advice of The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, specifically, that decision makers not apply the notion of internal relocation alternative when assessing international protection claims against Colombia given the following factors prevalent in the Colombian context.45 These factors include the highly fluid and volatile nature of the conflict, the destruction of socio-economic infrastructure and widespread internal displacement, the inability of the Colombian government to extend their authority to significant areas of the country and the effective communications networks established by illegal armed groups that are capable of tracing and reaching targets throughout Colombia.
Analysis of the Second Claimant's Claim
The second claimant's identity as a national of Colombia is established by her written testimony46 and supporting documentation including a certified true copy of her passport, citizenship card, and other identity documents47 The second claimant's identity as the spouse of the principal claimant is established by her written testimony,48 the principal claimant's written and oral testimony and supporting documentation, namely, the marriage certificate certifying that the principal claimant and the second claimant are married.49
I find that there is a reasonable chance that the second claimant will be persecuted by reason of her membership in a particular social group, namely, close family member of the principal claimant, if she returns to Colombia for the following reasons. The second claimant experienced past incidents of persecution in that many of the threats made by the ELN specifically stated that the principal claimant's family members were objects of their threats.50 As the spouse of the principal claimant, who is the primary target of the ELN, the second claimant fits a profile of persons often persecuted by the ELN according to the documentary evidence.51
Conclusion
I find that there is a reasonable chance that the principal claimant will be persecuted by the ELN by reason of his pro-government/anti-ELN political opinion if he returns to Colombia.
Given the evidence with respect to the second claimant's claim and the positive determination of the principal claimant's claim, upon which the claim of the second claimant is based, I find that there is a reasonable chance the second claimant will be persecuted by the ELN by reason of her membership in a particular social group, namely, close family member of the principal claimant, if she returns to Colombia.
Accordingly, the Refugee Protection Division determines that XXXXXX XXXXXX XXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXX XXXXXXXX XXXXXXX are Convention refugees and accepts their claims to refugee protection. Having found that the claimants are
Convention refugees, I did not assess their claims to be persons in need of protection due to a risk to their lives or of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment or torture.

XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX is a 37-year-old citizen of Costa Rica. He fears persecution at the hands of a gang of bank robbers whom he believes to be members of the mafia in Costa Rica. The following family members of the principal claimant, all citizens of Costa Rica, base their claims on being members of a particular social group, that being family members of the principal claimant. They are: The principal claimant's wife, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX (35 years old), and the adult claimants' 4 children, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX (18 years old), XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX (15 years old), XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX (10 years old) and XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX (7 years old). I have considered if the claimants are Convention refugees or if they face a risk to life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment or a danger of torture in Costa Rica.
Determination
I find that the claimants are not Convention refugees, as their claims do not have a nexus to a Convention ground. I also find that they are not persons in need of protection for the reasons outlined below.
Jurisprudential Guidelines
The determinative issue in this claim is state protection. I considered1 whether the Jurisprudential Guides'2 decision TA2-14980 applies in this case and determine that the facts and the evidence regarding country conditions in this case are sufficiently close to those before the panel in RPD decision TA2-14980 because 1) they both deal with Costa Rican claimants seeking protection due to their fear of criminality, and 2) the issue in both is the determination of the availability of state protection for victims of crime. I considered the evidence submitted by the claimant 3. In addition, I considered the April 2003 RPD Information Package, which was not before the Jurisprudential Guide panel. In reaching my decision, I have assessed the claimant's own experiences in the context of the entirety of the evidence.
Allegations
The principal claimant alleges the following: In XXXXX 1998 he witnessed a bank robbery and called the police. The police arrived and the robbers fled with hostages
and money. The claimant's name appeared in the paper as the person who alerted the police. The day after the robbery the police stationed 2 guards outside the claimant's shop for a 2 week period, to protect him from retaliation, as they believed the perpetrators to be mafia members. One bank robber was captured shortly after the robbery and another one was captured at a later date. Some weeks later the thugs returned and beat and threatened the claimant and demanded $5000.00 as payback from the failed heist. The claimant went to the hospital and the police were called and went to see him in the hospital. The police said they would investigate. The claimant requested protection but was advised that he could not be provided with permanent around the clock protection, as they did not have the resources. The police said they could simply patrol the area on occasion. A week later the perpetrators returned to the claimant's shop and demanded money and beat and threatened him again, and his wife got a threatening call. The claimants did not contact the police or seek any state protection after that attack or at any time subsequently. They moved residences and the claimant came to Canada in XXXXX 1998 after he heard the criminals had been looking for him. The claimant's family members followed him to Canada in XXXXX 1998 and they all made refugee claims. The refugee claims were rejected and the family returned to Costa Rica in XXXXX 2001. In XXXXX 2001 they were threatened again by the same perpetrators and wanted to return to Canada to seek protection but could not afford it. Again, they did not contact the police or seek any state protection because they believed protection would not be forthcoming. In XXXXX 2002 the male claimant returned to Canada, and after being threatened the female claimant and the children returned to Canada in XXXXX 2002, and they all made repeat refugee claims.
Analysis
The claimant's identities as nationals of Costa Rica are established by certified true copies of their passports4 submitted by Citizenship and Immigration Canada as well as by their testimony.
The availability of state protection for the claimants is the determinative issue in these claims. Counsel for the claimant argued that facts in this matter could be clearly distinguished from the Jurisprudential Guidelines (JG) case TA2-14980, as the agents of persecution in the case at bar were members of the mafia and not youth gang members as in the fact scenario in the JG case. I find on the contrary that the analysis in the JG case applies to the cases at bar because it points to the numerous mechanisms available in
Costa Rica for persons who are victims of crime, such as the claimants before me. I therefore determine that TA2-14980 applies in these cases since the availability of state protection in Costa Rica has been comprehensively analyzed in TA2-14980 and that reasoning applies to the facts of this claim. As a result, I adopt the reasoning in TA2-14980.
The documentary evidence reveals that the Costa Rican government is making serious efforts to protect people who are victims of crime, such as the claimants in the case at bar. Furthermore, there are a number of recourses available in Costa Rica for the assessment, prosecution, and the granting of remedies resulting from the failure of the law enforcement agencies to conduct their work.
In the case at bar, I accept that the claimants may have been pursued by the persons whom the principal claimant reported as the bank robbers. However, I find that adequate state protection was available to them for the following reasons.
The claimant submitted documentary evidence highlighting the fact that the mafia exists in Costa Rica5 and the fact that there exists no witness protection program and, "while not urgent", it has been identified as lacking in the Costa Rican criminal justice system.6 Notwithstanding these facts, I find that while there is no witness protection program per se, there is ample documentary evidence before me to conclude that the state authorities in Costa Rica are willing and able to investigate criminals such as those that may have been pursuing the claimants, and are making serious efforts to do so.
The claimant said that after he was refused protection he did not return to the police because he thought it would be futile. I find that since the claimant was not satisfied with the police response to his request for protection, that he had recourse to other authorities in Costa Rica. I find that he did not make reasonable efforts to pursue all the avenues open to him.
For example, when asked if he went to the Investigative Judicial Police (OIJ) to report the crimes against him, he said that he did not. He said that the OIJ might have intervened if asked. However, he was scared and his only desire was to leave town. Besides, he said, the OIJ was located 80 kilometers from his home. He did not know why he did not go there but in fact they have very few officers and their role is investigation not protection. I find that the state authorities in Costa Rica could not protect the claimants unless they did an investigation, and there is no chance they would investigate if they were not made aware of the problems. I find the claimant's reasons for not pursuing the matter with other state authorities to be unreasonable. I find the onus was on him to search for remedies beyond the single refusal for protection he got from one police office. A claimant must do more than simply show that he went to some members of the police force and that his efforts were unsuccessful. The more democratic the state's institutions, the more the claimant must have done to exhaust all the courses open to him.7 I find that the appropriate course of action taken by a reasonable person would have been to pursue his case through the available authorities, rather than assuming that the process was flawed and take the extreme measure of leaving the country.
I find that if the claimants did report the subsequent events to the police or to the OIJ, having considered the previous actions of the police and all of the documentary evidence before me, I find that it is likely that the police would have investigated the matter and provided further protection to the claimants.
Finally, the claimants submitted a psychological report8 that concluded that 10-year-old XXXXX is fearful of the killings in Costa Rica and that this predisposes him to
the development of several psychiatric disorders. I find this assessment very concerning for the child and his family. However, I find that while this psychological assessment addresses XXXXX fears and potential risks to him with respect to his mental health, it does not address the availability of state protection in Costa Rica for this family and therefore has little probative value with respect to the determinative issue. In other words, XXXXX fearfulness does not impact on the state's ability to provide protection to him and his family and I cannot give it any weight in the matter before me.
I considered that Costa Rica 9 is a long-standing, stable, constitutional democracy with an independent judiciary providing effective means to deal with individual criminal cases. With this in mind, and in the context of this claim and the claimants' country of origin, I find that the claimants have not taken reasonable steps to seek protection in Costa Rica. I therefore find the claimants have not rebutted the presumption of state protection with clear and convincing evidence of the state's inability or unwillingness to protect them.
Given that there is state protection for these claimants in Costa Rica, I find that there is not a serious possibility that they would face persecution, nor is there a risk to
their lives, a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, or a danger of torture should they return to Costa Rica.
Accordingly, the RPD finds that XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX and XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX are not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection and rejects their claims.
