XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, "the claimant", is a citizen of Colombia, and he claims refugee protection in Canada pursuant to ss. 96 and 97 (1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).1
In advance of the hearing, the claimant was advised2 by letter dated XXXXXX, 2002 that, pursuant to subsection 170 (e) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act,3 the Minister intended to participate in the hearing. The claimant was notified that matters involving Article 1F(a) of the 1951 Convention have been raised by the claim, in light of his former status as a soldier in the Colombian armed forces.
At the hearing on October 27, 2003, the claimant was unrepresented. On that day, at the end of the hearing, he gave oral closing remarks, followed by observations by the Refugee Protection Officer (RPO). Mr. David Cranton participated as the Hearings Officer (Minister's Representative).
Following receipt of the Hearings Officer's submissions on the issues of Article 1F(a), the claimant retained Counsel. Thereafter, post-hearing, documents and further written submissions were received from the claimant's new Counsel, and, as well, from the Hearings Officer, in response to new Counsel's arguments.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant alleges the following. He is seeking refugee protection in Canada because he has been victimized by members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia - Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC). He received death threats from FARC, as he did not comply with their requests, when, as a recruiting officer for the XXX Brigade XXXXXX Unit, in XXXXXX, he was asked to grant military exemptions for some of FARC supporters.
At the end of his basic military service, around XXXXX 1991, the claimant was appointed an XXXXX to the newly-conscripted privates. Later, he became a Reserve Officer, with quick promotion to the rank of XXXXXX, as he was among the XXXXX XXXXXX at the end of his mandatory service.
In 1993, there was a call by the XXXX Brigade XXXXXXX Unit of XXXXX for Reserve Officers to assist in XXXXX XXXXXX XXXXXXX XXXXXX for the army. The claimant served part-time in this process of administrative XXXXX from 1993 until around XXXX 1996, and later4 from XXXXX 2000 to XXXX 2000.
The claimant alleges that in December 1995 he was approached by two members of FARC and given a list of names that FARC wanted to be exempt from compulsory
military service. He was promised compensation. The claimant immediately rejected the request. However, one week later he was approached by two different members of FARC and he was told that he had to comply or else he would face serious consequences. He alleges that sometime later, he received a call from someone who identified himself as the "big boss", and he was told it was his last chance.
The claimant did not report these incidents to his superiors or to the Colombian police. He alleges that he was confused and frightened. His fear increased when, on XXXXX, 1996, he learned that his brother had been murdered while driving his (the claimant's) car. He believes that he was the intended target.
The claimant left XXXXX and pursued XXXXXXXX studies in Bogota, with a view to becoming a XXXXXXX. He graduated from XXXXXXX school in XXXXXXX 1999, and then did some XXXXXXX training. While awaiting a call up for employment from XXXXXXXXX, he returned to XXXXXXX, and he resumed his volunteer work as a reserve officer with the XXXXXX Brigade XXXXXX office, either in XXXXX 1999 or in XXXXX 2000.
While back in XXXXXXX, around XXXX 2000, he received another call from the "big boss" and he was told that FARC was aware that he had returned to the area. He was told that he had one week to leave or he would die. He quickly left Colombia in XXXXX 2000 and went to Spain where he lived for about one year. He arrived in Canada on June 7th, 2001.
In her observations, the RPO pointed out that there were areas of discrepancy and inconsistency in the testimony, and it was pointed out that the plausibility of some aspects of the allegations needed to be reviewed.
DETERMINATION
After careful consideration of all of the evidence, the RPO's observations, and the submissions of Counsel and the Hearings Officer, I am of the opinion that the exclusion provision (Article 1F(a)) of the Act is applicable in this claim and that the claimant is not a Convention refugee. I concur with the conclusion of the Hearings Officer that the claimant comes within the parameters of Article 1F of the Refugee Convention.
ANALYSIS LEADING TO DETERMINATION ON EXCLUSION:
(i) The law and statutory provisions
I am guided, primarily, by the decisions in Ramirez,5 Sivakumar6 and Moreno,7 and I note the following.
In Ramirez,8 the Court found that the burden of proving that the claimant should be excluded from determination as a Convention refugee is on the party so asserting, rather than on the claimant to demonstrate that he should not be excluded from such status. It held, further, that the test for determining whether there are "serious reasons for considering" that a crime has been committed, require less than a balance of probabilities.
The Court9 also reviewed the degree of involvement required on the part of the claimant in order to be excluded from Convention refugee status, and found that accomplices, as well as principal actors, may be subject to exclusion. It was held that a person could be considered to be an accomplice, if there is personal and knowing participation in the persecutorial act, and the Court went on to provide examples of this test. It stated10 that
"... mere membership in an organization which from time to time commits international offenses will be sufficient for exclusion from refugee status where the organization is principally directed to a limited, brutal purpose, which may, by necessity, involve personal and knowing participation in persecutorial acts...someone who is an associate of the principal offender can never be said to be a mere onlooker..."
The Court11 also looked at the claimant's opportunity to have left the organization earlier, without risk of harm to himself, and the length of time in the organization.
In Sivakumar,12 the Court looked at the method of recruitment (voluntarily) in the claimant's organization, the nature of the organization (violence/killings), the claimant's position/rank in the organization, including his high level promotions, the claimant's opportunity to leave the organization and the claimant's length of time in the organization.
In Moreno,13 the Court further clarified that a claimant can be held accountable where the organization in which he is involved is premised on achieving political or social ends by any means necessary, while still considering that mere membership in the organization involved in international offenses is not sufficient basis on which to invoke the exclusion clause.
(ii) The claimant's specific role/activities in the Colombian armed forces that give rise to a consideration of complicity:
In this claim the relevant factors for consideration are: the nature of the organization (the Colombian army); the claimant's rank; his knowledge of the atrocities; opportunity to leave the army and period of time spent in the army.
The written narrative, and his oral responses reveal that the claimant worked for at least three years as a XXXXXXXX officer with the XXX Brigade XXXXXXXX office in XXXXXX. At the end of his basic army service he was selected among XXXX XXXXX XXXXX soldiers of his group that were being made reservists.
The claimant was a 1st class reservist with the rank of XXXXXXXX in the army reserve, and he was one of XXXXX officers selected to assist in the XXXXX work. The XXXXXXXX entailed having interviews with XXXXXX XXXXXX XXXXXXXX XXXXXXXXX XXXXXXXXXXX XXXXXXXXXX XXXXXXX XXX for the army.
The claimant did two terms of office with the XXXXXX unit. He worked from 1993 to XXXXXX 1996. On completion of his studies at the XXXXXXXX in 1999 in Bogota, he returned to XXXXXXX and resumed work with the XXXXXXXXXX office, either in XXXXXX 1999 only, or from XXXXXXX 2000 until XXXX 2000.
Next door to the claimant's office, the XXX Brigade XXXXX unit, there was an office, or army command, of the regular army XXXX Brigade, and there were times when there was dialogue between both offices, when there was a specific need. For example, sometimes, the Commanders of the XXX Brigade army office personally visited the XXXXX office to give a final say as to who was to be XXXXXXX.
The claimant was involved in the XXXXX XXXXXX (XXXXX, XXXXand XXXX), for roughly six (6) weeks per year. He stated that an additional six (6) weeks of his time was probably spent in occasional meetings/sessions on policies. In each XXXXXX XXXXXXXXXX XXXXXX XXXX XXXXXX. However, the final decision on final XXXXX XXXXX XXX XXfor the army was made by the Commander of the army unit to which they were to be assigned.
The claimant severed his connection with the army, only after he had allegedly received threatening calls from FARC who sought his assistance in providing military exemptions for their members.
In summary, the claimant worked as a XXXXX officer for at least three years, and the evidence does not show that the was under duress to do that. He was a volunteer.
(iii) The documentary evidence on the Colombian armed forces
Section 98 of IRPA14 states that persons referred to in Article 1F(a) of the Refugee Convention are not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection, and states, in part:
"The provisions of this Convention shall not apply to any person with respect to whom there are serious reasons for considering that:
" (a)he has committed a crime against peace, a war crime, or a crime against humanity, as defined in the international instruments drawn up to make provision in respect of such crimes..."
Credible sources cited in the documentary evidence15 state that the Colombian armed forces have been guilty of committing gross human rights violations against the civilian population for decades, before and during the claimant's period of service. One such source16 says the following:
"...violations of international humanitarian law- the laws of war- are not abstract concepts in Colombia, but a grim material of everyday life. War bursts into the daily activities of a farm, a village, a public bus, or a school with the speed of armed fighters arriving down a path or in four-wheel drive vehicles. Sometimes armed men carefully choose their victims from lists. Other times, they simply kill those nearby, to spread fear. Indeed, a willingness to commit atrocities is among the most striking features of Colombia's war...the Colombian army teaches its officers the basics of international humanitarian law and makes instructional material available to officers, professional soldiers, and recruits...
...Nevertheless, after examining hundreds of cases and interviewing many officers, government investigators and civilians who have witnessed violations, Human Rights Watch concluded that the army continues to engage in serious violations of the laws of war, with little apparent will to investigate or punish those responsible. At the root of these violations is the Colombian army's consistent and profound failure or refusal to properly distinguish civilians from combatants..."
Other relevant documentary information,17 as cited by the Hearings Officer, shows that the Colombian army has been implicated in murder, torture and enforced disappearances, generally, and during the time of the claimant's service in that army and states as follows:
"...the information received by the Special Rapporteur shows that violations of the right to life are continuing to occur on a large scale and that there are no indications that an improvement is foreseeable in the short term. Members of the army, paramilitary groups, the police, and to a lesser extent guerrilla groups are reported to have been responsible for a large number of violations of the right to life..."18
"...during 1990 and 1991 the army launched major offensives against guerrilla forces in several parts of the country. Little or no effort was made to protect the civilian population during these operations...Military commanders routinely claim that unarmed civilians extrajudicially executed by soldiers were guerrillas killed in combat. Blaming the guerrillas is another of the army's usual responses to accusations of human rights violations..."19
The United States Department of State reports20 on Country Conditions in Colombia for the years 1991 and 1993 give the same grim picture and states that members and units of the army and the police participated in a number of human rights violations including extrajudicial killings, disappearances, torture and arbitrary detention, and that the army is reluctant to distinguish between guerrillas and non-combatants during counterinsurgency operations.
Further, a Report21 of 1994, prepared by the Inter-Church Committee on Human Rights in Latin America (ICCHRLA) states :
"...during its two most recent visits to Colombia, ICCHRLA representatives travelled to several conflicted zones in the country and received reliable reports of the same pattern of violations that have been signalled in the past. These include extrajudicial executions of civilians by military personnel which are later presented as " guerrillas killed in combat"; indiscriminate bombing and aerial strafing of communities where the military suspect a guerrilla presence and forced recruitment of civilians who are obliged to dress in military uniforms and act as guides in conflictive zones..."
The role of the Mobile Brigade is particularly relevant in this analysis. In particular, the XXXXX Brigade of the army which, as the claimant testifies, maintained an office adjacent to the XXXXX office where he worked, has committed atrocities.
A general commentary on the Mobile Brigade is as follows:
"...the centrepiece of army strategy is the Mobile Brigade. The Mobile Brigade is conceived as a highly mobile force equipped with weaponry and vehicles suitable for the country's rugged, often densely forested countryside...Mobile Brigades are composed of professional soldiers who volunteer..."22
"...since their creation in 1990 the army's Mobile Brigades have been accused of frequent and serious human rights violations against civilians. These specialist counter-insurgency brigades are made up of professional soldiers..."23
The claimant testified that he was aware of a parallel process of XXXXX volunteer soldiers. Whether he was involved in that particular process or not during his work of at least three years with the XXXXX Brigade XXXXX office, the documentary evidence24 highlights many instances of gross human rights violations by the Mobile Brigades, including XXXXX Brigade of the army, and by Commanders of the XXXXX Brigade of the army. For example, a November 1996 Human Rights Watch Report25 identifies the XXXXX Brigade in XXXXX as one of the units primarily devoted to fighting guerrillas and implicates the Brigade in human rights violations. Several Commanding Officers of the XXXXX Brigade have been accused26 of gross human rights violations and of colluding with paramilitary groups in committing human rights violations.
(iv)The claimant's/ counsel's arguments
The claimant gave inconsistent testimony about his involvement with the XXXXX office, beyond 1999. However, some very specific questions were asked at the hearing, and the claimant is not correct when, post-hearing, he submits27 through Counsel, that he did not testify that his activities with the XXXXX office went beyond XXXXX 1996.
Counsel submits, in part:
"...from this point in 1996 through XXXXX 1999 the claimant testified that he was a full-time XXXXX student.
The Minister, in his submissions indicates that he believed the claimant to have also been involved with the army from XXXXX to XXXXX, 2000, however the claimant denies that he was involved with the army in any capacity other than a social one (he had friends in the army and also played soccer with them). Certainly, information about army work from XXXXX to XXXXX, 2000 is not in the claimant's work history, nor is it contained in his narrative..."28
At the hearing, on October 27, 2003, in his oral reply to the Refugee Protection Officer's (RPO) observations, the claimant acknowledged that there were discrepancies, but only in the dates, and not in the facts. However, when he was specifically asked when did he stop wearing the uniform, he responded that it was in XXXXX 2000, after getting the call. He was then asked, when did he return to the reserve operation, and he responded that he resumed in XXXXX 2000 and that when he received the call, he stopped.
In response to an earlier question, however, the claimant stated, as interpreted, that he took a break in 1996 for two years; that he came back in 1999 and got involved for about one month in XXXXX 1999, but that he only got involved in one XXXXX XXXXX.
It is clear, therefore, that the claimant had two stints. He participated a second time, after his XXXXX studies, whether it was in XXXXX 1999 or from XXXXX 2000 to XXXXX 2000. And, there is no dispute that the second call from FARC was in XXXXX 2000, while he was in XXXXX, and still officially a member of the army reserve. He left only as a result of the alleged threat from FARC.
The claimant stresses that he was not complicit in the armies operation, since he only performed administrative functions and was never a combat officer. He states that there is a vast difference between the XXXXX Brigade XXXXX Unit and the XXXXX Brigade infantry, and that he never participated in the combat and massacres that are attributed to the XXXXX Brigade. Moreover, he says, he knew that the XXXXX Brigade had a good reputation.
In his submissions, counsel emphasizes that the claimant's duties as a mere XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX office, and the nature of his job itself, mean that the claimant cannot be seen as an accomplice in the crimes committed by the Colombian army. Counsel also argues that "volunteer work on a part-time basis does not constitute membership in an organization",29 and that "the claimant indicated in his testimony that he was unaware that human rights violations were being perpetrated by the army although he had heard reports of human rights violations perpetrated by guerrilla activities."30
I do not agree with Counsel's submissions in this area. The claimant's testimony, as interpreted at the hearing, is as follows. When asked what did he know of the Colombian army, after graduating, the claimant responded that he knew that the XXXXX brigade had a good reputation. When he was further asked, what did he hear of the Colombian army, he responded that he heard that the Colombian army had been involved in human rights violations; he heard and saw it on TV, but it involved other Brigades. He said that he doubted it at the time because his experience at the XXXXX brigade was that they were decent people, and that what he saw on the TV related to activity in combat zones.
In my view, that response establishes that the claimant had some awareness of the activities of the army, and his complicity is established. Even if the final decision on those chosen was left to his senior personnel officer, or to the senior personnel of the army, the claimant was involved in the XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX for the fight. That was the purpose of the XXXXX process in which he was involved. Whether or not, neither he nor any member of the XXXXX brigade XXXXX team was ever in a combat zone, never fired a rifle nor ever met or heard of all of the tainted commanding officers of the Colombian army, they participated in the process. Indeed, the claimant testified that there were times when there was actual direct dialogue with Commanders of the XXXXX brigade army, whose office was next door to the XXXXX office.
Therefore, it is not plausible that, during his volunteer work, the claimant had no knowledge of the operations and activities of the army, including the human rights violations in the combat zones, nor did he know of the Commanders that have been cited31 as having been guilty of gross human rights violations, as pointed out by the Hearings Officer. The claimant professed no knowledge of these Commanders, except General XXXXX XXXXX.32 He also submits that he was at University and not part of the process, during the period of atrocities attributed to these Commanders. He did
admit that he was aware of reports of incidents such as the San Rafael, San Carlos and El Aro massacres. He admitted that crimes attributed to General XXXXX were very much in the news. The fact is that, on the evidence, the claimant did participate with the XXXXX Brigade XXXXX XXXXX after some of these incidents, as he did participate in XXXXX XXXXX, either in XXXXX 1999, or XXXXX 2000. He had knowing participation.
In addition, the claimant was asked what influence did the TV news about the army's operation have on him, and his reply was that it determined whom they should XXXXX; that for example, "XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX it meant that they would not get involved in things that were bad". Clearly, therefore, the XXXXX XXXXX is an important one for the army, and a person involved, such as the claimant, whether military full-time or part-time, or civilian, is likely to have knowing participation in the army's activities, including its policies.
Counsel cites Ramirez33 and Cardenas34 and states that the claimant's work as a volunteer does not qualify him as a member of the Colombian army. He states that the claimant cannot be connected to the alleged criminal activities of the Colombian armed forces. Part of counsel's arguments, also, is that the Minister has not provided evidence to confirm that there was widespread awareness by the public regarding human rights violations during the relevant period (XXXXX 1993 through XXXXX 1996). Counsel cites documentary evidence35 which states that part of the negatives of the situation in Colombia is that there has been insufficient public reports in Colombia about the human rights violations perpetrated by all sides, that there is a silence of the mass communications media, and that it is plausible that the claimant was unaware of the instances of violations by the army.
I do not agree with Counsel's conclusion. The claimant was a 1st class reserve officer with a rank of XXXXX and member of the Colombian army. In addition, on the issue of knowing participation, in my opinion, the Minister properly cites the Court's finding in Bazargan36 in which the Court said:
"... in our view, it goes without saying that "personal and knowing participation" can be direct or indirect and does not require formal membership in the organization that is ultimately engaged in the condemned activities, It is not working within an organization that makes someone an accomplice to the organization's activities, but knowingly contributing to those activities in any way or making them possible, whether from within or from outside the organization..."37
The Hearings Officer further referred to the Court of Appeal's decision in Ramirez and submits the following:
"...Justice MacGuigan went on to establish "personal and knowing participation" and a "shared common purpose" as the essential requirements for finding of complicity, formulating the following test: "at bottom, complicity rests... on the existence of a shared common purpose and the knowledge that all of the parties in question may have it""
...In Harb, a recent Court of Appeal decision, Decary J.A, confirmed that personal commission of crimes against humanity is not required - one can be complicit by association. Once the organization with which one was associated has committed excludable crimes, and the requirements for complicity imposed by precedent are met, the Article 1F (a) exclusion applies even if the specific acts committed by the individual are not crimes against humanity..."
Further, on the issue of the awareness of the atrocities and human rights violations, in my opinion, the claimant cannot be deemed to be unaware of these facts. As cited above,38 these facts have been publicized in the DOS reports, and as well, by credible sources such as Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch and the ICCHRLA.
I have reviewed Counsel's references39 to the case law, and I note the submissions wherein he states that "even if it is determined that the claimant's volunteer, part-time work for the organization constitutes membership it is submitted that he was no more than a "mere" member of the organization and therefore should not be excluded from refugee consideration..."40
I find that I must disagree with counsel. In my opinion, the claimant was more than a "mere" member. He was an officer involved in the XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX for an army which has been cited as having been involved in widespread or systematic murder, torture and enforced disappearance of guerrillas and civilians. He contributed to the activities. He was one of only four reservists selected to assist in the XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX for the Colombian army in XXXXX. He did that job for at least three years. He did not disassociate himself at any early opportunity and he only left the army, allegedly after his difficulties with FARC. From all credible reports, that army has committed widespread and systematic crimes against humanity, and it was common knowledge.
Counsel's submissions that there may not have been widespread awareness by the public, including the claimant of the army's human rights violations do not apply to the claimant. He had heard about the violations, according to his oral testimony, and his post-hearing submissions are not accurate.
(v) The Conclusion/Findings
Based on the above, I find that there are serious reasons for considering that the claimant, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, has been an accomplice in crimes against humanity during his service with the Colombian army. Accordingly, he falls within the parameters of Article 1F(a) and is excluded from protection pursuant to s.98. He is not a Convention refugee nor a person in need of protection.

Application to Reinstate
I have considered the contents of the application to reinstate, the applicant's file, and Refugee Protection Division (RPD) Rule 53.
I am not persuaded that the applicant has been denied natural justice or that it is otherwise in the interests of justice to reinstate this claim. It would appear that the RPD gave the applicant a reasonable opportunity to pursue her claim and that she withdrew it pursuant to advice of counsel of choice. The claimant was represented by the law firm of Green and Spiegel when she withdrew her claim on October 21, 2003.
Even if such advice of counsel of choice was bad, that is a counsel/client matter that must always remain strictly between claimant and counsel. It cannot be a concern of the RPD. The RPD does not have the power or the tools to supervise these relationships in any way at all.
Moreover, there is no logical reason why the principle of caveat emptor should not apply. Claimants should exercise care in choosing counsel. And, if claimants do not, it should be those who do not exercise care that should be fairly forced to bear the loss, rather than all of the rest of the claimants waiting to be heard by the RPD, who have exercised care in prosecuting their claims, and whose hearings must necessarily be delayed if claims were reinstated solely for this reason.
The application is denied.

XXXXXXXXXXX, a citizen of Sri Lanka, claims refugee protection pursuant to sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act,1 (IRPA). These are the reasons for the negative decision in this claim.
The claimant's two previous claims2 were rejected in March 1999 and January 2001. The first panel did not believe the claimant's identity and the second panel did not believe his story. As the Immigration Act has changed since the claimant's last hearing, I applied the doctrine of res judicata with respect to his claim under section 96 and assessed his claim in regards to sections 97(1)(a) and (b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.3 I considered the new evidence presented in this claim, namely, that the claimant had learned from his father that in December 2001, his younger brother was picked up by the army and has disappeared.
Analysis:
Identity/Credibility:
I will assign the benefit of doubt and accept that the claimant is a Tamil-speaking Muslim from Sri Lanka. However, who exactly he is, is still an issue. Section 106 of IRPA states:
106. The Refugee Protection Division must take into account, with respect to the credibility of a claimant, whether the claimant possesses acceptable documentation establishing identity, and if not, whether they have provided a reasonable explanation for the lack of documentation or have taken reasonable steps to obtain the documentation.
I find that in this case the claimant did not provide acceptable documents to establish his identity and that he did not display due diligence in the pursuit of establishing his claim for protection. The claimant has known since receiving his first decision in March 1999 that the birth certificate and postal identity card, which he presented, were not considered trustworthy and persuasive evidence; however until this day he has not made any efforts in order to rectify this situation. Given that the second claim was turned down because of a further lack of credibility, one would expect such a claimant to make a special effort to obtain corroborating documents, however nothing was done. I took into account Rule 7 of the Refugee Protection Division Rules and the "Commentary" to that rule, when coming to this finding. Rule 7 states that,
7. The claimant must provide acceptable documents establishing identity and other elements of the claim. A claimant who does not provide acceptable document must explain why they were not provided and what steps were taken to obtain them.
I realize that a refugee claimant does not necessarily have to submit corroborating documentation to further a claim, however in this case, the claimant has gone through the refugee process twice and he claims to be well educated with 12 years of formal education. I find for a claimant with such a profile to indicate that his father let him down or to blame his depression for the neglect4 is not sufficient. The claimant showed that he knew for many years that he could not rely on his father to get documentation. However, he did not show that he made any effort to initiate requests from Canada directly to, for example, his school, mosque or the grama sevaka, in order to at least establish his personal identity and his whereabouts during material times. His counsel then suggested that he could go to the Sri Lankan Embassy to get a passport. However, he did not provide trustworthy and persuasive testimony as to why he had not taken this initiative prior to the hearing. I find that the claimant did not provide more documentation both in regards to his identity and his claim for persecution because his claim is not built on the truth.5 Based on the above, I find that I cannot give weight to his new evidence, namely, his unsupported statement that his brother was taken by the army and disappeared in December 2001.
Would the removal to Sri Lanka subject a young Tamil speaking Moslem to a serious possibility of persecution or to a danger of torture or to risk to his life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment?
After perusing the documentation6 in regards to Tamil speaking Moslems and the return of failed refugee claimants this question has to be answered in the negative. In addition, President Kumaratunga, in response to rioting of Moslems and Hindu mobs in Trincomalee has directed the acting Inspector General of Police to issue written instructions to the police stations in the eastern provinces to ensure the security of the Muslim community.7
Dr. XXXXXXXXXX Letter:8
This letter indicates that the claimant is depressed and he became emotional during the hearing and started to cry. Even though his state of mind is understandable, after all two of his claims were turned down, however, tears in a refugee hearing are not always signs of the truth of the allegations. I find that this letter cannot be used as corroborating evidence in support of his allegations, as he could as easily have lied to the doctor as he did in his hearings.
Conclusion:
For the above reasons, the Refugee Protection Division rejects this claim to refugee protection and finds that the claimant is not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection within the meaning of sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

The claimant alleges he is a citizen of Albania and fears returning there because he will be the target of the XXXXXX family in a blood feud like situation which involves the entitlement to a parcel of land by the claimant's family. The details are set out in the narrative to the PIF1 and will not be repeated here. There is also a political element to this claim as the XXXXXX family are prominent Socialist members, while the claimant and his family are Democratic Party (DP) members and supporters. This case is not purely based on political opinion, nor is it a traditional blood feud case based on the Kanun of Lek, as I am familiar with in Albanian cases. However the combination of factors including the traditional nature of vengeance in Albania and the political background of the families, establishes that the claimant faces a risk to his life in Albania in the meaning of s. 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).2
Analysis
Identity
The claimant's personal identity is established by a certified true copy of his passport attached to Exhibit M-1 and by the documents in Exhibit C-2 which include his birth certificate, family certificate, and drivers' license. The attestation from the XXXXX Commune3 establishes the fact that his family had a dairy on the property in question. The fact that the property was returned to his family is documented by a certificate of the XXXXXX Commune.4 The DP background of his family as well as his own membership in the DP Youth Forum is established in the documents.5 The certificate from the DPYF6 corroborates the claimant's testimony that a grenade was thrown at his house in 2002 and that the XXXXX family has since taken control of the properties. The claimant has documented all the major elements in his claim. In addition, while some of the information is confused, his statement at the Port of Entry7 was generally consistent with his PIF narrative.
Risk to Life or Risk of Cruel and Unusual Treatment or Punishment
The claimant testified that should he return to Albania he will be subjected to a risk to his life since this was the threat made to him personally by members of the XXXXXX family. According to section 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, a person in need of protection must demonstrate that he would personally face this risk having regard to his own circumstances. I find that the claimant is personally at risk because of the personal nature of the threat made against him. I find that the risk of harm feared by the claimant is not one generally faced by others in Albania.
Standard of Proof
I have considered the standard of proof to be applied in assessing the risk of harm under section 97(1)(b). In my opinion, the test is whether the claimant faces a reasonable
chance or serious possibility of a risk to his life or of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. The Act is silent as to the appropriate standard of proof to be used in applying s. 97(1)(b) and it seems logical that it should be consistent with the standard of proof for establishing a well-founded fear of persecution under the Convention. Both the Convention ground and this ground deal with a prospective risk of serious human rights violations and the harm contemplated under s. 97(1)(b) is no less serious than the harm to be protected against under the Convention. Further, a claimant who is fleeing from his country because of a serious risk of harm has the same difficulties in proving his case under s. 97 as he would under s.96. Therefore, a claimant should not have to establish the prospective risk to a higher degree of certainty than under the Convention. This argument becomes more compelling in a case like this, where the claimant might or might not have a nexus to a Convention ground depending on how one analyses this claim to determine whether it can meet the rather imprecise criteria for political opinion.8 If it does have a nexus, the claimant would only need to show a lower form of harm (persecution) on the Adjei standard. Otherwise if it were determined that the standard is higher under s. 97(1)(b), the risk to his life must be proven on a balance of probabilities. While I am satisfied that the risk the claimant faces is life-threatening and meets the Adjei test of "serious possibility", I would be hard pressed to say whether the risk is at the level
of 51 percent, in which case the claim succeeds, or rather is merely at the level of 45 percent, and thus must reject the claim.
In considering and applying the standard of proof to be applied in this case, I take into account relevant International and Canadian jurisprudence. In Kacaj9 the U.K. Immigration Appeal Tribunal discussed the practical and legal implications of a tribunal using different legal tests when applying different protection legislation in one hearing process. It specifically noted the practical difficulty of applying two legal tests to the same set of facts in a given hearing. It noted that the various expressions used in reference to the legal test for asylum cases, namely "reasonable chance," "substantial grounds for thinking", and "serious possibility", were taken to refer to the same degree of risk as a "real risk". I am aware that there is conflicting Canadian and international jurisprudence on the issue of the standard of proof to be applied in these cases. Similarly, before Adjei10 was decided, there was conflicting international and domestic opinion on the standard of proof to be applied in cases decided under the Refugee Convention, however; Canadian courts ultimately rejected the "balance of probabilities" standard in
favour of the "reasonable possibility" standard:11
The "reasonable possibility" test is the appropriate compromise between respect for the Convention's commitment to anchor protection decisions in objectively observable risks and the need simultaneously to avoid the establishment of an inappropriately high threshold of concern.12
In Thangasivam13 the Federal Court, in deciding a motion to stay the Applicant's removal pending the outcome of his application for leave and for judicial review concerning the Federal decision of the PRRA officer, stated in obiter that a "balance of probabilities" standard applies to ss. 96 and 97 of the IRPA. Similarly in Li14 the Court in analysing s.97 found that the "balance of probabilities" standard should apply. However, the Court in Tameh15 upheld the Panel's reasoning in applying the Adjei test to ss. 96 and 97. This was a decision dealing directly with the issue of one standard of proof for all three grounds. I also note that the CIC Guidelines issued for Post-Determination Refugee Claimants in Canada (PDRCC) reviews, the precursor of the s. 97(1)(b) provision, set the standard of proof at "less than a clear probability, or even a balance of probabilities, but greater than a mere possibility."16
I have chosen to follow the Court in Tameh and the panel in MA2-00869 which found that the Adjei test should apply to s. 97(1)(a). Like the panel in MA2-00869, I do not believe that the legislative intent was to make access to protection more difficult for people facing a risk to their lives or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment than for those at risk of persecution, particularly since mistreatment under s. 97(1)(b) can meet the definition of persecution under the Convention. Therefore, I am of the opinion that the standard of proof as set out in Adjei17 as applied to the Convention refugee definition is the standard that should be applied under s. 97(1)(b) and I have applied that standard to the facts of this case.
Risk of Harm
I find that there is a serious possibility that the claimant would be subjected personally to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, should he return to Albania. He has established that he has become a target of the XXXXX family in the context of a blood feud. He has also established that he has been threatened and assaulted on at least one occasion by the XXXXXX family. The documentary evidence discloses that the number of blood feuds has been increasing since the collapse of communism in 1991 and the collapse of the DP government in 1997. According to one article, published in June 1999, a total of 1,800 people were killed and 3,500 persons wounded as a result of blood feuds in the previous three years.18
State Protection
The documentary evidence indicates that the state has taken some steps to alleviate the problems caused by blood feuds,19 however these steps have not been adequate as the number of blood feuds continues to increase. On this point I note that it is the current lack of state control that has led to the increasing reliance on traditional blood feuds to address crime rather than official channels in the first place.20 I find therefore that adequate state protection is not available to the claimant.
Internal Flight Alternative
Section 97(1)(b)(ii) requires that the risk be one that would be faced by the person in every part of the country. I have considered whether the risk faced by the claimant is limited to part of Albania and whether there are other parts of the country, reasonably accessible by the claimant, where he would not face a risk to his life. However on the evidence before me I find that there is no internal flight alternative for the claimant. He has testified that the XXXXXX family is powerful and is connected to the ruling Socialist Party. The evidence indicates that those targets of blood feuds that remain in Albania, do so by living in isolation and hiding.21 Therefore I find that the claimant faces this risk in all parts of the country.
DECISION
XXXXXXXXX is a person in need of protection and therefore the Refugee Protection Division accepts his claim.

XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, "the claimant" is a citizen of Colombia, and he claims refugee protection in Canada pursuant to ss. 96 and 97 (1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).1
The claimant was represented by counsel, Richard Addinall, Barrister and Solicitor, and a Refugee Protection Officer (RPO) was present throughout the hearing.
A Hearings Officer (Minister's Representative), Mr David Cranton, participated in the hearing, pursuant to subsection 170 (e) of the Act.2 The claimant and counsel had been notified that matters involving Article 1 F (a) of the 1951 Convention have been raised by the claim, in light of the claimant's former status as a soldier in the Colombian armed forces.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant alleges the following. He is seeking refugee protection in Canada because, in Colombia, his life was threatened by members of the guerrilla organization, the ELN (National Liberation Army - Ejercito de Liberacion Nacional).
At the time of the first threats, the claimant was attached to the infantry Battalion, XXXXX, and he was involved in investigating the death of his best friend, army Lieutenant XXXXX XXXXX, whom he believed was ambushed and killed by the ELN. He received permission from his army superiors to be personally involved, and his probe included making a report to the "XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX".
The claimant alleges that the ELN warned him of serious consequences if he did not cease his involvement in the investigation, and he was told to mind his own business. In addition, ELN guerrillas approached the claimant, and asked that he cooperate with them, such as allowing them to carry on their activities in the area without interference. They also sought his cooperation in providing information about the location of the different government army patrols, and he was offered money in return.
The claimant rejected the ELN's demands and request, and he told them so. He alleges that, subsequently, he received threatening telephone calls and he was told that he would suffer the consequences. The calls continued even after he was transferred to Bogota in XXXXX 1997, to be with the XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX. He left the army in XXXXX 1997.
The claimant alleges, further, that, later in XXXXX 1998, he was kidnapped by guerrillas and taken to a mountain camp. He was tied up and kept in a room. However, he overpowered his guard and escaped. He made it to his aunt's home at XXXXX. From there he travelled to the USA in August 1998. He alleges that, while in the USA, in June 2002, his family in Colombia received telephone calls from the ELN who asked about him, and the caller indicated that he was aware that the claimant was in the USA, and that his address was needed. He alleges that he feared that he could be harmed in the USA, and therefore, he travelled to Canada in July 2002 and made a refugee claim.
DETERMINATION
After careful consideration of all of the evidence, I am of the opinion that the exclusion provision (Article 1 F (a)) of the Act is applicable in this claim and that the claimant is not a Convention refugee, or a person in need of protection. I concur with the conclusion of the Hearings Officer that the claimant comes within the parameters of Article 1F of the Refugee Convention, and section 98 of IRPA.3
ANALYSIS LEADING TO DETERMINATION ON EXCLUSION:
(i) The law and statutory provisions
I am guided, primarily, by the decisions in Ramirez,4 Sivakumar5 and Moreno,6 and I note the following.
In Ramirez,7 the Court found that the burden of proving that the claimant should be excluded from determination as a Convention refugee is on the party so asserting, rather than on the claimant to demonstrate that he should not be excluded from such status. It
held, further, that the test for determining there are "serious reasons for considering" that a crime has been committed, require less than a balance of probabilities.
The Court8 also reviewed the degree of involvement required on the part of the claimant in order to be excluded from Convention refugee status, and found that accomplices, as well as principal actors, may be subject to exclusion. It was held that a person could be considered to be an accomplice, if there is personal and knowing participation in the persecutorial act, and the Court went on to provide examples of this test, as follows. It stated9 that:
"... mere membership in an organization which from time to time commits international offenses will be sufficient for exclusion from refugee status where the organization is principally directed to a limited, brutal purpose, which may, by necessity, involve personal and knowing participation in persecutorial acts...someone who is an associate of the principal offender can never be said to be a mere onlooker..."
The Court10 also looked at the claimant's opportunity to have left the organization earlier, without risk of harm to himself, and the length of time in the organization.
In Sivakumar,11 the Court looked at the method of recruitment (voluntarily) in the claimant's organization, the nature of the organization (violence/killings), the claimant's position/rank in the organization, including his high level promotions, the claimant's opportunity to leave the organization and the claimant's length of time in the organization.
In Moreno,12 the Court further clarified that a claimant can be held accountable where the organization in which he is involved is premised on achieving political or social ends by any means necessary, while still considering that mere membership in the organization involved in international offenses is not sufficient basis on which to invoke the exclusion clause.
(ii) The claimant's specific role/activities in the Colombian armed forces that give rise to a consideration of complicity:
After his basic army training (1993-1994), the claimant voluntarily joined the Colombian army as a sub-Lieutenant and worked primarily in counter-insurgency operations for at least three years (1994-1997). He always liked the military world, from what he had seen in the movies, he alleges. He considered that it would be a good career. He received many notes of commendation (congratulations)13 for assignments accomplished, and when he left the army in XXXXX 1997 for personal reasons, he was XXXXX months away from being promoted to the rank of Lieutenant.
The claimant first worked with the Military Police XXXXX in Bogota, from around XXXXX 1994 to XXXXX 1995. There, he instructed soldiers in such areas as the military rules and riot control.
Later, the claimant accepted a transfer to the XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, a rapid defense mobile unit. He engaged in counter-insurgency operations in the Antioquia region of Colombia, while XXXXX a unit of thirty soldiers. Their work involved area control such as protecting the communities and preventing the guerrillas from setting a presence in the communities. The claimant's base was in XXXXX. However, the Battalion's area of operations included places such as Taraza, Caucasia, El Bagre, Caceres, Barrio Blanco, and Monte Libano. A military presence was needed in those areas and orders came on a daily basis from the Battalion Commanders of the army about what specific areas needed support. Sometimes the claimant and his unit would be away from their base for two or three months on a stretch.
From XXXXX 1997 to XXXXX 1997, the claimant was attached to the XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, whose headquarters was in Bogota. That outfit engaged in counter-insurgency work and was in charge of control of the Meta area, and areas on the outskirts of Bogota. Its purpose was to control the guerrilla deployments.
The claimant alleges that he left the army because of the threats from the ELN, and that he was tired of risking his life and that of his family. In response to specific questions from Counsel, the Hearings Officer and the panel member, the claimant testified that, during his army service he did not commit, nor was he guilty of any human rights violations. The men in his charge did not commit any atrocities nor were they guilty of any atrocities.
(iii) The documentary evidence on the Colombian armed forces
Section 98 of IRPA14 states that persons referred to in Article 1(F)(a) of the Refugee Convention are not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection, and states, in part:
"The provisions of this Convention shall not apply to any person with respect to whom there are serious reasons for considering that:
" (a) he has committed a crime against peace, a war crime, or a crime against humanity, as defined in the international instruments drawn up to make provision in respect of such crimes..."
Several credible sources in the documentary evidence15 cite the Colombian army with committing gross human rights violations and crimes against the civilian population for decades. Those years include the time immediately before and during the claimant's period of service. One such source16 says the following:
"...the army has taught its officers the basics of international humanitarian law and made instructional material available to officers, professional soldiers and recruits...despite these measures, the army continues to commit serious violations, with little apparent will to investigate or punish those responsible. At the root of many violations is the Colombian army's consistent and pervasive failure or unwillingness to distinguish civilians from combatants in accordance with the laws of war..."
It is also stated17 that:
"...areas of armed conflict continue to be the scenario of large-scale human rights violations and
abuses by members of the security forces, paramilitary or "private justice" groups often said to cooperate with them, and the armed insurgent groups..."
The United States Department of State Reports18 on Country Conditions in Colombia for the years 1993 to 1997 give the same grim picture. The summary is that members and units of the army and the police participated in a number of human rights violations including extrajudicial killings, disappearances, torture and arbitrary detention, and that the army is reluctant to distinguish between guerrillas and non-combatants during counterinsurgency operations. These are the years prior to the claimant's active army service and during his active army service with the XXX Military Police, the XXXXX XXXXX and the XXXXX XXXXX.
The Hearings Officer cited the following other documentary evidence:
"...military operations leading to the death of civilians include indiscriminate bombing of civilian settlements and armed incursions into villages during which the victims are said to be killed on the spot or abducted, either to extract information or use them as guides and for intelligence purposes. Often the guerrillas killed during such operations are later presented to the public as guerrillas who died in combat, their corpses being dressed y the soldiers in military clothes, and guns and grenades placed in their hands..."19
When the claimant opted for voluntary army service at the end of his basic training in 1994, the above documentary evidence was the reality of the situation in Colombia, as it relates to the army, particularly those segments that were dedicated to counter-insurgency operations, such as the claimant's activities.
Throughout the 90s, there was evidence20 of "disappearances and political killings" and during the claimant's tenure with the Colombian army. The claimant's last assignment was with the XXXXX XXXXX. In particular, all of the documentary evidence paint a very negative picture of the operation of the Mobile Brigades, and indicate that they were responsible for serious human rights violations.
A general commentary on the Mobile brigade is as follows:
"...the centrepiece of army strategy is the Mobile Brigade. The Mobile Brigade is conceived as a highly mobile force equipped with weaponry and vehicles suitable for the country's rugged, often densely forested countryside...Mobile Brigades are composed of professional soldiers who volunteer..."21
"...despite the government and military's assertions that Mobile Brigades do not commit systemic abuses, some government agencies and independent human rights groups have documented a broad, consistent, and often shocking pattern of serious violations of human rights and the international covenants governing internal armed conflicts. In sharp contrast to army assertions that the Mobile Brigades are better trained to protect the civilian population and are strictly controlled, Americas Watch believes that spreading terror among civilians is an integral part of Brigade strategy and appears to be tolerated and sometimes openly articulated by Brigade Commanders..."22
"...Mobile Brigades have on repeated occasions failed to distinguish between civilian non-combatants and armed guerrillas, causing avoidable injury and casualty. Frequently, Brigade patrols have forced civilians to walk in front of units to detonate mines or don military uniforms and work as guides..."23
The determinative issue, therefore, is whether the claimant is complicit in this scenario of human rights violations, given his years of service in the Colombian army, his senior rank while there, his knowledge of the atrocities, and the fact that he remained a member of that army and only disassociated himself when he felt threatened by the ELN for rejecting their demands.
(iv) The claimant's counsel's arguments
The claimant alleges that, during his service, he never discharged his weapon nor committed any human rights violations against civilians or guerrillas. He states that he is not aware of any human rights violations committed by the men in his charge against guerrillas or civilians. He contends that they were simply part of the army personnel that provided a military presence in the areas, and there was never a confrontation.
He alleges that the military presence was merely to protect the towns, roads and villages against guerrilla infiltration; they only engaged in intelligence work and in dialogue with the civilian population about the presence of guerrillas in the areas, or whether they had seen anything out of the ordinary. They sometimes checked civilians for weapons and questioned them about where they came from or to where they were going. He is not aware of any human rights violations by the XXXXX XXXXX.
I concur with the Hearings Officer when he characterizes much of the claimant's testimony in this area as being not plausible, and I note the Court's ruling in Faryna v. Chorny,24 on the issue of plausibility.
Counsel argues that the claimant's testimony given under oath is presumed to be true and cites the court's ruling in Maldonado.25 In addition, in his submissions, counsel argues that the evidence is insufficient to support a finding that the claimant has been an accomplice in crimes against humanity. Counsel contends that the evidence must show that the claimant had knowledge of the crimes committed by the army and that he shared in the organization's purpose in committing them. Counsel cites the ruling in Saridag,26 and submits that in order for the claimant to be excluded, there must be explicit findings as to his knowledge and participation in specific war crimes.
In my opinion, there is reason to doubt the truthfulness of the claimant's testimony that he never participated in any confrontations, given that the claimant and his group of soldiers served in counter-insurgency operations for at least two years, in conflict areas of Colombia. It is not plausible that he had no knowledge of the abuses committed by the counter-insurgency units, even if he may never have participated in confrontations. According to the documentary evidence,27 counter-insurgency operations in the conflict areas involved armed confrontations, and there were human rights violations committed by the army. For example, it is said:
"...armed confrontations are said to be particularly frequent in the departments of Antioquia, Santander, Norte de Santander, Cesar, Bolivar and Meta. In these areas, the armed forces allegedly continue to apply a counter-insurgency strategy based on the concept of national security whereby everybody who is known or suspected to be linked with the guerrillas is regarded as an internal enemy. According to the information received, in the areas labelled as zonas rojas (red zones) where the insurgents are active and armed confrontations take place, the security forces view virtually all civilians as collaborators of the subversion, an allegation that was denied by members of the armed forces met by the Special Rapporteurs..."
Counsel has argued that one should not speculate and infer that the claimant must have participated in any confrontations or must have been guilty of committing atrocities in his work in those areas. Even if I agree with counsel and consider all of the evidence to be credible and trustworthy, I must be guided by the binding case law28 which holds that a claimant can be an accomplice without having committed specific crimes or atrocities, but by his knowing participation in the activities in which are engaged, perpetrators of those crimes and atrocities. What is more, I note that the claimant testified, and the Hearings Officer submits, that the claimant has testified that he had knowledge of abuses committed by the Colombian army, as follows.
Through radio news and comments, the claimant had heard comments that the army had been in certain areas and had detained some peasants who had been considered to be guerrillas. Through the army intelligence system, he had heard of some civilian populations giving their support to the guerrillas. He maintained contact with his base through radio contact, while on his own work assignment, and he was aware that guerrillas had been captured by other company units.
He had heard of "bad apples" in the army, and, as a result, he sought whenever necessary to instruct his men to act within the law and to show respect for the human rights of the population and not to do anything that would give grounds to discredit the army and the population, he alleged.
The Hearings Officer has pointed out further, the claimant's testimony that, before he entered the military, he was aware that the army was blamed for numerous atrocities, and that, while in the military, he received news of atrocities for which the army was blamed. Therefore, the claimant had personal knowledge of the atrocities, even if I accept his testimony that he had no personal experience of atrocities, nor committed any.
Counsel suggests that I consider the Court's comments in Gonzalez,29 where the Court makes a distinction between the applicant, a private soldier, engaged in an action against an armed enemy and thus participating in war, as opposed to committing war crimes or crimes against humanity. Counsel argues that the claimant was not of high rank and that he was under the command of a number of superior officers, and, as such, he did not have a leadership role, nor is there evidence that he received or gave orders to engage in crimes against humanity.
As pointed out by the Hearings Officer, the claimant was of sufficiently high rank. He was a sub-lieutenant who was XXXXX months away from being promoted to the rank of Lieutenant. In his duties, particularly with the counter-insurgency operations in the Antioquia area with the XXXXX XXXXX, he XXXX XXXXX X a company of thirty men.
In addition, the claimant's term of duty in the Antioquia area is a significant factor to be considered and the Hearings Officer noted that " ...a November 1996 Amnesty International Report describes the department of Antioquia as "one of the most conflictive regions of Colombia over recent years... where civil conflict has been particularly intense in several regions...over recent years the northeast of Antioquia has registered numerous politically motivated non-combat killings committed by the security forces and their paramilitary allies and armed opposition groups...the region is described as being the focus of a strong guerrilla presence, both FARC and ELN, and an area of strategic importance to the government as a result of mining interests and the oil pipeline in the area..."30
Moreover, I considered the claimant's testimony that his XXXXX XXXXX operated in a "red zone", and that he was for a time a member of XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX. I noted the following other documentary evidence:
"...the Special Rapporteurs received numerous reports about human rights violations by various military battalions and other units of the security forces based in zones rojas (red zones). However, particular concern was expressed at the activities of the brigades moviles (mobile grigades), established in the recent past. For example, Mobile Brigade No.1 has been operating in the department of Meta and neighbouring Casanare and Boyaca since 1991...These brigades are reported to patrol the country during extended periods, without having a permanent base, and the battalions which normally operate in the region do not consider themselves responsible for their activities. Members of the mobile brigades are said to be accountable for a high number of enforced disappearances, torture and extrajudicial, summary or arbitrary executions..."31
I am of the opinion that, as a XXXXX of a unit of thirty soldiers engaged in counter-insurgency operations in areas such as Meta and other areas of Antioquia, the claimant demonstrated knowing participation in the atrocities, even if neither he nor his unit committed any specific atrocities. In Bazargan32 the Court said:
"... in our view, it goes without saying that "personal and knowing participation" can be direct or indirect and does not require formal membership in the organization that is ultimately engaged in the condemned activities.- It is not working within an organization that makes someone an accomplice to the organization's activities, but knowingly contributing to those activities in any way or making them possible, whether from within or from outside the organization..."33
In my view the claimant contributed to the army's activities, and he did not leave that situation at an early date. He testified that the process of leaving the army was very simple, especially since he had offered his services voluntarily. He resigned merely for personal reasons, and the evidence does not show that, during his assignments he complained about the widespread atrocities and systematic crimes against humanity of the army, or objected to his superiors regarding these atrocities.
(v) The conclusion/findings
Based on the above, I find that there are serious reasons for considering that the claimant, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, has been complicit in crimes against humanity during his service with the Colombian army.
Accordingly, he falls within the parameters of Article 1 (F) (a) and is excluded from refugee protection under s. 98 of the IRPA. He is not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection. I reject his claim.

XXXXXXXXXXX, a Tamil citizen of Sri Lanka, claims refugee protection pursuant to sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA). 1
The claimant alleges the need for protection because of her perceived political opinion, her membership in a particular social group, namely, being a young Tamil woman, originally from the North of Sri Lanka, and her ethnicity.
Allegations
The claimant, who is 24 years old, declared that she, together with her family, moved to Colombo early in 1992 because of the fear that the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) would conscript members of her family.
The claimant alleges that between 1992 and 2001, all of her family members fled Sri Lanka after having suffered problems. In XXXXX 2001, the claimant alleges the worst incident occurred when she was arrested at her home during a security check of Tamils in Colombo. The claimant was taken to the police station where she was interrogated and detained for three hours in a cell. The police suspected that the claimant was assisting the LTTE. The claimant was released after her uncle paid a bribe. The same happened after the July 2001, LTTE attack on the Colombo airport. The claimant alleges that police officers came to her home and questioned her but did not arrest her.
The claimant alleges that in XXXXX 2002, two female members of the LTTE attended at her home and attempted to recruit her. The claimant alleges that she refused outright and the LTTE said that they would check back with her again. The claimant fearing forced conscription by the LTTE, left for Canada on XXXXXX, 2002 and filed her refugee claim on September 26, 2002. The claimant alleges that the LTTE attended at her home after she had come to Canada. The claimant fears the army, the police and the LTTE upon return to her country.
Identity
The claimant's National Identity Card and marriage certificate2 were available at the hearing; therefore, I accepted her identity and nationality.
Credibility
I assign the benefit of doubt to the claimant's allegation that she was detained in XXXXX 2001 and interrogated in regards to helping the LTTE. The claimant testified that she was told by the police to leave Colombo and join her husband in Canada. However, after she was released, the police checked her identity on one other occasion, and they did not attend her home again between XXXXX 2001 and when she left Sri Lanka in XXXXX 2002, which is an indication that the security forces were satisfied that she did not pose a threat. In general, short detentions for legitimate law enforcement purposes do not constitute persecution.3 It is also noted that the claimant is not claiming that she left her country because of the detention by the police, even though she is still afraid of them. She alleges that she left because the LTTE tried to recruit her to join their ranks, in XXXXX 2002. I find that the absence of corroborating documentation indicating that the LTTE is actively recruiting members in Colombo reinforces my negative credibility assessment in regards to her reasons for leaving. Recruitment by the LTTE after the unilateral ceasefire in December 2001 is scrutinized and publicized in reports such as the Special Report No. 17,4 or the report in regards to a joint fact-finding mission to Sri Lanka by the Danish Immigration Service and the Research Directorate of the Immigration and Refugee Board.5 They point out that recruitment expanded into government-controlled areas6 and are prevalent in the Batticoloa district and the North and North East of Sri Lanka. The reports also show that parents are sending their children to Colombo7 or areas with a Sinhalese majority,8 in order to be safe. Perusing the documentation both from counsel and the Board's in its entirety, I find the human rights organizations or the press would have made us aware if the LTTE recruitment had expanded into Colombo. The LTTE opened offices in the Northern Islands9 and in Vavuniya, however, there are no reports that they opened offices in Colombo. One newspaper article in our package does shows that several businessmen in Colombo were approached for a "large contribution" for the LTTE and threatened with their lives and harm to their families if they failed to comply. The article also mentions that the police refuse to intervene. However, this is one article from a Tamil newspaper, published in the United States of America (USA).10 The allegations in this article are not reflected in any other documents before the panel.
The documentation before the panel indicates that the situation for Tamils in Colombo is far from being perfect, however, The United States Department of State (DOS) report11 points out that unlike in previous years there were no reports of the security forces failing to comply with legal protections, including impunity for those responsible for human rights violations. Unlike previous years there were no credible reports that security forces committed extra-judicial killings12 or that disappearances at the hands of these forces took place.13 Torture still does happen, however, and the Attorney General's Office and the Criminal Investigation Unit have established units to focus on torture complaints; these units forwarded 14 cases for indictments this year. An Interparliamentary Permanent Standing Committee and its Interministarial Working Group on Human Rights Issues have begun tracking criminal investigations of torture. In addition, the government also ceased paying fines incurred by security force personnel found guilty of torture and they have been prosecuted under criminal statutes, but none of the cases have come to conclusion.14 There were no reports of arbitrary arrests and detention during that year, including no large-scale arrests of Tamils, and the government released 750 Tamils as part of the peace process.15 The Emergency Regulations were lifted in July 200,116 however a ten-day state of emergency was declared in the beginning of November 2003 by President Kumaratunga, which was called a gross abuse of presidential power by the country's cabinet led by Prime Minister Wickramasinghe.17 There are no documents before the panel indicating that the State of Emergency was extended past the 10 days. By January 2002 most roadblocks and checkpoints in Colombo were dismantled,18 even though they were back on all major roads during the November crisis.19 There are no more registration requirements in Colombo for Tamils.20 The government legalized the LTTE as part of the peace process in September 2002,21 however, LTTE cadres have to register with authorities when travelling in government-controlled territories.22 Perusing the documents before me I am not saying that there is a complete change of circumstances in regards to young Northern Tamils, however, for a young woman, such as the claimant, who has been cleared of any involvement with the LTTE, which is now legal, the panel does not believe that the claimant has good grounds for fearing persecution because she is a young Tamil originally from the North of Sri Lanka.
Will the claimant's removal to Sri Lanka subject her personally to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment or a danger of torture?
The answer to this question is "No". The panel notes that the the claimant left the country legally with her own passport, which does not expire until August 10, 2004. Various reports indicate that many returnees to Sri Lanka are simply waved through by security forces at the airport.23
Conclusion
The claimant is not a credible and trustworthy witness and nothing else trustworthy was presented to establish the material aspects of this claim.
Therefore, after having considered the totality of the evidence, counsel's submissions, the relevant statutory provisions and jurisprudence, the Refugee Protection Division rejects this claim. The claimant is not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection.
