The claimant, XXXXX XXXXX, a citizen of Guyana, claims refugee protection pursuant to ss.96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.1
Allegations
Through her Personal Information Form (PIF)2 and oral testimony, the claimant testified that she is of East Indian (Indo-Guyanese) descent and as such has always felt discriminated against and persecuted by the supporters of the opposition PNC party in Guyana who are Black. She described running a XXXXX stand from 1995 until 1999 in Georgetown, Guyana where she faced threats and theft at the hands of Black criminals. She alleged that she was threatened by them not to report these incidents to the police, however she attempted to do so on several occasions but the police refused to take any reports and threatened to arrest her. She fears racial and political violence because she is Indo-Guyanese and as such is perceived as a supporter of the ruling party in Guyana.
Determination
I find that the claimant is not a Convention refugee as she does not have a well-founded fear of persecution for a Convention ground in Guyana. I also find that she is not a person in need of protection in that her removal to Guyana would not subject her personally to a risk to her life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, and in that there are no substantial grounds to believe that her removal to Guyana will subject her personally to a danger of torture. My reasons are as follows.
Analysis
Identity
I find that the claimant has established her personal identity and her identity as a citizen of Guyana through her testimony and with supporting documents, namely, her passport and Canadian Visitor's Visa.3 However, on the issue of identity, s.106 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) and Rule 7 of the Refugee Protection Division Rules go further. The claimant must provide acceptable documents establishing identity and other elements of the claim. If the claimant does not provide acceptable documents, she must explain why they were not provided, and what steps were taken to obtain them. I find that, on a balance of probabilities, the claimant is in default of both aspects of Rule 7.
In this case, the claimant has not provided any documents to the Board with respect to the fact that she owned a XXXXX booth in Georgetown XXXXX from 1995-1999. This is an essential element of the claim since the claimant alleges that the threats she received from Black criminals occurred while she was operating her XXXXX stand. These threats and criminals stealing her XXXXX is what caused her to make reports to the police, which she alleges were futile. Therefore, the issue that I must address is whether the claimant has taken reasonable steps to secure documents and have them before me at the time of the hearing. When she was asked what efforts she had made to document the fact that she had a stall in Georgetown, she stated that she had taken no steps to secure such documents, as she had not thought of it. Later she said that she had rented the stall from persons who may have left Guyana, however she had made no effort to document this part of her claim. Therefore I find that the claimant has not taken any steps to secure documents regarding her stall, in addition, has not provided any reasonable explanation for her failure to do so.
Credibility
Failure to Claim, Delay in Claiming
The claimant was in Canada from March 2002 until May 2002 in order to visit her son who is studying in Toronto. During this time she did not make a claim for protection. She returned to Canada on September 9, 2002 yet did not make her claim until October 8, 2002. The claimant was asked to explain why it was, if she was afraid to go back to Guyana, she did so in May 2002 rather than making a claim for protection. Her explanation was that she did not know that the refugee process was open to people from Guyana and only learned about it from a friend on her second trip to Canada. After having made her claim, she learned that her uncle who lives in Canada, had previously made a refugee claim. I do not find her explanation to be satisfactory. The claimant is a high-school graduate, and speaks English fluently. Moreover she has her mother and four siblings who live in Canada as permanent residents. I can see no reason why if she were genuinely afraid to return to Guyana, she would not have made the necessary inquiries regarding the possibility of claiming refugee status in Canada. I find that the claimant's action of returning to Guyana undermines her allegation that she faces a serious possibility of persecution or a serious possibility of a risk to her life in Guyana. Her behaviour is not consistent with the behaviour of an individual in genuine fear for her life.
Whether the claimant ran a XXXXX stall from 1995 to 1999
As stated above, the claimant alleged that she owned a stall in Georgetown Market from 1995-1999. However in the forms that she filled out when she made her inland claim for refugee protection, under "occupations" she stated that she was a homemaker in Georgetown, Guyana from XXXXX 1992 until XXXXX 2002.4 When she was asked why she did not indicate that she ran a stall from 1995-1999 in the inland forms, at first she had no explanation. Later she said that she did not know what to put and that she was tired with filling out the forms since she had to wait for a long time to make the claim that day. I do not find this explanation to be satisfactory. As stated earlier, the claimant speaks English fluently and is familiar with filling out immigration forms, having applied for permanent residence in Canada and for Canadian visitor's visas on several occasions. 5 In his re-examination of the claimant, counsel asked her to describe some details about
running her stall, however the details that she was able to provide were general in nature and included the fact that she had to shut down the stall in order to come to Canada in 2002. Again this was another internal contradiction in her evidence about the stall, since she had stated in her PIF and in her earlier testimony that she ran the stall only until 1999. In light of the lack of documentation about the fact that she ran a stall from 1995 until 1999, and in light of her inconsistent oral and written evidence about running the stall, I find that on a balance of probabilities, the claimant did not run a stall from 1995 until 1999. Consequently, I also find that she did not face the threats and harassment as alleged in paragraphs 4 and 5 of the narrative of the PIF as these were tied to her running the stall. I also find that she did not make any reports to police in Guyana since again these alleged reports were tied to the alleged incidents, which occurred while she was operating the stall.
General Finding on Credibility
In light of the above findings, I find that the claimant was generally not a credible witness and make an overall finding of lack of credibility on the part of the claimant.
Risk of Harm
While I have found that the claimant did not suffer the incidents of harm as alleged in her PIF and oral testimony, I must also consider whether her ethnicity, which in Guyana includes an imputed political opinion, establishes that she faces a reasonable chance or serious possibility of persecution, or whether it would subject her personally to a risk to her life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment or a danger of torture. I find, however, that the risk of harm alleged by the claimant is indiscriminate or random such that it is faced generally by others in the country. The claimant fears general levels of crime and violence in Guyana. The documentary evidence indicates that all persons living in Guyana are at risk and that regardless of race, crime victims are targeted due to their perceived wealth.6 I find that the claimant's fear of criminal violence is not linked to her ethnicity or to political opinion.
I must also consider whether her ethnicity or other factors makes it objectively unreasonable for the claimant to seek state protection. The documents indicate that there are concerns about police discrimination but note that "there is no firm evidence that police responses discriminate against Indo-Guyanese" and that the problem of slow response to crime is mainly related to the constraints facing the police force.7 The current government is led by the People's Progressive Party/Civic (PPP), a party supported predominantly by Indo-Guyanese and the president is Indo-Guyanese. Further, while the civil service and defense and police force overwhelmingly were staffed by Afro-Guyanese, the government continued efforts to recruit Indo-Guyanese for the security forces. The government also sponsored various forums for the discussion of racial problems and to promote inclusion, and it supported the work of NGOs that dealt with these concerns.8 Therefore, I find that on the evidence, the claimant's ethnicity does not make it objectively unreasonable for the claimant to seek state protection. Accordingly, I determine that the claimant's fear of persecution is not linked to a Convention ground.
As noted above, I also considered whether the claimant is a person in need of protection because of a risk to her life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or because she faces a danger of torture. No evidence was adduced that would support a finding that the claimant faces a danger of torture. With respect to a risk to her life or cruel and unusual treatment, I have found that the claimant did not suffer past incidents of serious harm. Moreover, she has not established an identifiable risk that is distinguishable from that of the general population. I find the claimant fears a generalized risk, one that is faced by all citizens of Guyana. Therefore, her claim falls under the exception in s. 97(1)(b)(ii) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
State Protection
In the alternative, I find that adequate state protection is available to the claimant. While states are presumed to be capable of protecting their nationals, it was open to the claimant, according to the law, to rebut the presumption of protection with "clear and convincing" evidence. I find on the evidence, that the claimant has not rebutted that presumption. The evidence before me is not clear and convincing that the government of Guyana is unwilling or unable to investigate, arrest and punish perpetrators of crime or that Guyana, a democratic state, is not in effective control of its territory and institutions.9 There is evidence that the government is making serious efforts to combat violent crime in Guyana. The president has stated publicly that the fight against crime remained a top priority for his government. The government has funded the purchase of new supplies of arms, ammunition, and protection gear for police, allocated 10% of its 2003 budget to fighting crime and national security, and set up joint army and police patrols in order to capture those responsible for increased criminal activity in areas such as the town of Buxton.10 The documentary evidence indicates that the police have been taking serious steps to get crime under control:11
"Since February 2002, the Guyana Police Force issued wanted bulletins for 42 notorious criminals who were wanted for crimes ranging from armed robbery to murder. Most of these criminals have been considered as armed and dangerous. Information available from the police force shows that 25 of the wanted persons have since died. Their deaths have mainly occurred from confrontations with the police and the joint police/army operations. Seven of the wanted persons have been arrested, while ten are still at large."12
Therefore I find that, even if the claimant faces a risk of harm as contemplated in ss. 96 and 97(1) of the Act, she has not rebutted the presumption of state protection. I find that adequate state protection is available to the claimant.
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, the Refugee Protection Division determines that XXXXX XXXXX is not a Convention refugee and not a person in need of protection and her claim is rejected.

The principal claimant, 40-year-old XXXXXXXXXXX (aka XXXXX XXXXXXX) and her 18-year-old daughter XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, claim to be citizens of the Philippines who seek refugee protection pursuant to sections 96 and/or 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA). The principal claimant bases her Convention refugee claim on her membership in a particular social group, namely, women in the Philippines subjected to domestic violence. Her daughter bases her Convention refugee claim on her membership in a particular social group, that of a family member. In assessing these claims, I have taken the Gender Guidelines1 into consideration before rendering a decision
ALLEGATIONS
The principal claimant alleges that after her husband left her to live with his mistress, she initiated legal proceedings against him and since then has received constant threats from both her husband and his mistress. The daughter alleges that he has beaten her and that he will kill her as a way to get back at his wife.
DETERMINATION
The panel finds that the claimants are neither Convention refugees nor persons in need of protection because they have failed to rebut the presumption of state protection.
ANALYSIS
Identity
I accept that the claimants are both citizens of the Philippines based on the true copies of their passports provided by Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC)2 and confirmed by the original of the passports provided by the claimants.
State protection
A determinative issue in this claim is whether adequate state protection is available and whether it is objectively unreasonable for the claimant to seek that protection. If state protection is to be reasonably forthcoming, then the claimant is required to approach the state for protection. The fact that the state does not provide perfect protection is not, in itself, a basis for determining that the state is unwilling or unable to offer reasonable protection in the circumstances of a particular case.3 The claimant has the burden of rebutting the presumption of state protection by presenting "clear and convincing proof" of the state's inability to protect.4
I am also mindful of the principle that international refugee protection is not meant to permit a claimant the opportunity to seek better protection abroad than she would receive at home.5
I find that the claimants have not rebutted the presumption of state protection, in that they have failed to provide clear and convincing proof of the government's inability to protect women from violence. In arriving at this conclusion, I have considered the documentary evidence in Exhibit R-1, and I find it to be persuasive evidence of the current conditions in the Philippines, as it is based on a variety of independent governmental, non-governmental and humanitarian sources.
Although recognizing that violence against women and in particular, domestic violence, is a serious societal problem in the Philippines,6 I conclude from this evidence that the government of the Philippines is making serious efforts to address the problem of violence against women and that state protection, even though not perfect7 is available for a woman in the Philippines who is subjected to domestic violence.
The documentary evidence8 describes the Philippines as a democratic republic with an elected president and bicameral legislature. The President oversees the Armed Forces of the Philippines (the AFP) and the Department of the Interior and Local
Government has authority over the civilian Philippine National Police (the PNP).
The government has set up special desks in some 600 police stations where staff members are specifically trained in and sensitized to women's issues.9 According to the US Dos Report10 the government of the Philippines spent an estimated 53 million pesos (equivalent to US $1 million) in 2002 for medical and psychiatric facilities and shelters for women who are victims of violence. While perhaps not a significant amount of money, this output demonstrates the government's recognition of the problem and its efforts to address it.
The government has also established a National Commission on the Role of Filipino Women (NCRFW), whose mandate includes advising the President, Cabinet and Congress on policies, programs and laws affecting women.11 The NCRFW has produced documentation to assist women who are victims of domestic violence,12 has participated in projects on violence against women in Philippine society13 and serves as a major link between government and non-governmental organizations on women's concerns.14
Of particular note is the Women's Crisis Center in Manila,15which is recognized as a pioneer in the area of domestic violence in the Philippines. This centre operates a hot line, provides crisis intervention, counseling and emotional support to victims, as well as temporary shelter. Moreover, staff from the centre are available to accompany battered women to the hospital, to police stations, to lawyers and to court.
In June 2002, legislators in Cebu City "passed the country's first local ordinance that penalizes perpetrators of domestic violence and provides protection to victims. Under this law, witnesses may file complaints as well as victims."16
In light of the government's efforts to address domestic violence and the principal claimant's own experiences in engaging the mechanisms of the state to deal with her husband, I find the claimants' explanations for not seeking police assistance to be unpersuasive.
The principal claimant tendered extensive documentary evidence relating to the criminal case for "concubinage" that she brought against her husband in the mid-1990s.17 In a letter dated February 26, 2003, the claimant's former legal counsel explained that,
Concubinage is a crime defined by the Revised Penal Code of the Philippines, in which a married man cohabits with a woman not his wife. It is penalized by imprisonment ranging from six months and one day to four years and two months ... is also a ground for legal separation...
The principal claimant made reference to physical assaults in her affidavit supporting this charge. However, the only documentary evidence she provided relating to physical aggression pertained to the time of their marriage break-up in the early 1990s. It does not appear that she pursued any avenue of redress in respect of the physical aggression either at the time it happened or later. Moreover, she subsequently entered into settlement negotiations with her husband's family, on his behalf, with respect to support for herself and her daughter, and withdrew the charge against him.
Although this evidence is dated, it demonstrates that the principal claimant is not only knowledgeable about the legal avenues available to her, but that she is prepared to pursue them. The principal claimant availed herself of the state mechanisms and the state in turn proceeded to advance her interests. In addition, she was in contact with organizations that could have assisted her in bringing further action against her husband in the event that he continued to be abusive towards her, such as the Women's Crisis Center (the WCC).18
According to Exhibit C-3, the principal claimant went to the WCC in order to obtain assistance with her concubinage case in 1995. The referral letter from this organization does not make note of any physical abuse suffered by her, although the principal claimant alleged that she ran to the WCC because her husband beat her up and that she told them her story. Her evidence on the number of times that she went to the WCC varied from one "other" incident to countless times. She indicated initially that the
only reason she went to the WCC was for assistance with her case. When asked if she told anyone at the WCC that she had been beaten, she said she did, but that they said nothing to her, implying that the WCC was not helpful when she sought assistance. Only after the role of the WCC was read to her19 did the principal claimant recall one time while her case was going ahead, that the counselors at the WCC asked her to stay at their crisis center and that they advised her to go to the police.
It was apparent that the principal claimant's story regarding the involvement of the WCC developed only in response to direct questions and after inconsistencies between her allegations and the documentary evidence were put to her. Given her attention to detail in collecting the documentary evidence to support her claim, the role the WCC plays in assisting abused women, and the significance that such assistance would have been to the claimants' situation, I find the principal claimant's explanation that she was only just recalling all of these experiences after the inconsistencies were identified to be not credible. From this, I conclude that she did not approach the WCC for assistance regarding the alleged physical abuse, and thus did not avail herself of a valuable resource that could have assisted her in accessing the protection of the state in the event she did not wish to do so alone.
The principal claimant indicated that on one occasion, when she went to see her husband after they had separated, he raised a stick against her and threatened to kill her. She stated that she went to the Barangay police and reported this incident. Although the principal claimant was not able to obtain a report, she indicated that they not only took the report, but that they went to her husband and warned him against further threats to her. She claimed, however, that it was fruitless to go to the regular police because they would not help her, as she had no money to bribe them. The principal claimant's daughter similarly stated that it would be no use to go to the Barangay or the police because her father had connections and would still want to kill her.
I find these claims fail because the claimants made little to no effort to avail themselves of the protection their own state had to offer. On those occasions that the principal claimant did seek state intervention, the evidence demonstrates that it was forthcoming. Moreover, both claimants stated that because they didn't think the police would help them, they never sought protection from that source. I find it objectively unreasonable for the claimants to make this assumption, particularly given the active assistance for victims of domestic violence from women's groups in the Philippines.
I find, based on the documentary evidence referred to above, and the favourable experiences that principal claimant had in accessing state intervention in the past, that it was not reasonable for the claimants to have made no effort to seek protection from their own state.
As a result, I conclude that the claimants have not rebutted the presumption of state protection. Accordingly, their claims for protection as Convention refugees must fail.
Consolidated grounds
The claimants did not adduce independent evidence to base a claim on danger of torture or risk to life or cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. Since I have found that adequate state protection is available to the claimants, their claims must also fail on these grounds.
CONCLUSION
For these reasons, these claims are rejected.

XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, a citizen of Macedonia claims refugee protection pursuant to subsections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.1
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant alleges that he faces persecution or other serious harm in Macedonia due to his Albanian ethnicity, his Muslim religion and a personal risk to his life at the hands of a known person. In addition to fearing Macedonians generally, he also fears a person named XXXXX, an ethnic Macedonian whom he knew from school and who beat the claimant in XXXXX 2001 in Bitola, his hometown. The claimant lived in Sturga, Macedonia (an ethnic Albania majority area) from XXXXX 2001 until he left for Belgium in XXXXX 2001. He returned from Belgium in XXXXX 2002 and in XXXXX 2002 he lived in Sturga until he left for Canada in XXXXX 2002. The claimant does not allege any incident of harm while he lived in Sturga, Macedonia. While he lived in Sturga, he visited Bitola from time to time to check on the family property with no problems. The only incident of harm he alleged occurred in Bitola was when three persons, including XXXXX, beat him in XXXXX 2001. This incident occurred in the context of general rioting that occurred during that time period.
DETERMINATION
I find that the claimant is not a Convention refugee, as he does not have a well-founded fear of persecution for a Convention ground in Macedonia. I also find that he is not a person in need of protection in that his removal to Macedonia would not subject him personally to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, and in that there are no substantial grounds to believe that his removal to Macedonia will subject him personally to a danger of torture. My reasons are as follows.
ANALYSIS
Identity
The claimant presented a number of original documents, which include his original Macedonian passport (seized by Canada Immigration).2 He testified in the Albanian language. On the basis of the documents presented and his testimony I find that the claimant has established his personal identity, his citizenship and his ethnicity.
Risk of Harm
The claimant testified that he feared general conditions throughout Macedonia. When asked for specific examples of current problems for ethnic Albanians, the only examples he gave pertained to Bitola. When asked what he fears in Sturga, he said that he simply does not feel safe there as an Albanian since Macedonia is a small country and "anything can happen" and that while there is no war going on currently in Macedonia, one could happen at any time. He also indicated that as an ethnic Albanian he would have difficulty finding a good job. When asked about his cousins who currently reside in Macedonia, he testified that he did not know of any physical harm that has come to them since he came to Canada. Other than a message that the claimant allegedly received from XXXXX through an ethnic Romanian neighbour in Bitola in XXXXX 2002 there is no evidence that XXXXX is interested in harming the claimant; nor was there any attempt by XXXXX to harm the claimant while he lived in Sturga from XXXXX to XXXXX 2002.
Based on the claimant's own evidence, he has not discharged his burden of demonstrating that there is a reasonable chance or serious possibility that he would be harmed in Macedonia, particularly in Sturga; nor has he provided any evidence of undue hardship to him in living in Sturga, which would go beyond the usual hardship of relocation.
While I have found that the claimant has not discharged his burden of demonstrating that he is personally at risk in Macedonia, I must also consider whether his ethnicity or religion in the current political context of Macedonia establishes that he faces a reasonable chance or serious possibility of persecution or whether it would subject him personally to a risk to his life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in Macedonia. I find however that there is no serious possibility that the claimant would be subject to such harm in the event of his return there. No evidence was adduced with respect to a risk of a danger of torture.
The documentary evidence indicates that contrary to the claimant's assertions, the Macedonian government has taken significant steps to redress the real or perceived wrongs of the Albanian minority. Significantly, the Ohrid peace agreement, signed on the 13th August 2001, appears to grant ethnic Albanians many of the greater civil rights that the rebels say they have sought. Tensions in the divided communities have eased since the NATO forces arrived. The documentary evidence also indicates that partly out of concern that a security vacuum may be created after the departure of the NATO troops currently deployed in Macedonia, on the 18th September 2001 Macedonia's Security Council backed a plan that would see a small NATO mission remain in the country. The mission's primary purpose would be to collect rebel weapons. In a series of reforms aimed at addressing some of the issues raised by the rebel leaders, Parliament approved a new constitution on the 16th November 2001. This new constitution broadened the rights of ethnic minorities, as called for under the peace plan. By November 2002 the new parliament, which came out of elections mandated under the Agreement, had voted in favour of a new multi-ethnic government.3 The reforms are intended to decentralise the government and to grant ethnic Albanians jobs in the public service, above all in the police force, reflecting the one third they represent of the population of two million in the former Yugoslavia republic.4
This is not to suggest that the peace accord has been universally accepted or completely implemented. The panel notes that the Peace Accord was intended to redress years of historic, systemic discrimination and cannot be expected to be immediately implemented. Nonetheless, taken as a whole, the panel finds that the documentary evidence suggests that the government of Macedonia is committed to keeping the peace and to honouring the terms of the peace accord and ensuring peace and stability for all its population despite the existence of extremist elements noted by counsel. The political changes that have taken place in Macedonia since the signing of the Peace Accord in August 2001 are fundamental and cumulative and constitute sufficient and durable changes, such as to render the claimant's fear unreasonable and therefore without foundation.
CONCLUSION
For these reasons the claim of XXXXX XXXXX is rejected.

Introduction and Summary of Allegations
XXXXXXXXXX is a citizen of Costa Rica. He claims to have a well-founded fear of persecution based on his membership in a particular social group. He also claims protection as a person who faces a risk to his life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment upon return to Costa Rica. I have also considered if he faces a danger of torture upon return to Costa Rica.
The claimant fears persecution in Costa Rica at the hands of a violent gang whom he denounced to the police in XXXX 2003 when he witnessed them robbing his friend's store. He alleges he was subsequently beaten up and threatened with death by some of the gang members and they put his car on fire. He came to Canada in XXXXX 2003 to seek protection. Since he came, his family had to re-locate in Costa Rica, as a man had come looking for the claimant. At no time after the initial denunciation did the claimant report the threats to the police or any other state agencies in Costa Rica because, he claims, protection would not be forthcoming.
Jurisprudential Guidelines
The determinative issue in this claim is state protection. I considered1 whether the Jurisprudential Guides'2 decision TA2-14980 applies in this case and determine that the facts and the evidence regarding country conditions in this case are sufficiently close to those before the panel in RPD decision TA2-14980 because 1) they both deal with Costa Rican claimants seeking protection due to their fear of criminality, and 2) the issue in both is the determination of the availability of state protection for victims of crime. In addition, I assessed the April 2003 RPD Information Package3 which was not before the Jurisprudential Guide panel. The claimant did not submit any additional documentary evidence. In reaching my decision, I have assessed the claimant's own experiences in the context of the entirety of the evidence.
Determination
I find that the claimant is not a Convention refugee, as his claim does not have a nexus to a Convention ground. I also find that he is not a person in need of protection for the reasons outlined below.
Analysis
The claimant's identity as a national of Costa Rica is established by a certified true copy of his passport4 submitted by Citizenship and Immigration Canada as well as his testimony.
I adopt the reasoning in RPD decision TA2-14980 as that reasoning, which has been comprehensively analyzed, applies to the facts of this claim and the availability of state protection for this claimant is the determinative issue in this claim.
In the case at bar, I accept that the claimant was being violently pursued by gang members. However, I find that state protection was available to the claimant in Costa Rica had he pursued it.
When the claimant originally contacted the police to report the gang, they arrived 3 hours after the perpetrators had been chased away by a group of taxi drivers with baseball bats. Four police officers arrived and one of them took a signed statement from the claimant and his friend the store owner, which included a description of the robbers. The claimant believed the police officers were dismissive of the complaint because, they said, there are so many similar cases and the gang members all look alike, for example. After the claimant was beaten and threatened by the gang, he did not return to the police because he feared greater reprisal from the gang members. He further stated that the police in Costa Rica are not helpful and in very few cases do they take action.
I find that while the police did arrive late in the first instance, it appears that they took the denunciation seriously as they did take a signed statement. I find that the onus was on the claimant to return to the police when the gang targeted him as one cannot get protection unless one asks. I find that the claimant's statements about the inability of the police to protect him are not supported by the documentary evidence.
The documentary evidence reveals that the Costa Rican government is making serious efforts to protect people who are victims of crime. Furthermore, there are a number of recourses available in Costa Rica for the assessment, prosecution, and the granting of remedies resulting from the failure of the law enforcement agencies to conduct their work.
A claimant is required to approach his or her state in situations such as this one in which protection might reasonably be forthcoming. Further, I find that the claimant should have returned to the police to report the attacks against him. I find that if the claimant was not satisfied with the police handling of the initial matter that he had recourse to the office of the Ombudsman. He said that he did not go to the Ombudsman because they rarely take effective action. Again, I find that the documentary evidence does not support this conclusion.
I find the appropriate course of action taken by a reasonable person would have been to pursue a complaint through the available authorities, rather than taking the extreme measure of leaving the country.
I considered that Costa Rica is a long-standing, stable, constitutional democracy5 with an independent judiciary providing effective means to deal with cases of criminals. In the context of this claim and the claimant's country of origin, I find that by not pursuing state protection, the claimant has not discharged the onus of presenting clear and convincing proof of the state's inability to protect him.
Given that there is state protection for this claimant in Costa Rica, I find that there is not a serious possibility that the claimant would face persecution, nor is there a risk to his life, a danger of torture, or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment should he return to Costa Rica.
Accordingly, the RPD finds that XXXXXXXXXXXX is not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection and rejects his claim.

TA3-17636
These are my reasons for the decision of the claim of XXXXXXXXXXX (a.k.a. XXXXXXXXX) for refugee protection. The claimant is a 25-year-old citizen of Jamaica from XXXXXXXXXXX. The claimant fears crime and violence in Jamaica.
I am satisfied that the claimant is a citizen of Jamaica and that he is who he says he is by reason of a certified copy of his Jamaican passport,1 which is contained in our file.
The claimant's testimony of past events going to the basis of his alleged fear is contained in the narrative to his Personal Information Form2 (PIF) and was given orally by the claimant during the hearing. For the purposes of these reasons, I do not repeat the contents of all of that here. However, I have considered all of it. I have also considered counsel's submissions and all of the documentary evidence before me. Furthermore, I have considered the claimant's level of education.
Issues for determination:
1. Does a claimant who advances a claim for protection on the grounds of risk to life or risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment need to demonstrate a subjective fear of the risk in order to be granted protection?
2. If a subjective fear is required, can a substantial delay in claiming protection negate that fear and therefore defeat the claim?
Issue 1 - Subjective fear and s.97(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
It is established beyond doubt in Canadian refugee law that subjective fear is a necessary element of a claim for protection as a Convention refugee. The language of s.96 of IRPA makes this clear, and so does Canadian jurisprudence.3 By contrast, the language of s.97(1)(b) does not make use of the term "fear".4 Does it follow from this difference between the two sections that fear is required to succeed as a Convention refugee, but not as a person in need of protection on grounds of risk to life or risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment?5 I do not think so.
First of all, current principles of statutory interpretation favour a contextual approach over a literal approach. For this reason it is necessary to examine the entire statutory context in which this issue arises. This includes both the substantive provisions which guide protection determination, and the procedural provisions which govern how the determinations are made. In terms of substance this means looking beyond the differences in the language of s.96 and s.97 to examine the statutory context and the legislative intent. Here the context is set out in Divisions 1 and 2 of Part 2 (Refugee Protection) of IRPA. In terms of process this requires examining the role of the Refugee Protection Division in determining claims for refugee protection. The procedural context is set out in Part 4 (Immigration and Refugee Board) of IRPA.
A. Substantive Context:
The Act grants only one status - refugee protection - regardless of whether a claimant succeeds as a Convention refugee or as a person in need of protection. In addition, the Act imports the principles of exclusion from the Refugee Convention so that they apply not only to claims made pursuant to s.96, but to claims made pursuant to s.97 as well.6 Division 2 sets out a procedural code governing a range of aspects, including referral, eligibility for referral, suspension of eligibility, and cessation and vacation of protection. Again, all of these provisions apply, regardless of whether the claim is made pursuant to s.96 or s.97.
What is the legislative purpose in creating a single status and a single procedural code in relation to Convention refugee claims and claims for protection? In my view it is grounded in a fundamental underlying principle, namely that Canada's protection is surrogate protection. This is established in Ward in the context of a claim made for protection as a Convention refugee,7 but it applies equally to claims made pursuant to s.97. The Supreme Court has recognized this by establishing that a claimant must first seek the protection of their own state before coming to Canada to claim protection, unless it is objectively unreasonable for the claimant not to have done so.8 The concept of state protection is integrally linked to the existence of a subjective fear on the part of any claimant. Why? Because there has to be a reason that is particular to the individual, and that motivates the individual to abandon their own country, such that the person arrives on Canada's doorstep asking for protection, rather than seeking the protection of their own state. It simply defies logic to suggest that a person who is seeking Canada's protection need not show a fear of persecution or a fear of risk to life or risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. If they have no subjective fear, why are they asking for Canada's protection in the first place?
In Ward the Supreme Court of Canada recognized the fact that a claimant's subjective fear is tied to lack of state protection. The Court adopts the following statement from Goodwin-Gill:
"Fear of persecution and lack of protection are themselves interrelated elements. The persecuted clearly do not enjoy the protection of their country of origin, while evidence of the lack of protection on either the internal or external level may create a presumption as to the likelihood of persecution and to the well-foundedness of any fear."9 [Emphasis added.]
In other words, it is implicit in any claim for Canada's protection - whether on Convention grounds or on grounds set out in s. 97 - that the claimant has a fear and that it cannot be addressed through protection from the claimant's home state. Any other approach makes no sense: Why is a claim being made if the claimant fears nothing?
In relation to the substantive provisions raised by this question, I conclude that a subjective fear is a necessary element of any claim made pursuant to s.97. Reading the words of s.97(1)(b) in the context of those sections of the Act which deal with protection, I conclude that:
* Divisions 1 and 2 of Part 2 of the Act establish Canada's surrogate protection obligations;
* Canada's surrogate protection obligations only come into play if there is a failure of state protection in the claimant's country of origin; and
* The assertion of a failure of state protection by the claimant must first be triggered by a subjective fear which the claimant asserts cannot be adequately addressed by the state in the claimant's country of origin.
These principles apply whether or not the claim is made on the grounds of the Refugee Convention, on the grounds of the Convention Against Torture or the grounds in s.97(1)(b).10
B. Procedural Context:
In order to have a complete grasp of the issue, it is also necessary to look at the context in which these decisions are made. The intent of Parliament as to how the Refugee Protection Division is intended to function is clearly not an overriding consideration in interpreting those provisions of IRPA which create substantive rights to Canada's protection. However, where there is ambiguity or uncertainty in the wording of the Act, it is of assistance to consider the Act in its totality, and this includes the procedural dimension. To begin with, Parliament decided to confer the authority to decide claims for refugee protection made in Canada solely on the Board,11 an administrative tribunal.
In doing so, the legislation specifies:
162 (2) Each Division shall deal with all proceedings before it as informally and quickly as the circumstances and the considerations of fairness and natural justice permit.
A range of other provisions make it clear that the Division must organize and conduct its proceedings in a way which balances fairness which efficiency, so that it can perform as a high-volume human rights tribunal.12 It follows from this that provisions of the Act which affect the operation of the Refugee Protection Division should, where possible, be interpreted in a manner which is consistent with the way Parliament intended the Division to function, namely simply, quickly and fairly.
In interpreting ss.96 and 97, the Division examines certain common elements in each case that comes before it: a claimant who is a foreign national or a stateless person comes before the Board seeking Canada's protection on the grounds that their country of citizenship or country of former habitual residence cannot protect them from a serious form of harm. An interpretation of ss.96 and 97 which makes subjective fear a necessary component of the former provision, but not the latter, would require the Division to launch two separate inquiries within the same hearing in order to test the credibility of the claimant's story, one (the s.96 inquiry) which includes and -- based on the Division's long experience in this area - focuses largely on the claimant's subjective fear, and another (the s.97 inquiry) which looks at all aspects of the same facts, but without regard to whether or not the claimant is believable in asserting that they fear a prospective harm. This is a prescription for longer, more cumbersome hearings and lengthier reasons for decision. The issue of subjective fear explored below demonstrates the inconsistency and inefficiency of such an interpretation of the Act.
By contrast, an interpretation which recognizes that subjective fear is a necessary element of both ss.96 and 97 allows the Division to examine the essential elements of a claim in a single inquiry. This enables the Division to conduct a more focussed hearing and to provide more focussed reasons. Not only does the latter interpretation allow the Division to balance fairness and efficiency in any individual case, it also allows the Division to manage its entire operation in a manner which is consistent with its statutory mandate as an administrative tribunal.
Both the substantive aspects of IRPA and the procedural context in which protection claims are adjudicated favour an approach to s.97 which makes subjective fear a necessary element of any such claim. For these reasons I conclude that s.97 requires an examination of the claimant's subjective fear.
Issue 2 - Delay and subjective fear
The importance of subjective fear as a necessary element of a successful claim - whether on the grounds of the Refugee Convention or on the grounds in s.97(1)(b) - becomes especially clear when considering a delay in making a claim for protection. In the case of claims based on the Refugee Convention, the jurisprudence is evolving to recognize that a lengthy delay in making a claim can, of itself, be a sufficient basis to conclude that a claimant lacks subjective fear.13 The Federal Court has held that reasoning supporting this approach is equally applicable to claims based on s.97(1)(b)14 - again, the principle of surrogate protection applies to both grounds. The actions of a claimant who delays substantially in seeking protection on any ground invite the question of whether the claimant really has anything to fear, and therefore whether Canada's surrogate protection obligations should be engaged.
The danger in reading out the requirement of subjective fear in claims made under s.97(1)(b) become obvious in cases where there is a long delay in claiming. Would it make any sense to say that a delay of three years in making a claim under the Refugee Convention can fail because there is no subjective fear, but the same claimant who delays three years before making a claim under s.97(1)(b) can expect to have that delay ignored by a decision-maker because subjective fear is not required by s.97(1)(b)? The absurdity in that position is obvious.
The anomaly is especially striking when the very facts on which a Convention refugee claim is rejected, because a subjective fear is lacking, are then reconsidered under the s.97(1) grounds, and the findings on the claimant's lack of subjective fear are treated as inconsequential. Was s.97(1) intended to extend protection to failed Convention refugee claimants whose claim would otherwise have a nexus to a Convention ground but whose behaviour belies a fear of serious harm? The panel thinks not.
Whether a claim is made on Refugee Convention grounds or on s.97 grounds, delay is a factor. Furthermore, a lengthy delay can be determinative of the fact that the claimant has no subjective fear. The importance of delay has to be assessed on a sliding scale. As Member Aulach indicated in RPD TA0-16602 (Espinosa),15
"The importance that one gives to this "relevant" element of delay depends on the circumstances of the case. The more inexplicable the delay, the greater the probability that subjective fear is absent. Sometimes the circumstances are such that the element not only is relevant but assumes a decisive role. In these circumstances, delay in making a refugee claim can be a decisive factor in turning down a claim..."
The Refugee Protection Division (RPD) needs to look at the behaviour of the claimant because it is a linchpin of the subjective component of a claim for refugee protection. Since claimants rarely admit to a lack of subjective fear, the subjective component would be virtually bereft of meaning if the claimant's behaviour which was inconsistent with a fear of serious harm was ignored. If that fear is absent, one needs to know why. If no apparent reason is found, then the absence of fear may indicate an absence of risk of harm to the individual concerned.
In RPD TA3-0495516 Member Berry outlined four critical factors relevant to the assessment of the claimant's explanation for delay in seeking protection:
* The length of delay;
* The nature of the harm feared;
* The efforts made to legalize one's status and what triggered them; and
* The reasonableness of the claimant's explanation for the delay.
It is reasonable to conclude that the longer the delay and the greater the degree and imminence of harm alleged upon return, the more compelling the explanation should be in order to qualify as reasonable. A lack of effort to legalize one's status and the making of a claim as a last resort further undermine the alleged fear of harm and the professed need for protection.
The principles outlined in these two RPD decisions provide a guide to deciding claims where there has been a lengthy delay in claiming on any ground of protection. If the claimant's explanations for the delay are reasonable, given all the circumstances, then the delay in claiming is explained satisfactorily. If not, then the RPD may conclude that the claimant does not in fact have a subjective fear.
In this case, the delay in claiming is substantial.
The claimant delayed over three years in making his refugee claim: he arrived in Canada in April 2000, but did not claim until August 2003. During that period, the claimant admitted that he had no status in Canada. The claimant also testified that he did not make a refugee claim until after he was arrested by Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC).
When asked to explain why he did not make a refugee claim or take steps to regularize his status in Canada earlier, the claimant testified that he felt safe and secure in Canada and that he did not know how to go about doing it.
I do not find this to be a reasonable explanation. The claimant also testified that the first time he asked anyone about how he might go about taking steps to remain in Canada was in the year 2002. It seems to me that if the claimant truly feared harm in Jamaica, once he arrived in Canada in April 2000, he would not have waited until 2002 to simply ask a question of a plan as to how he might go about remaining in Canada. I also infer from the fact that the claim was not made until after the claimant was arrested that protection was not a priority for the claimant.
Given the length of the delay and the claimant's failure to provide a reasonable explanation, I am drawing an adverse inference as to the claimant's subjective fear. Given the length of the delay, I am finding, based on that one factor alone, that the claimant does not have a subjective fear of harm.
Given that the claimant does not have a subjective fear of harm, the Refugee Protection Division rejects the claim and finds that the claimant is not a Convention refugee and not a person in need of protection within the meaning of sections 96 and 97 of the Act.17
Furthermore, for that same reasons, given the fundamental lack of evidence of the existence of a subjective fear, the Refugee Division finds that there is no credible basis for the claim.

Facts
The claimant is a 28-year old male citizen of Costa Rica. He left Costa Rica on XXXXXX 2004 and arrived in Canada the same day. He claimed refugee status upon arrival. He alleges he will be subjected to harm at the hands of a man with whom he exchanged motor vehicles, who subsequently threatened him, should he return to Costa Rica. His wife and two children remain in Costa Rica.
His Personal Information File (PIF) was filed on 19 March 2004. The claimant was scheduled to attend an Assignment court hearing for 10 May 2004 (the notice to appear was sent on 26 April 2004). The claimant failed to appear on 10 May 2003 so consequently a "show-cause" abandonment hearing was set for 26 May 2003 (the notice to appear for this matter was sent to the claimant on 10 May 2003).
The claimant appeared at the "show cause" hearing. When asked why he failed to appear on his original hearing day he said he got lost on the way to the Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB) premises.
Decision
The claimant's claim is abandoned.
Reasons
I find that the claimant was unable to show-cause why his case should not be abandoned.
The claimant alleges that he got lost on the way to the IRB to attend his hearing. When asked if he attempted to contact the IRB by telephone to explain his dilemma he said he tried to but he only got a voice message. When asked if he attended in person when he eventually found the Board he replied that he only found the Board today. When asked how he managed to find his way to the Board today he said a friend showed him. When asked the full name of this friend he replied that he only knew him as "XXXXX." The claimant was given ample opportunity to add any other comments or explanations. None were forthcoming.
I do not accept the claimant's explanation for missing his hearing as credible. I find the claimant lied about being unable to find the Board. I find that were that true a claimant could reasonably be expected to have made efforts to contact the Board by telephone or by letter or in person to explain his absence at his hearing. I find that the claimant's action in not attending his hearing reveals an unconcerned and lackadaisical attitude towards prosecuting his claim, which ultimately belies his allegations of being a Convention refugee or a person in need of refugee protection.
The claim is abandoned.
