XXXXX XXXXX (a.k.a. XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX and XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX) is a 27-year-old citizen of Iran and the Netherlands who claims to be a Convention refugee or person in need of protection in reference to both countries of nationality. In Iran he suffered because of his father's affiliation with the former regime of the Shah, and in the Netherlands he has been threatened by officials of the Iranian embassy following his refusal to traffic drugs on their behalf, under his trading company.
CHRONOLOGY OF THE CLAIM AND SUMMARY OF ALLEGATIONS
According to the claimant's Personal Information Form (PIF) signed December 18, 2001,1 he is a citizen of Iran and only Iran and resided in that country exclusively from birth until he came to Canada. Two years after he signed the PIF and nearly a year after he had sworn to its veracity at his refugee hearing, but before the panel had rendered a decision and was thus functus, the claimant admitted in an interview with a Citizenship and Immigration Enforcement Officer that he is also a citizen of the Netherlands.2 He said that he left Iran in 1988, made a successful asylum claim in the Netherlands, and lived there until he came to Canada and made a refugee claim inland on September 18, 2001. A resumption of the hearing was held to address this new evidence.
Originally his claim against Iran was based on a series of personal incidents that began four years after his father's departure from the country around 1993. In the PIF, he states that the Shah of Iran had appointed his father to be XXXXX of the city of XXXXX in 1974. Shortly after the Islamic revolution his father resigned the position. He was then arrested as part of an investigation of former XXXXX but received lenient treatment because of his early resignation. Upon being released from detention after just one week, his father was required to report to government security officials regularly and he was barred from government employment. Private employers refused to hire him because of his ties to the former regime. According to the PIF, the family experienced on-going discrimination, harassment and persecution for this reason and, as a result, when his father left Iran he made a successful asylum claim in the US. The claimant's brother and sister later immigrated to the US and his mother was in the process of doing do so around the time the claimant signed his PIF in Canada.
This had been the claimant's evidence at the first sitting of the hearing on December 12, 2002. However, at the resumption on February 2, 2004, he testified (as he had already told the Citizenship and Immigration Enforcement Officer), that he left Iran years before his father, in 1988. He suggested that he had departed first because, being the first son, he was even in greater danger than his father.
As originally stated in the PIF, the most serious consequences for the claimant of his father's past political association started in XXXXX 1997 when he got into a fight with a government agent who was harassing an unknown woman and improperly enforcing the regime's Islamic dress code. When he was taken into custody, the authorities found out about his father's history with the Shah's regime and this was an aggravating factor in their mistreatment of him. The claimant's evidence is that he was imprisoned for a period of 40 months among political dissidents and tortured repeatedly. His personal journals and essays were seized from home and he was accused of collaborating with his father abroad.
His mother eventually obtained his release in XXXXX - XXXXX 2000 upon payment of a very large bribe. The claimant went into hiding until he was smuggled to Turkey in XXXXX 2001 and then flew from Istanbul to Vancouver a month later. According to his PIF he traveled on a photo-substituted Israeli passport, although it appears he identified the passport as Italian to Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) at the port of entry.
When the claimant ultimately admitted to the Citizenship and Immigration Enforcement Officer that he had been living in the Netherlands all that time, not in Iran, he suggested that he had been arrested, detained and tortured in 1997 during a return visit to Iran. However, at the resumption of the hearing, he testified that all of the incidents described in the PIF took place before he left the country in 1988.
As for the claimant's activities in the Netherlands, his new evidence is that he was the owner and operator of an import-export business that conducted trade with Iran. He testified that he launched the business in XXXXX after the Iranian border opened up following the election of President Khatami and in the process he consulted the Iranian embassy in the Netherlands. Within a short period of time, officials from the embassy asked him to obtain drugs in Iran to be carried by diplomats to the Netherlands. When he declined their offer, they started making threats toward him, beginning in 1997, and in late 1998, they sent seven men to beat him up. Over the ensuing two years until he came to Canada, Iranian embassy officials would call him occasionally to chat about his business; he considered these calls threatening because of the "tone" and the implication that he was being watched. This made him fear for his life anywhere in Europe because of the presence of agents of the Islamic Republic, so he decided to make a refugee claim in Canada where it would be more difficult for them to reach him.
According to the claimant's PIF, dated December 18, 2001, he did not have a valid Iranian passport. Yet he produced a photocopy of just such a document at the resumption of the hearing, issued in the Netherlands on XXXXX, 1996, and said the original was at his home in North Vancouver. By reference to stamps in the passport, he confirmed that he traveled back to Iran (using that passport) four times: in XXXXX 1998, XXXXX 1999, XXXXX 2000 and XXXXX 2000, without incident. (Significantly, there was no record of a trip in 1997) The claimant himself brought up the fact that all of these trips occurred after he had received the threats from Iranian embassy officials in the Netherlands and explained that he had first gone as the agent of the Iranian government, with the agreement of the embassy, to broker a deal to import XXXXX from the Netherlands. In this context, he cultivated a faction in the government of Iran that would have defended him if he got into trouble while visiting the country.
The claimant testified that, on the surface, he may not be in imminent danger if he was to return to Iran, but he would not be able to live a "normal" life there because if he ever got into trouble his father's history would put him in danger.
At the resumption of the hearing, the claimant said that he came to Canada as a visitor in 1993 and looked into the possibility of immigration. Although he met the requirements, he learned that the process would take almost a year. A consultant named Hilal Bangash advised him it was better to go back (to the Netherlands). In 2002, she represented the claimant at the first sitting of the hearing, although in the meantime his PIF had been prepared with a lawyer, Martin Jones, and another lawyer, Brenda Wemp, was counsel of record for several months leading up to the first sitting.3
At the outset of the proceeding on December 12, 2002 the claimant amended his PIF to show that his real surname is XXXXX XXXXX or XXXXX XXXXX. This is the surname that appears on the Iranian identity documents he provided,4and it is also the surname of his putative father in the US.
ISSUES
Initially, the following issues were identified in the claim against Iran: personal identity; credibility; objective basis; subjective fear relating to his failure to claim elsewhere (in the US) and the apparent short delay in making a claim in Canada; destruction of documents (the putative false passport); and a second nationality or exclusion under Article 1E if it emerged that he has status in the US like other family members. Among the issues arising from the revelations concerning incidents in the Netherlands, canvassed at the resumption, were: credibility and state protection. The new evidence also had a bearing on the subjective and objective well foundedness of his claim against Iran.
ANALYSIS
Personal Identity
Ultimately, the Refugee Protection Division takes no issue with the claimant's identity as XXXXX XXXXX or the evidence that he is both a national of Iran and the Netherlands, although there are serious reasons to doubt that the US citizen, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, is his father and a former associate of the Shah.
The Refugee Protection Division emphatically does not accept the claimant's excuse for failing to tell the truth about his dual nationality to Canadian government officials, over a period of nearly two full years. He testified that it was an open secret in the local community that he is a Dutch citizen - but he withheld the information from the Canadian government on the advice of Hilal Bangash who warned him that Canada would send him back to the Netherlands. The Refugee Protection Division has no reason to doubt the claimant's damaging allegations concerning the immigration consultant. However, the Refugee Protection Division finds that this does not absolve the claimant of his responsibility to tell the whole truth to officials of the country he is asking for protection.
Moreover, as noted above, the claimant had the benefit of counsel by two successive highly respected lawyers after he made his refugee claim and thus the opportunity to discuss with each the wisdom of Hilal Bangash's guidance. It is reasonable to expect that either one of them would have assured him that if he made a refugee claim against his second country of nationality, he would not be returned there unless it were finally decided after lengthy and multifaceted due process that it was safe for him to do so. Also, the claimant himself could have figured out the parallel between his Iranian nationality and claim against Iran and his Dutch nationality and the corresponding opportunity to say what harm he faces there.
Furthermore, the Refugee Protection Division finds, on the balance of probabilities, in addition to hiding his Dutch nationality, the claimant also withheld from examination certain originals of Iranian documents relating to his personal identity. At the first sitting of the hearing, he provided just one original Iranian identity document -- his problematic military discharge card5 -- there are only copies and translations of the rest of the documents in evidence, including an Iranian identity booklet; high school diploma; some photos of his father; a few of the claimant's XXXXX; the Shah's order of his father's appointment; his parents' divorce decree; and a couple more documents about the claimant's XXXXX activities. He tried to suggest that his father mistakenly took all the other originals back home with him to Seattle.
As soon as the claimant reported this at the beginning of the hearing, the Presiding Member directed him to contact his father in Seattle and ask him to send the originals by courier. Since the documents had not arrived by end of the day when the hearing was adjourned, the claimant was given additional time to provide these originals for examination. Nothing of the kind was received in response by the due date or in the ensuing months.
Lastly, on this issue, the Refugee Protection Division finds that the claimant has not provided a satisfactory explanation for the discrepancy between the name he consistently gave to Canadian authorities - XXXXX XXXXX - and the surname that appears on his putative Iranian identity documents - XXXXX XXXXX or XXXXX XXXXX - which is also the surname of the naturalized US citizen he alleges to be his father.6 Paradoxically he says he never used the second surname in Iran, whereas on the face of the documents the opposite is true: this was his name in Iran but he has not used it in Canada (or, it now appears, in the Netherlands either).7 Since there is no dispute that he deceived Canadian authorities about his Dutch nationality, it is reasonable to assume he has done the same in respect of his real surname. During the interview with the Citizenship and Immigration Enforcement Officer he was asked how much of his original PIF was honest, and he replied, "Probably just my name," perhaps forgetting for the moment that he had amended that information.8
As a result, the Refugee Protection Division draws an adverse inference as to the credibility of the alleged relationship between the claimant and the man identified as XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, his putative refugee father in the US whose supposed appointment by the former Shah of Iran thirty years ago still places the claimant at risk in Iran.
Overall Credibility
Considering all of the evidence, the Refugee Protection Division finds that the claimant has failed to provide sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence to establish his claims to refugee protection, either with respect to Iran or the Netherlands, under any of the grounds afforded in the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA). The claimant's credibility has been fatally damaged by the fact he wilfully deceived Canadian authorities as to most basic elements of his life and experience: his nationalities and his whereabouts before coming to Canada. He made an oath to tell "the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth" at the first sitting of the hearing, only to tell a pack of lies - by his own admission.9 The Refugee Protection Division finds that he has continued to fabricate his evidence in alleging threats by Iranian agents and embassy officials in the Netherlands.
Claim Against Iran
The Refugee Protection Division finds it is not credible that the arrest, detention, assault and torture the claimant allegedly experienced over a period of more than 40 months in Iran could have occurred alternatively: starting in XXXXX 1997 (per the narrative statement in his PIF); or before he left the country in 1988; or during a return visit in 1997.
The pre-1988 timeframe is inconsistent with the allegation that the Iranian authorities accused him of collaborating with his father "who was then known to be abroad" and that they questioned him about why he had not departed Iran with his father.10 (Supposedly this is what grievously aggravated their mistreatment of him.) His evidence now is that his father did not go abroad until 1993. The timeframe of his alleged imprisonment in Iran, originally given in the PIF as XXXXX 1997 to XXXXX or XXXXX 2000, has now been discredited by the claimant's admission that he was residing in the Netherlands during that whole time. And the alternative suggestion that this all happened on a return visit to Iran the same year is inconsistent with the length of the alleged detention (more than three years), and it is not supported by the claimant's examination of entry stamps in his own Iranian passport (there being none for 1997). It is also at odds with his oral testimony that when he first went back to Iran he cultivated a faction of the Islamic regime to ensure he would be protected if things went wrong. Moreover, it is reasonable to expect that if the claimant had been arrested, detained and tortured by the Islamic regime during a trip in 1997, for some shorter period of time, he would not have returned just for the sake of doing business on four more occasions in 1998, 1999, and 2000. On the balance of probabilities this detailed and graphic account of arrest, detention and torture, is simply untrue.
Considering the claimant's admission that he visited Canada previously and looked into the possibility of immigration (but considered it would take too long), in all likelihood the claimant fabricated the story as the basis of a refugee claim against Iran in order to use the refugee system to circumvent proper immigration procedures.
The Refugee Protection Division finds that the specific allegations of cruel and unusual punishment or treatment, torture, and persecution that form the basis of the claim against Iran have no foundation in reality. .
Correspondingly, there are serious reasons to doubt that the claimant's putative father was ever discriminated against by the Islamic regime for association with the former Shah or that his profile in that regard was such that he would have been perceived as a political opponent some twenty years after the Revolution, especially to the degree that his son would be imperilled on his account upon return to Iran. This is the lynchpin of the claim to refugee protection against Iran under all of the grounds in Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).11
Supposedly his father is now an American citizen and resides in nearby Seattle. In the alleged circumstances, this individual should have been able to provide first-hand corroborative evidence, not only of his XXXXX appointment by the Shah in 1974, but his subsequent resignation and brief imprisonment after the Islamic revolution and the requirement that he report weekly upon release. If his son had endured such vile treatment at the hands of the Islamic regime in large measure because of him and he helped make the arrangements for his son's escape from Iran,12 it is reasonable to expect that he would have actively supported his son's refugee claim in Canada.
However, this has not been the case. As noted above, the claimant's putative father apparently has not responded to the Presiding Member's direction to forward the originals of various documents in evidence so they could be examined.13 While this individual gave his consent for the IRB to check his status in the US, it was open to him to obtain and provide the entire contents of his own US "A" (Alien) file and in particular his putative application for asylum and the reasons for its acceptance. If reliable and trustworthy, such information could have gone a long way toward providing at least an arguable basis for his son's derivative claim.
Instead, what is in evidence (apparently from the claimant's father) is a poor quality photocopy of a putative letter from the US Department of Justice Asylum Office that grants him asylum effective XXXXX, 1993; a photocopy and translation of a letter from the Shah of Iran dated XXXXX 1977 (not 1974 per the PIF) appointing him to the executive of XXXXX County; photocopies of various photographs purportedly showing him carrying out his civic duties and a photograph of the family when the (two) children were young, oddly enough posed in front of a Christmas tree - the claimant testified this was taken at a Christmas party in France at the institute where his father got a doctoral degree.14
The Refugee Protection Division gives no weight to the Shah's appointment confirmation given the discrepancy in dates and since it bears no royal (or other) official insignia. Similarly, the Refugee Protection Division accords no weight to the photographs of the man performing civic duties, for example, cutting a ribbon, watching young men parade, etc. because there is no way to identify him as the claimant's father. Had this individual attended the hearing and provided his own Iranian identity booklet, for example, such identification could have been possible. As for the putative grant of asylum, the Refugee Protection Division finds this photocopy is not reliable or trustworthy evidence. On its face, it appears to corroborate the claimant's statement in the PIF that his father requested asylum in approximately 1993 in Seattle. However, there is no independent trustworthy evidence that this individual's route to US citizenship began with an asylum claim.
After the first sitting of the hearing, the IRB received the results of the status check of the claimant in the US under his supposed hyphenated surname and its different spellings. The Refugee Protection Officer made written application to disclose this information under the provision in the Refugee Protection Division Rules and the Presiding Member accepted it into evidence.15 Minister's counsel and counsel for the claimant (Hilal Bangash) were given the opportunity to make additional submissions but none were received from either party.
The US response is that there is no immigration record for anyone using the same name(s) as the claimant. But more importantly the record provided from the US immigration file concerning the claimant's putative father fails to verify that he made a request for asylum in Seattle in 1993 as alleged by the claimant and as stated in the putative letter from the US Department of Justice. What the record does indicate is that XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, born in Iran, initiated an immigration application of some sort (the asylum request form I-589 cited in the letter is not indicated in the official record) on XXXXX, 1993. But apparently the application was made abroad because, although the procedure was finalized on XXXXX, 1993, he is shown to have entered the US on XXXXX, 1995 at Seattle and simultaneously his status changed. If nothing else, the clear contradiction here is that he entered the US a year and a half after the putative letter addressed to him in Seattle dated XXXXX, 1994 granting asylum. The Refugee Protection Division prefers the objective information provided by the US government and finds, on the balance of probabilities, that the photocopy of the letter supposedly concerning the claimant's father's asylum matter in the US has been fabricated for the purposes of the instant refugee claim.
Considering the adverse inference already drawn above in the analysis of personal identity from the discrepancy in the claimant's evidence as to whether in actual fact he has the same surname as the naturalized US citizen XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, coupled with this individual's lack of cooperation in the proceeding, the Refugee Protection Division finds that the claimant has failed to establish that he is indeed his father, or that he was ever perceived by Iranian authorities to have been associated with the regime of the former Shah of Iran through an appointment made thirty years ago.
This finding further undermines - if that is possible -- the credibility of the claimant's assertion at the second sitting of the hearing that he would not be able to live a normal life in Iran because, if he ever got into trouble, his father's history would put him in danger.
In addition, according to the objective country information,16 monarchists like the group, XXXXX XXXXX, that allegedly helped both the claimant and his putative father to flee from Iran are not taken seriously now by the Islamic regime because they do not pose a political threat. All active and militant monarchists left Iran during the 1980s and are mainly in Europe and North America. The only activities of the few remaining monarchists are small private gatherings where people remember the time of the Shah with nostalgia. They no longer have an audience in the Iranian population. Accordingly, the government is not interested in pursuing any Iranian with monarchist affiliations, as long as they do not engage in anti-regime activities and avoid making public statements about their monarchist ideology.
The claimant's evidence is that his putative father did not get involved in political activities after the Revolution, nor did he himself, although supposedly he wrote about his religious beliefs in personal journals and essays that the authorities seized from his home when he was in prison - evidence found above not to be credible.
Moreover, one report states there is no evidence of any pattern of action by the regime today against Iranians simply because at one time they were middle-level or low ranking functionaries of the Shah's bureaucracy.17
In light of this authoritative information, there does not appear to be an objective basis for the claim against Iran. Even if there was once some foundation for it, perhaps in immediate aftermath of Islamic Revolution in 1979, the claimant's own evidence is that he has long since cultivated allies in one of the factions of the Islamic regime who would protect him if he got into trouble. By this means he would be able to avail himself of state protection if he were to return to Iran, which is rare for Iranian refugee claimants fearing persecution by government officials.
Lastly, there is the matter of the claimant's voluntary re-availment to Iran after supposedly having been granted asylum in the Netherlands.18 His evidence is that he contacted the Iranian embassy as long ago as 1996 to get a new passport, acted as a business agent for the Iranian government, and returned to Iran (using his Iranian passport) four times between 1998 and 2000. He testified emphatically that this was only possible after President Khatami was first elected, but he thought that this had occurred in 1995 or 1996, while the documentary evidence shows it was in 1997.19 This means the claimant approached the Iranian embassy in the Netherlands well before the unpredicted election of Mohammed Khatami as President.
The Refugee Protection Division notes that the claimant became a naturalized citizen of the Netherlands in 1994, according to his oral evidence. This means he would have been eligible for a Dutch passport if he had wished to travel, and thus did not need to apply for an Iranian one. Moreover, his choice of business in the Netherlands is anomalous since presumably an import - export business between the Netherlands and Iran would require some contact with the feared Islamic regime. The Refugee Protection Division finds that the claimant's evidence about his alleged reticence to contact Iranian officials is not credible, given the date his passport was issued. Moreover, the nature of his business and fourfold re-availment in 1998, 1999, and 2000 demonstrates a profound lack of subjective fear, which is a necessary element of the definition of a Convention refugee under Section 96 of the IRPA.
By the same token, there is no credible evidence or argument that anything bad happened to the claimant during these four trips. (As noted in the analysis above, he suggested to the Citizenship and Immigration Enforcement Officer that the series of incidents beginning in XXXXX 1997 of arrest, detention and torture described in the PIF had still occurred, despite his residence in the Netherlands at the time, but on a trip to Iran instead, the same year. This allegation has been discredited in the analysis above.) However, as the passport entries serve to indicate, the fact that he encountered no problems in the course of these trips is strong evidence that if the claimant were removed to Iran he would not face a risk to life or risk of cruel or unusual treatment or punishment or a danger of torture, under Section 97 of the IRPA.
Taking all the evidence into account, the Refugee Protection Division finds that the claimant has failed to establish that he would face a serious possibility of persecution or a risk to life or risk of cruel or unusual treatment or punishment or a danger of torture if he were to return to Iran once more. His claim to be a person in need of protection under both Section 96 and 97 of the IRPA has no merit.
Claim Against the Netherlands
Since the claimant has not provided a satisfactory explanation for having deceived Canadian authorities about his Dutch nationality for nearly two years, while simultaneously asking for Canada's protection, the Refugee Protection Division finds, on the balance of probabilities that the substance of his belated claim against the Netherlands is not credible. It is a total fabrication and purely expedient.
Even in its particulars, the alleged basis of the claim is incredible. Most notably, his allegation that Iranian embassy officials proposed in 1997 that he traffic drugs from Iran for them is fundamentally at odds with the rest of his evidence that he is suspected of being a political opponent of the regime because of his family background. In that context, it is implausible that Iranian embassy officials would have found him to be sufficiently loyal and trustworthy to involve him in secret criminal activities that could have had dramatic political and diplomatic repercussions if revealed.
Moreover, the claimant contradicted himself during oral testimony at the resumption of the hearing, first saying clearly that they asked him to provide the drugs and then, when asked by the Presiding Member whether he was a recognized drug dealer in the Netherlands, trying to suggest that he was not supposed to supply the drugs, just do "research." He was vague about what that meant, but seemed to suggest it would have entailed locating illicit sources of drugs in Iran for the smuggling operation. Here again, if the claimant is being truthful that he was not a known drug dealer, it is not credible that the Iranian embassy officials would look to a novice living outside Iran to do that job. Supposedly at that stage he had only acted as the agent of the Iranian government to XXXXX XXXXX for export from Europe to Iran. Furthermore, the claimant's own testimony is that he was an unlikely choice because he worked in the Netherlands to encourage young people to avoid drugs and his activities were reported in the newspapers.
As well, there is a fundamental inconsistency in the claimant's allegation that Iranian embassy officials were threatening him and sending men to beat him up and telephoning him with implied threats over his refusal to traffic drugs, while simultaneously he was able to make repeated trouble-free trips to Iran for unrelated business purposes. There is no evidence that his entry to Iran was ever impeded or that he was even questioned by the security forces.
Finally, if the claimant made an asylum claim against Iran in 1988 and this is how he came to be a citizen of the Netherlands, the Refugee Protection Division finds it is objectively unreasonable that he did not, once again, seek the protection of his host country when Iranian embassy officials and government agents allegedly harassed and threatened him upon his refusal to traffic drugs for them. During his interview with the Citizenship and Immigration Enforcement Officer, he was asked why he did not report the matter to the police. He did not answer the question directly and only stated, rhetorically, that in Holland a child molester gets free and "there is no law there, believe me." His statements at the resumption of the hearing were similarly vague: it would have been a "waste of time" to talk to anyone about his problem and in Holland "they won't do anything unless something happened."
The burden of showing a state's inability to protect rests with the claimant and is discharged only if he provides clear and convincing evidence of the state's inability to protect.20 Absent a complete breakdown of the state apparatus, nations are presumed to be capable of protecting their citizens and the claimant was by then a citizen of the Netherlands.
The Refugee Protection Division finds in general there is little justification at this stage for Canadian authorities to "believe" anything the claimant says, even under oath. His failure to treat the matter seriously is perfectly congruent with the fact that his claim against the Netherlands is without foundation. The Refugee Protection Division finds that claimant's vague pronouncements do not constitute clear and convincing evidence of the Netherlands' inability to protect him against local representatives of the government of Iran and do not discharge the burden of proof on him as a Dutch citizen.
Considering all of the evidence, the Refugee Protection Division finds that the claimant has failed to provide sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence to establish that he has a well founded fear of persecution in the Netherlands, his second country of nationality, under Section 96 of the IRPA, or that his removal to the Netherlands would subject him personally to a risk to life, or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, or a danger of torture, at the hands of representatives of the Iranian government, under Section 97 of the IRPA. In this case, the overall negative credibility assessment and the specific adverse findings with respect to the Netherlands on the issues of credibility and state protection are determinative of the claim under all of the provisions of the IRPA.
Exclusion Under Article 1E
In relation to the claimant's evidence in the PIF and at the first sitting of the hearing, previous Minister's counsel Gordon Starr conceded in written submissions that there is no basis for exclusion and the claimant cannot avail himself of the protection of the US based on his father's status in that country. The Refugee Protection Division finds that Article 1E of the UN Convention does not apply in the absence of evidence that the claimant has resident status in the US.
No Credible Basis
In rejecting this claim to refugee protection, the Refugee Protection Division finds that there was no credible evidence on which it could have made a favourable decision. The claimant's evidence is without merit and there is no credible basis for his claims against Iran or the Netherlands.21
DETERMINATION
For all the reasons above the Refugee Protection Division finds that the claimant has failed to provide sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence to establish his claim to refugee protection in reference to either of his countries of nationality under Section 96 of IRPA.
The Refugee Protection Division also finds that the claimant has failed to provide sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence that he would be subjected personally to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture or to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, under Section 97 of the IRPA.
Accordingly, the Refugee Protection Division determines that XXXXX XXXXX (a.k.a. XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX and XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX) is not a Convention refugee or person in need of protection. Furthermore, there is NO CREDIBLE BASIS for his claim.

These are the reasons for the decision in the matter of XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, a 29 year old citizen of the United States. He claims refugee protection pursuant to sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).1
ALLEGATIONS
He alleges that in 1992 he first enlisted in the U.S. Navy at the age of 18. He served for four years in the nuclear program and, following a series of promotions, received an honourable discharge in 1996, two years in advance of the estimated duration of his service. He had decided to leave the military in order to attend school and had a good experience in the military up to this point.
In the year 2000, he re-enlisted in the U.S. Navy.2 He had advanced and received promotions on a regular basis and was ahead of schedule in his intended service.
Problems began to occur for the claimant around XXXXXX, 2001. He was asked to do a preventative maintenance system (PMS) check on some life jackets. There was a personality conflict between he and his immediate superior and between he and the more senior officers in the Chain of Command. Specifically, he ran into difficulty with the Damage Control Officer, XXXXX.
Exhibit 2.2 is a "Report and Disposition of Offenses," which took place around this time. The claimant was charged with "failure to obey a direct order," which originated from this PMS check on XXXXX, 2001. The claimant brought his documents with him when he left the U.S. in XXXXX of 2001. A hearing called a "Captain's Mast" took place regarding the allegations.
The sentence that the claimant received after his hearing, was a 45-day "restriction," which means that he was required to stay on the boat. He also received 45 days "extra duties," which included manual labour and a "suspended bust," which is a temporary reduction of rank. This sentence was rendered and took effect immediately on the Captain's Mast date, which was XXXXX, 2001.
The sentence was imposed pursuant to UCMJ Article 107. The claimant says that he does not know what the maximum penalty could have been for this charge. He also indicated that he paid a fine, which was not reflected in the disposition report.
Around this time the claimant suffered from sleeping disorders, knee problems, depression and anger. He was placed on light duty by the ship's doctor. As the pressure from his colleagues increased and accusations regarding poor personal hygiene and other matters were raised, the claimant became distraught and left the ship on Friday, XXXXX 2001, when he was finished his sentence.
The claimant testified that he "blanked out" on the weekend that he left the ship. He does not recall anything that happened during the course of that weekend. On Monday morning at approximately 6:00 or 7:00 a.m., approximately one to two hours before he was due back on the ship, he called his Chain of Command, the OS1, and told him that he was ill and unable to return to the ship. The OS1 started yelling at the claimant and told him that if he did not return to the ship he would be charged with further offences.
The claimant had somehow visited a doctor over the course of that weekend, although he does not recall having done so. He did, however, have a doctor's note in his possession which told him to stay home for three days. This note was in writing. He does not know where he got it and he was unable to produce it at his refugee hearing.
The claimant believes that if he had returned on that Monday morning in time to meet his 8:00 a.m. deadline, he would have been harassed by the Chain of Command and yelled at some more. If he was late, he would be charged with six further counts for missing the time, and if he did not come back for the three days as recommended by the doctor, he would face further problems and more charges.
He testified that each count has its own penalty and it is up to the captain what penalty to impose. He indicated there could have been more restrictions, further reductions in his rank and a further forfeiture of pay. He did not say that he was facing the risk of torture or risk to his life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, although in submissions counsel alleged that the treatment he could receive would amount to cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. I will have more to say about that below.
Around mid- XXXXX 2001, the claimant came to Canada and brought with him the Report and Disposition of Offenses and his Navy Identity Card, which he submitted to Citizenship and Immigration Canada when he made his refugee claim.
While the claimant is confused about some of the facts, he did testify in a fairly straightforward manner, and appear to comprehend the nature of the refugee proceedings. A designated representative was appointed to assist the claimant.
DETERMINATION
I find that the claimant is not a Convention refugee in that he does not have a well-founded fear of persecution for a Convention ground in the United States. I also find that the claimant is not a person in need of protection in that his removal to the United States would not subject him personally to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment and, in that there are no substantial grounds to believe that his removal to the United States will subject him personally to a danger of torture.
ANALYSIS
Identity
The claimant's identity as a national of the U.S. is established by his testimony and the supporting documentation filed.
Credibility
I have found the claimant to be a credible witness to the extent that he was able to elucidate the panel with respect to the facts of his case. I believe what he has alleged in support of his claim insofar as the allegations relate to facts, which can be proven. However, there are instances where the claimant speculated or drew conclusions not born out by the evidence.
The claimant was confused about some of the facts in the case. For example, the CIC Notes filed3 indicate that the claimant visited Canada in March, April and May of 2001. On at least one of these three dates, the claimant was confined to the ship and could not have travelled to Canada. He realized that this was the case when he was testifying but could not explain why there was a discrepancy. He indicated he had been in Canada in March and April in his Notification of Claim to be a Convention Refugee.4
Harm Feared: Is It Persecution?
The first question for the panel to resolve is whether what the claimant describes is persecution. The claimant alleged that should he return to the United States, he would be subjected to the following harm namely, degrading comments, fellow officers and military personnel getting him into trouble, having his bed torn apart, finding metal shavings in his bed, being ostracized by his colleagues, getting no support from his seniors, being unfairly targeted for his personal hygiene, which he has a difficult time maintaining, being forced into displaying his anger, which he has a difficult time controlling, and so on.
I find that the harm allegedly feared by the claimant does not constitute persecution. Persecution has been defined as a sustained or systematic violation of fundamental human rights. I find that the harm feared does not violate a fundamental right.
In view of my finding that the harm feared does not amount to persecution because it does not violate a fundamental right, I also find that the harm feared cannot amount to a risk to life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment or to a danger of torture, as the harm envisaged in all of these instances necessarily constitutes a violation of a fundamental right. To be considered persecution, the mistreatment suffered or anticipated must be serious. I find that the incidents complained of may amount to discrimination or harassment, but they do not amount to persecution.
The mistreatment suffered or anticipated by the claimant includes matters which are within the ambit of the U.S. Navy to control. Spending "a lot of time in the brig (military jail)" and being subjected to harassment and ostracism of his colleagues does not amount to persecution. In my view, the claimant would be permitted to mount a defence to any charges alleged, despite his fear that this would not be available to him. He would, in my view, also be permitted to call medical evidence to confirm the fact, if it does in fact exist, that he is clinically depressed, nervous, angry and has a medically certifiable mental illness. I do not know whether a
physician would make this determination but, if the claimant is in fact mentally ill, this could certainly be assessed by a physician or psychologist and presented to a military tribunal.
In view of my finding that the harm feared is not serious, I also find that the harm feared does not amount to a risk to life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment and punishment or to a danger of torture as the harm envisaged in all of these instances must necessarily be of a serious nature.
Cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, although not defined in the Act, has been described as "punishment or treatment that violates our sense of fundamental justice or shocks the conscience."5 Torture constitutes "an aggravated and deliberate form of cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment."
I have also considered whether the acts of discrimination or harassment alleged may cumulatively constitute persecution or whether the repeated incidents of discrimination or harassment in the past may lead to a serious possibility of persecution in the future. I find that the repeated acts of harassment feared by the claimant do not amount to persecution because the treatment does not amount to a violation of a fundamental right and because the harm feared is not serious.
To constitute persecution, the harm feared must occur with repetition or persistence or in a systematic way. I find that the harm complained of amounted to a few isolated incidents arising from one act and that, given all of the circumstances, there is no serious possibility that it will recur.
The claimant alleges that the prosecution awaiting him in the United States by the military tribunal constitutes persecution for a Convention reason. He alleges that he is a member of a particular social group as a military deserter. The claimant alleges that the law under which he is being prosecuted violates basic human rights and that the penalty he would suffer is disproportionate to the objective of the law and that the punishment constitutes persecution. He also alleges he would suffer extra-judicial punishment in that a military tribunal is not subject to the same rules as a criminal court, including a lack of due process.
The UNHCR Handbook on Procedures and Criteria for Determining Refugee Status6 is instructive in this regard. The claimant is alleging that he is a refugee because he would suffer disproportionately severe punishment for the military offence on account of his membership in a particular social group, and perhaps also, an account of his race as an Angle-Saxon. He alleges that Officer XXXXX is an African American and that he was targeted as a result of racism.
I do not find, on the evidence before me, sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence that this is so. In addition, I do not find that the claimant has properly defined the social group to which he belongs as envisaged by the Immigration Act or the Geneva Convention.
In certain cases, the type of military action with which an individual does not wish to be associated is condemned by the international community as contrary to basic rules of human conduct. In these cases, punishment for desertion or draft evasion could, in the light of all other requirements of the definition, in itself be regarded as persecution. However, the claimant must advance religious convictions, which are genuine and demonstrate that such convictions are not taken into account by the authorities in his country in requiring him to perform military service.
The claimant has not advanced any evidence of a religious conviction or a moral reason of conscience to not obey his superior officers. I do not find that the claimant has invoked genuine reasons of conscience to exempt him from military service, which could offer an explanation for his refusal to follow the Chain of Command.
The claimant presents as a person with a mental illness. However, a medical report was not filed as part of his hearing. I am basing my assessment simply on my observations of the claimant's demeanour during the hearing. Because of this mental illness, if one exists, the claimant may be discriminated against by the U.S. Navy. However, in my view, at most this is discrimination and not persecution for a Convention ground.
I note that the claimant was promoted a number of times while in the Navy and it is clear to me that there may be a personality conflict between he and his direct superiors in this, his second tour of duty. However, he has not demonstrated that the discrimination or harassment is systematic in any way, in the U.S. military.
Because I am sensitive to the fact that the claimant may have a mental illness, with respect to the issue of delay, I have relied upon the UNHCR Handbook, paragraph 210:
It will, in any event, be necessary to lighten the burden of proof normally incumbent upon the applicant and information that cannot easily be obtained from the applicant may have to be sought elsewhere, e.g. from friends, relatives and other persons closely acquainted with the applicant or from his guardian, if one has been appointed.
XXXXX XXXXX testified that the claimant was confused about his status in Canada and Mr. XXXXX was not aware that the claimant had filed a refugee claim. I am satisfied that the reason for the claimant's delay in making a claim is not at all related to his subjective fear but is more related to the nature of his mental condition, which at times causes him to be confused.
What is the claimant likely to face upon return to the United States? To answer this question, I have reviewed the documentary evidence filed in the claim.
According to the Manual of Courts-Martial, Article 85, paragraph 9, the offence of desertion includes the case of a person who remains absent from his unit, organization or place of duty with intent to remain away there from permanently.7
The document goes on to discuss the maximum punishments for desertion and indicates that they vary based upon the circumstances. For example, where the person has attempted or completed desertion with intent to avoid hazardous duty or to shirk important service, the maximum punishment would be dishonourable discharge, forfeiture of all pay and allowances, and confinement for five years.
In situations where the desertion is for other reasons and the person is captured involuntarily, the maximum punishment is dishonourable discharge, forfeiture of all pay and allowances, and confinement for three years.
Where, however, desertion is for other reasons than those already mentioned and the person voluntarily surrenders, the maximum punishment is dishonourable discharge, forfeiture of all pay and allowances, and confinement for three years.
The claimant's counsel submits that the claimant may face death upon return because, since his desertion, the United States government is at war. The Manual of Courts-Martial, Article 85, indicates that the maximum punishment for desertion during a time of war is death or such other punishment as a court-martial may direct.8 I do not find that this section of the Courts-Martial Act applies to the claimant since his desertion took place long before September 11, 2001 and long before war was declared on Iraq.
The claimant was asked what he believes would be the sentence he would be facing, given the number of charges that may be laid against him. He indicated that, because of the fact there were multiple charges, he might be facing eight years in the brig. If this is indeed the sentence that the claimant faces, I do not find that the sentence is persecutory, in the circumstances.
State Protection
The claimant must approach his state for protection if state protection is reasonably forthcoming.9 The claimant has the burden of rebutting the existence of state protection with "clear and convincing proof of the state's inability to protect."10
The claimant has failed to rebut the presumption that his state is willing to protect him from rogue military officers if, in fact, this is what he faces upon return. If the military is discriminating against the claimant because he is, in fact, mentally ill, he is entitled to raise this as an explanation for his past behaviour. If he feels that he has been unfairly treated by the United States Navy, he has the option of a civil action against the military available to him.
The United States is a democracy with a highly sophisticated justice system with checks and balances such as those envisaged by the Federal Court of Appeal in the decision of Satiacum.11
In the absence of exceptional circumstances, Canadian tribunals must assume a fair and independent judicial process in a foreign country. In a democracy such as the United States, with a free and independent judicial system, it would be necessary to impeach substantially the relevant jury selection process or the independence and fair mindedness of the judiciary.
The decision of Satiacum was considered with approval in Ward. After completing its analysis of Satiacum, the Supreme Court explained further the purpose of the presumption of a state's ability to afford protection in these words:
Although this presumption increases the burden on the claimant, it does not render illusory Canada's provision of a safe haven for refugees. The presumption serves to reinforce the underlying rationale of international protection as a surrogate, coming into play where no alternative remains to the claimant. Refugee claims were never meant to allow a claimant to seek out better protection than that from which he or she benefits already.
In Kadenko12 the Court of Appeal revisited the issue of state protection and set out the refugee claimant's burden of proof in terms of the level of democracy in the country in question.
Once it is assumed that the state has political and judicial institutions capable of protecting its citizens, it is clear that the refusal of certain police officers to take action cannot, in itself, make the state incapable of doing so. When the state in question is a democratic state, as in the case at bar, the claimant must do more than simply show that he or she went to see some members of the police force and that his or her efforts were unsuccessful. The burden of proof that rests on the claimant is in a way directly proportional to the level of democracy in the state in question. The more democratic the state's institutions, the more the claimant must have done to exhaust all of the courses of action open to her or to him.
The issue, therefore, is whether Mr. XXXXX has advanced "clear and convincing" evidence to rebut the presumption of state protection in the United States. The fact that Mr. XXXXX has experienced difficulties with certain military officers in the United States does not make him a Convention refugee.
With respect to risk to the claimant's life or the risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, I find that the treatment that the claimant fears is not inhuman or degrading, nor does it rise to the level that it is cruel and unusual treatment. The treatment that the claimant describes is not premeditated, applied for hours at a stretch and causing, if not bodily injury, intense physical and mental suffering. Degrading treatment has been described as arousing in its victims
feelings of fear, anguish and inferiority, capable of humiliating and debasing them and possibly breaking their physical and moral resistance.13
I find that the treatment feared by the claimant is not cruel and unusual treatment because it is not so excessive as to outrage standards of decency and surpass all rational bounds of punishment. The test is one of proportionality: Is the punishment grossly disproportionate to the inherent seriousness of the offence?14 Is the punishment so demeaning that all human dignity is lost?15
I find that the punishment alleged by the claimant is not cruel and unusual. Is it torture? Torture is distinguishable from other forms of harm on the basis of the severity of the pain or suffering inflicted. Torture constitutes an aggravated and deliberate of cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.
The term "torture" is reserved for deliberate treatment causing particularly cruel suffering, namely, acts by which severe pain or suffering, whether physical or mental, is intentionally inflicted.16 I find that the severity of the pain or suffering inflicted does not constitute torture.
CONCLUSION
Whether the claim is framed under the Convention refugee sections of the Act or the risk of torture or the risk to life or of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, the outcome is the same. There is no evidentiary basis for the claim under IRPA.
For the reasons given, and upon consideration of the whole of the evidence, the Refugee Protection Division determines that XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX is neither a Convention refugee as defined in section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act nor a person in need of protection as defined in section 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act. For these reasons, his claim is rejected.
