XXXXXXXXXX is a 47-year-old citizen of China. She claims she has a well-founded fear of persecution based on political opinion and membership in a particular social group. She also fears a risk to her life, a risk of cruel and unusual punishment or treatment, and a danger of torture. Specifically, the claimant, who worked for a major family planning office for 20 years, fears beatings, arrest, false charges, detention and possible death because she convinced the daughter-in-law of a prominent person to have an abortion.
The Minister's Representative argues the claimant should be excluded under section 98 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (Act)1 and Article 1F(a) and (c) of the Refugee Convention because of her participation in forced abortion in furtherance of family planning goals.
The issues in this case are whether the claimant should be excluded under section 98 of the Act and, if not, whether the claimant is a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection under sections 96 or 97 of the Act.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant worked for the XXXXXXXXX Company from 1978 to 2000 and, from 1980 to 2000, she was the office manager of family planning. According to the claimant, under the family planning laws, with a few exceptions, women were not allowed to have more than one child. The claimant said, prior to 1985, several women at the XXXXXXXX Company had extra births. The company faced significant fines for those extra births. However, the claimant says, beginning in 1985, she was able to offer more incentives and, from 1985 to 2000, there were no out-of-plan births at the XXXXXX company. The company employed approximately 8000 people. When the claimant left the company there were approximately 3800 female employees. The claimant was in charge of the enforcement of the family planning regulations for all these women. She had ten assistants who reported to her.
The claimant said, starting in 1985, every woman at the XXXXX company who became pregnant contrary to the family planning regulations agreed to an abortion. Almost always this occurred within the first three months of the pregnancy. The claimant says she never "forced" any woman to have an abortion; rather she used arguments, education and financial incentives. She said personally she did not agree with the strict one-child-policy and felt women should have a right to have children. However, she recognized that overpopulation was a problem in China that affected the social economy. She said she was just following orders, as family planning was the only way to limit the problems of overpopulation.
In May 2000, the claimant discovered that XXXXXXXXX, the daughter-in-law of the general manager of the XXXXX company, was six months pregnant. XXXXXXX already had a daughter and was not entitled to have another child, but she and her husband wanted to have a son. XXXXXXXX had stayed home from work on sick leave for two months to avoid detection. The claimant said no one at the XXXXX company had previously managed to remain pregnant for so long without detection. Once the claimant discovered XXXXXX was pregnant, she visited her at home every other day for three to six hours at a time to try and persuade her to have an abortion. Her assistant, XXXXXXX, accompanied her on most visits because the claimant says it was easier when there was a second person there. After about a month, the claimant persuaded XXXXXX to have an abortion and the abortion was performed when XXXXXXX was about seven months pregnant. The claimant went to the hospital with XXXXXXXX for the abortion. It was determined the child would have been a male. The claimant said she saw the aborted fetus and it was fully-formed. The claimant says she later found out XXXXXXXXX father-in-law, the general manager of the XXXX company, was getting a false medical certificate that would have allowed his daughter-in-law to have the second child, but he did not get that document in time to prevent the abortion. The claimant never saw that document, nor was she aware of it at the time of the abortion.
The claimant says she suffered significant consequences for persuading XXXXXXXX to have an abortion. The windows at her house were broken. She was badly beaten on several occasions. The police would do nothing to help her. She was dismissed from work. She was forced to put her fingerprints on an anti-Communist poster. The PSB (Public Security Bureau) were pursuing her. She complained to the City and Provincial Family Planning authorities and the People's Complaints Department, but they would not assist her. Finally, the claimant paid an agent to leave China and come to Canada. Since she has been in Canada, she has discovered the PSB want to question her about charges that she was embezzling public funds. The claimant says these are false charges. The claimant fears continued physical attacks and no police protection, arrest, detention and imprisonment on false charges if she returns to China.
DETERMINATION
I find the claimant is excluded by virtue of section 98 of the Act and Article 1 F(a) of the Refugee Convention, as I find there are serious reasons for considering that she committed a crime against humanity. In the alternative, I find the claimant is not a Convention refugee and is not a person in need of protection, as I do not accept her story of alleged persecution or serious harm. I find she has not rebutted the presumption of state protection.
ANALYSIS - EXCLUSION
Forced abortion
I find the claimant "forced" XXXXXXX to have an abortion by relentless and extreme psychological pressure and threats. The claimant admits she put considerable pressure on XXXX XXXXX to have an abortion, but she says she did not "force" her to have the abortion. She said she did not take XXXXXX to the hospital until she agreed, and she would not have allowed the abortion to proceed if XXXXXX had changed her mind.
The Minister's Representative says the claimant forced XXXXXXX to have an abortion through the extreme psychological pressure she placed on her for a month. The Minister's Representative also says the claimant admitted in her interview with an Immigration Officer that she forced women to have abortions and sterilizations.
The claimant entered Canada on XXXXX, 2001, and made her refugee claim in October 2001. The Declaration of the Immigration Officer who interviewed the claimant on October 18, 2001, using a certified Mandarin interpreter, indicates the claimant provided background information; she said she was "very serious in carrying out her duties and had done a lot of enforcing, e.g. forced abortions and sterilization"; the worst case was in August 2000 when she "forced" the daughter-in-law of the general manager of the XXXXX company to have an abortion when she was seven months pregnant; and she then suffered significant consequences for her role in that abortion including being beaten up by four men and receiving serious wounds, all her windows were broken, she was threatened by the woman's husband, she was suspended from her job, and her husband was suspended from his work at the same employer.2
The Declaration of the Immigration Officer is dated January 9, 2002 - although it concerns an interview on October 18, 2001. It is not a document made under oath. It is not obvious from the face of the Declaration how this information was recorded at the interview and how the accuracy of the information was checked when the Declaration was signed in January 2002. However, the Declaration has much information that is accurate and, generally, I accept that the information set out in the Declaration is a reasonably accurate reflection of the information provided by the claimant at the interview on October 18, 2001. That information contains two clear references to forcing women to have abortions. At one point in the hearing, the claimant denied she said that at the interview. Later, when asked by her counsel if she recalled what she said at the interview or just what is true, the claimant said she is not quite sure. Thus, not surprisingly, she does not remember exactly what she said at the interview on October 18, 2001. However, she says she told the truth to the Immigration Officer and it is not true that she forced any women to have abortions.
I have considered whether the words "forced" and "pressured" (or "convinced" or a similar word) could have been used interchangeably, either by the claimant or by the interpreter or in the Immigration Officer's record of the interview. However, the interpreter, Mr. XXXXX XXXXX, has interpreted at many Refugee hearings and I am confident he would appreciate the significant difference between those two words in this context. I am also satisfied an Immigration Officer would appreciate the difference between the words "forced" and "pressured" in this context. Thus, on a balance of probabilities, I do not think that either the interpreter or the Immigration Officer would casually or mistakenly use the word "forced" if the claimant had said "pressured", or some similar word. Therefore, I am satisfied the claimant said she "forced" women to have abortions. However, I do not necessarily conclude that the claimant meant she physically dragged women off to have abortions without any indication from them that they agreed to the process. She seems to have meant "forced" in the sense that she put such extreme pressure on them that they "agreed" to an abortion that they would not otherwise have agreed to. The claimant had the position and authority to apply this pressure effectively. I find this use of the word "forced" in the interview would reflect the claimant's perspective on the process - these were not situations where women freely consented to an abortion, but rather situations where women were forced to consent. That also would be consistent with current country documentation that indicates, increasingly, family planning officials, and especially those in urban areas, are not physically dragging women off to have abortions against their will, but are using a range of incentives, disincentives, psychological pressure and threats to achieve their family planning goals.3 Counsel referred to this as the modern approach to family planning in China.
At the hearing the claimant says she never "forced" any women to have an abortion. However, she admits she knew XXXXXXXX was six to seven months pregnant, she and a co-worker visited her every other day at home, and they stayed for three to six hours each time to try and persuade XXXXX to have an abortion. She told XXXX if she did not have an abortion she and her husband would lose their jobs at the XXXX company - which were well-paid jobs, they would lose their house, they would be fined, they would not be able to register their second child in their Household Registration - which would mean the child would not have the usual rights to education, and XXXXXXX would be arrested. The claimant says all these threats were true, except the last one, but she added it toward the end to put additional pressure on XXXXXX to have the abortion, even though the claimant knew XXXXXXXX would not be arrested if she did not have an abortion. The claimant says she added this threat because timing was becoming very critical, as XXXXXXXX would soon get to the point where it would be too late for an abortion. Hence, the claimant and her co-worker increased their contact with XXXXXXXXX and the pressure they put on her to have an abortion. The claimant says she and XXXXXXX were at XXXXXXXX house for six hours on the final day before XXXXXX finally "agreed" to the abortion. The claimant immediately took her to the hospital and the abortion was performed the same day. XXXXXXXXX husband had been at home at the start of that day when the claimant arrived, but he had gone to work. He opposed the abortion, and the claimant speculated that when he went to work he was confident his wife would not consent to the abortion. The claimant did not contact him once XXXXXXX "agreed" to the abortion. She says she asked XXXXXXX but she did not want to contact her husband.
I find, when the claimant now says she never "forced" any woman to have an abortion, she is using it in a more limited sense than she did at her initial interview. The claimant now means she never physically dragged a woman to the hospital for an abortion. However, I find the extreme pressure exerted on this woman to have an abortion when seven months pregnant amounted to "force". The claimant lied to XXXXXXXXXX about being arrested in order to pressure her. The claimant was clearly an older and experienced person in a position of authority, and XXXXXXXXXX would not have known the claimant was lying about the threat of arrest and loss of liberty. After a full month of extreme and unrelenting pressure and threats at her home from two women, XXXXXXXXXX finally "agreed" to go with the claimant to have an abortion. The claimant said she had visited XXXXXXXXXX at least fifteen times.
The claimant's threats amounted to taking away the livelihood of the family, imposing fines they would not be able to pay, forcing them out of their home, removing the claimant's liberty, and saying the child would not be registered. I find, given the claimant's position and authority, and the relentless pressure she put on this woman, the claimant "forced" XXXXXXXXXX to have the abortion, in the sense that, on the last day, XXXXXXXXXX was under such duress that she felt she had no choice but to agree to the abortion. The claimant says she used arguments and incentives to get women to agree to abortions. However, she made no mention of incentives, in the sense of additional benefits, in this case. Rather, everything was a threat to remove what XXXXXXXXXX already had and threats that the child would not be entitled to normal education and social benefits. I find these threats were not incentives, as they did not offer any additional benefits. Rather, they were serious threats to her physical and economic well-being. Most of these threats were real, in that these consequences could and likely would occur if she had the baby. I find this left her virtually no choice about having an abortion. When the claimant added the threat of arrest, it appears XXXXXXXXXX finally realized she had no choice. It was the abortion or her liberty. She would not even call her husband before going for the abortion, even though they obviously had decided together to have this baby. The claimant added the final, improper, threat for exactly that reason - to force XXXXXXXXXX to agree to an abortion. There was no other purpose for that additional threat.
Based on this information and the above analysis, I find the claimant "forced" this woman to have an abortion. I also find, on a balance of probabilities, she forced other women to have abortions as well. She said this at her interview with the Immigration Officer. When she now says she did not "force" any women to have an abortion, she means she did not drag them off for an abortion. However, I find, at the time of the interview she was using the word "forced" in the same way I am here - to include situations when a woman "agrees" to an abortion after extreme, unrelenting psychological pressure and threats.
Crime Against Humanity - Law
Counsel for the claimant made oral and written submissions on this issue. Counsel argued that forced abortion is not a crime against humanity and cited the Supreme Court of Canada decision in Finta:4
... for example, robbery without the additional component of barbarous cruelty is not a crime against humanity... To convict someone of an offence when it has not been established beyond a reasonable doubt that he or she was aware of conditions that would bring to his or her actions that requisite added dimension of cruelty and barbarism violates the principles of fundamental justice (para. 227, emphasis added).5
Counsel also argued, while the Federal Court decision in Cheung6 found forced sterilization constitutes persecution for the purposes of protection, that is not authority for the proposition that forced abortion or sterilization is a crime against humanity under article 1F(a) of the Refugee Convention. Counsel also said the Supreme Court of Canada decision in Chan7 said there is no persecutory intent on the part of the Chinese government in their one-child-policy; rather, it is necessary to examine the method of enforcement of that policy to ascertain whether there is persecution. Counsel argued that because the activities of the Chinese birth control committees were not intended to have a persecutory intent, they cannot amount to an intentional act of "barbarous cruelty" that is required to make them crimes against humanity under Article 1F(a).8
The Minister's Representative said victims of forced abortions are recognized as Convention refugees in Canada, pursuant to Federal Court decisions, and the Act cannot be used to protect both victims and perpetrators. The Minister's Representative also said forced abortion is an inhumane act that causes great pain and suffering.
The relevant part of Article 1F(a) of the Refugee Convention, as set out in the Schedule to the Act is as follows:
F. The provisions of this Convention shall not apply to any person with respect to whom there are serious reasons for considering that:
(a) he has committed a crime against peace, a war crime, or a crime against humanity, as defined in the international instruments drawn up to make provision in respect of such crimes;
Clear authority on this issue is found in the Federal Court decision in Yang.9 There, the CRDD (Convention Refugee Determination Division) found there were serious reasons for considering that the claimant had committed a crime against humanity, and thus was excluded from the definition of a refugee by Article 1(F)(a) of the Refugee Convention. This was based on the claimant's participation in the enforcement of China's family planning policies through forced abortions and sterilizations. In dismissing the judicial review of the CRDD decision Evans J. stated:
There is no doubt that a person who is a willing participant in a forced sterilization or abortion cannot be a refugee by virtue of article 1F(a).
Mr. Justice Linden in the Federal Court decision in Cheung10 found that forced sterilization constitutes persecution, and is in clear violation of human rights:
... the forced sterilization of women is a fundamental violation of basic human rights. It violates Articles 3 and 5 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights and is a serious and totally unacceptable violation of her security of the person ... forced sterilization subjects a woman to cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment ... there are few practices that could be more intrusive and more brutal than forced sterilization ... I have no doubt, then, that the threat of forced sterilization can ground a fear of persecution within the meaning of Convention refugee under the Immigration Act.
Earlier in the decision, Linden J. A. referred to "forced or strongly coerced sterilization". I interpret that to mean he equated the two in his decision. I find the statements made by Mr. Justice Linden in Cheung about forced sterilization apply equally to forced or strongly coerced abortion.
Based on the decisions in Yang and Cheung, I find that forced abortion is a crime against humanity for the purposes of Article 1F(a) of the Refugee Convention. I am satisfied that the test for a crime against humanity is an act of barbarous cruelty that shocks the conscience. I find that forced abortion involves barbarous cruelty and is contrary to human dignity, and constitutes a crime against humanity, even if committed against only one person.
Crime Against Humanity - Analysis of this case
I find there are serious reasons for considering the claimant committed a crime against humanity - both in regard to the forced abortion of XXXXXXXXXX and the forced abortions of other women at the XXXX company. These forced abortions were carried out in pursuance of a policy that had widespread and systematic application in China for many years and was targeted at women. I find the claimant's role in implementing the family planning regulations in this way is a serious reason for considering she committed a crime against humanity. She put such extreme pressure on XXXXXXXXXX that, when was seven months pregnant, she went along with the claimant to have an abortion, even though she had been clearly and resolutely opposed to the abortion.
I find the claimant has no defence to her involvement in this crime. The claimant had been nominated for this position by her leader at the XXXX company as she was a good worker. She said it was not a promotion, although she said she received more pay. Previously, she had been a purchasing clerk at the XXXXX company, and this job was the office manager of family planning with ten assistants reporting to her. Clearly it was a promotion that she accepted.
The claimant remained in the position for twenty years. She said she was good at her work and enjoyed it. She won several awards for her "outstanding achievement".11 She said her boss liked having her in this position. From 1985 to 2000 she had complete success with no out-of-plan births. Clearly she was very good at this job and applied herself to it conscientiously and energetically.
The claimant says she did not agree with the strict enforcement of the one-child-policy, but she was just doing her job, as it was her duty. She said she could not leave the job because her boss wanted her to be there and it was not possible to just transfer or quit. At one point she said she could not quit because of her pension. The claimant said sometimes her assistants would not do very well in their position and would be transferred to another department. I do not accept that the claimant could not have left the job much earlier if she strongly disagreed with putting extreme pressure on women to have abortions and sterilizations. Like some of her assistants, if she had not done a good job, her boss likely would have transferred her elsewhere. I do not accept that she could not have quit and looked for other work if she was really opposed to the strict enforcement of the one-child-policy. This was a good paying job with much authority. The claimant took a lot of pride in her work. Clearly, she had no intention of leaving that job until she says she was forced to leave. She may not have been able to get another job with as much authority or remuneration, but that is no defence to remaining in this job for so long if she was actually opposed to some of the enforcement activities. Moreover, not only did she not leave the position, but she continuously engaged for many years in strong pressure tactics that clearly had effective results in the enforcement of this policy.
The family planning office was involved in matters other than abortions and sterilizations. The claimant said she was responsible for the health of all the women who worked at the XXXXX company, and this included regular checkups for various potential health problems. As well, many family planning activities did not involve abortions or sterilizations, but counselling and provision of birth control assistance. However, I find the claimant actively participated in forced abortions - both with XXXXXXXXXX and with other women. This is how the claimant achieved a perfect record of no out-of-plan births for fifteen years.
Counsel for the claimant said that exclusion does not apply in this case because the Minister has not established the requisite mens rea to find the claimant has committed a crime against humanity. I find there is no real issue of mens rea here. The claimant directed this department and was fully aware of all its activities. She was clearly involved in the abortion of this woman and other abortions. She said she went to the hospital with all women who were having abortions. In the matter of XXXXXXX, the claimant was the one who applied the extreme and relentless pressure for a month. The claimant made threats, including the threat of jail. The claimant took XXXXXXXXXX to the hospital for the abortion and waited for it to be done. The claimant ensured it was performed as she saw the aborted fetus. Thus, while the claimant did not actually perform the abortion, she was a knowing and wilful participant in the process. She clearly was complicit. Her actions for the whole month were directed toward one end - an abortion. There was no other purpose to those actions. She ensured it was carried out. I find she clearly participated directly, knowingly and wilfully in this forced abortion.
With respect to counsel's argument about no persecutory intent, the Supreme Court of Canada in Chan said China's one-child-policy in itself has no persecutory intent. The Court did say methods of enforcement could be persecution. That is what happened here. The claimant was involved in enforcement of the policy and the methods she used were clearly intended to force women to have abortions. I agree she did not do this for the purpose of being cruel. She was doing it to enforce the one-child-policy. However, I find that acting for a valid political or social goal is not a defence for people who commit, or are complicit in the commission of, acts of barbarous cruelty or serious violations of human rights in pursuing those goals.
In conclusion on this issue, I find that forcing a woman to have an abortion is a crime against humanity and the claimant forced XXXXX, and others, to have an abortion. I find her participation was direct, knowing and wilful. Therefore I find there are serious reasons for considering the claimant committed a crime against humanity. Therefore, I find she is excluded by section 98 of the Act and Article 1(F)(a) of the Refugee Convention.
ANALYSIS - INCLUSION
I am satisfied the claimant suffered some consequences after forcing XXXXXXXXXX to have an abortion. There are country reports that indicate that people involved in the harsh enforcement of the family planning regulations have experienced backlash from people whom they have persecuted.12 However, I do not accept the claimant's evidence about the extent of the consequences she faced or may face in the future. I find her evidence lacked credibility on some of these matters.
There are several problems with the claimant's story of serious persecution after XXXXXXXXXX had the abortion. First, I find she is unable to provide a satisfactory explanation as to why the general manager would have such a change of attitude toward her. The claimant had a very good relationship with her employer for at least twenty years. She had been promoted into her position in 1980, and since 1985 had maintained a perfect record of no out-of-plan births. She felt she could not leave this position because her employer wanted her in this position as she performed it so well. In this case the claimant was doing exactly what she had been doing for the past 15 years - successfully "convincing" women to have abortions. XXXXXXXXXX was not permitted to have another child. The claimant performed her job and "convinced" XXXXXXXXXX to have an abortion. Yet, for some reason, her employer suddenly turned on her.
When asked why, if she did not "force" XXXXXXXXXX to have an abortion, her father-in-law would turn on the claimant, the claimant said she did not know. However, she said he was very powerful and used his connections to have the PSB refuse to assist her and pursue her on false charges, and to have the City and Provincial Family Planning offices and the People's Complaints Department also refuse to assist her when she made complaints about being persecuted.
I can understand why XXXXXX husband may have been angry and may have caused trouble for the claimant after the abortion, although the claimant said she and XXXXXXXXXX continued to get along fine after the abortion. However, the father of this potential son may have realized the claimant had "forced" his wife to have an abortion and he wanted some revenge. But that does not explain why the claimant's employer also turned on her and why the police would take no action in response to these alleged assaults on her and her property and instead would participate in pursing the claimant on false charges.
The claimant thinks the general manager of the XXXX company turned on her because she convinced his daughter-in-law to have an abortion. However, the general manager would have been well aware of the success of the claimant's pressure tactics, but there is no evidence he interfered in any way with the claimant's activities during that month. If the general manager was so powerful that he could subsequently have the claimant fired and use his influence to cause the PSB to investigate her on false charges and cause the City and Provincial Family Planning Offices to abandon her, it seems likely he also would have had the power to stop the claimant from exerting such extreme pressure on his daughter-in-law to have an abortion. I find it is not plausible that the general manager would do nothing in the circumstances until after the abortion, and then be able to exert such wide influence, including on organizations outside the XXXX company, in a personal vendetta against the claimant.
I also find it is not plausible, on a balance of probabilities, that the family planning authorities in the City and Province would just abandon the claimant, after 20 years of good performance, for performing her job on this occasion.
The claimant says she later learned the general manager was getting a medical certificate that would allow his daughter-in-law to have a second child. That medical certificate would have falsely indicated the first child was not normal, as in that situation the couple would be permitted to have a second child. I find it is not plausible the general manager would take steps to get a false medical certificate, and yet apparently make no effort over the period of a month to try and restrain the claimant in the performance of her duties. Also, it is not clear why the general manager would wait so long to get a false medical certificate if he was trying to prevent an abortion. Finally, it is not clear why XXXXXXXXXX would consent to the abortion if she knew her father-in-law was getting a false medical certificate. I find the story about this false medical certificate does not stand up to analysis. On a balance of probabilities, I find this part of the claimant's story is not plausible and hence not credible.
Counsel suggested, that in pursuing the claimant so vigorously, the general manager was really trying to protect himself and deflect any investigation of the out-of-plan pregnancy away from him to the claimant. Counsel suggested the general manager was trying to cover up the fact he had obtained a false medical certificate, so he put the attention on the claimant. I find this is mere speculation. The claimant did not put forward this theory in her evidence, even though counsel asked her a clear, and leading, question about it. I have already found the story about the false medical certificate is not credible, so a key factual component of counsel's theory is missing. Further, since the general manager never produced the false medical certificate and the abortion proceeded, it is not clear why he had to deflect attention from himself in any investigation. On a balance of probabilities, I find this theory is speculative and not supported by the evidence. It does not provide a reasonable explanation for why the general manager would try to cause the claimant so much harm for doing her job.
The claimant also relies on a letter from her assistant, XXXXXXX, to show that she is being framed and persecuted for doing her job.13 There is a significant problem with this letter. In the letter, XXXXXX says she was demoted to a cleaning position, and then provides information about the investigation into the claimant's case and the actions of the general manager, his son and the PSB. XXXXXX is very critical of these people and very supportive of the claimant. Amazingly, the letter from XXXXXX was sent by airmail in an envelope that shows the XXXXXXXX Company and XXXXX for the return address. If this letter had been intercepted or returned for any reason and opened by someone at the XXXX company or at the PSB, where the general manager is alleged to have strong connections, XXXXXX would have put herself at great risk. I find it is not credible that XXXXXXX would make such strong accusations in a letter, and then send it in an envelope with her name and the XXXX company name on the outside of the envelope, if the general manager of the company and the PSB were involved in serious retaliation or persecution against the claimant. Thus, I find, on a balance of probabilities, the fact that XXXXXXX felt safe enough to send this letter as she did indicates the general manager and PSB are not pursuing the claimant.
The claimant relies on a number of other documents to support her claim of persecution. However, since I find her basic story of persecution by the general manager and the PSB is not plausible, I put little weight on most of these documents. As with XXXXXXX letter, I find the claimant is able to get unreliable supporting documentation. This includes two Writs of Summons - which are very general and do not set out any alleged offence,14 the letters from her husband - who is clearly an interested person,15 the two Approvals for Disciplinary Action at her former employment - both of which merely indicate the firings are for absence from work,16 and another Writ of Summons - which also is very general and does not set out any alleged offence.17 The claimant also provided medical records that indicate she had been struck and wounded and received continuing medical treatment.18 I think it is possible that XXXXXXXX husband could have retaliated against the claimant and had some people attack her. This is consistent with country documentation that indicates recently, in some instances, people who have been enforcing family planning regulations through forced abortions and sterilizations have experienced significant backlash from the recipients of that enforcement. However, even if XXXXXXXX husband did retaliate against the claimant, I find that by itself is not persecution or serious harm for the purposes of section 96 or 97 of the Act. Rather, it is criminal activity by an individual. That raises the issue of state protection.
I find the claimant has not presented clear and convincing evidence to rebut the presumption of state protection. I am not satisfied, on a balance of probabilities, that the PSB are improperly pursuing the claimant. She says the PSB did not deal with her complaints of being assaulted and they are pursuing her on false charges. However, in her statement to the Immigration Officer, provided on October 18, 2001, the claimant made no mention of her problems with the PSB, nor to signing an anti-government poster, nor to a Summons, nor to the need to go into hiding.19 All of that information was added later in her Personal Information Form. The claimant is a very intelligent, articulate woman who gave her evidence freely and in great detail at the hearing. The fact that her statement to the Immigration Officer referred only to problems with private individuals, and not to problems with the PSB, casts serious doubt on her story of persecution by the PSB. That is a crucial omission, because if the claimant was having problems with only private individuals, she would need to explain why she had not sought protection from the authorities or the police. Only later did she add this important aspect of her story. Her counsel said the main purpose of the immigration interview was to ascertain how she got to Canada. Thus, he says it would have been out of place for the claimant to talk at length about her persecution in China. However, I find the claimant did provide details about her persecution in China. In her PIF she indicated that when she received the summons from the PSB, she went into hiding and took steps to leave China. Thus, the involvement of the PSB was apparently critical to her decision to leave China, yet she made no reference to that in her interview with the Immigration Officer.
I find the claimant has failed to provide sufficient credible evidence to establish, on a balance of probabilities, that the public authorities or PSB are pursuing her. As a result, even if some people were causing trouble for the claimant, I find these were the actions of private individuals. The country documentation about China indicates it has a functioning police force. I find the claimant has failed to provide clear and convincing evidence to rebut the presumption of state protection.
Sur Place
Counsel also argues the claimant has been placed at risk by the inquiries made at the claimant's former workplace in China by CIC during this hearing.20 However, since I do not accept the claimant's story that she is being persecuted by her employer with the cooperation of the PSB, I find these inquiries did not increase her risk.
CONCLUSION
I find there are serious reasons for considering the claimant has committed a crime against humanity contrary to Article 1F(a) of the Refugee Convention. Therefore, pursuant to section 98 of the Act, I find XXXXXXX is not a Convention refugee and is not a person in need of protection.
In the alternative, I find the claimant has failed to produce sufficient credible evidence to show there is a real possibility she faces persecution on any Convention ground, or a risk to her life, or a risk of cruel and unusual punishment or treatment, or a danger of torture if she returns to China. She has failed to produce clear and convincing evidence to rebut the presumption of state protection. Therefore, I find XXXXXXX is not a Convention refugee and is not a person in need of protection under sections 96 or 97 of the Act.

XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX is a 36-year-old citizen of Algeria of Berber descent who claims to be a Convention refugee and a person in need of protection because members of the Armed Islamic Group (GIA) would again try to forcibly recruit him and would take retribution for the fact he slipped away in mid-1999 without keeping his promise to join them.
SUMMARY OF ALLEGATIONS
According to the claimant's Personal Information Form (PIF),1 his story covers ten years, from the time in XXXXX 1991 he first left Algeria to XXXXX in Libya as a way to avoid military service, to a brief sojourn in Europe and his final departure from Algeria in XXXXX 1999 which took him to Thailand, where he made a refugee claim with the UNHCR in XXXXX 2001, and then to his arrival in Canada on December 24, 2001.
His mother, two brothers and three sisters continue to live in Algeria. His father was murdered on XXXXX, 1998 by his own uncle's adopted son, XXXXX (spelled XXXXX in the PIF), who was a member of the GIA and is currently in prison serving a 25 year term for the crime. The claimant's cousin, XXXXXXXX, was born in the same place in Algeria as the claimant, just a year earlier, but like the whole paternal side of the claimant's family, he resides in France, using a different official spelling of the surname. They acquired French nationality in XXXXX 1981.2 XXXXX forwarded identity documents for the claimant while he was in detention in Canada for six weeks pending the determination by Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) of his eligibility and investigation of security concerns.
The family lived on XXXXX in the borough of XXXXX, in the province or XXXXX of XXXXX, about XXXXX km. east of the city of XXXXX. After the claimant graduated with a degree in XXXXX from the University of Algiers at XXXXX in the city of Algiers, he took a XXXXX job in Libya to avoid compulsory military service. He had obtained a passport earlier in 1991 and had several more days left on his student deferral and thus was able to leave the country legally. With great reluctance, according to the PIF, he went back to Algeria in XXXXX 1996 when the Libyan government advised him his services were no longer required and his visa would not be renewed.
Upon his return the claimant discovered a civil war was raging in which young men were being arbitrarily conscripted for both the army and for local militia groups, "Auto Defense," organized by the government. He took safety precautions but decided to apply for post-graduate study abroad. His cousin in France, XXXXX, had promised to lend him the money. He was accepted by a university in Ukraine and left Algeria in XXXXX 1996 to get visas in Tunisia. This time he had to bribe an acquaintance in the border police in order to depart, since he had not served in the military.
Upon arrival in Poland, however, he learned that XXXXX could not immediately provide the expected level of financial support and was disdainful of study in Ukraine, and the claimant considered that he would have to spend the first year just learning the language. So instead of going to Ukraine he decided to travel to Switzerland and make a refugee claim. According to his oral testimony, he took a taxi on the way to Switzerland and easily crossed the border into Germany. But the taxi driver thought he was a Turk and drove him straight to a police station where he was detained. After being fingerprinted and photographed and his passport seized, the claimant told his story and found out that it would not be possible to make a claim in Switzerland. According to the PIF, he was offered the choice of making a claim in either Germany or Poland, but the German police recommended the latter because it was easier and quicker. His oral evidence is that the German police explained that since he arrived through Poland he had to be returned there to make his refugee claim. Two days later he was escorted back to Poland and, although the German police handed over his file, he was put in jail and Polish officials said they knew nothing about a claim in Germany. He was given the choice of waiting for two months while the information was verified or agreeing to deportation to Tunisia. He chose the latter and arrived in Tunisia in XXXXX 1997.
The claimant's father persuaded the claimant to return to help on the family XXXXX with the promise to ask for an exemption for him from military service in light of the fact that his brother XXXXX had been conscripted. The GIA was known to be active in the area but XXXXX XXXXX was relatively calm. One night about six months after his arrival, a group of GIA members, including XXXXX, came to visit his father. They asked the claimant where he had been for the past seven years and he told them about Libya. While in the PIF he says merely that they were impressed, according to his oral evidence the GIA accused him of indoctrinating people with Occidental ideas and being un-Islamic and the claimant countered with a philosophy lesson about the life and death of a state and cast the GIA in a flattering light. He understood that the XXXXX was a place they came to from time to time for relaxation.
Following that encounter, the claimant was asked on two occasions to courier envelopes between the XXXXX and XXXXX, and felt he had no choice but to cooperate. His father explained that they were forced to assist this way in lieu of paying the GIA taxes, "Zaket." As a solution, his father agreed to move into the town of XXXXX XXXXX because the GIA would not come there. However, in order to buy another house, the claimant's father needed to call in a loan he had made to XXXXX. When he was unsuccessful he threatened to go to the police, according to the PIF. On XXXXX, 1998 XXXXX came to the XXXXX and struck and killed his father with an axe. The police came and arrested him, and at the funeral, the closest Auto Defense group promised to protect the family's home and XXXXX.
About a year later, the GIA came to see the claimant and their Emir told him they were looking for new followers. Because he had been in Libya they had confidence in him and it was also important to recruit him as a Berber. He pretended to agree with them but said he would need time to get some money together for his mother's support and then he would join them. One GIA member pointed a rifle and bayonet at him, but the Emir intervened and asked for whatever money he had. The claimant gave them some XXXXX dinars. Before the men left, according to the PIF, they said he had better not be deceiving them. He testified that they said, prepare for the next time.
Over the next two weeks the claimant sold all the XXXXX and XXXXX and left for Algiers. He spent a couple of weeks there and moved on to XXXXX, a calm part of Algeria near the XXXXX border, where he knew somebody with a XXXXX. But he stayed there for only a month because in early XXXXX 1999 there were two incidents, one in which the police killed terrorists and another in which terrorists killed people.
So he left Algeria again and stayed in Tunisia until XXXXX 1999 when he traveled to Thailand, since it was easy to get a visa. He made one attempt to come to Canada in XXXXX 2000 but was intercepted at the airport in Beijing when his document was found not to be genuine and he was told to leave China. He made a refugee claim at the UNHCR in Thailand in XXXXX 2001 and waited almost a year but before he had received a decision he tried to come to Canada once more. This time he succeeded with the use of a false Dutch passport in the name of XXXXX XXXXXXXXXXXX but destroyed it on the plane. He made a refugee claim at the Vancouver airport on December 24, 2001.
ISSUES
The issues identified in this claim included: personal identity; credibility; subjective basis; previous claims elsewhere in Germany/Poland and at the UNHCR in Thailand; re-availment in 1996 and 1997; objective basis; state protection; and Internal Flight Alternative (IFA).
According to the PIF, the claim is based on the Convention ground of political opinion, under Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).3 Counsel argued that, in the alternative, the claim is based on the consolidated grounds under Section 97 as a person in need of protection.
For his part the claimant clarified that he does not face persecution on account of his Berber ethnicity and he is no longer liable for military service in Algeria owing to a new law that was passed - evidently a reference to the clemency or regularization granted to men over age 27 beginning in XXXXX 1999 (just when he left the country).4
ANALYSIS
Personal Identity
The Refugee Protection Division finds the claimant has failed to provide sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence to establish that XXXXX XXXXX is his true personal identity.
In part this is because the reliability of all of the claimant's identity evidence is tainted by the fact that he alleges a history of falsifying documents to enter and leave countries, including the use of false passports on two separate attempts to enter Canada illegally. He boasted that the German police were impressed by the ease with which he breached border security in that country. In order to bolster his misrepresentation of himself as XXXXXXX XXXXXXX, the holder of the Dutch passport he used in XXXXX 2001, the claimant says he made fake entries in the address book and wrote travelogues in the notebook found in his possession upon arrival.5
The claimant has provided a few original documents to corroborate his identity as XXXXX XXXXX, such as three versions of an Algerian birth certificate (two in French, one in Arabic) and two Information Sheets, the latter bearing identical photographs. But as the forensic analyst at CIC observed, these particular documents lack security features.6 Moreover, they were sent from France, not Algeria, by the claimant's putative cousin, XXXXX XXXXX, with no explanation as to how they were obtained or by whom.7
The President of the University of Algiers sent a copy of XXXXX XXXXX "Interim Graduation Diploma" issued XXXXX, 1992,8 directly to Canada's mission in Algiers with a covering letter confirming its authenticity.9 Having received these documents, CIC apparently only needed to have the cousin in France provide the corresponding original student card (as had been offered) in order to release the claimant from detention.10 However, the card was not translated until the hearing, and the Refugee Protection Division notes that it is in the name of XXXXX XXXXX (spelled the same way as the paternal family in France which was the result of an official change of name when the claimant's uncle served under the flag of France during the Algerian war).11 Moreover, the translation indicates this card was issued by the University of XXXXX, not the University of Algiers.12
Photocopies of various other identity documents have been provided, such as a partial copy (six out of twenty-eight pages) of XXXXX XXXXX expired Algerian passport issued XXXXX, 1991. This document shows two Libyan residence visas, for 1994 and 1995. The claimant's brother XXXXX in Algeria is identified as the sender of copies of two Libyan records of employment for XXXXX XXXXX.13 The problem is that only one of these documents, pertaining to the academic years 1991/92 and for 1992/93, lists the same passport number as on partial passport itself XXXXX. The other, for the period covering the next three academic years, XXXXX 1993 to XXXXX, 1996 indicates a different passport number (XXXXX). This turns out to be the number the claimant gives in the PIF for an Algerian passport he did not even obtain until XXXXX, 1996.
In her oral Observations the Refugee Protection Officer (RPO) noted that there are two documents which taken together indicate on their face that the claimant was living in Algeria during the time of the alleged murder of his father, in XXXXX 1998, and the visit a year later by the GIA when they tried to forcibly recruit him and asked for money. One is a medical certificate of good health issued at XXXXX on XXXXX, 1998, according to the translation of the date by the hearing interpreter,14 and a validation of his Libyan Driver's License. The claimant testified that he obtained the medical certificate in order to apply for an Algerian driver's license (supposedly that's why the photograph is attached), and in order to expedite the process he got the Libyan Embassy in Algiers to issue him the Validation of Libyan Driver's License, on XXXXX, 1998.15 These documents could have been probative evidence of his residence there if the claimant had actually obtained a new driver's license in Algeria, since he listed this type of identity document as one of the most important to prove identity in every day life in Algeria. However, he testified that he stopped the application process because he found out that financially it was not easy to buy a car. That is a dubious answer but, in any event, there is no Algerian driver's license, and as a result, the Refugee Protection Division can give little weight to the only two documents issued to the claimant between XXXXX 1997 when he allegedly arrived back from Europe and XXXXX 1999 when he left for Asia. It is also worth noting that this photograph shows the subject clean shaven although the claimant testified that he wore a moustache during this period (in contrast to the members of the GIA who had full beards).
What is also questionable about the assortment of documents provided is how they could have been so readily available if, as the claimant testified, his mother told him while he was in Algiers, that all the contents of their home on the XXXXX had been destroyed and burned -- and "they" had left word on the walls that they would find him.
The other two key identity documents used by citizens of Algeria according to the claimant are the Algerian Identity Card and a valid passport. The claimant has provided neither to corroborate his identity as XXXXX XXXXX. He testified that "maybe" his Algerian Identity Card is Algeria and probably his family did not mail it to him because it is expired. The Refugee Protection Division finds this is not a satisfactory explanation since he obviously recognized the importance of this particular document. It was the only one of the three documents accessible, and he could have specifically requested that it be sent.
As for an Algerian passport, the claimant states in the PIF that the one issued in 1996 from the Algerian Embassy in Libya, which he used to go to Poland and Germany and to countries in Asia, was "lost" in Thailand. However, he testified that he lived in an apartment with a girl in Thailand and put the passport behind the heater (which was never used). One day he returned to find her gone and she had taken all of his belongings. This hardly fits the description of it being "lost."
Since that passport would have expired on XXXXX, 2001, according to the PIF, the claimant was asked at the hearing whether he had approached the Algerian Embassy in Ottawa to obtain a new one. He was clearly alarmed by the idea even though he has both legal status in Canada as a refugee claimant and a work permit, both conditions that would have to be met, according to him. There is no evidence or argument that the Algerian government is an agent of persecution in his claim, and the claimant would have been painfully aware from his detention that his personal identity was in doubt.
The Refugee Protection Division finds under Section 106 of the IRPA and Rule 7 of the RPD Rules that the claimant has not made reasonable efforts to obtain acceptable documentation establishing identity by failing to request the putative Algerian Identity Card from his family members in Algeria or to apply for a new passport since he has been in Canada.16
While the claimant was in detention in Canada, CIC received word from the German authorities that a subject by the same name and place of birth (XXXXX, Algeria) was intercepted on XXXXX 26, 1997 along the German/Polish border.17 Later, Interpol confirmed that the claimant's fingerprints matched that of the subject processed for violation of the German Immigration (Aliens) Act in 1997. "However, legitimate particulars are unknown."18 Thus the claimant has used this identity before. Such corroboration would stand in his favour were it not for the fact that his evidence about the events leading up to his encounter with the German police appears very far-fetched.
The claimant demonstrated that he is knowledgeable about Algeria, its history and geography, especially the area of the country where the family still owns its XXXXX. But he also presents as an intelligent, resourceful and well educated individual and this information would not be difficult for him to master for the purposes of his refugee claim.
Considering all of the evidence, the Refugee Protection Division finds that more likely than not there is an actual person named XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX whose tombstone data fit the alleged facts, and who graduated from the University of XXXXX in XXXXX, as the XXXXX of that university has confirmed to Canadian authorities directly. However, the claimant has failed to provide sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence that this is his true identity. And the fact that all the members of the whole paternal side of his putative family are nationals of France gives rise to the possibility that the claimant may be as well. This would certainly help account for the fact that most of his documents were sent from there.
These negative findings are determinative of the claim for protection under both Section 96 and 97 of the IRPA. However, out of an abundance of caution, the Refugee Protection Division will address several of the other issues below, on the presumption that the claimant is who he claims to be.
Credibility
The Refugee Protection Division finds there are serious reasons to doubt the truthfulness of core elements of the claimant's story of forcible recruitment by the GIA in Algeria.
The material discrepancy between the description in the PIF and his oral evidence about the reception he was given by the GIA during their first encounter in 1997 undermines the credibility of his allegation that this meeting ever happened and weakens the argument that there is any imputed political opinion behind the GIA's supposed threats to recruit him.
As the RPO pointed out in her examination and in her oral Observations, the objective information in evidence is that the Islamists in Algeria, including the GIA, do not use force to recruit their members. Two specialists are reported as saying that forced recruitment would lead to a high rate of desertion and adversely affect combat effectiveness. GIA recruits must be ideologically committed to the cause.19
Moreover, as the RPO also addressed, the claimant does not fit the profile of a typical member of the GIA. According to an expert at the University of Algiers who commented in XXXXX 1997, this would be a young man in his twenties, single, unemployed, with little education and a poor knowledge of French and Arabic.20 Another authority on the armed groups has commented that as of XXXXX 2000 the armed groups were still recruiting among young people and at that time the profile of GIA members was of young people at the fringes of society, unemployed youths or former delinquents, and the majority of them had no political culture.21
Counsel argues in her written submissions that, "Surely the GIA would not be averse to having an educated member in their midst."22 With due respect, however, she has not provided any evidentiary basis for that argument. There is objective information that the GIA is composed of semi-autonomous groups each controlled by local emirs.23 So it might also be that an emir's power would be threatened by recruiting to the ranks an educated and worldly man like the claimant.
The claimant's evidence about the GIA's extortion of money is somewhat more plausible and consistent with the documentary evidence. While some killings by armed groups relate to opposition to the authorities and the amnesty program that began in 1999, some of their activities are criminal rather than political such as turf wars between rival groups, revenge banditry, land grabs, committing robberies or operating protection rackets. The GIA also kidnap women for servitude and rape.24
However, the claimant has provided only two documents issued in Algeria at the time to corroborate the allegation that he returned to Algeria from Europe in XXXXX 1997 and lived and worked on the XXXXX near XXXXX XXXXX until about six weeks prior to his departure for Asia in XXXXX 1999. As the Refugee Protection Division has found above, these deserve little weight.
The very day the hearing started, the claimant provided a handwritten letter, which he says comes from his mother in XXXXX, Algeria.25 The courier waybill indicates it was sent by his brother XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX (again, the spelling used in France). However, the claimant testified his mother is illiterate, and it follows that she could not have written the letter. Since XXXXX XXXXX mailed the letter, it would seem plausible that she dictated to him, but the claimant said he was unsure and did not think it was a man's handwriting. This supposed uncertainty is not credible given that the claimant has a conversation with her when he requested the letter.
Further indications that this letter is not reliable or trustworthy evidence of the claimant's interactions with the GIA are found in the discrepancies between the contents and the claimant's oral testimony. (It is more consistent with the version of events in the PIF.) For example, the claimant testified that his mother told him after they had left the XXXXX and he was in Algiers, that their home had been ransacked and all the contents burned and a threatening message written on the wall for him. Yet there is no mention of this important incident in his mother's chronicle.
There were also discrepancies in the claimant's evidence concerning the events leading up to his father's alleged murder. But, in any event, this murder by XXXXX, an adopted member of the extended family, does not appear to have had anything to do with his involvement in the GIA. The claimant indicated he was a new member and supposedly the dispute was over repayment of a long-standing loan, although the claimant failed to mention the loan in any of his interviews with CIC. Presently XXXXX is safe behind bars serving a lengthy prison term for the crime and therefore poses no danger to the claimant.
Finally, the claimant testified that his refugee claim with the UNHCR in Thailand had the very same basis as this claim in Canada. He described the fact that he completed an application like the PIF, supplied photographs, attended an interview and was given a card with a number. He abandoned the claim owing to the long wait for an answer, since his status in Thailand was insecure, and because he had researched Canada on the Internet and through associates and preferred to come to this country.
He testified that he does not have the UNHCR card and did not think to ask any one of the lawyers who have represented him to contact the UNHCR in Canada to try to obtain corroboration of his claim. The Refugee Protection Division draws an adverse inference as to the credibility of the allegation that he made a previous refugee claim on the same basis, as a result of his failure to make efforts to obtain corroborative evidence, as that evidence is reasonably available
Overall, the Refugee Protection Division finds that the claimant has failed to provide sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence that he would be the target of retribution or forcible recruitment by the GIA and thus there would be a serious possibility that he would be persecuted by reason of his political opinion if he were to return to Algeria.
Objective Basis/ Consolidated Grounds
The documentary evidence26 shows that in the early and mid-1990s the GIA made specific threats against many categories of people thought to be anti-Islamic, such as the security forces and, government employees. In a later stage, its targets were intellectuals, journalists, lawyers, artists and foreigners. Following that, during another stage, the attacks were aimed at the general infrastructure of the country, such as bridges and railways. By 1998, it was the general population. The types of attacks committed now include apparently indiscriminate killings in massacres and with small bombs. They also ambush victims by mounting fake roadblocks. The violence takes place primarily in the countryside and smaller towns as the security forces have largely forced the insurgents out of the cities. The total number of GIA members in the country is unknown but estimates vary between several hundred and several thousand. Approximately one thousand members surrendered to the Algerian authorities under the terms of the Civil Concord.
According to the same source, in the year 2000 more than 50 % of the attacks were carried out in areas west of Algiers, mainly in the provinces of Medea, Ain Delfa and Tipaza -
where the claimant's family XXXXX is located. Meanwhile the situation in the cities of Algiers and Constantine was relatively calm, although the GIA was still active in the surrounding region.
This objective information shows that if the claimant faces a risk to life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment at the hands of the GIA, it is a risk faced generally by other individuals in or from that country - including his brother XXXXX in XXXXX XXXXX and his brother XXXXX XXXXX in Algiers. Furthermore, if he were to find the incidence of violence in Tipaza province intolerable, the claimant could move to the city of Algiers, which is relatively calm. He attended university there and in 1999 upon leaving the XXXXX, he went there seeking refuge.
Therefore the Refugee Protection Division finds that his claim to be a person in need of protection under Section 97(1) (b) is not objectively well-founded. As Minister's counsel argued in her oral submissions, there are no substantial grounds for believing that the claimant would be subjected to a danger of torture since there is no evidence of harm by the state.
Finally, on the question of whether he would be subjected to such mistreatment for the mere fact of his removal to Algeria as a failed refugee claimant, the Refugee Protection Division finds there is not a serious possibility of that.
According to information obtained in Algeria by a counselor of the Canadian Embassy, European countries remove hundreds of "deportees" yearly, and their diplomats and the local UNHCR office say there has never been any problem encountered by these persons, to the best of their knowledge.27 If the deportees did have serious difficulties, the embassies expect their relatives would complain.
The UNHCR has not called for a ban on the return of rejected asylum seekers. At a seminar in 2001, a UNCHR representative stated that one should seek guarantees of safety and be reluctant to return rejected applicants in the cases where the exclusion clauses have to be applied.28
Considering this objective information, the Refugee Protection Division finds there are no substantial grounds for believing that if the claimant were removed to Algeria he would be subject to a danger of torture or a risk to life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
DETERMINATION
For all the reasons above, the Refugee Protection Division finds that the claimant has failed to provide sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence to establish his personal identity. In the alternative, he has failed to provide sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence to prove essential elements of his story. Furthermore, he does not meet the definition of a person in need of protection under Section 97 because the risk he would face from the GIA would not be faced by him in every part of the country and it is a risk faced generally by other individuals in and from that country. Accordingly the Refugee Protection Division determines that XXXXX XXXXX is not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection.
