[1] These are the reasons for the decision in the claim for refugee protection of XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX. Mr. XXXXX is a 36 year-old citizen of the United States of America. He seeks refugee protection pursuant to sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).1
[2] I have considered the claimant's testimony, and the other evidence filed in the claim, which was heard over the course of several hearing days. The claimant was not represented by counsel, however he had the assistance of his friend XXXXX XXXXX, throughout most of the proceedings. Mr XXXXX also filed documentary evidence and made submissions on behalf of the claimant.
SUMMARY OF THE EVIDENCE
[3] The claimant alleges he is a Convention refugee because he has a well founded fear of persecution on account of his imputed anti-government political opinion. He is claiming that a federal prosecution against him is "selective prosecution with political motivation". He is also claiming to be a person in need of protection because he faces a danger of torture as defined in Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture,2 and because he personally faces cruel and unusual treatment or punishment and a risk to his life.
[4] By way of background, it is important to be aware of the history behind Mr. XXXXX claim for protection. The Controlled Substances Act (CSA)3 is a US federal statute providing that marihuana is a Schedule I drug.4 Schedule I drugs are recognized by federal authorities as having no medicinal value. Persons charged under federal law are not given the benefit of the "medical necessity" defence afforded those charged under state law.5
[5] In California, a new Act was passed in 1996 called the Compassionate Use Act (CUA).6 Under the CUA a medical user or his/her "primary caregiver" in California, is permitted to grow and possess marihuana with a medical note or verbal recommendation. No amounts are proscribed in the statute nor can amounts be prescribed by a doctor. There is no central state registry at present, although a new Bill which came into force in January 2004, may change this.7 Accordingly, California's Compassionate Use Act directly conflicts with the federal Controlled Substances Act.
[6] It is safe to say that the state of the law was and continues to be in flux as regards the medicinal uses and abuses of cannabis as the cases wind their way through the US courts, and must therefore be viewed as evolving. There was one witness other than Mr. XXXXX who testified in these proceedings, Mr. Panzer, Mr. XXXXX criminal defence attorney, who also testified at Mr. Kubby's hearing. He stated that federal agents targeted cannabis dispensaries. He represented one such dispensary.8 The Oakland Cannabis Buyers' Cooperative (OCBC) was formed to grow and dispense marihuana to approved medical users under the auspices of the City of Oakland. The federal government Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) charged individuals with federal offences, who were distributing under the auspices of the City of Oakland. XXXXX XXXXX, who was a XXXXX in Mr. Kubby's case,9 had been deputized by the City of Oakland to grow for third party patients. He found himself charged by the DEA for activities he believed were sanctioned by state law.
[7] The US government sued to enjoin The Oakland Cannabis Buyers' Cooperative arguing it violated the CSA's prohibition on distributing and manufacturing or possessing with intent to
distribute, a controlled substance. The OCBC was unsuccessful in its defence of distribution for "medical necessity", a term used in the Compassionate Use Act. The Ninth Circuit Court recognised the existence of the defence of "medical necessity" for caregivers, however that decision was appealed to the US Supreme Court, which overturned the decision.
[8] Justice Stevens, speaking for the Court, held:
...this case does not call upon the court to deprive all such patients of the benefit of the necessity defense to federal prosecution, when the case itself does not involve any such patients." [Emphasis in original]10
[9] The net result of the US Supreme Court decision in this hallmark case was to preclude cannabis clubs from dispensing to third parties. The decision was rendered May 14, 2001, before Mr. XXXXX came to Canada, and before the new charges against him were filed in federal court. It is clear from the decision of the US Supreme Court that there is no ambiguity in the Controlled Substances Act: "medical necessity is not a defense to manufacturing or distributing marijuana."11
[10] Following this ruling, the US Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia on May 24, 2002, upheld the DEA's right to enforce the federal CSA even within states with medical exemptions for marihuana use. This cleared the way for the DEA to crack down on cannabis dispensaries in California, which they clearly did. Raids of caregivers became more frequent because the DEA believed that traffickers were hiding behind these clubs. Both Mr. XXXXX and Mr. XXXXX were growing for third parties, and were therefore vulnerable to federal prosecution.
[11] Mr. XXXXX has been charged federally with a variety of marihuana charges, and he feels these charges are politically motivated. In XXXXX 2002, after his arrival in Canada, Mr. XXXXX was charged by federal authorities in San Francisco, California, with various drug offences including cultivation of marihuana, conspiracy to manufacture marihuana, and maintaining a place for the purpose of cultivating marihuana. On XXXXX, 2002, the United States District Court issued a warrant of arrest on these charges.12
[12] Mr. XXXXX suggests that he is being "selectively prosecuted"13 for his political beliefs and marihuana advocacy, on behalf of sick and dying medical marihuana patients. Mr. XXXXX claims that he is a "person in need of protection" because he fears the consequences of conviction, which, if he is incarcerated, would find him imprisoned. He submits that the prison conditions he will be forced to live in, amount to cruel and unusual treatment or punishment.
[13] In addition to his allegations about prison conditions, Mr. XXXXX alleges in his Personal Information Form (PIF), 14 if he were returned to the United States and incarcerated, he would be denied adequate medical care, which would place him personally at risk to his life.
[14] In short, Mr. XXXXX is alleging that the prosecution against him is "politically motivated persecution . . . by US federal and state authorities"15. It was Mr. XXXXX understanding that the Compassionate Use Act16 permitted a third party (in this case, Mr. XXXXX through a compassion club) to possess and cultivate marihuana, to help bona fide medical marihuana patients with their ailments.17
[15] Holding a Bachelor of Arts degree from the University of California in XXXXX, Mr. XXXXX has worked as a nurse's aid in various residential settings, as a counsellor and caregiver in several institutions for people who were developmentally disabled.18 Through his work he learned about the potential benefits of cannabis in certain medical contexts. For example, he witnessed its benefits with AIDS and cancer patients. He saw that cannabis helped dying patients to live far longer than medical practitioners had anticipated, and he attributed their longevity to the use of cannabis.
[16] He saw cannabis help patients with nausea, pain, and to stimulate their appetite. He thought there was an enormous untapped potential for assisting numerous sick and dying patients with their ailments. He therefore opened a cannabis dispensary/distribution centre that had been closed, called CHAMP (Californians Helping Alleviate Medical Problems).19 Investing his own money, he renovated and stocked the dispensary with cannabis inventory and officially reopened CHAMP in XXXXX of 1998. While the dispensary was under his control he alleged he provided cannabis to sick and dying patients qualified to use cannabis pursuant to the CUA. He maintained that he only provided cannabis to those who had medical problems and considerable documentation to confirm their medical condition and need for cannabis.
[17] In order for a patient to obtain cannabis from CHAMP, the patient was required to present a notarized physician's recommendation (prescriptions by doctors were expressly forbidden by the CUA and subsequent jurisprudence arising from its implementation), valid identification, and a release of medical information so that CHAMP could verify with the doctor that the information was correct. CHAMP did not provide cannabis free, because there was a cost to the dispensary to produce the cannabis required, which was subsequently covered off by the patient. In some instances, donations from non-governmental organisations (NGO) such as churches, would pay on behalf of the patients. William Panzer confirmed that "caregivers" could be reimbursed for costs and this would not be considered a "sale".20
[18] Sonoma Narcotics Enforcement showed up at Mr. XXXXX XXXXX address to discuss CHAMP's cultivation of marihuana. Mr. XXXXX was arrested and charged on XXXXX, 1999 with his co-director, XXXXX XXXXX.21 He was released on bail pending trial. Approximately 2000 patient files were found between Mr. XXXXX home and CHAMP offices combined.22 Prosecutors were seeking one year in jail time, if Mr. XXXXX was convicted.
[19] Mr. XXXXX ran CHAMP from XXXXX 1998 to XXXXX 1999 (when he was arrested), making enough money to hire and pay approximately thirty employees and volunteers.23 He had been growing around 1000 plants in a variety of places, for patients. He alleges that in order to press Mr. XXXXX into a plea bargain on these charges, the DEA also charged his spouse XXXXX XXXXX and his employee and CHAMP XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, with drug charges. They later dropped the charges against Ms. XXXXX prior to trial. The claimant was acquitted of all charges.
[20] The year before his trial, he XXXXX another dispensary called the Harm Reduction Centre (HRC) in San Francisco. It was smaller but ran on the same principles as CHAMP and continued to run after the claimant was acquitted of state charges. Mr. XXXXX attempted to close down the HRC when he left for Canada, but XXXXX XXXXX a friend and XXXXX, allegedly cut the locks and continued to run the business despite the fact that the claimant had closed the HRC. HRC was busted after the claimant arrived in Canada, and Mr. XXXXX was arrested, and the claimant was charged federally.
[21] Mr. XXXXX takes the position he never had possession of the plants seized subsequent to his departure from the US. He testified that he had changed the locks, removed all of the plants and records, and informed the landlord of his departure. When the DEA found the plants in XXXXX 2002 that resulted in the outstanding federal charges against him, Mr. XXXXX alleges he had severed his relationship with the HRC and CHAMP.
[22] The claimant came to Canada in January 2002. In XXXXX 2002, he was charged in Canada with drug charges arising out of a grow operation at his home, for his personal use. Mr. XXXXX has never applied for, nor has he obtained, a Health Canada medical exemption. At the time of his arrest in Canada, he was made aware of outstanding federal drug charges against him in the US.
PROTECTION GROUNDS CLAIMED
Convention Refugee (IRPA Section 96)
[23] Mr. XXXXX is claiming to be a Convention refugee24 on the basis of his political opinion and his membership in a particular social group: those who grow cannabis for patients in the US (also referred to herein as "medical marihuana patients").
96. A Convention refugee is a person who, by reason of a well founded fear of persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership in a particular social group or political opinion,
(a) is outside each of their countries of nationality and is unable or, by reason of that fear, unwilling to avail themself of the protection of each of those countries; or
(b) not having a country of nationality, is outside the country of their former habitual residence and is unable or, by reason of that fear, unwilling to return to that country.
Person in Need of Protection (IRPA Section 97)
[24] Mr. XXXXX also claims to be a "person in need of protection"25 because he alleges that his life is at risk, if he returns to the United States.
[25] Section 97 provides:
97. (1) A person in need of protection is a person in Canada whose removal to their country or countries of nationality or, if they do not have a country of nationality, their country of former habitual residence, would subject them personally
(a) to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture; or
(b) to a risk to their life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if
(i) the person is unable or, because of that risk, unwilling to avail themself of the protection of that country,
(ii) the risk would be faced by the person in every part of that country and is not faced generally by other individuals in or from that country,
(iii) the risk is not inherent or incidental to lawful sanctions, unless imposed in disregard of accepted international standards, and
(iv) the risk is not caused by the inability of that country to provide adequate health or medical care..
[26] Finally, he asserts that he fears a risk of torture pursuant to section 97(1)(a).
WEAKNESSES IN THE EVIDENCE
[27] Mr. XXXXX testified to his advocacy work going back to 1996, however in his PIF he does not mention this work, which included being a medical marihuana activist, and work on a variety of political campaigns. In addition, although Mr. XXXXX testified that he has a medical necessity for marihuana, he has not filed medical evidence to support this need, nor has he applied for a Health Canada exemption while in Canada. In his submissions, he conceded that he has not made the claim that his life would be in jeopardy if he was denied cannabis while in jail.26 This is in direct contradiction to his evidence filed in the PIF. He says that he chooses to use marihuana, but does not claim a medical necessity. This was not clear from the PIF and other documentation filed.
[28] Mr. XXXXX is alleging he is innocent of the charges in the US in that he had closed the HRC and had nothing more to do with the plants seized there and on his premises. Those plants, he alleges, belonged to XXXXX XXXXX and to Mr. XXXXX. He did not mention this in his PIF, a significant omission, in my view. If this is so, an able defence attorney in the US ought to be able to mount a defence to the charges, on this basis. Mr. XXXXX claims he is destitute and cannot afford bail and/or to mount a defence in the US. The US criminal laws are obligated to follow due process, and require that Mr. XXXXX be provided with a public defender, if he cannot afford a lawyer. I am not persuaded by his argument that in order to mount a defence, he has to incriminate himself, and then cannot avail himself of the "necessity" defence. If he is innocent because the marihuana seized at the HRC was not his, there would be no need to argue "medical necessity". His allegations in this area are circuitous and illogical.
[29] I also find problematic Mr. XXXXX attempt to surreptitiously enter the country. He flew to Canada by plane in XXXXX 2001, initially. He was questioned at Vancouver airport and made to empty his pockets, by Canada customs officials.27 Later in testimony, he said his run-in was with US custom officials at the Blaine border crossing.28 He testified it was his belief that US and Canadian border officials were working together and that his name was on a "list."29 XXXXX 2002 he drove with his wife until they were close to the Canada/US border, then he took a cab back to Seattle and his spouse Ms. XXXXX entered Canada without him. She had $10,000 US in her possession at the time she entered Canada.
[30] The claimant then flew to Boundary Bay, a small airport, to avoid a second questioning by border officials. He was carrying $13,000 US hidden in his pants. He had also transferred $6,000 US to a Canadian account, at the time he was under investigation in the US. He said this was so that US officials could not seize his money.30 His entry into Canada was suspicious to say the least.
[31] In addition, he blames omissions in the PIF and inconsistencies among the PIF, the CIC notes31 and his testimony, on his Canadian lawyer retained to help him file a refugee claim.
[32] There are some fairly significant credibility concerns therefore. However, credibility concerns aside, it is clear on the evidence that Mr. XXXXX is facing federal charges in the US, and that Mr. XXXXX was tried on similar charges, convicted and sentenced to one day in jail. These facts are not in dispute.
ISSUES RAISED BY THE CLAIM
[33] The determinative issues in this claim are first, whether the claimant has a well founded fear of persecution and second, whether he has rebutted the presumption that the United States is capable of protecting him from any persecution alleged. In addition, I will canvass whether he has rebutted this presumption vis-à-vis any possible risk to his life, or of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, or whether there is a potential danger of torture.
CREDIBILITY
[34] There are some credibility concerns, as set out above. Notwithstanding this, I am of the view that whether or not Mr. XXXXX is being truthful about the allegations is irrelevant to the outcome. There is nothing blatant on the face of the record that would cause me to conclude Mr. XXXXX was lying. He came across as sincere throughout his hearing. I will accept for the purposes of my analysis that the events as alleged by Mr. XXXXX, occurred in the way that he has described them. Notwithstanding this, I find much of Mr. XXXXX stated fear of persecution, and risk of harm is, nonetheless, speculative.
[35] There is no evidence that Mr. XXXXX would receive any greater sentence if convicted of his outstanding charges, than XXXXX XXXXX received when he was convicted of cultivating marihuana for medical patients. Mr. XXXXX sentence was a one-day jail sentence.32 In addition, I find it noteworthy that Mr. XXXXX was only sentenced to one day in jail despite the federal probation department's recommendation that he receive a twenty-one month sentence. There was public condemnation by several high-ranking state officials about the charges against Mr. XXXXX, and appeals to the judge including from California's Attorney General William Lockyer asking for maximum leniency in Mr. XXXXX case.
[36] This case demonstrates that federal courts are likely to deal fairly with persons caught between federal and state laws on medicinal marihuana, at least in some circumstances.
[37] In the midst of all the legal wrangling lies the fate of many sick and dying patients. I have tremendous sympathy for the uncertainty suffered by Mr. XXXXX as a result of the ambiguity the CUA has engendered. California Senate Bill 420, which has recently come into force, is the state's attempt to clarify its intent under the CUA and it has been both hailed and criticized by medical marihuana activists.33 Mr. XXXXX submits, on behalf of the claimant, that I should regard Bill 420 with a critical eye. I have read the Bill and believe it has clarified many of the ambiguities in the CUA, that are of concern to this panel.
STATE PROTECTION
[38] The heart of this claim lies with the issue of state protection. It is a hurdle that Mr. XXXXX has been unable to vault. Mr. XXXXX needs to demonstrate, through "clear and convincing"34 evidence, that his state is unwilling or unable to protect him from the risk of harm. I find that adequate state protection was available to the claimant in the United States. In coming to this decision, I adopt my reasoning in the decision of Steven Kubby, et al. v. M.C.I. (RPD VA2-01374), Dauns, November 17, 2003, commencing at paragraph 154 of the decision, regarding the availability of adequate state protection to similarly situated persons in the United States. The availability of state protection in the United States has been comprehensively analyzed in the Kubby decision. My reasons for adopting the relevant finding in the Kubby decision is that the facts and the evidence regarding country conditions in this claim are sufficiently close to those before me in the Kubby case.
[39] In addition, most of the same country documentation was filed by the Refugee Protection Officer in both cases. The Minister's country documentation was identical in all material aspects in both cases, and a full transcript of the evidence in Mr. Kubby's claim was filed in Mr. XXXXX claim, as was a copy of Mr. Kubby's decision.35 While there are factual differences between the two claims, they are not material to my decision which is founded exclusively on the issue of state protection.
[40] In finding that adequate state protection was and will be available to the claimant, should he return to the United States, I have assessed the claimant's own experiences in the context of the entirety of the evidence. The claimant has not availed himself of the protection of his state when there is a clear onus upon him to do so, as set out in the jurisprudence in this area of the law.36
SUMMARY
[41] The claimant is wanted on criminal charges and is accordingly a fugitive from justice, not a refugee fearing persecution. The claimant has the burden of demonstrating his state is unable or unwilling to protect him from the harm feared, whether that harm arises on account of one of the enumerated grounds, or as envisioned in section 97(1) of IRPA. While the elements necessary to establish a claim under section 97(1) are not identical to those necessary to establish whether a person is a Convention refugee under section 96 of IRPA, as noted by the Court in Bouaouni37 the Board must review whether there exist reasons for refugee protection under section 97(1) that may not be sufficient to determine the claimant is a Convention refugee. I have considered Mr. XXXXX claim in light of all three protection grounds, and have considered the jurisprudence that pertains to the analysis of state protection vis-à-vis his risk of harm. I have concluded that there is nothing in this claim whether documentary or otherwise for establishing a "risk" for the claimant pursuant to section 97(1). Likewise, there is no evidence the claimant faces of danger of torture as envisioned in Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture.38
[42] Whether the claim is framed under section 96 or section 97(1) of the Act the outcome is the same, since an analysis of state protection is necessary to the determination of refugee protection generally.
DETERMINATION
[43] Accordingly, I find that XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX is not a Convention refugee, as he does not have a well-founded fear of persecution for a Convention ground in the United States. I also find that the claimant is not a person in need of protection in that his removal to the United States would not subject him personally to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, and in that there are no substantial grounds to believe that his removal to the United States will subject him personally to a danger of torture. Accordingly, for the foregoing reasons, the claim for refugee protection of XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX is hereby rejected.

XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, the claimant, is a 32-year-old citizen of Israel fears persecution by her former husband who continued to harass and abuse her after their divorce and abducted their elder daughter, XXXXXXXXXXX, aged 7, a minor claimant. The couple's younger daughter, XXXXXXXXXXXXX, aged 3, also a minor claimant, was conceived during a brief reconciliation after the divorce but her father did not acknowledge the child as his. A separate ground for the claims is that in Israel children are the victims of explosions and it is not a safe country.
The claimant is the Designated Representative for the minors.
SUMMARY OF ALLEGATIONS
According to the claimant's Personal Information Form (PIF),1 she was born XXXXX XXXXX in the Crimean Republic of the former USSR, and is of Russian Jewish nationality. She immigrated to Israel in 1990 with her mother and sister under the Law of Return. In 1994, she married XXXXX XXXXX, and in 1995 they settled in the city of XXXXX and he joined the police force.
Her husband began to drink heavily and to abuse her physically when he was drunk starting in 1996. After XXXXX was born, he would often disappear from the house and when he was home would drink and threaten to strangle the child if she was not quiet. Often he would shove them out of the house because the child was interfering with his sleep. During this period he had lovers and made no attempt to hide them.
Following an argument in XXXXX 1997, she made a complaint against him at the police station but the officer convinced her to retract it because this would cause her husband to be fired and they had no other means of survival. When he found out she had gone to the police, he became very angry and beat her up and threatened to kill their daughter if she ever went again. To prove his point, he slaughtered their cat, put it on the porch and said he would do the same thing to her and her daughter. After that, the claimant left home with XXXXX but a week later learned she could return because her husband had gone to live with his lover.
She filed for divorce and six months later, on XXXXX, 1998, they were divorced. The claimant got custody of XXXXX and her former husband was not given visitation rights. Until 1999 they barely saw one another although a few times he came over drunk and tried to start fights, but each time friends or neighbours who were visiting her would take him away. At the end of 1999 they got back together again because he had straightened himself out and promised not to drink anymore. For several months he was the model husband and father. At the beginning of 2000, she told him she was pregnant. At first he reacted well but later started drinking again. He would yell that the baby was not his and he had no intention of supporting it. Then in XXXXX 2000, he locked XXXXX in a bathroom and beat the claimant on the stomach trying to cause a miscarriage. She left him and when she gave birth to XXXXX on XXXXX, 2000, she did not name him as the child's father.
In 2001 when they were not at home, her former husband came around, very drunk, wanting to see the children according to the neighbours. When she returned she found he had broken all the dishes, turned the house upside down and taken almost all of the photographs and valuables. The following year, in XXXXX 2002, he came to the house, quite drunk, after the children were asleep. When she did not let him in, he broke the door down and when she grabbed the phone and threatened to call the police he smashed the phone and started to beat her. Neighbours heard her screams and managed to lead him away. Finally, in XXXXX 2002, a friend was walking XXXXX home from kindergarten when her former husband abducted the child and took her to his parents' house and told his mother she was going to live with him. His mother was not happy and called the claimant's sister who together with her husband and two friends brought XXXXX back.
After this incident, the claimant went to see a lawyer about getting a restraining order against her former husband to prevent him from seeing the children and coming to their house. But the lawyer's fee was unaffordable to her as a single mother who did not work and had two children to support. The lawyer also told her that even if the court issued the restraining order it would have to be enforced by the same police force where her former husband served. This would not guarantee her safety.
She could not continue to live in fear for their lives so made the decision to leave the country. Friends in Canada helped with the cost of the plane tickets and the claimants arrived on XXXXX, 2002 in Toronto. After a week they traveled to Vancouver and two months later, on XXXXX, 2002, they made claims to refugee protection inland.
According to an amendment to the PIF made at the hearing, the claimant married XXXXX XXXXX, a Canadian citizen, on XXXXX, 2003 and their son was born on XXXXX XXXXX, 2003. At the time of the hearing her new husband had a sponsorship application in progress.
She claims that in Israel her former husband is a constant threat to her and the minor claimants and he has weapons in his possession. During her interview with the Immigration Officer, she said the second reason for making the refugee claim is that she does not want to live in a country where children are the victims of explosions, and it is not a safe country in which to live.2
ISSUES
The following issues were identified: personal identity; credibility; subjective basis, especially with respect to the delay in making a claim in Canada; objective basis; Internal Flight Alternative (IFA); and state protection. It was recognized that given the nature of the alleged persecution, the Chairperson's Guidelines for Women Refugee Claimants fearing Gender based Persecution (Gender Guidelines)3 apply in this case.
As set out below, the Refugee Protection Division finds that the determinative issues are credibility and subjective basis and, had the evidence of spousal abuse been found to be credible (which is was not), state protection.
Personal Identity
The claimants arrived in Canada using Israeli passports and were admitted as visitors since visas were not required. Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) seized their passports when they later made refugee claims.
While the claimant has provided her own birth certificate she has not provided the same for the minors. As the analysis below indicates this is cause for concern, especially in the case of XXXXX because apart from her passport, which contains minimal biographical information, she is undocumented. XXXXX is referenced in the divorce documents, which also show that the claimant has legal custody of her.
The claimant presented her Israeli identity card to the Immigration Officer but this document was not seized and the claimant failed to bring it to the hearing for examination or provide a translation of its contents. As outlined below, she also appears to have deliberately withheld from Canadian authorities the supplement to the identity card, which would contain detailed information about her children, marital status, address and so forth.
However, the Refugee Protection Division believes there is no reason to doubt the authenticity of the claimants' Israeli passports and finds these documents are sufficient to establish their respective personal identities for the purpose of the refugee claims.
Credibility
The Refugee Protection Division finds there are serious reasons to doubt the truthfulness of the claimant's allegations that she was the victim of spousal abuse or that her elder daughter was the victim of abduction, by her former husband. There are numerous discrepancies in her evidence for which she did not have an acceptable explanation and she was not a credible witness. More likely than not, she has fabricated the basis of the claim in order to use the refugee system to circumvent proper immigration procedures.
Facts of Marriage and Divorce Established
During the hearing ,the Refugee Protection Officer (RPO) drew attention to a number of anomalous features of the divorce certificate dated XXXXX, 19984 and its attachment, the divorce agreement drawn up on XXXXX, 1998,5 that could undermine the reliability and trustworthiness of both documents. The claimant was questioned about these. For example, according to the translation, the court decision states that the couple was married in Israel by civil marriage while there is objective information that couples cannot get married in a civil court in Israel.6 The claimant testified that they did not have a wedding in Israel so their marriage was not acknowledged until they sent their papers to Paraguay (the other option was Cyprus) and received a marriage certificate from Paraguay. (She did not have the marriage certificate in her possession at the hearing although she had indicated in the PIF that she was expecting to receive it.) The claimant could not explain the legal reference to a civil marriage but said she was represented by a lawyer in the divorce proceeding. However, her explanation of the circumstances of the marriage is supported by objective information from the same source that indicates couples of different religions (as is the case here) must marry outside the country and then they may register as a married couple upon return.7
In addition, the RPO pointed out that the husband's identity number is different on the two court documents. The claimant said it must be a mistake. The RPO also questioned why a Rabbinical court would have dissolved a civil marriage, but the claimant maintained that her marriage had been recognized in Israel and she had to get a divorce through a religious court. She said it was sufficient for there to be one Jew in the couple. This appears to be borne out in the documentary evidence, which cites several reports that Rabbinical courts have sole jurisdiction over marriage or divorce in Israel.8 The RPO also asked her to explain why a section of the original Hebrew version of the divorce agreement was crossed out.9 To this the claimant had a full and forthright answer in effect that the section pertained to access by the father of the child on the Sabbath and religious holidays but because her husband was not Jewish (and she is) and thus he could not teach their daughter how to celebrate properly the judge asked him to consent to waive such access and he did and the section was crossed out.
Moreover, the claimant has given consistent evidence - to the Immigration Officer in making the claim, in the PIF, and in oral testimony - that she was divorced from XXXXX XXXXX on XXXXX, 1998, and the court documents bear this out.
The Refugee Protection Division finds that the claimant has established the alleged fact that she was married to this man and divorced from him and the minor claimant, XXXXX, is the child of that union. Their daughter, XXXXX, born in XXXXX 1996, is specifically identified in the Divorce Settlement.
Beyond that, however, the Refugee Protection Division finds there is insufficient credible evidence to support any of the claimant's allegations of spousal abuse, particularly following the divorce, or of the brief reconciliation that led to her former husband also fathering her younger daughter, XXXXX, or his abduction of XXXXX (supposedly to coerce the claimant into getting back together) shortly before the claimants left for Canada.
Spousal Abuse during the Marriage
The Israeli court documents indicate that the claimant's divorce was amicable and make no reference to verbal and physical abuse or drunkenness on the part of her husband. The claimant testified that her husband wanted a divorce and paid the entire cost of the process himself because he wanted to marry someone else and subsequently he did live with another woman and had two children by her. This appears to be at odds with the level of violence and acrimony she now alleges in her refugee claim.
The claimant's evidence that her former husband was a police officer in their city serves as her blanket rationalization for not having made an official complaint against him for the spousal abuse after a fellow police officer allegedly dissuaded her from doing so in XXXXX 1997 because her husband would be fired. However, the claimant has not provided any corroborative evidence of this material alleged fact, despite specific direction on the screening form disclosed by the RPO fully eight months before the hearing.10 She testified that she has no photographs of her husband in police uniform and that most of the time he was in plain clothes. She claims to have asked everyone in Israel to find a photo of him to no avail and asked her friends who were with him in the police to get a document but such documents are not issued for police officers, not even their personal telephone numbers. Allegedly she contacted the same police officer she had spoken to about her husband's abuse in 1997 because she remembered seeing photographs of her husband in uniform at the station, but the officer said he could not find them. Her sister sent along a photograph of a man and a woman in Israeli military uniforms but because this had no relevance or probative value it was not accepted into evidence under the Rules for late disclosure.11
The Refugee Protection Division believes it is reasonable to expect that if the claimant's former husband truly was a police officer in the city of XXXXX in Israel she would be able to provide some kind of corroborative evidence of his position, and that she would take all possible steps because this fact is so crucial to her alleged need for international refugee protection from his abuse. The evidence suggests, for example, that she could have sought the cooperation of the divorce lawyer, or the government agency that was aware her former husband was in default on child support payments. The Refugee Protection Division finds the claimant has not discharged the onus on her under section 106 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) and Rule 7 of the Refugee Protection Division Rules, and draws an adverse inference as to the credibility of all of her allegations of her former husband's verbal and physical abuse that form this basis of her claim.
Furthermore, in the PIF the claimant states that when her former husband found out she had gone to the police in XXXXX 1997 he was so angry that he threatened to kill their daughter if she went again, and to prove the point, he slaughtered their cat. After that, she filed for divorce, which was granted six months later. During the claimant's prior interview with the Immigration Officer, she had indicated this incident happened in 1998 but otherwise said much the same thing. However, by contrast, she testified at the hearing that her former husband killed their cat and made the death threat sometime after the divorce and she could not remember how long afterward. The Refugee Protection Division finds it difficult to believe that if her former husband really had slaughtered their cat to emphasize a death threat while they were still living together she would recall the circumstances in a consistent manner. The Refugee Protection Division finds this important discrepancy further undermines the credibility of her claim that the alleged spousal abuse began during the marriage and her initial complaint to the police provoked a death threat from her former husband.
Spousal Abuse after the Marriage including Child Abduction
The claimant reported to the Immigration Officer that in 1999 she and her former husband tried to live together but when he found out she was pregnant he beat her up and that was the end of it. They went their separate ways. She made no reference to any of the continuing harassment alleged in the PIF, notably that he entered the house in 2001 and vandalized the contents, or broke into her home in XXXXX 2002, and that he abducted their daughter in XXXXX 2002.
Yet the claimant testified that her former husband's abduction of XXXXX was the incident that caused her to leave Israel in XXXXX 2002. She was given an opportunity to explain this omission in particular because of the significance of the alleged abduction to her departure and its relatively recent occurrence. Her reaction was to shrug and say that she did not tell the story in so much detail at that time and was telling things that were less significant and more significant. The Immigration Officer had made the comment at the end of the interview that, "the client stated she had nothing further to add."12 When this was drawn to her attention, she sighed and said there were 20 incidents like that. The Refugee Protection Division finds the claimant's response does not satisfactorily address her omission of this pivotal incident at the time she made her refugee claim, and draws an adverse inference about the credibility of the claimant's allegations of abuse following the divorce in XXXXX 1998 or that her daughter XXXXX was abducted by her former husband.
The claimant says that her former husband beat her when she was pregnant with XXXXX because he did not believe he was the father. The Refugee Protection Division also has suspicions, in part because the claimant has not provided the child's birth certificate or other objective evidence to corroborate her allegation that she did not officially name XXXXX XXXXX as the father due to that violent attack. She claims that the proof lies in the different validity terms of her daughters' respective Israeli passports.
Her evidence is that in Israel, despite the fact that she had legal custody of XXXXX, she would either have had to get her former husband's permission to take her daughter out of the country or apply to the court. But she "got a bit lucky" because he was in hiding to avoid making child support payments with the result that the passport office could not reach him by mail. So the government issued only a one-year international passport for XXXXX (apparently without the required application to court in lieu of the father's permission). But because there were none of these complications in the case of XXXXX, hers is a four-year international passport.
The claimant has not provided any objective information about the Israeli passport procedures for minors and the Refugee Protection Division has difficulty believing that court documents proving the claimant's divorce and legal custody of the XXXXX would have been insufficient. The Refugee Protection Division does not accept that the different validity terms of the minors' passports is proof that XXXXX XXXXX was named the father of one but not the other.
It is apparent that the claimant has deliberately failed to provide Canadian authorities with the "supplement" to her laminated Israeli personal identity card that according to the documentary evidence contains such personal information as her place of residence, civil status, name of spouse, identity number of spouse, and place of residence.13 She claims to have only brought with her to Canada the identity card (seen by the Immigration Officer).14 Allegedly "by coincidence" she left the supplement in a purse in Israel and it was lost in the mail along with photographs and other documents when her sister sent it to her later. This is simply too convenient, given the value of this document. She has not offered any evidence that she or her sister initiated a postal search for the missing mail or that she applied for a replacement when she realized it was lost.
Coupled with this, she did not bring her original identity card itself to the hearing and said she did not know where it was and maybe the children played with it and destroyed it. She explained that she did not realize its importance, which is not reasonable because this is part of her official Israeli identity document, and the fact that the Immigration Officer made a certified copy should have signaled its importance for the purposes of her refugee claim. The Refugee Protection Division could only speculate why the claimant would withhold the original identity card from further scrutiny and not supply a translation of it, and mislead the Board about the loss of the supplement.
Subjective Basis
Consistent with the claimant's lack of credibility regarding the basis of her claim is the two-month delay between her arrival in Canada, on XXXXX, 2002, and when she and her daughters finally claimed refugee status in Vancouver, September 4, 2002. Considering that she allegedly fled Israel to seek international protection for herself and her daughters against her abusive former husband, it is reasonable to expect that she would have made the claim at her earliest opportunity, which would have been at Pearson International Airport in Toronto, the port of entry. According to her oral evidence, she had friends in both Vancouver and Toronto who knew her situation and helped finance her travel.
The claimant did not have a satisfactory explanation for the delay. She said that she did not know the law and whether she had enough grounds to ask for refugee status and during the interval her friends asked around. The Refugee Protection Division finds it is reasonable to expect that her friends in Canada could have done the necessary research before she arrived or within short order. How to claim refugee status and who is eligible is information that is publicly available, as are the Gender Guidelines.
Seen in the context of the negative credibility findings above, the fact that the claimant became pregnant within five months of making her refugee claim and married the Canadian father of her son a year afterward, on XXXXX, 2003, and that he made a sponsorship application, indicates, on the balance of probabilities, that she claimed refugee status to circumvent proper immigration procedures, not to obtain Canada's protection from her former husband in Israel.
State Protection
It is worth noting that the claimant, had she been a credible witness, would not have succeeded in rebutting the presumption of state protection in Israel.
According to the PIF, after XXXXX was abducted she went to see a lawyer about getting a restraining order against her former husband but did not go through with this because she did not have enough money to pay the fee and also it would have been enforced by her former husband's police department and thus not guarantee her safety anyway. However the claimant testified that she was receiving government assistance in lieu of his support payments and it is reasonable to expect that she would have sought additional government aid for this purpose if her life and those of her children were at risk. Moreover, as the RPO pointed out in her oral Observations, she did find enough money to leave the country instead.
There is comprehensive information in evidence on the incidence of violence against women in Israel and the law, services available, and police attitudes.15 It shows that in recent years the government has progressively made stronger efforts to address the problem of widespread domestic violence, and to protect the victims and raise public awareness. In 1998, Israel adopted a sexual harassment prevention law and due to the public outcry at light sentences imposed on abusive men, legislation mandating minimum sentencing was enacted at the beginning of 1999. In March 2000, the Equality of Women law was passed, prohibiting domestic violence. A recent amendment to the Penal Code has recognized the Battered Women's Syndrome acknowledging a woman's right to defend herself. In late 2000 three women were murdered by their husbands and this prompted the Prime Minister to allocate the equivalent of nearly $16 million (CDN.) to a prevention plan including hiring more crisis intervention counsellors, emergency hotlines, a treatment program for children who have witnessed violence, an emergency centre for children and a hostel for abusive men.
In 2001 new legislation granted additional benefits to battered women living in shelters or in some other place of hiding. This provides that a battered woman who has gone into hiding for at least three months and has begun divorce proceedings is eligible for state assistance which includes an education grant, housing assistance, and preference for child day-care acceptance.
Police receive some training in the handling of domestic violence and pinpoint the main source of failure in their efforts as the "conspiracy of silence within the domestic cell," according to one police chief. Still, in 2001, a total of 20,931 complaints of "assault against women" were filed and that year 3,129 husbands were arrested for attacking their wives, 2,501 restraining orders were issued against husbands and 643 women were treated in shelters.16
The claimant's evidence is that she approached the police in Israel for protection only once, at the station where her then husband was employed, and the officer there persuaded her to retract her complaint. The Court of Appeal in Kadenko17 has ruled that:
Once it is assumed that the state (Israel in this case) has political and judicial institutions capable of protecting its citizens, it is clear that the refusal of certain police officers to take action cannot by itself make the state incapable of doing so...
When the state in question is a democratic state...the claimant must do more than simply show that he or she went to see some members of the police force and that his or her efforts were unsuccessful. The burden of proof that rests on the claimant is, in a way, directly proportional to the level of democracy in the state in question: the more democratic the state's institutions, the more the claimant must have done to exhaust all the course of action open to him or her.
Section 97
The Federal Court has ruled that a negative credibility determination under section 96 of the IRPA is not necessarily determinative of a claim under section 97. In this case, the negative credibility assessment with respect to the allegations of spousal abuse and child abduction are also determinative of the fact that upon removal the claimants would not be subjected personally to a risk to life or risk of cruel or unusual treatment or punishment at the hands of the claimant's former husband.
When the claimant was interviewed by the Immigration Officer, she mentioned that the "second reason" she was making a refugee claim was that she did not want to live in a country where children are the victims of explosions, and that Israel was not a safe country. She did not include this in the PIF or mention it at the hearing. However, the Refugee Protection Division believes that this ground should be assessed under section 97.
According to the US Department of State Report for 2002, there was a sharp increase in suicide bombings, shootings and other acts of terrorism by Palestinian groups or individuals in the country and the Occupied Territories, which resulted in the deaths of least 469 Israelis that year.18 However tragic these deaths and the sense of insecurity they instilled, they must be viewed in relation to the fact that the country's population is approximately 6.4 million, including Israeli settlers in the Occupied Territories. Thus, the probability of the claimants becoming victims of this violence is extremely low and would not even meet the minimum standard of proof in refugee law, more than a mere chance or a serious possibility.
Moreover, the reports of individual incidents show that these suicide bombings and car bombings are random and indiscriminate. It cannot be said that the terrorists even target Jews alone because Arab Israelis make up approximately 20 percent of the general population.
The Refugee Protection Division concludes from this that the claimants' removal to Israel would not subject them personally to a risk to life or risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment from terrorist attacks. The degree of that risk does not meet the required standard of proof, and it is faced generally by other individuals in or from that country.19
There is no evidence or argument that the claimants would be subjected personally to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture.
The Refugee Protection Division finds that the claimants do not meet the definition of persons in need of protection.
DETERMINATION
For all the reasons above, the Refugee Protection Division finds that the claimants have failed to provide sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence to establish that they would face a serious possibility of persecution or a risk to life or risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment at the hands of her former husband and the minors' father, XXXXX XXXXX. Upon removal to Israel they would not be subjected personally to a risk to their lives or to cruel and unusual treatment of punishment from terrorist attacks.. No evidence or argument has been advanced that the claimants' removal would subject them personally to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture. Accordingly, the Refugee Protection Division determines that XXXXX XXXXX, XXXXX XXXXX, and XXXXX XXXXX are not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection.

[1] XXXXX XXXXX (“the principal claimant”) is a 44 year-old citizen of Vietnam. XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX (“the associated claimant”) is a 43 year-old citizen of Vietnam. They are friends, whose claims have been joined. They bring their claims for refugee protection pursuant to sections 961 and 97(1)2 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).3
[2] The Minister of Citizenship and Immigration, through her representative, is opposing their claims for refugee protection. It is the Minister’s position that both claimants are persons referred to in section 98 of IRPA (and the Schedule) and should therefore be excluded from the definition of Convention refugee as outlined in section 96 of IRPA. Further, they should not be found to be persons in need of protection as outlined in section 97(1) of IRPA. The Minister is of the opinion that both claimants ought to be excluded pursuant to article 1F(b) of the Convention.4
[3] Article 1F(b) reads as follows:
F. The provisions of this Convention shall not apply to any person with respect to whom there are serious reasons for considering that:
(b) he has committed a serious non-political crime outside the country of refuge prior to his admission to that country as a refugee.
[4] Section 98 of IRPA states:
98. A person referred to in section E or F of Article 1 of the Refugee Convention is not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection.
[5] Because no person within the scope of Article 1(F) can qualify for refugee status, a review of the claimant’s case must first be conducted with reference to Article 1F.
[6] Ms. XXXXX is referred to as the “principal claimant” and Ms. XXXXX is referred to as the “associated claimant”.
SUMMARY OF THE EVIDENCE
[7] This is a complex case in which a substantial amount of evidence was tendered by the claimants, the Minister’s representative, and the Refugee Protection Officer. The claim was heard over five days, and several witnesses testified. Both claimants testified.
Other Witnesses Called Included
Professor Ian William Townsend-Gault, Director of the University of British Columbia (UBC) Centre for Asian Legal Studies;
XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, the principal claimant’s Canadian sister;
Ms XXXXX XXXXX, Counsellor and Consul, Canadian Embassy, Hanoi (by telephone);

The claimant is entitled to such notice so she can know the case against her with sufficient particularity to mount a “defence”.
