I find that the documentary evidence filed by the Minister is sufficiently detailed for the claimants to know the position of the Minister and her reasons for that position.
5. Findings of Fact
(a) What is the crime alleged?
[46] The crime the principal claimant is alleged to have committed is international drug trafficking. There is sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence in the Minister’s evidence to support these allegations.27
[47] The Red Circle Notice28 is based on a Warrant of Arrest issued by the Vietnamese government.29 That Warrant outlines the charges, gives the principal claimant’s correct date of birth, addresses, nationality, and details of the allegations. The Warrant itself, was issued based upon the information provided by the Ministry of Interior’s General Department of People’s Police. It gives a full page of details regarding the allegations of drug trafficking, and names the principal claimant and several of her family members and customers.
[48] The principal claimant has not persuaded me that false charges have been laid in her case. Her husband was convicted after a trial, and the conviction was later upheld on appeal. I have taken into consideration the evidence of lawyer XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX (that the case against Mr. XXXXX was not strong),30 and am nonetheless not persuaded that false charges were laid against the principal claimant.
[49] Ms. XXXXX is wanted on a Red Circle Notice from INTERPOL that sets out that she is wanted for drug trafficking. The evidence is that the drug being trafficked is heroin. The crime of heroin trafficking equates in Canada to Article 5(2) of the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act.31 Section 5(2) reads as follows:
Trafficking in substance 5(1) No person shall traffic in a substance included in Schedule I, II, III or IV or in any substance represented or held out by that person to be such a substance.
Possession for purpose 5(2) No person shall, for the purpose of trafficking, of trafficking possess a substance included in Schedule I, II, III or IV.
Punishment 5(3) Every person who contravenes subsection (1) or (2)
(a) subject to subsection (4), where the subject-matter of the offence is a substance included in Schedule I or II, is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for life. (Emphasis added)
[50] Diacetylmorphone (Heroin) is found in Schedule I at item (10). Therefore, a conviction for trafficking in heroin in Canada has a maximum penalty of life imprisonment.
(b) Did the principal claimant commit the crime alleged?
[51] In order to assess whether there are serious reasons for considering that the claimant has committed the crimes alleged, an understanding of who INTERPOL is and their jurisdiction, is instructive.
[52] INTERPOL’s mandate is to promote international police co-operation among its member countries in solving international crime. This is done through the exchange of criminal intelligence with its member states. The mission of the Asia and South Pacific Sub-Directorate of INTERPOL is “to support ... crime fighting activities by providing quality operational and administrative services on a daily basis through a regionally based geopolitical structure.” The Sub-Directorate’s Goals include the following:
To address regional crime issues;
To provide adequate support on regional and national levels;
To make relevant regionally-based information available;
To increase relevant information exchange with regions; and
To increase the flow and exchange of information related to the specialized crime areas.32
[53] Vietnam has been a member of the International Police Organization (INTERPOL) since November 1991.33 The co-operation and collaboration between Vietnam and INTERPOL since 1991 was described in late 2002 as “efficient and practical,” involving the exchange of over 20,000 pieces of information “related to individual criminals and organised gangs involved in drugs, smuggling and other crimes”.34
[54] The INTERPOL Warrant for Ms. XXXXX was issued in 1997, and she has been of interest to the police at least since that time. It alleges that the countries the principal claimant has likely visited are: China, Cambodia, Canada and the US. It alleges that Ms. XXXXX is a member of a “drug trafficking gang” in China, Canada, and elsewhere and that several of her relatives have been arrested in Vietnam for drug trafficking. It says she has fled the country. 35
[55] An “Urgent Warrant of Arrest” was issued by “First Deputy Chief of CID, (Criminal Investigation Division) Security General, Department of the Interior. It lists the principal claimant’s addresses at No XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, XXXXX XXXXX District, Hanoi, and XXXXX XXXXX Rd. A letter went to INTERPOL in Ottawa, Canada on XXXXX, 1998 because it was believed, presumably, given their information, that the principal claimant had ties to Canada. In fact, her two sisters and other family members were here.
[56] This document implicates the principal claimant and XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, as “dangerous drug traffickers” involved in “transnational drug trafficking” from Vietnam to Canada and US for “decades”.36 The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) have been co-operating with the Vietnamese police on this case, since 1992, although the Minister’s counsel has been unable to provide further information. We know that XXXXX XXXXX has not been arrested, but that XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX was arrested in 1991 in Los Angeles37 and that XXXXX XXXXX, a Vietnamese Canadian was arrested for drug trafficking in Canada in 1993 and is likely related to the group.
[57] The principal claimant submits that she will not get a fair trial in Vietnam because the process of investigation and interrogation of detained persons in Vietnam demonstrates the government’s willingness to use torture or cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, to elicit confessions. She argues that the statements made by detainees, including those who have allegedly pointed the finger at the principal claimant, cannot be relied upon. The principal claimant’s allegation is that the government of Vietnam has a vested interest in prosecuting and convicting her in order to execute her as the last of the group of twenty persons accused of drug trafficking in 1997. She alleges they will rush to judgment without due process.
[58] The principal claimant argues that this evidence, buttressed by general country conditions documents, confirms her position that she will not get a fair trial, she will be tortured upon capture, and detained without regard to international human rights. Accordingly, she urges me to offer her refugee protection.
[59] Counsel argues that the Minister must establish that the “confession” by XXXXX was voluntary and the failure to do so must result in a finding that there is insufficient evidence to justify criminal charges in Vietnam. Mr. XXXXX allegedly pointed the finger at Ms. XXXXX. Mr. XXXXX faced execution, therefore had a vested interest in having his sentence commuted from the death penalty to a life sentence. Therefore, given these factors, the submissions goes, it would be dangerous to rely upon Mr. XXXXX evidence to find there are serious reasons for considering that Ms. XXXXX has committed a serious non-political crime.
[60] There is no evidence to support the principal claimant’s contention that the Warrant was issued based on the word of an informant. In fact, the supplementary information provided suggests that Ms. XXXXX family has been of interest to the Vietnamese police for “decades” long before the jail house informant allegedly pointed the finger at her.38
[61] In short, we do not need to rely solely on a jailhouse informant’s death row accusation, if this is in fact the source of Ms. XXXXX problems, as she asserts. Counsel’s argument is therefore not persuasive.
[62] Moreover, it was the evidence of the lawyer Mr. XXXXX, that Ms. XXXXX did not stand up in court and absolve the principal claimant of involvement in the trafficking case39. He was at the courthouse – the principal claimant was not. I therefore prefer his evidence to hers.
[63] Given the level of detail in these documents, I find there are serious reasons for considering the principal claimant has committed criminal acts and that she was involved in a large-scale drug trafficking operation, and has been for years.
6. Analysis Regarding Exclusion Pursuant to Article 1F(b)
[64] A significant body of law has developed over the years with respect to exclusion and how Members hearing cases where the Minister is alleging the claimants are excluded from refugee protection, should deal with the evidence. Several factors must be considered in arriving at a determination: whether the crime is political, serious, and whether there are serious reasons for considering the claimant has committed the crimes alleged.
(a) Is the Crime Political?
[65] The seriousness of the crime must be weighed in light of the political nature of the crime. In the case at hand, there is nothing political about the charges of drug trafficking. The motivation of the principal claimant when the crime was allegedly committed was non-political. Despite this, the principal claimant alleges that there are political motives behind the charges, however she has not produced any evidence, other than her unsupported allegation, that this is so. She testified it was her belief the police in Vietnam may have charged her in order to extort funds from her, which she said is common. Her allegation is unsupported and does not rebut the credible and trustworthy evidence of the Minister that she was involved in drug trafficking. Her allegation that the charges were falsely laid is not supported by any credible and trustworthy evidence. I do not find any evidence to suggest a political motive when the charges were laid against the principal claimant, or in the surrounding circumstances.
[66] The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) Handbook40 and the courts have analyzed at length, the “political crime exception” rule.41
Although the concept of “political crime” is not normally thought of as known to Canadian criminal law, in two respects at least, the laws of Canada recognize that the consequences of an otherwise criminal act may vary if that act can be characterized as political.
The “political offence” exception is thus applicable only when a certain level of violence exists and when those resorting to violence are seeking to accomplish a particular objective such as to bring about political change or to combat violent political opposition.
The nature and purpose of the offence require examination, including whether it was committed out of genuine political motives or merely for personal reasons or gain, whether it was directed towards a modification of the political organization or the very structure or the state, and whether there is a close and direct causal link between the crime committed and its alleged political purpose and object. The political element should in principle outweigh the common law character of the offence, which may not be the case if the acts committed are grossly disproportionate to the objective, or are of an atrocious or barbarous nature.42
[67] There is insufficient evidence, other than the principal claimant’s assertion, of a political motive by the police in Vietnam, when they laid these charges against the principal claimant and her family members. The principal claimant is indirectly suggesting that I assume another person implicated her to protect himself. Other than the principal claimant’s indirect assertion, which I find is not credible; we have no evidence that this is so. In fact there is evidence to the contrary.
[68] The principal claimant argues she does not fit the profile of a drug trafficker because rather than bribe her way out of trouble; she went into hiding and became destitute. There is insufficient evidence, she argues, that she benefited from drug money. However, this ignores that we have more than simple conjecture in the evidence adduced. There are court documents, police statements, testimony of her husband’s lawyer, and so on. There is much more evidence pointing to a criminal past, than away from one.
[69] Whether we analyze the facts from the point of view of Ms. XXXXX or her alleged persecutor, I can find no political opinion in the acts alleged. Therefore, I have concluded there is no political motivation behind the actions of the government of Vietnam in the laying of criminal charges against the principal claimant or in the issuance of the Warrant.
(b) Is the Crime Serious?
[70] I must be satisfied that the crime in question is “serious”. In Chan43 the Court ruled that drug trafficking offences in Canada could not lead to exclusion under Article 1F(c). The Court made reference to the fact that drug trafficking is a serious non-political crime and goes on to find in obiter that where a crime results in greater than a ten-year sentence, it can be presumed to be a serious crime.
[71] The UNHCR Handbook44 is instructive in this regard.
151. The aim of this exclusion clause is to protect the community of a receiving country from the danger of admitting a refugee who has committed a serious common crime. It also seeks to render due justice to a refugee who has committed a common crime (or crimes) of a less serious nature or has committed a political offence.
155. Minor offences punishable by moderate sentences are not grounds for exclusion under Article 1F(b) even if technically referred to as “crimes” in the penal law of the country concerned. (Emphasis added)
[72] The maximum penalty for trafficking in heroin is life imprisonment. This clearly puts a conviction for this activity into the “serious” category, as envisioned in Chan.45 This is not a “minor offence punishable by a moderate sentence”.
[73] I find as a fact that the crimes alleged are serious.
[74] Finally, I must be satisfied that the crimes in question were allegedly committed prior to the person entering the country of refuge, which is not in dispute.
[75] I have also considered whether I must balance the seriousness of the crime, and the fear of persecution as the UNHCR Handbook suggest I must.46 The Court of Appeal in Malouf47 clearly held there is no balancing or proportionality test between the seriousness of the principal claimant’s conduct, and the alleged fear of persecution.
(c) Are There Serious Reasons to Consider That the Principal Claimant Has Committed A Serious Non-Political Crime?
(i) Onus of Proof
[76] The parties agree that the onus is on the Minister to establish there exist “serious reasons to consider” that either or both of the claimants have committed a serious non-political crime. The Federal Court has defined “serious reasons to consider” as less than the civil standard of balance of probabilities but more than mere speculation.48
[77] There must be a finding that the principal claimant committed a crime in order for the exclusion clauses to apply. The courts have been clear that there is no requirement that the Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB) be convinced the principal claimant was convicted in her country. It does not in fact, require any outstanding charges in the country of origin, for exclusion to apply.49 A person’s admission is sufficient to establish exclusion. Moreover, had the principal claimant been charged, convicted and served her sentence, exclusion would not apply.50
(ii) Serious Reasons for Considering
[78] There is sufficient evidence before the panel to find there are serious reasons to consider that Ms. XXXXX committed a serious non-political crime. There is the previously mentioned INTERPOL Warrant, detailing why she is wanted in Vietnam. In addition, there is her husband’s conviction for trafficking. She is considered to be the accomplice of her husband. Ms. XXXXX provided more detailed information following her discussion with the INTERPOL agents, including information of drug trafficking transactions over the period of many years, or perhaps decades.
[79] In addition, the documents provided by the Minister’s counsel make a compelling argument that the principal claimant’s roots to international trafficking are tied to her family.
[80] The documents also confirm that where, like here, the person is out of the country when the Warrant is to be executed, a procedure must be followed. An official of the court or police cannot issue an arrest Warrant unless the Prosecutor has signed off its issuance. Second, the Public Prosecutor supervises the action of the court and the police, and third, for those outside of the country, the government of Vietnam asks INTERPOL’s assistance to help detain and perhaps to extradite.51
[81] I do not think it necessary to set out in detail the criminal activities alleged, such as the time, place, methods, goods or people affected, which are included in the many documents filed,52 and the testimony of the witnesses.
[82] I am of the view that the INTERPOL Warrant is trustworthy. The principal claimant has been unable to explain why the government would falsely accuse her of international drug trafficking. The principal claimant’s husband was convicted after a trial. The principal claimant declares herself to be innocent yet chose to stand by while her husband went to trial. She allegedly believed her husband was wrongly arrested in her place. Her husband may not have had the defences available to him that were available to her, had she been tried in his place. For example, she was the lender of the money, not her husband.
[83] We will never know whether the outcome might have been different had she come forward when she was under suspicion. What we do know is that there is a Red Circle Notice for the principal claimant that has been confirmed by a Canadian diplomat in a face-to-face meeting with INTERPOL police.
[84] Counsel for the principal claimant argues that there is a presumption of innocence afforded accused persons, at least in Canada. The Warrant is therefore simply an allegation of wrongdoing without real effect until a conviction has taken place.
The presumption of innocence cannot apply to the issuance of the documents initiating criminal proceedings because this presumption is inconsistent with an allegation of wrongdoing. One does not issue a warrant for arrest of a person without a reasonable belief that the person has committed a criminal offence.53
The Board was entitled to presume the warrant for the appellant’s arrest was issued in the belief that she was guilty of misconduct but it does not apply so as to prevent the Board from taking the Chinese state’s belief in her guilt into account in deciding if there are serious reasons to consider that she committed the crime with which she is charged.54
…The Board was entitled to consider that it named the appellant, it referred to a specific criminal offence, as well as the time and place when the offence was alleged to have been committed, and stipulated a maximum sentence. All of those details could reasonably lead the Board to give the warrant a certain amount of weight.55
[85] It is the evidence of Ms. XXXXX, XXXXX Counsellor at the Canadian Embassy in Hanoi, that Ms. XXXXX was involved in drug trafficking going back to 1988, and that her activities
continued until at least 1995.56 Counsel urges that I give no weight to the INTERPOL Warrant, and submits that Ms. XXXXX evidence is problematic. He argues the Warrant is based upon unproven facts.
[86] The Minister arranged for an investigation of Ms. XXXXX activities by the Canadian Embassy staff in Vietnam. Ms. XXXXX understood her task to be to question witnesses in the area of Ms. XXXXX home and businesses, and to speak with the INTERPOL offices. The Vietnamese police at the INTERPOL offices would have likely been unwilling to disclose information about Ms. XXXXX to Ms. XXXXX, without a legitimate purpose. Ms. XXXXX formed the opinion that she must disclose Ms. XXXXX whereabouts in Canada, in order to obtain more information about why Ms. XXXXX was wanted by the INTERPOL offices.
[87] It would have been preferable for Ms. XXXXX not to disclose the fact that Ms. XXXXX was in Canada, however, I find that Ms. XXXXX was sensitive to the concerns of privacy and asked and provided only as much information as she felt was required to obtain the necessary information. It is regrettable that she disclosed the principal claimant’s whereabouts. However, I find that her evidence is relevant, probative, obtained without jeopardy to the principal claimant, and provided in a timely manner. As such I am relying upon it to assist in my determination of the claim.
[88] Ms. XXXXX met with the INTERPOL police, armed with a copy of the INTERPOL Warrant. The evidence demonstrates that the INTERPOL police are Vietnamese police assigned to the INTERPOL office, which is a separate office from the local authorities. While communications are said to be confidential, the fact is the INTERPOL police are charged with the duty of tracking alleged criminals or offenders, who have fled the jurisdiction. In this way, the INTERPOL offices deal not only with international policing forces, but local ones as well. Ms. XXXXX, as a new Consul to the Canadian Embassy, and with limited experience in the area of immigration (although with a lengthy record of employment in the foreign service) disclosed to the INTERPOL police that Ms. XXXXX was in Canada. She did not disclose the principal claimant’s actual whereabouts in Canada.
[89]
I have read and prefer the documentary evidence provided by the Minister, which I find is very persuasive and thorough.57 The evidence suggests that the justice system in Vietnam, while very different from Canada’s is not a system that necessarily convicts on fabricated evidence. Evidence of country conditions generally, including the evidence of Mr. XXXXX regarding what took place at Mr. XXXXX trial and appeal, do not provide sufficient doubt about the surrounding circumstances, such that I would question the validity of the INTERPOL Warrant and the evidence upon which it is based. The combination of factors which have not been satisfactorily addressed by the principal claimant, is what makes the Minister’s case so strong.
[90] Given the number of drug-related convictions in the principal claimant’s immediate family, there are serious reasons for considering the principal claimant committed the offences detailed in the INTERPOL Warrant.
[91] Justice Kelen in Xie58 held that the IRB is entitled to consider an international Warrant in deciding whether there are serious reasons for considering that the principal claimant has committed a serious non-political crime.
[92] I am therefore satisfied there are serious reasons for considering the principal claimant has committed a serious non-political crime, and nothing she has alleged in her own defence justifies a different finding.
[93] Therefore, on the totality of the evidence adduced by the Minister opposing the principal claimant’s claim for refugee protection, I find that XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX is a person referred to in section 98 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (and the Schedule). She is therefore, excluded from the definition of Convention refugee or person in need of protection, as outlined in sections 96 and 97(1) of IRPA. The principal claimant is excluded from all three protection grounds available to refugee claimants, pursuant to Article 1F(b) of the Geneva Convention.59
The Xie Decision60
[94] Having concluded that Ms. XXXXX is excluded from the definition of Convention refugee, should I now go on to deal with whether she has a well-founded fear of persecution? In Xie, the Court had this to say about the Refugee Protection Division’s jurisdiction:
“…the Board, having found that the exclusion applied, went on to consider whether the applicant was at risk of torture upon her return to China. In my view, the Board exceeded its mandate when it decided to deal with the appellant’s risk of torture upon return with the result that the Minister is not bound by that finding. Once the Board found that the exclusion applied, it had done everything that it was required to do, and there was nothing more it could do, for the appellant. The appellant was now excluded from refugee protection, a matter within the Board’s competence, and was limited to applying for protection, a matter within the Minister’s jurisdiction. The Board’s conclusions as to the appellant’s risk of torture were gratuitous and were an infringement upon the Minister’s responsibilities.” (Emphasis added)61
[95] The facts in Xie are also similar to those in the present case. The Xie case involved a Red Circle INTERPOL Warrant, which alleged embezzlement, a crime with a maximum penalty of death. In Xie, a letter was filed by the Canadian Embassy in Beijing from China’s Public Security Minister outlining the charges against Xie, and confirming that the Canadian consulate in Guanzhou had advised the Public Service Branch, by letter, that the claimant had made a refugee claim in Canada. They did so in the process of seeking verification of the criminal charges against her in China.
[96] Counsel submits that the principal claimant faces a very real danger of torture should she return to Vietnam and this “trumps” the Minister’s application for exclusion. I disagree. The Board is not required to balance the principal claimant’s crimes, real or alleged, against the risk of torture, upon her return to the country of origin.62 The court in Suresh63 prohibited the removal of an individual to a country where there is a risk of torture, in the absence of
“exceptional circumstances”. It does not require Canada to grant that individual a right of entry as a refugee or person in need of protection.
[97] The Refugee Protection Division is charged with dealing with issues of entry into Canada, and not removal from Canada, which is the mandate of the Minister at a Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (PRRA) interview. The balancing process required by section 7 of the Charter64 would then take place as part of the PRRA application, which would have the effect of staying the removal order.
[98] Mr. Justice James Russell in A.C.,65 dealt with the issue of torture and how it impacts an analysis of a claim for refugee protection. In that case, the claimant was convicted in absentia in Bangladesh for his alleged role in a bloody coup in 1975. He was sentenced to death by firing squad. The words of the Court are instructive.
Behind this Application in my opinion lies a justifiable fear that, if returned to Bangladesh the Principal Applicant at least, could face torture and death. The issue will need to be confronted directly if a decision is made to deport him. The Panel, however, was fixed with considering the status of the Applicants. Within the narrow context of a Decision on refugee status alone, and bearing in mind that the panel only had to conclude that there were “serious reasons” for considering that the Principal Applicant had committed a serious, non-political offence, I believe the panel made no reviewable error.66
[99] I cannot therefore assess whether the principal claimant has a well-founded fear of persecution in Vietnam, since to do so would be an infringement upon the Minister’s responsibility. Applying this reasoning to the sur place claim (set out below), I find that I have no jurisdiction to deal with this aspect of the claim since the sur place argument relates to the principal claimant’s fear of persecution.
THE CLAIM OF XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX
1. Allegations of XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX
[100] The associated claimant was married once in 1983 to XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX (no relation to the principal claimant) while she was working in Russia. They had one child together born in 1985. They were divorced in 1990 and she was granted custody of their daughter XXXXX and had possession of the matrimonial home, a small, three-story structure in Hanoi – the house in which the principal claimant allegedly hid.
[101] In 1991 she met XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX who helped her recover money she had loaned to someone. They began to live in a common-law relationship in XXXXX 1991.
[102] She met the principal claimant on a trip to a pagoda in 1993 or 1994. They became very good friends and socialized regularly. She describes the principal claimant’s restaurant as “fancy” and frequented by foreign guests.67 In 1997 when the principal claimant’s troubles began, she went to Ms. XXXXX home. According to Ms. XXXXX, Ms. XXXXX was allegedly very afraid to return to her own home because the police were looking for her.
[103] Although Ms. XXXXX was afraid of what might happen to her for harbouring the principal claimant, she acquiesced and permitted Ms. XXXXX to stay with her. She confirmed the principal claimant stayed in a small attic room hidden from view for five years, and never left the house. She did all of the shopping, cooking and cared for Ms. XXXXX.
[104] She alleges that when XXXXX began to hit her, he also began to sexually assault the principal claimant. The associated claimant did not blame her friend for these sexual acts; rather, she sympathized with her. She realised XXXXX was very dangerous and that she had to leave him. When she confronted him, he told her he would report her to the police for harbouring Ms. XXXXX. Believing she could be executed for this act, it was decided that she and Ms. XXXXX would leave Vietnam.
[105] She left her daughter with her common-law spouse, and the two claimants left Vietnam, making their way to Canada to seek protection. The associated claimant testified that she is in touch with her daughter.
2. Identity
[106] Ms. XXXXX identity as a national of Vietnam has been established by her oral testimony and the documentation filed, namely a birth certificate,68 an Australian passport,69 and an identity card.70 She entered Canada using a fraudulent Australian passport, bearing her true name and photograph.71 I am satisfied she is a national of Vietnam and of no other country.
3. Allegations of the Minister
[107] The Minister is of the opinion that the associated claimant should be excluded pursuant to Article 1F(b) by virtue of her activities in harbouring Ms. XXXXX for five years as well as her participation in helping Ms. XXXXX escape Vietnam. She is therefore an “accessory after the fact”.
[108] Article 23(1) of the Criminal Code of Canada72 reads:
Accessory after the fact—An accessory after the fact to an offence is one who, knowing that a person has been a party to an offence, receives, comforts or assists that person for the purpose of enabling that person to escape.
[109] The three requirements for a person to be convicted of this crime include: the person must have knowledge that a crime has been committed; the person must show a desire to help the delinquent escape; and the person must engage in a positive act of omission to aid him in making his escape. 73
[110] The Minister argues that it is clear from Ms. XXXXX evidence, if I find her evidence is credible, that she fits all three of the above requirements.
[111] Mr XXXXX argues further that since section 463(a) [(the penalty section for section 23 (1)] of the Criminal Code of Canada74 carries a maximum penalty of 14 years, it falls within the “serious non-political crime” definition set out above.
4. Exclusion pursuant to Article 1F(b)
[112] There is insufficient evidence that the authorities in Vietnam are interested in the associated claimant. We do not have a Warrant for her arrest, or any information to suggest that she is wanted by INTERPOL or the Vietnamese authorities for harbouring Ms. XXXXX, or for any other reason.
[113] I find that Ms. XXXXX should not be excluded pursuant to Article 1F(b) by virtue of her activities for allegedly harbouring Ms. XXXXX for five years as well as her alleged participation in helping Ms. XXXXX escape Vietnam, because I am not persuaded she did in fact harbour Ms. XXXXX or help her escape from Vietnam. The story is implausible in my view and this, together with the other credibility concerns, has caused me to conclude the story is concocted.
[114] In addition, there is no evidence of criminal charges in Vietnam. This fact alone suggests there is reason to doubt the fact that Ms. XXXXX was in hiding for several years in Ms. XXXXX attic.
[115] There is insufficient credible or trustworthy evidence to find her excluded. Therefore, there are no serious reasons for believing that the associated claimant committed a serious non-political crime.
Well-Founded Fear of Persecution (Inclusion)
[116] Ms. XXXXX testified that she was concerned that Mr. XXXXX was a “dangerous man”. She alleges he is very violent, that he raped Ms. XXXXX on a number of occasions and she was concerned for their personal safety. She testified that she overheard him ordering people killed and witnessed a stabbing.75 She said her boyfriend was highly connected and acted with impunity.76 She described him as “chief”77 and or “leader”78 of a criminal gang – a “gangster”.79
[117] I find it noteworthy that none of this is mentioned in her Personal Information Form (PIF)80 or in her interview with Canada Immigration at the Port of Entry.81 In addition, at the hearing for the first time, we learned that her boyfriend was actually allegedly married to another woman,82 and that he travelled back and forth between her house and his.83 These are critical details that were not part of her claim at the Port of Entry,84 or in her PIF.85
[118] In addition to these significant omissions in her evidence, there are plausibility concerns with her story. Is it reasonable that she would she leave her vulnerable young daughter in the care of this violent, murderous, sexual assaulting predator?86 The associated claimant was asked about this in the hearing. She replied that she had hoped her father or brother would keep her daughter safe, although she admitted that she had made no provision for this.87
[119] Is it reasonable she would not have asked her brother, a police officer, for assistance with her boyfriend?
[120] Is it plausible, given her boyfriend’s violent personality and police connections, that Ms. XXXXX would apply for a Vietnamese passport in her own name and go through a police clearance to obtain it, one week before her departure, rather than use her falsely obtained Australian passport as Ms. XXXXX did?88
[121] The fact that Ms. XXXXX obtained her own passport, visited her parents, and arranged to leave the country are contrary to her claim of a fear of reprisals from her gangster boyfriend with high connections and her alleged fear she could face the death penalty for harbouring Ms. XXXXX Is it plausible her boyfriend would not have reported her to the police? Why has he not gone to the police if his threat to report the two women’s activities was a real one? Mr. XXXXX could have reported her activities to the authorities if he is so inclined, given his apparent police connections. Apparently, he is not so inclined. I think it is reasonable to assume that if criminal
charges of any kind have been laid against the associated claimant, we would have had evidence of this in the hearing.
[122] The Immigration Officer who interviewed the associated claimant noted the contradictions in both claimants’ information when they were asked questions about their travel to Canada, and other aspects of their refugee claims.89
[123] I have considered the Chairperson’s Gender Guidelines,90 because the associated claimant has alleged she has a well-founded fear of persecution on the basis of her membership in a particular social group, as a woman.
[124] Because of the credibility concerns noted above, I find her evidence is patently unreliable and have therefore concluded there is insufficient credible and trustworthy evidence upon which to make a finding that the associated claimant has a well-founded fear of persecution.
[125] Even if I accepted the associated claimant did in fact harbour Ms. XXXXX this would make her a fugitive from justice, nothing more. She alleges that she is afraid she will be arrested for harbouring Ms. XXXXX. Rather than remain in Vietnam to see whether charges ever materialized, she fled. What she fears is prosecution for the violation of a law of general application, and not persecution for a Convention ground.
[126] I do not believe she is being truthful with the Board and therefore do not believe what she has alleged in support of her claim.
[127] The onus of proof is on the claimant to establish a well founded fear of persecution for a Convention reason, or that there are serious reasons for believing she is otherwise at risk. She has not established on reliable evidence that what she fears is persecution, or a risk to life, or of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, or of torture.
Sur Place Claim
[128] Concern was expressed that an article published in The Asian Post on October 10-23, 2002 referred to the two claimants. Counsel accuses the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration, or her delegate of releasing this confidential information about these claims to The Asian Post.91
[129] He further asserts that it is “well-known that that [sic] Vietnamese government has spies in Vietnamese communities overseas, including in the one [sic] in the Lower Mainland”.92 Counsel for the claimants has advanced no evidence that the Vietnamese government has spies in the Lower Mainland and he has had many months to do so, if such evidence was available. Counsel is attempting to lead evidence through his submissions.
[130] The claimants were not named in this article, which was written two years ago. No repercussions or fallout from this article has been demonstrated. The claimants could have brought such evidence and it would have been considered along with the other evidence in the claim. Moreover, the information about this case is known only to the parties since the hearing was held in camera.
[131] Counsel accuses the Minister of breaching the confidentiality of these proceedings, without a scintilla of evidence to support this assertion. The claimants’ families could also have released this information to The Asian Post. I refuse to speculate about how this information found its way into the newspaper. The claimants have had two years to produce evidence that this article has come to the attention of the authorities in Vietnam. They still have family members and friends there who could have provided evidence that the authorities knew about the article and there were problems as a result. They have not provided any evidence that this has occurred.
[132] I do not know whether the Vietnamese government has spies in Vancouver. This is conjecture on the claimants’ part. There is simply no credible evidence before this panel to conclude there is a sur place claim.
[133] Therefore, there is insufficient credible and trustworthy evidence to find the associated claimant is a Convention refugee. Whether the claim is framed pursuant to section 96 or section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, the outcome is the same. There is insufficient credible and trustworthy evidence upon which to found a claim for refugee protection.
DETERMINATION
[134] Pursuant to section 98 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, I find the principal claimant XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, is a person referred to in section F of Article 1 of the Geneva Convention. She is therefore not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection. Her application for refugee protection is therefore rejected.
[135] The associated claimant XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX is not a Convention refugee, as she does not have a well-founded fear of persecution for a Convention ground in Vietnam. I also find the associated claimant is not a person in need protection in that her removal to Vietnam would not subject her personally to a risk to her life, or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, and in that there are no substantial grounds to believe that her removal to Vietnam will subject her personally to a danger of torture. Her application for refugee protection is therefore rejected.
[136] For the reasons given, there is insufficient evidence to conclude that the associated claimant is a person referred to in section F of Article 1 of the Refugee Convention.

1 Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), S.C. 2001, c. 27. Section 96, Convention refugee.
96. A Convention refugee is a person who, by reason of a well-founded fear of persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership in a particular social group or political opinion,
(a) is outside each of their countries of nationality and is unable or, by reason of that fear, unwilling to avail themself of the protection of each of those countries; or
(b) not having a country of nationality, is outside the country of their former habitual residence and is unable or, by reason of that fear, unwilling to return to that country.
2 Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27. Section 97(1), Person in need of protection.
97. (1) A person in need of protection is a person in Canada whose removal to their country or countries of nationality or, if they do not have a country of nationality, their country of former habitual residence, would subject them personally
(a) to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture; or
(b) to a risk to their life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if
(i) the person is unable or, because of that risk, unwilling to avail themself of the protection of that country,
(ii) the risk would be faced by the person in every part of that country and is not faced generally by other individuals in or from that country,
(iii) the risk is not inherent or incidental to lawful sanctions, unless imposed in disregard of accepted international standards, and
(iv) the risk is not caused by the inability of that country to provide adequate health or medical care.
