XXXXXXXXXXXXX is a putative citizen of Algeria, aged 41, who left that country in XXXXX 1994 and lived in the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the United States (US) before making a refugee claim in Canada in XXXXX 2002. He seeks refugee protection because he worked as a government official in Algeria and this makes him the target of armed Islamic groups in his country while, on the other hand, he is wanted by Algerian authorities who suspect that because he left his government job he went to join armed Islamic groups in the mountains. Now they would also be suspicious of the fact he has lived abroad for a long time. In addition, he claims to be a refugee on religious grounds because when living in Taiwan he became a Christian convert and as an apostate he would be in danger from Muslim fundamentalists and others in Algeria. Also his fundamental human right to freedom of religion would be violated by the clandestine way he would be forced to practice Christianity if returned to Algeria.
While visiting the US in 1998-99 his one-year visa expired and he made an affirmative asylum claim because he did not want to return to Algeria or Taiwan. Believing that his claim had been rejected he returned to Taiwan in late XXXXX 2001 and only found out in Canada, when he obtained a copy of his official US file, that he had been granted asylum just a few days after his departure.
SUMMARY OF ALLEGATIONS
According to the claimant's original Personal Information Form (PIF),1 he was born in the city of XXXXX in Algeria, and lived and worked there continuously, between 1963 and 1994, except for the fou-year period when he earned a certificate to be a XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX in the city of Algiers. He was employed by the city of Constantine in a position of this kind from XXXXX 1991 until his departure from Algeria in XXXXX 1994.
As a civil servant he was assigned to work at the polling station in the first round of the 1991 elections. The FIS (Islamic Salvation Front) protested that the election was not fair and there was talk that there would be recriminations against government officials if the FIS came to power. Although the FIS won the election, the president dissolved parliament and a military government took power and cancelled the election result.
The government seized the Islamic University and Mosque under construction in Constantine; XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX. Many people were loyal to the FIS and made threats on the walls of the building and there were bomb scares. He received anonymous calls at home. He asked his employer to be reassigned but was refused because all of the other workers wanted transfers too. The civil conflict worsened with the terrorists killing people and the government arresting everyone they suspected of being terrorists. The economic situation was very grim and the government was diverting all available funds for security uses. The risk of investigation was severe and if one was to resign from a government job they would automatically be suspect as a terrorist.
Amid this chaos the claimant prepared to leave the country and assembled all the documents he needed for a visa. In XXXXX 1993 on his way to Algiers the bus he was riding was stopped at a roadblock by people wearing camouflage clothes, armed with machine guns. In this encounter he lost his backpack that carried all his belongings, life savings and identity documents. He borrowed money and tried to obtain new documents. By XXXXX 1994 he had organized things and found a way to get a French visitor visa, and so he left for France.
However, the claimant found it hard to survive in France and could not get his visa renewed. So he obtained a visa for Taiwan where a female friend of his lived. They married in 1995 and he finally obtained a temporary resident visa valid for three years. In Taiwan the claimant experienced problems with the language and culture and documents, as well as racial discrimination.
In 1998 he got a chance to go America. He wanted further training that would help him support his family, and an American pastor whom he had met in Taipei had encouraged him to go to learn more about his new religious faith. The claimant was baptized on XXXXX, 1997 and states in his PIF that he has been a practicing Christian since then.
When his US visa expired he did not want to return to Algeria or Taiwan and sought some advice. His counsel advised him to apply for asylum. He states in the PIF that his application was rejected on the grounds that he still had temporary residence in Taiwan and after he received a letter from the INS (US Immigration and Naturalization Service) of their intent to deny his application, he went back to the Republic of China in XXXXX 2001. There his situation was complicated by the expiration of his residence visa, and his wife getting pregnant for a
second time, even though they were not on good terms. By the time he received a one-year visa extension, until XXXXX 2002, he and his wife were already divorced - he gives the date of the divorce as XXXXX 2001 in the PIF. He had no other way but to leave the country when the residence visa expired. He learned about Canada and tried to apply for a visa but it was refused without a reason.
The claimant went to Thailand where he bought a French passport and then destroyed his Algerian passport in order to carry just one with him on the trip. He flew via Hong Kong and arrived in Vancouver on XXXXX, 2002.
In the original PIF, the claimant states that he was mistreated by Canadian immigration authorities. Specifically, he was kept for extended periods in solitary confinement and interrogated by Immigration, the RCMP and CSIS (Canadian Security Intelligence Service). He was isolated and not given access to a lawyer until XXXXX, 2002. He was detained for one month even after he had established his identity and was shocked at this treatment.
In an amendment to the PIF signed on August 6, 2003, the claimant lists his sister XXXXX as residing in Bern, Switzerland rather than in Constantine, Algeria and provides details of his work history in France, Taiwan, and Thailand. He also lists other travel destinations including Malaysia and Hong Kong and various places in China. His amendment to the narrative statement includes further allegations of mistreatment by Canadian officials when he made his refugee claim at the Vancouver International Airport (VIA).
ANALYSIS
ISSUES
The following issues were identified: personal identity; Christian religion; credibility; subjective basis related to his previous claim elsewhere (US) and re-availment; agents of persecution; objective basis and change of circumstances; and Internal Flight Alternative (IFA). The claimant's alleged Christian conversion was recognized as a sur place claim.
In counsel's submission, the evidence that raises the issue of re-availment is in the excluded port of entry notes and therefore cannot be considered in the determination of the claim. The Refugee Protection Division has found there is no other evidentiary basis for the issue.
Exclusion of Port of Entry Notes
Counsel made oral application at the outset of the hearing to have certain port of entry notes excluded from the evidence before the Board: Schedule 1 - Background Information, dated XXXXX, 2002; CSIS examination notes dated XXXXX, 2002; statutory declaration of the Immigration Officer, XXXXX XXXXX, dated XXXXX, 2002; and four pages of notes included in the XXXXX, 2003 disclosure by Minister's counsel. On the basis of the claimant's affidavit dated XXXXX, 2003, and an amendment the claimant had made to his PIF the same day, counsel argued that Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) had violated the claimant's rights under sections 7 and 10 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms (Charter).
According to the affidavit and the PIF amendment, the claimant was mistreated by Immigration and other Canadian officials the day he arrived at the Vancouver International Airport (VIA) on a flight from Hong Kong on XXXXX, 2002, between 10:00 and 11:00 a.m. and in the days that followed. He had already been told by airport security prior to boarding his plane in Hong Kong that there was a problem with his passport - described elsewhere in his PIF as a French passport in the name of XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX that had been improperly obtained.
At VIA, I was referred to an examination room. I told the officer there that my passport was fraudulent and that I wished to seek safety in Canada. When I told the officer that I was from Algeria, he said to sit and wait. Throughout the course of the day, I was interrogated by many different people. Some with guns, some with suits and dark glasses, a woman, and one man with a leather jacket and a gun. They asked me questions about my travel, my opinions, and often joked and insinuated that I was a terrorist. I was searched, handcuffed and put in a cell at different times. My jacket was taken from me, and I was cold. I was prevented from sleeping, and even from lying down. I was given only a vegetable sandwich and a juice box to eat. I was threatened. I was terribly afraid.
Later in the day, I met with Immigration Officer XXXXX XXXXX. She would ask me questions and then would be called away. Late in the night of XXXXX XXXXX, 2002 and into the early morning of XXXXX XXXXX she asked me more questions, the answers to which she typed on a compute. I later learned that these questions and answers given were the same as those found on Schedule 1 and Officer XXXXX declaration. I knew that it was close to midnight because there was a clock on the wall and because Officer XXXXX and her supervisor complained repeatedly about how late it was getting and were pressuring me to finish.
As I was completely traumatized by the treatment I had received throughout the course of the day I have no recollection of being told that
I had a right to a lawyer. I do remember at one point in time, after Officer XXXXX had completed filling out answers on the computer that I has handed the phone and told a lawyer was on the line. Because I had been mistreated for so long I did not believe the person I was speaking to was a lawyer, but rather that it was some kind of trick or game that was being played on me. All the lawyer said was "don't worry, be good, do what they say." A few minutes afterwards I was told by Officer XXXXX supervisor that I would be detained. I was never told the reason for my detention.
I was similarly treated over the next three days, but did not see a lawyer until Monday, XXXXX, 2002, just shortly before my first detention hearing.2
Essentially counsel argued in light of these allegations that the claimant had not been subjected to the kind of "routine" secondary examination at the port of entry, which was the benchmark for the Supreme Court's findings in the lead case, Dehghani.3 The court had ruled in 1993, concerning the appellant's arrival in Canada in 1989 without valid travel or identity documents, that an examination by an immigration officer for refugee screening does not constitute detention within the meaning of section 10(b) of the Charter, and the principles of fundamental justice cited in section 7 of the Charter do not include a right to counsel during such questioning.4
In counsel's submission, the physical restraint and psychological compulsion the claimant describes in the affidavit and PIF amendment was anything but "routine." He surmised that the people with guns must have been RCMP officers or agents of the Canadian Security Intelligence Service (CSIS), since Immigration officers do not carry firearms. He emphasized that the claimant had been kept in a "holding cell" intermittently over a period of approximately twelve hours from the time he was referred for secondary examination and he was taken downstairs to the airport detention centre to stay overnight. In his opinion, even the questioning exceeded what was necessary to determine whether the claimant was eligible to make a refugee
claim and admissible to Canada, the twofold statutory requirement. He also argued that the claimant's examination was not routine because a CSIS officer had participated in the Immigration Officer's interview.
Both the claimant and the Immigration Officer, XXXXX XXXXX, testified about what had happened at the port of entry during the claimant's secondary examination. Officer XXXXX had also made a brief statutory declaration in writing.5 Their respective evidence was contradictory on key alleged facts in the claimant's PIF amendment.
For her part, Officer XXXXX stated that she recalled and had in the meantime verified that the RCMP was not involved with the claimant's secondary examination, although there were RCMP officers in plain clothes questioning someone else at the time. A CSIS officer who wore a suit and glasses (not dark glasses) did sit in during her interview of the claimant on XXXXX XXXXX and questioned him the following day while she took notes. She testified that airport policy prohibits firearms on the premises by anyone, including US immigration officers who normally are armed. She did not handcuff the claimant herself and could not remember anyone else doing so until he was taken downstairs to sleep in a different facility at the airport, the B.C. Holding Centre, whose policy requires that those being transferred from the CIC area be handcuffed. She noted that complaints about the cold are common but the commissioner supplies blankets upon request. She denied that she or anyone else made jokes or comments to the effect that the claimant was a terrorist. Officer XXXXX was aware from the file that two other Immigration officers had spoken to the claimant before she came on duty: one was a member of the disembarkation team who brought him from the airline gate to the CIC area and placed him in a line-up and the other was the officer at the counter to whom he stated his claim to refugee status and how he planned to obtain his genuine identity documents.
Officer XXXXX described in detail the steps she had taken to inform the claimant of his legal right to counsel (through a French interpreter by telephone) at 22:25 hours on XXXXX, 2002, approximately five hours after she had been given his file and started the interview. She explained her annotations on the Notice of Rights6 that the claimant had signed when the Schedule 1 examination was completed and she received approval by the Senior Immigration Officer to detain him for identity purposes - to allow him further opportunity to obtain his own identity documents. She testified that in her belief he had fully understood that he has the right to counsel because he signed this document; otherwise she assumed he would have said something as he had been very vocal throughout the examination and had asked a lot of questions. As to the delay of a couple of hours between the time the claimant was administered his Charter rights and actually had the chance to talk to a lawyer by telephone, Officer XXXXX explained the procedure is for her to leave a message and once the legal aid duty counsel has picked it up and arranged to have an interpreter by telephone he or she calls back and speaks to the refugee claimant. According to her evidence, the claimant took this call at 00:35 hours on XXXXX, 2002. There appeared to be no dispute in oral testimony that while awaiting the return call from Legal Aid, Officer XXXXX was busy preparing her paperwork and did not resume questioning the claimant.
Officer XXXXX was a very credible and guileless witness while the claimant was not. In this area of his oral evidence, he was vague and repetitious and kept suggesting that he had been so traumatized and afraid at the port of entry that he could not remember the details of what had happened. The Refugee Protection Division prefers Officer XXXXX evidence of what took place at VIA during the secondary examination over the claimant's dramatic account in the amended PIF.
More specifically, the claimant's admission at the hearing that he had the benefit of a lawyer at every single stage of his previous asylum claim in the US casts doubt on his explanation that because of "cultural" differences he did not know about the concept of a right to counsel and therefore did not even think to ask the legal aid duty counsel on the telephone his name or how to get in touch with him again. Objective information about the justice system in Algeria also discredits the notion of a cultural factor because it shows that, following the French model, defendants have the constitutional right to legal counsel in the claimant's own country.7 With this national background, if the claimant really thought he was being treated like a criminal upon arrival in Canada, he should have been prompted to seek legal assistance.
The lack of credible evidence of physical or psychological mistreatment or verbal abuse at the port of entry undermines the claimant's allegation that as a consequence he thought it was a trick when Officer XXXXX had handed him the telephone and said it was a lawyer he could talk to about his situation. In addition, Officer XXXXX testified that she expressly informed him of the reason for his detention, as required under the Charter. Even if he had trouble understanding what she meant, however, it is difficult to believe that the claimant would not have grasped that the basic reason for his detention was because he needed to prove his true identity to Canadian authorities, since he was fully aware that the French passport he had used to come to Canada was fraudulent and he had not yet succeeded in efforts to obtain his own identity documents, initially from Switzerland.
As to the proposition that the claimant was formally detained when he was physically placed in a separate room for intervals during the secondary examination process, Officer XXXXX pointed out this so-called "holding cell" is in reality a room for one person with windows and a washroom, which does not have bars. In her description of it, this small individual waiting room is distinctly different from the detention centre downstairs at VIA. Although the room has a surveillance monitor and the door is locked to restrict access to public areas in the airport, the other waiting area for women and children either making refugee claims or awaiting removal from Canada is also locked as a matter of routine for the sake of public safety and security purposes. Access by refugee claimants to the nearby baggage area and airport exits is necessarily restricted until decisions on admissibility are made.
Moreover, the credibility of the claimant's allegation that he regarded this room as a "cell" and thought he was treated like a "criminal" throughout the day is undermined by his failure to make a complaint to the legal aid lawyer later that night, or to have duty counsel raise the matter at his first detention hearing.8 (Counsel submitted that the Immigration Division could not grant him a remedy, only the Refugee Protection Division was in a position to do so - by excluding the port of entry notes. However, the Refugee Protection Division does not accept that such a fine legal point would reasonably have occurred to the claimant on his own and stopped him from voicing his grievance about his alleged mistreatment.) As it was, in his original narrative statement of the PIF signed January 6, 2003 the claimant alleged that he was isolated and kept for extended periods in "solitary confinement" and not given access to a lawyer until XXXXX, 2002 - the latter allegation is disproved by Officer XXXXX documented oral evidence.
In summary, the claimant provided insufficient credible evidence to distinguish his experience from that of his forerunner, the appellant Abdul Rassoul Dehghani, in 1989. The reason the Refugee Protection Division allowed the application to exclude the specified port of entry notes was decidedly not that the claimant had been mistreated by Immigration officials at the port of entry, or denied the right to counsel at the point Officer XXXXX recommended and her supervisor decided to detain him. Rather it was that he should have been advised of his right to counsel as soon as the CSIS agent indicated to Officer XXXXX that he was going to join her in interviewing the claimant.
According to her oral evidence, this was the first time Officer XXXXX had had a CSIS agent present during a secondary examination of a refugee claimant and her supervisor failed to instruct her that this circumstance may amount to a constitutional detention under the Supreme Court ruling in Dehghani and that she should advise him of his Charter rights. Yet the CIC manual for Port of Entry examinations states the following:
The right to counsel depends on what transpires after the foreign national is first subject to examination
* if a foreign national is being examined and the examination does not go beyond what is required to establish admissibility the foreign national is not entitled to legal counsel;
* if the examination becomes very lengthy and exhaustive yet not beyond what is required to establish admissibility the foreign national is not entitled to legal counsel. The officer may, however, give consideration to allowing the foreign national to acquire legal counsel;
* if the foreign national is not retrained in any way but advised to come back the next day for further examination (A23), then they are not detained and there is no right to counsel;
* if a foreign national is being held for a lengthy period of time and is subject to questioning by other agencies such as the RCMP or CSIS, then this may constitute detention and the foreign national should be notified of their right to counsel;
* if restraining devices are used or the foreign national is placed in a holding cell, even temporarily, then an officer should inform the foreign national of the reason for the detention and of their right to counsel;
* if the foreign national is detained overnight in a detention facility, the foreign national shall be advised of their right to counsel once the decision to detain has been made by an officer.9 (Emphasis Added)
Officer XXXXX testified that although she knew about the court decision in Dehghani she was not aware of this detailed interpretation in the CIC manual and does not recall whether it was in the edition of the manual in use when she was trained. In reference to the point highlighted above, her belief was that the secondary examination can, as a matter of routine procedure, be conducted as a "joint interview" by the Immigration officer and a CSIS agent if the circumstances warrant.
The Refugee Protection Division notes that the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) makes no provision for the secondary examination to involve anyone other than an authorized Immigration officer.10 That is not to suggest that participation by CSIS in the interviews is necessarily inappropriate. On the contrary, the Refugee Protection Division accepts the argument made by both Minister's counsel and the RPO in oral submissions on the application that among the objectives of the IRPA is the promotion of international justice and security by denying access to Canadian territory to persons, including refugee claimants, who are security risks or serious criminals.11 The conditions that constitute inadmissibility are spelled out in detail in the IRPA and include areas where CSIS could apparently be of assistance in the Immigration officer's fact-finding.12
However, the presence of CSIS at the secondary examination did not arise in the facts in the case of Dehghani. The Refugee Protection Division believes it is reasonable to assume that the direction in the CIC manual for port of entry examinations reflects a considered legal opinion by the Department that the contemporary practice of conducting joint interviews with CSIS during the secondary examination could well be distinguishable in law from the Supreme Court ruling. In the absence of a definitive legal interpretation of this practice by the courts, however, the manual states only that when a foreign national is subject to questioning by other agencies such as CSIS, this "may constitute detention," leaving open the possibility that the courts could eventually rule either way, that direct involvement by CSIS does or does not go beyond the routine immigration processing defined in Dehghani, as conducted in the post-September 11, 2001 context, under the newer legislative framework of the IRPA. Still, the instruction in the CIC manual leaves little room for discretion on the part of the Immigration officer in stating that in this situation the foreign national should be notified of the right to counsel. (It is not quite as strong as the word "shall" applied in the event of overnight detention in a detention facility, but categorical nonetheless.) The Refugee Protection Division regards this instruction as the Department's practical way to manage the risk of possible misapplication of Dehghani in the present day.
It is of no relevance that the CSIS agent simply sat in but asked no questions during the first day of the secondary examination, XXXXX, 2002, only the following day when the joint interview continued. In light of Officer XXXXX testimony that the CSIS agent could have asked questions from the start, this meant the claimant was "subject to questioning" by CSIS at all times during the secondary examination.
The Refugee Protection Division found there were grounds to exclude the specified port of entry notes in Officer XXXXX failure to follow the direction in the CIC manual (notwithstanding her lack of awareness), which appears to reflect that Department's legal opinion that the direct involvement of CSIS may take the secondary examination of a refugee claimant beyond that which the Supreme Court in Dehghani established to be routine. Exercising a similar abundance of caution, the Refugee Protection Division allowed counsel's application and excluded from evidence the information that may have been obtained at the port of entry through a breach of the claimant's Charter rights and not in accordance with the principles of fundamental justice.
Having already decided that the claimant should have been informed of his right to counsel on the basis of the participation of CSIS in the secondary examination, it was not necessary for the Refugee Protection Division to make a finding as to whether or not the accommodation where the claimant was intermittently held is a "holding cell" for the purposes of the CIC manual or constitutes detention under section 10(b) of the Charter.
Personal Identity
The Refugee Protection Division finds there are serious reasons to doubt the reliability and trustworthiness of the claimant's documents that indicate his personal identity to be XXXXX XXXXX, a national of Algeria and only Algeria. There is ample evidence to show that he has used this identity in Taiwan and the United States before coming to Canada but whether it is his true identity (and he alone assumed it) is still in question.
One general cause for concern is the ease with which the claimant talked about obtaining fraudulent documents for himself. In the PIF he notes that he "found a way to get" a French visa in 1994 that allowed him to leave Algeria and live in France for a while. In oral testimony he described how in 1998, with the aid of a former colleague of his sister XXXXX, in Geneva, who had transferred and was then working in the Algerian Embassy in Tokyo, he was able to pay someone to have a fake paper issued saying he was a resident of Japan. Allegedly this in turn allowed the Embassy to issue him a new Algerian passport since residence in Japan was a requirement (and there was not an Algerian Embassy in Taiwan). However, in 2002, with the expiration of his residence visa in Taiwan and his divorce pending, he needed a "good" passport to travel to Canada so went to Thailand and "bought" a French passport.13 This evidence is at odds with the indignation the claimant expressed at times in the hearing when the authenticity of his identity documents was challenged.
The Refugee Protection Division finds that the copy of the claimant's putative Algerian passport issued in 1998 in Japan merits little weight because of his convoluted story of how it was improperly obtained and the fact the claimant has not produced the original. He testified that in Bangkok he threw away this genuine Algerian passport (despite all the effort to obtain it), after getting the fraudulent French one. Supposedly he was advised not to travel to Canada with both in his possession and he did not know anyone in Taiwan with whom he could have left it for safe-keeping - which is dubious given his evidence that he had resided in that country for more than four years, in two different places. The Refugee Protection Division draws an adverse inference as to the reliability and trustworthiness of this identity document from the claimant's failure to produce the original, without a reasonable explanation, for examination by Canadian authorities.
Furthermore, his evidence that the issuance of this Algerian passport was dependent on him being a resident of Japan is inconsistent with the fact that the copy plainly shows his domicile as being in Ilan in Taiwan, Republic of China.14 In addition, his original PIF gives the whereabouts of his sister, XXXXX, as Constantine, Algeria, while his oral evidence about her in the context of this passport is that she is employed by the XXXXX XXXXX in Geneva and has lived in Europe for a long time. The claimant tried to suggest that he made an error in the PIF because he thought the information was all about him, but this is not credible. The question that asks the claimant to list relatives and indicate their place and country of residence was interpreted to him when he prepared the PIF and he had the benefit of legal counsel.
At a resumption of the hearing the Presiding Member asked the claimant in reference to the copy in the US record whether he had only one Algerian passport and, for once he answered in a spontaneous forthright manner, words to the effect, "Of course, I had just one. This is the passport I left my country with." When the Presiding Member pointed out that was not his prior evidence, the claimant quickly corrected himself and testified that he wanted to say it was the passport he left the US with. What had precipitated the question was the claimant's inconsistent evidence as to the expiry date of the 1998 passport - the copy in the US record indicates it was XXXXX, 2003 while he had informed an Immigration Officer this passport had expired in XXXXX 2002.15
The documents that the claimant ostensibly obtained from Algeria, sent via his sister in Switzerland, are of dubious probative value partly because he was not able to specify in advance which they were likely to be, and said he had asked his family to send whatever documents they could find in his name.16 Yet it is reasonable to expect that the claimant would have known the sort of identity documents he left behind in Algeria, particularly because according to the PIF, in XXXXX 1993, shortly before he had left Algeria he lost all of his belongings, life savings, and documents, including his passport, ID, and driver's license, to armed rebels at a roadblock on his way to Algiers, in an area "famous for rebels of the GIA and GIS." He states that he tried to get new documents but it was very difficult, almost impossible (without saying what the problem was), but managed to do so.
The main Algerian identity documents that have arrived in Canada to prove his identity were issued on their face during the period XXXXX 1993 - XXXXX 1994. They include: a National Identification Card issued XXXXX, 1993; 17 a "replacement" Driver's License issued XXXXX, 1993; 18and a duplicate military exemption card issued XXXXX, 1994. 19 There is also an International Driver's Permit dated XXXXX, 1994 (which strangely enough the claimant must have left behind when he departed);20 and even a pay stub issued XXXXX, 1993.
According to the report of the forensic analysis by CIC,21 the claimant received two other employment records written in French, one a translation, dated 1988 and 1991 respectively, from different ministries of the Algerian government referencing his duties in construction. Similarly the report of the forensic analysis includes a copy of an extract from the birth registry in Constantine that appears to have been issued XXXXX, 2002 just after the claimant arrived in Canada (the date is very faint on the CIC copy). These three documents were not tendered directly in the refugee claim nor were the originals presented for examination at the hearing (although it is possible they were seized by CIC and were no longer in the claimant's possession). The CIC analyst did not assess their authenticity because the employment records were not considered identity documents and the birth certificate contained no security features.
Lastly, the claimant provided his putative Voter's Card issued on XXXXX, 1990,22 which bears a stamp indicating that the holder voted in June 1990. According to the objective country information there were local elections in June 1990 in Algeria, and the Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) won a landslide victory in all major cities. However, the claimant states in his PIF that he worked at a polling station in a national election in 1991, and in that context it is reasonable to expect that his voter's card would be stamped for that election too. The card does not bear a photograph or the holder's signature.
Considering all of this evidence, the Refugee Protection Division finds that little trust can be placed in the documents obtained by the claimant while he was in detention in Vancouver to establish his personal identity and afterward to bolster that identity. More likely than not the subsequent story in the PIF about the confiscation of previous documents by rebels at a roadblock has been concocted to provide a justification for the clustered dates of issuance and pristine physical condition of the main identity documents submitted.
It emerged in the course of testimony that the claimant's father had worked in France his whole life. Initially the claimant said his father had French citizenship and did not want it at the time, then immediately amended this to say it was possible for him at the time (before 1973 when every Algerian working in France was eligible) but he did not want it. This new evidence raises questions about the claimant's possible status in France.
In his written submissions, counsel points out that a transcript of the claimant's final detention hearing23 indicates the Minister was satisfied as to Mr. XXXXX identity on the basis of far fewer documents than have been entered in evidence in the instant proceedings. That fact is of no particular relevance to the assessment of this issue in the refugee claim since the claimant is subject to a separate onus under section 106 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) and Rule 7 of the Refugee Protection Division Rules to provide documents establishing identity that are acceptable to the Board and, if not, to provide a reasonable explanation for the lack of documents or to have taken reasonable steps to obtain the documentation. A Member of the Refugee Protection Division is not bound by the findings of a Member of the Immigration Division.
In the end, the Refugee Protection Division finds that the claimant has not provided sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence to establish his personal identity or that he is a national of Algeria and only Algeria. However, in the particular circumstances the Refugee Protection Division believes it would be prudent to assess other central issues on the premise that he is the person he claims to be.
Credibility - Christian Conversion / Muslim Apostasy
The Refugee Protection Division finds the claimant's alleged Muslim apostasy and conversion to Christianity is, on the balance of probabilities, not a genuine matter of religious conviction or belief on his part. Rather this is a conversion of convenience that serves as the basis for not just one claim to refugee protection but two - previously in the US24 and now in Canada.
There is no issue that the claimant attended the XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX Christian Church in Taipei, Taiwan, went through an instruction program, received baptism, and attended services at that church for a while. The claimant's original Certificate of Baptism dated XXXXX, 1997 and signed by the American pastor there at the time, XXXXX XXXXX, forms part of his US record,25 and the photograph on it resembles the claimant, although he is wearing a full beard (as on his Alien Resident Certificate from Taiwan).26 However, in a subsequent e-mail from the former pastor, who now resides in California, XXXXX XXXXX in retrospect, "looking back at the events that followed," believes that the claimant was not ready for baptism, although he had gone through instruction and appeared to be so.27 Mr. XXXXX states that, "XXXXX deceived us both," referring to himself and the claimant's Moroccan friend known by his adopted Christian name, XXXXX XXXXX.
His motive has always been to find some way to get into a western country. He attended church for a few months, but then stopped coming.28
He goes on to describe briefly the mutual verbal abuse that plagued the claimant's marriage to a Taiwanese woman and how he had counselled both of them until the claimant dropped out of sight and never came back to the church. He states:
My blunt opinion is that XXXXX is a liar and will say whatever it takes to get what he wants. That is my opinion based on many conversations with him. I personally would not trust him or could not recommend him to most anything, except that he repent.29
Counsel submits that the reader is left to speculate (and indulges in doing so) as to the reasons Mr. XXXXX believes he and XXXXX XXXXX were deceived. The claimant for his part tried to suggest that the former pastor was bitter because he had rejected his advice in the marriage counselling and that while he did not attend the XXXXX church again in Taipei, he went to others, including one with a congregation from the Philippines.
The Refugee Protection Division gives full weight to this character appraisal by XXXXX XXXXX because it carries the wisdom of hindsight, so important in evaluating religious commitment, and evinces appropriate Christian values.
Rather than obtain a copy of the original baptismal certificate from his US attorney or from the US INS to support his refugee claim in Canada, the claimant had another sent by facsimile on August 21, 2003 from the current pastor of the XXXXX church, XXXXX XXXXX.30 In a subsequent letter that followed inquiries by Minister's counsel, Pastor XXXXX confirms that this document was issued but it was on the basis of information provided by church members who knew the claimant, not by reference to church records or personal acquaintance.31 Thus the new "baptismal certificate" is downright misleading -- it does not clarify Pastor XXXXX role or the circumstances and does not even name the other pastor (who left Taiwan in 2001) who had in fact baptized the claimant.
In an email to Minister's counsel from XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, a Migration Integrity Officer at the visa section of Canadian Trade Office in Taiwan, Ms. XXXXX reports on a conversation with Pastor XXXXX, whom she knows personally, about how this baptismal certificate came to be issued. She writes,
He was contacted by XXXXX who desperately wanted a proof that he had been baptized and provided pastor XXXXX with the date of said baptism...pastor XXXXX gave him what he asked for.32
The Refugee Protection Division regards this as prime illustration of how the claimant manages to get what he wants, as XXXXX XXXXX has observed.
In Vancouver the claimant has found support from a minister, Reverend XXXXX XXXXX, and XXXXX XXXXX, who holds a Master's Degree in Divinity and operates a charity hostel, both of whom are associated with the XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX Church in Vancouver, which the claimant reportedly attends. Each provided a written testimonial,33 and testified briefly at the hearing. Both attested to the claimant's religious conviction and his involvement in the life of the congregation.
Meaning no disrespect, the Refugee Protection Division gives their evidence little weight in the assessment of this refugee claim. It is reasonable to assume that members of an evangelical church such as this would not be inclined to cast a critical eye upon or deliberately test the faith of anyone who professes to be a Christian and wishes to participate, perhaps especially a refugee claimant who declares he has converted from Islam and demonstrates fluency in the Christian language and prayer in the conservative evangelical tradition (as Mr. XXXXX put it). On the balance of probabilities, experience will prove that they too have been deceived by the claimant.
Moreover, despite the close relationship Reverend XXXXX has with the claimant, he could not remember whether he knew the claimant had lived in the US. Still, he expressed no surprise that the claimant had not attended church in the US because he did know of his estrangement from Pastor XXXXX and the church in Taiwan. The Refugee Protection Division finds that the apparent fact Reverend XXXXX was unaware of the previous asylum claim in the US based in part on Christian conversion is further evidence of the claimant's duplicity.
As to the claimant's admission that he did not attend church services or take Bible classes or seek out other Christians in the US during his sojourn of XXXXX months, the Refugee Protection Division finds this behaviour makes a mockery of fact that in part he had allegedly gone to the US with the encouragement of Pastor XXXXX to learn more about his religious faith,34 and that he was at the same time pursuing an asylum claim on the basis of his conversion to Christianity. This evidence also contradicts the statement in the PIF that he has been a devout Christian since his baptism in 1997 and, "I have been regularly attending Church and learning about Christ where ever I have been."35
He testified at the hearing that he once sought help from a church in the US because he did not have social assistance and was told to come back on Sunday. He took this response to be a rebuff but the comment could also reasonably be interpreted to mean that he was welcome to attend the church services on Sunday and ask for charity in that setting. He says he practiced Christianity while in the US by reading his Bible on his own, but that would seem to defeat the stated purpose of his visit, as he could have done this in Taiwan.
Finally, the claimant was given several specific opportunities during his examination at the hearing to explain how he came to have a Christian conviction. Each time he was extremely evasive in his answers and wound up not having addressed the question. Similarly, he testified that he had explicitly renounced Islam but this is cast in doubt by his explanation that he did so by pledging not to have any other God. Again, this answer was evasive since it is a generally recognized fact that Muslims also worship God (called Allah) and this "renunciation" would only be meaningful if they are not the same God.
The Refugee Protection Division concludes that the claimant has failed to provide sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence to establish that he is a Muslim apostate who has become a Christian and this religious conversion would subject him to a serious possibility of persecution and of a danger of torture and a risk to life and risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if he were to return to his country of Algeria.
Credibility / Objective Basis / Change of Circumstances - Target of Islamic Groups and Arrest by Government
Allegedly the claimant fears persecution and would be subjected personally to a risk to life and a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in Algeria by armed Islamic groups because he would be perceived by them as a government employee, a member of a particular social group they still target. The Refugee Protection Division finds there is insufficient credible evidence that he was personally of interest to Islamic groups in 1993-94 before he left Algeria, let alone that he would be upon return in 2004, a decade later.
Leaving aside the negative findings on the claimant's identity and his Algerian nationality, and assuming for the sake of analysis that the claimant was indeed a government employee in Algeria during the civil conflict at that time, the credibility of his allegation is undermined by the fact that the rebel group that stopped him and others at a roadblock in XXXXX 1993 let him go physically unharmed, even after checking his identity documents and thus potentially learning that he was a government employee, indeed a particular government employee whose official duties related to XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX in Constantine. According to his description of the incident in the PIF, this was a violent and potentially deadly encounter. In addition to checking IDs and asking questions and taking personal valuables, the rebels threatened everyone with machine guns.
Much has happened in the ensuing decade to reduce any potential threat to the claimant's life from armed Islamic groups. Most importantly, the claimant did not continue to work as an
Algerian government employee - he vanished. According to the documentary evidence,36 the approaches of the armed Islamic groups have evolved and changed over time, from initial targeting of certain categories of people, to indiscriminate attacks on civilians and infrastructure, and on to include criminal rather than ideologically-motivated activities, such as "turf wars" between rival groups, revenge banditry, land grabs, robberies and protection rackets.
The Civil Concord Law of 1999 led to an amnesty for members of these groups who had not personally committed murder, rape and bombings. Only two groups turned down the plan from the start and continue to operate, the Armed Islamic Group (GIA) and the Salafist Group for Preaching (or Call) and Combat (GSPC). Even so their numbers are greatly reduced, and vary from several hundred to several thousand. Estimates of the number who surrendered under the amnesty range from 4200 to 7000. The armed wing of the FIS,37 which the claimant referred to in his PIF and US asylum application, engaged in a ceasefire in 1997, and declared an end to their guerrilla struggle in 1999. They took advantage of the amnesty and disbanded in January 2000.
According to the most recent reports in evidence, the violence by armed Islamic groups currently takes place primarily in the countryside and smaller towns as the security forces have largely forced the insurgents out of the cities, except in the strongholds of the groups. The authorities are in control of the vast majority of their territory and engage in ongoing anti-terrorist operations.
In the mid 1990s the GIA made specific threats against many categories of people who they considered anti-Islamic. More recently, the types of attacks have included apparently indiscriminate killings in massacres and with small bombs, and ambushing intended victims by mounting fake roadblocks. In the dangerous areas that remain, government officials and security forces and their families are still targeted but of course the actual risk has diminished greatly because of the smaller numbers of members. Although some networks are said to still exist in Algiers and Constantine - both are cities where the claimant has lived and worked or studied - the situation there was relatively calm at the time the documentary information in evidence was produced.
Thus, in regard to this basis of the claim to refugee protection, the Refugee Protection Division finds that the claimant has provided insufficient credible evidence to establish that he was once at real risk from armed Islamic groups by reason of him being a government official. A decade on, his claim is no longer even well-founded on a strictly objective basis. As a result of the amnesty and the success of the Algerian security forces, the strength of the armed Islamic groups has been reduced and their geographic scope restricted, such that there is not a serious possibility that the claimant would be subject to persecution or personally face a risk to life or risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment by their hand, if he were to return to Algeria.
According to the PIF, the claimant is also afraid that the Algerian government would arrest and torture him upon return due to suspicions he is a terrorist because he left a government job in 1994 and his subsequent absence could be interpreted to mean he joined the armed Islamic groups in the mountains. Supposedly a friend he contacted who is with the Algerian police told him in late 1995 that he was being sought by the authorities for exactly this reason and threatened to arrest the claimant himself if he were to return.
The Refugee Protection Division finds this alleged basis of the claim is not credible. Despite his statements about the friend's inside knowledge that he was wanted by the police in 1995 and his assertion that the cause for suspicion was his departure from the government job, the claimant did not give a categorical answer when he was asked if the police had ever suspected him (while he was still in Algeria) of being a member of an armed Islamic group; his answer was, "Not that I know of." Moreover, if he realized this was a possible consequence, it is reasonable to expect that he would have called his employer when this leave of absence expired and ensured that the Algerian government was not left with the wrong impression of his whereabouts and activities. Supposedly he was aware at the time that his departure could raise suspicions but he did nothing to allay them. It does not make sense that a decade (of inaction) later he fears there would be sufficiently serious consequences that he needs Canada's protection. Moreover, the Refugee Protection Division reasons that the amnesty granted by the Algerian state to thousands of confirmed members of the armed Islamic groups demonstrates a certain tolerance in the interests of achieving peace that would similarly work in the claimant's favour. On the balance of probabilities, however, this basis of the claim to refugee protection is also a fabrication and the claimant is not wanted by the Algerian authorities on suspicion of his involvement with armed Islamic groups because he left his government job in 1994.
At the hearing the claimant added a twist to this allegation and said that the fact he has been out of the country for so long would be viewed with suspicion by the Algerian authorities. The Refugee Protection Division notes that according to a 1998 report by an academic at the Centre for Middle Eastern and Central Asian Studies in Australia,
Algeria is a country of hundreds of thousands of migrants and expatriates, and movement by its citizens is not in itself cause for concern or for state suspicion. Should the state have information on returning asylum seekers, especially those with no history of political opposition, Islamic affiliation, or criminal activities, some irritations, I should imagine (would) be expected. Asylum is not always about politics; it has economic motivations. This latter category does not necessarily invite state suspicion or retaliation. I see no problem with Algerian seekers of asylum, which more often than not are motivated by economic concerns, returning home without being retaliated against by the state.38
There is no evidence before the Board that the claimant has engaged in any political or criminal or terrorist activities in his ten years abroad that would raise concerns. His new allegation is no more credible than the rest.
Section 97
The Federal Court has ruled that negative credibility assessments that are determinative of claims to refugee protection under section 96 of the IRPA may not necessarily be determinative under the consolidated grounds in section 97. In this case, the Refugee Protection Division finds that the adverse credibility findings above are all relevant and determinative of the enumerated risks in respect of the alleged bases of the claim.
In particular, the claimant's alleged Christian conversion has been found not to be genuine - his baptism in Taiwan and his church attendance in Canada are a sham. If he were removed to Algeria, more likely than not he would discontinue the pretense of being a Christian and thus he would not be perceived as a Muslim apostate or a Christian. While the name, XXXXX XXXXX, was published in the Directory of the XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX Church of Vancouver in XXXXX 2003,39 there is no evidentiary basis to believe this association would come to the attention of people in Algeria who might be inclined to harm him. According to the country information, the Government follows a de facto policy of tolerance by not inquiring into the religious practices of individuals, and conversion is not illegal under civil law.40
Finally, as to the treatment of returned rejected asylum seekers, the most detailed documentary evidence is as follows:
Two country reports in 2001 stated that European countries returned hundreds of such persons to Algeria either under formal agreements or on a case by case basis. One stated that applying for asylum abroad is not regarded by the Algerian authorities as a political act. An Algerian has no need to fear persecution on return solely on the grounds of submitting any asylum application. Western countries do not regard the overall situation in Algeria as a reason not to deport rejected non-suited asylum seekers and other, inadmissible, persons to that country.
The other report stated that while none of the countries concerned appears to have carried out a formal study of what happens to 'deportees' they all believe they would have heard had persons who were returned to Algeria encountered serious difficulties. 'Deportees' sometimes contact the embassies concerned to sort out administrative matters relating to the time they spent in the country and none have ever complained of their treatment by Algerian authorities upon their return to Algeria. It could also be expected that relatives of 'deportees' would in some cases make it known if a person had suffered at the hands of the Algerian authorities but there has been no incident of this sort ever brought to the attention of the embassies concerned. The UNHCR office in Algiers and the Algerian Foreign Ministry both reported that persons returned to Algeria do not encounter problems.41
Exclusion Under Article 1 E of the Convention
According to the claimant's complete US INS record in evidence, he was informed in a letter dated XXXXX, 2000 of the intent to deny his asylum claim because he had not provided evidence of persecution in Taiwan, the country of last habitual residence where he had lived from XXXXX 1994 to XXXXX 1998, or proof that he was unable to return to Taiwan and had been denied citizenship on the basis of being an Algerian, or that he was getting a divorce from his wife. He was allowed to provide new rebuttal evidence within sixteen days. His attorney submitted rebuttal evidence and arguments in a letter dated XXXXX, 2000 and supplemental information on immigration and nationality law in Taiwan.
With that issue satisfied, the final decision by the US INS made a year later, on XXXXX, 2001 was to grant asylum status to XXXXX XXXXX. There is a notation to this effect on the first page of the Asylum Application form,42 and an undated letter on the file said to attach a completed I-94 Arrival Departure Record indicating he had been granted asylum as of XXXXX, 2001 for an indefinite period.43 A copy of an I-94 form stamped to this effect is also on the file.44
But the claimant alleges that by then he had already left the US to return to Taiwan, after he learned of the intent to deny his claim. He testified that the reason he left was that his work permit was going to expire at the end of XXXXX 2001 and he had not received a response to his application to renew it and in light of the intent to deny he thought it would not be renewed, in which case he did not want to live illegally in the US. Supposedly he was unaware of the process underway and thus did not know of the rebuttal that had been sent by his lawyer (nearly a year before), but rather took the notice of intent to deny his claim as final. He had asked his lawyer about his right to appeal but she was not hopeful and indicated she would do that on her own and he did not need to be there. The claimant's evidence is that several months after he went back to Taiwan he applied for a US visa to return, having in mind that he would pursue an appeal.
There is some corroborative evidence that XXXXX XXXXX left the US in late XXXXX 2001. A printout from the US INS computer system obtained and interpreted by the IRB Research Directorate indicates a departure date of XXXXX 2001 is listed there.45 In addition, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX at the visa office in Taipei had checked with her American counterparts and confirmed that XXXXX XXXXX had been granted a US visa and had left Taiwan and entered the US on XXXXX, 1998. He had overstayed his visa (which expired XXXXX, 1999) and only left on XXXXX, 2001 to return to Taiwan. On XXXXX, 2001 and again the following day he applied for another US visa but was refused both times because he had overstayed his previous visa. Information she obtained from the entry-exit bureau of Taiwan confirmed those dates.46
The problem for the claimant is that the acceptance letter from the US INS states that if he planned to depart the US he had to obtain permission to return before leaving. In that event he would be issued a Refugee Travel Document. If he did not obtain permission - and the claimant testified that he did not obtain such a document before he left - he could be unable to re-enter or be placed in proceedings where he would be required to establish his asylum status.
As well there is a section on, "Departing the U.S. before a Final Decision," in the Affirmative Asylum Procedures Manual, provided by the RPO.47 It contains detailed information on the elaborate due process afforded to applicants who were not in the US at the time of the asylum approval.
If it is determined that the applicant was not in the United States at the time of the asylum approval, INS lacked jurisdiction to approve asylum and the prior grant of asylum must be rescinded. However, the actions to take after rescission will depend on whether the applicant received advance parole or not, whether the applicant traveled back to the country of feared persecution, and whether the absence from the US affects the applicant's substantive claim.48
Counsel provided supplementary information from different sources after the hearing.49
However, the Refugee Protection Division finds there is contradictory evidence as to whether the claimant was in fact out of the country when his US asylum claim was finally approved and therefore that his status has been rescinded.
Firstly, the claimant lacked credibility as a witness concerning his motivation for leaving the US and his knowledge of the process underway in his asylum claim at the time and the protections he still enjoyed. In comparison to the importance of potentially receiving asylum status, he has not given a very compelling reason why he would have abandoned his asylum claim before receiving a final decision, to return to Taiwan (where allegedly he was the victim of racial discrimination). Moreover, he had only to ask his attorney to be assured that, work permit or not, he would not have been living illegally in the US provided his asylum claim and any subsequent appeal were still pending. His professed ignorance of the asylum process is at odds, for example, with his precise description of the format and directions for use of the entry and exit document issued by US INS upon arrival, apparently the I-94 form, and generally the way he has actively prosecuted his refugee claim in Canada. As Officer XXXXX XXXXX had observed at the port of entry, the claimant asked a lot of questions.
Furthermore, the US INS record reveals that he launched a divorce action in a Los Angeles court in early XXXXX 2000,50 which would appear to be aimed at addressing one of the deficiencies noted in the notice of intent to deny his claim dated XXXXX, 2000, and he also made a declaration that he had approached the Taiwan Information Agency in Los Angeles on XXXXX, 2000 and a supervisor reviewed his residence visa in the passport and told him that he could not return to Taiwan.51
The claimant's testimony also raised doubts as to his credibility because, despite the precision he evinced above on the Los Angeles airport exit procedures and his apparent acute awareness of the expiry date of his US work permit, he was unable to specify the exact date he supposedly left the US. In fact, he testified that he exited the US on XXXXX, 2001 but when the omission of this information in the PIF was drawn to his attention for comment, he said that he did not recall exactly the date but did recall being in Taiwan for his birthday on XXXXX, alone in the hotel. (For what it is worth, the claimant's putative birth date is XXXXX, 1963.)
He had stated in the PIF that he was not given any reason for the refusal of his apparent subsequent application in Taiwan for a Canadian visitor visa (CVV) at the end of XXXXX 2001. When asked about this, he was vague and evasive and demonstrated a lack of familiarity with the details of that application. Yet the visa officer's notes clearly indicate that the requirements were communicated to the applicant in person and he was told that failure to comply would mean refusal of the visa - out of four supporting documents that were necessary the applicant had supplied just two.52 Once the contents of the visa officer's notes were spelled out to him at the hearing, however, the claimant improvised explanations as to why it would not have been feasible for him to supply the missing documentation. Furthermore, the claimant testified that when he applied in Taiwan for a new US visa he said it was to return to pursue an appeal in his asylum claim, but the most detailed information available on the two visa applications contains no reference to any asylum claim in the US.
The evidence is that the applicant for the CVV was holding an Algerian passport in the name of XXXXX XXXXX. The claimant alleges that the US INS only made a copy of his passport and did not seize the original when he made the asylum application, and that he had traveled on it back to Taiwan. However, his dubious oral testimony raises the possibility that someone else was using this Algerian passport in Taiwan in XXXXX 2001 - which the claimant categorically denied - and perhaps the claimant himself did not leave the US on XXXXX, 2001.
Secondly, the US INS records that show this departure date of XXXXX, 2001 (or XXXXX, 2001 as rendered in Taiwan) make no reference to the fact that this same individual had made an asylum claim in the US. This is true of both the computer printout obtained by the IRB Research Directorate and the information provided by the American Trade Office in Taipei. The omission of this critical piece of information is most glaring in the latter case which records only that XXXXX XXXXX had overstayed his visa in the US.
Conversely, the complete US INS record for the asylum applicant XXXXX XXXXX contains no information about his putative departure on XXXXX, 2001 - despite his oral evidence that he supposedly traveled on the same Algerian passport that is copied in the US INS record and that when he left he showed officials, in addition, two US documents: the (then expired) work permit and the US INS entry and exit form - apparently a reference to the I-94 form - which he always carried from the time he entered the US. He said the officials removed a part of the form when he left. (As noted above, the claimant denied that he possessed a Refugee Travel Document giving him permission to leave.)
Only the US authorities can sort this out and determine objectively whether the claimant was or was not in the country when his asylum claim was approved on XXXXX, 2001. If they have already done so, they are not telling the Immigration and Refugee Board. After the sitting of the hearing on December 15, 2003, the Presiding Member directed the RPO to ask the IRB Research Directorate to contact the US Embassy in Ottawa and "request a definitive statement from the US authorities as to whether the grant of asylum to the claimant on XXXXX, 2001 is still valid and the claimant would be allowed to re-enter the country to enjoy the benefits of that status."53 Minister's counsel, without prior consultation with the RPO or Presiding Member, sent a parallel inquiry to the US Embassy, which took as established fact that the claimant had left the US on XXXXX, 2001. The Presiding Member asked her to withdraw the request because the way it was worded could compromise the probative value of the reply and separate inquiries could complicate and delay a response. Minister's counsel agreed to do this. However, the Americans have told the IRB Research Directorate that they will not provide the information to the IRB, because unlike CIC, the IRB does not have a formal agreement with the US regarding information sharing.54
At a minimum, a refugee claimant must be able to return to and remain in the putative Article 1E country before this provision can be invoked to exclude him from Convention refugee status. As the RPO puts it in her written submissions, in the absence of further evidence, it appears the United States should not be considered an Article 1E exclusion country in this case.
DETERMINATION
For all the reasons above, the Refugee Protection Division finds that the claimant has, without a reasonable explanation, failed to provide sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence to establish his personal identity or the fact that he is a national of Algeria and only Algeria. In the alternative, the Refugee Protection Division finds he has failed to provide sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence to prove that he has undergone a religious conversion from Islam to Christianity and thus would be subjected to a serious possibility of harm in Algeria by that reason, or on any other alleged bases of his claim to refugee protection. The Refugee Protection Division finds there is not a serious possibility that the claimant would face persecution for any of the enumerated grounds under section 96. Nor is there a serious possibility that removal to Algeria would subject him personally to the dangers and risks set out in the consolidated grounds under section 97.
While XXXXX XXXXX, a citizen of Algeria, was granted asylum status in the US on XXXXX, 2001, there is insufficient evidence to allow the Refugee Protection Division to determine - even assuming the claimant is this individual - whether he was present in the US at the time and has the right to return to and remain in the US.
Accordingly, the Refugee Protection Division determines that XXXXX XXXXX is not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection.
