On January 30, 2004, the Refugee Protection Division (Refugee Division) heard the claim of XXXXXXXXXXXX for refugee protection. On that same day, the panel rendered its oral decision and reasons. This is the written version of that oral decision and reasons.
ORAL DECISION AND REASONS
I have had an opportunity to consider all the evidence in this claim by XXXXX XXXXXXXX XXXXXXXX for refugee protection and I am now prepared to render a decision. This claim is being heard under the provisions of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (Act)1 to determine firstly, under section 96, if the claimant is a Convention refugee or secondly, under section 97(1), if he is a person in need of protection.
At the conclusion of these reasons and once they have been transcribed into writing, the written version will be sent to the claimant, to his counsel and to counsel for the Minister. Those written reasons may be edited for grammar, syntax, spelling, punctuation and general readability. They may also include references to applicable statutes and case law.
In coming to this decision, I have considered all of the evidence: the claimant's Personal Information Form (PIF),2 his oral testimony, the materials from Canada Immigration, the materials filed by his counsel, the materials filed by the Refugee Protection Officer (RPO), the materials filed by the Minister's counsel, along with the oral submissions of both counsels.
The Minister appeared on the basis that they had reasonable grounds to believe that the claimant was excluded under Article 1F(a) of the Schedule of the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees.3 In this regard, the Minister has the onus in regard to exclusion. The claimant has the onus under inclusion to provide sufficient credible or trustworthy evidence to find there is a "serious possibility"4 for considering that he has a well-founded fear of persecution for a Convention reason or is a person in need of protection. The
Minister's onus is to establish sufficient evidence to find there are:
... serious reasons for considering that: (a) he [the claimant] has committed a crime against peace, a war crime, or a crime against humanity, as defined in the international instruments drawn up to make provision in respect of such crimes.5
In considering this claim, I am now going to tell the claimant what conclusions I have reached and then I will explain why I have done so. Firstly, I have determined that the claimant is not excluded from consideration for protection. However, I have also concluded that the claimant is not a Convention refugee nor is he a person in need of protection. I am now going to explain why I have come to those decisions.
There were a number of relevant issues in this claim. The issue of credibility applies to both the inclusion and exclusion aspects. While testimony that is given under oath is presumed6 to be true, there may be valid reason to doubt its' truthfulness. In my view, there were more than sufficient grounds to find that regarding this claim, a significant portion of the claimant's evidence was not credible or trustworthy. There were numerous inconsistencies, omissions, implausibilities and contradictions in the claimant's evidence. Overall, as to much of the claimant's evidence, I found it lacked "rationality and common sense".7
The Minister's representative filed a large amount of documentary evidence8 to allege that the claimant was active during the 1980s in the DGSE (Directorate General of State Security), which committed gross human rights abuses. The claimant was an enlisted member of the DGSE during that time. As I said earlier, the burden of proof to establish "serious reasons for considering" that international offences have been committed is the responsibility of the Minister's counsel.
Let me say that the claimant came to Canada with a valid Nicaraguan passport9 and I accept that he is a citizen of Nicaragua and of no other country.
In dealing with exclusion, the Minister's counsel intervened some time ago on the basis that the claimant's activities with the DGSE meant that he was excluded from consideration. During this hearing, Minister's counsel also raised for the first time that the claimant's activities in support of the FUAC, the Andres Castro United Front, also provided grounds for excluding him. In my view, the Minister is bound by the basis on which they have intervened. It is not sufficient, in the course of a hearing, to raise new grounds and then suggest that exclusion may apply to those grounds.
In the case of Moreno,10 the Federal Court of Appeal set out the standard of proof as follows:
... one well below that required by either the criminal law ("beyond a reasonable doubt") or the civil law ("on a balance of probabilities" or "preponderance of evidence").
In another decision,11 the Federal Court of Appeal stated that both of these standards:
... require something more than suspicion or conjecture, but something less than the balance of probabilities.
Now, much of the claimant's evidence was evasive, unresponsive and unclear about his activities as a member of the DGSE. The claimant today provided two documents12 from the government of Nicaragua, issued in the XXXXX of 2002, which simply provided confirmation that he worked at that organization in the 1980s, specifically from XXXXX 1981 XXXXX, 1989 "in the position of XXXXX. under the Department General of State Security.
However, in my view, the claimant (and the credibility aspect played importantly into this) failto provide a consistent statement as to what his activities were in the DGSE. His version varied from his interview with Canada Immigration, to his PIF and to his testimony. Because there were so many examples, I am only going to provide some of the concerns that I had.
First of all, the claimant (in his PIF and in his interview with Canada Immigration) provided different dates as to when he was in the DGSE. Surely he could remember exactly what year he joined and for how long he served. Initially, in his interview and PIF, he said that as early as 1987, he was no longer working there. First of all, I found that seriously damaged his credibility.
As well, his duties in this organization, his training there, and what happened in that organization were equally lacking in credibility. For example, in his interview with Canada Immigration, he said he was sent two times in the mountains to fight, in 1982 and 1984. He said that there were two or three times in which there was an exchange of gunfire between themselves and the Contras.
In his Schedule 1, Background Information13 document that he completed for Canada Immigration, he said the following: "During the war, I was involved in combat situations on numerous occasions throughout Nicaragua." [emphasis added] In his PIF, there was no mention that he was ever engaged in combat. In his oral testimony, he said he was sent out once, but he was never involved in combat.
In answer to many of these concerns, the claimant would say either that he could not recall or he would change his testimony. For example, today and for the very first time, the claimant alleged that he had twice been convicted of insubordination while he worked for the DGSE. No such information was provided in his interview with Canada Immigration. He only amended his PIF today to allege that it had occurred. Why was that not mentioned previously? In my view, the claimant was attempting to evade allegations that he was involved in any human rights abuses or other activities once the Minister had raised intervention. This was an attempt by him to show that he was actually on the outs with the leadership of the DGSE. In fact, he went so far today as to say that he was even considered a dissident from 1986, when he told his superior that he did not agree with him. Again, this information was never previously provided.
What were the claimant's duties while he was in the DGSE? Was he involved in military training? Was he in the military or not? He gave inconsistent and contradictory evidence in various forums. Today, for example, he said that he was given a pistol but all he was taught to do was to assemble and disassemble it. However, in his earlier interview with Canada Immigration, he said he was trained to use weapons and he gave (as examples) the names of rifles and machine guns, such as Galil, FAL, M16s, AK47s.
I just found all of the claimant's evidence to be completely evasive concerning his involvement with DGSE, in my view. He alleged that he had been twice charged with insubordination and spent two months in jail, a month on each occasion, in 1985 and 1986. He said he was demoted from the Chief of XXXXX to be simply a XXXXX XXXXX and he was considered to be a dissident. Because this was never mentioned before, I found it completely lacked credibility.
When I look at the Minister's documents, there were a lot of documents about the DGSE. However, one factor I noted was that vast majority of those documents were either issued by the United States government or by its subsidiary institutions or by persons supportive of the United States government during the 1980s and even into the 1990s. The documentary materials tell us very clearly that the United States government, from the very earliest part of the 1980s, had an ongoing campaign to overthrow the Sandinista government of Nicaragua. Those documents that emanate from the United States government (or similar other sources) are not impartial documents. They emanate from a body that has an interest in the outcome of the proceedings. In my view, the materials prepared by or on behalf of the United States government or by its supporters in the United States have little or no credibility as a basis for me to consider their contents as worthy of serious consideration. They are not independent and they are not impartial.
There are a few materials from independent and impartial sources, such as Americas Watch and Amnesty International among others. Those documents give a considerably different view than the documents produced by the United States authorities.
In my view, contrary to what the United States government was attempting to portray, I consider that the documents clearly show that right up to the present day, institutions of the United States government are still attempting to interfere in Nicaraguan affairs. They have an ongoing campaign to ensure that the Sandinistas do not even return to power in a democratic way. Some of the documents even relate the U.S. Government's attempts to influence the last elections held in Nicaragua. More importantly, in their actions during the 1980s and early 1990s, the U.S. government et. al. were consistently attempting to portray the Sandinistas, both as the government of Nicaragua and associated bodies, in the worse possible light.
There was a civil conflict in Nicaragua. One side was supported by the United States, both militarily and financially. There were abuses that were committed on both sides in that conflict. However, from the materials (and looking particularly at the materials from Americas Watch and Amnesty International), I do not find that the DGSE was a body that was principally directed to a "limited brutal purpose."14 It would be illogical for me to suggest that a state is not entitled to have security forces to obtain intelligence and assist the state (and other institutions of the state) to repel an invasion or to stop other armed forces attempting to overthrow the government of that state.
At most, what the documents indicate is that the DGSE was an organization (and I might say its successor organization does still exist) "which from time to time has committed international offences."15 It would be difficult, during a time of war, to suggest that there are not abuses that are committed. In my view, the evidence is lacking that the DGSE was an organization with such a "limited, brutal purpose". In my view, the claimant's employment in that organization certainly does not indicate that he was involved in activities that might equate to crimes envisaged by Article 1F(a).
In my view, the claimant was so lacking in credibility that it was impossible for me to conclude what he was doing there and what his activities were in the DGSE. It was not clear whether he was or was not involved in activities that might even have assisted some human rights abuses. However, on the evidence before me, I certainly do not find that the claimant's membership in the DGSE or the evidence on the DGSE itself would lead me to conclude that the claimant should be excluded from consideration for protection.
I note as well that the claimant subsequently obtained visas from the United States government and travelled to the United States on several occasions in the 1990s. Surely, if the United States government did not consider that the claimant's past activities (and I am certain that they would be well aware of his past activities on behalf of the DGSE) to be such that they would bar him from entering the United States, that is a further indication for me to not find the claimant was excluded from consideration.
Accordingly, I find that the Minister has not met the onus to provide sufficient evidence for me to conclude that this claimant was excluded from consideration for protection under sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
However, after having said that I do not find the claimant's evidence to be credible as far as his activities in the 1980s are concerned, I will go further and say that the lack of credibility followed the claimant's evidence thereafter. For example, the claimant said today that he had attended university in 1983 and 1984, but that was not mentioned in his PIF. In fact, in his PIF, he indicated that he did not attend university until 1988. The claimant's evidence also lacked credibility because his activities were unclear after he left the DGSE. He said that in 1991, two persons that he knew from the DGSE came to him and forced him to pay money to them on behalf of the FUAC, the Andres Castro United Front. The FUAC can be seen from the documents as an organization that had a rather spotty existence during the 1990s. It was composed of former Sandinista supporters or members of the military. As a group, they were subsequently seriously affected by the state security forces, which undertook actions to defeat them and appear to have done so.
However, the claimant's evidence about his involvement with the FUAC was equally unsatisfactory. The claimant initially testified that he paid the FUAC two to three hundred dollars twice a month on a salary of one thousand dollars a month. I pointed out to him that in his interview with Canada Immigration, he said then that he paid them three to four hundred dollars per month on a salary of three to four thousand dollars. The claimant then became evasive and testified that he did not make a thousand dollars a month as that was actually his base salary. He said that he made much more than that and also said that he paid the FUAC two to three hundred dollars a month. He was not even consistent about that evidence.
In any event, the claimant said that he paid the money, from approximately 1991 until the XXXXX of 1999, because these individuals (or the FUAC) would have killed him and his family if he had not paid. I found it completely implausible that these individuals, allegedly the leaders of the FUAC, would come to the airport in Managua twice a month for some eight years to collect money from him. I find it even more implausible that the claimant was out of Nicaragua on numerous occasions during those years, but at no time did he attempt to make a refugee claim until he notified Canada Immigration (in the XXXXX part of 2002) that he wished to do so. This also raised concerns with the claimant's evidence because, in his PIF (question 21), he was asked to state what trips he had taken in the last ten years, including any previous trips to Canada. I pointed out to him that in his PIF, he had not mentioned his trip to Canada in 2000, when he was here for some six months.
The claimant was in the United States on a number of occasions as well during those times, both with and without his family. In my view, based upon the threats to kill him and his family, it was completely implausible that he would then continually return to Nicaragua, on at least one occasion with his family and by himself on a number of occasions. In my view, all of this evidence is not credible or trustworthy and I put no reliance upon it.
The question of state protection was also brought up. The claimant made no mention in his PIF, or in his interview with Canada Immigration, that he had ever approached the Nicaraguan authorities at any level to seek protection from the FUAC. However, the claimant testified today that from 1996 to 1998, and again in 2000, he went to the police on about seven occasions. In fact, he said that he went repeatedly to the chief of police in Managua to seek assistance. He said the police did not help him. They simply told him to move or said that they were afraid to take action against the FUAC because it was too dangerous for them to do so.
His PIF (question 41) required him to set out if he had sought protection and if not, why not. The omission of that information was another damaging aspect against the claimant's credibility. I find it implausible and inconceivable that the claimant, after he had finished his job at the XXXXX and had told these individuals he could not pay them any more, would come to Canada in 2000, stay here for some six months, and would then return again to Nicaragua. In fact, the claimant had initially mentioned in his PIF that he continued to work at the XXXXX until 2001 and gave no other employer after that date. His PIF was then amended to say that he had finished his work with the XXXXX earlier and had then worked in a laboratory. However, I could not conceive of why he would return to Nicaragua if he had already told these people he could no longer pay them and they had threatened to kill him and his family.
The claimant returned again to Canada in XXXXX 2001. Although he alleged that he had left Nicaragua in fear (according to his PIF), he did not make a refugee claim. His excuse for not doing so was that he was arrested and charged with soliciting for the purpose of prostitution in Vancouver in the XXXXX of 2001. (Surprisingly, that information was not mentioned in his PIF when he later filled it out.) It was not until some 15 months after had returned to Canada that he first notified Immigration he wished to make a refugee claim.
The numerous times that the claimant returned to Nicaragua, his failure to make a claim when he was here in 2000, and the delay in making a claim after he returned here (from XXXXX 2001 until the XXXXX part of 2002) are all indicative of a lack of subjective fear. In my view, he did not provide a satisfactory explanation for any of these instances in which he failed to seek protection when he had the opportunity to do so. In my view, they seriously damaged the credibility of his allegations that he was ever threatened by the FUAC. In addition, I find it inconceivable that the claimant would have left his family alone in Nicaragua after they also had been threatened to be killed if he did not pay the money to the FUAC.
I noted further that the claimant did not mention in his PIF that he was in hiding before he left Nicaragua. However, according to his interview with Canada Immigration, since he stopped paying the FUAC in XXXXX 2002, he said then that he was in hiding and lived with different members of his wife's family. However, when I asked the claimant if he was living at his house before he came to Canada on the last occasion, he said he was. So, was he living in hiding (he did not mention that he was living in hiding in his PIF) or was he living at home and came to Canada for other than protection reasons? Was that why no claim was made? Did an intervening criminal charged delay him making a claim until he finally did so in the XXXXX part of 2002?
Overall, there was a complete lack of credible or trustworthy evidence to find that this claimant had any problems of any kind in Nicaragua. In my view, he left Nicaragua and came to Canada for reasons unrelated to any of the protection grounds set out in the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, whether in section 96 or in section 97.
As I say, those are just some of the concerns that I had with the claimant's evidence. Let me just give a couple more concerns. According to what the claimant told Canada Immigration about part of his duties in the DGSE, he said: "I just watched houses abandoned by the XXXXX family. We watched houses so people would not enter." That information was never mentioned in his PIF or in his testimony. The claimant also said that he had not resigned earlier (or asked for a discharge) from the DGSE. In his testimony, he said that Lenin Cerna, the head of the DGSE, had told them in a meeting that anyone who asked for a discharge would be "disappeared". Asked what the claimant meant by disappeared, he said "assassinated". That allegation was never mentioned in his PIF or in his interview with Canada Immigration. Again, I found those allegations to be completely lacking in credibility because they were never mentioned previously.
In my view, the lack of credible or trustworthy evidence leads me to conclude that there was no credible or trustworthy evidence to find that this claimant was either a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection. There was no Convention ground that I can find to be applicable in his case because of the lack of credible or trustworthy evidence.
I am aware that a negative credibility determination under section 96 (having determined the claimant is not a Convention refugee) is not identical in dealing with section 97. The elements necessary to establish a claim under section 97(1) are not identical to those necessary to establish whether a person is a Convention refugee under section 96.16 However, in the case at hand, when I have considered the negative credibility determination, along with all of the evidence, personal and documentary, I found there was no foundation for establishing any personal "risk" for this claimant under section 97(1) of the Act.
In conclusion, let me say the following: I have determined that the Minister has not established sufficient evidence to find that the claimant was excluded from consideration under Article 1F(a). I have also determined that the claimant is not a Convention refugee and is not a person in need of protection.
However, in my view, the lack of credible or trustworthy evidence leads me to conclude that there was no independent or credible evidence, documentary or otherwise, that would support a positive determination of this claim for refugee protection. Accordingly, I find there is "no credible basis"17 to this claim.
In conclusion, I determine that the claim for refugee protection of XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX is rejected.
This concludes my decision and the reasons for it.

XXXXXXXXXXXXX is a 30-year-old citizen of Iraq who claims to be a Convention refugee and a person in need of protection because of his perceived association with the United States (US), due to both his long-term residence in that country and the assistance two of his brothers, American citizens, have given to the US military forces during the occupation of Iraq. The claimant also participated in the Shia uprising fostered by the US in the wake of its victory in the 1991 Gulf War. He has a lengthy criminal record in the United States, where there is an outstanding warrant for his arrest.
SUMMARY OF ALLEGATIONS
According to the claimant's Personal Information Form (PIF)1 as amended at the hearing, he is a Shia Muslim, who was born and lived in the town of Hilla. He has just five years of formal education having helped his father sell XXXXXX in the market from the time he was around ten years of age. His father still resides in Hilla with his other family.
In XXXXX 1991, at sixteen years of age, the claimant fought in the Shia uprising that was quickly crushed by Saddam Hussein's troops. His father was imprisoned but the claimant, his mother and four siblings fled to the American-controlled area in the south. From there they were relocated to the United Nations refugee camp in XXXXX, Saudi Arabia, where they lived for three and a half years. In XXXXX 1994 the family was resettled in the US.
The claimant became a permanent resident of the US in 1996 but owing to criminal convictions his green card was taken away and he was not allowed to apply for citizenship. His mother, three brothers and a sister are all American citizens.
In his answer to question 37 of the PIF, the claimant lists nine prior convictions in the state of Washington. He says that he was ordered deported from the US in 2000 but because of the danger in Iraq he was given a "Withholding of Removal." Then in XXXX 2002, the US Immigration and Naturalization Service sought to reopen the ruling on the basis of his new criminal convictions. According to the narrative statement in the PIF, his fear of being returned to Iraq was the reason he came to Canada on February 5, 2003. At the hearing he denied that was a fugitive from justice.
At the time the claimant completed his PIF, the Saddam Hussein regime was still in power in Iraq and his claim was based on the fact he is a Shia Muslim who participated in the 1991 uprising. He stated that his father had been released from prison but the government continued to persecute him.
At the hearing held after the Saddam Hussein regime had been overthrown, the claimant asserted that his participation in the 1991 Shia uprising in Hilla continues to be a reason he would be at risk in Iraq. Speaking for him on this point in her submissions, counsel for the claimant argues that the former dictator's loyalists and former members of the Ba'ath Party remain a force and the rival Sunni Muslims are now a disaffected and hostile minority of the population.
He also claims a new sur place basis due to the fact that two of his brothers, XXXXX and XXXXXX, have returned to Iraq to assist the US military forces as Arabic interpreters and there is great resentment toward this occupation and the Americans generally. This family association and his long-term residency in the US are factors that would make it dangerous for him to go back. He testified that his older brother XXXXXX had recently visited their father in Hilla, and afterward his father was told that if his son came again he would be killed.
The claimant's evidence is that the residents of Hilla would identify him with the Americans because they know the details of his family's history and association with the US, yet Hilla is the only place where he could live given the social structure in Iraq.
ISSUES
The following issues were identified: personal identity, including religion as a Shia Muslim; credibility; objective basis and change of circumstances, and related compelling reasons; Internal Flight Alternative (IFA); previous claim elsewhere (US grant of refugee status in XXXXX 1994 and the defensive asylum claim to stay removal in XXXXX 2000);2 generalized risk under the Risk to Life ground in section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA);3 and possible exclusion under Article 1E (permanent residency in the US) and under Article 1F(b) for serious non-political crimes, specifically burglary in the 2nd degree which the claimant is accused of having committed on XXXXX, 2003, in the state of Washington.
ANALYSIS
Personal Identity / Shia Muslim
The claimant provided the original and a translation of his Personal Identity Card issued in Iraq in 19904 and documents proving that he and other members of his family were accepted as refugees and resettled in the US.5 With the claimant's consent, the Research Directorate of the IRB obtained his electronic record from the Bureau of Citizenship and Immigration Services in Washington.6 Earlier, when the claimant was arrested by the RCMP soon after his arrival in Canada in February 2003 and finally revealed his true identity, Canadian Immigration officials conducted background checks with their US counterparts and found that he had an extensive file. All of this evidence corroborates the claimant's personal identity.
He states in the PIF that he is a Shia Muslim and at the hearing he satisfactorily answered questions about his religion.
The Refugee Protection Division finds that the claimant has satisfied the issues related to personal identity.
Beyond these essential findings of fact, the Refugee Protection Division has not assessed the claimant's inclusion claim for refugee protection since it is not necessary for a determination of his claim to refugee protection. Even if he were found to be a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection under the consolidated grounds, the analysis below shows that he is excluded from enjoying Canada's protection under Article 1F (b) of the UN Convention relating to the Status of Refugees7 and is not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection pursuant to section 98 of the IRPA.
Exclusion Under Article 1E
Minister's counsel conceded at the final sitting of the hearing that he has no information from the US that the claimant would be allowed to go back to face charges. The claimant testified credibly that he lost his permanent resident status in the US and the judge told him that if he left the US he would not be able to return. He failed to attend the last proceedings in the US on XXXXX, 2003 and the judge found that as a result he had abandoned any and all claims for relief from removal.8 In light of this, at the conclusion of the oral examination at his refugee hearing in Canada, the Refugee Protection Division removed this exclusion issue and indicated that the parties need not address it in written submissions. The Refugee Protection Division is satisfied that the claimant no longer has the right to return to and remain in the US, which at a minimum, would have to be established before the claimant could be excluded under Article 1E. He has lost permanent resident status in that country as a result of his criminal behaviour.
Exclusion Under Article 1(F) (b) For A Serious Non-Political Crime
The police in Washington State initially accused the claimant of committing the offences of burglary in the 1st degree and possession of stolen property (computer equipment) in the 2nd degree on or about XXXXX, 2003.9 For reasons that are not clear from the US documents, the Prosecuting Attorney ultimately charged him with the crime of burglary in the 2nd degree, that he entered and remained unlawfully in the (XXXXX Clinic) building with intent to commit a crime against a person or property therein.10 On XXXXX, 2003, a judge in the Superior Court of Washington for King County found that "probable cause exists to believe" that XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX committed this offence and ordered that a warrant be issued for his arrest.11
Are there "serious reasons for considering" that the claimant committed this crime?
When the claimant was confronted at the hearing with the detailed information in the police report of the XXXXX, 2003 incident from Washington State, he denied any involvement. He suggested that the police probably got his name off the computer from his previous convictions, rather than reading his name on a Washington State identity card and the vehicle registration as they had stated. He also denied having previously committed a burglary in 2002 for which he was convicted and suggested that he was falsely accused because he had associated with the wrong people and was charged along with them. He denied having made a confession to police for one of his crimes, which appears in evidence,12 and explained he had pleaded guilty on his attorney's advice even though he had done nothing wrong. He did acknowledge that the list of all his earlier criminal convictions included in the US court documents is correct,13 despite the fact that it is rather more extensive than his own list in the PIF.
The claimant was evasive in his answers on the exclusion issue and generally avoided taking responsibility for any wrongdoing in the US. He was also very suggestible, for example when Minister's counsel led him to subscribe to the notion that there was a conspiracy against him by the US authorities.
This demeanour is fully consistent with the claimant's surreptitious entry into Canada and his dishonesty at the time he was intercepted by the RCMP about his identity, and when and how he had arrived in this country, and even his fluency in English.14 The Refugee Protection Division finds that the claimant is not a credible witness concerning his criminal activities, and his denial of any involvement in the offence in question on XXXXX, 2003 in Washington state deserves little weight.
In her written submissions counsel for the claimant has asserted that this is a case of mistaken identity because the Certificate of Probable Cause says the man found at the scene was an "East Indian male," while Mr. XXXXX XXXXX is not an East Indian male, nor does he appear as such. The Refugee Protection Division finds that the police officer's description of the claimant's race/ nationality was subjective and it is not material in light of the positive identification of the claimant by name, based upon examination of his Washington State driver's licence and his motor vehicle registration at the scene.
By contrast to the claimant's evidence, the Refugee Protection Division gives full weight to the police and court documents provided by the Washington State authorities. Counsel for the claimant argues that the officer who laid the charge was not available for cross-examination but, with due respect, it was open to her to ask Minister's counsel to produce this witness. The Refugee Protection Division is not aware of such a request.
Judicial interpretation of "serious reasons for considering" has established the standard of proof at less than a balance of probabilities,15 but more than suspicion or conjecture.16
The Refugee Protection Division finds on the preponderance of credible evidence that indeed there are serious reasons for considering that the claimant did commit the crime of burglary in the 2nd degree on XXXXX, 2003, in the US, for which there is an outstanding charge against him.
Is this offence a serious non-political crime?
The Federal Court has also ruled that Article 1F (b) is not applicable to refugee claimants who have been convicted of a crime committed outside Canada and who have served their sentences prior to coming to Canada.17 There is no issue here that the claimant still has charges pending in the US for anything other than the most recent offence on XXXXX, 2003.
Counsel for the claimant argues that the offence of burglary in the 2nd degree is not sufficiently serious as to exclude the claimant because it was essentially a crime of property, and no weapons were used and no violence was perpetrated against any person. She finds support in Brzezinski18 in which the Federal Court Trial Division ruled that the minor crime of shoplifting in the conventional sense or "theft under" pursuant to section 334 of the Criminal Code, even when committed repeatedly, is not "serious crime" within the meaning of Article 1F (b).
She draws upon the quotation from The Refugee in International Law by Goodwin- Gill considered by Judge Lufty in the Brzezinski decision:
With a view to promoting consistent decisions, UNHCR proposed that in the absence of any political factors, a presumption of serious crime might be considered as raised by evidence of the commission of any of the following offences: homicide, rape, child molesting, wounding, arson, drugs trafficking, and armed robbery. ...However, that presumption should be capable of rebuttal by evidence of mitigating factors, some of which are set out below: The following offences might also be considered to constitute serious crimes, provided other factors are present: breaking and entering (burglary); stealing (theft and simply robbery); receiving stolen property; embezzlement; possession of drugs in quantities exceeding that required for personal use; and assault. Factors to support a finding of seriousness included: use of weapons, injury to person; value of property involved; type of drugs involved; evidence of habitual criminal conduct.19
In addition to the fact that the claimant is not alleged to have used weapons or physical violence in committing the offence, counsel for the claimant speculates (without adducing evidence to this effect) that the value of the computer equipment he is suspected of stealing (a computer mainframe, keyboard, power cords and a small stereo) was probably insubstantial. While the claimant has a long criminal record, she argues that the lack of seriousness of his crimes is evidenced by the fact that he has never served sentences of more than two years for any of them.
On the first point made by counsel for the claimant, the Refugee Protection Division notes that the Federal Court decision in Xie20 has thoroughly canvassed the question of whether purely economic crime falls within Article 1F (b) and ruled that as a matter of principle it does - and this is not at odds with Brzezinski.
As to the value of the goods stolen, the Refugee Protection Division finds that computer equipment in the claimant's situation is distinguishable from the items shoplifted by the applicants in Brzezinski, which included, for example, a dress and a chocolate cake.
Judging by their respective written submissions, there is no dispute between the parties that an individual's criminal record should be a factor in the assessment of the seriousness of the crime. This is also consistent with respected academic opinion and the UNHCR Handbook.21
The claimant has an extensive criminal record which at last count showed he had been booked 11 times since 1995 when he arrived in the US and had 26 warrants.22 In addition to two prior convictions for burglary in the 2nd degree (in 1999 and 2002) and related convictions for possession of stolen property, his record includes other types of crimes such as those related to threatening behaviour (stalking, harassment, and driving with a loaded gun in his vehicle). He was considered a threat to community safety and unlikely to appear for proceedings. Accordingly, in XXXXX 2003 bail for the claimant (in the event of his arrest) was set at $30,000. The Refugee Protection Division finds that the claimant's criminal record in the US is further evidence that this offence is a serious crime and that he is a habitual criminal.
Finally, the Refugee Protection Division takes the view that the proper measure of seriousness is the maximum allowable sentence for the offence in question, not the actual length of the sentences pronounced in the past, as counsel for the claimant suggests.
The Federal Court of Appeal in Chan23 presumed without deciding that a serious non-political crime equates with one in which a maximum sentence of ten years or more could have been imposed had the crime been committed in Canada. Later in Xie, Judge Kelen finds this to be a sensible approach and consistent with the definition of "serious criminality" in subsection 36(1) of the IRPA dealing with inadmissibility.
This provision demonstrates Parliament's desire to exclude from Canada individuals who have committed crimes punishable in Canada by a maximum term of imprisonment of at least 10 years, even if the offence in question is a purely economic one. 24
This parallel is particularly noteworthy because in the instant case Minister's counsel states in his written submissions that shortly after the claimant's arrival in Canada he was brought before the Immigration Division for a hearing on admissibility under this provision of the IRPA,25 and the Immigration Division found him inadmissible and issued him a conditional deportation order for serious criminality.
Counsel for the claimant argues that the fact he was still allowed to make a refugee claim under section 101(2)(a) of the IRPA is prima facie reason that he should not be excluded under Article 1F(b). With due respect to counsel, the paragraph that deals with eligibility where there is a criminal conviction outside Canada is section 101(2)(b) not (a), and it states that a claim is not ineligible by reasons of serious criminality unless the Minister is also of the opinion that the claimant is a danger to the public in Canada. While the decision of the Immigration Division is not in evidence, presumably the claim was considered eligible despite serious criminality, because the claimant was not considered a danger to the public. This does not detract from the finding of inadmissibility due to serious criminality under section 36(1) of the IRPA. There is nothing in IRPA to suggest that the Refugee Protection Division loses jurisdiction over exclusion issues if a claimant is found eligible to make a claim.
According to the documentary evidence provided by Minister's counsel drawn from the US statute under which the claimant was accused,26 and an excerpt from the Criminal Code of Canada,27 the Washington State offence of burglary in the 2nd degree equates to Section 348(1)(a), with the penalty covered at 348(1)(e). In both countries the crime of breaking and entry in a non-dwelling house with intent to commit an indictable offence carries a maximum penalty of ten years.
Considering all of this evidence and argument, the Refugee Protection Division finds that the criminal offence for which the claimant was charged in the US on XXXXX, 2003, which is still outstanding against him, is a serious non-political crime within the definition of Article 1F(b).
Should the nature of the offence be balanced against the degree of persecution or risk of harm established in the inclusion claim?
Counsel for the claimant quotes the UNHCR Handbook at paragraph 157 that suggests in applying the exclusion clauses it is necessary to "strike balance between the nature of the offence presumed to have been committed by the applicant and the degree of persecution feared." She argues that the Refugee Protection Division must weigh the exclusion evidence against the well-foundedness of the inclusion claim and find that the claimant's relatively minor criminal offence is outweighed by the grave risk he would face upon return to Iraq.
The Federal Court of Appeal has considered and rejected this notion of balancing the seriousness of the persecution the claimant is likely to suffer against the gravity of the crime there are serious reasons to consider that he has committed.28
In Xie,29 the balancing argument is revisited in light of new Supreme Court jurisprudence in the cases of Pushpanathan30 and Suresh.31 Judge Kelen makes a distinction between decisions affecting a claimant's entry to Canada as a Convention refugee or person in need of protection and those that concern a rejected claimant's removal from Canada to a country where there may be a risk of torture. He concludes that the balancing process needed to satisfy section 7 of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms properly belongs under the Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (PRRA) provisions of the IRPA.32
Most recently, the Federal Court of Appeal in answering the questions certified by Judge Kelen in Xie has upheld that analysis, consistent with the prior jurisprudence on the issue of balancing, in light of the division of authority between the Refugee Protection Division and the Minister under the IRPA.33 The Court points out that claimants who are excluded from refugee protection under section 98 of the IRPA (by the Refugee Protection Division) can still apply to the Minister for protection, at the pre-removal stage. The grounds are the same, although the Minister has additional discretion to assess the dangers to Canada as well as to the failed refugee claimant, and a successful application would result only in a stay of the deportation order, not access to permanent resident status. However, the Court makes it very clear that once the Refugee Protection Division has excluded a claimant from refugee protection, the jurisdiction shifts to the Minister. The Refugee Protection Division simply does not have the authority to balance the nature of the offence that forms the basis for exclusion and the risks associated with removal from Canada.
In the particular circumstances of Mr. XXXXX claim, the Refugee Protection Division also considers that such a weighing would be more meaningful if it is deferred until that later stage in his removal processing because the governance of Iraq is at a turning point and this affects even the definition of state authority and the identification of state agents for the purposes of evaluating the possibility of harm and the protection available. The Refugee Protection Division takes judicial notice that as this decision is being rendered the US occupying force has just returned partial sovereignty to the interim government of Iraq - a limited transfer of power from the civilian authority appointed by the US following the military victory that overthrew the Saddam Hussein regime. The interim government is scheduled to remain in place for seven months until elections are held. Meanwhile, the Americans retain responsibility for security. The way in which the new Iraqi government exercises its control and the way the Iraqi people ultimately perceive the US military forces will both be critical factors in assessing the risks the claimant may face upon removal from Canada.
The bases for the inclusion claim and the exclusion claim in this case are entirely separate. Thus, while the full conditions the claimant would return to in Iraq are presently unclear, what is clear is that he is excluded from refugee protection in Canada under Article 1F (b) because there are serious reasons for considering that he committed a serious non-political crime in the US.
DETERMINATION
For all the reasons above, the Refugee Protection Division finds there are serious reasons for considering that the claimant has committed a serious non-political crime, burglary in the 2nd degree, outside Canada. Accordingly, the Refugee Protection Division determines that XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX is excluded from refugee protection under Article 1F(b) of the UN Convention and section 98 of the IRPA.

These are the reasons of the Refugee Protection Division in the Application, made by the Minister pursuant to section 108 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, to declare that XXXXXXXXXXXXX (the Respondent) has ceased to be a Convention refugee, and/or a person in need in protection, pursuant to section 108 of the Act. The Respondent was determined to be a Convention refugee on February 10, 1994.
ALLEGATIONS
On September 4, 2002, the Minister (Applicant) filed an Application pursuant to section 108(1)(a) of the Act, setting out the grounds for the Application. The Applicant alleges inter alia that the Respondent had now ceased to be a Convention refugee and/or a person in need of protection, because he (a) has voluntarily re-availed himself of the protection of authorities in Russia; (d) has voluntarily become re-established in Russia, a country he left, or remained outside of and in respect of which he claimed refugee protection in Canada; and/or (e) that the reasons for which he sought refugee protection have ceased to exist.
After hearing the evidence of the Respondent, the Applicant withdrew the allegations in respect of subsection (e). This analysis will deal only with a determination pursuant to sections 108(1)(a) and (b), therefore.
According to the Statutory Declaration XXXXXXXXXXX, Immigration Officer with the Immigration Enforcement Office in Vancouver, pursuant to section 108(1)(a), the Respondent voluntarily re-availed himself of the protection of his country of nationality by returning to Russia sometime during 1994, for a period of five years.1 Mr XXXXX also declares that the Respondent admitted to having travelled to Russia on his own Russian passport. Also filed is an Affidavit of XXXXXXXXXX,2 which sets out the allegations. She alleges that she has reviewed the contents of the Respondent's immigration file and declared to certain matters, as follows:
* The Respondent confirmed he has left Canada to travel to his home area of XXXXX, Russia because his mother was ill.
* He was charged at least three times in Vancouver with shoplifting, while collecting social assistance, and he failed to appear for his court dates when he left the country to return Russia.
* He obtained a Russian Driver's Licence in 1998 valid from XXXXX 1998 to XXXXX 20083 and a Temporary Driver's permit dated XXXXX 1998 from the State Motor Vehicle Inspectorate, in XXXXX, Russia.4
* He had both an internal and external Russian passport issued to him by Russian authorities while he lived in Russia between 1994 and 1999.5
* He was arrested and imprisoned at least three times in Russia, for causing a disturbance or fighting and found guilty and sentenced to jail time.
* He destroyed his Russian passport while in the US.6
* He was arrested in Montreal because he was in possession of a false Denmark passport, and did not appear for his court date as required.
* He fled to Vancouver, thereby avoiding a trial on this matter.
* He filed a second refugee claim in January 2000 and was found to be ineligible to make a second claim on the basis he had previously been found to be a Convention refugee.
* He filed a Notification of Claim to be Convention Refugee, and at Question 27 indicated he was a Citizen of Russia from XXXXX 1994 to XXXXX 1999.
* He indicated in the Notification of Claim that he left Canada in XXXXX of 1994.
* He told XXXXX XXXXX he left either late 1993 or early 1994
Accordingly, the Applicant also alleges that the Respondent is a person who has voluntarily re-established himself in the country that the person left, or outside of which the person remained, by reason of a fear of persecution section 108(1)(a).
Section 108 of the Act clearly places the burden of proof on the Minister to show that the person who was determined to be a Convention refugee under this Act has ceased to be a Convention refugee.7
It is uncontested that the Respondent returned to Russia in or around 1994, and resided in XXXXX until his return to Canada in XXXXX 1999. The Respondent admitted this to XXXXX XXXXX, and also to the panel in his oral evidence at the hearing. It is also uncontested that when the Respondent returned to Russia, he obtained several official government issued identity documents, including an external passport.
It is also uncontested that when Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) officials interviewed the Respondent and when he testified at his hearing, he presented inconsistent and contradictory testimony regarding the date of his return to Russia. In his interview with Officer XXXXX he said that he left for Russia in late 1993 and later, XXXXX 1994, whereas it is clear from his PIF and oral testimony that he left for Russia in XXXXX 1994. It also remains unclear whether he was in possession at any time, of a Canadian Visitor Visa (CVV).8
The Respondent was asked about the inconsistent and contradictory testimony that he presented in his interviews with CIC officials and the IRB. He stated that he was unsure of these details at the time. The panel does not accept this as a satisfactory explanation and inferred instead that he was not being truthful and consistent to Canadian immigration officials and this panel.
The Respondent's testimony at the cessation hearing was not always presented in a straightforward or direct manner. There were times the Respondent appeared to be changing his testimony to suit the circumstances, and times when he delivered long and circuitous, but nonetheless non-responsive answers to questions put to him by the panel, the Minister's counsel, and even his own counsel, whose frustration with his client was evident in the hearing. Counsel conceded that the Respondent's credibility was questionable but that the panel should nonetheless, give him the benefit of the doubt.
He was asked why he returned to Russia. He stated it was because his mother was about to have emergency surgery to treat her varicose veins. He testified that he was told by a Russian doctor that it was urgent that he return immediately to Russia to be with his mother who could die if she did not have surgery right away. During his hearing the Respondent confirmed that his mother was in general good health prior to this and had not had any medical problems before this surgery, other than what would be usual for an elderly woman.
In the interview with XXXXX XXXXX, the Respondent admitted that his mother's surgery did not take place for two months after his return to Russia, suggesting it was not an emergency. When confronted with this and other problems with the evidence, the Respondent continued to repeat that it was an emergency and he had to return to see his ill mother. Yet, he did not provide any documentary evidence to substantiate the fact his mother was ill. He said there was too much "red tape" and he thought it would be difficult to obtain such corroboration now, ten years after the fact. Later he said it never occurred to him and he might be able to obtain this information if necessary.
While the onus is on the Minister to advance a prima facie case for cessation, the Respondent must answer the allegations of the Minister, once a prima facie case has been established. The Respondent knew or ought to have known, that medical evidence to corroborate the fact his mother had been ill would be necessary to establish he had a pressing reason for leaving Canada. His failure to provide any evidence of his mother's illness, even evidence that should have been readily available, such as letters of appointment, prescriptions, follow up reports, and the like, causes me to suspect he was not being truthful.
In addition, the fact that the Respondent went to government authorities to obtain official documents such as passports and driving permits, causes me to conclude that he has sought and received the protection of his state, and voluntarily re-established himself in Russia. He was also self-employed, buying and selling vehicles, which suggests he was living and working in Russia as any normal citizen would.
I am not persuaded by the Respondent's explanations for his departure from Canada, or his lengthy stay in Russia. The Respondent testified repeatedly that he returned to Russia in 1994 to help his sick mother. I note once again that if his mother did indeed have surgery, it did not take place, according to the Respondent's own evidence, until two months after his arrival in Russia. She did not experience any life-threatening consequences from this surgery - at least none are alleged by the Respondent, and she is alive and well in Russia today, some ten years later.
Again, when he was asked if he had any documentation to substantiate that his mother was staying at this hospital, during her serious illness, he answered, "No." He also stated that he did not try to get any documents to corroborate his mother's stay at this hospital.
The panel finds that the Respondent's failure to make any efforts to obtain the supporting documentation regarding his mother's alleged illness in Russia demonstrates a lack of due diligence on his part. Accordingly, the panel draws a negative inference from the Respondent's failure to provide any supporting documentation that his mother was seriously ill and staying in a hospital in Russia during the relevant periods of his stay there.
It would be reasonable to expect a person in the Respondent's position to have made serious efforts to obtain documentation to support his case against the Minister's application for cessation, but he clearly failed to do so. Therefore, taking the totality of the evidence into consideration, the panel concludes that this Respondent is neither a reliable nor trustworthy witness.
It is uncontested that the Respondent has not been entirely truthful to Canadian immigration officials since his first arrival in Canada. He attempted to enter the country surreptitiously on a fraudulent Danish passport. He did not initially declare himself to Canada immigration officials. He thought he could enter illegally, and resume his life as a Convention refugee in Canada. He admits to shoplifting on several occasions, including times he did not get caught.
There is no reason to accept that the Respondent presented the panel with credible evidence to counter the Minister's evidence in support of its application for cessation.
With respect to section 108(1)(a) of the Act, the panel finds the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees Handbook to be persuasive. It states that the cessation clause implies three requirements:
(a) voluntariness: the refugee must act voluntarily;
(b) intention: the refugee must intend by his action to re-avail himself of the protection of the country of his nationality;
(c) re-availment: the refugee must actually obtain such protection.9
With respect to the issue of voluntariness, at no time did the Respondent indicate that he was pressured to return to Russia. When he was asked why he would risk his life to return to Russia, he stated, "My mother was sick and that is why I left. She had no one else and needed me to help her with groceries, cleaning and taking care of her." The Respondent would have the panel believe that he returned to Russia solely for altruistic reasons and out of a deep sense of obligation to his mother. The Respondent alleges that he called Canada Immigration to see what
he could do to leave the country. He was allegedly told that if he completed an application form, filed supporting medical documentation and waited around thirty days to process this form, his application would be considered and he might be permitted to leave to assist his mother. Counsel for the Respondent argues this suggests the Respondent did not intend to remain in Russia and had every intention to return to Canada as soon as he was able.
Yet, his past history of deceit, would suggest he has exaggerated his mother's illness, if it existed at all. As preciously stated, he presented no credible evidence to show that his mother was ill or that he ever cared for her while he resided in Russia from 1994 to 1999. The Respondent returned to Russia because he wanted to do so. His choice to return was freely made. Accordingly, the panel finds his return to Russia was a voluntary act.
What was the Respondent's intention of returning to Russia? The Minister submits it was to re-avail of the protection of the country. The Respondent testified that he went there solely to see his mother during her illness. However, the Respondent remained there for five years. He worked, obtained identity documents and a driver's licence, and generally lived like any other citizen. He said he did not vote while he was there and did not have a bank account. Counsel argues this suggests his sojourn in Russia was transitory and his mere presence for five years is not sufficient to establish an intention to establish himself there.
He was asked whether he had ever previously voted or had a bank account when he lived in Russia before he made his refugee claim in Canada. He said "no, it is against my philosophy" which suggests that when he returned to Russia, he carried on, in his home, and in with his usual habits, as before he made his refugee claim.
The Respondent's length of stay in Russia, and the fact he was gainfully employed while there, cannot be considered as merely incidental to going to see and aid his sick mother. As stated previously I have made the finding that the Respondent willingly returned to Russia. The Respondent's intentions can be inferred from his actions. The panel finds his intentions were to return and to live in Russia. Hence, the Respondent's action reveal his intentions were to re-avail himself of the protection of his country of nationality and to re-establish himself in Russia.
The evidence before the panel shows that the Respondent not only obtained an internal passport to aid him with his business, but he also obtained an external passport from the authorities, without difficulty. The Respondent's intentions can clearly be inferred from his
actions while he lived and worked in Russia. It is evident that he lived there like any other Russian citizen, apparently, and with the exception of being drunk and disorderly and arrested for the minor offences of hooliganism and fighting, abiding by the laws of the state.
Consequently, I find that the Respondent re-availed himself of the protection of the Russian state.
The Respondent's testimony establishes that he was able to obtain a variety of services from the Russian state. The Respondent was allowed to get a driving permit, he was allowed to work, and he was allowed to get medical benefits, according to his testimony. The Respondent's ability to live and work in Russia, establishes a prima facie case that the Respondent was able to obtain the protection of the Russian state. The ability to obtain an internal passport to do business in Moscow, the ability to buy and sell cars, obtain an external passport, and other identification indicative of Russian nationality indicates not only the Respondent's willingness to seek state protection, but also his ability to receive it.
Thus, I find that the Respondent not only sought the protection of the Russia but that he was able to obtain it.
Accordingly, the panel finds that the Respondent meets all three requirements of section 108(1)(a) and, therefore, concludes that the Respondent voluntarily re-availed himself of the protection of his country of nationality.
With respect to section 108(1)(a) of the Act, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees Handbook states that "voluntary re-establishment" is understood as return to the country of nationality "with a view to permanently residing there."10 Moreover, Professor James C. Hathaway notes the following, on this point:
Re-establishment requires more than mere physical presence and a greater commitment to the country of origin than is evinced, for example, by a temporary return to visit an ailing parent or to bring out relatives, friends, or property. Careful scrutiny of more prolonged and frequent visits for such purposes as holidays or business is warranted, however, since at some point the degree of attachment may qualify as re-establishment. While an occasional visit of up to a few weeks is too transitory to sustain the cessation of status, a regular presence in the state of origin for a significant part of the year is prima facie inconsistent with a continued need for protection.11 [Emphasis added]
The panel has duly considered the Respondent's evidence with respect to his voluntary re-establishment in Russia. It is clear that the Respondent did not remain in Russia for a mere few weeks but more than five years. In my view, this certainly constitutes "a regular presence in the state of origin". Hence, the panel finds this to be inconsistent with the Respondent's allegations for the continued need for surrogate state protection abroad, that is, in Canada. A stay of this duration cannot be considered temporary but, rather, it must be deemed as permanent. Moreover, it belies a subjective fear of persecution that the Respondent testified to, while he was resident there. Hence, the panel finds that the uncontested evidence presented establishes the Respondent voluntarily re-established himself in Russia, given his length of stay there before his return to Canada.
Thus, having considered the circumstances in this case, the panel concludes that the Minister has satisfied the burden of establishing, on a balance of probabilities, that the Respondent not only voluntarily re-availed himself of the protection of his country of nationality but also voluntarily re-established himself in the country that he left and in respect of which he claimed international protection in Canada.
For these reasons, the Minister's application pursuant to subsections 108(1)(a) and (d)) is granted. The panel, therefore, determines that the Respondent, XXXXX XXXXX, has ceased to be a Convention refugee. Pursuant to section 108(2) of the Act, the Minister's Application is allowed, and the claim of the Respondent is deemed rejected.

These are the reasons for the decision in the matter of XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX, a citizen of Sri Lanka. Mr. XXXXXXXXX claims a well-founded fear of persecution pursuant to section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (Act)1 based upon his political opinion and his race, as a Tamil male. The claimant also alleges he is a person in need of protection pursuant to section 97(1)(b) of the Act in that he fears a risk to his life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment should he return to Sri Lanka.
He also claims he is entitled to protection pursuant to section 97(1)(a) of the Act in that he is a person in danger of torture as defined in Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture.2
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant alleges he is a 38-year-old Tamil male from the Jaffna area of Sri Lanka who fled Sri Lanka because he has been persecuted by the Sri Lankan Army (SLA) who suspect him of being connected to the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE). He alleges the SLA and the Eelam People's Democratic Party (EPDP) extorted work from him. He alleges that he was forced by the LTTE to dig trenches near the SLA base camps, forced to build bunkers and fortify the LTTE camps, donate blook, look after the sick and wounded, and cut the hair of LTTE members (because he was a XXXXX by profession). Although he was harassed to join the LTTE, he did not do so. He alleges in addition, that the LTTE extorted funds from him, to aid their cause.
He was also arrested by the SLA on three occasions: XXXXX 1997, XXXXX 1999 and XXXXX 2000. He was detained with others, asked questions about his involvement with the LTTE, and then released. He was ordered to cut the hair of members of both the SLA and the LTTE, from time to time. He was warned against cutting the hair of members of the SLA by the LTTE.
Because he felt caught in the middle between the SLA and the LTTE, he fled Jaffna and moved to Colombo with his family. He left Sri Lanka and came to Canada to make a refugee claim May 2003. His wife and children returned to Jaffna, where they remained up to the time of the hearing.
DETERMINATION
I find that the claimant is not a Convention refugee as he does not have a well-founded fear of persecution for a Convention ground in Sri Lanka. I also find the claimant is not a person in need of protection in that his removal to Sri Lanka would not subject him personally to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, and in that there are no substantial grounds to believe that his removal to Sri Lanka will subject him personally to a danger of torture.
ANALYSIS
The duty of this panel is to find whether there is sufficient credible or trustworthy evidence to determine that there is a "serious possibility"3 that the claimant will be persecuted or at risk to his life or at risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if he is returned to Sri Lanka. This means that it must not be possible for him to get protection from this persecution in his own country and, further, that there is no other location in his country where he could live safely. The single decision, therefore, is whether the claimant is a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection.
The Immigration and Refugee Protection Act provides a definition of a Convention refugee and of a person in need of protection. Over the years, the courts have interpreted these definitions. I am bound by the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and the Courts' interpretations of that Act. In arriving at my decision, I have considered the testimony of the claimant, the other evidence filed and the submissions of counsel and the Refugee Protection Officer (RPO).
In order to establish a successful claim a claimant must demonstrate either a well-founded fear of persecution or that he is a person in need of protection. I found that the claimant's testimony was not credible. In assessing credibility I am guided as always by the principles enunciated by the Federal Court of Appeal in the decision of Maldonado,4 which stands for the proposition that when a claimant swears to the truthfulness of certain facts this creates the presumption that these facts are true, unless there is reason to doubt their truthfulness.
I am also guided by the principles in Rajaratnam5 and in Shahamati6 where the Federal Court of Appeal stated that the Board is entitled in assessing credibility to rely on criteria such as "rationality and common sense."
In this case I find there are reasons to doubt the claimant's truthfulness and that his evidence was, at times, irrational and lacking in common sense. In particular, I noted contradictions, inconsistencies and implausibilities in his evidence. He was asked about the issues that were of concern to me and the explanations provided by him were not satisfactory in resolving these issues, in my view. I will cite only a few examples.
The claimant has established that he is Tamil through the documentation filed, including his national identity card, birth and marriage certificates and those of family members. All of the documents indicate that he is a Tamil from the Jaffna area.7
The claimant has established he is a XXXXX through the same documents, which refer to his occupation as "XXXXX."8
There were numerous inconsistencies as between the Canada Immigration notes9 the Personal Information Form (PIF)10 and his oral testimony. There were discrepancies with respect to his education and employment, including where he worked and for which period of time. There was inconsistency as to when the last threat was made to him by the LTTE, and whether
he was present when the threat was made or not. There was inconsistency as to where he lived before he came to Canada, and when he moved to Colombo. The dates of his detention differed as between the CIC notes,11 his interview with CIC and the omission of these detentions from his hand-written notes at the Port-of-Entry. Because this is such a significant event as to why he seeks protection, the omission and inconsistency in this very important area, is significant, in my view.
The inconsistencies between his testimony and the CIC notes included the time and period he worked for the SLA as a XXXXX, and the work he did for the EPDP. This evidence is also inconsistent with the PIF, which mentions he was taken to the SLA army camp "after the ceasefire in XXXXX of 2002."
As well, there were significant omissions in the evidence. The claimant said that the LTTE visited his wife in Colombo, a detail not present in the PIF, nor the amendments to the PIF, even though he testified that he was aware of this in 2003. The first time we heard of this, was in the hearing. The claimant made a trip to Malaysia in 1995. The purpose of this trip was identified as to "visit his aunt with cancer" (PIF), to "escape to Canada" (CIC notes) and he returned to Sri Lanka rather than carry on to Canada, because he was cheated by the agent who assisted him.
The claimant's explanation for these inconsistencies and omissions was that he was tired when he was interviewed by CIC, and he was "confused." I do not accept his explanation. The claimant was asked several times by his counsel, what he feared today if returned to Sri Lanka and his answer was: "war will start any time now" which suggests a fear not personal to him.
Finally, the claimant was evasive. He was often non-responsive to questions put to him, or answered in a circuitous manner.
In addition, there is no mention of his fear of the SLA or the EDPD in his interview with Canada Immigration and his handwritten statement, only his fear of the LTTE.
Because Mr. XXXXX did make submissions with respect to a potential explanation for the variance between the CIC notes and the testimony today, I want to comment on this. Counsel conceded that there were apparent inconsistencies in the evidence but submitted that the CIC notes are not a previous statement of the claimant and support for this proposition is that the document is not signed by the claimant. Counsel asserts the document does not appear to have been read back to the claimant and it is, therefore, not reliable.
The entire file is provided to counsel for the claimant and the claimant and counsel were aware of what was written in the notes. If these inconsistencies raised concerns they could have been dealt with. The onus remains on the claimant at all times to prove his refugee claim and I do not accept the inconsistencies as I have described have been adequately addressed today, although the claimant has been given ample opportunity to do so.
If the claimant had legitimate concerns about the CIC notes the officer could have been brought to the hearing or asked to explain what happened and that did not happen. I find that the claim as set out by the claimant is not credible.
While the claimants fits the general profile of those at risk in Sri Lanka today, not all Tamil males will automatically be granted protection as refugees. The claimant must establish his claim on the facts surrounding his claim, and he must establish he has either a well-founded fear of persecution or a risk to his life. The credibility concerns raised by this claim overshadow his profile. I note as well that his wife and children remain in Jaffna, apparently without problems. The claimant is therefore not a Convention refugee.
Section 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act outlines the definition of a person in need of protection. The elements necessary to establish a claim under section 97(1) are not identical to those necessary to establish whether a person is a Convention refugee under section 96 of the Act. Consequently, as noted by the court in Bouaouni,12 a negative credibility determination which may be determinative of a refugee claim under section 96 of the Act is not necessarily determinative of a claim under section 97(1) of the Act.
In the case at hand there is nothing in the evidence, whether personal or documentary, that would provide a foundation for establishing a personal risk for the claimant pursuant to section 97(1) of the Act. I, therefore, find the claimant is not at risk of harm in that there is insufficient evidence that there is a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment or a risk to his life.
Whether the claim is framed under the Convention refugee sections of the Act or the risk to his life or of cruel and unusual treatment and punishment, the outcome is the same. The panel did not find the claimant's testimony credible, so there is no evidentiary basis for his claim.
For these reasons and upon consideration of the whole of the evidence I determine that XXXXX XXXXXXXXXXX is neither a Convention refugee as defined in section 96 of the Act nor a person in need of protection as defined in section 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
CONCLUSION
For these reasons, the claim for refugee protection is rejected.
