ORAL DECISION AND REASONS
This is the decision of the Refugee Protection Division in the claims of XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX and her daughters, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX , XXXXX XXXXX and her son, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX. All but the son, make their claim for protection against Egypt. The son is an American citizen who makes his claim against the United States. The date is February 5, 2004. The claimants claim to have a well-founded fear of persecution at the hands of XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, the divorced husband of the main claimant and the father of the children.
It must be noted that the boy has only American citizenship and, hence, may not have to return to Egypt. In that case, his claim is against the United States on the ground of separation from family. Counsel has stated that this would be contrary to stated rights in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and other international covenants. As such, it would constitute cruel and unusual treatment.
It is the duty of this panel to find if there is sufficient credible or trustworthy evidence to determine that there is more than a "mere possibility"1 that the female claimants would be persecuted if they returned to Egypt or be at risk. Similarly, what is the case with the son if he should be returned to the United States?
The claimants must also demonstrate that it would not be possible to get protection from their own countries and that there is no other location in their countries where they could live safely. The mother was appointed the designated representative for the three children. A reference to the claimant in this decision is a reference to the mother.
In coming to my decision, I have considered the testimony of the mother, the evidence before me, the observations of the refugee protection officer and submissions by counsel. Given the nature of the claim, I have also kept in mind the points raised in the Chairperson's Gender Guidelines.2 I will briefly outline the story. The story is one of domestic abuse faced by the mother and her two daughters delivered by the husband or father. The mother and her ex-husband were married in 1987 and divorced in 2003.
During this period the wife was beaten repeatedly. Her two daughters were also beaten and physically abused by the father. The claimant sought advice from her brothers about what to do and was advised to simply put up with it for the sake of the children. Her brothers went on to warn her that if she divorced her husband they would take her and the children in, but only as domestics.
At one point in the late 1990's, the claimant stated that she visited the local police station to request help. She said she was told by the policeman that it was a trivial event and they had much more important things to do than assist her. She testified that she was not surprised by this as she had a twice-divorced friend who had often sought assistance from the police but had been unsuccessful in obtaining any.
In XXXXX 2000, the claimant went on a trip with her two daughters to the United States and Canada. Her son was born in South Carolina on XXXXX, 2000. Upon returning to Egypt in XXXXX 2001, the claimant's husband continued his abuse towards her and the children. However, he had moved out of their common home and had, in fact, begun a relationship with another woman with whom he was living. Eventually, the claimant sought and was granted a divorce on XXXXX, 2003. At that time she renounced all rights to any possessions or future rights and her husband signed a document renouncing his rights to the children.
With this in hand the claimant and her children came to Canada and claimed for protection. After having been in Canada she has had no direct contact with her former husband, although one of her brothers in Egypt stated that the sister of her former husband had called him screaming and angrily demanded to know when the children would be returning.
Credibility is an issue in every claim. There is some reason to doubt the credibility of the claimant. In particular, at the outset of the hearing, she amended her Personal Information Form (PIF).3 Where the original PIF stated that she had never gone to the police, her amendment stated that she had. She was asked to explain this contradiction. Her explanation was that she had omitted to mention the police in the first version of her PIF because she had no documentary proof that she had been and also did not think its omission was very important. The panel pointed out that the directions to filling out the PIF were explicit in this regard. The panel does not find the explanation provided by the claimant believable.
Apart from this embellishment, the claimant's testimony was consistent with her statements to Canada Immigration and with her PIF. Her demeanour was not inconsistent with, and I use counsel's phrase "a submissive person" from a poorly educated background, which is what she claimed to have come from. Overall, I found her to be a truthful witness and I accept her account of the experiences she claims with the noted exception of the visit to the police station.
The panel finds that the claimants have established their identities and nationalities through certified copies of their passports.
With respect to the nexus under the Convention, the panel finds that what the female claimants' fear constitutes persecution and that persecution is linked to the Convention ground of particular social group, namely, women or child victims of spousal or parental abuse.
I will have more to say about the boy further on in these reasons. In the panel's view, the central issue in this case, as concerns the three female claimants, is state protection. The panel has considered whether state protection is available to them. The country documents4 make it clear that domestic violence and general violence against women in Egypt is a serious concern. Egypt has in recent years brought in a new divorce law to make it easier for women to divorce men. This has earned the anger of the conservative in Egypt.
However, even with regard to this new law, men appear to receive more favourable consideration than women. As well, CEDAW, which is the Committee to Eliminate Discrimination Against Women, has stated that the reality for women has not changed significantly since the introduction of the new law. The documentary evidence also notes that
police and society in general in Egypt, do not take the issue of domestic abuse seriously, notwithstanding the laws against it.
Effective protection requires not only that the state have laws prohibiting the actions in question, but also that the State take steps to enforce these laws. It is in this area that one notes Egypt's weakness. The claimant's evidence about the lack of success faced by her friend in getting protection from the police when her husband abused her is consistent with these documents.
The claimant had a document purporting to be from her husband in which he renounced his rights to the children forever. The claimant stated that her ex-husband signed it only in order to get her to give up everything else, including her right to alimony and child support. Consequently, the claimant feared that upon returning to Egypt her ex-husband would simply ignore the document and she stated he would be able to take the children legally.
The documents on the right of custody in Egypt do not support the claimant's understanding of the process. Currently, the law in Egypt is that girls under the age of 12 and boys under the age of 10 remain with the mother. When the children reach those ages the father becomes the custodian. However, there is a right to go to the court to extend the mother's custodial right of the boy until he becomes 15 or of the girls until they marry.
Reflecting on the father's renunciation, the panel does not know whether it is legally binding or not. The panel does note, however, that the phone call from the ex-husband's sister in which she demanded the children, would appear to indicate that her ex-husband has a continuing interest in his children. In any event, the mother has little money to bring on a motion before the court to retain custody. The outcome of that would be uncertain, anyhow.
Consequently, in the panel's view, there is more than a mere possibility that if the girls return to Egypt their custody would revert to their father. As he has abused them in the past there is no reason to suppose that he would not continue to do so in the future. That would constitute persecution. Consequently, the panel finds, for the reasons earlier given, that state protection would not be available to the girls under these circumstances nor to children of that age is Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) an option.
Because of these reasons the panel determines XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX and XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX are Convention refugees.
With respect to the wife, the case is different. Unlike her children, she cannot be returned to her husband. Even so, the panel is of the view that the ex-husband has demonstrated a violent past towards her and that the issue of custody with the children would exacerbate relations and the panel finds that there is a more than a mere possibility that the husband would abuse her once again. As noted, the panel is of the view that the state could not provide effective protection to her for this. Given her particular situation and the general situation for women in Egypt, an IFA is also not a reasonable option
Because of this the panel determines that XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX is a Convention refugee.
Turning to the claim of XXXXX XXXXX against the United States, in that case the claim is against the United States on the ground of separation from the family. As noted, counsel has argued that this would be contrary to stated rights in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and of other international covenants. As such, he stated it would constitute cruel and unusual treatment to deprive him of his family.
In order to come within the Convention or the categories of risk or torture, the claimant must establish the likelihood that he would be persecuted or at risk if returned to his country, which is the United States. There is no evidence before the panel that suggests that the boy, if returned to the United States, would be at any risk or subject to persecution. The Federal Court of Appeal has ruled that being part of a family group is not an independent ground for establishing membership in a particular social group.
The argument by counsel is based on the notion that the act of separating the boy from his mother constitutes cruel and unusual punishment. It is worth noting that the action of separation would be taken by Canada and not the United States in the first place and the boy has no claim against Canada as, indeed, he could not as he holds no status here other than as an applicant for Canada's protection. As well, the panel notes the statement of Mr. Justice Rothstein in the case of De Busto.5 Mr. Justice Rothstein stated:
Finally, I do not see how the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child assist the applicant in this case.
This was a case where one of the children was not granted refugee status and the rest of the family were. As Mr. Justice Rothstein goes on to note:
Regrettably, removals do cause disruption in families but if they are as a result of proper judicial and/or quasi judicial processes, such disruptions must be seen as acceptable.
Accordingly, the panel rejects XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX claim to Convention status or person in need of protection status.

XXXXX XXXXX a.k.a. XXXXX XXXXX is a 23-year-old citizen of Israel. He says he does not want to return to Israel because he does not want to serve in the Israeli army and he generally fears for his life in Israel.
The claimant is not represented by counsel. He confirmed at the hearing that he was taking no steps to get counsel and wished to proceed without counsel. The claimant also indicated he speaks and understands English and did not wish to have an interpreter. Finally, the claimant says he received the documents sent to him in regard to this hearing.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant was born in Israel in 1981. From XXXXX 1999 until XXXXX 2002 he performed his compulsory military service. He said he was keen to serve in the military, but once there he did not like it. He says he did not like the loss of personal freedom nor the danger. The claimant has XXXXX and was able to use that as a way to avoid combat. However, he was put on guard duty and he says there was a danger of being shot. He says he tried to get out of the military after about sixteen months of service by pretending he was depressed and not sane. He says others had managed to convince the military authorities they were not well mentally and had been exempted from further service. The claimant was not successful with his attempt, and was required to finish his military service.
He says that, once released, he would be recalled each year for one month of service and could be recalled on a more permanent basis if the military needed more soldiers. The claimant says he never applied for an exemption as a conscientious objector as he was not in a fighting role. He said he was just afraid of being killed. The claimant says he did not refuse to serve in the army because he did not want to go to jail. The claimant was unable to produce any documentation regarding his military service and release.
The claimant worked after being released from the army until he came to Canada in August 2003 with four friends. After about a month he made his refugee claim. He says two of the friends who travelled with him have also made refugee claims in Canada, while the other two returned to Israel.
The claimant also says generally he feels unsafe in Israel, as suicide bombers have killed many people including civilians. He fears this could happen at any time to anyone, including himself. He says there is security everywhere.
DETERMINATION
I find the claimant is not a Convention refugee, as he does not have a well-founded fear of persecution for a Convention ground in Israel. I also find the claimant is not a person in need of protection in that his removal to Israel would not subject him personally to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, and in that there are no substantial grounds to believe that his removal to Israel will subject him personally to a danger of torture.
ANALYSIS
I find the claimant gave credible evidence about his background and reasons for wanting to remain in Canada. He is a young man who honestly fears for his life in a country where many people have been seriously injured or lost their lives. He also much prefers the personal freedom and lifestyle in Canada as compared to Israel. I feel sympathetic to the claimant, but I find his claim does not come within section 96 or 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act. I do not have any jurisdiction to consider his claim otherwise.
The claimant's identity as a national of Israel is established by his testimony and the passport he provided to Canada Immigration.1
Prosecution Versus Persecution - Law of General Application
The claimant objects to the law that requires him to report for military service in Israel. Generally, a state is entitled to enact laws that will contribute to the better, safer, and more just functioning of the national community and its government. Further, a state is entitled to impose penalties upon those who break its laws. Normally a person who objects to the general laws of their country or fears a penalty for violation of such a law will not meet the requirements to be a protected person in Canada. However, there are limits to this proposition.
The Federal Court of Appeal in Zolfagharkhani2 set out the analysis to apply in these situations:
After this review of the law, I now venture to set forth some general propositions relating to the status of an ordinary law of general application in determining the question of persecution:
(1) The statutory definition of Convention refugee makes the intent (or any principal effect) of an ordinary law of general application, rather than the motivation of the claimant, relevant to the existence of persecution.
(2) But the neutrality of an ordinary law of general application, vis-à-vis the five grounds for refugee status, must be judged objectively by Canadian tribunals and courts when required.
(3) In such consideration, an ordinary law of general application, even in non-democratic societies, should, I believe, be given a presumption of validity and neutrality, and the onus should be on a claimant, as is generally the case in refugee cases, to show that the laws are either inherently or for some other reason persecutory.
(4) It will not be enough for the claimant to show that a particular regime is generally oppressive but rather that the law in question is persecutory in relation to a Convention ground.
First, I find the claimant has not discharged the onus upon him of establishing that the Israeli conscription law is inherently persecutory in relation to a Convention ground. I find the Israeli military conscription law is a law of general application. Israel is a democratic country. The law applies to all Israeli citizens, although there is some difference in the length of service for men and women, and women and certain religious groups have more scope to apply for an exemption from service.3 I find these differences do not mean it is not a law of general application. The intent of the law is that all men and women are subject to be called for military service, and certain limited exemptions then apply. I note the Federal Court has said it is not persecution for a country to have compulsory military service.4
Second, I find the claimant has not shown on a balance of probabilities that the law is persecutory as applied to him. The Federal Court has said an aversion to military service or a fear of combat is not in itself sufficient reason to justify a fear of persecution.5 However, conscientious objectors and people who object to particular military operations that the international community has judged to be contrary to international law or to the basic rules of human conduct may be found to be Convention refugees. 6
In this regard, I note the claimant never said he is a conscientious objector - he says he does not want to die. He said other young men in Israel share these views, although many are willing to serve their country. He gave no political or religious convictions for his views. He participated in the Israeli military for three years, although he tried to pretend he was not sane in order to get out. The claimant did not apply for an exemption from service as a conscientious objector as he said he was not in a combat role. I think this indicates the claimant is not a conscientious objector, as if he objected to war on the basis of his conscience, I am satisfied he would have applied for an exemption from the military whether or not he was in an active combat role. He was on guard duty and carried a weapon. The claimant gave no evidence of any activities or other conduct that would suggest he was a conscientious objector.
Further, the claimant gave no evidence of objecting to any particular activities of the Israeli military. Thus I find his claim cannot be considered as one in which a person, although not a conscientious objector generally, objects to serving in military operations that the international community has judged to be contrary to basic rules of human conduct or contrary to recognized basic international principles of human rights.7
In conclusion on this point, I find the claimant has failed to establish on a balance of probabilities that he has a credible nexus to any Convention ground. As a result, I find his objection to military service is not persecution based on a Convention ground.
Third, even where a law of general application is found not to be inherently persecutory nor persecutory with respect to the specific individual, the Federal Court has indicated it is necessary to consider whether the penalty for violation of the law may constitute persecution.8 This raises the issue of whether the imprisonment the claimant could face if he returns to Israel and refuses to report for military service if he is recalled would be sufficiently serious to constitute persecution.
The UNHCR Handbook9 comments on the punishment for individuals who do not perform compulsory military service.
167. In countries where military service is compulsory, failure to perform this duty is frequently punishable by law. Moreover, whether military service is compulsory or not, desertion is invariably considered a criminal offence. The penalties may vary from country to country, and are not normally regarded as persecution. Fear of prosecution and punishment for desertion or draft-evasion does not in itself constitute well-founded fear of persecution under the definition. Desertion or draft-evasion does not, on the other hand, exclude a person from being a refugee, and a person may be a refugee in addition to being a deserter or draft-evader.
I note there is no alternative service available in Israel for people who claim conscientious objector status. Further, there is only a very limited opportunity to gain exemption from military conscription. The result is that many people who refuse to serve face charges, convictions and jail sentences. The maximum sentence for each conviction appears to be two years and, once released from jail, the person may face repeated convictions and jail sentences if he/she still refuses to serve. However, the documentation indicates the usual sentence for each conviction is 28 to 35 days in jail, followed by repeated sentences of the same length for people who continue to refuse to serve. This may continue until the person has served five or six of these sentences - apparently to a maximum of approximately 150 days of jail in total, although there is one report of one person serving seven 28-day terms and another report of several people serving a total of nine months in jail before being released and exempted from further military call-up.10
If the claimant returns and is recalled and refuses to serve in the military, he could expect to serve a period of incarceration. The most up-to-date information we have is that such a period would likely be from five to nine months in total. In the panel's view such a penalty would not be disproportionate to the breach of the law. Therefore I find the expected penalty for failing to abide by the law is not persecutory.
In conclusion with respect to the claimant's aversion to military service, I find the law and its penalty do not constitute persecution on a Convention ground for the purposes of section 96 of the Act. I find the claimant fears prosecution and not persecution in this regard.
With regard to section 97 of the Act, I find the risk the claimant fears in serving in the military is a risk faced generally by other individuals in Israel. Military service is compulsory with few exceptions. Therefore I find it is covered by section 97(1)(b)(ii). Further, in accordance with the reasoning above, I find the risk the claimant fears if he refuses to serve is inherent or incidental to lawful sanctions that have not been shown to be contrary to accepted international standards. The claimant has provided no evidence that the penalty for refusing to serve in the military is contrary to international norms. The normal sentences outlined above do not appear to be excessive for the nature of the offence. Therefore, I find this is covered by section 97(1)(b)(iii) of the Act.
General Fear of Serious Harm
The claimant also expressed a fear of serious harm generally as many people are seriously injured or killed by suicide bombers in Israel.
I find the government of Israel is making serious efforts to reduce or prevent these attacks on its citizens. The Court of Appeal in Villafranca stated:
No government that makes any claim to democratic values or protection or human rights can guarantee the protection of all its citizens at all times. Thus it is not enough for a claimant merely to show that his government has not always been effective at protecting persons in his particular situation. Terrorism in the name of one warped ideology or another is a scourge afflicting many societies today; its victims, however much they may merit our sympathy, do not become Convention refugees simply because their governments have been unable to suppress the evil. ... where a state is in the effective control of its territory, has military, police and civil authority in place, and make serious efforts to protect its citizens from terrorist activities, the mere fact that it is not always successful at doing so will not be enough to justify a claim that the victims of terrorism are unable to avail themselves of such protection.11
I find this statement applies here. Israel is in control of its territories; it is taking extensive measures to prevent and combat attacks on it civilian population; the measures taken are serious and consistent; and there is no clear or convincing evidence that the state is unable or unwilling to protect its citizens. While the protection against random and unpredictable terrorist attacks on Jewish civilians in Israel is not perfect, Israel is nevertheless making serious efforts to protect is citizens. I find the claimant has not rebutted the presumption of state protection.
CONCLUSION
Based on the evidence, country documentation and law, I find there is less than a serious possibility the claimant faces persecution on the basis of any Convention ground for the purposes of section 96, and less than a serious possibility he faces a risk to his life, a risk of cruel and unusual punishment or treatment, or a danger of torture for the purposes of section 97 of the Act if he returns to Israel.
Therefore, the Refugee Protection Division determines XXXXX XXXXX, a.k.a. XXXXX XXXXX, is not a Convention refugee and is not a person in need of protection.

The claimant is a thirty-five year-old citizen of Iran. He fears persecution from the state authorities in Iran because of his activities as a photojournalist.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant says, between 2000 and 2002, he worked as a photographer for a daily newspaper in XXXXX. In the summer of 2000 he took photographs of a man who died in suspicious circumstances in a court building in XXXXX. The newspaper published the photographs. The editor of the paper and the claimant were required to report to the Ministry of Islamic Guidance in XXXXX and were reprimanded. The authorities prohibited the claimant from taking photographs in certain areas.
In XXXXX 2002 the claimant took video pictures and still pictures of the New Year celebrations in an area of XXXXX. The police arrived to break up the celebrations, and they detained the claimant and others. The authorities mistreated the claimant and kept him in jail for approximately eight months. The claimant was released on conditions, and was required to report on several occasions.
The claimant returned to work with his former editor, who had started a new publication because the authorities had closed the newspaper. The claimant was involved in taking photographs at special events at the University of XXXXX and got to know students who opposed the Iranian government. Through his contacts, the claimant assisted these students in getting materials printed and helped them distribute those materials at various demonstrations. In XXXXX 2003, these students held large public rallies. The claimant attended some of those rallies. The authorities raided the university and arrested some students who had worked with the claimant. A week later, the police stopped and detained the claimant's brother while he was driving the claimant's car. The police detained his brother for about a week. They told his brother they were looking for the claimant because he had participated in demonstrations and helped the student protesters.
The claimant was concerned for his safety. He thought the authorities maybe had taken photographs of the demonstrations and had identified him through those photographs, or some of the students who had been arrested had given his name to the authorities. The claimant went into hiding. With the assistance of one of his brothers, he left Iran with the assistance of an agent and came to Canada. He fears the authorities will detain, torture and possibly kill him if he returns.
DETERMINATION
I find the claimant is a Convention refugee.
ANALYSIS
There are some weaknesses in the claimant's story. The primary one is that he was unable to produce any examples of his published work. However, he produced an undated XXXXX XXXXX and several other documents to confirm his identity and occupation.1 The claimant was also vague on what has happened to the editor of his paper, even though his editor's difficulties with the authorities are publicly available.2 Finally, the claimant had difficulty producing a logical story as to how he ended up in Canada, rather than Azerbaijan or Turkey.
However, generally, I find the claimant provided sufficient credible evidence to establish his story. I accept he worked as a photographer in a newspaper, he was arrested and jailed for approximately eight months in 2002 for taking photographs of the New Year celebrations, and the authorities now want him for his participation in student demonstrations in XXXXX and assistance he provided to the students at the University of XXXXX.
The country documentation indicates the authorities can treat dissidents very harshly in detention.3 I find that treatment can amount to persecution. In this case that persecution would be on the basis of his political opinion - either actual or perceived.
CONCLUSION
Based on the evidence, country documentation and submissions, I find there is more than a mere possibility the claimant faces persecution on the basis of his political opinion in Iran.
Therefore, the Refugee Protection Division determines that XXXXX XXXXXXXX is a Convention refugee.

On October 20, 2003 the Minister, pursuant to s. 109 (1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA),1 filed an Application to Vacate the determination that XXXXXXXXX XXXXXXXXXX (the "Respondent") is a Convention refugee. It will be useful to set out an overview of the facts.
THE BACKGROUND
The Respondent, a citizen of Pakistan, arrived in Canada on April 15, 1995. On May 29, 1995 he signed his Personal Information Form (PIF)2 and a hearing into his claim was held on December 19, 1996 in front of a two-person panel of the CRDD in Calgary, Alberta. The claimant based his claim upon alleged persecution he faced in Pakistan due to his membership in the Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front (JKLF). The panel raised the issue of possible exclusion with the claimant and his counsel and questions about the nature of the organisation and the claimant's particular role in it were asked at the hearing. Specifically, counsel for the claimant asked whether he had "...any knowledge that the JKLF indulges in any - any acts of terrorism or crimes against humanity."3 The claimant responded as follows:
No. There is nothing - there is nothing like this because JKLF does not participate in any such activities - any activities that are against the humanity, or against the law, or against democracy. It is a registered political party of Pakistan, of Azar Kashmir, who believes in democracy, and we believe - and we also try. The solution to every problem should be found out through negotiations and should be done in a democratic fashion. And this is our belief, and we follow our belief.4
Counsel for the claimant then asked his client whether he had "...ever assisted or participated in any tradition of crime against humanity"?5 The following exchange took place:
A. Neither I have participated in any such activities that is against the humanity, nor - nor - nor my party has ever participated in any such activity that is against the humanity or against the democracy, and - neither I'm aware of any such activities, or nor we participate in any such.
Q. Okay. Does your organization advocate violence against opponents of Kashmiri cause in Pakistan?
A. No. No, never. Not myself nor neither my party, neither we are ever aware of such - such things.6 [Emphasis added]
Shortly after this the panel expressed that it was satisfied that exclusion was "...no longer an issue."7 A positive decision was rendered at the conclusion of the hearing although detailed reasons were not given. A written decision, outlining the reasons for the decision was signed on March 19, 1997. At the hearing the panel noted that they had found the claimant to be a credible witness.8 In its reasons for judgment the panel noted:
The claimant related credible evidence which convinced the panel that he was not an advocate of violence in his own political objectives. In this context, the panel concluded that there was no issue of exclusion in relation to this claim. ...
The panel concluded that the claimant was a credible and trustworthy witness, and accepted his testimony.9
The Respondent made an Application for permanent residence following his successful claim for refugee status.
On September 5, 2000 an Immigration Officer (IO) interviewed the Respondent. As a result of this interview and the IO's view that the JKLF was a terrorist organisation a Section 27 Report was issued pursuant to the old Immigration Act.10 An Inquiry before an Adjudicator of the Adjudication Division (AD) was held on May 18th and June 1, 2001. On July 19, 2001 the Adjudicator determined that the Respondent was a person described pursuant to S. 19 (1) (f) (iii) (b) of the old Act; namely that he was a member of a terrorist group and thereby removable from Canada. This decision was appealed to the Immigration Appeal Division (IAD) and a hearing was held on November 15, 2001 in front of a three-person panel in Vancouver, B.C. A unanimous decision was delivered on December 17, 2001 denying the appeal.
THE CURRENT APPLICATION
In his Application to Vacate counsel for the Minister alleges that the Respondent:
...misrepresented and concealed both the nature of the JKLF and its activities to the CRDD, foreclosing the CRDD from assessing whether the Respondent should be excluded from the Convention Refugee definition under Articles 1 (F) (a) and 1 (F) (c).
The Application to Vacate section of the IRPA is set out in S. 109. It reads:
(1) The Refugee Protection Division may, on application by the Minister, vacate a decision to allow a claim for refugee protection, if it finds that the decision was obtained as a result of directly or indirectly misrepresenting or withholding material facts relating to a relevant matter.
(2) The Refugee Protection Division may reject the application if it is satisfied that other sufficient evidence was considered at the time of the first determination to justify refugee protection.
(3) If the application is allowed, the claim of the person is deemed to be rejected and the decision that led to the conferral of refugee protection is nullified
The previous section under the IA was s. 69.3 (5), which read:
The Refugee Division may reject an application under subsection 69.2 (2) that is otherwise established if it is of the opinion that, notwithstanding that the determination was obtained by fraudulent means or misrepresentation, suppression or concealment of any material fact, there was other sufficient evidence on which the determination was or could have been based.
The courts have not interpreted the new section. In the past the courts generally have held that for the purposes of conducting an analysis pursuant to this section there is a two-step process. Firstly, the burden is upon the Minister to adduce sufficient evidence to demonstrate that the claimant misrepresented, was fraudulent, suppressed or concealed a material fact. If the Minister demonstrates this then the Board is obliged to consider the remaining evidence available to the original panel in order to determine whether there is still sufficient evidence upon which to conclude that the claimant was or could have been a refugee.
THE MINISTER'S ARGUMENT
The Minister takes the position that the Respondent withheld from the CRDD his true knowledge of the activities of the JKLF. The Minister argued that had he been truthful with the panel members about his knowledge of the activities of the JKLF they would have concluded that the JKLF was engaged in either crimes against peace, war crimes, or crimes against humanity - contrary to Article 1F(a) - or had been guilty of acts contrary to the purposes and principles of the United Nations - contrary to Article 1F(c). This being so, the Minister contends that the clamant would have been excluded from consideration under the Convention refugee sections of the Act.11
To demonstrate his argument the Minister contrasted the testimony of the Respondent before the CRDD in 1996 and his testimony before the Adjudication Division in 2001. I have already fully quoted the relevant testimony given by the Respondent at his hearing before the CRDD in 1996.
It is not in dispute that the Respondent was a member of the JKLF from 1988 until 1994 and that he was appointed XXXXXXXXXXXXXX for the XXXXXXXX District sometime in 1993. In my view, for the Minister to be successful in the preliminary step of this Application he must demonstrate that the Respondent directly or indirectly misrepresented or withheld a material fact or facts relating to a relevant matter. It is clear that facts relating to the exclusion issue would be relevant. The question is whether the Respondent "misrepresented" directly or indirectly or "withheld" information respecting the JKLF's involvement in activities contrary to either or both of Articles 1F(a) or 1F(c). The following exchange took place between the respondent and the Minister at the Adjudication hearing on June 1, 2001:
Q. Now, are you aware that the JKLF accepts responsibility for a number of bomb attacks in areas of Kashmir?
COUNSEL: Can we have a time frame with respect to you - your comments?
MR. WILKINSON: Certainly, 1988 through 1989.
INTERPRETER: "You want me to answer?" And I said, "Yes."
A. I have joined JKLF in 1988. And my duties in JKLF was to collect donations. But during that time if a member of JKLF was part of these sort of activities, then I have no knowledge of that.
BY MINISTER'S COUNSEL:
Q. But are you aware or were you aware at any time that the JKLF was accepting responsibilities in 1988 and 1989 for - bombings and explosions in Kashmir?
PERSON CONCERNED: Excuse me.
A. The Pakistan held - I don't remember and I don't recall that there has ever been an incident where a Pakistan-held Kashmir has such - something like that happening.
BY MINISTER'S COUNSEL:
Q. Let me refer you to and read from our book of documents.
MR. WILKINSON: At Tab 6 you'll find a document, Mr. Adjudicator, called Asia Watch, a highly recognized human rights organization, entitled "Kashmir Under Siege." At page 13 or that document, top of the page.
BY MINISTER'S COUNSEL:
Q. I'll read from the paragraph starting with the word "Beginning."
"Beginning in the latter half of 1988 and continuing through 1989, militants of the JKLF, the organization formed more than two decades earlier to win independence from India, claimed responsibility for a series of explosions in Kashmir which damaged government buildings, buses and the houses of present and former state government officials."
Are you aware that the JKLF was publicly accepting responsibility during this period of time for bombings? [Emphasis added]
A. As far as I remember, some of the news which you just read, they were in the newspapers. But whenever we had our meetings to collect donations, we always talked about that, who are those people who are part of these kind of - now who are doing these kind of things, which are not only inhumane but they are illegal.
But these things were always looked at and - with indifferently but nobody ever accepted responsibilities of the - personal responsibilities for these things. The thing is that the news which is printed in the newspaper and the media is under the government. But these things were always discussed in the meeting that nobody took personal responsibility. We always talked about that whoever is doing these kind of things, they're inhumane, unjustifiable, illegal. And usually when the news are printed in the newspapers, nobody - we always discussed in the meeting that these were - must be rumours because nobody ever had personal responsibility. So we always looked at them as they were not - these were not right things. Who would do such a thing? [Emphasis added]
Q. So, notwithstanding the fact that the JKLF was admitting responsibility, you stayed with the organization.
A. JKLF is basically like an umbrella, and there are a lot of other groups which are under that umbrella. [Emphasis added]
Q. Oh, let's stop there. Let's - you can tell me about that because I've never heard that before. I'd be very interested in you telling me what the structure of the JKLF is, then, because I've read all this material and it doesn't talk like that.
A The majority of the people who are in that party are - who want the Kashmir to be free as - on the political personal democracy and - on a democratic basis for - from the India and Pakistan. Want to get - have them freed and also to start a Western-style democracy. So the majority of the members in JKLF have this idea.
But like you were just saying and like in the newspaper, and I may have read in the newspaper in Pakistan, as well, these kind of violent activities which are mentioned, nobody has ever admitted personal responsibility. [Emphasis added]
Q. But your organization admitted responsibility. Repeatedly in the documents the JKLF says they did it.
A. [Foreign language spoke - response not interpreted]
Q. Do you deny that?
A. That's what I'm saying.
Q. So you agree that the JKLF publicly announced that they did those bombings.
A. No, I do not agree with that, because over there nobody admitted to - to accept responsibility for that.
Q. Not an individual, sir. An organization is what I'm saying.
A. But I have never read about that this organization have accepted any responsibility. And neither I know the whereabouts, or I know them personally, or in the newspaper and anywhere as - at all that who have admitted to taking responsibility of each activities.
Q. So you've never read in the newspapers that the JKLF was accused or admitted to committing bombing or other terrorist acts?
A. Like I said before, and that it's been six, seven years ago if I have read it in the newspaper. These - the news were always discussed in our meetings, that who are the people who are involved in such kind of activities in the JKL - JKLF. [Emphasis added]
Q. Now, I have a question for you. Why did you stay with JKLF if there was all these allegations that they were engaged in bombings?
A. If I had known anybody in JKLF that personally from anywhere at all - that if I have known anybody who - in JKLF who - but this - anybody who was in the JKLF -
INTERPRETER: I'm just going to ask him to say it again because he was very -
MR. WILKINSON: Thank you.
A. Like I said before - like I mentioned before, that I don't know anybody personally who was involved in such kind of activities. The main purpose of JKLF is to free Kashmir from India and Pakistan and to start a Western-style democratic government.
MR. TUCCI: Just a moment, Mr. Adjudicator, please.
MR. WILKINSON: I'd like you to take - take you to - Mr. Adjudicator, to Tab 11 and an article entitled, "Kashmir in the Crossfire," page 240, the third paragraph.
BY MINISTER'S COUNSEL:
Q. Part way down that paragraph I'll read.
"...the JKLF made headline news with the kidnapping of the home minister's twenty-three-year-old daughter, Dr. Rubaiya Sayeed, an intern at the Lalded {L-a-l-d-e-d} Memorial Women's Hospital..."
Were you aware of this kidnapping?
A. I was - I was not aware of that kidnapping, as far as I remember.
Q. You don't remember the headlines speaking of this woman's kidnapping.
A. As far as I remember, in Kashmir and Pakistan I haven't read about this kind of news.
Q. Okay. But you had a lot of discussions about the fact that the JKLF was being accused of bombings and other acts, acts of violence.
A. Yes, I was often asked these kind of questions. [Emphasis added]
Q. And, nonetheless, you stayed with the organization. You got promoted to the XXXXXXXXXXXXX for the district with the XXXXXXXXXX of the JKLF. You didn't ever feel that you had any obligation to distance yourself from an organization that was so seriously accused of very serious crimes, such as bombings, kidnappings, murder?
A. Like I said before, when this kind of news were printed in the newspaper, we discussed them in our meetings. But nobody -- nobody admitted responsibility of who has done it.
But, secondly, it doesn't - if there is a news, it doesn't matter whether it's a rumour or not, and it was always looked at that nobody should be apart of activities which were inhumane and illegal. And it was always looked at and made a commitment as to in the meetings, as well, and we discussed with each other and that the only way the - and the Kashmir can be free is - was based on political and also democratic level.12 [Emphasis added]
It is clear from a reading of the transcript and with particular regard to the highlighted parts that the Respondent's answers to the questions, directed at what he knew about his party's possible connection with violent acts, were unclear. At no point does the Respondent admit that he was involved personally in any crimes committed by the JKLF. In fact he states that he knew no one personally in the organisation who had been involved in the commission of the various crimes alleged. Nor does he testify that he knew that members of the JKLF were involved in these alleged crimes. He goes further and states that he and others wondered who were involved although it is unclear whether he means other JKLF members or just other people in society. Nonetheless he does mention that the "majority" of the members of his party think as he does about the proper approach to take on achieving independence. This implies that others in the party - which he describes as like an umbrella - do not.
It is unclear what the Respondent is saying. The particular passages above can be interpreted in more than one way. However, what can be discerned is that the Respondent was at least aware while he was still in Pakistan that allegations in the newspapers were being made that his party - the JKLF - was involved in violent acts. He indicates that these allegations were frequent topics of discussion at his donation meetings. It is this, which was not mentioned to the CRDD. In my view this can either be characterised as "indirectly misrepresenting" or "withholding" material facts relating to a relevant matter. The information he withheld is clearly a material fact and it relates to the relevant matter of whether he should be excluded and his possible complicity. The panel finds that the Respondent indirectly and knowingly misrepresented a material fact and/or withheld that same fact from the CRDD.
Section 109 (1) reads:
The Refugee Protection Division may, on application by the Minister, vacate a decision to allow a claim for refugee protection, if it finds that the decision was obtained as a result of directly or indirectly misrepresenting or withholding material facts relating to a relevant matter.
I do not take this to mean that the Minister must be able to demonstrate that it is the particular withholding or misrepresenting that "caused" the panel to arrive at the determination that it did. Rather, it is sufficient if the misrepresentation or withholding was material and could have caused the panel to make the determination that it did, in the sense that the material fact is inextricably woven in to the other evidence. That being the case the panel finds that the Minister has presented a prima facie case that the misrepresentation or withholding did cause the original panel to come to the determination that it did.
At this point it is necessary to turn to the second part of the review; namely, was there "other sufficient evidence" in front of the original panel that could "justify refugee protection." In order to consider s. 109 (2) we need to review what information was available to the original panel. It is clear that the panel had raised the issue of exclusion and Respondent's counsel asked questions specifically about the possible criminality of some of the actions of the JKLF. Clearly, the panel was alive to the issue and aware that there were documents - which were in disclosure - that dealt, perhaps inconclusively, with the issue of the terrorist activities of the JKLF. In particular, PAK19133.E; dated February 6, 199513 referred to the JKLF having a "military wing." PAK20606.E dated May 19, 199514 referred to a national spokesman for the JKLF denying that the organisation was involved in "military or violent activities." There is as well, documentary evidence that indicates that the Pakistani government at times mistreated members of the JKLF. However, the documentary evidence in front of the original panel made it clear that there appeared to be both a militant and non-militant wing of the party. As to the issue of violence or terrorism it must be said that the evidence was vague and inconclusive. Given this, and the fact that the claimant admitted at the IAD to no more than reading newspaper reports that
accused his party of committing acts of violence, the panel finds that there was sufficient evidence in front of the original panel that could have justified a finding of refugee protection.
Accordingly the Application to vacate is dismissed.
"Michael Ross"

These are the reasons for the decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) in the refugee-protection claim of XXXXXXXX (the "claimant"), a citizen of China. The hearing into the claim was held pursuant to section 170 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA),1 at Vancouver, B.C. on 26 July 2004.
In determining whether the claimant is a Convention refugee or person in need of protection, I have considered all the evidence, including the claimant's Personal Information Form (PIF),2 oral testimony, the documentary evidence filed by counsel and the Refugee Protection Officer (RPO), counsel's submissions, IRPA, and the relevant caselaw.
ALLEGATIONS
In his PIF, the claimant alleges that he issued false invoices for his manager in the XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX. From 1995 to 2000, his manager appropriated 10 million RMB. To avoid further complicity in the scheme, the claimant went on long-term medical leave and was subsequently asked to resign by the manager and given two years' severance pay.
When the company was facing financial problems in 2003, and after the manager had left, an audit was taken which revealed the scheme. His manager blamed the claimant for the problem.
In addition to facing a court inquiry into the scheme, the claimant alleges he will be blamed for a fraud practiced on the company in 1997. A large shipment of XXXXX XXXXX, for which he had signed the invoice and make the transportation arrangements, failed to reach the warehouse. While he was initially cleared of blame, which was attached to a different factory manager, he believes the new 2003 audit will also attach the blame to him for this action.
ISSUES
The determinative issue in the claim was Exclusion 1F(b).
ANALYSIS
Exclusion 1F(b)
Article 1F(b) of the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees states:
The provisions of this Convention shall not apply to any person with respect to whom there are serious reasons for considering that:...
(b) He has committed a serious non-political crime outside the country of refuge prior to his admission to that country as a refugee.
The Federal Court of Appeal held in Sivakumar that "serious reasons for considering is something more than mere suspicion or conjecture, but something less than the balance of probabilities."3
According to the Federal Court of Appeal, "a claimant can be excluded from refugee protection by the Refugee Protection Division for a purely economic offence."4 Justice Kelen in Xie5 found "sensible" the earlier practice of Justice Robertson in Chan6 of defining a serious crime by reference to the maximum sentence that could be imposed had the crime been committed in Canada. Justice Kelen followed it because it was consistent with the definition of serious criminality in subsection 36(1) of IRPA and it dovetailed with the general principle of extradition set out in seubsection 3(1) of the Extradition Act, S.C. 1999, ch. 18. Justice Kelen also cited academic sources such as Waldman,7 Hathaway8 and Goodwin-Gill9 as supporting the view that economic crimes could be included within the scope of Article 1F(b).
Justice Kelen's lead was followed by Justice Pelletier in the Court of Appeal's review of the same claim.10
Subsection 36(1) of IRPA stipulates that
36. (1) A permanent resident or a foreign national is inadmissible on grounds of serious criminality for
(c) committing an act outside Canada that is an offence in the place where it was committed and that, if committed in Canada, would constitute an offence under an Act of Parliament punishable by a maximum term of imprisonment of at least 10 years.
While this section of the Act applies to immigrants rather than refugees, I find that Parliament's intent was to associate serious criminality with a punishment of at least ten years' imprisonment in Canada.
Section 334 of the Criminal Code of Canada states that the penalty for theft over $5,000 is "a term not exceeding ten years."11 Section 380(1) of the Criminal Code states that the same penalty attaches to defrauding the public or any person of money over $5,000. Ten million RMB equals over $1 million.12 Following the lead of the Courts and IRPA, I find that the fraudulent scheme that the claimant describes is a serious non-political crime.
What was that scheme? In his PIF, the claimant alleges that his boss asked him to mark up incoming lumber by 20-30 RMB/sq. m.
I was surprised by his request. The total mark-up would have been approximately 200,000 RMB mark up/month and I thought this was too much. He wanted me to do this in order to have a larger expense account for himself. ... I thought this was the right of the factory manager to do as long as he accepted responsibility for it. It was his right to decide. I thought as well this would help the business. I would prepare the (false) invoices and Mr. XXXXX would sign them. In the beginning I did not think this was a problem, as I saw Mr. XXXXX doing business banquets with clients. Later on in 1997 as China became more deregulated, I became more suspicious because Mr. XXXXX was becoming too close to the lumber sellers and he was purchasing poor quality lumber. I did not know he was pocketing the money himself. Later, I realized the factory manager used the 10 million RMB, accumulated over time, to put in his own pocket.13
In the claimant's Port of Entry (POE) interview, he stated:
The job that I was given is purchasing of lumber and also sales of lumber. In 1995 the person in charge of my unit he told me [sic] that when I purchase the lumber I should add $20.00-$30.00 [sic] on top of the original price and that is per cubic meter. At that time the policy is such that the supervisor can withdraw some kind of a fund from the company for whatever purposes. In my unit every month we would consume 9,000 cubic meters of lumber. In other words, every month he could withdraw up to about 200,000.00 RMB. So within a year it would amount to over 2 million RMB. Because he was my superior so all I can do is to do the reporting of the accounts according to the instruction that he gave me. In the year 2000 I have some health problem. I left the company and right now this company is closing down and they need to audit the accounts. Because since 1995 up to the year 2000 within this 5 years of the price difference that I did they found a discrepancy of close to 10 million RMB. They said to me that it was because I was the one who did this pricing that I should bear this responsibility, but I told them there was no point for me doing the pricing this way because I gained nothing from it, it was rather my supervisor who could benefit from it. The auditor said that I must have pocketed the money from the customers.14
The claimant explained that it was legal for the manager to take 4 percent of profits for his business expenses. But his boss raised the price of the lumber and took 4 percent of the inflated price. Inflating the price he considered to be not legal. Moreover, later he allegedly discovered that the boss was also skimming off the 96% of the inflated price that was not his to appropriate, and splitting it with the suppliers.
While the appropriation of 4 percent of uninflated profits had a legal justification, both inflating the price of the lumber and also misappropriating the remaining 96 percent had no legal justification.
The claimant said that he only learned about the manager's appropriation of the 96 percent at a dinner he had with company suppliers in 1998. However, when asked to relate the conversation he had with those suppliers in which these revelations were made, he could not give a satisfactory report of it. Instead he said that the suppliers made general comments such as that the manager was greedy. The claimant said that this comment meant that the manager wanted to increase the mark-up. Given that he already knew about the mark-up, this explanation was not
helpful in showing the panel how he came to know about the splitting of profits with the suppliers in the first place. The rest of his descriptions of what was said at the dinner were equally unhelpful in disclosing how the conversation led to his full knowledge of the manager's scheme. To be sure, the claimant took the opportunity to explain to the panel details of the scheme he had not shared so far, but the panel's request had been to relate those parts of the conversation which brought about his sudden awakening and conversion to opposition against the scheme. This he did not do. I find the explanations he provided in lieu of descriptions of the conversation to be an attempt to deflect the panel's attention from its search for an explanation.
The claimant acknowledged having a sense from the beginning that the manager was up to fraud and embezzlement. In his PIF, he says that he had misgivings from the beginning ("I thought this was too much.")15 In the hearing room, the claimant explained that inflating the purchase was wrong but that he had to do what he was told, an admission that also shows that he was aware of the illegality of inflating the lumber's price in the first place. Asked by the Minister's Representative if he was aware that the invoices had false values, he said that he was. I therefore find that the claimant had knowledge from the start that he was involved in an illegal and fraudulent arrangement.
I find it improbable that the claimant would have continued the arrangement he had with the manager as long as two and a half years if he had reservations about its legality from the start. I also do not believe that his manager could have kept the second half of the arrangement (keeping the remainder of the marked-up price and splitting it with the suppliers) from his assistant (the claimant) for two and a half years and that the manager's assistant (the claimant), in the context of his involvement with the financial affairs of the company, came to learn of it in the manner he describes. While I cannot know the truth of the situation, I find the scenario the claimant has presented it to me to be, on a balance of probabilities, an attempt to hide the truth. Thus I find it to be not credible.
Moreover, even if I believed the claimant's story of how his knowledge unfolded (which I do not), I do not believe that he was obliged to wait six months to separate himself from the scheme. The claimant's explanations of why he could not leave were for the most part posited on him remaining employed and needing to go through channels to find another position.
But it was open to him simply to leave the company in order to avoid being part of the criminal appropriation of funds, a choice he did not take for the full three years during which the scheme operated. By way of explanation, the claimant stated that even leaving the company outright was not that easy a task and he described his elaborate ruse of sick leave as an attempt to allay suspicions about his reasons for separating from the company. I do not accept the claimant's allegations that he could not have left the company soon after discovering the fraudulent intentions of his boss, whether that was sometime after the scheme began (as he testified at the beginning of the hearing) or in early 1998 (as he testified later). The claimant said that when he was not in the office, other employees signed the invoices. He was away a great deal of the time between 1998 and 2000. I believe it reasonable therefore to assume that others would also be signing the fraudulent invoices and facing the same risk. Moreover, he discussed a female employee who would have taken over from him and she was described as leaving the company at the same time as him, but without sick leave. I do not believe that it was not reasonably open to the claimant to leave the company if he were concerned about the illegality of his boss's actions.
Asked why he did not change jobs, the claimant stated that changing jobs is not easy in China and that he was afraid he would get saddled with the blame for the arrangement, even though he also alleges that he did not profit from it. Asked why he did not move to another post, he answered evasively that he did not want to work in the lumber business because as a business it was corrupt.
In the years that he continued the illegal arrangement with his boss, the claimant testified that he did not cover himself by taking photocopies of faked invoices or assembling any other evidence in order to protect himself in the event of discovery by the authorities. When asked to explain why not, he said that he had to hand over everything to his boss when he left, evading the question why he had not assembled a package of evidence before leaving. He also revealed that other members of his department would sign invoices in his absence and yet he did not speak to any other members of the department as a means of assembling evidence for his case. Asked why, he said they did not speak of personal matters. I find the claimant's lack of efforts to protect himself to be improbable.
The claimant described the efforts of the audit department inconsistently, in a manner that simply seemed designed to support his allegations. On the one hand, the claimant stated that the investigating audit department was very sharp and able to get to the bottom of financial misdealings. On the other hand, he represented them as willing and able to be duped by managers into blaming the lower-echelon staff.
The claimant acknowledges being involved in corrupt practices himself. He obtained medical leave certificates with falsified information from a hospital doctor who owed him a favour. He explained his help in the following manner: when his friends wanted a certain thing, he supplied it. A family doing renovation work would need plaster and he would supply it from the company stores. He said that if a person knew him, that person could buy things from him; if they did not, they could not. If they had a good relationship, there need be no money changing hands. He added that the company did allow him to do that for a "certain" amount. He had allowed the doctor to have building materials and so the doctor had benefited from him. In return, the doctor supplied him with fake medical certificates which allowed him to take extensive sick leave for a condition he did not have. I find the claimant himself to be involved in corrupt activities.
Regarding the matter of the vanished cardboard fibre, the scheme had already been investigated and responsibility affixed to the deputy factory manager who signed the invoice and who was subsequently removed from his position. Given that responsibility has already been assigned to the deputy factory manager some years earlier, I do not accept the claimant's story that he stands to be punished for this criminal action.
I accept the summons that the claimant has produced16 and fact that he has been summoned by the Economic Court as part of their investigation of XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX financial irregularities. The summons says that the Court "suspect[s him] of corruption and malpractice" in the theft of 10 million RMB from XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX.17 Of a similar situation, the Federal Court of Appeal ruled that:
[20] The Board was entitled to presume that the warrant for the appellant's arrest was issued in the belief that she was guilty of misconduct. The presumption of innocence would apply to the proof of that misconduct, but it does not apply so as to prevent the Board from
taking the Chinese state's belief in her guilt into account in deciding if there are serious reasons to consider that she committed the crime with which she is charged.18
The claimant has acknowledged to the Board that he was part of a scheme that succeeded in defrauding the XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX of 10 million RMB. His denials of complicity and his explanations of his role in the scheme are marred by serious credibility problems. He has substantiated the Chinese government's interest in him by providing a summons to Economic Court. On the basis of the totality of the evidence and pursuant to Article 1F(b), I find that serious grounds exist for considering that the claimant has committed a serious non-political crime in XXXXX, China, prior to admission to Canada.
DETERMINATION
In light of these findings, I determine that, pursuant to IRPA, Section 98, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX is excluded under Article 1F(b) and not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection. I therefore reject this claim for refugee protection.

Counsel for the claimant, XXXXXXXXXXXX, has asked the Board to issue an Order that the Refugee Protection Officer's disclosures of March 2, 2004 and July 28, 2004, be struck from the Exhibit List. These disclosures contain what is referred to as "Updated Regional Disclosure" indexes of documents, but do not contain the documents referred to. Counsel takes the position that by failing to attach the actual document referred to the Board does not conform to Refugee Protection Division (RPD) Rule 27 or the Chairperson's Guideline 7.
The issue of whether actual documents or index lists need be disclosed has been dealt with by the courts. The Federal Court of Appeal, in Hassan,1 has held that disclosure of the index where the documents are readily available to counsel is adequate in order to comply with s. 68(5) of the previous Immigration Act.2 There is no equivalent to former section 68(5) in the new Act.3 In the old Act 68(4) dealt with the Board relying upon "generally recognized facts...", etc and made it subject to section 68(5). There is no such limitation in the current equivalent of section 68(4).4
However, Rule 18 of the RPD Rules does contain the equivalent of the old section 68(5). Consequently, the rationale provided by the Federal Court of Appeal remains: where ready access is available to claimant's counsel then the claimant has a reasonable opportunity to prepare by reading that material. In this case the documentary material is readily available at the Immigration and Refugee Board's Document Centre.
Guideline 7, paragraph 3, states, "The RPD has to follow the same rule." Reference to the RPD having to follow the same rule was intended to show that the RPD is subject to the same
timing restriction - disclosure of documents no later than 20 days before the hearing. It does not mean disclosing individual documents from the index. Paragraph 5 underlines the fact that the RPD is responsible for providing basic documentary evidence on country of reference.
Consequently, the Board takes the position that the index constitutes appropriate and fair notice of documents that may be relied upon by the Board in coming to its decisions.
