On July 8, 2004 the Minister, pursuant to s. 109 (1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA),1 filed an Application to Vacate the determination that XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX (the "Respondent") is a Convention refugee. It will be useful to set out an overview of the facts.
THE BACKGROUND
The Respondent, a citizen of Sri Lanka, arrived in Canada on January 9 2000. On March 28, 2000 he signed his Personal Information Form (PIF)2 and a hearing into his claim was held on January 31, 2001 in front of a panel of the CRDD in Vancouver, British Columbia. The respondent based his claim upon alleged persecution he faced in Sri Lanka from the Sri Lankan Security Forces (SLSF).
Specifically, he claimed in his PIF3 and at his hearing that after his mother hosted two of his cousins in XXXXX 1999 the family began to get visits from the Sri Lankan Police (SLP) because of their suspicions that the cousins were involved with the Tamil Tigers (LTTE). On XXXXX, 1999 one of the cousins - XXXXX - went missing and was never seen again. Later that day the SLP detained both the respondent and his other cousin - XXXXX. The respondent was taken to a Sri Lankan Army (SLA) camp and held until released on XXXXX, 1999. During his detention he was physically beaten and sexually abused continuously by a Colonel in the army.
On XXXXX, 1999 the respondent was awakened one morning by noises from SLSF coming to arrest him. He fled and after a period of hiding succeeded in escaping to Canada. The other cousin, XXXXX, was never seen again either.
A hearing into the claim took place on January 31, 2001. A positive decision was rendered at the conclusion of the hearing. The panel noted the centrality of the issue of credibility. In its reasons for judgment the panel noted:
At the outset, credibility was identified as a significant issue and it is particularly so because the claimant provided false information and a false document to corroborate information that he was younger than he really is. When an individual lies to the Board with respect to identity, that is always a concern and it raises issues with respect to credibility.
...The next issue that I need to deal with is the credibility of the allegations about his experiences with the Sri Lankan Army and the reasons for those experiences...
...Having heard the claimant's evidence and heard the testimony of Dr. XXXXX, I'm satisfied that the claimant had the experiences that he alleges in his Personal Information Form and in his testimony...4
On February 6, 2004 the respondent arrived on a flight from Hong Kong. At the airport CIC became interested when they found him in possession of two passports in the name of XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX along with other documents in the name of XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX. A check with US officials revealed that he was one and the same person and had been living in the United States from XXXXX, 1999 and remained there until coming to Canada in XXXXX 2000.5 As a result of this information the Minister filed an Application to Vacate.
At his hearing the claimant admitted that he had lied to the original panel and that he, in fact, had not been in Sri Lanka during the time the events he alleged had taken place. However, he stated that all the events that he had spoken of had taken place except that they had occurred exactly one year earlier. By way of explanation he stated that because he was operating under two different names he had to conceal the passports which would have shown him to have been in the United States rather than Sri Lanka at the times of the alleged incidents.
The Current Application
The Application to Vacate section of the IRPA is set out in S. 109. It reads:
(1) The Refugee Protection Division may, on application by the Minister, vacate a decision to allow a claim for refugee protection, if it finds that the decision was obtained as a result of directly or indirectly misrepresenting or withholding material facts relating to a relevant matter.
(2) The Refugee Protection Division may reject the application if it is satisfied that other sufficient evidence was considered at the time of the first determination to justify refugee protection.
(3) If the application is allowed, the claim of the person is deemed to be rejected and the decision that led to the conferral of refugee protection is nullified.
The previous section under the IA was s. 69.3 (5), which read:
The Refugee Division may reject an application under subsection 69.2 (2) that is otherwise established if it is of the opinion that, notwithstanding that the determination was obtained by fraudulent means or misrepresentation, suppression or concealment of any material fact, there was other sufficient evidence on which the determination was or could have been based.
In the past, the courts generally have held that for the purposes of conducting an analysis pursuant to this section there is a two-step process. Firstly, the burden is upon the Minister to adduce sufficient evidence to demonstrate that the claimant misrepresented, was fraudulent, suppressed or concealed a material fact. If the Minister demonstrates this then the Board is obliged to consider the remaining evidence available to the original panel in order to determine whether there is still sufficient evidence upon which to conclude that the claimant was or could have been a refugee.
The Minister's Argument
The Minister position is simple. The documents show, and the respondent acknowledges, that he was not in Sri Lanka at any of the times relevant to the alleged incidents in Sri Lanka. Consequently, the Minister states that she has demonstrated that the respondent mislead the original panel on the material facts. Secondly, the Minister has argued that absent this information all that is left as evidence for the original panel to consider is that the respondent is a citizen of Sri Lanka. This, the Minister contends, is not sufficient by itself to support a successful claim for refugee status. Consequently, the Minister urges the panel to vacate the respondent's status as a refugee.
The Respondent's Argument
Counsel for the respondent acknowledges that the respondent was not in Sri Lanka at the relevant times. However, he noted that, as to evidence left in front of the original panel, there remained the claimant's testimony about what happened to him - namely the sexual abuse by the SLA Colonel. As well, there was the testimony of Dr. XXXXX who concluded, on the basis of objective tests and the respondent's evidence that he had in fact been the victim of sexual abuse at the hands of a Colonel in the SLA. Consequently, even after removing the dates from the incidents the panel would be left with evidence, which indicated that the respondent was sexually abused and persecuted while in Sri Lanka and that is enough to justify a finding that he was a Convention refugee.
Dr. XXXXX Evidence
In his testimony to the original panel Dr. XXXXX stated that he performed two objective assessments upon the respondent - the Beck Depression Inventory and the Impact of Events Scale. On the former he testified that he found XXXXX to be "moderately depressed".6 On the latter Dr. XXXXX stated that he could not have scored higher.7 The doctor went on to state that, according to XXXXX other misfortunate events in his life - the death of his father, witnessing the carnage of the civil war over many years - did not traumatize him. The doctor stated that he could not second guess XXXXX on that.8 He concluded that: "So, there's nothing in which - that he said to me that suggested that there were any, you know, prior conditions that would account for this posttraumatic stress disorder."9
Dr. XXXXX was also asked whether he thought XXXXX could have misled him. Dr. XXXXX was adamant that he had not been fooled. He elaborated that he believed that he was very good at what he does and that he had objectively tested the respondent.10
Findings
With respect to the first prong of the test the panel finds that the respondent's lies about the events taking place as he stated they had in his PIF and to the original panel can be characterised as "directly misrepresenting" or "withholding" material facts relating to a relevant matter. The information he withheld are clearly material facts and they relate to the relevant matter of whether the respondent suffered persecution in Sri Lanka. The panel finds that the
Respondent directly and knowingly misrepresented a material fact and/or withheld that same fact from the CRDD.
At this point it is necessary to turn to the second part of the review; namely, was there "other sufficient evidence" considered by original panel that could "justify refugee protection." In order to consider s. 109(2) we need to review what information was available to the original panel.
If we subtract all the events between XXXXX 1999 and XXXXX 2000 from the respondent's PIF we are left with nothing other than a Sri Lankan man whose mother was Tamil and father was Malay and because of this their parents and siblings - excepting one - would have nothing to do with them. In the panel's view this evidence would have been insufficient for the original panel to have found that the respondent was a Convention refugee.
However, counsel for the respondent has argued that "other" evidence that was considered by the original panel included the report of Dr. XXXXX, his testimony and indeed the testimony of the respondent himself. Dr. XXXXX concluded that the respondent was a victim of male sexual abuse at the hands of a Colonel in the SLA. That, argues counsel, is enough other "sufficient" evidence for the original panel to have found the respondent to be a Convention refugee.
In the panel's view this reasoning is flawed. Reasonably considered, what the original panel would have had was evidence from the doctor that the respondent suffers from PTSD and that the respondent offered as an explanation for this that he had been sexually abused by a Colonel in the Sri Lankan Army.
It is true that Doctor XXXXX concluded that the respondent suffered from PTSD. He testified that he concluded this because of his observations of the respondent on the basis of 6 hours of interviews and the respondent's scores on two objective tests. As to what caused this PTSD the doctor relied upon the story of abuse told by the respondent. It is important to note that both in his report and in his testimony Dr. XXXXX made it clear that he did not explore what happened to the respondent in any depth because he feared re-traumatising him.11 Perhaps, most importantly he stated in his report:
While the basis for my conclusion [that the respondent suffers from post traumatic stress disorder] on this point is supported only by the evidence provided by Mr. XXXXX, I have no reason to doubt what he has said and feel satisfied in concluding that there are no other circumstances which could account for this symptom presentation.12
It is for this panel to form conclusions on credibility and while a medical practitioner's views may be of assistance they cannot supplant it. However, if we remove the incidents of 1999 in which the abuse is rooted then there remain no incidents. The fact that the events are alleged to have take place in 1998 is new evidence and the panel has no jurisdiction to consider this. If the respondent cannot rely upon this lie as to what happened to him in 1999 to found his claim then how could the doctor do so simply because he believed the lie and wrote about it and testified about it. In the panel's view what is left after subtracting the 1999 incidents is that the respondent is a Tamil suffering PTSD. Nothing else. It would have been speculation for the original panel to connect the PTSD to any particular event. As Dr. XXXXX put it himself in his testimony:
The type two events, of which XXXXX falls into, are people who will go through repeated trauma, exposure to events which are beyond their control over an extended period of time and this fits into people such as prisoners of war, torture victims, domestic violence and child abuse.13
The panel finds that there was insufficient evidence in front of the original panel that could have justified a finding of refugee protection. Accordingly the Application to vacate is granted.

The claimant, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, is a citizen of Venezuela claims refugee protection pursuant to ss. 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.
XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, a citizen of Venezuela, is the spouse of the claimant and claims refugee protection pursuant to ss. 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act because of her being a member of a particular social group: the family of the claimant.
XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX and XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX are daughters of the claimant and his spouse. They are citizens of Venezuela and claim refugee protection pursuant to ss. 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act because they are members of their father's family. The claimant is the designated representative of XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, the minor claimant.
ALLEGATIONS
The claimant alleged that members of the Bolivarian Circles, the government of Chavez and its security agencies would harm or kill him if he were to return to Venezuela.
He alleged that on XXXXX 2002 some members of the Bolivarian Circles intercepted his car as he drove to his home from a meeting, pulled him out of his car and started to beat him but luckily some passers-by intervened and he was let go. He alleged that his assailants threatened to harm or kill him if he did not quit his political activities.
He further alleged that he started to receive threatening phone calls at his home towards the end of the month so he and his wife decided that he should leave the country. He went to the United States of America from where he came to Canada to seek protection.
The claimant's spouse and daughters seek protection because they are members of the claimant's family.
DETERMINATION
I find that the claimant is not a Convention refugee, as he does not have a well-founded fear of persecution for a Convention ground in Venezuela. I also find that he is not a person in need of protection in that his removal to Venezuela would not subject him to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment and no substantial grounds exist to find that his removal to Venezuela would subject him personally to a danger of torture.
I make the same findings and for the same reasons for his spouse and his daughters.
ANALYSIS
The claimant testified that he started participation in political activities in the 1970s and that he did not have any problems as a result of his political activities until the general problems arising from the political turmoil in Venezuela starting in 1998. His political involvement included active participation in the Convergencia Nacional Party (CN) and COPEI and the Movimiento al Socialismo (MAS). He stated that with the coming into power of Chavez it became increasingly more problematic for those opposed to Chavez as his supporters, especially members of the Bolivarian Circles, harassed members of the opposition.
He stated that utilizing his XXXXX XXXXX skills he provided XXXXX XXXXX support for MAS to help maintain the membership XXXXX While the claimant mentioned a number of his colleagues and fellow opposition members who were harassed and in some instances beaten by Chavez supporters, he did not indicate they were involved in the same line of work for the party that he was engaged in; XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX. I find that the claimant's involvement in providing XXXXX XXXXX entailed work that was not exposed to the Chavez supporters. I find the incident he refers to of XXXXX, 2002 to be an isolated incident that does not amount to persecution. I find it to be harassment. To constitute persecution, the harm feared must occur with repetition or persistence, or in a systematic way. The claimant did not suffer any serious harm as a result of this incident. I find, for the same reasons that the few alleged telephone threats that he stated that he received towards the end of XXXXX 2002 also amount to harassment and not persecution. I find, consequently, that the claimant's fear of persecution for his political activities in Venezuela is not well founded.
I also find the claimant's failure to make a claim for asylum in the United States of America where he spent about three months before coming to Canada indicates a lack of subjective fear in Venezuela. When asked why he did not make a claim for asylum in the United States the claimant responded that "the United States was paranoid about immigrants and was going to war against Iraq". I do not find his explanation to be reasonable and acceptable. It is an expression of the claimant's opinion not supported by fact. The claimant's circumstances have no bearing to the situation between the United States and Iraq.
Based on the foregoing I find that there is no serious possibility that the claimant would be persecuted for a Convention ground if he were to return to Venezuela today. I also find that his removal to Venezuela would not subject him to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment and no substantial grounds exist to find that his removal to Venezuela will subject him personally to a danger of torture.
I make the same findings and for the same reasons for the claimant's spouse and children as their claims depend on the circumstances of the claimant.
CONCLUSION
For those reasons I find that XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX and XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX are neither Convention refugees nor persons in need of protection and I reject their claims.

The claimant, XXXXX XXXXX, a 33-year-old citizen of Ghana claims refugee protection pursuant to subsections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).
Allegations
The claimant claims to have a well-founded fear of persecution based on her membership in a particular social group, namely gender, women in Ghana subjected to abuse and incidents of rape.
The claimant alleges that she was a XXXXX and a XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX officer named XXXXX, came to her XXXXX with his alleged wife. He became interested in the claimant and wanted to help her get a XXXXX downtown where the business was lucrative. He told her to meet him at a restaurant in XXXXX 2003. When the claimant met XXXXX he told her that he was interested in having a sexual relationship with her. The claimant refused to accept this proposal. At that point, XXXXX XXXXX apologized to the claimant and they continued to stay for dinner. After the dinner the claimant felt weak and XXXXX offered to give her a ride. When she regained consciousness she realized that she had been raped. The claimant rushed to the clinic for treatment and later reported the incident of rape to the police; however, no action was taken because XXXXX is a very influential man. She reported the incident to Women and Juvenile Unit (WAJU) and they promised to investigate the matter.
In XXXXX 2003, the claimant realized that she was pregnant. She told XXXXX XXXXX, but he advised her to abort the child. The claimant refused to do so and it made XXXXX angry. On XXXXX, 2003, she received an anonymous phone calls threatening her that XXXXX had hired a man to kill her. The claimant fled to her uncle's house who subsequently assisted her in fleeing Ghana. The claimant travelled to the United States (U.S.) on a fraudulent passport. She impersonated as a U.S. citizen and came to Canada with an agent and made her claim for refugee protection two days later.
Determination
The Refugee Protection Division determines the claimant not to be a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection within the meaning of subsections 96 and 97(1) of the IRPA, because key aspects of the claimant's testimony were found not to be credible.
Analysis
The issues in the claim included state protection, internal flight alternative (IFA) and any credibility issues arising from the claimant's testimony.
Identity
The panel is satisfied on a balance of probabilities that the claimant is a citizen of Ghana. In this respect she presented copies of the claimant's Ghanaian passport are included in the port-of-entry (POE) notes.1
Credibility
The central issue in the claim is whether it is credible that a former XXXXX, official, who allegedly raped the claimant is targeting her because she refused to abort the child.
The panel finds the claimant to be neither a credible nor a trustworthy witness. Both in the claimant's Personal Information Form (PIF)2 and oral testimony, she stated that XXXXX was interested in having a sexual relationship with her. When she refused to accept his proposal, XXXXX raped her. When asked if she did not accept XXXXX XXXXX proposal and knew that it was his intention that he wanted something before he did any favours to her, why she continued to stay there, the claimant stated that she had accepted the apology and thought she would leave after having dinner.
The claimant admitted that she did not personally know XXXXX other than he was her client's husband. The panel finds it highly implausible that after knowing the wrong intentions of an individual person they would continue to socialize with him.3
According to the claimant, when she realized that she was pregnant, she phoned XXXXX to give him the news however, he advised her to abort the child. The claimant refused to do so. Subsequently, in XXXXX 2003, an anonymous caller informed the claimant that XXXXX had tried to hire him to kill her and was confident that someone else would be contracted to kill her. The panel notes that this individual who carried out killings to extort money did not ask the claimant to provide him with money.
Taking the claimant's testimony into consideration, that the hired assassin informed her that his agreement was not finalized, as XXXXX was not willing to pay the amount of money demanded, the panel finds it implausible that XXXXX would provide information regarding the victim when the deal had not been confirmed. The panel places no weight on such hearsay evidence since it comes from an unknown person to the claimant. It is the claimant's testimony that police, WAJU and the doctor did not co-operate with her and no legal action could have been taken against XXXXX because he was very influential. Given this profile, the panel finds it highly implausible that XXXXX XXXXX would arrange to kill the claimant because she was pregnant, when he simply could have denied that he raped the claimant. The panel finds on a balance of probabilities that the claimant did not receive death threats as alleged.
In resolving this issue, the claimant has not provided a medical report as required in Rule 7 of the RPD rules to establish her claim does not assist the panel. On a measure of such fundamental importance one would expect it to be addressed with more reasonable evidence. The claimant provided a statutory declaration from her mother to support her contentions4 that following the rape incident she sought treatment at XXXXX Clinic in XXXXX. When asked why there is no medical report in this respect, the claimant stated that she asked her mother to obtain a medical report from XXXXX, because it was required for her refugee hearing. She further explained that her mother made five unsuccessful attempts to secure the medical report. Each time the doctor made an excuse and advised her to come back some other time. The claimant further explained that her mother believed XXXXX was afraid of XXXXX.
Hence, in XXXXX 2004 the claimant requested her mother to provide a sworn declaration. The panel does not find the claimant's explanation reasonable because this document is prepared 17 days prior to the date of request i.e., XXXXX, 2004. The panel sees this document as being specifically prepared to support the claimant's claim.
The panel notes that the documentary evidence5 states,
Regarding state protection of victims of sexual violence, the country reports on human rights practices for 2001, claims that although violence against women, including rape and domestic violence remains a significant, the police tend to intervene in domestic disputes hence to not intervene in domestic disputes, and abuses usually go unreported and seldom come before the courts.
It further states that the commissioner of police responsible for the WAJU, which was established in 1998 to manage cases of domestic violence, stated that "the fees charged by medical personnel to conduct examinations, required by the police in cases of suspected sexual assault, were too high and this deterred many poor women from pursuing their cases."
When asked if she obtained a medical report while she was in Ghana, the claimant stated 'no', she personally never requested to have the clinical records assuming that he would give it to her when needed. The panel finds it highly implausible that the claimant made no attempt to secure a medical report, especially because she was aware that such a document was crucial and was required by the police and WAJU to investigate the matter.
The panel takes into consideration the claimant's testimony that she was aware that her friend who had suffered domestic abuse had obtained a medical report before she reported her case to the police and WAJU. The panel finds that the claimant is a reasonably well-educated person. She worked in Ghana for a number of years as a XXXXX and was aware of the, similar situation. She herself did not make any efforts to obtain a medical report in her alleged case. The panel finds the claimant's actions inconsistent with a person truly being raped and abused as alleged.
In the absence of efforts made by the claimant to produce satisfactory evidence, i.e., the medical report that is central to the claimant's claim, the panel draws an adverse inference with respect to the claimant's credibility.
Furthermore, the claimant gave conflicting evidence regarding her work history. In the claimant's oral testimony, she stated that she continued to work XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX, XXXXX Ghana until XXXXX 2003. However, according to information on individuals seeking refugee protection,6 the claimant when asked about her work history, the claimant stated that she worked until XXXXX 2003. When this contradiction was pointed out, in light of her testimony that XXXXX had hired a killer to kill her, she stayed in hiding, and had fled to her uncle's house. The claimant stated that she continued to work until XXXXX 2003 from home.
This information is in conflict with column 4, question 18 of the claimant's PIF. When asked to list the period of employment including self-employment, the claimant stated that she worked as a XXXXX at XXXXX XXXXX until XXXXX 2003. The claimant explained that she worked from home as her employer redirected clients to her home. The panel finds it highly implausible that a person truly in hiding would continue to work and attend clients while they are in hiding. The panel finds on a balance of probabilities that the claimant did not receive threatening phone calls and was not in hiding, as alleged.
Based on all the evidence adduced, the panel finds the claimant's claim that XXXXX XXXXX, a former XXXXX official raped her and continues to look for her, not to be credible.
Internal Flight Alternative
Even if the panel were to believe the claimant's contentions, which it does not, the panel finds that there is an IFA for the claimant. The documentary evidence notes that the main consequences in this case is that the claimant has shown herself able and willing to remove herself from the vicinity of her alleged abuser by coming to Canada.
The question for the panel is whether the claimant would achieve the same results by removing herself from XXXXX and settling in another large urban city such as XXXXX.
The panel believes that if the claimant were to return to Ghana, she could reasonably settle in XXXXX. The panel notes that the claimant's father resides in XXXXX. There is no persuasive evidence that XXXXX will seek her out if she returned to live in XXXXX assuming that he knows she has moved there.
The existence of several women and juvenile units of the police force will be further deterrent. There is not a serious possibility that the claimant would be persecuted if she were to return to XXXXX, Ghana. The claimant admitted that no one ever went to her father's residence to inquire about her whereabouts.
For the second prong of Rasaratnam,7 IFA test, the panel finds it reasonable that in all of the claimant's circumstances that she can settle in XXXXX. As noted, she is a reasonably well-educated woman. She has shown herself in being flexible in coming to Canada to make a better life. The claimant worked as a XXXXX for approximately three years. The panel believes that with the same effort and resourcefulness, the claimant is prepared to show in Canada she can reasonably make a life in her own country where language and customs are more familiar to her. The panel finds that the claimant has an IFA in XXXXX, Ghana.
Even if the claimant's story is true and that she fears psychological and physical punishment at the hands of XXXXX, the documentary evidence notes that, "the Ghana police established several units at various police stations to deal with cases of abuse of women as well as the cases of abuse of children's rights."8
During the year 2003, WAJU recorded 2,244 cases including assault on women and rapes.9 The Director of WAJU stated the increase in reported cases was due to increased awareness programs. He further stated that WAJU international donors and NGO's collaborated to create a medical trust fund for victims of such violence. The unit works closely with the Department of Social Affairs, the International Federation of Women Lawyers and Legal Aid Board, all whom the claimant can appeal to for assistance.
It is the claimant's testimony that XXXXX, an ex- XXXXX official, is still influential with the law enforcement agencies in Ghana. Each time the claimant went to report to the police, they did not take any action and advised her that XXXXX was influential, and the police officer told her that XXXXX was his friend. She received no assistance from WAJU that assists abused women in Ghana. Again, it is her testimony that the doctor who treated her did not provide her with a medical report. According to the claimant, all these actions were because of XXXXX influence on the authorities in Ghana. While the panel acknowledges that state protection is not perfect, the panel finds that the claimant has not provided clear and convincing evidence that the government is unwilling or unable to protect her. According to Villafranca.10 No government can guarantee the protection of all its citizens at all times.
The panel finds that Ghana is a state, which is exhibiting effective control of its territory; it has military, police and civil authority in place, and it is making serious efforts to protect its citizens. Given the earlier credibility findings, the panel finds that the claimant did not seek protection from the police. Based on the foregoing, the panel concludes that there is adequate state protection available to the claimant in Ghana.
The panel finds that there is not a reasonable chance that the claimant would be persecuted if she were to return to Ghana. Given that the panel found the claimant's claim not credible, the panel finds there is no basis for a claim under 97(1) of the IRPA.
The Refugee Protection Division rejects this claim.

Introduction
These are the reasons for the decision of the Refugee Protection Division concerning the claim of XXXXX XXXXX to refugee protection. The claimant is a 25-year-old female citizen of China. She based her claim on a well-founded fear of persecution at the hands of the Chinese authorities on the grounds of perceived political opinion and membership in a particular social group, namely, members and practitioners of Falun Gong (FG). This is a sur place claim because the claimant was allegedly discovered of being a FG practitioner in China after returning to Canada at the end of a short visit in XXXXX, 2003. The claimant had arrived first in Canada in April, 2001 on a Student visa. Allegedly, she was accused of having sent banned FG material from Canada by way of E-mail to her fellow FG practitioner. The claimant alleged that should she return to China, she would be arrested and sentenced to imprisonment just as her fellow practitioners who have had been sentenced to three years of imprisonment.
In addition, I considered whether she is a person in need of protection either (a) by a danger of torture or (b) by a risk to her life or to cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in China. The hearing was held pursuant to sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).
The evidence consisted of the claimant's oral testimony, her Personal Information Form (PIF)1 and its subsequent amendments and documentary material filed by the claimant's counsel2 and the Refugee Protection Officer (RPO).3 The panel considered the observations of the RPO and counsel's submissions, both rendered orally at the end of the hearing. The panel also considered the post-hearing documentary evidence submitted by counsel by way of an application dated September 2, 2004 pursuant to Rule 37(1) of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) Rules.4
Issues
At the outset of the hearing, credibility was recognized as the major issue. The claimant's personal identity, as to who she is as she describes herself in her PIF narrative and as a national of China, was not an issue considering the identity documents such as the passport and the resident identity card (RIC) that the claimant submitted. Delay in making the refugee claim, a element interlinked to the sur place nature of the claim and the re-availment, were also recognized as legitimate issues.
Determination
I made a general finding of a lack of credibility.5 Accordingly, I determined that, on a balance of probabilities, the claimant's assertion of being a FG adherent is not genuine, and her alleged devotion to FG is just a ruse to claim refugee protection on a sur place basis. I have valid reasons to arrive at this finding due to inconsistencies, lack of corroboration, unlikely coincidence and implausibilities that arose in the claimant's evidence, for which the claimant could not offer satisfactory explanations.
Analysis
In arriving at the findings that I made, I have taken into account the cultural factors, the milieu of the hearing and the anxiety that a claimant may feel in responding to a viva voce examination in the context of the refugee hearing process.
Inconsistencies, discrepancies and implausibilities may be taken into consideration when making an assessment of the credibility or trustworthiness of the evidence.6
In addition, in considering the credibility of the claimants' story, I have been guided by the Federal Court's ruling that, to be considered credible or trustworthy, a claimant's story must be "probably so, not just possibly so."7
Credibility Findings
I had the opportunity to observe the claimant providing testimony for nearly three hours. The claimant was a pleasant young intelligent lady who was straightforward in areas of testimony for which she had come well prepared. However, the claimant was evasive when she had to deal with questions that she did not anticipate. The claimant demonstrated a high level of sophistication. The claimant was well aware of what was
expected of her in establishing her claim and as stated, she was relying on a well-rehearsed and memorized script for providing her testimony. I found her responses to crucial questions impacting on some material aspects of her claim were hesitant and measured. There was no spontaneity in her answers taking pauses before coming up with responses. That said, the claimant was quite articulate and showed considerable facility when providing testimony respecting some other aspects of her evidence. Her hesitation was mostly in areas that I found to be fabricated for the purpose of her claim. It is reasonable to consider the demeanour as an important factor inter alia the credibility concerns in assessing the credibility of the claimant. I did not find a reasonable justification for her uneven demeanour unless she was attempting to present a concoction as a true story. I acknowledge that a negative credibility finding cannot be based on demeanour alone and that the demeanour of a witness is not infallible for fact finding. Nonetheless, it can be of help to a decision-maker to sense the lack of ring of truth to the story being narrated.
It was the claimant's evidence that she had become an ardent FG practitioner since XXXXX, 1997. Purportedly, her interest in FG manifested after being introduced to it in the year 1997 by her friend, XXXXX XXXXX, while she was studying at XXXXX University. Apparently, she was convinced of the benefits one would accrue from the practice of FG after reading "Zhuan Falun," the FG book written by its founder that was lent to her by her friend XXXXX. The claimant alleged that she kept up with the practice of FG by secretly practising it at her home and the homes of fellow practitioners following the ban of FG in July, 1999. Ostensibly, the secret group consisted of six practitioners including the claimant. The claimant came to Canada on a student visa in April, 2001 and allegedly kept in touch with her fellow practitioners back in China by talking to them over the telephone despite her studies. Purportedly, she told them about the vast FG information that was available in Canada. The claimant alleged that she sent two E-mails to her friend XXXXX on two different occasions, once at the end of the year 2001 and again in the middle of 2002. On each of these occasions, the claimant testified that she sent FG material as attachments to her E-mail; on the first occasion, allegedly it was some speeches of Master Li while on the second occasion, it was material related to the media coverage of protests against the Chinese government's ban of FG. The claimant asserted that she only sent the E-mails to her friend XXXXX and to nobody else. The claimant returned to China in XXXXX, 2002 to visit her family and stayed there until XXXXX, 2003. During her stay, the claimant allegedly continued to practice with her old group. Allegedly, on XXXXX, 2003 the claimant was informed by a telephone call from her mother that her FG group had been discovered by the Public Security Bureau (PSB) on XXXXX, 2003. The claimant also learned that the PSB had visited her home on the morning of XXXXX, 2003 looking for her. Purportedly, the PSB had found the FG material that the claimant had sent and that they had enough incriminating evidence to conclude that the claimant was a FG practitioner, both within and outside China. The claimant also stated that she learned that four fellow practitioners were arrested during the PSB raid on the practice station on XXXXX, 2003. Purportedly, the PSB demanded that the claimant should return to China immediately. Subsequently, it was alleged that the claimant's parents were dismissed from their jobs as part of mounting harassment due to the claimant's FG involvement. Because of the above allegations, the claimant asserts that she would be arrested should she return to China and, therefore, seeks surrogate protection from the government of China.
The panel does not find the above scenario as presented by the claimant to be credible for the reasons discussed in the analysis to follow. The claimant asserted emphatically that she regards FG as her life and that she would not exist without practising FG. Ostensibly, her devotion to FG was solidified by the enormous benefits in terms of her academic, intellectual and spiritual enhancement that she derived following her practice of FG since XXXXX, 1997. Her commitment to FG was so firm that she took enormous risk to her freedom and security of life by practising FG secretly in the homes of other fellow practitioners despite knowing the crack down of FG practitioners that ensued the government announcement of FG ban on July 22, 1999. It was the claimant's purported plan to return to China after completion of her studies in Canada in the year 2005. However, the claimant seemingly made an unplanned decision in XXXXX, 2002 to visit China to see her parents, which she did in XXXXX, 2002. These raised some troubling questions: if the claimant were that devoted to FG as she alleged, why did she not make a refugee claim soon after her first arrival in Canada on April 20, 2001? Her explanation was that her group had not been discovered practising FG secretly and her belief that justice would prevail over evil. On being pressed why would she not seize the opportunity to be able to practice FG openly and freely in Canada thereby getting the full benefits of bigger energy field resulting from larger group practice, the claimant was evasive in her responses. Furthermore, why would she return to China and take unnecessary risk by practising secretly with her former small group? After all, she could have avoided the risk by practising on her own at home as she purportedly had done following the ban of FG. Given the above, the panel draws a negative inference with respect to her credibility that she was an ardent FG adherent in China before coming to Canada for the first time in April, 2001.
Improbable Coincidence
Reinforcing the above negative credibility determination is the alleged coincidence of her small FG group being discovered within two days after her departure from China on XXXXX, 2003. It belies credulity that the PSB was just waiting in the wings for the claimant to leave before raiding the practice station of the claimant's group that was allegedly successful in secret practice of FG for nearly four years. It raises the question: was the alleged discovery of her FG small group two days after her departure just a lucky coincidence? The panel does not think so. It was the claimant's evidence that her alleged E-mails evaded being caught by the censorship procedure due to the non-use of suspicion triggering words such as FG in the cover letter to her friend XXXXX.8 Apparently, the incriminating FG material, that did not include pictures, was part of the attachments thereby passing the filters undetected. The following, in part, was stated in the post-hearing document submitted by counsel:
... it would be quite difficult, or nearly impossible, to scan every attachment that is sent via email. So if an individual is already under surveillance, it is quite likely that their attachments will be scanned and/or blocked, but if not, it isn't likely to be the case...9
Granting that the above were to be true, it is reasonable to conclude that neither the claimant nor her group was under surveillance. Allegedly, the PSB traced the FG material that they found when they raided the practice station to the E-mails that the claimant had sent. It was not made clear to me as to how hard copies of information pertaining to FG could have been linked to E-mail messages that were sent some months before the raid. It is highly unlikely that XXXXX would have her computer at the practice station and that too without erasing the E-mails after taking out prints of the attachments. Was it therefore sheer luck that the PSB got suspicious of the group, all of a sudden, within two days after the claimant's departure, when they had not entertained any suspicion or surveillance before? In the opinion of the panel, it is highly implausible. The negative credibility findings rebut the presumption of truth by virtue of its cumulative impact on the inherent unlikelihood. Therefore, I find it reasonable to conclude, on a balance of probabilities, that the alleged discovery of the claimant's group was not just a lucky coincidence, but part of a well-planned fraudulent scheme to claim refugee status in Canada.
Other Credibility Findings
When pressed for details as to how she was certain that the PSB discovered her to be the source of the alleged incriminating FG material, she could only state that she learned from her mother that the PSB found out that the claimant had sent the material on the day of the raid that also culminated in the arrest of her four fellow FG practitioners. She stated that she did not know any further details. The claimant testified that the claimant after ascertaining the receipt of the E-mails by her friend, she never asked XXXXX, or any other fellow practitioner about the FG material. On being pressed, the claimant got flustered and provided inconsistent and dithering testimony as regards whether she had any discussion about the material during the time she was in China and practising FG with her group from XXXXX, 2002 to XXXXX, 2003. It emerged that she did ask her friend XXXXX having read first E-mail material; that she did not ask or wanted to know anything about the second E-mail. The panel finds it highly implausible that the claimant did not have any discussion whatsoever about the utility of the information that she sent when she returned to China and practiced with them for nearly three months. Given the above implausibilities, I draw an adverse finding with respect to the claimant's credibility. In making this determination, it is singularly important, given her intelligence and sophistication, that she failed to provide copies of the incriminating information in the attachments that she sent. Further, I also noted the discrepancy between her written PIF narrative10 and her testimony. She testified that she was exclusively in touch with her friend XXXXX after coming to Canada resulting in her sending two E-mails. However, she indicated in her written narrative that she often spoke to fellow practitioners and at their request, she sent FG information via E-mails, albeit, she was reluctant to do so in the beginning. As an explanation for this discrepancy, her response was that her intention to send E-mails to her friend was to benefit the group. I did not find her response reasonable to be satisfactory.
For the aforesaid reasons, it is the panel's finding that the claimant was not a FG adherent practising secretly in a group and that she did not send any incriminating FG material to China as she alleged. As such, the claim should be rejected on this count alone as it goes to the crux of her claim.
There were other credibility concerns that could be considered peripheral when considered in isolation, but material when considered cumulatively with other findings. There was this anomaly in claimant's evidence respecting the consequential adverse effects on her parents. It was alleged in her written PIF narrative that both of her parents were dismissed from their employment. The claimant was confronted with the contradictory information in the Hukou11 that the claimant submitted. The Hukou shows her father as being a retired worker as of XXXXX 1998, the issue date of the document. When questioned, her hesitant explanation was that her father took up another job, but she was not able to provide when he took up the new job. Further, the claimant did not produce any corroborative documents respecting the dismissal of her parents. Nor did she produce any corroboration in terms of arrest warrant, summons that the claimant was being actively sought in China.
The claimant testified that she improved knowledge of FG and its philosophy by extensively reading the book "Zhuan Falun" that she bought in May, 2001 soon after her arrival in Canada. Yet, the book that she showed to the panel appeared to be pristine in its condition and did not appear to have been extensively read as the claimant alleged. The book did not even bear her name and there were no discernible markings such as underlined or highlighted text.
The claimant testified that she had been diligently practicing FG in Canada from XXXXX 2001 with the XXXXX XXXXX at XXXXX XXXXX. Notwithstanding that the claimant provided names for the contact persons, different from those in the IRB document,12 the claimant did not attend any Group Study sessions that she said takes place on Sundays in contradiction with the said document that shows the Group Studies taking place on Saturdays.
Claimant's Knowledge and Her FG Practice in Canada
As stated, the claimant testified that she had been practicing FG at the XXXXX practice station since XXXXX, 2001. The claimant did not produce any corroboration in terms of a testimonial letter from the group or photographs of her practicing albeit she produced photographs of her alleged participation in the latest FG activities of the year 2004.13 Given the clear determinative negative credibility findings, I do not give any probative value to these photographs. In the panel's opinion, the claimant has attempted to mislead the panel by posing for these photographs knowing that her hearing was coming up shortly.
I acknowledge that the claimant was knowledgeable about FG, its philosophy and FG related events that happened in China. She was able to draw and describe the FG logo.14 Given the determinative negative credibility findings, the panel does not give any probative value to this demonstrated knowledge. It is the panel's determination that whatever knowledge she acquired, was for the purpose of the claim. After all, the information on FG is readily available and given her intelligence and high level of sophistication, it would not have presented much of a challenge for the claimant to come
prepared. In the opinion of the panel, it is the knowledge derived not from conviction, but for convenience. The claimant was not asked to demonstrate any of the FG exercises, as it is not difficult to demonstrate the rudiments of the exercises. To sum it up, the claimant has spun a tale about a non-existent adherence to FG.
Summation
For all the aforesaid reasons, I find the claimant devoid of any credibility or trustworthiness. It is my finding that the claimant's story that she narrated is a total fabrication concocted for the purpose of providing a basis for her sur place refugee claim.
For the same reasons I found the claimant not credible, I also find that the claimant is not a person in need of protection in that there exist no substantial grounds to believe that she will be subjected personally to a danger of torture nor is there a serious possibility that she will be subjected personally to a risk to her life or to cruel or to cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in China.
Conclusion
For the reasons as discussed in the above analysis and after considering all of the evidence, the Refugee Protection Division finds that XXXXX XXXXX is not a Convention refugee; neither she is a person in need of protection.

This is the decision regarding the claim for refugee protection made by XXXXX XXXXX [principal claimant], XXXXX XXXXX and XXXXX XXXXX, who allege persecution in their country of origin, Pakistan. The principle claimant claims protection because of her membership in a particular social group, battered wives in Pakistan, pursuant to section 961 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act. She also alleges that she is a "person in need of protection" pursuant to section 972 of the Act.
ALLEGED FACTS
The incidents that led the principal claimant and her children to claim protection in Canada occurred from 1996 to her arrival in Canada on XXXXX, 2003.
ANALYSIS OF THE FACTS
The claimants have valid identity documents.
The child's designated representative, XXXXX XXXXX, made no representations regarding a claim against the United States. The panel therefore does not have this aspect of the American child not claiming against his country of citizenship to analyze.
According to question 21 of her Personal Information Form (PIF), the principal claimant made three trips abroad. The first trip was to New York, from XXXXX to XXXXX 1997, when she gave birth to her first child; the second, to Pakistan, in XXXXX 2001; and the third, to Canada, in XXXXX 2002.
In the course of the hearing, the panel learned that, in 1994 and 1995, the principal claimant made four or five trips to London and one other to the United States, in addition to those appearing on her PIF. The panel learned that the principal claimant also came to Canada with her husband in XXXXX 2001, as she said, just to visit, while staying in their hotel room in Montreal for a week.
The panel wishes to cite Basseghi3 and believes that these numerous omissions from her PIF, although not central to the principal claimant's claim on her PIF, taint her credibility.
During her testimony, the principal claimant alleged that her husband had informed her, in XXXXX 2002, of his intention to take their children away and give them to another woman who was his future wife. However, the principal claimant's PIF narrative made no mention of this XXXXX 2002 threat. When asked to comment on this significant omission, the principal claimant stated that in XXXXX 2002, her husband was probably joking. The panel does not accept this explanation and wishes to point out that the principal claimant initially stated that she had been informed of her husband's intention in XXXXX 2002 and that, confronted with this inconsistency, she has simply changed her answer. The principal claimant's credibility is, once again, tainted.
The principal claimant claims that her husband had beaten her and that she was still afraid he could abduct her children. During her testimony, she also referred to the attempted kidnapping of her child after their separation. The panel pointed out to the principal claimant that this incident did not appear in her narrative either, whereas, in the panel's view, this was an important incident because it related to the fears expressed by the principal claimant. Confronted with this omission, the principal claimant stated that this had not come to her mind before the second hearing on January 7, 2004. The panel does not accept this explanation and believes that this forgetfulness, combined with the preceding, further taints the principal claimant's credibility.
When she arrived at the Lacolle border post on XXXXX, 2003, during her interview, the principal claimant made no mention of her husband's intention to kidnap her children. The principal claimant stated that she had been about to give birth and that she had not had all her wits about her. This was why the Immigration Officer had written, (translation) "Interview incomplete as subject had to be rushed to Saint-Jean Hospital due to pregnancy."
However, the interview was resumed on January 21, 2003, and the principal claimant made no mention of her husband's intention to kidnap her children. When the panel confronted her to explain this omission, the principal claimant claimed that she had not been in her normal state. In addition, after the birth of her daughter in Canada on XXXXX, 2003, the principal claimant called her mother to tell her the news, and her mother, in turn, hastened to call her former son-in-law to tell him the good news. The panel simply does not believe that the claimant fears that her husband will kidnap her children.
The principal claimant submitted a document (Exhibit P-7) that was allegedly the couple's divorce decree. The panel dwelled upon this document at length and pointed out to the principal claimant that it was signed by two justices of the peace, that it seemed more akin to an affidavit than an official divorce decree and that it contained many spelling mistakes. This document gives the principal claimant custody of the children:
Whereas it was mutually decided that the said children will remain under the custody of the second party and whatever the said second party (the principal claimant - panel's addition) would marry to anyone else, the child will be delivered to his father.
The panel accords no weight to the contents of this document. Moreover, it refers to an Information Request of the German authorities about false documents used in Pakistan (Montreal Regional Binder, section 8.6 PAK.35362.E) and finds that the panel does not attach any credibility to the fact that the child or children should be delivered to the father, in other words, the principal claimant's husband.
When the panel pressed her to say why she had not claimed refugee protection in the United States, where she had been many times, the principal claimant stated that she had learned it would be easier for her in Canada. The panel wishes to cite Ilie, Leul, and Hibo Farah Mohamed and Ardo Abdi Omer here.
In Ilie4 the Federal Court stated that:
[TRANSLATION]
A claimant's failure to claim refugee status in a signatory country of the 1967 Protocol contradicts the claim that he/she fears persecution.
In Leul5, the Honourable Justice Muldoon expressed the following:
[...] Just as I would not wish to send back to his country a person who stood in jeopardy of a reasonable chance of persecution, so I just do not wish to leave in Canada a person who isn't entitled to be here; a person who passed through a country which was a signatory to the convention and did not think to claim refugee status there.
The panel also refers to the decision of April 9, 1997 in Hibo Farah Mohamed and Ardo Abdi Omer6 in which the Honourable Justice Rothstein stated:
The Geneva Convention exists for persons who require protection and not to assist persons who simply prefer asylum in one country over another. The Convention and the Immigration Act should be interpreted with the correct purpose in mind.
The principal claimant's testimony demonstrated that she is not a person subjected to the danger of torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture or a person whose life is at risk or who is at risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment within the meaning of subsection 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act. During the preparation of these reasons, the panel considered the IRB Chairperson's Guidelines concerning Women Refugee Claimants Fearing Gender-Related Persecution.
CONCLUSION
The refugee protection claim is therefore rejected.
The panel concludes that the claimants XXXXX XXXXX, XXXXX XXXXX and XXXXX XXXXX are not "Convention refugees" under section 96 of the Act. The panel also concludes that the said claimants are not "persons in need of protection" under section 97 of the Act.

96. A Convention refugee is a person who, by reason of a well-founded fear of persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership in a particular social group or political opinion,
(a) is outside each of their countries of nationality and is unable or, by reason of that fear, unwilling to avail themself of the protection of each of those countries; or
(b) not having a country of nationality, is outside the country of their former habitual residence and is unable or, by reason of that fear, unwilling to return to that country.

97. (1) A person in need of protection is a person in Canada whose removal to their country or countries of nationality or, if they do not have a country of nationality, their country of former habitual residence, would subject them personally
(a) to a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture within the meaning of Article 1 of the Convention Against Torture; or
(b) to a risk to their life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment if
(i) the person is unable or, because of that risk, unwilling to avail themself of the protection of that country,
(ii) the risk would be faced by the person in every part of that country and is not faced generally by other individuals in or from that country,
(iii) the risk is not inherent or incidental to lawful sanctions, unless imposed in disregard of accepted international standards, and
(iv) the risk is not caused by the inability of that country to provide adequate health or medical care.

XXXXX XXXXX is a 23-year old citizen of Pakistan, who bases his claim pursuant to ss. 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).1
ALLEGATIONS
The allegations are set out in the claimant's Personal information Form (PIF)2.
He alleges he fears members of the Pakistan Muslim League and the present government for he was active at first with the People's Student Federation (PSF) student wing of the People's Party and later with the Pakistan People's Party (PPP). He left college for he was fired upon, but he did finish his education as a correspondence student. He was named the XXXXX XXXXX of the youth wing of his village, XXXXX, in XXXXX 2001. He was attacked on XXXXX, 2002 as he was XXXXX XXXXX at the Independence Day celebration. He was hospitalized for ten days and a First Information Report was registered. Some people were arrested, but later were released. He resumed his activities and took part in the election of October 2002. He worked very hard for the party and the opposition Pakistan Muslim League (PML (Q)) wanted him to leave the PPP and join their party but he refused. His candidate won in his area so the opposition held a grudge against him. In XXXXX 2002 he was fired upon while he was coming home on his motorbike but he was not hurt. He went to his aunt's home. His father went to the police to report the incident; the police refused to file any report for there was no proof. His father later received threatening phone calls that his son should have joined PML (Q) and also stating that they would not miss the next time. His father received two more calls and decided to send the claimant to Canada on XXXXX, 2002, and the claimant made his claim on December 30, 2002.
DETERMINATION
After considering all of the evidence, I find that the claimant is not a Convention refugee, as he does not have a well-founded fear of persecution for a Convention ground in Pakistan, nor is he a person in need of protection, for the following reasons.
The panel finds with respect to the material elements of the story, on a balance of probabilities, that the claimant is not credible. The panel finds that the claimant would not face a risk to life, or risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, or danger of torture, if he were to return to Pakistan.
ISSUES
The determinative issues were the claimant's profile as a PPP worker, credibility and a lack of subjective fear, which is not supported objectively.
ANALYSIS
The Refugee Division only received the disclosures of the claimant on August 23, 2004 and on August 27, 2004; however, the panel accepted the disclosures, as the documents were relevant to his political affiliation.
The panel allowed two post-hearing documents: one authenticating the name the claimant used, and the other, a letter from the PPP party in XXXXX, which counsel had received via fax but which was not legible. The hearing was adjourned for these documents until September 18, 2004. The documents were received and considered for this hearing. The panel will refer to the letter later on.
Identity
The panel accepted the claimant's personal and national identity. His profile as a PPP activist was an issue.
Credibility
The panel considered the claimant's testimony in its entirety, and also took into consideration the claimant's age, education, cultural differences, and the stress of the hearing room setting that might have impacted on how his testimony was given. The panel finds that the central issue in this claim and both material and peripheral aspects of his evidence were not credible or trustworthy.
Political affiliation
The panel has considered the claimant's testimony in regard to his fear in Pakistan and his alleged political affiliation and his fear of the PML (Q). The claimant presented two PSF cards, one PPP card, two letters of his designations3 and a letter from the PPP office in Canada4 to establish his political affiliation.
PSF Cards
The claimant presented two cards, one dated XXXXX 1997, and the second one does not have a date but a number "XXXXX", which states he is the XXXXX XXXXX. There was also a corresponding letter stating he has been elected the XXXXX XXXXX. The claimant was asked why the letter was from XXXXX and not from the president of the village and his explanation was that the district office appointed him solely to write the letter. The panel does not find that explanation reasonable for one would expect the village committee to issue a letter and not the district level. The conditions of the party as a general rule are for renewal of membership normally after two years as indicated on the reverse of the PPP card, whereas the claimant has the cards from the PSF in consequent years, which shows they are not genuine.
PPP Card
The claimant presented a PPP card dated XXXXX, 2001, and a letter dated XXXXX, 2001, on the letterhead of a lawyer who has a PPP Party letterhead from XXXXX that the claimant has been selected/nominated as the XXXXX XXXXX. This letter has no address on the letterhead, just a stamp under the author's signature, which states "PPP XXXXX CITY." The panel does not give much weight to the letter since it is not on proper party letterhead and has no address on it. The panel does not find it to be a genuine letter, which impugns the claimant's overall credibility.
The claimant testified that his activities included:
1. XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX.
2. XXXXX XXXXX.
3. XXXXX XXXXX.
The claimant's family was well off and he was able to assist the PP and his family always supported and voted for the PPP.
When asked if he did this alone he said no, there were others. With him were the president, general secretary, and other people who worked very hard. He was asked if they were all in Pakistan and he stated that he knows that his father told him that the president was now in London, England. He also said that the General Secretary is a poor man and stays at home. The panel finds that there is no evidence, other than the claimant's testimony, which the panel does not believe, that these individuals encountered any problems due to their political affiliation.
Post-hearing letter
The word Peoples in the letterhead of the letter does not have an apostrophe. It is written in English with a lot of spelling and grammatical mistakes. There is no mention of the PML (Q) requiring him. Since the panel does not find the claimant's testimony credible and considering the anomalies of the letter, the panel does not give it any weight. The panel finds that the claimant was affiliated with the party, but did not have the profile to be a target. The documentary evidence also does not support his claim.
Incident of XXXXX, 2002
There were discrepancies between the written, oral and the contents in the First Information Report (FIR) about this incident. The claimant's oral description painted a different picture to what he has presented in the written version, and the FIR had another version. In his PIF he states:
..on XXXXX, 2002, while I was XXXXX XXXXX on the occasion of "Independence Day" in Pakistan, some goons of the P.M.L.(Q) attacked all of the participants and beat us with rods and hockey sticks. As their primary target, I received serious injuries when one of the attackers hit my head with his hockey stick. They left me unconscious with a bloody nose and mouth. When the gathering dispersed, I was taken to the hospital, where I received twenty-six stitches to my head. I remained in the hospital for approximately ten days. This incident was reported to the police by my senior party members....[sic] 5
In oral testimony he stated:
* There were about 100 people present
* He was on the stage XXXXX
* The goons came straight to the stage and started beating him
* There were five other people who were injured
* Gave names of five people who were injured
* He said the president and he were the targets
After, he was asked how many people came on that day and, he said more than 15, he did not have a count. When asked what was the means of their travel, he said that they came on motorbikes. He stated that he was XXXXX XXXXX about 1947 independence and military rule. He said they came straight to the stage and started beating him with hockey sticks or guns. He was asked why they beat him and he said because he worked hard for the Party. He stated orally that his father reported the incident.
FIR
The information in the FIR about this particular incident was:
* His father and two other gentlemen reported
* 6/7 goons
* Armed with fire guns
* The goons starting calling bad names
* When they started to call bad names the claimant asked them not to make a noise
* His son was beaten with gun butts and hockey
* Son was seriously hurt and fell down
* The people around intervened and they ran away
There is no mention of anyone else being injured. The claimant was asked why these three descriptions of the same event were different. His explanation was that it is not different and that it has been two years since the incident and that his father did report the incident. The panel does not find his explanation reasonable and finds that the discrepancies in all three versions make the panel believe that the incident never happened.
The claimant was also asked if this incident was in their local newspaper and he said it was not. Whereas the documentary evidence6 states that incidents of harassment of a political nature are mostly reported in newspapers. The panel relies on the documentary evidence and finds that such an event should have been reported in the local newspaper since it was related to Independence Day.
Medical report
The claimant was asked what he was wearing when he alleges he was injured on XXXXX 2000, and he said he was wearing a shirt and pants. He was asked if he was sure about that and he said he was. When it was pointed out to him that the document he presented states it was a "shalwar," traditional dress, the claimant said that this was not the case and he was asked if the document was wrong to which he said that the doctor must have made a mistake, for he wore pants. The report the claimant has presented is dated the same day as the alleged incident. Since the panel does not find his testimony credible, the panel finds that the medical document has been obtained only to present his claim.
Photographs
The claimant was asked why the photos were taken and he said that the party wanted to keep a record. When asked how and where did they keep the record, he said they were kept in the office. The pictures show people with bandages, with some blood on one person's bandage. The panel does not find his explanation reasonable. The photos were taken for a record, why were the photos not taken when their injuries happened. They seem to be posing for the photo while their heads are bandaged. The panel finds that the photos have been staged and presented merely to bolster the claim and not genuinely taken, which impugns his credibility.
Objective basis
The documentary evidence indicates that PPP members were detained in corruption cases. Some did face harsh treatment in the early stages of the coup in 1999. It further states that, "it would be highly unlikely that this [would] apply to rank and file PPP members." 7 The same document states that through 2001 to March 2004, some PPP activists were arrested. That was to stop parties from having rallies planned by the ARD, some on corruption but were later released. The document states that some did face problems leading up to the 2002 election, but since the election, this harassment has decreased, although PPP leaders have faced problems. The same document states that the PPP has not faced targeted violence from other opposition parties, and is in alliance with many of them. The same document lists three incidents of violence against the PPP. One of them occurred in a clash between the PPP and the PML, whereas the other is about a member of a provincial assembly.
Since the panel does not find the claimant's testimony credible and due to the anomalies in the documents presented and lack of recent documents, the panel finds that the claimant has not established that he had a profile in the PPP party.
In summary, the panel finds that the claimant did not discharge his burden of proof to establish the subjective basis of his claim, which the panel finds is also not supported objectively. Furthermore, the panel finds that the testimony of the claimant is not credible, which negates his claim.
CONCLUSION
Given the above analysis and after considering all of the evidence, the panel finds that there is not a serious possibility that the claimant would be persecuted for a Convention ground if he returns to Pakistan.
The panel also finds that the claimant would not face a risk to life, or risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, or danger of torture, if he were to return to Pakistan.
The Refugee Protection Division concludes that XXXXX XXXXX is not a Convention refugee and is not a person in need of protection and, therefore, his claim is rejected.
